title: Rethinking Cross-Table Quantization Step Estimation: From Global and Local Perspectives
authors: Xin Cheng, Hao Wang, Xiangyang Luo, Bin Ma, Baowei Wang, Bin Li, Jinwei Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The quantization step is a crucial parameter in the JPEG compression process, and provides prior knowledge for JPEG image steganography and forensics. Existing neural network-based methods typically estimate the quantization steps for all discrete cosine transform (DCT) subbands jointly, by treating the entire quantization table as a unified input and leveraging the inter-subband relationships. However, subband relationships vary across different quantization tables, leading to poor generalization for methods that rely heavily on such relationships. To address the above issues, we depart from the strategy that relies on inter-subband relationships and instead train the model on a specific single subband. To compensate for the possible decrease in accuracy due to the lack of relationships between subbands, we extract the ranking features and histogram features from the DCT coefficient histograms of the subbands. Ranking features capture local patterns in DCT histograms by modeling the relative relationships between neighboring coefficients, thereby compensating for the absence of local detail. On the other hand, histogram features represent the overall distribution pattern of the DCT coefficient histograms and capture the global trends and statistical properties in the subbands. We subsequently employ convolutional groups and multilayer perceptron (MLP) structures to extract compression artifacts from these two features. Finally, we introduce a comprehensive evaluation metric, called GenAQt, to quantify the algorithm’s generalization ability across quantization tables. The experimental results demonstrate that our method maintains high accuracy across quantization tables, with RelGenAQt (relative accuracy decrease) exceeding 81% and AbsGenAQt (absolute accuracy decrease) being less than 0.38.

title: A Brief Survey of Two Recent Polynomial Commitment Schemes from Lattices
authors: Minuk Ban, Hyung Tae Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: A polynomial commitment scheme (PCS) enables a prover to commit to a polynomial and later prove the correctness of its evaluation without revealing the polynomial. Although discrete logarithm-based PCSs offer succinct proofs, they are not quantum-safe. Lattice-based PCSs provide post-quantum security and additive homomorphism, making them suitable for applications such as zero-knowledge proofs and secure multiparty computation. In this article, we review two recent lattice-based PCSs, Greyhound and HyperWolf, both relying on the Module-SIS assumption but differing in target polynomial classes and proof techniques. In particular, Greyhound achieves a smaller proof size O(log log N) through folding and LaBRADOR proofs, while HyperWolf supports univariate and multilinear polynomials with lower verifier cost O(log N) using hypercube evaluation.

title: Adaptive Geometric Representation Learning through Mixed-Curvature Mixture-of-Experts Diffusion for Link Prediction_supp1-3665660.pdf
authors: Wentao Fan
publish: N/A
abstract: Link prediction serves as a foundational task in a wide range of graph-based applications, including recommender systems, drug discovery, anomaly detection, and biological network analysis. Real-world graphs that support these applications seldom conform to a single geometry: hierarchical communities favour negative curvature, lattice-like regions are nearly Euclidean, and densely cyclic sub-structures lean toward spherical manifolds. However, existing approaches often fall short by assuming a fixed geometric curvature or relying on shallow decoders, which limits their ability to capture the full spectrum of geometric relationships and accurately model edge likelihoods. To address these limitations, we propose MC-MoE-Diff, a Mixed-Curvature Mixture-of-Experts framework that integrates geometry-adaptive representation learning with a scorebased diffusion process for robust and expressive link prediction. Specifically, MC-MoE-Diff embeds nodes into a trainable product space spanning spherical, Euclidean, and hyperbolic geometries, enabling the model to flexibly adapt to local structural variations. A Lipschitz-gated curvature-aware mixture-of-experts module dynamically routes node representations to specialized experts, each tuned to a specific geometric regime. The model then employs a two-channel diffusion-based decoder that iteratively denoises a latent edge map to reconstruct pairwise connectivity patterns. We validate MC-MoE-Diff across multiple benchmark datasets where it consistently achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming competitive baselines by up to 7 percentage points in AUC and AP, while maintaining linear training complexity. Furthermore, we demonstrate the model’s practical utility in a real-world biomedical application by accurately predicting cellular interactions from spatial transcriptomic data.

title: Incremental Q-Learning for Data-Driven Adaptive Critic Control of Wastewater Treatment Processes With State Constraints
authors: Mingming Zhao, Ding Wang, Junfei Qiao, Jin Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: With the widespread adoption of massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology, itThe wastewater treatment process (WWTP) can effectively convert wastewater into reusable water, with dissolved oxygen (DO) concentration playing a crucial role in treatment efficiency. To achieve online control of DO concentration, a data-driven incremental Q-learning (IQL) method with utility reshaping is proposed. The core idea is to integrate the incremental information of control inputs, the norm value of tracking errors, and a control barrier function into the utility function. First, the IQL method designs an online controller by utilizing tracking errors and the incremental information of control inputs, which reduces the approximation pressure on neural networks caused by excessively large control inputs. Second, the IQL leverages the norm value of tracking errors to influence the magnitude of the incremental control inputs, thereby enhancing the adaptive capability and online stability. Third, an adjustable control barrier function is employed to ensure that the tracking errors do not exceed the predefined constraints, thus meeting the specified tracking accuracy requirements. Fourth, a stability criterion related to learning rates is established to demonstrate the convergence of neural network weights. Finally, the superior control performance of the IQL method is validated via simulation results under two distinct weather conditions.

title: Twisted Bend Refractive Index sensor with dual-wavelength volume compensation
authors: Nazrah Ilyana Sulaiman, Nor Hafizah Ngajikin, Nurfatihah Che Abd Rashid, Maslina Yaacob, Siti Hajar Aminah Ali, Noran Azizan Cholan
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This paper presents a twisted-bent fiber optic sensor with volume compensation for precise refractive index (RI) measurement in transformer oil applications. The sensor design combines a twisted structure with an additional controlled bending, enhancing the interaction between the evanescent field and the surrounding medium. A plastic optical fiber (POF) was used, and its performance was systematically characterized through bending diameter variation, RI detection, and oil volume sensitivity analysis. An optimal bending diameter of 4.5 cm was identified, where the sensor achieved RI sensitivities of 2167.4 RIU⁻¹ at 680 nm and 2058.5 RIU⁻¹ at 780 nm, with corresponding linearity values of 0.9172 and 0.9046. The twisted bend configuration also showed strong responsiveness to oil volume variation, with volume sensitivities of 5.9512 ml⁻¹ and 5.5438 ml⁻¹. To address measurement error due to volume effects, a dual-wavelength compensation technique was applied. By utilizing the distinct RI and volume sensitivities at 680 nm and 780 nm, a matrix-based compensation method was applied to separate the RI effects from volume effects and determine the actual RI values. This compensation reduced relative error from 1.7 × 10⁻² % to as low as 1.86 × 10⁻¹³%. Overall, the proposed twisted bend fiber optic sensor demonstrates high sensitivity, reliable compensation for environmental variation, and robust performance. It simple, low-cost design makes it a promising tool for transformer oil monitoring and other chemical or industrial sensing applications requiring high accuracy and stability.

title: Hand-Gesture Based Robot Tracking and Teaching Framework: Demonstration in Surface Polishing Task
authors: Eui-Chan Kim, JaeYun Sim, Eunseop Song, Seung Yeon Lee, Jae Yoon Sim, Hyouk Ryeol Choi
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Modern manufacturing is rapidly shifting toward high-mix, low-volume (HMLV) production, which requires flexible and intuitive robot programming methods. However, conventional approaches such as teach pendants or external trackers remain complex and inefficient for non-expert users. This paper presents a hand-gesture based tracking and teaching framework that enables intuitive and no-code robot programming for industrial applications. The system estimates a stable local coordinate frame from robust hand-joint landmarks and employs visual servoing with an eye-in-hand RGB-D camera to continuously and stably track the user's hand. A finger padding filter is introduced to enhance depth estimation at the fingertips, ensuring reliable 3D point extraction for trajectory definition. On top of low-level pose tracking, a gesture recognition model combined with a finite state machine allows non-expert users to design diverse robot programs entirely through hand gestures, without coding. The proposed framework was first validated through controlled experiments, demonstrating improved teaching accuracy and reduced errors compared to a fixed-camera baseline. Its practical utility was then evaluated in a representative application scenario, where the complete workflow of a surface finishing task such as polishing was carried out solely via hand gestures. A usability study further confirmed its effectiveness, showing high user acceptance and reduced workload. Overall, the framework provides an accessible and generalizable interface for robot programming, supporting flexible deployment in high-mix, low-volume manufacturing.

title: Gradient Direction Consistency-Based Redundancy Optimization for Smooth Joint Paths Generation of Industrial Robots
authors: Mansen Chen, Yuwen Sun, Shanglei Jiang, Jinting Xu, Chengxiang Lu, Qiang Guo, Jun Liu
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: The discontinuity of geometric paths is a primary obstacle to high performance robotic milling, because it can easily cause abrupt changes in velocity, acceleration, and cutting load, which is adverse to milling stability and accuracy. To address this challenge, this article provides a novel approach to generating smooth joint paths for industrial robots through redundancy optimization. Specifically, a new smoothness metric based on a gradient direction consistency principle is introduced at first. Subsequently, a simple yet effective redundancy optimization model is built by incorporating the joint space limitation, singularity avoidance and stiffness constraints. This transforms the complex smooth joint paths generation problem into a manageable binary classification task. In addition, by combining the Taylor series expansion, a generalized solution algorithm based on sequential quadratic programming is also proposed to solve the problem. Comparative experiments are conducted to validate the proposed method. The experimental results demonstrate that, in comparison to other representative approaches, this method achieves a significant improvement in the smoothness of joint paths, with an 88% reduction in the metric, but also enhances machining accuracy, as evidenced by a 23% contour error reduction.

title: Boosting Compiler Fault Localization: Getting the Best of Both Worlds by Fusing Dynamic and Historical Data
authors: Qingyang Li, Yibiao Yang, Maolin Sun, Jiangchang Wu, Qingkai Shi, Yuming Zhou, Baowen Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
abstract: Compilers are prone to bugs that can have severe consequences for downstream applications. Accurately identifying and localizing compiler faults poses unique challenges due to the inherent complexity and large scale of modern compiler infrastructures. Existing studies have proposed various techniques to construct passing and failing executions by generating witness test programs from bug-inducing test cases or by producing adversarial compilation configurations for the same test program. These executions are then leveraged to apply spectrum-based fault localization (SBFL) techniques for isolating compiler faults, yielding promising results. Recently, Yang et al. revisited SBFL-based techniques and showed that a simple yet widely adopted debugging practice—treating files modified in bug-inducing commits (BICs) as potential fault candidates—can surprisingly outperform SBFL-based techniques on the most critical localization metrics. Moreover, they further demonstrated that BIC-based and SBFL-based techniques are highly complementary, as they tend to localize different subsets of compiler faults. Consequently, effectively integrating these two sources of information to improve compiler fault localization remains an open and largely unexplored challenge. To address this problem, we propose D<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">UAL</small>T<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RACK</small>, a hybrid approach that integrates dynamic execution information from SBFL with historical information derived from BICs. D<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">UAL</small>T<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">RACK</small> employs a two-layer framework that first prioritizes files modified in bug-inducing commits and then refines their rankings using suspiciousness scores computed by SBFL formulas. An evaluation on 120 real-world compiler bugs from GCC and LLVM shows that DUALTRACK successfully identifies 52% of faulty files at the Top-1 rank, demonstrating a substantial improvement over existing state-of-the-art compiler fault localization techniques.

title: Efficient and Precise Homo-Hetero Teleoperation Based on an Optimized Upper Limb Exoskeleton_supp1-3479873.mp4
authors: Huimin Lu
publish: N/A
abstract: Teleoperation has been widely used to expand human working capability in remote, unstructured, and dangerous environments, such as explosive disposal and rescue tasks. In such scenarios, both large-scale flexible obstacle avoidance and small-scale refined operations are often required. However, existing teleoperation devices rarely manage to meet both of these requirements at the same time. This article proposes a new exoskeleton capable of functioning in homogeneous and heterogeneous teleoperation to achieve efficient and precise human-like teleoperation. Regarding hardware design, the exoskeleton fully considers the motion coordination of the human arm. It covers all degrees of freedom of the human arm, including the sternoclavicular motion. A new elbow structure and special overall layout are implemented to reduce the motion inertia and enhance the range of motion. Regarding teleoperation control, a novel teleoperation framework is proposed that seamlessly switches between homogeneous (phased posture mapping) and heterogeneous (workspace operation). With this, the operator can quickly avoid obstacles, approach the target position in a homogeneous manner, and then perform precise operations in a heterogeneous manner. Thorough analyses and experiments demonstrate that our proposed exoskeleton system and teleoperation method exhibit superior performance in rapidity with high success rates in complex teleoperation tasks.

title: Carrier Mobility in a 55-nm CMOS at 4 K: Characterization, Modeling, and Circuit Implications
authors: Ao Tan, Cheng Wang, Gaohao Chen, Jie Ning, Xueye Hu, Futian Liang, Xinzhe Wang, Jinhong Wang, Shubin Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Accurate characterization of carrier mobility in scaled CMOS at cryogenic temperatures is essential for applications such as quantum computing. This article presents a comprehensive study of effective carrier mobility in a 55-nm bulk CMOS technology at 4 K. Using a physics-based extraction technique, we decompose the inverse mobility into its constituent weak-field (Coulomb) and strong-field (surface roughness) scattering components. The characterization across various device geometries and threshold voltage options reveals that mobility degradation at 4 K is primarily governed by the weak-field component. A significant finding is the asymmetric width dependence, where PMOS mobility is strongly enhanced in narrow channels due to mechanical stress, while NMOS mobility remains largely unaffected. An empirical model for the key scattering parameters is developed and validated against a verification set of experimental data, demonstrating excellent predictive accuracy for drain current. The results provide critical physical insights and a direct pathway for developing accurate cryogenic compact models, with important circuit implications for device selection and layout optimization.

title: ZK-HybridFL: Zero-Knowledge Proof-Enhanced Hybrid Ledger for Federated Learning_supp1-3658993.pdf
authors: Amirhossein Taherpour
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model training while preserving data privacy, yet both centralized and decentralized approaches face challenges in scalability, security, and update validation. We propose ZK-HybridFL, a secure decentralized FL framework that integrates a directed acyclic graph (DAG) ledger with dedicated sidechains and zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) for privacy-preserving model validation. The framework uses event-driven smart contracts (EDSCs) and an oracle-assisted sidechain to verify local model updates without exposing sensitive data. A built-in challenge mechanism efficiently detects adversarial behavior. In experiments on image classification and language modeling tasks, ZK-HybridFL achieves faster convergence, higher accuracy, lower perplexity, and reduced latency compared to Blade-FL and ChainFL. It remains robust against substantial fractions of adversarial and idle nodes, supports sub-second on-chain verification with efficient gas usage, and prevents invalid updates and orphanage-style attacks. This makes ZK-HybridFL a scalable and secure solution for decentralized FL across diverse environments.

title: FLISC: Federated Learning-Oriented Resource Optimization in ISCC-Enabled Edge Collaborative Networks_supp1-3622026.pdf
authors: Jie Jia
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated edge learning (FEEL) greatly facilitates the development of ubiquitous intelligence by combining federated learning and edge computing. However, traditional FEEL implementations assume fixed-sized local datasets, neglecting the potential of edge devices to acquire sensory information actively. Such a simplistic scenario leads to overestimating data availability and underestimating resource utilization in networks with varying resource capacity. Moreover, the existing FEEL-oriented systems with integrated sensing, communication, and computation (ISCC) have separate-based designs, leading to an inefficient use of wireless resources. To alleviate these issues, we propose a novel FEEL-oriented ISCC framework in edge collaborative networks, by leveraging the integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technique to achieve the dual purpose of data sensing and parameter transmission. Then, over the designed framework, we present FEEL convergence analysis under non-independent and identically distributed (non-iid) and iid data. Correspondingly, we formulate a joint beamforming and flexible time duration optimization problem to maximize the convergence speed of FEEL, subject to limited resources on the devices and requirements for data sensing and communication. To address the problem efficiently, we propose an alternative optimization framework, in which the successive convex approximation (SCA) method is adopted to solve the nonconvex beamforming design subproblem, and a low-complexity method is derived for optimal time allocation. Extensive results reveal that the proposed framework can achieve excellent performance in model training accuracy by efficiently utilizing limited resources in edge collaborative networks, under iid and non-iid data.

title: Proposal of Simple Expressions to Estimate AC Losses in HTS Pancake Coils Placed Within Iron Core Slots
authors: Kazuhiro Kajikawa, Shunsuke Yanagisawa, Taketsune Nakamura
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Simple expressions are proposed to evaluate AC losses in armature windings placed within iron core slots. The armature windings are assumed to be composed of single or double pancake coils in the form of a racetrack wound using a 2nd generation high temperature superconducting (HTS) wire, i.e., REBCO coated conductor. Since the superconducting (SC) layer in the coated conductor is very thin, it is treated as an SC strip with infinitesimal thickness. The straight part of the racetrack coil is considered to be placed inside one of the iron core slots of the armature. AC losses in the windings are numerically calculated using the two-dimensional finite element method, combining current vector potential formulation for the SC strips with magnetic vector potential formulation for vacuum region. The electric-field versus current-density characteristics in the SC strip are assumed to follow Bean's critical state model, where the critical current density is unaffected by the local magnetic field. Various parameters such as the amplitude and frequency of applied transport current, pitch and turn number in the winding, and the width and depth of the iron core slot systematically vary to investigate their influence on AC losses. Using the obtained numerical results of AC losses, simple expressions to reproduce them almost accurately are established based on vectorial dimensional analysis.

title: Dynamic Backdoor Attack Based on Multiscale Local Binary Pattern
authors: Zhenyan Luo, Jiao Peng, Yirong Jiang, Fuxiu Li, Yifan Shu, Qiaoshi Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The data security and integrity of deep learning model is very important. Backdoor attack poses a serious challenge to the security of deep learning system because of its concealment and destructiveness. Most of the existing backdoor attacks rely on static triggers and are easy to be detected by pattern analysis methods. This paper proposes a dynamic backdoor attack (lbpdba) based on multi-scale local binary pattern (LBP). In this method, LBP is used to extract the multi-scale texture features of the image, and the features of different scales are weighted by information entropy to generate dynamic triggers that change with the input image, so as to improve the concealment and adaptability of backdoor attacks. Experiments are carried out on cifar-10 and tiny Imagenet datasets. The results show that compared with badnets, blended and blind methods, lbpdba not only performs better in attack success rate, but also has less impact on the normal performance of the model. In addition, lbpdba can effectively circumvent the mainstream defense methods such as strip and spectre, showing strong concealment and robustness, and providing reference for the research of more effective defense methods.

title: Agent-driven Cognitive Object/Motion/Environment Hybrid Vision-Language Model on CCTV Surveillance-Video Bigdata
authors: Dinh-Lam Pham, Eunbi Cho, Kwanghoon Pio Kim
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel big-data generation framework, COME-HVLM (Cognitive Object–Motion–Environment Hybrid Vision–Language Model), which integrates multiple deep learning–based vision–language architectures into a unified hybrid model. Built upon the foundations of established and advanced VLMs—such as YOLO, BLIP, CLIP, and VILA—COME-HVLM is designed to automatically detect and interpret active contextual elements including objects, motions, and environmental features within CCTV surveillance video streams. Operating primarily in edge-computing environments of smart city surveillance systems, the framework systematically extracts and encodes these contextual elements—termed CCTV-Surveillance Active Contexts—into a structured representation format known as COME-Code (Contextual Object–Motion–Environment Code), expressed in JSON. Furthermore, COME-HVLM supports the augmentation of these COME-Code datasets with additional semantic attributes and descriptive properties, thereby enabling enriched and machine-processable contextual representations for large-scale CCTV video analytics and intelligent surveillance applications.

title: Optimizing Federated Block-Term Tensor Regression: Strategy Comparisons and Applications
authors: Axel Faes, Liesbet M. Peeters
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Block-Term Tensor Regression (BTTR) is a multilin-ear modeling framework suited for high-dimensional biomedical data, but its centralized implementation conflicts with privacy and regulatory constraints. To overcome this, we propose Federated Block-Term Tensor Regression (FBTTR), which integrates BTTR into a federated learning setting. We systematically evaluate multiple federated aggregation strategies, including FedAvg, FedYogi, to assess their effect on model performance and stability. Experiments on the BCI Competition IV dataset demonstrate that the choice of strategy strongly influences predictive accuracy: FedAvg yields the most stable and accurate results across subjects, while adaptive methods such as FedYogi show less consistent performance. These findings highlight the importance of strategy selection in federated learning and establish FBTTR as a practical approach for privacy-preserving analysis of multi-institutional biomedical data.

title: Deep Learning-Based Approach for Detecting Fake News in Social Media
authors: Mahra Alsuwaidi, Maryam Alzaabi, Amani Alabed, Sanaa Kaddoura
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The proliferation of fake job postings has emerged on social media platforms as a significant threat to public safety and trust, resulting in financial and psychological harm to job seekers. This paper presents a machine learning-based approach for detecting fake news on social media platforms, with a specific focus on job-related scams. The proposed system utilizes the LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) model integrated with GloVe (Global Vectors for Word Representation) for semantic-aware text classification. A custom dataset of real-world job-related content was used for training and testing the model. The proposed LSTM-GloVe model, achieving 88.24% accuracy, outperforms alternative approaches, such as LSTM with BERT and ANN with GloVe, in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency. The LSTM-GloVe model reduces false positives and offers real-time classification. However, when the model is tested on an external dataset, its performance drops to achieve 50% accuracy, indicating a limitation in generalizability and the need for performance adaptation. This paper contributes to the field by offering a robust solution for detecting fake job offers, aligning with the UAE's Digital Government Strategy 2025 and AI Strategy 2031 to enhance public safety and information integrity.

title: Exploring the Intersection of Web Scraping and Next.js 14 for Real-Time Price Monitoring
authors: Thejasree Devarapalli, Manoj Sharma, Redrouthu. Madhuri Devi, Bhavik Kuchipudi, Ankur Kumar Agrawal, Ravi Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The focus of our research project is a complex art of web scraping in the framework of Next.js 14, which is dedicated to the creation of the highly advanced eCommerce price tracker. In the paper, the core principles of web scraping have been explored including the difference between web scraper and web crawler as well as offering a detailed insight into the working principles of these two processes. Based on the open-source scrapers, the structure of the project is the design of a dynamic home page and a powerful scraping environment. One of the most important aspects of the methodology is the process of scraping the Amazon products data with the use of advanced methods to retrieve and process data in the constantly changing web environment. It involves the complex configuration of a database, the development of a comprehensive product description page, the addition of email functionality with the help of NodeMailer to get timely notifications, the introduction of a cron job to update the application automatically, and the smooth release of the Next.js 14 application. In the real-world implementation section, practical challenges that were faced in the implementation of the project are indicated with viable solutions and optimisation strategies being offered. The study results provided an insight into the precision and reliability of scraped information, the performance indicators of the system, and user experience feedback. The paper will end by outlining the prospects of improvement and expansion in the future, proposing the advancement of the features, its integration with other eCommerce sites, scaling aspects, and perspectives about the new technology. The study would be a worthy addition to the developers and researchers who would want to master the art of web scraping in the Next.js 14 framework to drive innovation and development in the sphere of dynamical eCommerce price tracking.

title: Modeling Cultural Bias in Facial Expression Recognition with Adaptive Agents
authors: David Freire-Obregón, José Salas-Cáceres, Javier Lorenzo-Navarro, Oliverio J. Santana, Daniel Hernández-Sosa, Modesto Castrillón-Santana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) must remain robust under both cultural variation and perceptually degraded visual conditions, yet most existing evaluations assume homogeneous data and high-quality imagery. We introduce an agent-based, streaming benchmark that reveals how cross-cultural composition and progressive blurring interact to shape face recognition robustness. Each agent operates in a frozen CLIP feature space with a lightweight residual adapter trained online at σ = 0 and fixed during testing. Agents move and interact on a 5×5 lattice, while the environment provides inputs with σ-scheduled Gaussian blur. We examine monocultural populations (Western-only, Asian-only) and mixed environments with balanced (5/5) and imbalanced (8/2, 2/8) compositions, as well as different spatial contact structures. Results show clear asymmetric degradation curves between cultural groups: JAFFE (Asian) populations maintain higher performance at low blur but exhibit sharper drops at intermediate stages, whereas KDEF (Western) populations degrade more uniformly. Mixed populations exhibit intermediate patterns, with balanced mixtures mitigating early degradation, but imbalanced settings amplify majority-group weaknesses under high blur. These findings quantify how cultural composition and interaction structure influence the robustness of FER as perceptual conditions deteriorate.

title: Design of a quantum computing education program for high school students
authors: Jung-In Choi, Hanjin Cho, Aeyoung Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This study aims to design and implement a quantum computing education program suitable for high school students, given the growing significance of quantum computing in diverse scientific and industrial fields. While quantum computing is rapidly gaining attention for its potential to revolutionize computational speed and address complex problems, the gap in early education for pre-university students remains notable, especially in South Korea. This research examined international and domestic trends in quantum computing education, developed an activity-based curriculum integrating simulation tools and collaborative problem solving, and applied it to a group of high school students. Through pre- and post-program surveys, activity sheets, and qualitative feedback, the results show a significant increase in students’ understanding and interest in quantum computing concepts such as superposition, entanglement, and quantum gates. The study highlights that an experiential, STEAM-integrated approach using visual and hands-on resources effectively lowers conceptual barriers and enhances engagement. However, challenges such as a lack of prior knowledge and limited educational materials persist. The research suggests policy and curriculum improvements as well as extended teacher training are required to bridge the global educational gap in quantum computing, and indicates that systematic integration of quantum concepts at the high school level is both feasible and impactful.

title: Predictive Analytics in Food Supply Chain and Waste Management
authors: Soummya Chowdhury, Pooja Prasad, Lakhan Patidar, Shankarpally Swetha, Sunny Prakash, Meenakshi Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Effective demand forecasting, inventory control, and wastage minimization are top issues within the restaurant business, in which volatile demand trends contribute to unwanted food wastage and economic loss. This study investigates the utilization of machine learning (ML) models such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), XGBoost, and Random Forest (RF) to maximize supply chain functions through effective demand forecasting and wastage minimization. The models were evaluated and optimized on actual restaurant data gathered over a period of time in order to make reliable predictions to control waste and inventory. Precision, recall, F1-score, accuracy, MAE, RMSE, MAPE, $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, Stock Turnover Ratio (STR), Fill Rate, and Waste-to-Sales Ratio were the performance metrics used to measure the performance of the models. Among the models, the best performing was XGBoost with the best prediction accuracy in the residuals, minimum waste-to-sales ratio, and maximum cost savings and thus the best model for restaurant operation optimization. The findings show the promise of predictive analytics with AI in enhancing sustainability, minimizing food waste, and maximizing profitability in the food supply chain.

title: Comparing Intuitive Virtual Reality Control with Screen-based Control for Response Robots with a Manipulator
authors: Boris Illing, Bastian Gaspers, Dirk Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: This paper investigates the benefits of immersive and intuitive 3D virtual reality (VR) control versus conventional 2D screen-based control for teleoperating a mobile manipulator in hazardous scenarios. We implemented two functionally similar control methods on a ruggedized response robot: (1) a mouse-driven 2D GUI with multiple live video streams and a 2D projection of environment and robot, and (2) a Godot-based walkable VR environment operated with a commercial VR headset, featuring an interactive digital twin and overlaid sensor data. In a within-subjects experiment with nine participants (with robot control experience) performing inspection and manipulation tasks, we measured objective performance (time on task, accuracy) and subjective responses with standardized questionnaires (SSQ, SEQ, ASQ, UMUX, NASA-TLX). Both control methods were well suited for the given tasks, but participants predominantly preferred the VR control. Without inducing excessive simulator sickness, VR control yielded statistically significant 12% faster task completion, 45% lower mental workload, and higher usability ratings. These results demonstrate that intuitive VR interfaces can enhance expert operators’ performance and the usability of response robots with a manipulator in time-critical scenarios.

title: Task Offloading in Open RAN: Deployment Scenarios, Research Trends
authors: Heejae Park, Seongryool Wee, Seungyeop Song, Laihyuk Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: By disaggregating base station functions, Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) enables enhanced interoperability, scalability, and intelligence throughout the RAN infrastructure. However, end devices within the O-RAN environment continue to face constraints in computing power, memory, and energy capacity. To address these limitations, task offloading emerges as a critical solution. This paper investigates representative O-RAN deployment scenarios and explores current research trends.

title: A Spatio-Temporal Deep Neural Architecture Combining CNN and LSTM for Intelligent Exoplanet Detection and Classification
authors: Bashar S. Khassawneh, Ghaith M. Jaradat, Ala Mughaid, Mahmoud Aljamal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Uncovering exoplanets is hence an important endeavor in the field of astronomy, providing key insight into the potential presence of life in locations other than our solar system. The results reveal that traditional techniques for finding exoplanets may be both limited in accuracy and speed. In this work we propose a new Convolutional Neural Network and Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) model to enhance the planetary transit detection performance from the table containing the cumulative Kepler Objects of Interest (KOI). To improve detection performance, our approach benefits from the strengths of the CNN in feature extraction and LSTMs in handling sequential patterns. This model was also tested on a fractionated dataset and displayed an Accuracy of 99.78%, a Precision of 99.75%, a Recall of 99.83% and an F1-score of 99.79%. The outcomes yield a significant distinction in performance when compared to the current detection results, therefore confirming that the CNN-LSTM model can be employed to improve the effectiveness of exoplanet detection. Our findings indicate promising applications in future astronomical research and smooth the way for further progress in this field.

title: Monolithic Hybrid-3D Standard Cell Library with Sandwiched Inter-Metal Layer for 3D Digital Computation-in-Memory Circuits
authors: Chieh-Ling Lee, Chu-Hsiu Hsu, Chih-Chao Yang, Chang-Hong Shen, Kuan-Neng Chen, Po-Tsang Huang, Chenming Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: To address the increasing limitations of planar CMOS scaling and enhance integration density and energy efficiency in memory-centric computing, we propose a monolithic 3D (M3D) design methodology based on the Elevated-Laser-Liquid-Phase-Epitaxy (ELLPE) technique. This low-thermal-budget process enables the direct formation of (100)-oriented single-crystalline silicon thin films on the middle-end-of-line (MEOL) tier, enabling the integration of high-performance FinFETs while maintaining compatibility with underlying front-end-of-line (FEOL) circuitry. Leveraging this technology, we develop a hybrid 3D standard cell library that combines single-gate and multi-gate stacking strategies to optimize layout flexibility, reduce tall via (TVIA) usage, and improve overall PPA. The proposed methodology is validated through the implementation of a 12T-latch-based digital computation-in-memory (CIM) macro, achieving a 43% area reduction and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.9 \times$</tex> improvement in energy efficiency over a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 D$</tex> baseline. The hybrid 3D CIM demonstrates competitive latency and throughput, confirming the efficacy of ELLPE-enabled integration and hybrid 3D cell architecture for advanced, energy-efficient logic-in-memory systems.

title: Create Cloud-Based Access Control Rules Cybersecurity: Applications of AI-Driven Policies and Zero Trust Architecture
authors: Antony Helena Antony Alwyn, Antony Alwyn Michael Adrian, P. Deepalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The inclusion of cloud computing has changed how institutions can be able to manage and secure their digital infrastructure, allowing them to be more flexible, more scalable, and more cost effective. But, as users rely more and more on cloud environments, cybersecurity becomes more complex for access control and data security too. Perimeter based security models are less effective as organizations increasingly rely on cloud systems that enable remote access and sharing. In turn, deployment of AI-centric policies and Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) presents an alternative way to improve the monitoring of access to cloud-based services. In this paper, we present a study on advanced cybersecurity trends: the development and deployment of AI-based policies and Zero Trust principles for the management of access control rules in cloud-based environments. With AI-driven policies, decision-making can be automated as to who is allowed to access which resources, at what time, and under which conditions. Through analyzing such a large pool of historical and real-time data, machine learning AUTOMATION can anticipate potential threats, judge user behavior and adapt access control regulation dynamically to minimize risks. One example for these intelligent systems is to provide a more fine-grained control for making accesses that only authorized people are allowed to access sensitive data or systems. At the same time, Zero Trust Architecture changes the security model from protecting the edge to continuous validation of trust through an approach in which users are required to authenticate and authorize themselves before accessing a resource, regardless of where they are and the networks they're using. It is based on the belief that both internal and external networks can be compromised and applies a design principle of “never trust, always verify”, so everything is tightly controlled, with access only granted after identity and context are fully assessed. This article examines the advantages as well as the limitations of utilizing AI-driven policies implemented in cloud with Zero Trust guidelines. It investigates how these technologies can work together to form a powerful, flexible and context-sensitive access control system that adapts to threats and to unauthorized access attempts.

title: AI-Assisted Strategic Intelligence: A Hybrid Approach Using LLMs and Deterministic Methods
authors: Yosr Ben Amor, Paul Vanabelle, Christian Colot
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Strategic and scientific intelligence increasingly draw on artificial intelligence (AI), yet its precise role across different tasks remains unclear. This paper contributes a three-fold perspective. A review of recent research shows how NLP and machine learning are applied to patents, publications, and other textual data. A market overview highlights strong automation capabilities but limited integration of large language models (LLMs), with only exploratory use in current tools. Finally, a case study on the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Animals (OMIA) database compares deterministic and LLM-based methods across data acquisition, extraction, change detection, coherence evaluation, and rigor assessment. Deterministic techniques remain optimal for structured tasks, while LLMs add value in summarization and contextual analysis. Together, the findings underscore the potential of hybrid architectures that combine deterministic precision with LLM flexibility to strengthen future AI-assisted intelligence systems.

title: KeyBlob: A Standardized Format for Secure HSM Key Transport and Storage
authors: Sarat Chandra Prasad Gingupalli
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Secure key transport and storage between Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) is a critical requirement in cryptographic systems, particularly in offline or air-gapped environments where network connectivity cannot be assumed. This paper introduces KeyBlob, a standardized format designed to address HSM key management challenges, including offline security, multi-key transfers, rich metadata handling, and key origin authenticity. KeyBlob uniquely combines support for multiple wrapping standards with the encapsulation of multiple keys in a single, cohesive format. It enhances security through flexible key wrapping, a Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS) SignedData structure for origin authenticity, optional padding to obscure key sizes, and per-key MACs for integrity. Practical features include compressed attributes for efficiency, attribute encryption for flexible access control, PKCS\#8 compliance for private key management, and protocol-specific key wrapping for HSM clusters. An optimized request structure and multi-key support via an ASN. 1 SEQUENCE OF WrappedKey enables efficient offline HSM-to-HSM key exchange. Comparative analysis with standards like TR-31, TR-34, and the Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) highlights KeyBlob's distinctive advantages: unparalleled flexibility in key type and wrapping support, robust CMS-rooted security, and a design tailored for offline scenarios. Comprehensive evaluation and design objectives comparison demonstrate KeyBlob's practicality as a cutting-edge solution for contemporary HSM key management challenges.

title: An On-Device System for Analyzing Chat Conversations
authors: Sunghee Lee, Jonghwan Kim, Byungjun Bae
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes an on-device system for detecting harmful content in smartphone chat applications used by minors. Unlike conventional cloud-based filters, the system locally captures chat screens, extracts relevant text and media, and analyzes them using lightweight NLP and vision models all on-device to preserve user privacy. The system, implemented on Android and evaluated using KakaoTalk data, demonstrates real-time performance and practical viability for child safety use cases.

title: A Manipulation Scheme of Intelligent Moving Objects through an AI-Driven Management Framework
authors: Jisuk Chae, Mose Gu, Yoseph Ahn, Jiwon Suh, Jaewon Hwang, Jooseung Nam, Yeonjoo Lee, Jaehoon Paul Jeong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Intent-Based Networking (IBN) enables goal-driven control of systems, yet its application to indoor autonomous driving remains limited. This paper presents a perception-centric extension of the framework for Interface to In-Network Computing Functions (I2ICF) using a ROS2-based robotic platform. To ensure stable real-time operations, we resolve conflicts between ROS2 and Flask with a multi-processing architecture, while a fine-tuned YOLOv8s model improves object detection in complex indoor environments. The system, composed of an Intelligent Moving Object (IMO), a desktop client, and a controller. It transforms raw sensor data into semantically rich records for monitoring and analysis. Results demonstrate the reliable translation of user intents into high-level policies for safe and efficient indoor navigation.

title: Translation Learner Competence Development Trajectory Prediction Model Using XGBoost and Multimodal Feature Fusion
authors: Youming Zhang, Shaoxi Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Predicting translation learner competence development trajectories is crucial for personalized instruction and formative assessment in translation education. However, existing approaches rely heavily on summative evaluations and fail to capture the dynamic, multidimensional nature of competence growth. This paper proposes a translation learner competence development trajectory prediction model based on XGBoost and multimodal feature fusion. We collected comprehensive learning data from 237 translation major students over two semesters on a MOOC platform, including 1,896 translation assignments, 14,220 revision records, 3,554 peer review entries, and over 50,000 learning behavior logs. A three-dimensional competence representation framework was developed, encompassing linguistic competence, bilingual transfer ability, and cultural awareness. From this framework, 92 feature variables were extracted across three categories: translation quality features (lexical diversity, syntactic complexity), learning behavior features (practice frequency, reflection depth), and social interaction features (peer review quality, discussion participation). The XGBoost-based prediction model achieved an accuracy of 85.1%, outperforming traditional machine learning methods including Random Forest (82.3%), SVM (78.6%), and Logistic Regression (74.2%). Feature importance analysis revealed that revision behavior depth (0.18), social interaction quality (0.15), and cultural awareness performance (0.12) are the most critical predictors of competence development. The model successfully identified four distinct development patterns: steady improvement (42.6%), fluctuating development (28.7%), plateau (19.4%), and regression (9.3%). A time-series-based competence development stage recognition algorithm was implemented to track learners' progression through initial adaptation, rapid growth, and stabilization phases. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of multimodal feature fusion and demonstrate that translation competence development is a complex process involving linguistic skills, cognitive strategies, and social interactions. This research provides data-driven support for process-oriented evaluation and personalized learning interventions in translation education, contributing to the intelligent transformation of translation pedagogy.

title: IO-NeuS: A Fusion Network for ISAR-Optical 3D Reconstruction of Space Targets
authors: Ziyu Zeng, Ling Wang, Chengwen Zheng, Bo Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: High-fidelity 3D reconstruction of non-cooperative space targets faces challenges due to single-modality limitations: optical images suffer from geometric collapse under sparse views, while Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) images struggle with speckle noise. To address these conflicts, we propose IO-NeuS, a dual-stream heterogeneous fusion neural implicit framework designed for deep geometric consensus. Specifically, we introduce: (1) an asymmetric pose optimization module to correct ISAR misalignment via differentiable rendering; (2) a frequency-enhanced geometry learning strategy incorporating Gabor filters for time-frequency localization and DCT-based Fre-quency Channel Attention (FCA) to overcome spectral bias and capture high-frequency fine structures; and (3) an uncertainty-aware rendering mechanism to adaptively suppress radar speckle noise. Experiments demonstrate that IO-NeuS achieves high accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art methods like IDR and NeuS.

title: SCA-VAGAD: Multi-Stage Variational Autoencoding and Genetic-Adaptive Boosting Framework for Intelligent Anomaly Detection in Spaceborne Satellite IoT Networks
authors: Yogendra Chhetri, Srinivas Reddy Kosna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The converged terrestrial and Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks that have opened tremendous room to connect the world but is creating other security vulnerabilities, especially in the time when the infrastructures of the Internet of Things (IoT) are growing incredibly fast. Customary fixed security measures fare poorly in maintaining with the shifting and high dense telemetry flows that have become typical of web-based satellite-based IoT communication. This study finds such an inspiration inherent in the above challenge which is seen to cluster around need of sturdy and adaptive intrusion defence system able to detect both feature-based and structure attacks which stall grounded models. Though state-of-the-art deep learning and hybrid models are quite effective in normal settings, they fall short in challenging situations relative to advanced adversary strategies that meet satellite communications limitations like restricted bandwidth and long latency. We make proposals to overcome this gap: SCA-VAGAD, a new Satellite Communication Anomaly Detection framework that would simply integrate the following elements synergistically: a Variational Encoder-Decoder to compress features, a Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm to weight the features based on Information Gain and Gini Index, and Adaptive Boosting to optimize the detection boundaries. When assessed against the TON_IoT benchmark with the data reflecting realistic application of IoT network and telemetry settings, the proposed pipeline demonstrates stable high detection accuracy with an overall accuracy of above 95 percent for the primary attack categories and the good performance of precision, recall, and F1-Scores of largely underrepresented threats. The comparative findings confirm that SCA-VAGAD exceeds current deep learning and hybrid baselines by far and is the most robust and effective such tool that promises a scalable anomaly detection solution across next-generation satellite communication ecosystems.

title: FPGA Implementation and Analysis on Parallel and Pipeline Approximate Softmax for Transformer
authors: Abdullah Celep, Trio Adiono, Infall Syafalni, Nana Sutisna, Nur Ahmadi, Rahmat Mulyawan
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The Softmax function plays a crucial role in transformer architectures, particularly in the context of multi-head attention. Due to its reliance on exponential functions and normalization, implementing Softmax in hardware is challenging. This paper presents a scalable Softmax approximation optimized for fully local computations on FPGA platforms. The proposed design is derived from the Sparse Transformer Accelerator and employs a first-order Taylor expansion for exponential approximation. An adder tree is used to sum the approximate exponential values, while cascaded divider blocks perform the normalization. The proposed Softmax also uses a pipeline to enable the simultaneous processing of multiple data inputs. The scalable Softmax approximation was tested and evaluated on the ZUCU104 FPGA, where the implementation achieved resource savings of up to 75 % for DSPs and 43 % for LUTs, with output deviations of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1. 2} \%$</tex>. Furthermore, the experiments demonstrated that increasing the number of input elements reduced the approximation error, and that parallelization strategies enhanced performance. The results indicate that the scalable Softmax approximation offers a viable solution for low-latency deep learning accelerators.

title: A Survey on Near-Field Communication Systems : Channel Estimation, Beam Alignment, CSI Feedback
authors: Chihyun Song, Junsuk Oh, Jaemin Kim, Gahyun Kim, Sungrae Cho
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Extremely large-scale antenna array (ELAA) is key enabler of stringent requirement for sixth generation (6G) mobile networks, such as ultra-high data rate, and terahertz communications. Due to the extremely large number of antennas in ELAA, the impinging wavefront must be characterized by spherical waves, which deviates from the conventional planar-wave assumption in massive MIMO. As a result, near-field MIMO communications cannot be neglected in 6G wireless networks. In this paper, we comprehensively investigate the near-field communication techniques. First, we present the fundamentals of near-field communications and the metric to determine the near-field ranges in typical communication scenarios. Then we investigate recent works in near-field communications, classifying them into three categories: channel estimation, beam training, and CSI feedback schemes developed to address spherical wavefront effects.

title: Low-Voltage Reference with Enhanced CLM Immunity in 130NM CMOS for IoT Edge Nodes
authors: Khang Yian Ng, Harikrishnan Ramiah, Kai Song Tan, Yee-Chyan Tan, Gabriel Chong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents a MOS-resistor-only threshold (VTH) reference circuit operating from a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.6-2 \mathrm{V}$</tex> supply in a 130NM CMOS process. Unlike traditional bandgap reference circuits (BGRs), which rely on bipolar BJT devices and typically require <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${\geqslant} {1.2} \mathrm{V}$</tex> supply voltage to ensure proper biasing and headroom for analog blocks such as op-amps and current mirrors [3], the proposed design achieves a low reference voltage of 365 mV without curvature compensation or startup circuitry. A key innovation is the use of an active feedback mechanism that suppresses channel-length modulation (CLM) effects, ensuring drain-source voltage matching in the PTAT core. This technique improves current mirroring accuracy and VREF stability, even under low-nm process nodes where CLM effects are more pronounced. Simulation results validate the robustness of the design across supply and temperature variations.

title: A V-Band Low-Noise Amplifier Using 0.13-µm SiGe BiCMOS for Very Low Earth Orbit Satellite Communications
authors: Eun-Taek Sung, Jongho Yoo, Junhan Lim, Seong-Mo Moon, Dong-Pil Chang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a V-band low-noise amplifier (LNA) designed for communication payloads in very low Earth orbit (VLEO) satellites. In VLEO satellite communication systems, the 50 GHz frequency band is widely adopted for uplink, and extensive research and development efforts are currently underway to support this spectrum. To achieve both high gain and a low noise figure at 50 GHz, the proposed LNA adopts a single-ended cascode topology in the first stage and a differential cascode topology in the second stage. The LNA was designed using a 0.13-µm SiGe BiCMOS process, achieving a gain of 24 dB and a noise figure of 2.26 dB at 50 GHz.

title: Development of Drowsiness Detection in Elderly Drivers Using an AI Chip
authors: Asavaron Limsuebchuea, Rakkrit Duangsoithong, Nattha Jindapetch
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a realtime drowsiness detection system tailored for elderly drivers, utilizing a dedicated AI chip for edge computing. Given the increasing number of aging drivers and their heightened vulnerability to fatigue-related accidents, the proposed solution aims to enhance road safety through timely and reliable detection of drowsiness symptoms. The system captures eye states via camera and processes data locally with a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN), eliminating the need for cloud connectivity. The model was optimized and quantized for the MAX78000 AI microcontroller, leveraging its hardwareaccelerated CNN engine to achieve low-latency processing and ultra-low power consumption suitable for in-vehicle applications. Two models were trained and evaluated: one using a publicly available dataset from Hugging Face, and another using a smaller, custom-collected dataset gathered under controlled conditions with volunteers. Results show that the model trained on the Hugging Face dataset achieved higher accuracy due to the larger size and greater diversity of data. However, the model trained on the smaller, environmentspecific dataset still demonstrated acceptable performance for practical deployment, indicating that even with fewer images, reliable drowsiness detection can be achieved when training data reflects the intended application context.

title: A Concentration Prediction Method with TCN-LSTM Network in Machine Olfaction Field
authors: Haoxuan Chen, Lin Xie, Wei Xu, Xiaoyan Peng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: In the field of machine olfaction, mixed gas concentration prediction is challenging due to the high dimensionality and complexity of gaseous mixtures. This work built a hybrid LSTMA-TCN model that combines Time Convolutional Network (TCN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and self-attention mechanism for mixture concentration prediction. LSTM captures long-term sequential correlations between different samples, while TCN extracts local features of individual sample, with the attention mechanism enhancing the focusing capability. Additionally, an adaptive dynamic learning rate strategy is employed during the training process to facilitate rapid and stable convergence of the model. A dedicated platform is built to collect an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2} ~\mathrm{S}-\text{SO}_{2}$</tex> mixed gas dataset, and the model is validated on both public and private datasets. Results show that it outperforms comparative models in convergence speed and prediction accuracy, achieving a Coefficient of Determination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>) over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 8}$</tex> for mixed gas concentration prediction.

title: AI-Assisted Gamified Experiences for Teaching IEEE Standards in Software Engineering Education
authors: Lydia Velázquez-García, Antonio Cedillo-Hernández, Ismael Domínguez-Jiménez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Teaching software standards frequently encounters challenges related to student motivation and understanding of technical documents. This paper proposes a gamified instructional strategy supported by generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools to enhance learning outcomes in an undergraduate software development course. The design includes mission-based tasks and simulated audit scenarios, structured around key standards such as software testing (IEEE 29119), configuration management (IEEE 828), and the CMMI model. ChatGPT was integrated as an interactive assistant to provide real-time guidance and formative feedback during the activities. A quasi-experimental study was conducted with a control group to evaluate academic performance and student engagement. Results suggest a significant advance in students’ conceptual retention and active participation, as well as a positive perception of the use of AI-enhanced gamification. This work contributes to the pedagogical understanding of ethical and effective AI utilization in computer science education and offers a replicable model for standards-based instruction.

title: Generative AI in the Classroom and Beyond: A Dual Perspective from Software Engineering Academia and Industry
authors: Tharanga Peiris
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The research presents the perspectives of both Software Engineering industry professionals and Software Engineering academics on using Generative Artificial Intelligence, in Software Engineering classrooms and beyond. The study has adopted purposeful sampling where a sample of forty Software Industry professionals and thirty Software Industry academics were targeted to analyze perspectives. The study followed an Exploratory study design with Focus Group Discussions to collect perspectives and utilized thematic analysis to analyze the responses. The current research concludes that even though few similarities exist, Software Engineering industry and academia mainly poses different perspectives on the use of Generative AI tools in Software Engineering classroom and beyond.

title: A 4.5 GHz Optical Receiver Utilizing an 800uW Modified RGC Transimpedance Amplifier
authors: Shadrach K. Sarpong, Jeongyong Yang, Junwu Bai, Andreas Beling, Travis N. Blalock, Steven M. Bowers
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A modified regulated-cascode transimpedance amplifier implemented in a 28-nm CMOS technology is presented with a 3-dB transimpedance bandwidth of 11 GHz with a 50-Ω input load and a transimpedance gain of 52 dBΩ while the core amplifier consumes only 0.8 mW of power. To achieve low power and high bandwidth, the proposed design makes use of an inverter-based auxiliary amplifier which employs a high threshold transistor. The entire integrated circuit includes a core transimpedance amplifier followed by a gain stage and an output buffer. To demonstrate an optical receiver utilizing the transimpedance amplifier, an InP-based photodiode was externally connected to the amplifier. The PD alone exhibited a responsivity of 0.53 A/W and a bandwidth of 13 GHz. The optical receiver achieved an amplification of 18.5 dB, consistent with the gain of the transimpedance amplifier. The optical receiver demonstrated a conversion gain of 2500 V/W.

title: Comparison of RIS-Assisted and DF Relay-Assisted NOMA Communication Systems
authors: Jiaqi Li, Seung-Hoon Hwang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) communication networks represent a current research hotspot. This study presents a comprehensive performance comparison between RIS-assisted and decode-and-forward (DF) relay-assisted NOMA systems in an urban environment. Complete system models are developed for both configurations, and their performance is evaluated across multiple metrics, including transmission power, decoding strategy, number of RIS elements, and energy efficiency under varying data rate requirements. The results reveal that in RIS-assisted systems, the effective user channel quality, and thus the optimal decoding order, can change with the number of RIS elements, requiring dynamic adaptation to maintain fairness and maximise throughput. Furthermore, while the DF relay-assisted system performs better at low to moderate data rates, the RIS-assisted system outperforms it when the data rate exceeds a certain threshold. Notably, as the target data rate increases, the number of RIS elements required to surpass DF relay performance decreases sharply, with only a single RIS element needed when the rate exceeds 8 bit/s/Hz. Although the DF relay-assisted system achieves higher energy efficiency at moderate data rates, the RIS-assisted system becomes the most energy-efficient option in high-rate scenarios, because of its passive design and low perelement power consumption.

title: Experimental Study on mmWave FMCW Radar for Detecting Objects beyond Transparent Barriers
authors: Dongrak Choi, Saewoong Bahk
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar is increasingly used for sensing in indoor and in-cabin environments. We investigate its ability to detect objects located behind transparent obstacles such as acrylic boards. Experiments were conducted under three scenarios: only the acrylic board, only the target object, and target behind acrylic board. We processed the received signals in MATLAB by applying range FFT, angle FFT, and background subtraction using reference data without objects. The resulting range–angle maps revealed reflections not only from the acrylic board but also from the target placed behind it, confirming that the radar waveform propagated through the transparent material. These findings indicate that mmWave FMCW radar can detect objects beyond transparent obstacles, implying that unintended objects outside the region of interest may also appear in radar images. This effect should be considered in future designs and applications of mmWave radar sensing systems.

title: Federated Learning-Driven Digital Twins for Adaptive Optimization in Industrial IoT Systems
authors: P. William, Thipendra P Singh, Firas Tayseer Ayasrah, Sivaperumal S, Rajanikanth Aluvalu, Kavitha Rani P.
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Industrial systems are getting smarter, but managing all the data they generate—especially in real time and across multiple locations—has become a major challenge. Traditional machine learning setups struggle with privacy concerns, data overload, and slow response times. That’s where this study comes in. We explored what happens when Federated Learning (FL)—a way for machines to learn without sharing raw data— is combined with Digital Twins, which are virtual versions of physical systems that help monitor and predict performance. Together, they form a powerful team: digital twins provide deep insights into how machines behave, while FL ensures each system learns from its own environment and then contributes to a smarter, shared global model. We tested this combo in simulated environments like factories, power grids, and logistics networks. The results Less downtime, more accurate predictions, and dramatically reduced data usage. It’s a win-win for industries looking to be more efficient, secure, and future-ready.

title: Image Generation Over Multi-Hop MIMO Networks
authors: Junhwa Jeon, Doyun Lee, Hoon Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent advances in diffusion models have attracted great attention owing to their ability to generate diverse modalities, particularly high-quality images. In practical scenarios, most requests for image generation services originate from wireless devices such as smartphones and robots. However, due to the intensive inference calculations of current diffusion models, such generation services cannot be executed locally on resource-constrained devices. To reduce the computational burden of devices, it is necessary to offload inference calculations to nearby computing servers over wireless fading channels. In this paper, we propose a multi-hop diffusion network that allows devices to complete their image generation tasks by utilizing multiple computing servers. Each server forwards latent outputs of diffusion models to proximity servers. A group of servers along with devices collectively form multi-hop networks. Consequently, the computational cost of individual nodes can be fairly reduced. To further enhance the quality of image generation tasks, we present multi-antenna signal processing techniques at the servers. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed strategy successfully generates high-quality images through multi-hop coordination.

title: Intelligent Spam Analyzer: AI based Accurate Classification and Scoring for Spam Emails
authors: Asad Ali, Min-Chun Peng
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Email remains a dominant communication channel, with over 361 billion emails sent daily in 2024, but it is also a primary vector for cyber threats like romance scams and Business Email Compromise (BEC), costing billions annually. Current spam filters offer binary classification, lacking detailed analysis of attacker techniques or motives. We propose a novel email classification framework that supports multiple fine-grained categories by leveraging the Fraud Incident Structured Threat (FIST) framework, a fraud threat modeling methodology inspired by MITRE ATT&CK, and integrating large language models (LLMs) to enable both tactical and technical analysis. Our framework outputs detailed risk assessments, including confidence and severity scores at sentence and email levels, alongside preventive measures. Using datasets for phishing and fraud, combined with models like BERT+KNN, CyBERT, and Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), we achieve high accuracy and comprehensive scoring.

title: Distributed Architecture for XL-Metasurface Beamforming
authors: Kofi Anane Boateng, Di Zhang, Kyungchun Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a distributed beamforming framework for extremely large (XL) dynamic metasurface antenna (DMA) systems, offering an energy-efficient and scalable solution for 6G deployments. The transmit array is partitioned into clusters, each managed by a distributed node (DN) that estimates local channel state information (CSI) and designs DMA weights using global CSI provided by a central node (CN). The CN also performs digital precoding based on the global CSI. A downlink capacity maximization problem is formulated, and an efficient joint optimization algorithm for digital precoding and DMA weights is developed. Simulations show that the proposed approach achieves near-optimal spectral efficiency with substantially reduced interconnection overhead, offering a practical solution for scalable 6G deployments.

title: Comparative Study of Convolution Methods on Embedded AI Platforms for Inference Efficiency
authors: Mooseop Kim, Youngmi Song, Chi Yoon Jeong, SuGil Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Efficient deployment of deep learning models on embedded systems requires careful consideration of inference latency, resource utilization, and energy efficiency. This paper presents an empirical comparison of three convolution approaches—Direct convolution, GEMM-based convolution, and the Winograd algorithm—on two representative embedded AI platforms: Jetson Nano and ODROID-XU4. Each method is evaluated under various execution modes (CPU-only, GPU-only, and CPU+GPU hybrid) across multiple input sizes and batch configurations. The key performance metrics including latency, throughput (FPS), hardware utilization (CPU/GPU usage and memory consumption), and energy efficiency (FPS/Watt) are measured to assess practical viability. The results reveal that Direct convolution achieves the lowest latency but scales poorly, GEMM-based convolution offers strong throughput with higher memory demands, and Winograd convolution shows limited latency benefits but excels in energy efficiency under certain conditions. Power consumption analysis using a Monsoon Power Monitor confirms that optimal energy-performance trade-offs vary by platform and execution strategy. These findings provide practical guidance for selecting appropriate convolution strategies in resource-constrained embedded AI deployments.

title: Just Dork and Crawl: Measuring Illegal Online Gambling Defacement in Indonesian Websites
authors: Luqman Muhammad Zagi, Girindro Pringgo Digdo, Wervyan Shalannanda
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This study examines the defacement of Indonesian websites by actors promoting illegal online gambling. Using a lightweight methodology that combines keyword-driven dorking with systematic crawling, we identified 453 defaced webpages within one month. Although dorking alone yielded a false positive rate of approximately 20.3%, the integration of crawling and keyword-counting enabled reliable differentiation between true and false positives. Our measurements revealed diverse defacement behaviors, including repeat defacements (150 cases), fixed instances (129), keyword modifications (55), and redirections or hidden URL injections. In total, 8,837 unique third-party URLs spanning 5,930 domains (eTLD+1) were captured, with a small subset recurring across multiple domains. Responses varied, with an average reaction time of 75.3 hours. These findings demonstrate that simple, reproducible techniques can provide meaningful insights into the scale, persistence, and dynamics of defacement, highlighting the importance of continuous measurement for strengthening defenses against online gambling activities.

title: Research on Grid-Connected Control Impedance and Oscillation Mechanism of String-Type Grid-Forming Energy Storage Converters
authors: Fengshun Jiao, Hao Zhang, Xinming Jiang, Weijie Gao, Wen Lan
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control is prone to oscillatory instability when integrated into a strong grid, while existing approaches fail to elucidate the influence of internal control loops on impedance characteristics. To address this issue, this paper proposes a circuit-based small-signal stability analysis method for grid-forming (GFM) converters. The VSG control loops are equivalently represented as interconnected impedance elements, and the underlying mechanism responsible for the emergence of negative resistance-capacitance behaviour in the positive-sequence output impedance near 50 Hz is revealed from a circuit perspective. Building upon this insight, a quantitative design method for virtual impedance is developed to effectively suppress the negative resistance-capacitance region and significantly enhance grid-connected stability. Simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach in improving system impedance characteristics and strengthening stability.

title: Foundation Models for Tabular Intrusion Detection: Evaluating TabPFN and LLM Few-Shot Classification on IoT Network Security
authors: Pablo García, J. de Curtò, I. de Zarzà
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
