abstract: While ensemble methods have dominated tabular intrusion detection systems (IDS), recent advances in foundation models present new opportunities for enhanced cybersecurity applications. This paper presents the first comprehensive evaluation of foundation models—specifically TabPFN (a probabilistic transformer for tabular data) and large language models (LLMs) using few-shot in-context learning—against traditional machine learning and deep learning approaches for IoT network intrusion detection. We conduct rigorous experiments on the CIC-IDS2017 and N-BaIoT datasets using a unified evaluation framework that addresses critical methodological issues: methodological rigor through appropriate train/test splits, severe class imbalance via stratified sampling up to 20,000 instances per class, and comprehensive evaluation across four data variants (raw vs. incremental PCA-compressed features with 95% variance retention, original vs. semantically grouped attack classes). Our results demonstrate that TabPFN achieves superior performance on CIC-IDS2017, by being the only model capable of detecting all attack classes including rare ones like Heartbleed, while using only up to 3,000 examples per class and requiring no traditional training or hyperparameter tuning. In contrast, traditional ensemble methods like Random Forest and K-NN, while achieving high overall accuracy (>99%), fail to detect several minority attack classes. TabNet shows competitive performance only when augmented with SMOTE-based synthetic data generation, highlighting the importance of data augmentation strategies for deep learning approaches on imbalanced cybersecurity datasets. LLM-based few-shot classifiers demonstrate surprising effectiveness in identifying rare attack classes like Heartbleed and Infiltration and provide inherent explainability, though they remain limited by context size and inference latency for large-scale deployment. These findings challenge the assumption that tree-based ensembles are optimal for tabular IDS applications and suggest that foundation models, particularly TabPFN, offer a promising paradigm shift toward training-free, generalizable intrusion detection systems capable of handling zero-day threats in IoT environments.

title: Efficient FPGA Implementation of Compressor Trees Based on Generalized Parallel Counter Chains
authors: Mugi Noda, Nagisa Ishiura
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a circuit design method based on chained connection of generalized parallel counters (GPCs) as an efficient FPGA implementation technique for multi-input adders, which are key components in multipliers, multiplyaccumulate units, and neural networks. Conventional methods construct carry-save adders using GPCs, which are extended full adders, but the most bit-efficient GPC, the GPC(6,0,7;5), has not been effectively utilized. The proposed technique reduces circuit area by fully leveraging this GPC through chained GPC connections. Experimental implementations on a Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA demonstrated an average area reduction of 13.06% for 8 to 32-bit multipliers and 11.08% for multi-input adders compared to the best-known methods, while maintaining a critical path delay comparable to conventional designs.

title: A V-Band Four-Channel Beamforming Receiver IC for Very Low Earth Orbit Satellite Communication Systems
authors: Jongho Yoo, Eun-Taek Sung, Junhan Lim, Seong-Mo Moon, Dong-Pil Chang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a V-band four-channel beamforming receiver for very low Earth orbit satellite communication systems. Implemented in a 0.13µm SiGe BiCMOS process, the IC integrates low-noise amplifiers, variable-gain phase shifters, and a 4-to-1 power combiner together with serial peripheral interface control logic and bias circuitry within a <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.0×1.3</sup>mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> core. Except for the LNA input stages, the signal path is fully differential, and an on-chip RF balun converts the output to a single-ended signal. The simulated performance of the receiver shows a peak gain of 21 dB and a 3 dB bandwidth of 45–55 GHz (20% fractional), with a coherent noise figure of 2.7 dB. The phase sweep from 0◦ to 360◦ in 5.625◦ steps yields an RMS amplitude error of 0.21 dB and an RMS phase error of 1.3°.

title: Explainable Time-Series Feature Engineering for Sleep Quality Prediction Using Lifelog Data
authors: Gwangseop Lee, Sungmin Choi, Jiyoung Woo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This study proposes a model for predicting human sleep and health states using lifelog data collected from wearable sensors. The time-series data are transformed into static features through various statistical methods, such as rolling mean, variance, IQR, and exponential moving average, and are used as input to an ensemble classification model that combines LightGBM and CatBoost. The input features consist of both time-series sensor statistics and date-derived variables, and the model’s performance is evaluated through 5-fold stratified cross-validation. Experimental results demonstrate that the ensemble model outperforms individual models in prediction accuracy. Furthermore, SHAP-based feature importance analysis provides visual insight into the contribution of each feature to the model’s predictions. This study confirms that traditional static feature engineering can serve as a strong method in multi-target prediction tasks involving lifelog data.

title: Research on Information System Integration and Business Process Optimization Methods: Taking ERP System as an Example
authors: Liwen Zuo, Lu Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The information security issues of intelligent connected vehicles face composite threats due to their end-toend data exchange characteristics of “end-to-end management cloud”. This study focuses on the security protection requirements of intelligent connected systems in automobiles. Through hierarchical architecture analysis and full chain risk identification, a multi-level security protection system integrating protocol simulation, encryption authentication, and intrusion detection is constructed. Firstly, based on the GB17691-2018 standard, design a vehicle remote communication service provider (TSP) communication simulation system to achieve full process simulation of protocol data exchange; Subsequently, the platform and machine learning anomaly detection model are validated through man in the middle attacks to quantitatively evaluate the system's resistance to attacks. The experiment shows that the proposed scheme can reduce the success rate of man in the middle attacks from 92.3 % to 1.6 %, achieve a classification accuracy of 96 % for unknown protocols, and control the data transmission delay within 220 ms, meeting the real-time requirements of vehicle mounted systems. The research results provide a systematic solution for the information security protection of ICV. In the future, the dynamic protection capability can be further optimized by combining blockchain technology and edge computing.

title: Modelling of Proton Exchange Membrane-based Fuel Cell for Hydrogen Electric Vehicles
authors: B. Eswaraiah, K. Balakrishna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This low use of nonrenewable energy sources relies on its installation costs, which are considered to be high and unfriendly to the environment, inapplicability to the shortrange target domestic applications, and its low rate of durability of the systems. The research introduces an advanced power pack through the use of a fuel cell module, which is effective in the provision of power transmission in hydrogen-powered electric automobiles. The proposed system does not demand much time delay of time and a constant source of energy to use to power cars. The uncertain and non linearly energy generation consequently leads to the unstable flow of power to the DC-DC conversion circuit to be smoothened with the help of a bioinspired Moth Flame Optimization (MFO) method. The MFO approach enhances the efficiency of the system, and the advantages of the approach are that it has less complexity in designing the system, greater efficacy of energy transmission, and energy deployment. BY integrating a voltage multiplierbased DC-DC converter, it obtains more voltage to be delivered at the load interface. This power converter is profiled with a single switch design, a large multiplication of high voltage, authenticity of outstanding voltage, minimal pressure on the switching elements, and realization.

title: Enhanced Thermal Performance of RF Amplifiers via Manifold Microchannel with Porous Structure
authors: Minsoo Kang, Hyun-Wook Jung, Seong-Ll Kim, Sangmin Lee, Haecheon Kim, Ho-Kyun Ahn, Dong-Min Kang, Hyoungsoon Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: High-power RF amplifiers, such as GaN high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs), generate intense local heat fluxes in the active device region, which can degrade electric performance. Conventional indirect cooling is limited by thermal resistances, making it difficult to manage localized hotspots efficiently. In this work, we evaluate an embedded manifold microchannel cooling structure designed for direct heat removal from the backside of a GaN-on-SiC HEMT device. Three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations of the baseline microchannel configuration were performed to quantify thermal resistance, pressure drop, and coolant flow effects. The results show a significant reduction in thermal resistance. In parallel, we present a fabrication concept for integrating a porous metal insert into the microchannel to enhance heat transfer area and uniformity. This approach is broadly applicable to high-power RF components, offering a path toward improved thermal performance, compact packaging, and operational stability.

title: QKD-TLS Integration Model for End-to-End Secure Communication
authors: Jeongyun Kim, Taesang Choi, Sang-kil Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: An integration of Quantum Key Distribution and Transport Layer Security is an important research area aimed at addressing the vulnerabilities of traditional cryptographic systems posed by the advancement of quantum computing. QKD leverages the principles of quantum mechanics to provide absolute security, while TLS is a widely used protocol that ensures the confidentiality and integrity of internet communications, offering end-to-end security. The combination of these two technologies is considered a method to enhance TLS by incorporating QKD-generated keys, thereby mitigating potential security risks arising from quantum computing. This paper proposes the QKD-TLS integration models that can support end-to-end secure communication.

title: A 10-bit 40-MS/s Capacitor-Swapping SAR ADC in 180-nm CMOS
authors: Ying-Liang Li, Yung-Hui Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This work presents a 10-bit successive-approximation-register (SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC) to achieve a sampling rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0 ~ M H z}$</tex> in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 0 - n m}$</tex> CMOS process. By employing the capacitor swapping technique, the linearity of the binary-weighted capacitor digital-to-analog converter (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C$</tex> DAC) can be improved, eliminating the need for larger capacitance to ensure better matching. Such a small total capacitance of the C-DAC results in less power consumption and higher operation speed. This prototype SAR ADC consumes a total power of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 7 ~ m W}$</tex> at a sampling rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0 ~ M S} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. Measured peak SNDR and SFDR are 57.2 dB and 73.9 dB, respectively. Measured DNL and INL are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\mathbf{0. 5 8} /+\mathbf{0. 3 5 ~ L S B}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\mathbf{0. 5 5} /+\mathbf{0. 3 7}$</tex> LSB, respectively. The measured ENOB is 9.21 bits, equivalent to a figure-of-merit of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 1. 8 ~ f J}$</tex>/conversion-step.

title: A 112Gb/s PAM4 Mach-Zehnder modulator Driver in 12nm FinFET with 3.8 V Output Swing for Analog-Digital Co-Integration
authors: Giovanni Marco Rubino, Alessio De Prà, Danilo Manstretta
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: In this paper, we present a high-linearity driver for a Mach-Zehnder modulator (MZM), capable of supporting 112 Gbp/s with PAM4 signaling. Implemented in 12 nm FinFET technology, the driver achieves a 3.8 V peak-to-peak differential output swing, significantly above the nominal 0.9 V technology core voltage. The output stage operates from a 3.6 V supply and employs a stacked double-cascoded CMOS inverter composed of three NFET and three PFET devices, achieving both high swing and linearity, while ensuring 10 -years device reliability. The design includes a pre-driver offering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 ~ d B}$</tex> of gain adjustment and a peaking control circuit. The total power consumption is 280 mW (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \text{pJ} / \text{bit}$</tex>). This architecture enables full analog-digital co-integration, eliminating the need for a dedicated optical driver chip in next-generation optical links.

title: Bio-Evolutionary Sparse Clustering Algorithm for Alzheimer's Detection using Multimodal Neuroimaging Data
authors: Bikash Baral, Nurul Jannah Mohd Asngari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The neurodegenerative disease known as Alzheimer's disease (AD) gradually diminishes mental capacity and standard of living. Timely intervention and management of Alzheimer's disease depend on early and precise detection. It is possible that the complicated heterogeneity of brain alterations is unnoticed by conventional diagnostic approaches since they depend on manual feature extraction or single-modality imaging. The authors of this work provide a solution: the Bio-Evolutionary Sparse Clustering (BESC) method. This approach can improve AD detection by integrating multimodal neuroimaging data, such as MRI and PET scans. Using evolutionary optimization, BESC efficiently clusters patient data, finds unique patterns linked to disease development, and selects sparse yet informative characteristics. In terms of classification accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity, experimental results on benchmark datasets show that BESC surpasses traditional clustering and ML approaches. The results show that BESC can help with early AD diagnosis and offer a solid, understandable foundation for physicians to use when creating individualized treatment plans.

title: User Side Energy Storage Capacity Configuration and Optimal Operation Strategy Analysis Based on Two-Layer Planning
authors: Kai Yuan, Chongbo Sun, Zhiwei Wan, Yuguang Zheng, Shiling Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated decisionmaking model based on two-layer programming for the collaborative optimization of capacity configuration and operation strategy of user side energy storage systems. The upper level aims to maximize the net profit throughout the entire lifecycle, optimize the rated power and capacity of energy storage, integrate initial investment, operation and maintenance, and retirement costs, while incorporating income items such as peak valley arbitrage and demand electricity bill reduction; The lower level aims to minimize daily operating costs, predict controllable load schedulable capacity through Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks, and optimize energy storage charging and discharging strategies through dynamic programming. The model achieves bidirectional coupling between the upper and lower layers through state of charge (SOC) constraints and power balance conditions, and introduces a virtual energy storage equivalent mechanism to handle controllable loads, synchronously integrating the comprehensive power flow analysis of the heating network and power grid. The simulation results show that in the scenario of 40 % renewable energy penetration rate, the generalized energy storage capacity reaches 1.25 MWh, the annual net income is 2.06 million yuan, the investment payback period is 4.5 years, and the peak load reduction rate is 13.2 %, which verifies the advantages of the model in terms of economy and load balancing ability. Engineering verification shows that the calculation error of the full life cycle cost does not exceed 7%, indicating good engineering applicability.

title: MedVision AI: An Intelligent Mobile System for Medical Report Summarization and Health Risk Alerts
authors: M Prabha, A S Ruban, A Kiran Kumar, P Saraswathi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Patients usually struggle with understanding their medical reports because of convoluted clinical jargon and numeric data, resulting in confusion, delayed decision-making, and inadequate health literacy. MedVision AI is an Android mobile application designed to simplify understanding of medical reports for non-clinical users. The application uses the OCR feature of Google ML Tool Kit to scan laboratory reports (images or PDFs), identify vital health indicators such as hemoglobin, sugar, WBC, and RBC, and compare them to standard medical thresholds based on rules. Using automation tools like n8n, it uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) to generate plain-language summaries and delivers personalized health information and real-time reminders via email, SMS, or in-app notifications. In order to support collaborative care, MedVision AI also makes it easier to track medical histories, store data securely, and grant guardians or physicians rolebased access. MedVision AI bridges the gap between raw medical data and meaningful interpretation, enabling users—especially the elderly and non-technical—to actively manage their health, in contrast to existing health applications that ease the viewing of data.

title: Analyzing the Implementation Gaps in ISO/IEC 27001:2022 Controls: Insights from PDPC Singapore's Cybersecurity Breaches
authors: Jeremy Leonard Naramuda, Nathaniel Gillbert Sjaibani, Gary Wiliam Kurniadi, Diana
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The rise of digital transformation across industries has led to more frequent cybersecurity incidents, highlighting the need for strong data protection measures. ISO/IEC 27001:2022 provides a structured framework for securing information assets, yet many organizations face challenges in implementing its controls effectively-especially those in Annex 8. This study analyzes 27 major enforcement cases in Singapore from 2022 to 2024 to examine common failures in technology-related controls under the Personal Data Protection Commission's (PDPC) decisions, Singapore's main authority body for administering the Personal Data Protection Act. The most frequently failed controls include 8.16 (Monitoring Activities), 8.3 (Information Access Restriction), 8.11 (Data Masking), 8.15 (Logging), and 8.8 (Technical Vulnerability Management). These failures point to weaknesses in managing vulnerabilities, sensitive data, access rights, and system monitoring. Correlation analysis also revealed that failures in certain controls, such as network security (8.20) and network services (8.21), or malware protection (8.7) and privileged utility programs (8.18), often occur together. This suggests a cascading effect, where the breakdown of one control can lead to others failing. The findings support the need for integrated strategies aligned with ISO/IEC 27001:2022 to strengthen overall information security.

title: Internet of Things based Automated Polyhouse Control System
authors: Anmol Sethi, Rakesh Kolluri, Amanjot Singh, Bura Vijay Kumar, Ramendra Singh, Venkata Siva Bathula
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Automated polyhouse control system is an internet of things-based device which completely automate the process of irrigation, temperature/humidity, and air quality management via use of various sensors such as moisture sensor, DHT11, smoke detector that are integrated by a microcontroller ARDUINO UNO. The data collected from sensors are used to display information and notifications on LCD liquid crystal display and completely automate the process of soil moisture, temperature, and humidity management inside polyhouse with the help of Solenoid valve and Motor Fan respectively without any manual aid from the farmer maintaining higher level of precision of environmental factors needed for crop growth and yield thus making it a fully automated labour less polyhouse system for growing crops to their maximum yield capacity also with great efficiency in terms of input resources, capital as well as labour involved. Furthermore, the automated polyhouse control system reduces the risk of crop failure due to human error, as it operates based on predefined parameters and rules which are flexible and can be adjusted with help of programming thus making this device for universal crop usage.

title: Stochastic Analysis of LEO Satellite Backhaul Connectivity over Great-Circle Airline Routes
authors: Fatemeh Rafiei Maleki, Ayush Kumar Dwivedi, Taneli Riihonen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The rapid growth of satellite-enabled aviation demands robust, scalable models to accurately predict connectivity performance for aircraft globally. This paper introduces a novel stochastic geometry (SG) framework capturing the intricate interplay between large inclined low Earth orbit (LEO) constellations and aircraft traversing great-circle (GC) flight paths — the shortest and most realistic global routes. Satellites are modeled as points uniformly distributed on circular orbits, while aircraft positions are uniformly distributed along their GC trajectories. We derive exact analytical expressions for the distribution of distances to the nearest visible satellite, coverage probability, and ergodic capacity under line-of-sight constraints imposed by Earth’s curvature. Our model transcends specific flight scenarios, offering a versatile, generalizable tool for any aircraft navigating worldwide routes. Extensive Monte Carlo simulations confirm the accuracy of our analysis and reveal how orbital parameters and aircraft positioning fundamentally shape communication quality. These insights empower the design of optimized satellite communication systems that meet the soaring demand for seamless global aviation connectivity.

title: Well Seismic Big Data Analysis for Reservoir Prediction
authors: Bai ShuKong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Reservoir prediction is a key link in oil and gas exploration and development, and efficient analysis of well seismic big data is of great significance for improving prediction accuracy. Currently, there are problems with heterogeneous formats, low processing efficiency, insufficient generalization ability of prediction models, and difficulty in quantifying uncertainty in well seismic data, which constrain the accuracy of reservoir prediction. This article constructs a well seismic big data analysis framework for reservoir prediction, which efficiently integrates and standardizes multi-source heterogeneous data through distributed storage technology. Key seismic attributes are selected using feature selection algorithms, and an optimized machine learning model is used to predict reservoir parameters. The prediction uncertainty is quantified by introducing coefficient of variation. This framework forms a complete closed loop of “data fusion feature mining accurate prediction reliability evaluation”, effectively solving the limitations of traditional methods in data processing and model adaptation. Experimental verification shows that the framework improves throughput by 125% in TB level well seismic data processing, significantly reduces root mean square error in reservoir parameter prediction, and the uncertainty assessment results are consistent with geological laws. The research provides technical support for precise exploration of complex oil and gas reservoirs, and enhances the application value of well seismic big data in reservoir prediction.

title: DT-RAN: Enabling Next-Generation RAN Optimization and Control through Digital Twin-Based O-RAN
authors: Jaehyung Choi, Geon Kim, Een-Kee Hong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper outlines the background and key components of the Digital Twin Radio Access Network (DT-RAN) in the context of an Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) environment, demonstrating the potential for real-time optimization and intelligent network control. Furthermore, various use cases are presented, and improvement directions are suggested based on the limitations of existing studies. As DT-RAN is still in the conceptual stage, this work provides guidelines for researchers and developers aiming to initiate DT-RAN research.

title: Ensemble-Driven Alzheimer's Classification Model Using 2D MRI and Deep CNN Fusion
authors: Nayan Tarachand Pandule, Vijay M Khadse, Virendra Bagade
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Alzheimer's dementia (AD) is a degenerative ailment, which impairs memory, thinking ability, and daily functioning with a growing number of cases reported globally. Early diagnosis and classification of AD is essential for starting treatment and care planning in a timely manner. This study presents a robust classification system based on deep learning that uses MRI brain scans to distinguish between distinct Alzheimer's disease stages. The approach combines three powerful convolutional neural networks ResNet50, DenseNet121, and EfficientNetB0, into a unified ensemble model. After extracting features from each network, a lightweight attention mechanism is applied to refine the combined output by emphasizing the most relevant channels. The model is evaluated on both the Kaggle and ADNI datasets, demonstrating reliable performance across varying data sources. The model achieved overall accuracies of 94.6 % and 84.0 % on the Kaggle and ADNI datasets, respectively. To address class imbalance in the datasets, class weights and extensive data augmentation techniques are applied during training. The experimental results show good classification performance in all stages of AD, indicating the potential of the model to support the clinical diagnosis in the real world.

title: Augmented State Neural-Transition Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Seungcheol Oh, Seonggyu Jung, Joongheon Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: We propose the Augmented State Neural-Transition EKF (ANT-EKF), a hybrid filtering framework that embeds a learnable neural transition model inside the extended Kalman filter. By augmenting the state with the neural network’s parameters, ANT-EKF jointly tracks the physical state and adapts the dynamics model online using Jacobians obtained via autograd. We instantiate the method for (i) object trajectory tracking and (ii) RIS-assisted mobile channel tracking, where the measurement remains linear in the real-stacked channel. Simulations show that ANT-EKF achieves accurate tracking and reduces NMSE compared with EKF variants relying on fixed, hand-crafted dynamics.

title: Bit-Preserving Analog Alignment-Based Cross-Domain FP-CIM for LLMs
authors: Huiwon Kim, Dongwoo Lew, Jongsun Park
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Recently, low-bit floating-point (FP) formats have gained popularity in large language models (LLMs), as they better maintain model accuracy than integer formats. However, compute-in-memory (CIM) architectures face two major challenges in efficiently supporting FP operations: 1) the need for alignment of different exponents, which is typically implemented by shifting the mantissa and often results in bit truncation; and 2) complex FP operations inherently consume significant energy. To address these challenges, we propose a bit-preserving analog alignment-based cross-domain FP-CIM (BPA-CIM) architecture tailored for low-bit FP quantized LLMs. Our design decomposes FP operations across two analog domains: 1) a time-domain exponent processor (TD-EP) detects the maximum input exponent through pulse-based comparison; and 2) a charge-domain mantissa processor (CD-MP) performs an analog-based alignment via charge sharing, thereby minimizing precision loss. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed BPA-CIM achieves up to 56.81-TFLOPS/W, with an average accuracy improvement of 2.7% compared to conventional FP-CIM.

title: A High-Performance RRAM-Based PMM Accelerator for Lattice-Based PQC
authors: Yang Chen, Zeren Zhu, Bei Wang, Chenghua Wang, Yijun Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Lattice-based post-quantum cryptography (PQC) algorithms have emerged as a promising solution for secure communication in the post-quantum era, where these algorithms heavily depend on polynomial modular multiplication (PMM). However, the computationally intensive and time-consuming nature of PMM remains a significant bottleneck affecting the overall performance of lattice-based cryptographic algorithms. In this paper, we propose a high-performance PMM accelerator to accelerate PMM by mapping the schoolbook algorithm onto a resistive random access memory (RRAM)-based computing-in-memory (CIM). This accelerator leverages the inherent parallelism and low-latency characteristics of RRAM arrays to perform PMM directly within memory, thereby substantially enhancing throughput per area by minimizing time-consuming data transfers between memory and processors. Experimental results demonstrate a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$195 \times$</tex> speedup compared to CPU-based implementations, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.6 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.4 \times$</tex> improvements in computational density over state-of-the-art in-memory computing schemes based on convolution and the number-theoretic transform (NTT), respectively. The proposed methodology not only accelerates the PMM in lattice-based PQC algorithms but also provides a scalable and efficient solution for PMM over (fully) homomorphic encryption.

title: 2D Material Characterisation Using in-Memory Predictive Analytics
authors: Kishan Kartha, Aleena Kabeer, Alex James
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This work introduces a domain-aware, sequential modelling framework for the characterisation of 2D materials such as graphene, graphene oxide (GO), and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) using impedance spectroscopy. The proposed approach combines a recurrent prediction model with a material classifier, enabling early inference from partial impedance-phase sequences. By forecasting the remainder of the frequency sweep based on initial measurements, the system achieves accurate classification while reducing dependence on full-spectrum acquisition. To enhance efficiency, a domain-informed early stopping mechanism is integrated, which halts inference once classification confidence stabilises and predictive features saturate. The architecture is further optimised through deployment on memristive crossbar arrays, leveraging in-memory computation for energy-efficient matrix-vector operations. The integration of hardware acceleration and real-time inference approaches is particularly suited for scalable, high-throughput applications in materials research and industrial settings. This work has potential for rapid, scalable, and sustainable material characterisation in industrial applications such as composite manufacturing and energy storage.

title: STO-CH: A Metaheuristic Approach for Optimal Cluster Head Selection in Heterogeneous Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Mandeep Singh, Megha Sharma, Sumita Ray Chaudhuri, Ajeet Pratap Singh, Pranshu Saxena, Gaganjot Kaur
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper introduces STO-CH, which represents an energy-efficient clustering protocol for heterogeneous WSNs using the STO metaheuristic approach to dynamically select cluster heads optimally. The spiral and migratory behavior of sooty terns can be modeled using STO-CH, maintaining a fine balance between the exploration and exploitation phases involved in CH selection. A multi-objective fitness function incorporating residual energy, cluster compactness, and proximity to a sink node is used, and K-Means clustering is helpful for initial partitioning. STO-CH is implemented using MATLAB and evaluated on $\mathrm{1 0 0 m} \times \mathrm{1 0 0 m}$ and $\mathrm{5 0 0 m} \times \mathrm{5 0 0 m}$ fields. In comparison with PSO-ECSM, STO-CH has achieved 9.8% higher throughput in the dense network and 24.6% in the sparse network, while maintaining longer stability and consistently higher PDR. In comparison with LEACH, SEP, PSEP, and PSO-ECSM, the superiority of STO-CH in node longevity, throughput, and packet delivery ratio especially in sparse deployments can be seen. STO-CH has thus proved to be robust and scalable in energy-constrained WSNs.

title: Development of an Automated System for Glaucoma Detection Using Retinal Fundus Images
authors: Priyanka Kaushik, YerraReddy Alekya Rani, Molla Khamar, Saurabh Pratap Singh Rathore, Ankur Goyal, Anshika Tyagi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Glaucoma is a revolutionary ocular ailment that damages the optic nerve and may ultimately lead to irreversible imaginative and prescient loss. Early analysis is therefore essential to prevent severe impairment. current advances in deep mastering (DL) have furnished promising answers for automated glaucoma detection. This look at proposes a convolutional neural network (CNN)-based framework for the identity of glaucoma from retinal fundus pictures. The version is designed to classify photographs as both healthy or glaucomatous, providing an efficient and reliable method for clinical screening. CNNs are especially perfect for this challenge, as they mechanically study discriminative capabilities and provide hierarchical photograph representations for effective segmentation. The proposed framework is evaluated across six diagnostic levels, making sure robustness and flexibility. moreover, a dropout mechanism is integrated to reduce overfitting and improve generalization performance. According to the findings of the experiment, CNN-based totally procedures are able to identify the initial signs of glaucoma and help clinicians in decision-making and help to create intelligent, computer-aided diagnostic frameworks.

title: DiffEraser: Generalized Text Erasure Based on Latent Diffusion Prior_supp1-3659329.pdf
authors: ChangSheng Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Text removal is an important task in processing both scene and document images. However, existing scene text removal (STR) methods are primarily focus on scene text images. The STR models (trained by scene text images) perform poorly on document images with dense, complex textured backgrounds. We discover that the limitations of existing methods can be attributed to the difficuties in background features estimation in the regions to be erased, which is based on the knowledge from neighboring regions in the input images and priors learned from the training data. The background features estimation performance degrades under the cross-domain scenarios, and compromises the quality of STR results. To address these issues, we introduce DiffEraser, a novel text removal framework that leverages prior knowledge from the Latent Diffusion Model (LDM) for removing text in both scene and document images. Our DiffEraser incorporates two key innovations to fully exploit the prior knowledge of LDM. First, we replace the conventional Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE) encoder with a Diffusion-Prior (DP) encoder, aiming to integrate the heterogeneous information from the LDM prior knowledge in latent space with the multi-level encoded features of the input image. Second, we introduce a Latent-Fusion (LF) decoder that integrates the heterogeneous features from both the LDM and DP encoders to generate high-quality text-erased results. To evaluate the generalization performance of our DiffEraser, we focus on the cross-domain protocols and construct a document image dataset, NPID295, which contains 295 types of passports and identity cards. Notably, when trained on a scene text dataset, DiffEraser significantly outperforms existing STR methods in the challenging NPID295 dataset. The resources of this work will be available online upon acceptance.

title: Compact Oneshot Modelling of High Dimensional Demonstrations using Laplacian Eigenmaps_supp2-3666134.mp4
authors: Sthithpragya Gupta
publish: N/A
abstract: Learning control policies from high-dimensional robot demonstrations remains challenging due to the need for large datasets, limited generalization, and high model complexity. These limitations hinder data-efficient learning and reactive deployment from limited demonstrations. This paper introduces LEMON-DS, a compact and data-efficient framework for one shot learning of stable control policies from high-dimensional demonstrations. LEMON-DS proceeds in three stages: (i) a graph Laplacian–based spectral embedding that reveals a quasi linear latent structure from a single trajectory, (ii) defining a globally asymptotically stable dynamical system (DS) in the latent space, and (iii) learning a diffeomorphic mapping that reconstructs the demonstrated behaviour. Collectively, this pipeline yields a lightweight reactive control policy in the form of a dynamical system that is parameter-efficient, globally asymptotically stable, and faithfully reproduces the demonstrated behaviour generalizing across initial conditions. We show empirical performance across diverse robot tasks up to 23 dimensions, outperforming prior approaches in accuracy and model compactness.

title: A Survey on Fuzzy Private Set Intersection Protocols
authors: Yunki Kim, Hyunjung Son, Seunghun Paik, Jae Hong Seo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Similarity matching has been a fundamental operation in various real-world applications, e.g., illegal content detection and biometric authentication. In particular, regarding the increasing needs for maintaining data privacy during similarity matching, the fuzzy private set intersection (FPSI) protocols, which enable participants to privately learn which one party’s set item is close enough to one of the counterpart’s items, have attracted significant attention recently. In this paper, we survey existing FPSI protocols in various aspects, including distance metrics supported by protocols, protocol designs, and core cryptographic tools. Furthermore, we discuss (potential) technical challenges regarding deployments of them in real-world application scenarios.

title: Time Synchronization Calibration for MERSI Autonomous Geolocation
authors: Hongbo Pan, Shun Zhou, Zhichao Guan, Jiajun Xu, Chengbao Liu, Siyuan Zou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Autonomous geolocation is the direct georeferencing of remote sensing imagery without ground control points (GCPs), which is a critical problem for direct broadcast satellites. For the Medium Resolution Spectral Imager (MERSI) with a 250 m ground sample distance, the attitude and orbit determination system meets sub-pixel geolocation accuracy requirements. However, latitude-related geolocation errors were observed from global GCPs of FY-3D MERSI-Ⅱ, and attitude jitter errors were observed in FY-3F MERSI-Ⅲ. In this study, three time synchronization errors of four dynamic components were investigated for spaceborne integrated sensors, the time delay between Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receivers, Earth time, and navigation system, when the time of the whiskbroom scanner was the reference. The time synchronization calibration method was developed to calibrate MERSI-II and MERSI-III with two orbits. Given the correlation between the time synchronization and spatial parameters, the scanning compensation angles were used to select the optimal parameters. MERSI-Ⅱ exhibits a 0.590 s delay with the GNSS receiver, whereas MERSI-Ⅲ shows 0.27 s and 0.175 s delays with the GNSS receiver and the navigation system, respectively. After correcting the time synchronization of MERSI-II, the median geolocation error in the scan direction at 80° N decreased from 1.5 to 0.5 instantaneous field of view (IFOV). The global root mean square errors (RMSEs) was 0.493 IFOV (109.02 m) in the image plane. After correcting the time synchronization of MERSI-III, the global RMSEs was 0.374 IFOV (93.5 m) in the image plane.

title: How Dare You Refuse Me? How and When AI Negative Hiring Decision Influences Applicants' Reactions_supp4-3665195.docx
authors: Xinyi Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Despite the growing attention given to applicants' reactions to the utilization of artificial intelligence (AI) within organizational recruitment contexts, scholars have paid little attention to the emotional mechanism between AI decision-making (especially negative) and applicants' procedural justice perception, as well as how the perception affects their subsequent behavior. Drawing on the cognitive–functional model of discrete negative emotions, we propose and empirically test the effect of anger triggered by AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' procedural justice perception and complaint behavior. General support for the model testing is obtained from two studies, namely, a laboratory experiment (N = 97) that uses technology for facial expression analysis (i.e., Face Reader 8.0) and an online scenario-based experiment (N = 270). The rigor of our findings is enhanced by collecting data from multiple participant sources, using FaceReader and self-reports in a complementary manner to measure anger, and by introducing control variables for robustness checks. We find that AI-driven negative decisions, rather than human-driven ones, elicit greater anger from applicants. Notably, this effect is weakened for applicants with extensive prior AI experience. Moreover, anger suppresses applicants' perceptions of procedural justice, thus yielding a distinct effect on their complaint behavior. Our study contributes to the understanding of the effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' emotional, cognitive, and behavioral reactions. It also sheds light on the influence of applicants' prior AI experience in reducing the negative effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' subsequent responses.

title: Merging the Graphene Plasmons to Cavity Resonance for Controllable THz Multifunctional Metasurface
authors: Rana Vikram Pratap Singh Yadav, Pushpa Giri, Gaurav Varshney
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: Merging the graphene surface plasmon resonance (GSPR) with the cavity resonance can provide a controllable multifunctional terahertz (THz) metasurface. A reflective metasurface containing a metallic resonator with discontinuities operates with a finite length and short dipoles. The insertion of graphene perturbs the field and can provide the GSPR along with the dipolar resonance of a short metallic dipole. Here, the field enhancement factor in graphene surface plasmons (GSPs) in all the generated GSPs mode indices significantly dominates the field confinement (FE) of metallic short dipolar formation. Consequently, the Fermi energy of graphene can provide the controllable multifunctional operation of the metasurface. The proposed metasurface can provide the conversion from linearly polarized (LP) to left-hand circularly polarized (LHCP) operation in the first band for all the values of Fermi energy of graphene. The operation is as LP to cross-polarization conversion (CPC) for Fermi energy up to 0.4 eV and LP to LHCP for Fermi energy up to 1 eV, in the second band. The metasurface provides the narrow absorption peaks and LP to right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) operation in the third band for particular values of Fermi energy of graphene.

title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Control for Human–Machine Cooperative Systems Based on Dynamic Authority Allocation
authors: Dehua Zhang, Lei Meng, Linlin Liang, Chunbin Qin, Derong Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article addresses the challenging problem of constrained optimal control for human–machine systems subject to external disturbances and the bounded rationality of the human operator. To this end, a novel game-theoretic framework is proposed. Unlike monolithic game formulations, the framework uniquely disaggregates the control problem by transforming it into a multifaceted game via logarithmic barrier functions (BFs): it models human–machine cooperation as a positive-sum game oriented toward shared objectives, and disturbance rejection as a zero-sum game tailored for robustness enhancement. To capture the nonideal human decision-making, we integrate the level-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math> </inline-formula> reasoning framework to model the operator’s bounded cognitive dynamics. The corresponding coupled Hamilton–Jacobi–Isaacs (HJI) equations for this human–machine game are derived, and critically, a rigorous proof of global asymptotic stability (GAS) for the transformed system is provided, establishing a solid theoretical foundation. For online implementation without requiring prior knowledge of the system dynamics, we develop a resource-efficient learning architecture based on the adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) and a novel dynamic event-triggered mechanism (DETM). A key feature of this architecture is a fuzzy logic-based module for dynamic authority allocation, which adaptively adjusts control sharing in real time. Rigorous analysis demonstrates that all signals in the closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded and that Zeno behavior is precluded. Simulation results are presented to validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed control strategy.

title: Enhanced three-phase inverter topology and PWM strategy for electric vehicle powertrains with reduced common-mode voltage
authors: Endika Robles, Iker Aretxabaleta, Jon Andreu, Ander DeMarcos, Jose Ignacio Garate
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: In electric drive systems, common-mode voltage (CMV) fluctuations cause bearing currents that damage the motor, deteriorate stator winding insulation, and generate electromagnetic interference throughout the system. Several methods have been proposed to mitigate this stray voltage, especially in electric vehicles, where reliability requirements are increasingly stringent. At the same time, improving efficiency — by minimizing power losses — is essential to enhance driving range and thermal management. This paper presents a novel two-level three-phase inverter topology combined with hybrid modulation techniques for electric vehicle propulsion systems. The proposed architecture aims to significantly reduce CMV variations while maintaining high overall efficiency. Simulation and experimental results confirm that, depending on the specific operating condition, the proposed solution achieves reductions of more than 80 % in CMV fluctuations compared with standard SV-PWM operation, efficiency improvements between 0.6 % and 1.5 % relative to a conventional VSI, and a redistribution of switching losses that can reduce the power dissipated per main VSI device by more than 25 %. Unlike previously proposed alternatives, the converter preserves full compatibility with standard VSI control schemes and achieves a superior balance between reliability, CMV mitigation, and efficiency. Therefore, it represents a feasible and promising alternative for future electric vehicle drive systems.

title: Action Model-Based Natural Language Control System for Digital Twins
authors: Younghwan Jeong, Won Gi Choi, Taemin Hwang, Jin-Young Lee, Sang-Shin Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Digital twins, which enable seamless interaction between the physical and virtual worlds for simulation and control, have garnered significant attention across various domains. However, operating and managing digital twins beyond mere monitoring typically requires substantial expertise and effort, presenting a high barrier to entry for non-experts. In this study, we propose an Action Model-Based Digital twin control system that allows non-specialists to intuitively operate digital twins. By leveraging a large action model, the system interprets user intent from natural language commands and dynamically controls key functions of the digital twin without the need for domain-specific knowledge.

title: Printed Circuit Board Defect Detection System Using Deep Learning on FPGA
authors: Lee Jia Qian, Nasri Sulaiman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents the development and implementation of a real-time Printed Circuit Board (PCB) defect detection system using deep learning on FPGA. A YOLOv3-Tiny object detection model was trained using a publicly available dataset containing 9014 high-resolution images annotated with six common PCB defect types: missing hole, mouse bite, open circuit, short circuit, spur, and spurious copper. The training was conducted using the Hank AI Darknet framework, and the best weights were achieved at iteration 28,819 with a mean Average Precision (mAP) of 99.55%. To enable deployment on resource-limited hardware, the trained model was optimized using the DNNDK toolchain. The model was quantized to 8-bit fixed-point and compiled for execution on the Deep Processing Unit (DPU) integrated into the Xilinx PYNQ-Z2 FPGA board. Both static image inference and real-time inference were successfully executed. The FPGA-based system achieved a real-time frame rate of 2.015 FPS and a post-deployment mAP of 28.17% at IoU threshold of 0.5. Despite a reduction in detection accuracy due to quantization, the system remains suitable for a standalone, power-efficient, and cost-effective PCB defect detection system for real-time industrial applications.

title: A Harmonic Energy Metering Algorithm Based on Four-Term Five-Order Nuttall Window and Three-Spectrum Interpolation FFT
authors: Yingying Cheng, Yu Su, Gaolin Wu, Wenli Chen, Xingzhi Liu, Minghui Ma, Ji Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: In ultra-high voltage direct current (UHVDC) transmission systems, the nonlinear characteristics of converters and the integration of new energy sources introduce a large amount of harmonics, which causes measurement errors in traditional FFT algorithms due to spectral leakage and the picket fence effect. To improve the accuracy of energy measurement under harmonic conditions, a three-spectrum line interpolation FFT algorithm based on the four-term fifth-order Nuttall window is proposed. Firstly, the main lobe width, side lobe level and attenuation rate of commonly used window functions are compared, and the four-term fifth-order Nuttall window is selected to suppress spectral leakage. Then, the deviation caused by the picket fence effect is corrected through three-spectrum line interpolation. Finally, a multi-harmonic simulation model is built to verify the performance of the algorithm. Simulation results show that the amplitude error of each harmonic of this algorithm is ≤ 0.0105%, and the phase error is ≤ 0.0389%, which is significantly better than the traditional windowed interpolation algorithm, and can provide a high-precision solution for harmonic measurement in UHVDC systems.

title: Face Detection and Recognition Using PCA and Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Dhananjay Kumar, Richa Tiwari, Sharmila, Geetanjali Sharma, Priyanka Tyagi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper presents a face recognition system based on grayscale facial images, with the main attention to computational efficiency and classification accuracy. To prepare the data, the dataset is normalized and increased through data augmentation. Dimensionality reduction is done by Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and the Eigenface method, selecting 95% of the variance of the dataset. Extracted features are used for training and testing several machine learning models, including Support Vector Ma- chines (SVM), Logistic Regression (LR), and Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA). Experimental results, validated through crossvalidation, reveal that LDA and LR achieve the best classification performance at $93 \%$. The obtained results prove that the combination of statistical dimensionality reduction with standard classifiers can be used for reliable face recognition in resource-constrained conditions.

title: Constructing an Intelligent Learning Environment for Engineering Cognition and Practice Course Based on the Rain Classroom Platform
authors: Xiuqin Han, Xiaohui Xing, Hongliang Yang, Jun Bao, Yuhong Wang, Chen Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: With the rapid development of the economy and continuous advances in engineering technologies, engineering cognition and practice courses play a crucial role in higher education for engineering disciplines. This paper explores the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies into engineering education through the use of the “Rain Classroom” intelligent teaching platform. It highlights the platform’s functional advantages in enhancing classroom interaction, learning analytics, and personalized learning. Through real-world teaching cases, the study validates the effectiveness of intelligent classroom models in improving student motivation, teaching efficiency, and the development of engineering competencies. Furthermore, the paper identifies current challenges in building intelligent classroom — such as fragmented teaching resources, limited platform capabilities, insufficient digital literacy among instructors, and low student autonomy, and it proposes corresponding improvement strategies. The study aims to provide both theoretical foundations and practical guidance for the development of intelligent classrooms in engineering education, thereby promoting innovative talent cultivation models.

title: CFDITA-Based Current-Mode All-Pass Filter
authors: Anupam, Atul Kumar, Sajai Vir Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This study introduces a current-mode first-order all-pass filter (CM-FOAPF) with the fewest active and passive components. A sole Current Follower Differential Input Transconductance Amplifier (CFDITA) serves as the active element in the suggested configuration. Because of its low input impedance, the circuit works well for current-mode signal processing applications. Another benefit of this design is that its pole frequency can be tuned electronically. To evaluate the performance of the suggested circuit, the simulations are done through PSPICE. The technology used in the simulations is 180 nm CMOS process at a $\pm 1.25 \mathrm{~V}$ operating voltage. The simulated power consumption of the filter is 1.5 mW, demonstrating its low-power and efficient performance.

title: Effective Container Allocation Strategies for Multi-Yard Inland Container Depots
authors: Junghyun Lee, Hyeonseok Seo, Jun Kyun Choi, Jaeeun Park, Jaewon Jang, Gyeong Ho Lee, Merve Gözde Sayın
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Efficiently assigning incoming containers to inland container depots is critical for reducing operational disruptions and improving overall terminal efficiency. This paper addresses the container depot selection problem with the objective of minimizing container relocations, a key factor influencing terminal performance. We propose an integrated approach that accounts for both immediate relocation costs incurred upon container arrival and future relocation risks estimated via Monte Carlo simulation. The proposed method provides a balanced decision-making framework that considers both short-term and long-term relocation factors. To evaluate the effectiveness of our proposed method, computational experiments were conducted under diverse conditions, including varying container volumes, initial yard occupancy levels, and weighting parameter.

title: Beyond Word-for-Word: A BERT-Based Learning Framework for Emotion Interpretation in English Poetry for ESL Students in Chinese Universities
authors: Marco Bidin, Jiaqi Du, Tiange Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Interpreting the emotional depth of English poetry presents a unique challenge for ESL (English as a Second Language) students, who often rely on word-for-word translation strategies that obscure nuanced affective meaning. This paper proposes a BERT-based learning framework that integrates affective computing with guided literary interpretation to support ESL learners in developing emotional literacy in poetic texts. The methodology is presented through a set of annotated poetry case studies that illustrate how transformer-based sentiment modeling can scaffold multi-level emotional understanding. Drawing on selected English poems frequently included in undergraduate humanities curricula, the framework shows how BERT can be used to analyze divergences between literal semantic meaning and contextual emotional tone. Students are guided to compare machine-predicted affect (Anger, disgust, fear, joy, neutral, sadness and surprise) with their own interpretations, enabling reflective discussions on emotional subtext, metaphor, and cultural resonance. The approach supports inclusive learning by accommodating linguistic diversity and offering non-native learners affective insights often inaccessible through vocabulary alone. By centering emotion as a critical entry point into literary analysis, this AI-augmented framework promotes deeper engagement with poetry while contributing to digitally empowered humanities education.

title: Localization Performance Analysis of UAV-based Integrated Sensing and Communication System
authors: Dongmin Kim, Jiyoon Noh, Juhyung Lee, Jaesung Lim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems enabled by unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), the selection of hovering points (HPs) plays a pivotal role in determining target localization performance. This paper analyzes and compares three HP selection methods. Simulation results demonstrate that considering both range and angle can achieve accurate localization while using significantly fewer HPs. These findings highlight the importance of informative HP selection in UAV trajectory design, enabling efficient and accurate target localization with minimal sensing resources.

title: A Modular Domain-Aware Neural Network Architecture for Power Amplifier Linearization
authors: Lotta Rantala, Arne Fischer-Bühner, Alberto Brihuega, Sasan Sharifipour, Praneeth Susarla, Miguel Bordallo López, Constantino Álvarez Casado
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Next-generation wireless systems demand highly efficient power amplifiers (PAs), which introduce complex non-linearities and memory effects. Traditional digital pre-distortion (DPD) methods, such as the Generalized Memory Polynomial (GMP), struggle with these impairments. This paper proposes a Modular Domain-Aware Time-Delay Neural Network (MDA-TDNN), a hybrid physically-inspired architecture that combines established signal processing components into a unified TDNN-based structure. Rather than introducing fundamentally new building blocks, the contribution lies in the systematic integration and evaluation of these components, providing a structured characterization of their individual and joint effects on DPD performance. It includes a Finite Impulse Response (FIR) layer for memory modeling, a phase normalization layer for complex signal behavior, an envelope layer for amplitude non-linearities, and a residual path for stable training. MDA-TDNN was trained on an ideal dataset generated by an Iterative Learning Control scheme and experimentally validated on an RF testbed using a 75 MHz 5G NR signal. The results demonstrate that MDA-TDNN outperforms GMP by 7.95 dB in Adjacent Channel Leakage Ratio (ACLR), achieving performance within 1 dB of ideal DPD. An ablation study highlights the importance of phase normalization and FIR layers. These findings validate the effectiveness of domain-aware neural architectures for PA linearization.

title: Design and Implementation Real-Time Web-Based Iot Monitoring of Off-Grid Solar Power Plants for Drying Racks
authors: Nunung Nurhasanah, Nida Salsabila, Suci Rahmatia, Iksan khosiya Rohman, Taufik Baidawi, Ivan Adhi Pramana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: The growing need for renewable energy is driving the development of off-grid solar systems to support the availability of sustainable energy in rural and agricultural areas. One of the applications is in the post-harvest process of drying sunflower seeds, where temperature and humidity stability are essential to maintain the quality of the results. This study presents the design and implementation of a real-time web-based IoT monitoring system on off-grid solar power plants used for sunflower seed drying rack space. The system integrates PZEM-017 DC, PZEM016 AC, and DHT22 sensors connected to the Raspberry Pi 3B as a data publisher, then transmits the measurement results through the MQTT broker Mosquitto. The data is processed and stored in the SQLite database, then visualized through web dashboard that can be accessed via PC or smartphone. The test results show that the system is capable of monitoring electrical and environmental parameters in real-time, is responsive to a wide range of devices, and provides a practical solution for users to improve monitoring efficiency while reducing reliance on manual measurements.

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence, Techno-Educational Ethics, and Academic Integrity in Higher Education
authors: Tomás Peralta Palazón, Cristina Galván Fernández, Maria Rosa Buxarrais
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The integration of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) into higher education is reshaping teaching and learning processes from both methodological and ethical perspectives. This article explores this transformation through the lens of techno-educational ethics—a concept introduced in this study—with a particular focus on academic integrity and the ethical competencies necessary for the critical and responsible use of these technologies. Employing a conceptual and analytical approach, the study draws on theoretical frameworks and institutional reports to identify the main challenges and opportunities that GenAI poses within the university context. Building on its conceptual contribution, the article offers strategic orientations to support an institutional integration of GenAI that is ethically grounded, pedagogically coherent, and aligned with existing frameworks of university responsibility, from a techno-educational ethics perspective.

title: An Efficient Indexed Network Threat Gene Library Construction Scheme in Smart Grid
authors: Muxian Liu, Liyu Lu, Yuan Tang, Guihua Liu, Zhibo Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The power system is a critical infrastructure underpinning the modern socio-economic framework, making its security and stable operation paramount. The ongoing intelligent and digital transformation of power grids, however, has exposed them to increasingly severe cybersecurity threats, revealing the inadequacy of conventional defense mechanisms against novel attack paradigms. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel framework for constructing a network threat gene library for power systems that integrates biological immune mechanisms with similarity comparison techniques. The core of our approach involves abstracting network traffic characteristics into “genes”, which are efficiently stored and retrieved using a Prefix Hash Tree. To assess whether a new sample exhibits similarities to known threats, we employ a Radial Basis Function to quantify inter-sample similarity. Furthermore, the proposed scheme incorporates an immune memory mechanism and a dynamic update strategy, enabling continuous refinement of the gene library, ensuring its dynamic adaptability to the evolving threat landscape and facilitating rapid responses to emerging attack patterns. The experimental verification on the CICIDS2018 dataset shows that for the dataset of 1000 to 10000 samples, the system improves the total insertion time of the maximum amount of data by 21.43% while maintaining the query time below 0.05 milliseconds, showing superior scalability and real-time response capabilities.

title: Rethinking BiLSTM Superiority under Severe Data Heterogeneity in Federated Load Forecasting
authors: Nanteza Adah Lubwama, Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae Min Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) offers promising solutions for energy load forecasting in smart grids while preserving data privacy. However, most existing studies assume bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks outperform LSTM models, an assumption derived from centralized learning scenarios. This paper challenges this conventional wisdom by evaluating both architectures under extreme data heterogeneity conditions in federated environments. We propose an adaptive Dirichlet partitioning approach integrated with a novel Proof-of-Authority-and-Association (PoA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) consensus mechanism for real-time energy forecasting. Our experimental evaluation using hourly energy consumption data across 10 federated rounds with 5 clients show that LSTM consistently outperforms BiLSTM under high data heterogeneity (α = 0.1), achieving superior R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores (0.92 versus 0.81), lower loss values (0.08 versus 0.19), and reduced mean absolute error (500 versus 780). The PoA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2-</sup>based PureChain framework maintains low latency (166ms) while supporting high throughput (147 predictions/minute) with 97% security score. These findings demonstrate that architectural simplicity in LSTM provides better generalization capabilities under extreme non-identical data (non-IID) conditions, while our adaptive partitioning method stabilizes training performance. The integrated blockchain solution ensures secure, decentralized coordination suitable for real-time Smart grid applications, offering both theoretical insights and practical implications for federated energy forecasting systems

title: Making Knowledge Acquisition Fun! Generating Content-Related Humor for Learning with Large Language Models
authors: Karl Fischer, Thorsten Zylowski, Matthias Wölfel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The introduction of large language models (LLMs) and their accessibility to the general public have transformed how we acquire knowledge. This paper explores how knowledge acquisition through LLMs can be enhanced and made more enjoyable through the use of humor. A particularly effective type of humor for this purpose is content-related humor, which consists of multiple subcategories. To determine whether an LLM can intentionally generate content-related humor, Llama 3.1 was prompted to produce humorous responses across five subcategories, namely: jokes, examples, stories, sarcasm, and creative language. The model was instructed to respond humorously while aligning with the specific humor subcategory prompted. To evaluate this capability, a classifier was trained, linguistic metrics were analyzed, and a human evaluation was conducted on the generated responses. The findings indicate that the LLM successfully adapts to the humor subcategories through targeted prompting, demonstrating its ability to generate a distinct form of content-related humor.

title: Towards a trustworthy AI chatbot for crop commodity market
authors: Abir Chebbi, Guido Kniesel, Jérôme Chételat, Nabil Abdennadher, Tewfiq EL-Maliki, Giovanna Di Marzo Serugendo
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The rapid adoption of Artificial Intelligence systems in high-stakes domains such as agriculture underscores the need for trustworthiness. In this paper, we present a chatbot system designed to provide actionable insights for crop commodity markets by leveraging a Retrieval-Augmented Generation framework. The system integrates a Trust Engine to evaluate its performance across key dimensions, including data reliability, source reputation, and user feedback, ensuring accurate and reliable information delivery. The Trust Engine calculates trust scores at two levels: (1) for individual interactions using fuzzy logic and (2) for the system’s behavior over time by aggregating metrics such as user feedback, discrepancy counts, and unknown answer rates. We conducted an initial evaluation on ten representative queries commonly encountered by market stakeholders, highlighting variations in response quality and trust scores.The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the Trust Engine in distinguishing between high- and low-trust responses and emphasize the critical role of trust assessment in AI-driven decision support tools. This work lays the foundation for more robust and explainable AI systems.

title: Enhancing the Reliability of Large Language Models in Specialized Domains by Balancing Internal and External Knowledge
authors: Yuran Li, Di Wu, Benoit Boulet
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: With the widespread application of large language models, numerous approaches have been proposed to enhance their performance. Most existing works focus on general-purpose tasks. Although some domain-specific approaches have emerged, they typically rely on enriching LLMs’ knowledge through additional training or retrieving external information, without effectively leveraging internal knowledge or balancing it with external sources. To address this, we propose a framework that operates effectively with only a few representative training samples (no more than one order of magnitude) to adapt to specialized tasks. This method is well-suited for scenarios with limited data, where fine-tuning is infeasible. Our method first adopts LLM-generated few-shot examples from training set, involving Chain-of-Thought, to maximize the utilization of internal knowledge. Then, uncertainty-guided retrieval-augmented generation is employed to selectively incorporate external information. This method balances internal and external knowledge, thereby reducing hallucinations arising from knowledge gap and errors caused by inaccurate retrieved context. Our method is compared with several representative, general-purpose methods on domain-specific datasets (law and finance). Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing training-free, general-purpose methods across most tasks.

title: Automated Research Article Classification and Recommendation Using NLP and Machine Learning
authors: Shadikur Rahman, Hasibul Karim Shanto, Umme Ayman Koana, Syed Muhammad Danish
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: In the digital era, the exponential growth of scientific publications has made it increasingly difficult for researchers to efficiently identify and access relevant work. This paper presents an automated framework for research article classification and recommendation that leverages Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques and machine learning. Using a large-scale arXiv.org dataset spanning more than three decades, we evaluate multiple feature extraction approaches (TF–IDF, Count Vectorizer, Sentence-BERT, USE, Mirror-BERT) in combination with diverse machine learning classifiers (Logistic Regression, SVM, Naïve Bayes, Random Forest, Gradient Boosted Trees, and k-Nearest Neighbor). Our experiments show that Logistic Regression with TF–IDF consistently yields the best classification performance, achieving an accuracy of 69%. To complement classification, we incorporate a recommendation module based on cosine similarity of vectorized articles, enabling efficient retrieval of related research papers. The proposed system directly addresses the challenge of information overload in digital libraries and demonstrates a scalable, data-driven solution to support literature discovery.

title: AxAdderNet: Combining Approximate Computing to Quantized AdderNet
authors: DaeRyong Shin, Min Kee Chang, HyunJin Kim, Alberto A. del Barrio
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a so-called AxAdderNet, applying approximate computing to the quantized AdderNet. Along with the advantages of replacing multiplication operations with add operations in convolutions, the proposed design adopts the approximate adder in the quantized AdderNet. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first approach to apply approximate computing to the quantized AdderNet used in convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Because the AdderNet has different ranges of activations and weights, the proper arrangements of scaling factors for convolutions are analyzed. The degree of approximation in AdderNet is varied to evaluate the impact of approximation errors on the training results in the quantized AdderNet. Based on evaluation results and analysis, a detailed methodology is provided to apply the approximate adders to the quantized AdderNet considering the accuracy. In the evaluations, LeNet5-BN and ResNet-20 show 98.43% and 88.10% Top-1 accuracy in MNIST and CIFAR-10.

title: RoPE on the Fast Track: Latency-Optimized LLM Inference on GPUs with Low-Rank QKV Factorization and Rotary Positional Embedding
authors: Gilhyeon Lee, Jihoon Jang, Kyungmin Goh, Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: In large language model (LLM) inference, rotary positional embedding (RoPE) contributes significantly to overall decoding latency due to accumulated overhead from numerous micro-kernel invocations and its sequential execution after Q and K generation, which prevents effective parallelization. Additionally, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Q}, \mathrm{K}$</tex>, and V (QKV) generation weights in modern LLMs-where the model dimension reaches several thou-sand-are each several gigabytes in size, making it impractical to store them in the on-chip memory of FPGAs or custom ASICs. This necessitates repeated off-chip accesses, limiting hardware utilization and inference speed. To address these bottlenecks, we apply rank <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=8$</tex> factorization to the QKV generation weights, reducing memory usage by over 99% and lowering per-token FLOPs to 1.41% of the baseline, with minimal loss in accuracy. Furthermore, we reformulate RoPE as a Weight-side RoPE mechanism by pre-applying it to low-rank weights and enabling its parallel execution with RMS normalization on the GPU. This structural change improves execution efficiency by enabling concurrent computation. Experimental results using a Llama3based model on an RTX 3090 GPU show that decoding latency is reduced by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.14 \times$</tex> for batch size 1 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.17 \times$</tex> for batch size 2, while maintaining comparable accuracy to the baseline.
