title: Multi-Output Forecasting of Electricity and Gas Fees: A Comparative Study of Deep Learning and Statistical Models
authors: Nematullo Rahmatov, Jinsol Kwon, Jonghyeon Bae, Hyerim Jeon, Jiwoong Jeon, Eunjeong Jo, Dongkyu Lee, Juyeol Park, Jiyeon Nam, Seongmin Roh, Hoki Baek
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Forecasting energy consumption with high accuracy is crucial for effective resource planning and policy decision-making. This study presents a hybrid approach that combines statistical and deep learning models to predict both gas and electricity consumption over an 18-month period. The proposed model integrates GRU, LSTM, VAR, and DFM techniques to improve multi-output time series forecasting. The evaluation is conducted using three widely-used error metrics: RMSE, MAE, and MAPE. Experimental results show that the presented hybrid model outperforms some individual models in predicting electricity consumption and provides competitive accuracy for natural gas forecasting. These findings demonstrate the potential of model fusion strategies in enhancing utility usage prediction for long-term energy management and budgeting.

title: CEEMDAN-AI Based Equalizer for Nonlinear Distortion Mitigation in Satellite Communications
authors: Yongkyun Kim, Jongbeom Lee, Minyong Park, Byungju Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Non-linearity introduced by from high-power amplifiers (HPAs) significantly degrades signal quality in satellite communication systems. In this paper, we propose a complete ensemble empirical mode decomposition with adaptive noise (CEEMDAN)-AI based equalizer for mitigating such non-linear distortion at the ground station. Specifically, the proposed equalizer employs the CEEMDAN to decompose the distorted signal into multiple intrinsic mode functions (IMFs). These IMFs are served as supplementary input features to the AI-based equalizer, allowing the model to better capture the distortion characteristics. Through numerical results, we show that the proposed method using the long short-term memory (LSTM) model with IMFs achieves a 31.6% reduction in error vector magnitude (EVM) and better bit error rate (BER) performance compared to the baseline and the LSTM without IMFs at all signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regimes.

title: Optimized Dispatch Strategies of Electrolyzer Cluster and Battery Considering Renewable Power Fluctuation
authors: Shaohua Dong, Yi Zheng, Ziyue Wang, Xin Zhao, Dingzhang Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: Coordinated dispatch of electrolyzer clusters is a key technology for large-scale water electrolysis hydrogen production systems, as it can effectively reduce the cost of hydrogen produced via electrolysis. Existing research has mostly focused on the scheduling of electrolyzer clusters themselves, addressing the optimal power allocation problem within the clusters, but has not fully explored the potential of energy storage to improve the overall utilization efficiency of electrolyzer clusters. Additionally, there is a lack of research on the coordinated scheduling of energy storage and electrolyzer clusters. This paper proposes a coordinated scheduling method for electrolyzer clusters and energy storage battery packs, which fully considers the dynamic characteristics and start-stop behavior of electrolyzers. The proposed algorithm is validated through a case study involving 18 electrolyzers and 3 energy storage batteries. Research results demonstrate that the proposed scheduling method can be effectively applied to the coordinated operation of large-scale electrolyzer clusters and battery systems. Frequent charging and discharging of batteries can effectively mitigate the volatility of renewable energy sources and enhance the overall utilization efficiency of electrolyzer clusters.

title: An Interactive AR-Based Level-2 Gamified System for Robotic Education: Mobile and Manipulator Platforms
authors: Alberto Vadillo-Villalobos, Jhedmar Callupe-Luna, Deyby Huamanchahua
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Robotics education faces challenges due to limited access to physical laboratories and the complexity of teaching abstract concepts. In response, technologies such as Augmented Reality (AR) and gamification have emerged as promising strategies to enhance student engagement and knowledge retention. However, their application in robotics education, particularly for first-year engineering students, remains limited. To address this gap, a Level 2 augmented reality gamified system was developed to introduce essential concepts of mobile and manipulator robots. Results from the implementation indicate that students who engaged with the AR system achieved significantly better learning outcomes, with an average improvement of $17.98 \%$ in their scores compared to those instructed through traditional methods. Furthermore, an evaluation based on the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) revealed that perceived usefulness and enjoyment significantly influenced students’ intention to continue using the system. These findings highlight the practical value of integrating AR and gamification into robotics education, as they transform conventional engineering education into a more accessible, engaging, and interactive experience. Index Terms-Augmented reality, mobile robots, manipulator robots, gamification, interactive learning

title: Behind the Curtains of VLM: Analyzing the Influence of Background Knowledge
authors: Ga San Jhun, Hyun Jun Yook, Min Kyu Choi, Joongheon Kim, Youn Kyu Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent Vision-Language Models (VLMs) achieve impressive performance in multi-modal tasks by utilizing their background knowledge, acquired by their large-scale training dataset. However, their internal operation process remain black-box as the models increase in size. Therefore, the influence of background knowledge during their operational process is not well explored. In this paper, we propose a novel testing method that evaluates the influence of such background knowledge on VQA tasks through precisely controlled datasets. By isolating visual and textual information, we analyze how background knowledge affects the model’s judgments in each modality. The proposed method enables systematic analysis of this phenomenon and provides insights for enhancing VLM performance.

title: A Cloud-Edge Architecture for Real-Time Fault Detection in Smart Grids
authors: Sushil Bhattarai, Divya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of distributed edge and fog computing infrastructures has significantly enhanced real-time data processing and service responsiveness. Nevertheless, these environments' decentralized characteristics and heterogeneous architectures make them vulnerable to complex and dynamic cyber attacks, which traditional IDSs can't detect effectively. Problem Statement: traditional IDS models do not adjust well to entropy variance as they shift across multi-layered environments, resulting in a loss of detection accuracy and an increased false alarm rate. Proposed Approach: In this article, we propose an Entropy-Driven Intrusion Detection Algorithm (EDIA) for distributed edge-fog-centers. EDIA utilizes information entropy and temporal correlations of network traffic flows to detect anomalous behaviors. The approach merges information theory with a hybrid detection engine that combines the Shannon Entropy Analysis (SEA) and state-of-theart frameworks, such as the lightweight Deep Residual Network (L-DRN), to support adaptive thresholding. Results: The evaluation of multi-layered real-world edge-fog benchmark data shows that EDIA achieves a 97.4% detection rate, 2.1% false-positive rate, and 21 % compute overhead reduction relative to EdgeIDS and FogGuard. Conclusion: we propose a practical, scalable, lightweight, and low-latency IDS framework for distributed edge-fog environments, improving the security resilience of edge-fog computing ecosystems.

title: LiDAR Reflection Recovery via Shadow Boxing
authors: Kyungmin Kim, Jeongyeup Paek
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Light detection and ranging (LiDAR) sensor is a device that can effectively collect 3D spatial information using lasers. However, reflective surfaces like mirrors pose a challenge for LiDAR, making it difficult to distinguish between objects in front and behind a mirror and their reflected counterparts. In this paper, we propose the Shadow Boxing Method, a technique for effectively classifying reflected points that appear to be behind the mirror. We will differentiate reflected points from points behind the mirror, and further restore these identified points to their original 3D locations by accurately detecting the relative position of the mirror and the angle of reflections. This will overcome the existing limitations of LiDAR sensors, enabling more accurate sensing. We envision that our idea can potentially improve the safety of LiDAR-based autonomous vehicles even when confronted with highly reflective surfaces such as traffic safety mirrors.

title: Development and Performance Optimization of 4G Signal Enhancement Device and Signal Transmission System for Box-Type Substations
authors: Lei Zhou, Liang Zhu, Jing Shao, Ziyuan Zhou, Li Wei, Puqing Liu, Kaidi Shi, Han Bao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: In the field of electricity information collection, terminal devices are often in enclosed environments such as boxtype substations, which leads to obstacles in public network signal transmission, resulting in problems such as weak signals and equipment failure to work normally. This paper introduces a 4 G signal enhancement device for box-type substations. The device is composed of a power module, a radio frequency combiner, and a signal transponder. By processing uplink and downlink signals, it can effectively enhance signal strength and improve signal quality. Practical applications show that the device can significantly improve the signal transmission performance of electricity information collection terminals and ensure the stability and reliability of data transmission.

title: Towards Privacy-Aware IoT Audit Framework: A Grounded Theory Approach
authors: Handry Fratama Diansyah, Yudhistira Nugraha, Muhamad Erza Aminanto
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies in today's electronic society has raised pressing concerns about personal data privacy. Existing audit frameworks for traditional IT systems do not adequately address the unique challenges posed by IoT environments, including continuous data collection, device heterogeneity, and limited user interfaces. Moreover, most IoT systems lack auditability by design, and no standardised mechanisms exist to assess compliance with data privacy principles. To address this gap, we developed a privacyaware IoT audit framework using Grounded Theory Analysis. In-depth interviews were conducted with ten professionals from Indonesia, a newly industrialized country that recently enacted a Personal Data Protection Law, comprising IT auditors and cybersecurity experts, to extract insights from real-world practices. Through a structured coding process (open, axial, and selective), we developed a modular framework comprising seven components: Risk Assessment, Governance, Asset Management, Security Controls, Privacy Controls, Incident Management, and Compliance Assessment. Our findings reveal that privacy considerations are frequently overlooked in current IoT audit practices. The proposed framework offers a systematic and empirically grounded approach to evaluating personal data protection in IoT systems. By embedding regulatory compliance and auditability into its design, this paper addresses a key shortcoming in current audit standards and contributes to stronger, more accountable data privacy governance in connected digital ecosystems.

title: Cluster-Based Resampling for Imbalanced Datasets in Software Defect Prediction
authors: Harsih Rianto, Omar Pahlevi, Demulyati, Amrin, Budi Supriyadi, Arfan Sansprayada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Software defect prediction is an important task in software engineering because it helps identify defective modules early and reduces maintenance costs. However, the imbalanced nature of datasets often causes classification models to be biased toward the majority class while neglecting the minority class. This study aims to address this issue by applying Cluster-Based Resampling (CBR) and evaluating its effectiveness compared to baseline models. Secondary data were obtained from the NASA Metrics Data Program (MDP). Three classification algorithms were employed, namely Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF), and Gradient Boosting (GB), evaluated using Accuracy, Area Under the Curve (AUC), Recall, F1-Score, and G-Mean with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex>-fold cross-validation technique. The results show that before applying CBR, the models had high accuracy and AUC, for example LR achieved an accuracy of 0.99 on MC1 and GB achieved an AUC of 0.97 on PC5, but the recall and G-Mean values were very low, such as LR recall of only 0.02 and G-Mean of 0.15 on CM1. After applying CBR, although accuracy slightly decreased (e.g., CBR-LR only 0.84 on MC1), model performance significantly improved in other metrics, such as CBR-GB with a recall of 0.74 on PC1, an F1-score of 0.87 on MC1, and a G-Mean of up to 0.91 on PC5, while AUC remained stable in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.80-0.94$</tex>. These findings confirm that CBR is effective in reducing class imbalance and producing fairer and more representative evaluation. In practical terms, CBR can be integrated into software development pipelines or continuous integration/continuous deployment (CI/CD) workflows to enhance defect prediction models, enabling teams to detect high-risk modules earlier, automate quality checks, and optimize testing efforts in real-world industrial environments.

title: Hybrid Blockchain Model to Enhance Transparency and Data Privacy Protection for Employee Career Ladder
authors: Inayatulloh, Usman HM, Denok Sunarsi, Titin Suhartini, Nurjaya Nurjaya, Indra Kusumadi Hartono
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: A crucial aspect of the employee career ladder is data privacy, which guarantees the secure management of employee personal information in compliance with applicable regulations. Proper data management not only protects employees from potential misuse of information but also maintains the company's reputation. The system used for career ladders currently does not provide transparent information about employee ladders and does not guarantee the privacy of their data. So employees cannot have accurate information to file complaints if their careers are not targeted. The purpose of this research is to develop a hybrid blockchain model that integrates a private blockchain for storing employee privacy data and a public blockchain for the verification process and transaction storage. All nodes on the blockchain network will validate every transaction related to employee career ladders to ensure transparency and validation of information. The research method employs a qualitative approach that includes both a literature review and model simulation. According to the research, employee privacy data can be kept on a private blockchain network, and transactions can be checked by employees using a public blockchain. The conclusion is shown by a proposed model and a prototype built with Hyperledger Fabric.

title: Impact of NTN UE Deployment on Downlink Interference in TN/NTN Coexistence Scenarios
authors: Seungwoo Jo, Woncheol Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper examines the validity of the 1.5 km isolation distance between the terrestrial network (TN) cluster edge and the non-terrestrial networks (NTN) user terminal (UE) assumed in the 3GPP coexistence scenario. Monte Carlo simulations under LEO conditions show that coexistence is feasible at this distance, but deployments at the cluster edge or inside cause notable throughput degradation, indicating that the assumed distance may be overly conservative for LEO environments.

title: A Microwave Photonic Convolutional Accelerator With Increased Computational Efficiency
authors: Mahdi Chegini, Jianping Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A microwave photonic processor for convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with an increased effective speed of convolution was previously reported, but its system complexity remains a challenge. Here, we propose and experimentally demonstrate a novel microwave photonic convolutional accelerator (MWPCA) that maintains high-speed convolution performance while significantly simplifying the system architecture. Instead of using M modulators for an M×M kernel in our earlier approach, a single modulator is required, which greatly simplifies the system implementation. Experimental evaluation using the MNIST and Fashion MNIST datasets demonstrates that for a 2×2 kernel, the proposed simplified MWPCA achieves a twofold speed enhancement, delivering 102.4 giga operations per second (GOPS) processing capability.

title: AI Feels Time: Augmenting LLMs with a Bio-Inspired Temporal Cognitive Notebook : FLLM2025
authors: Naba Alghudran
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable linguistic capabilities but often struggle with complex, multi-step reasoning tasks. We hypothesize that this limitation stems, in part, from the absence of temporal cognition—the capacity to represent, track, and reason over time. Inspired by neuroscience, particularly the role of "time cells" in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex, we introduce the Temporal Cognitive Notebook (TCN): a novel architecture that integrates adaptive computation, temporally structured memory, and entropy-based metacognitive control. The TCN enables LLMs to dynamically allocate reasoning resources and monitor progress over time, promoting more patient and context-aware reasoning. Theoretical analyses and preliminary evaluations suggest that embedding temporal cognition could bridge a fundamental gap between human and artificial reasoning.

title: SpyderCrawl A Platform for Dark Web Bio-Hacking Market Intelligence
authors: Geetha C, Dharshini Sabari Saravanan, Fathimunisha A
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Dark Web is becoming a haven of offenders, who are hiding their criminal practices and identity using its ecosystem and cryptocurrencies due to anonymity and decentralization. The mix of coins and the growing use of privacy-saving tools also add to the problem of the financial and network transaction traceability. The experiments conducted before had targeted underground forums and markets, but due to the dynamic nature of the hidden services, such experiments normally pose challenges to the extent of reliability, scaling, and coverage. Considering these shortcomings, this paper covers SpyderCrawl a Dark Web Marketplace Intelligence Platform which collects bio-hacking and illicit trade information in bulk, divides and examines the information. The suggested model unveils, with the help of smart crawling of the key-words, organized data mining, and graphical dependency analysis, the latent relationships among different vendors, merchandise, and clusters of threats. To this end, SpyderCrawl is developed on a modular Python, Scrapy, and MongoDB architecture to be able to detect trends continuously and associate activities across several domains. The suggested system will help to raise the level of situational awareness of underground ecosystems and offer valuable insights in terms of threat intelligence, forensic analysis, and research on cybercrime prevention.

title: Parameter-Efficient Transfer Learning for DNN-based Channel Estimation: Adapter vs LoRA Comparison
authors: Joo Won Lee, Kae Won Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: With the increasing complexity of wireless communication systems, deep neural network (DNN) based channel estimation has become essential for 5G and beyond networks. However, adapting these models to different environments while maintaining parameter efficiency remains challenging. Due to the practical difficulties of collecting diverse real-world channel data across multiple environments—including cost, reproducibility, and privacy constraints—we utilize 3GPP-compliant channel models to systematically evaluate parameter-efficient transfer learning methods. This paper presents the first comprehensive comparison between Adapter and Low-Rank Adaptation (Lo-RA) methods for DNN-based channel estimation. We evaluate both approaches on Indoor Factory (InF) and Rural Macro (RMa) environments using transformer-based architectures at two parameter scales: initial efficient settings (20k vs 27k parameters) and scaled configurations (131k vs 133k parameters) for fair comparison. Our experimental results demonstrate that LoRA consistently achieves superior performance across both parameter scales, providing up to 1.97 dB NMSE improvement in challenging scenarios. The parameter scaling analysis reveals that while both methods benefit from increased capacity, LoRA maintains better efficiency and demonstrates superior adaptation to rural environments compared to indoor scenarios, likely due to the base model’s comprehensive multi-environment training. Additionally, cross-domain experiments using LoRA show consistent adaptability across diverse environment pairs. The lightweight nature of these methods enables real-time inference and deployment in O-RAN edge computing environments, providing crucial insights for industry practitioners seeking efficient model deployment in resource-constrained wireless systems.

title: Dental Professionals' Perspectives on Artificial Intelligence: A Survey of Adoption and Expectations
authors: Chintan Desai
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is rapidly emerging as a transformative force in healthcare, with significant potential to reshape dental practice. This study explores the perceptions, current utilization, and anticipated future trends of AI among dental professionals. Through a cross-sectional survey of 500 participants, including undergraduates, postgraduates, practitioners, and academicians, we investigate the awareness, acceptance, and integration of AI technologies in dentistry. The findings reveal notable group differences, such as limited familiarity among undergraduates (70 % not familiar) compared to higher recognition among academicians (33 % very familiar), with statistically significant variations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p; 0.05$</tex>). Attitudes also varied, with undergraduates showing higher comfort with AI tools, while postgraduates expressed greater skepticism. These insights highlight AI's potential to enhance diagnostic precision and treatment planning, while also emphasizing concerns regarding reliability, ethics, and training needs. By mapping these perspectives, this research informs strategies for effective implementation and supports the seamless integration of AI into clinical workflows to improve patient care.

title: Leveraging Advanced Data Analytics for Improved Extreme Weather Event Assessment and Mitigation
authors: P. Kaushik, Balajee Jeyakumar, Molla Khamar, Rizwan Arif, Vineet Kumar, Priya Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The study introduces an alternative method in which effectiveness can be significantly enhanced and it also addresses certain gaps that have been left by the past researches. Instead of looking at integrated methodologies, earlier studies often used individual analyses. It is the effective combination of GIS spatial analysis, numerical weather prediction models, historical data analysis, machine learning algorithms, and remote sensing technologies that improve the existing landscape. The proposed method is very efficient and Accurate with perfect prediction in terms of accuracy in both numerical models and machine learning. The output metrics include comprehensive thematic mapping, precise temperature prediction, and identifying of geographical risks. It is the overall and integrated nature of this study that makes it unique; it illuminates the extreme weather occurrences in subtle manner. The multi pronged approach assists in resilience by creating a more substantive base of assessment and aversion.

title: Extending gem5 for Accurate PCIe-Based Device Modeling in Heterogeneous Architectures
authors: Seunghyun Song, Junehyuk Boo, Yeongwoo Jang, Daye Jung, Jangwoo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The growing demand for heterogeneous computing in AI workloads has heightened the need for efficient CPU–accelerator communication. For this purpose, PCI Express (PCIe) has emerged as the dominant interconnect in recent systems. However, current architectural simulators provide limited support for accurate performance evaluation of PCIe devices. In this paper, we present a guideline to extend the gem5 simulator for arbitrary PCIe device integration. While gem5 is widely used for CPU simulation and architectural exploration, it only supports a limited set of PCI devices and lacks a standardized framework. By analyzing the mechanisms of gem5, particularly its support for AMD GPUs, we identify key components involved in communication: MMIO, DMA, and interrupts. Based on these insights, we propose a methodology for integrating arbitrary PCIe device simulators into gem5, enabling development of heterogeneous systems.

title: Adaptive Fuzzy Logic-Driven Predictive Analytics for Energy-Efficient Green Communication Networks
authors: Abdul Momen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: With the ever-growing population of interconnected devices and data traffic over next-generation networks, the need to have communication infrastructures that are sustainable and energy efficient is more than ever before. Green communication networks are a new paradigm of energy consumption with reduced performance and reliability in place of energy consumption. Still, it is a massive task to optimize energy consumption and guarantee adaptability in changing network environments in real-time. To address this issue, this study proposes an Adaptive Fuzzy Logic-Driven Predictive Analytics (AFL-PA) framework that is specially designed to enhance the energy efficiency of green communication networks. The proposed AFL-PA model optimizes routing, regulates transmission power, and dynamically balances network load in a synergy of predictive analytics and decision control based on fuzzy logic. The system is based on effective context-aware learning and real-time monitoring of traffic so as to predict any variation in energy consumption and take proactive measures in a network to minimize the power wastage without affecting the QoS. Simulated large-scale network tests indicate that AFL-PA is more energy efficient than traditional heuristic and static optimization techniques. Energy efficiency ranges from 70.8% to 90.1%, latency from 38.9 ms to 60.1 ms, throughput from 16.8 Mbps to 26.1 Mbps, and packet delivery ratio from 88.5% to 97.0%. The adaptive fuzzy inference process will ensure sound decision-making even in a non-linear and uncertain network environment. Lastly, allowing modern communication systems to be sustainable in the management of energy, the AFL-PA framework offers a smart, scaled, and selfoptimizing solution. This brings in smarter and stronger network infrastructures that are green-friendly.

title: MariAuth: Ultra Lightweight Mutual Authentication in NTN-assisted 6G Maritime Networks
authors: Aatif Suleman, Shabeer Ahmad, Umar Ajaib Khan, Ahmad Mustafa, Muhammad Asghar Khan, Arshad Saleem, Farhan Ullah, Sagheer Abbas, Zahid Ali Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) are a key component of the future sixth-generation (6 G) era. The integration of NTN networks with 6 G maritime networks is able to provide ubiquitous communication for connected vessels. In this study, we proposed an ultra-lightweight authentication scheme named MariAuth to secure communication between high-altitude platforms and the command and control station (GCS). We utilized physical unclonable functions (PUFs) to enhance the security features of MariAuth. Performance analysis demonstrated that the designed authentication scheme is ultra-lightweight compared to existing studies. The proposed MariAuth reduced the computational cost by 53.97% and 29.09%, which demonstrates the efficiency of the proposed work. An extended version of MariAuth, named Block-MariAuth, is in the design phase, in which we plan to integrate blockchain to enhance the security features of MariAuth. In the next study, we will also provide a detailed performance analysis of the proposed scheme.

title: Inner Sleeve Constriction for Remote Timed Payload Deployment in Vine Robots
authors: Johnathon Ciecierski, Guadalupe Bernal, Alejandro Alarcon Merchan, Sidney Nimako Boateng, Francesco Fuentes, Sicheng Wang, Laura H. Blumenschein, Melisa Orta Martinez, F. Zeynep Temel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Vine robots offer unique capabilities for navigating confined environments through growth via eversion, making them suitable for urban search and rescue operations. Prior research has demonstrated the potential of vine robots to deploy passive payloads or mobile agents for distributed mapping and exploration. However, existing deployment methods rely on passive delivery, pushing payloads toward the robot tip during growth, thus limiting control over deployment timing and location. In this work, we introduce a compact wireless gate mechanism designed to achieve controlled payload deployment within the vine robot. This mechanism operates by selectively constricting the vine’s inner sleeve, securely retaining payloads and releasing them upon receiving a remote command. Fully integrated into the robot’s structure, the gate allows unimpeded vine growth and supports wireless communication with an external mobile controller. Experiments with benchtop and integrated vine robots show that the gate remains co-located with the tip and enables on-command hold and release without impeding eversion. The gate supports sequential delivery of multiple payloads and can deploy irregular payloads by preparing specific accommodations. These results establish timed, location-accurate deployment for USAR scenarios while keeping vine robot hardware composition regular.

title: Digital Twin-Aided Fingerprinting for Device-Free RF Sensing
authors: Hiroto Somi, Norisato Suga
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a digital twin-aided devicefree indoor localization method that can be implemented with a single antenna. Conventional fingerprint-based localization methods require considerable effort to build a channel state information (CSI) dataset. A lack of sufficient data can lead to a degradation in positioning accuracy. To improve the efficiency and resolution of localization, we utilize a digital twin (DT) that mimics the real environment, enabling CSI acquisition on a finer reference position grid without physical constraints. In the proposed localization framework, CSI samples are collected from both the real environment and the DT. We also propose a linear transformation to align the virtual CSI with real measurements. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach improves localization accuracy while reducing the time and effort required for extensive offline data collection, highlighting the effectiveness of combining CSI-based fingerprinting with digital twin technology.

title: Large Language Model for 5G Network: Architecture and Research Trends
authors: Seongryool Wee, Heejae Park, Seungyeop Song, Laihyuk Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: 5G networks provide high-speed data transfer, ultra-low latency, and large-scale connectivity, making them suitable for a wide range of industrial applications. Despite these advantages, 5G networks face new challenges in network management and optimization due to the increasing complexity of heterogeneous network components, massive device connectivity, and dynamic service requirements. LLMs (Large Language Models) offer a promising approach to address these challenges due to their outstanding capabilities in language understanding and data processing. This paper reviews the latest applications of LLMs in 5G networks and specifically focuses on resource allocation, QoS (Quality of Service), anomaly detection, and automated network configuration. It analyzes research studies using models such as GPT-3.5, Llama2, and Mobile LLAMA and evaluates how LLMs contribute to maximizing efficiency and performance in 5G environments.

title: Coupled End-to-End Transfer Learning with Generalized Fisher Information
authors: Vineet Shrivastava, Nidhi Malhotra, Chhaya Sharma, Akash Goel, Manshee Agarwal, Isha Gupta
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: For vision tasks, deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are only effective when there are enough data, which may be hard to get or very expensive. Although transfer learning offers some hope through knowledge transfer from similar domains; nevertheless, it is prone to domain adaptation gaps and catastrophic interference while being applied on unrelated data distributions. In this paper, we propose a Coupled End-to-End Transfer Learning (CETL) framework that directly couples source and target CNNs through a shared decoder, enabling bidirectional knowledge transfer while preserving task-specific specialization. A generalization bound that links target error to source performance and coupling strength theoretically justifies the introduction of a novel coupled loss function. We use Generalized Fisher Information (GFI), which dynamically distributes weights among tasks to prevent catastrophic forgetting, to further stabilize optimization. Extensive research on MNIST, USPS, SVHN, CIFAR-10/100, STL-10, and ImageNet subsets are examples of benchmark datasets that show that CETL attains outstanding results in domain adaptation, knowledge distillation, and transfer learning. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness and adaptability of CETL as a framework for practical transfer learning applications.

title: Thermal-Stability-Optimized SoC Design Algorithm for MEMS-Driven Biomedical Wearable Sensor Systems
authors: Md. Aminul Islam, Shailendra Shah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The increased need for smart biomediacl wearable sensors. integrated Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) sensors poses increased challenges to System-on-Chip (SoC) architectures within varying temperature gradients. Within these small enclosed systems, thermal variations cause drifts in sensor readings, degrade signal quality, and impair energy utilization. Consequently, systems lose their long-term operational dependability posing a challenge to their incorporation in biomedical wearable sensors. This paper addresses these concerns and proposes a Hybrid Thermal Equilibrium and Predictive Reconfiguration Algorithm (HTEPRA) which is a newly designed SoC aimed at optimized thermal stability within MEMS biomedical wearable sensors. While standard approaches employ static control at each level, HTEPRA innovatively integrates a control dual layered system comprising a predictive-thermal controller based on machine learning algorithms, coupled disposal hardware freedoms, and thermal override control switches. The predictive controller uses real-time readings and historical data to create and adjust thermal profiles. The controller coupled with disposal hardware freedoms dynamically recalibrates and reconfigures the computational loads to maintain thermal equilibrium. HTEPRA performs better than existing thermal-aware SoC methods with 35% lower thermal drift, 25% higher energy efficiency, and 18% higher sensing accuracy on a custom built MEMS-biology platform. This hybrid has operational stability without real time degrade, responsiveness, or miniature volume loss.

title: A Rank-Aware Retrieval Precision Modeling and Calculation Method for Retrieval Augmented Generation
authors: Binghao Liang, Chuangang Zhang, Mingming Yuan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is a key paradigm for enhancing the capability of Large Language Models (LLMs) in educational applications, such as intelligent tutoring systems and knowledge-based Q&A platforms. However, existing retrieval precision models often fail to adequately account for the ranking of retrieved knowledge, which critically influences the quality and factual consistency of educational content generated by LLMs. To address this gap, this paper proposes a Rank-aware Retrieval Precision Modeling and Calculation Method. We introduce the Weighted Context Precision (WCP) and its computationally efficient variant, Simplified Weighted Context Precision (SWCP), which incorporate rank-sensitive weighting and multi-level relevance scoring to better reflect the impact of retrieval ranking on educational content generation. A multi-agent experimental environment, including a virtual educational data generation system and an LLM-based scoring framework, was designed to systematically evaluate the proposed models while mitigating the influence of LLMs' parametric knowledge. Experimental results demonstrate that SWCP achieves a significantly stronger correlation with LLMs response quality compared to traditional models like IDCP, reducing Mean Squared Error (MSE) by 61.8% and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) by 38.7% on average. The proposed method provides a practical, automated evaluation tool for optimizing retrieval and re-ranking strategies in educational RAG systems, thereby enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of knowledge delivery in digital learning environments.

title: Contextual Attention-Driven Transformer Model for Precision Analysis of Age-Specific Chest Compression Dynamics in CPR
authors: Chetana Krishnan, Vijay Jeyakumar
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: We present a Contextual Attention-Driven (CAD) Transformer model for precision analysis of age-specific chest compression dynamics in CPR. Using a synthetically generated dataset based on a viscoelastic mass-spring-damper system and Multisim simulations, we modeled thoracic stiffness, damping, and hysteresis across five manikin types. The CAD Transformer leverages temporal context and attention mechanisms to model compression sequences, outperforming traditional models including Kelvin-Voigt, Maxwell, and CNN baselines. Quantitatively, the model reduced stiffness estimation RMSE by up to 60 % and achieved force prediction errors under 5N. Simulink-based validation confirmed alignment with physical behavior, yielding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>0.92$</tex> Pearson correlation and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5 ~\text{mm}$</tex> MAE. Attention maps revealed the model's ability to detect fatiguerelated shifts across sequences. The CAD framework achieved over 92 % accuracy in age group classification and demonstrated interpretability through attention visualization. These results underscore the model's potential for real-time feedback in CPR training and personalized resuscitation systems.

title: Language Model Guided Reinforcement Learning in Quantitative Trading
authors: Adam Darmanin, Vince Vella
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Algorithmic trading requires short-term tactical decisions consistent with long-term financial objectives. Reinforcement Learning (RL) has been applied to such problems, but adoption is limited by myopic behaviour and opaque policies. Large Language Models (LLMs) offer complementary strategic reasoning and multi-modal signal interpretation when guided by well-structured prompts.This paper proposes a hybrid framework in which LLMs generate high-level trading strategies to guide RL agents. We evaluate (i) the economic rationale of LLM-generated strategies through expert review, and (ii) the performance of LLM-guided agents against unguided RL baselines using Sharpe Ratio (SR) and Maximum Drawdown (MDD).Empirical results indicate that LLM guidance improves both return and risk metrics relative to standard RL.

title: Real-World Deployment of an LLM-Enabled Voice-Commanded UGV for Logistics in SAR Missions
authors: Alejandro Jarabo-Peñas, Juan Bravo-Arrabal, Da-Hui Lin-Yang, Francisco Pastor, Robert Ladig, Juan Jesús Fernández-Lozano, Anders Lyhne Christensen, Alfonso García-Cerezo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: This paper presents a robotics framework to support emergency entities, integrating a large language model-based multi-agent system (LLM-MAS) to manage the movements of uncrewed ground vehicles (UGVs) in search and rescue (SAR) operations. The system allows operators without robotics expertise to issue natural language voice commands to autonomous UGVs, ensuring their safe and context-aware navigation based on real-time mission data. The proposed ROS 2-based communication architecture integrates UGVs into existing SAR command hierarchies, featuring robust methods for message acknowledgment, prioritization, and operational window synchronization that enable effective coordination between human teams and autonomous robots. During the XIX Workshop on Security, Emergencies, and Catastrophes (Málaga, Spain), over 150 first responders participated in six parallel SAR missions, with some teams providing their real-time positional data via equipment-integrated sensors. The LLM-MAS used this data to make autonomous decisions on the ground, such as determining which SAR team the UGV should assist, and then sent the selected target location to an external path planner through a tool call. The planner generated a route to the target, which the UGV followed while its movements were monitored in real time through a web interface. The system successfully executed material transport tasks across three critical service routes that supported the six parallel missions. Direct feedback from first responders confirmed that our system improved mission efficiency and was praised for its intuitive, responsive performance in coordinated decision-making.

title: Investigating the Effects of Negative Sampling in Knowledge Graph Completion
authors: Sooho Moon, Yunyong Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) are powerful tools for representing structured knowledge, but their incompleteness limits the effectiveness in real-world applications. Knowledge graph completion (KGC) addresses this issue effectively, with negative sampling (NS) playing a crucial role in training KGC models. However, the impact of NS has not been systematically explored. In this paper, we investigate how the number of negative triples per positive triple affects the performance of KGC models. Experiments on four state-of-the-art models reveal the following findings: (1) NS consistently improves performance; (2) the performance gain diminishes as more negatives are used, with excessive negatives sometimes degrading model performance; and (3) sensitivity varies across KGC models, indicating that the optimal number of negatives is model-dependent. These insights provide practical guidance for designing more effective negative sampling strategies in KGC.

title: Efficient Modality Fusion Framework for Driver Cognitive Load Classification
authors: Sumin Park, Sungjun Wang, Chi Yoon Jeong
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Accurate estimation of drivers’ cognitive load is essential for ensuring driving safety and performance. Although unimodal physiological signals, such as EEG or ECG, are widely used, they often provide limited information, leading to suboptimal classification performance. To address this limitation, we proposed an efficient modality fusion framework that leverages multimodal physiological signals for cognitive load classification. The framework can extract features from EEG and ECG signals using parallel 1D convolutional layers and ResNet-Style blocks, followed by self-attention to refine intramodality dependencies and cross-attention to capture complementary inter-modality interactions. Experiments on the CL-Drive public benchmark dataset evaluated the framework’s performance under both binary and ternary classification settings, using 10-fold cross-validation and leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) protocols. The proposed framework consistently outperformed conventional machine learning models and state-of-the-art deep learning approaches, achieving accuracies of 85.69% (10-fold CV) and 76.26% (LOSO) for binary classification, and 78.79% (10-fold CV) and 63.68% (LOSO) for ternary classification. These results highlight the importance of attention-based multimodal fusion for robust cognitive load estimation, suggesting its strong potential for applications in intelligent transportation systems and brain–computer interface development.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Predictive Analysis of Medical Images Using Hybrid Deep Learning
authors: Gyanender Kumar, Sonia Choudhary, Bhawna Goel, Deepak Kumar, Subhash
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Recent years have seen substantial progress in the medical services business, propelled by the merger of emerging technologies. Healthcare data has been stored and controlled by centralized systems, such as EHR systems managed by healthcare providers. With the advent of digital imaging technologies, the transmission of medical images has become essential for sharing diagnostic information among healthcare professionals. The research focuses on developing a cognitive blockchain framework for predicting chronic diseases and secure storage of the prediction information. The Hybrid deep learning algorithm is developed for prediction and is suitable for the blockchain environment. The efficiency of this framework is validated based on 96.9% accuracy, 96.45% specificity, 96.85% sensitivity and the model building time takes about an average of 1.9 sec. The merit of this developed framework is its less complexity and less overfitting issues. But this framework struggles with numerous feature inputs that affect stability.

title: Adaptive PDCP Duplication for Reliability Enhancement
authors: Jun-Sik Kim, Soon-Gi Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Conventional PDCP duplication mechanisms ensure high reliability through simultaneous packet transmission across multiple paths; however, this approach introduces substantial overhead during stable channel conditions or when services do not require ultra-high reliability guarantees. To overcome these limitations, this paper introduces an innovative Adaptive PDCP Duplication framework that intelligently enables or disables packet duplication based on real-time network conditions and service-specific requirements. Our proposed mechanism dynamically optimizes the trade-off between reliability enhancement and spectral efficiency, thereby achieving superior performance compared to static duplication approaches.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Agv Path Planning Method
authors: Zhen Sun, Zheng Du, Hanwen Chen, Hao Qin, Qisen Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This study proposes a path planning method that integrates deep reinforcement learning and Petri net constraints for conflict prevention and efficiency optimization of AGV dynamic path planning in storage environments. By constructing a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework with “path branching points as agents”, road network intersection nodes are defined as independent agents, equipped with a symmetric Actor Critic network structure, and combined with an improved multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient (MADDPG) algorithm and posterior experience replay (HER) strategy, collaborative decision-making in dynamic environments is achieved. Design a three-layer multiobjective reward function that integrates basic task completion, multi vehicle collaboration constraints, and business efficiency indicators. Implement conflict pre detection through Petri net library transition mechanism. In a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${1 0} \boldsymbol{\times} {1 0}$</tex> grid environment, the average task completion time is reduced by 41.7 % compared to traditional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}^{*}$</tex> algorithm, the collision rate is reduced by 85.7 %, and the task success rate remains at 92.3 % in a 20 AGV collaborative scenario. The experiment shows that this method effectively balances the security and efficiency of path planning through the coupling of Petri net logic constraints and deep reinforcement learning. In the future, Kalman filtering will be introduced to optimize state observation and explore the application of attention mechanisms in multi-agent communication.

title: Time-Frequency Analysis of Complex THz-Bandwidth Waveforms using Linear Microwave Photonic Processing
authors: Geunweon Lim, Benjamin Crockett, Majid Goodarzi, José Azaña
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We propose a microwave photonics-based linear processing method for joint time-frequency analysis over broad bandwidths by mapping the waveform’s sonogram along the frequency axis. We experimentally demonstrate picosecond-resolution analysis of sophisticated optical waveforms extending over a 5-THz bandwidth and a 3-ns temporal duration.

title: Multistage Real-time Violence Detection using Convolutional Neural Network and Long Short-term Memory
authors: Manh Dung Nguyen, Soonghwan Ro
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Action recognition is a challenging research topic in the field of computer vision, with numerous practical applications, including violence detection. Early detection of violent behavior enables timely intervention, helping to prevent or minimize the damage caused by such incidents.In this paper, we present a multi-stage method for violence detection. In the first stage, groups at high risk of violence are detected using YOLO, the Deep SORT object tracking algorithm, and a 2D CNN image classification model. In the second stage, entropy-based features are employed to eliminate non-violent objects that visually resemble violent ones. In the final stage, 2D features of the remaining groups are extracted using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and then fed into a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network to determine whether the group is engaged in violent or normal activity.Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to previous studies, the proposed method not only achieves effective detection of violent behavior but also reduces false positives, delivering strong performance suitable for real-world applications

title: Asynchronous Federated Learning for Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Giwon Sur, Seunghyun Yoon, Hyuk Lim Korea
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative training of intrusion detection systems (IDSs) without exposing raw network traffic. However, synchronous FL is limited by straggler effects, where slower clients cause idle time and reduce overall efficiency. We present an asynchronous FL (AFL) IDS that updates the global model as client updates arrive while explicitly mitigating stale updates. The server applies a selective aggregation rule that retains only the informative portion of each delayed update and discards components already reflected in the current global model. This stabilizes learning under heterogeneous clients and non-IID traffic while preserving data locality, making AFL a practical approach for privacy-preserving IDS.

title: Project CERBERUS: Development of A Dual-Mode Mobile Robot for Urban CBR Emergency Remediation Operations
authors: David Megson-Smith, Tom Bennett, Vidar Marsh, Samuel Fearn, Yannick Verbelen, Sofia Leadbetter, Tom Scott
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Urban decontamination tasks are hazardous, complex, and time-critical, often requiring human intervention in environments with diverse geometry and unpredictable conditions. This work presents CERBERUS (Collaborative Emergency Response for Biohazard Environmental Remediation via Uncrewed Systems), a novel, field-tested multirobot platform that integrates an uncrewed ground vehicle (UGV), uncrewed aerial system (UAS), and a robotic manipulator to deliver spray-based decontamination and surface sampling across multi-elevation urban environments. Designed for modularity and robustness, CERBERUS combines high payload capacity, extended operational time, and precise surface interaction through coordinated control of its ground and aerial subsystems. A custom-built spraying and sampling system enables decontamination across complex geometries, from kerbs and door handles to rooftops and overhangs. Field trials conducted in a full-scale urban training compound demonstrated the system’s ability to navigate obstacles and challenging terrain, apply decontaminant in varied modes, and collect environmental swabs. The results highlight both the feasibility and the challenges of deploying multi-modal autonomous systems in high-consequence environments. This paper outlines the technical architecture, field performance, and future development roadmap towards greater autonomy and operational resilience for deployment in civil protection and national recovery scenarios.

title: PureTrack-IR: Blockchain-Enabled Infrared Imaging Agent AI-UAV System for Military Tracking
authors: Sium Bin Noor, Adnan Md Tayeb, Mohtasin Golam, Subroto Kumar Ghosh, Muhammad Sannan Khaliq, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent military UAV surveillance systems struggle in low visibility and challenging operational environments because they rely on visible light sensors, centralized data storage, and human-in-the-loop decision making. This paper introduces PureTrack-IR, a decentralized framework that integrates infrared (IR) imaging, edge optimized object detection, autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) control, and Pure Chain-enabled data management system. Thermal cameras first capture IR images, which are then denoised, aligned, and resized before being processed by an 8-bit–quantized YOLOv11x model on NVIDIA Jetson hardware. This model accurately detects hostile military personnel in darkness, smoke, and adverse weather. The detection outputs are georeferenced and passed to an Agent AI module that uses reinforcement learning for real time threat detection, prioritization, and mission adaptation, thereby reducing operator workload and response time. At the same time, every image, detection, and AI decision is immutably recorded on Pure Chain, a lightweight blockchain employing Smart Auto Mining Plus(SAM+) and a Proof of Authority and Association (PoA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) consensus mechanism to secure peer-to-peer transactions in under three seconds. Performance evaluation confirms robust detection, low latency decision making, and tamper-proof data integrity. PureTrack-IR enhances situational awareness, operational security, and tactical effectiveness through state-of-the-art detection with 99.4% accuracy, providing a robust and autonomous solution for UAV-based hostile military tracking.

title: Predicting Trends Through Social Sentiment
authors: Rajesh Reddy Vuyyuru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Social media reflects real-time public sentiment, influencing industries like entertainment and finance. This study analyzes sentiment trends in user-generated content to assess their predictive value for market performance and consumer behavior. Using a lexicon-based sentiment analysis approach, we examine correlations between online discussions and real-world outcomes. Our findings highlight the complexities of sentiment-driven forecasting and its implications for opinion mining and trend analysis.

title: 23.7 fJ/Conv. Double-Tail Dynamic Comparator Design Using 180nm CMOS Technology
authors: Julie Roslita Rusli, Suhaidi Shafie, Wan Maziyah Ab Halim, Izanoordina Ahmad, Balqis Budiman, Roslina Mohd Sidek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: The performance of a Successive Approximation Register (SAR) ADC is critically influenced by the precision of its comparator, which is responsible for resolving the least significant bit (LSB) within stringent timing constraints. With continued scaling in nano-scale technologies, supply voltages are increasingly reduced to enhance dynamic energy efficiency. However, this reduction in voltage headroom poses significant design challenges for dynamic comparators, often driving transistors into the subthreshold regime and compromising accuracy. This work presents the design of an ultra-low power, high-precision dynamic comparator tailored to reliably resolve a 0.8 mV differential input under a 0.8 V supply. Targeting integration into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200 \text{kS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, 10-bit differential SAR ADC, the design is implemented using Silterra 180 nm CMOS technology, characterized by a threshold voltage (VTH) of approximately 0.4 V. The comparator architecture is optimized through careful transistor sizing to minimize bias currents and to operate with gate-source voltages (VGS) close to VTH value. Simulation results confirm that the comparator achieves accurate resolution of 0.8 mV input differences with an average power consumption of 47 nW and a Figure of Merit (FoM) of 23.7 fJ/conversion.

title: Advanced Techniques for Mitigating Power Supply Induced Jitter in Low-Cost, Multi-Lane, Multi-PHY Timing Controller Solutions in 8 nm FinFET
authors: Subhadeep Datta, Ankur Ghosh, A Santosh Kumar Reddy, Umamaheswara Reddy Katta, Manohar Seetharam, Byunghyun Lim, Jongjae Ryu, Goeun kim, Doohee Lim, Sachin Kashyap, Mohit Arora, Bhargavi SPH, Saikat Hazra, Sumanth Chakkirala, Avneesh Singh Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Semiconductor technology advancements have improved D-TVs' resolution and image quality, leading to an increase in image information. However, the larger size of the D-TV SoC causes a significant power coupling resonance effect resulting in challenges for power integrity. Merging multiple power domains offers cost-effectiveness but also presents challenges in terms of supply-noise induced jitter. To mitigate these challenges faced in the most vulnerable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 - 2 0 0 ~ M H z}$</tex> frequency range, a co-optimization approach is needed, which includes lowering board and package impedances and reducing the supply sensitivity of the PHY. This work focuses on reducing the supply sensitivity. A three-stage, nested-miller compensated, supply-referenced 1.8 V -to- 1.5 V LDO with high PSRR is used to shield the RO-VCO from accumulating the supply noise in the said frequency range. The proposed V-byOne TX-PLL PHY with full-rate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6-\text{GHz}, 1.8 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> IO-supply ROVCO was fabricated in 8 nm FinFET technology node and achieves a 50 % lower total jitter compared to its previous generation in presence of multi-lane, multi-PHYs with shared power supply domains. The proposed solution has successfully addressed the power-supply noise at product level.

title: Design of a Low Phase Noise Quadrature DCO Using Dual Superharmonic Injection in 55nm CMOS for Ka-Band Applications
authors: Devesh Bhaskaran, Shashidhar Tantry
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to mm-W quadrature differentially controlled dual superharmonic injected digitally controlled oscillator (QDCO). Dual-harmonic injection is adopted to reduce phase noise and improve spectral efficiency. The proposed oscillator supports a frequency range from 26.2 GHz to 32.5 GHz. The simulated results show cutting-edge results with phase noise around -125.38 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz and a jitter of 18.23 fs. This is accomplished with each oscillator core consuming only 5.96 mW of power, operating on a 1.2 V supply. These results thus confirm the QDCO has superior phase noise performance and frequency stability, which support its utilization for use in advanced wireless and radar applications with high performance low-jitter RF systems, requiring accurate timing and signal integrity.

title: A Synthetic Depth Map Creation Mechanism based on RGB images for Object Distance Estimation
authors: Jaehong Kim, Misbah Bibi, Muhammad Faseeh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The scarcity of annotated data remains a critical bottleneck in training robust computer vision models, particularly for depth-aware tasks such as object detection and object distance estimation. Manual annotation is both labor-intensive and error-prone, often leading to inconsistencies in ground truth data. To address this challenge, we present a synthetic depth maps creation mechanism based on procedurally generated RGB images. The proposed approach simulates diverse scenes by varying object placement, illumination, and camera parameters to produce photorealistic RGB data along with corresponding depth and distance maps. All generated outputs are stored in HDF5 format to ensure efficient data handling and large-scale usability. This mechanism enables the automatic generation of high-quality annotations, significantly reducing manual effort. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that models trained on the resulting synthetic dataset achieve strong performance in object detection and distance estimation tasks, highlighting the effectiveness of the proposed method in supporting depth-aware computer vision applications.

title: Hierarchical Structures in Human Networks Using a Graph Neural Network-based Unsupervised Learning Framework
authors: Yeri Gu, Jion Kim, Byeongkwan Woo, Myung-Sun Baek
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Cybercrime, characterized by anonymity and decentralized operations, presents major challenges in identifying suspects, uncovering hidden accomplice ties, and dismantling organizational structures. Traditional investigative methods often fail when explicit connections are absent, and early analytical approaches based on simple similarity metrics lead to significant information loss. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel unsupervised learning framework centered on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). Our approach begins by constructing a 3-layer heterogeneous graph that models entities as distinct node types: persons, cases, and identifiers (e.g., bank accounts, IP addresses), preserving the rich context of investigative data. The GNN then directly learns deep relational patterns from the graph's structure. This enables: (1) latent link prediction to uncover hidden relationships, (2) community detection on learned embeddings to identify criminal organizations, and (3) a comprehensive risk assessment that integrates network centrality with GNN-derived node importance scores. By effectively modeling the intrinsic complexity of the data, our framework provides investigators with objective, quantitative evidence to prioritize targets and enhance strategic decision-making.

title: Protecting Organizational Assets in the Digital Age: A Strategic Approach to Cybersecurity Risk Management
authors: Gajendran, Samaila Kasimu Ahmad, Ashwini Sonawane, Md Faisal Ahmed, Rv Meenakshy, Gudla Anjaneyulu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: In the digital age, the cybersecurity threat is rising, taking over infrastructure, operations, and sensitive information. It needs to manage cybersecurity risks in order to secure the organizational assets in case of cyberattacks, data breach, and other susceptibilities. In his paper the author mentions very important risk-reduction techniques such as threat intelligence, threat assessment models, encryption and access control systems. It also brings out the importance of machine learning (ML) in enhancing the threat detection and response capabilities. To ensure that their organizations are secure, they must implement a multi-layered security solution that is proactive and incorporates the most current security techniques as well as regulatory compliance and staff awareness of their organizations. In addition, regular security check, incident management and follow-up will help in the reduction of risk and business continuity. Threats on the internet have always been changing and to ensure that the networks are made more secure, organizations must continuously adjust to them with the assistance of the latest cybersecurity technologies. This study provides an understanding of the most effective ways of managing risks, which can be applied by organizations to develop strong security systems in a virtual world that is highly interconnected and risky.

title: Energy Savings Analysis of Automated Chilled Water Supply Pump Control in HPF Process
authors: Taehyung Kim, Jinsoo Han, Wan-Ki Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The Hot Press Forming (HPF) process is highly energy-intensive. While extensively researched, energy reduction in industrial HPF operations often relies on manual control. This study systematically analyzes operational data to find practical energy-saving opportunities. Based on this, we designed and implemented an automated control strategy for the Chilled Water Supply Pump (CWSP), a target selected for its high impact with minimal disruption to the operational workflow. A comparative analysis demonstrated that the automated system reduced the pump's energy use by approximately 51% and its Specific Energy Consumption (SEC) by approximately 60%. This study validates that field-data analysis can yield practical, empirically supported solutions for energy conservation, contributing to the sustainable operation of HPF processes.

title: Explainable and Privacy-Preserving Multi-Class Network Intrusion Detection Using SHAP and LightGBM
authors: Kunal Dudi, Mandeep Singh, Dhananjay Kumar, Naween Kumar, A Sharmila
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Modern IDS tools struggle to detect attacks well while still protecting user privacy and staying transparent. To meet this balance of competing demands, this paper proposed an explainable and Privacy-preserving IDS (PIDs) framework that combines lightGBM classifier optimized with an Optuna based hyperparameter search and SHAP-based feature attribution techniques with differential privacy mechanisms. The performance of this framework has been evaluated on the CICIDS2017 benchmark dataset with over 2.83 million instances and 79 features and has produced an F1 score of 0.894, indicating a good ability to classify multiple classes accurately. The model demonstrates an ability to withstand adversarial perturbations, maintaining its accuracy of 82 % at (ϵ = 0.1 (under the Fast Gradient Sign Method); thus, demonstrating robustness. Finally, this framework achieves a very high degree of trade-off between the privacy and utility of a differential privacy budget (91.2% accuracy at (ϵ = 1.0). The findings presented in this paper support the feasibility of creating robust, explainable, and compliant IDS systems that incorporate the principles of privacy protection and cybersecurity as they relate to modern data protection standards.

title: On the Impact of Training Mismatch in Deep-Learning-Based Channel Denoising
authors: Sungyoung Ha, Yo-Seb Jeon
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: To further improve the accuracy of channel estimation in multiple-input multiple-output orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (MIMO-OFDM) systems, we study deep-learning (DL)-based channel denoising. We train a denoising neural network offline on simulated realizations from a single baseline channel scenario and evaluate the pre-trained model—without adaptation—across multiple online deployment environments. When the deployment environment aligns with the training scenario, the denoiser provides the strongest gains; however, under distribution shift (e.g., differing delay/Doppler characteristics or signal-to-noise ratio regimes), estimation accuracy degrades, revealing limited cross-scenario generalization. These findings highlight the sensitivity of DL-based denoising to channel mismatch and motivate further investigation into online robustness to sustain performance in dynamic wireless settings.

title: 1Tb/s Intradyne Coherent Receiver for Optical Fiber Transmission over 100km
authors: Jong-Hoi Kim, Young-Tak Han, Seo-Young Lee, Shin-Mo An, Won-Seok Han, Jang-Uk Shin, Sang-Ho Park, Dong-Hoon Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Intradyne coherent receivers that incorporate hybrid integration of InP-based high-speed waveguide photodiode array chips and polarization multiplexed optical hybrids for coherent detection have been implemented, achieving 1 Tb/s optical fiber transmission over a distance of 100 km.

title: A Deep Learning-Powered IoT Architecture for Student Performance Assessment Using RFID
authors: Jayanthi Muthuswamy, A Parvathy, C.N. Savithri, Chanda V Reddy, P. Malathi, Darren Samuel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The classification of student performance using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) data is crucial research area. While Adaptive Linear Regression Classification (ALRC) has demonstrated superior accuracy over other classifiers, it requires extensive data pre-processing and feature selection. To overcome these limitations, this study investigates a Deep Neural Network (DNN)-based classification approach that eliminates the need for data pre-processing and feature selection. Two deep learning architectures-Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-are implemented in MATLAB to classify RFID data and support grade-based learning. The models are evaluated based on accuracy and loss function metrics to determine the most effective classification approach. Experimental results indicate that the LSTM model outperforms CNN in classifying RFID data for student performance evaluation. The finding suggest that LSTM is the most suitable choice for student performance classification, offering improved accuracy while reducing the need of extensive data preprocessing.

title: Formal Analysis of the Munilla Authentication Protocol Using ProVerif
authors: Rohiqi Maghtum Imama, Nadia Paramita Retno Adiati, Nia Yulianti, Yeni Farida
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) technology is widely used in various sectors such as logistics, transportation, and digital payment systems. However, due to its wireless nature, this technology is vulnerable to various security threats, including eavesdropping, message modification, and multiplexing attacks. To address these challenges, Munilla et al. (2020) proposed a 5G-Compliant Authentication Protocol for RFID, which is claimed to be able to withstand passive, active, and replay attacks. However, this claim is based only on informal analysis without formal proof. In this study, a formal analysis of Munilla's protocol was conducted using ProVerif, a symbolic verification tool based on applied pi-calculus used for security protocol analysis. The verification results indicate potential key leaks, message modification, and failure of certain property authentication. To address these weaknesses, an improved scheme is proposed by adding an HMAC function and refining the KSEAF derivation process. The results of the reanalysis using ProVerif indicate that the improved scheme can improve the level of security and resilience to attacks.

title: How Dare You Refuse Me? How and When AI Negative Hiring Decision Influences Applicants' Reactions_supp2-3665195.docx
authors: Xinyi Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Despite the growing attention given to applicants' reactions to the utilization of artificial intelligence (AI) within organizational recruitment contexts, scholars have paid little attention to the emotional mechanism between AI decision-making (especially negative) and applicants' procedural justice perception, as well as how the perception affects their subsequent behavior. Drawing on the cognitive–functional model of discrete negative emotions, we propose and empirically test the effect of anger triggered by AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' procedural justice perception and complaint behavior. General support for the model testing is obtained from two studies, namely, a laboratory experiment (N = 97) that uses technology for facial expression analysis (i.e., Face Reader 8.0) and an online scenario-based experiment (N = 270). The rigor of our findings is enhanced by collecting data from multiple participant sources, using FaceReader and self-reports in a complementary manner to measure anger, and by introducing control variables for robustness checks. We find that AI-driven negative decisions, rather than human-driven ones, elicit greater anger from applicants. Notably, this effect is weakened for applicants with extensive prior AI experience. Moreover, anger suppresses applicants' perceptions of procedural justice, thus yielding a distinct effect on their complaint behavior. Our study contributes to the understanding of the effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' emotional, cognitive, and behavioral reactions. It also sheds light on the influence of applicants' prior AI experience in reducing the negative effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' subsequent responses.
