title: A Context-Aware Service Recommendation System for the Social Internet of Things
authors: Amar Khelloufi, Huansheng Ning, Guan Mingxiang, Muhammad Sadiq, Sahraoui Dhelim
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Areas in Sensors
abstract: The Social Internet of Things (SIoT) refers to the interconnection of Internet of Things (IoT) devices with the addition of a social layer, enabling them to mimic human like behavior. This technology facet facilitates data and service sharing among devices, creating a scalable network of socially interconnected devices. However, this rapid increase in device numbers and generated data has led to the challenge of data explosion. To address this challenge, service recommendation systems play a crucial role in improving network navigability and service discovery within the SIoT context. However, existing research often overlooks important aspects that could make service selection more pertinent and relevant. Specifically, current service recommendation approaches focus on extracting social relationships between devices while neglecting the contextual presentation of service reviews. In this research, we introduce a service recommendation framework for SIoT context that integrates service-review aggregation and feature learning processes by utilizing the Factorization Machines to capture complex feature interactions unique to each SIoT device-service pair. Empirical results across three benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed CASR-SIoT framework consistently outperforms state of-the-art baselines, achieving up to 14% improvement in Recall, 8%inPrecision, and 15% reduction in RMSE, thereby validating its effectiveness in delivering accurate and context-aware service recommendations in SIoT environments.

title: Optimal Model Selection For k-Nearest Neighbours Ensemble with Feature Weighting and random projection
authors: Naz Gul, Muhammad Aamir, Dost Muhammad Khan, Muhammad Hamraz
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: High-dimensional datasets pose several challenges for classification algorithms, such as redundancy and noise.Various dimensional reduction procedures have been proposed in the literature, aiming at overcoming these challenges. Random Projection is one of such dimension reduction techniques that reduces dimensionality without discarding any feature from the original space. Inspired by this approach, the proposed work uses randomly projected bootstrap samples to construct base kNN models, utilizing feature weighting scheme in the distance formula. The feature weights are computed via support vectors and incorporated into the distance calculations for neighborhood identification. This is how a large number of base learners are built and their respective out-of-bag errors have also been calculated. A portion of the top ranked models are chosen on the basis of out-of-bag errors and combined to create the final ensemble. The novel method is assessed on 14 benchmark datasets taken from the openML repository. A comparison of the newly proposed method with other on the shelve classifiers demonstrates improved classification accuracy in majority cases. The novel approach is further examined for different values of the nearest neighbors k. Boxplots of the novel method and the other methods have also been constructed for further illustration.

title: Directly from Alpha to Omega: Controllable End-to-End Vector Floor Plan Generation_supp1-3665422.pdf
authors: Shidong Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Automated floor plan generation aims to create residential layouts by arranging rooms within a given boundary, balancing topological, geometric, and aesthetic considerations. The existing methods typically use a multi-step pipeline with intermediate representations to decompose the prediction process into several sub-tasks, limiting model flexibility and imposing predefined solution paths. This often results in unreasonable outputs when applied to data unsuitable for these predefined paths, making it challenging for these methods to match human designers, who do not restrict themselves to a specific set of design workflows. To address these limitations, we introduce CE2EPlan, a controllable end-to-end topology- and geometryenhanced diffusion model, that removes restrictions on the generative process of AI design tools. Instead, it enables the model to learn how to design floor plans directly from data, capturing a wide range of solution paths from input boundaries to complete layouts. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method surpasses all existing approaches using the multi-step pipeline, delivering higher-quality results with enhanced user control and greater diversity in output, bringing AI design tools closer to the versatility of human designers.

title: Fourier Decomposition-based Phase Processing Technique: A Novel Approach for One-dimensional Phase Unwrapping
authors: Chenghao Lu, Donglin Li, Hengyi Jia, Taoli Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The performance of coherence analysis system (CAS) is critically dependent on phase accuracy. Most advanced phase unwrapping (PU) algorithms are designed for two-dimensional (2D) problem, but data from various interferometric systems are typically acquired as one-dimensional (1D) time series. The 1D PU problem is more challenging since it suffers more seriously from noise and the available adjacent points are severely restricted compared to the 2D case. To address the prevalent challenge of 1D phase noise with a skewed non-zero-mean distribution, this paper introduces a novel fourier decomposition-based phase-processing technique (FDPT). The FDPT procedure begins with a fast fourier transform (FFT) of the original noisy phase signal. The frequency spectrums of them are then divided into sub-bands, which undergo a flatness evaluation to identify and extract the dominant frequency components. The inverse FFT (IFFT) is applied to each phase component, converting them back for individual processing using the adaptive non-local (NL) filtering algorithm. Finally, the sub-phase components are coherently summed, and followed by PU methods to reconstruct the phase. Simulation results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed FDPT over conventional methods, confirming improvements in waveform similarity and a reduction in root mean square error.

title: TCPFMC: Trustworthy Cyclic Progressive Fusion for Multimodal Classification
authors: Ao Li, Dehua Miao, Tianyu Gao, Sanlin Mei, Fengwei Gu, Chen Chen, Aichen Wang, Haoyi Fan, Xinwang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: The exponential growth of multimodal data has facilitated significant advances in multimodal classification techniques. Most multimodal classification algorithms aggregate information from different modalities into a unified representation to capture the holistic information. However, existing fusion mechanisms overly rely on high-quality data, which compromises the robustness of the model. Meanwhile, the fusion process can cause the loss of modality-specific information due to inherent modality differences. In this work, we propose a trustworthy cyclic progressive fusion method for multimodal classification, named TCPFMC. To enhance robustness and reduce reliance on high-quality data, we designed a modality energy score to evaluate the confidence of each modality, quantifying the informativeness of the modalities. In addition, for efficient integration of modality-specific information, we propose a novel cyclic progressive fusion approach that combines modality information at a fine-grained level, enhancing the overall performance of the model. Extensive experiments on six multimodal datasets show that TCPFMC outperforms state-of-the-art methods. The original code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/aoli-hrbust/TCPFMC</uri>

title: Practical Prescribed-Time Cooperative Path Following of Underactuated Multi-ASVs Without Velocity Measurements via Intermittent Control
authors: Jian Liu, Huiming Yang, Jun Liu, Yongbao Wu, Changyin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: In this article, the problem of practical prescribed-time (PT) cooperative path following (CPF) is investigated for underactuated autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs), which are not equipped with velocity sensors and subject to unmodeled dynamics and actuator saturation. First, a practical PT velocity observer (PTVO) is designed to estimate unmeasurable velocity information, which is then employed in the design of the guidance law and controller. At the kinematic level, a cooperative guidance law based on aperiodic intermittent communication is developed for synchronized path following, effectively saving communication resources. At the dynamic level, an aperiodic intermittent controller incorporating neural networks (NNs) is designed to approximate unmodeled dynamics and effectively avoid continuous operation of actuators with input saturation. Meanwhile, the intermittent adaptive law is constructed to estimate the optimal weights of the NNs, thereby reducing their complexity. The closed-loop system is verified to converge to a residual set within a PT interval. Finally, we conduct numerical simulations to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

title: Hands-Free Mobility Control: A Low-Latency Asynchronous MI-BCI System for Real-Time Robotic Navigation With Cognitive-Ergonomic Enhancement_supp1-3659708.docx
authors: Xia Wu
publish: N/A
abstract: Individuals with severe motor impairments face significant challenges operating conventional interfaces due to reliance on physical movement. While brain–computer interfaces (BCIs) offer alternative control pathways, traditional paradigms (SSVEP/P300) suffer from stimulus dependency, high latency, and cognitive fatigue, limiting real-world deployment. This study presents a novel asynchronous motor imagery-BCI system for hands-free robotic platform navigation, integrating cognitive ergonomics principles to enhance operator experience. We developed an intuitive four-command control paradigm using a cascaded classifier architecture, eliminating dependence on external triggers. Key innovations include: 1) sub-100 ms ultralow-latency pipeline via hybrid feature fusion and ensemble learning; 2) stimulus-independent operation leveraging endogenous sensorimotor cortex activation (μ/β-band); and 3) cognitive load-optimized interaction with ROS-based neurofeedback and NASA-TLX-validated ergonomic design. Evaluated on BCI Competition IV 2a dataset (nine subjects) and self-collected high-resolution electroencephalography data (seven subjects), the system achieved 72.15% offline classification accuracy and 95.36% online command execution success rate with 97ms mean computational latency. NASA-TLX evaluation revealed a 32% reduction in cognitive workload compared to synchronous paradigms. This work establishes a framework for cognitively enhanced mobility assistance, advancing practical brain-controlled assistive technologies.

title: FLARE: Efficient Distributed Large-Scale Graph Neural Networks Training With Adaptive Latency-Aware Probabilistic Caching_supp1-3660379.pdf
authors: Young-Koo Lee
publish: N/A
abstract: Since the emergence of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), researchers have extensively investigated training on large-scale GNN training because of their success and wide usage in various domains including biological networks, finance, and recommendation systems. This work focuses on training large-scale distributed GNNs, where partitioning massive graphs across multiple machines creates remote communication overhead that becomes a major scalability bottleneck. We introduce a policy-driven caching mechanism that prioritizes node features and embeddings based on access frequency and cross-partition fetch cost, significantly minimizing communication overhead without sacrificing accuracy. Our policies are based on analysis of Node Affinities (NAFs) during multi-hop neighborhood sampling that extend substantially beyond the graph partition boundaries. Analyzing NAFs not only alleviates the communication bottleneck but also provides a systematic mechanism to manage in-memory data effectively, prioritizing GPU storage for node features with high fetch latency. We present FLARE, a system designed to handle partitioned feature data while leveraging the NAF-based caching policy. FLARE substantially reduces both communication overhead and training convergence time. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets show that training FLARE on a three-layer GCN, GAT, and GraphSAGE across eight GPU machines achieves up to 12.04× (8.12× on average) speedup over DistDGLv2, demonstrating substantial performance gains compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Unsupervised Domain Adaptive Object Detection via Semantic Consistency and Compactness Learning
authors: Yajing Liu, Zhen Zhang, Yiming Su, Chunhui Hao, Xiyao Liu, Jiandong Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Unsupervised domain adaptive object detection methods enhance model robustness in the target domain without requiring target-domain annotations. Despite notable progress, existing methods face two major challenges: 1) insufficient and inefficient learning of holistic feature consistency due to cumbersome pixel-level style matching and semantic discrepancy elimination between domains as well as the overlooking of their collaborative effect, and 2) unreliable learning of category feature compactness caused by poor-quality target-domain samples, inaccurate pseudo-labels and noisy cross-domain contrast paradigms. To address these challenges, we propose a novel Semantic Consistency and Compactness Learning (SCCL) network. For consistency learning, we introduce a Visual Adaptation-guided Semantic Alignment (VSA) module that achieves style matching through simple feature adaptation and incorporates a novel adversarial-free self-supervised method for feature disentanglement. The collaboration between these two aspects enables sufficient and efficient consistency learning. For reliable compactness learning, we develop a plug-and-play Instance Center-Contrastive (ICC) head that, for the first time, comprehensively addresses all three potential causes of unreliable learning through three integrated innovations, concerning sample pseudo-label quality enhancement, reliable sample storage and updating, and a robust sample contrast paradigm. Besides, the mutual reinforcement effect of VSA and ICC simultaneously enhances feature transferability and discriminability. Extensive experiments across four UDA object detection benchmarks with two baselines show that SCCL achieves superior adaptability and robustness.

title: A Multi-Task Deep Learning Framework for Cooperative Optimization of Spectral Data Classification and Reconstruction
authors: Yuanyuan Xiang

title: Improving Edge-Case Reasoning in GPT-4.1 through Adaptive Fine-Tuning and Context-Aware Prompt Engineering
authors: T. Ratha Jeyalakshmi, Smitha GV, Hrudai Kumar K, Ijaz Ahmad S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper presents RECAP (Reasoning Enhancement through Context-Aware Prompting), a dual-strategy framework that combines sophisticated prompt engineering techniques that restructure inputs to emphasize disambiguation, analogical examples, and counterfactual reasoning, and parameter-efficient fine-tuning using synthetic edge-case datasets tailored to particular domains in order to address this shortcoming. Over the GPT-4.1 API, RECAP functions as a thin, modular layer that allows for enhancements without changing the foundational model. Comprehensive tests on five domain-specific benchmarks show that RECAP greatly increases the interpretability of generated outputs, lowers the rate of contradiction, and improves logical consistency. In addition to offering a methodological contribution, this paper offers a useful road map for implementing LLMs in delicate, high-stakes situations.

title: Exploratory Analysis of Browser Fingerprint in Online Anonymity Internet Browser, Proxy, VPN, and TOR
authors: Bimo Setyo Husodo, Jeckson Sidabutar, Setiyo Cahyono, Amiruddin Amiruddin, Stefanus Santori Zen
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: In the era of information technology, third-party trackers are commonly used by website owners for personalization and advertising, but they also threaten the privacy of internet users by recording browsing and device information This tracking utilizes browser fingerprinting, which is a unique pattern of information that is difficult for users to control. This study conducted an exploratory analysis to evaluate the effectiveness of four commonly used online anonymity techniques such as internet browser incognito mode (Chrome incognito mode), proxy, VPN, and TOR in blocking, deceiving, or detecting browser fingerprints. With a sample of 30 devices, the analysis results show that browser fingerprints are still detected by www.deviceinfo.me on Chrome incognito mode (28 devices), KPROXY (16 devices), and SecurityKISS VPN (15 devices). Conversely, TOR is proven to be the most effective online anonymity technique with only 5 devices detected. This demonstrated TOR's ability to obscure identifiable browser information, thereby minimizing digital traceability and overcome browser fingerprint recording.

title: A study on the Expected State of Mind of elementary school children participating in MR virtual hands-on experiments
authors: Hsieh I Ling, Chiu Fu Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This study explores the changes in the Expected State of Mind (ESM) of elementary school students when participating in virtual hands-on experiments by using Mixed Reality (MR) as a substitute for actual hands-on experiments. To test ESM, this study referred to Wu, Chiu, Mayerová, and Kubincová [1] and compiled the “Students MR Learning Expected State of Mind Scale” (LESMS), which is divided into six dimensions: PE (Performance Expectancy), EE (Effort Expectancy), IT (Influence from the Teacher), CQ (Course Quality), PI (Personal Innovation), and BI (Behavioral Intention) to investigate ESM of elementary school students before using MR virtual hands-on activities and their self-assessment after the experiment. 104 valid questionnaires were collected, and data analysis was conducted using JASP 19.0 and SPSS 29. The reliability of the pre-test, measured by Cronbach’s $\alpha$, was 0.942, indicating good reliability. Through a T-test statistical analysis, it was found that there were no significant differences in the ESM of students before and after using MR for virtual hands-on activities, nor were there significant differences in the improvement scores of the ESM and the six dimensions of different genders. However, regression analysis showed that higher pre-test scores in PE, CQ, and BI were associated with better post-test ESM. Conversely, EE, IT, and PI did not significantly impact post-test ESM. It is hoped that the results of this study can provide a reference for the design of future augmented reality-related teaching materials.

title: LLM Reproducibility using Three-Way Caching
authors: Abhijit Nayak, Raj Bhowmik
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Generative chat systems often return different answers to semantically equivalent queries, increasing latency, cost, and inconsistency [1]. A response-caching layer has been introduced in this work that stores model outputs and serves them on future requests when the incoming query matches a past query with a user-driven semantic similarity, for instance: ≥90%. Queries are embedded and normalized (lower-casing, stop-word handling, punctuation and whitespace canonicalization) to produce cache keys; nearest-neighbor search retrieves candidates, which are re-ranked by cosine similarity and lightweight intent features. If the top candidate exceeds the 90% or any set threshold score, and passes validators, its stored answer from the cache repository are returned; otherwise the request falls back to live generation and the cache is updated. We outline an evaluation protocol measuring latency reduction, cost savings, and consistency of cached response (exact cache, semantic and causal matches) versus fresh LLM generations (manual and task metrics), and analyze threshold–precision/recall trade-offs. Mitigation of the flaws of simple semantic matches (cosine similarity) are discussed with the introduction of a causal verification in the response caching layer. This simple architecture yields a practical path to faster, cheaper, and more stable chatbot behavior while preserving answer quality through freshness and safety gates.

title: Reliability Modeling and Failure Prediction in 3D NAND Flash Memory
authors: Ritesh Deshmukh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Increasing complexity of 3D NAND Flash memory scheme requires a more sophistic reliability model framework to predict and mitigate early failures. This study provides an overall prediction model by combining DPPM analysis with qualification stress tests methods. The proposed method uses the machine learning tool for trend analysis in retention errors, threshold voltage distribution, and endurance characteristics. This paper shows improved fault detection capability by orderly examination of Error bit prediction schemes and adaptive lifetime prediction methods. The approach applies reinforcement learning designs to identify failures patterns and concepts on failure pattern recognition whilst mitigating edge word-line reliability issues of 3D charge-trap designs. Validation tests show predictive performance benefits in comparison with conventional statistical methods, paving the way for the pursuit of optimizing the reliability of the next generation of solid-state storage devices.

title: Advancing Healthcare Predictive Analytics: AIDriven Diagnosis and Real-Time Monitoring
authors: Shanthi Makka, Padala Naga Vaishnavi, Padala Sai Meghana, Adai Rasagna
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Predictive healthcare analysis has become an important technology that has brought many changes to the healthcare sector. It helps in detecting the patients’ conditions and deadly diseases at an early stage and help them to recover at a faster rate. This analysis method includes gathering a large amount of information regarding the patients’ past health records, current symptoms, and the surroundings in which the user lives. In addition to this information, it also collects information from wearable gadgets like smart watches and other medical equipment using tools like decision trees and neural networks. But these tools often struggle with the unstructured and unpredictable nature of the healthcare records and data. Here comes the use of our proposed method that overcomes this problem by using better ways to handle features and AI- powered tools for sorting out that unstructured information. It takes detailed information about the patient, like their surroundings, present condition, whether they are someone who travels a lot, or whether their family has any hereditary issues, that is, genetic issues and all to make much precise prediction. The AI algorithm helps by taking in all these details and cutting down the possibilities of what the patient might be suffering from. On top of that, this method will consistently keep tracking data from wearable gadgets, gives the algorithm more details about view of patient’s health condition. Combining these new features with the existing approaches helps in diagnosing more accurately by using medical history with habits, climate, and DNA. These changes aren’t just improving how we are able to easily detect diseases at an early stage, but they are also providing a way for healthcare professionals to quickly respond and focus on individuals.

title: Classification of Bank Statement using CNN Algorithm for Accounting Support
authors: Varsha Mittal, Zokir Mamadiyarov, Kamol Komilov, Izzatbek Nafasov, Madina Raimjanova, Satendra Pratap Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Accounting operations involve accurate and timely processing of financial documents Efficiently. The bank statements are classified manually in conventional method are time consuming causes several errors and labour-intensive process in large volume of data. The research study proposed convolutional neural network model for automated classification of bank statement and categorization based on the accounting workflow. The study utilizes text-based and image-based representation of bank statement that enable structural and spatial features. The system uses dataset for classification, input processing followed by CNN classification. The proposed model is trained with labelled dataset collected from the financial institution that covers layouts and formats. The results of the experiment provide enhanced accuracy and outperform other models that achieve robustness. The accounting system is inte4grated with CNN model reduces operational cost, improved efficiency of audit and streamlined financial entry. The research also highlights the potentiality of neural network for automated classification bank statement and documents in the accounting domain. In this study, accuracy was slightly lower for dataset 3 is $82 \%$ but significantly higher for dataset $\mathbf{2}$ is $\mathbf{9 9 \%}$.

title: VitalSystem: A FauIt-Tolerant System Architecture for Wafer-Scale Integration
authors: Yiyang Liu, Jinghe Wei, Wenxin Xu, Leran Wang, Huixiang Li, Ying Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Wafer-Scale Integration (WSI) technology addresses exponential computational demands, yet hardware failures pose critical challenges. Existing convex fault region (CFR-based) fault-tolerant routing algorithms fail to efficiently utilize healthy resources under scattered fault conditions. This paper presents VitalSystem, a fault-tolerant Network-on-Chip architecture featuring Multi-Tier Health Assessment System (MHAS), Dual Routing Table Router (DRR), and Fault-Tolerant Hierarchical Block-aware Adaptive Optimization (FT-HBAO) routing algorithm. MHAS provides hierarchical health monitoring, DRR enables flexible routing configuration, and FT-HBAO employs two-stage optimization maximizing healthy node utilization. Synthesis results using SMIC 28nm technology yield 20.313mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> total area, 500MHz operating frequency, and 1.004W power consumption while maintaining competitive hardware overhead. Experimental evaluation reveals FT - HBAO achieves superior performance with over 10% improvement in healthy node utilization compared to existing CFR-based approaches under high fault intensity scenarios.

title: Data-Driven Analysis of Human Locomotion: Artificial Intelligence Applications in Comparative Gait Biomechanics of Amputee and Control Populations
authors: Roopali Salwan, Swapnesh Taterh, Deepali S Ahuja, Mohit Shukla
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: This paper discusses the growing application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) algorithms in prosthetics to provide better outcomes rehabilitation for individuals with lower limb amputations. The paper begins with a discussion of how AI has been utilized in prosthetics technologies related to the analysis of gait motions, the construction of prosthetic knees, and simply improving the lives of amputees. These AI-driven prosthetics do require self-adjusting AI functions, as they utilize advances in data analysis and machine learning algorithms to detect the gait, and adjust for specific balance and movement in real-time when transitioning to different surfaces. Further advances in prosthetic knee designs provide the opportunity for the device to be interacted with and learned from, customizing the prosthesis based on the user's preferences and level of comfort. At the minimum, providing individuals with an autonomous opportunity to physically engage in greater amounts of activities can create positive feelings of self-worth. More importantly, these implementations support engagement in activities that physically elevate an individual beyond just physical mobility. This paper will investigate the value of developments in AI and augmented reality and designing more efficient, effective, and rudimentary prostheses that not only have enhanced capabilities of consideration for the end-user experience but may also enhance mobility and everyday living. The goal of the paper is to demonstrate a sustaining paradigm where choice is made readily available to everyone based on quality-of-life improvements related to mobility and autonomy. The issues surrounding ethics related to the evaluation and development of technologies warrant consideration.

title: Analysis on Unmanned Intelligent Power System Substation Short-term and Temporary Forecast and Early Warning Technology
authors: Honghao Liu
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: With the increasing frequency of extreme weather events, the need for innovative forecasting methods becomes critical for maintaining grid reliability and resilience. To mitigate the risks associated with environmental fluctuations, one meteorological monitoring cooperation layout, on improving substations’ channels to predict operational challenges, is proposed and discussed. Moreover, this study identifies prospective research areas such as the application of machine learning algorithms promoting predictive analytics, the adoption of digital twin technology on operational monitoring, and the implementation of IoT systems for improving communication and data collection in the evolving landscape of power systems. The findings contribute to the broader goal of developing intelligent infrastructures that can adapt to the complexities of modern energy demands while supporting sustainable practices.

title: High-Speed Matrix-Thread Co-Optimized NTT Design for ML-KEM
authors: Gong Chen, Jiansheng Chen, Tianyang Yu, Zhirui Zhang, Bei Wang, Fangyu Zheng, Yijun Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a GPU-accelerated Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) design optimized for Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) standards ML-KEM. The proposed approach reformulates NTT computations as parallel matrix-vector operations while incorporating an enhanced Plantard modular reduction algorithm with preprocessed twiddle factors. Our architecture combines efficient thread allocation strategies with optimized memory access patterns to maximize GPU utilization, demonstrating significant improvements in computational efficiency. By leveraging matrix-based parallelism and thread-level optimization, our design achieves highly efficient and scalable NTT computation on GPU platforms, making it well-suited for high-performance PQC applications. Experimental results show a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times$</tex> speedup over conventional CPU implementations and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.34 \times-9.25 \times$</tex> improvement over existing GPU-based solutions.

title: DA-VAE: A Semi-Supervised Approach for Anomaly Detection in Microstructure Imaging
authors: Sungmin Lee, Dongyong Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The DA-VAE model is a semi-supervised anomaly detection framework designed to identify defects in microstructure images, especially in contexts where defective samples are scarce. In manufacturing environments such as acupuncture needle production, the lack of defective data hinders the training of traditional supervised models. To address this, we developed DA-VAE by combining data augmentation techniques with a Variational Autoencoder trained solely on normal samples. The model generates feature representations that capture the normal distribution and identifies anomalies through deviation detection. Comparative experiments show that DA-VAE outperforms conventional algorithms in both precision and recall, achieving robust performance even under extreme data imbalance. The model can be deployed in microstructure-based quality control systems across various precision manufacturing applications, improving reliability and efficiency while reducing reliance on manual inspection.

title: Poincaré Embeddings for Brain Age Estimation and Hierarchical Biomarker Discovery
authors: Seung Woo Heo, Nam Jun Kim, Hyuk Jae Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The estimation of brain age from neuroimaging data has emerged as a crucial biomarker for quantifying brain health and identifying risks for neurodegenerative diseases. However, conventional deep learning models, which operate in Euclidean space, often fail to capture the complex, inherently hierarchical structure of brain anatomy and its aging process. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages the principles of hyperbolic geometry to address this limitation. We introduce a Hyperbolic Embedded Brain Age Estimator (HEBAE), which first extracts high-level features from T1-weighted MRI scans using a deep CNN backbone. It then embeds these features into a hyperbolic latent space (Poincaré ball), which is uniquely suited to representing hierarchical data with low distortion. We hypothesize that this geometry-aware representation allows the model to learn more robust and anatomically meaningful features of brain aging. To validate our approach, we trained our model on the public IXI dataset and compared its performance against an equivalent Euclidean baseline model. Experimental results show that our HE-BAE model achieves improved performance over the baseline in age prediction. This work pioneers the application of non-Euclidean geometry in 3D volumetric medical image analysis, offering a novel framework to discover hierarchical biomarkers and creating more efficient, anatomy-aware predictive models.

title: Leveraging Blockchain-Empowered Lightweight Language Agent for Efficient Distributed DoS Detection in IoV Networks
authors: Mohtasin Golam, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: As the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) continues to expand, enabling real-time communication and data exchange among vehicles and roadside infrastructures, it encounters an increasing threat from Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks. These attacks can disrupt vehicular communication, threatening traffic safety and system reliability. To address this, this paper introduced a novel blockchain-empowered lightweight language agent model for scalable and efficient DDoS detection in IoV networks. The proposed model leverages lightweight language agents to analyze communication patterns, enabling fast anomaly detection with low computational overhead suitable for vehicular nodes. Blockchain is employed to ensure tamper-proof logging and decentralized coordination of mitigation actions, leveraging a Proof-of-Authority-and-Association (PoA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) consensus mechanism for secure and transparent threat management. The model demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving 95.4% and 96.9% detection accuracy across both the CICIoV2024 and Car-Hacking datasets, with precision scores exceeding 94.8% and F1-scores above 95%. The system achieves sub-5 milliseconds (ms) latency through an optimized processing pipeline: 2.3 ms for detection, 1.8 ms for PoA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> consensus validation, and 0.9 ms for zk-Rollup processing. The blockchain implementation delivers transaction throughput exceeding 2,187 TPS with a 92% reduction in on-chain storage requirements, enabling scalable deployment across large-scale vehicular networks while maintaining energy-efficient operation with a 4.3 times computational reduction compared to cloud-hosted solutions.

title: Enhanced OFDM Signal Detection via Hybrid MMSE and Deep Neural Network Architecture
authors: Muhammad Usman, Iqra Hameed, Md Habibur Rahman, Mohammad Abrar Shakil Sejan, Md Abdul Aziz, Hyoung-Kyu Song
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In wireless systems, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) is often used because it can handle channel fading well. To detect the transmitted signals, receivers usually use methods like least squares (LS) or minimum mean square error (MMSE). MMSE gives better results than LS, but it still makes errors, especially when there is noise. In this work, we improve signal detection by combining MMSE with a deep neural network (DNN). First, we use MMSE to estimate the received symbols. Then, we use a DNN to refine these estimates and reduce errors. The DNN takes the MMSE output as input and learns to predict the original signal more accurately. We test our method using both binary phase-shift keying (BPSK) and quadrature phase shift keying (QPSK) modulation in an OFDM system over different signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). Our results show that the MMSE + DNN approach gives lower bit error rates (BER) than using LS or MMSE alone. This shows that deep learning (DL) can help improve signal detection when used with traditional methods.

title: A Systematic Review of AI and Multimodal Techniques for Depression Detection and AR/VR-Based Therapy
authors: Vanshika Vishnawa, Neeraj Kumar Verma
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Depression is a complex, multidimensional mental health disorder influenced by biological, psychological, and behavioral factors. Traditional diagnostic methods, such as clinical interviews and self-report questionnaires, remain limited by subjectivity and cultural bias. Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI), wearable sensing, and immersive technologies have enabled objective, continuous, and multi- modal assessment of depression. This systematic review synthesizes findings from 24 peer-reviewed studies published between 2020 and 2024, examining the integration of physiological signals electroencephalography (EEG), electrocardiography (ECG), heart rate variability (HRV)with behavioral modalities such as speech, text, gaze tracking, and facial analysis, alongside augmented and virtual reality (AR/VR) frameworks for therapeutic engagement. The reviewed studies employed machine learning and deep learning architectures (CNNs, RNNs, transformers) and fusion strategies (early, intermediate, late) for multimodal data integration. Evidence indicates that multimodal fusion improves depression detection accuracy by 8–12% over unimodal systems. However, methodological gaps persist regarding dataset diversity, synchronization, clinical validation, and explainability. By consolidating trends in sensing, modeling, and AR/VR-based feedback, this review provides an evidence-based roadmap for the development of scalable, interpretable, and ethically aligned AI systems for next-generation mental health assessment and intervention.

title: Real-Time Visualization of Learning Progress in Online Programming Exercises Using Google Classroom and Colaboratory
authors: Kazuaki Yoshihara, Nobukazu Iguchi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: In online programming education, it is often challenging for instructors to monitor learners’ engagement with coding exercises in real time. In this study, we developed a system that integrates Google Classroom and Colaboratory to automatically collect the execution results and error messages from each learner’s Python notebook. The system is implemented using Google Apps Script, which periodically analyzes the. ipynb files and visualizes the results in a Google Spreadsheet. Correct outputs are highlighted in green, while error outputs are marked in red, enabling instructors to easily track students’ progress during live sessions. A preliminary trial with 11 learners demonstrated that the system effectively supported real-time visualization of learning progress in an online programming class.

title: Multi-Scale Feature Fusion and Context Module for Lung Cancer Detection in RetinaNet
authors: B. Hakkem, A. Suresh Babu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: In many nations throughout the world, One of the most horrible diseases is lung cancer, and it's still challenging to detect it early. To evaluate the tumors, the oncologists take into account the results of blood tests and CT scans, which takes time and requires additional human labor. Therefore, in order to lower mortality, an automated system that effectively detects lung cancers and evaluates their severity should be created. Even though a number of researchers have put out methods for detecting lung diseases, the current methods still fall far short in terms of early-stage tumor detection accuracy. Therefore, our work proposes Lung-RetinaNet is a new and effective lung tumor detector based on RetinaNet. To simultaneously improve the semantic information from the shallow prediction layer, a multi-scale feature fusion-based module is proposed to merge many network layers. Additionally, by simply and lightweightly integrating contextual information with each network stage layer, the context module improves features and efficiently locates the small tumors. The suggested approach achieved 0.989 Auc, 99.8% accuracy, 99.3% recall, 99.4% precision, and 99.5% F1-score. The performance of our proposed model was compared to the state-of-the-art DL-based techniques. Our strategy produces more significant results than existing approaches, as the results show.

title: Experimental Validation of Clustering-based Multipath Component Classification with 28 GHz Indoor Measurements
authors: Hyunsoo Lee, Adam P. Dubs, Nakyung Lee, Sunwoo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In high-frequency wireless systems, reliable classification of multipath components (MPCs) remains challenging due to environment-dependent propagation. This paper introduces a real-time two-stage clustering method that couples a constraint-based preprocessing step with probabilistic clustering on a reduced feature set. The first stage suppresses noise and prunes features derived from delay, angle, and power-domain observations, yielding compact representations. The second stage conducts lightweight probabilistic assignment that accommodates residual uncertainty without strong prior assumptions. Experimental validation on measurement data indicates that the method further improves stability and suggests that real-time MPC classification can be achieved without sacrificing fidelity.

title: A Maritime Loitering Behavior Analysis with Multi-Stage Framework based on Extended Kalman Filter and HDBSCAN
authors: Tuan Manh Tao, Ukhatov Aleksandr, Changha Lee, Thanh Lam Tran, Chan-Hyun Youn
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Loitering vessel behavior—marked by slow, irregular, or circling motion without navigational intent—is a key indicator of illicit activities such as illegal fishing or covert rendezvous. Detecting such behavior is challenging due to sparse AIS transmissions, noisy measurements, and the lack of labeled datasets. We propose an unsupervised framework that integrates trajectory reconstruction, adaptive segmentation, and anomaly detection to automatically label loitering segments without manual annotation. A Reconstructive Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter (R-AEKF) restores missing AIS points by modeling nonlinear vessel dynamics with adaptive noise estimation. Inter-adaptive sliding windows capture local kinematic and entropy features, which are clustered via HDBSCAN to isolate anomalous segments. Loitering behaviors are further verified using spectral and directional metrics. Experiments on real-world AIS data demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms threshold-based and supervised baselines, offering a scalable solution for Maritime Domain Awareness.

title: cnFlow: An eBPF-Driven Telemetry Framework for Cloud-Native Networks
authors: Jisu Kim, Jaehyun Nam
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Cloud-native platforms such as Kubernetes have transformed modern networking by decomposing applications into thousands of microservices communicating over heterogeneous protocols and dynamic multi-interface topologies. However, existing telemetry tools fall short in this environment: xFlow-style solutions omit application and identity context, while sidecar-based service meshes introduce high overhead and cannot observe hostNetwork or SR-IOV traffic. We present cnFlow, a sidecar-free, eBPF-based telemetry framework that provides low-overhead, context-rich observability for Kubernetes clusters. cnFlow attaches in-kernel eBPF programs to Traffic Control ingress/egress hooks on all pod and host interfaces, enabling real-time packet classification and export via lock-free ring buffers. In user space, it reconstructs higher-layer transactions, which are then enriched with Kubernetes metadata (e.g., namespace, service account, security context) and geolocation. Evaluations on a multi-protocol testbed show that cnFlow captures L3–L7 traffic (e.g., HTTP, Redis, DNS, ICMP) with 2% CPU overhead and sub-millisecond latency, outperforming Istio and Kubeshark in both efficiency and observability coverage.

title: Extended Self-Adaptive Honey Encryption (XSHE) for User Authentication Scheme Using a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)
authors: Adek Muhammad Zulkham RK, Girinoto, Herman Kabetta, Hermawan Setiawan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Robust user authentication is essential for safeguarding privacy and restricting system access to authorized personnel. Although password-based authentication remains a standard and cost-effective method, it continues to be vulnerable to malicious attacks. Existing enhancements, such as honey encryption and honeywords, seek to complicate password guessing; however, they still possess vulnerabilities related to genuine passwords. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes Extended Self-Adaptive Honey Encryption (XSHE), an innovative user authentication methodology. XSHE utilizes the PassGAN model to generate highly realistic synthetic passwords, further enhancing adaptability and real-time threat response, thus reducing dependence on actual user passwords and alleviating risks associated with conventional attacks. We have implemented and evaluated XSHE within a Python-based password authentication system. The results demonstrate that the seamless integration of PassGAN on the login interface significantly enhances the security of the password database and improves the detection of password-cracking attempts, thereby contributing to a more resilient authentication framework.

title: MATDS : Multi-Agent Task Decomposition System based on LLMs
authors: Joonyoung Jung, Dong-Oh Kang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In multi-agent systems, task decomposition must consider physical constraints, temporal dependencies among tasks, and interactions between agents. Decomposing high-level natural language instructions into executable multi-agent actions is a core component of multi-agent planning systems. In this paper, we propose the multi-agent task decomposition system (MATDS), which leverages the natural language understanding, reasoning, and evaluation capabilities of large language models (LLMs) to perform multi-agent task decomposition. The MATDS takes high-level task instructions provided in natural language as input and decomposes them into executable forms that can be carried out by multiple agents. The MATDS employs LLMs to iteratively decompose high-level tasks through Chain-Of-Thought (CoT) reasoning and evaluates the decomposition results through a critic module to ensure that the generated task plans satisfy feasibility and logical consistency. This enables effective task decomposition that considers multi-agent execution capabilities and parallelism. We conducted experiments on task decomposition using the AI2-THOR simulator and demonstrated that the MATDS can mitigate errors that may occur in few-shot prompting approaches. Overall, MATDS provides a flexible and scalable solution for generating and refining task decompositions for multi-agent systems.

title: A Highly Linear and Compact Si Ring-Assisted Mach-Zehnder Modulator at X Band
authors: Min-Hyeok Seong, Yongjin Ji, Woo-Young Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We demonstrate a Si ring-assisted Mach-Zehnder modulator (RAMZM) that achieves high spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) at X band. The Si RAMZM has suppressed 3rd- and 5th-order intermodulation distortions (IMDs), resulting in a dominant 7th-order IMD component. The measured SFDR is 105.4 dB.Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6/7</sup> at 10 GHz. The Si RAMZM also has a small footprint of only about 1 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These results highlight its potential for analog photonic applications.

title: An Integrated System for Signal Modulation and Sparse Channel Estimation with Elman Recurrent Neural Network
authors: Y. Roji, K. Jaya Sankar, L. Nirmala Devi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) and Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) are increased as wireless communication technology advances quickly and these technologies are essential components of mobile communication networks. A MIMO-OFDM communication system's performance is significantly impacted by the channel estimation methods. Considering the benefits of MIMO-OFDM technology, there are still a lot of issues with practical applications. Conventional linear channel estimation techniques do not take possible sparsity of the real communication channel; rather they rely on the assumption of multi-path channel densities. To reduce the pilot overhead problems, a sparse channel estimation model for Multi UserMIMO (MU-MIMO) systems has been implemented. In the initial stage, essential signals are gathered from standard sources. These signals then undergo signal modulation using Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK) in the transmitter phase. Pulse Shaping Algorithm (PSA) process the modulated signal to minimize inter-symbol interference and inter-carrier interference. The Inverse Fast Fourier Transform (IFFT) technique is applied in the transmitter phase to map the symbols and the resulting signal is sent to the receiver side. On the receiver side, the semi-blind sparse algorithm is employed to validate the spare channel. The estimated sparse channel values are then used to generate new data and this data is given as input to the proposed Elman Recurrent Neural Network (ERNN) for obtaining sparse channel estimation outcomes. Finally, experimental analysis is carried out to assess the performance of the implemented sparse channel estimation model against various techniques.

title: Vertical Beamwidth Optimization of 3D-BF Pico-BS in mmWave HetNets
authors: Naoto Inagaki, Takatoshi Sugiyama
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: By incorporating picocells operating in the millimeter-wave (mmWave) bands into heterogeneous mobile networks (HetNets), a wide bandwidth becomes available, thereby improving user throughput. Downlink three-dimensional beamforming (3D-BF) in HetNets is a promising technology for improving the received SINR at user equipment (UE). Previously, we have proposed a three-sector picocell equipped with 3D-BF for mmWave HetNets and have investigated its effectiveness in improving user throughput. In this paper, we discuss the vertical beamwidth optimization of 3D-BF pico-BS in mmWave HetNets from the perspective of user throughput. From the results of system-level computer simulations, when the vertical beamwidth of 3D-BF was 10 degrees, the average user throughput reached approximately 289 Mbps, providing the maximum average user throughput among the five patterns.

title: AI-vOLT: Multi-Stage Agentic Translation from Operator Intent to Executable PON Procedures
authors: Chansung Park, Yongwook Ra, Hwan Seok Chung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: We propose AI-vOLT, a virtual OLT system integrating SEBA with large language models (LLMs) to enable intent-based PON provisioning through natural language interfaces. Manual provisioning in traditional Passive Optical Networks (PONs) remains resource-intensive and error-prone, limiting their adaptability to next-generation service demands. AI-vOLT addresses this challenge by translating high-level operator intent into low-level executable commands through a multistage agentic workflow of planning, shaping, and execution. We evaluate the framework across four representative provisioning scenarios and multiple LLM backends under varying contextual inputs. Experimental results show that AI-vOLT achieves near-perfect provisioning success (≈ 99%) in simulated environments and is further validated on a 25G physical PON testbed. These findings confirm the practicality of AI-vOLT for reliable, language-driven automation of optical access networks.

title: Optimized English Thesis Outline: An Unmarked Vision-Based Upper-Limb Rehabilitation Interactive System with Multimodal Feedback and Experimental Study
authors: Xin Fan, Genglie Zhou, Liwen Fan, Haolin Meng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: This study presents a markerless vision-based upper limb rehabilitation system integrated with multimodal feedback to address the limitations of traditional rehabilitation methods, such as high cost, reliance on wearable sensors, and lack of real-time quantitative assessment. The proposed system utilizes a lightweight convolutional neural network (MoveNet) for real-time human pose estimation from RGB camera input, enabling accurate tracking of upper limb joints—shoulder, elbow, and wrist—without physical markers or sensors. A rule-based engine analyzes joint angles and movement trajectories to evaluate exercise performance and detect compensatory motions. Multimodal feedback, including visual, auditory, and haptic cues, is provided to guide users toward correct movement execution. Furthermore, an adaptive training strategy dynamically adjusts task difficulty based on the user's performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves a mean pose estimation accuracy of 94.4% with a processing delay below 100 ms. In a four-week training study involving participants with upper limb motor impairments, significant improvements in joint range of motion (32.1% increase) and movement smoothness (34.2% improvement) were observed. User feedback evaluated via the System Usability Scale (SUS) yielded a score of 82.5, indicating high acceptability. This work offers a feasible, low-cost, and effective solution for supporting upper limb rehabilitation in both clinical and home-based settings.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease Detection and Segmentation Using YOLOv8 for Medical Imaging
authors: Balla Shailesh Chowdary, Bopparaju Meher Lakshmi Meghana, Karnam Poojitha, B. Swapna, Ganesh B. Regulwar, Sareddy Sai Kiran Reddy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Renal failure is a significant cause of mortality globally, and prompt diagnosis is crucial for effective management.Conventional methods, involving CT scan analysis on a hands-on basis, are tedious and need technical skill. This study investigates the use of YOLOv8, a state-of- the-art learning model, for computerized detection and delineation of renal pathology, including normal kidney, cysts, stones, and tumors. Training as well as validation was conducted using a manually annotated kidney image dataset. Experimental findings reveal that YOLOv8 delivers high efficiency with the F-measures of normal kidneys, cysts, stones, and tumors as high as $0.9971,0.9857,0.6460$, and 0.9810, respectively. Supporting Sørensen-Dice Indexs validate correct segmentation. Detection and segmentation of cysts and tumors had impressively high Positive Predictive Value (0.9803, 0.9719) and Sensitivity ($0.9912,0.9902$). Though detection of kidney stones was significantly poor $(F 1=0.6460)$, the general segmentation accuracy is strong. These findings reveal the high efficacy of YOLOv8 in the detection and segmentation of CKDrelated pathologies with high promise in real-time application in the field as well as possible early, accurate intervention.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Mapless Navigation for Ground Vehicles in Dense Forests Using 3D LiDAR
authors: Francesco Cancelliere, Dario Guastella, Giuseppe Sutera, Simone Palazzo, Giovanni Muscato, Concetto Spampinato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Navigating autonomous ground robots through dense and unstructured environments, such as forests, remains a major challenge due to the complexity of natural terrains and the computational burden of traditional navigation pipelines. Conventional approaches often rely on detailed prior maps, rigid rule-based systems, and computationally heavy sensor fusion techniques, which tend to lack generalization across varying environments.In this work, we present a reinforcement learning (RL) strategy for mapless navigation of ground robots in dense forested areas, relying solely on a 3D LiDAR sensor and the position of the target and the agent. The agent is trained using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) within a photorealistic simulation framework tailored for outdoor navigation tasks. We adopt a curriculum learning scheme that incrementally increases obstacle density during training.Experimental results in simulation show that the trained agent is capable of navigating challenging forest scenarios effectively, consistently reaching target locations even under high obstacle density. Evaluation based on Success Rate and Success Path Length (SPL) metrics highlights the robustness and adaptability of the learned policy, underscoring its potential for real-world deployment on resource-constrained robotic platforms.

title: A Single-Mode Three-Phase Dual-Path Hybrid Buck-Boost Converter with Extended VCR Range and Always-Reduced Conduction Loss
authors: Xinman Li, Xiongjie Zhang, Yang Jiang, Yan Lu, Rui P. Martins, Pui-In Mak
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a single-mode three-phase dual-path hybrid buck-boost (DPHBB) converter, featuring enhanced inductor DC current (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{l, D C}$</tex>) reduction and flyingcapacitor (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{C}_{\mathbf{F}}$</tex>) inrush current suppression over a wide voltage conversion ratio (VCR) range for lithium-ion battery-powered devices. The proposed converter eliminates topology-level mode transitions thanks to the multiple voltage options of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text {IN }}, 2 V_{\text {IN }}$</tex>, and GND for the inductor switching operations. With an input of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 7} \sim \mathbf{4. 2} \mathrm{V}$</tex>, the proposed DPHBB converter provides three selectable output levels of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3. 4 V, 1. 8 V}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 V}$</tex>. Incorporating an auxiliary <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C_{\mathrm{F 2}}$</tex> path to the output in parallel with the inductor branch, the inductor current (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{\mathrm{L}}$</tex>) can always be lower than the load current (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{\text {load }}$</tex>) across the entire VCR range, reducing the total conduction loss. Moreover, the three-phase operation prevents excessively short conduction duration for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C_{\mathrm{F}}$</tex>, effectively suppressing the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{C}_{\mathbf{F}}$</tex> inrush current in narrow-duty hard-charging conduction cases. Implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 0} \boldsymbol{-} \mathbf{n m}$</tex> BCD process, the proposed converter achieves 97.47 % peak efficiency when converting a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.7-\mathrm{V}$</tex> input to a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.4-\mathrm{V}$</tex> output at an Iload of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 3 A}$</tex> using an inductor with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1 0}-\mathbf{m} \boldsymbol{\Omega}$</tex> DC resistance (DCR).

title: Progressive Vocabulary Learning via Pareto-Optimal Clustering
authors: Deepika Verma, Daison Darlan, Rammohan Mallipeddi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Vocabulary acquisition is a foundational component of language learning and is most effective when learners engage with texts that gradually increase in lexical complexity. However, most existing text simplification systems produce only a single simplified version, lacking support for controlled progression in vocabulary difficulty. To address this gap, we propose a framework that generates multiple lexically varied yet semantically accurate text variants from a given text and organizes them into structured reading levels. Our method first creates a Pareto front of optimal variants by balancing two competing objectives: improving readability, measured by the Flesch–Kincaid Grade Level (FKGL), and preserving semantic integrity by limiting the number of word substitutions. The generated variants are organized into three progressively challenging levels, Beginner, Intermediate, and Advanced, using a clustering process that groups texts with similar vocabulary and complexity. Experimental results across diverse inputs show that our approach consistently produces well-stratified, interpretable text variants, supporting personalized and incremental vocabulary development for language learners.

title: Modeling Sustainable Digital Personality States through Constrained Nonlinear Dynamical Systems and Bounded Ethical Control Functions in Socio-Technical AI Frameworks
authors: Kuldeep Singh Kaswan, Nitin Jain, Jagjit Singh Dhatterwal, Suman Chahar, Anupam Baliyan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The introduction of the Al systems that communicate longitudinally with human participants provokes the need to develop solid models of sustainable digital personality states (SDPS) in socio-technical interactions. The existing models of digital identity design do not implement ethical protection and tend to provide unstable or misaligned personality development. This paper proposes a new model which combines constrained and nonlinear dynamical models with controlled ethical mechanisms which would serve to orient the evolution of digital personalities in the long run. The software real-time models control the state of digital personality as a vector. Moral boundaries are coded as well as sustainability ensured through a Lyapunov stability analysis. Bounded feedback laws that synthesize control inputs have norm-limiting actuation and ethical barrier functions as constraints are met. The use of social reward signals to make behavioral adjustment with the help of an adaptive gain mechanism. The socio-technical architecture is multi-agent and allows response feedback cycles between humans and Al as well as co-simulation of the digital twin. The presented solution makes further progress in the ethical al personality development by creating a tradeoff between responsiveness and adherence to constraints with ethical potential gradients as a measure of resilience.

title: Entanglement-aware Quantum Error Mitigation for Complex Quantum Circuits
authors: Su Yeon Kim, Ga San Jhun, Yae Jin Kwon, Joongheon Kim, Youn Kyu Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Quantum computing is highly sensitive to environmental noise, leading to quantum errors—defined as deviations between measured and expected outcomes. To mitigate these errors, various Quantum Error Mitigation (QEM) methods have been proposed; however, they show limited performance in complex quantum circuits due to error-propagation caused by entanglement. In this paper, we propose a novel entanglement-aware QEM method that simultaneously considers circuit architecture and entanglement information. Our method achieves high QEM performance by encoding entanglement strength as self-attention bias and edge features, thus effectively capturing error-propagation patterns. Experimental results on complex quantum circuits demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing QEM approaches and achieves effective error mitigation across various noise types.

title: Digital Twin-based Sim2Real Framework for Real-Time Robotic Task Evaluation
authors: Yoo Ho Son, Hyonyoung Han, Eun Seo Lee, Kang-Woo Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a digital twin-based simulation to real (Sim2Real) framework for real-time evaluation of robotic task performance through continuous synchronization between physical and virtual environments. The proposed system establishes bidirectional communication between a physical robotic station and its virtual counterpart, enabling task monitoring and evaluation during execution. By capturing real-time task states and maintaining a synchronized digital representation, the framework compares physical and virtual task outcomes to assess execution accuracy and validate Sim2Real consistency. This approach supports reliable performance analysis and contributes to the advancement of digital twin in robotic task verification within automated manufacturing settings.

title: StockVision AI: Dynamic Forecasts and Intelligent Personalized Recommendations with Real-Time Analytics and ChatBot Integration
authors: Anju Gera, Aryan Kumar Singh, Arun Sharma, Arpit Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The field of stock price prediction is one the most fascinating and interesting especially in the field of machine learning. This article describes recent important studies and illustrates how computer programming is lending a hand and also where it’s stumbling in guessing stock prices, along with discussing the accuracy of the model described in the research and the scope of crowdsourcing real-time market streams. The aim is to provide easy-to-understand and well-arranged insights that those studying and investing can use to develop better tools for guesswork.

title: A Novel Region-Based Cancelable Template Generation Technique for Secure Fingerprint Biometrics
authors: Vivek H. Champaneria, Mukesh A. Zaveri, Sankita J. Patel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: With the widespread use of biometric systems, the need to protect fingerprint templates from unauthorized access has become essential. Traditional methods often face challenges related to template renewability and potential exposure of sensitive biometric data. A novel approach is proposed to secure fingerprint templates by focusing on minutiae points, such as bifurcations, ridge endpoints, and the fingerprint's core point. The distances and ridge counts are computed from the core point to each minutiae point. The fingerprint is segmented into different regions, and a region-specific transformation is applied to each, using a distinct key set, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\{a, \alpha\}$</tex>. This regionwise transformation strengthens security by reducing the risk of template reconstruction by unauthorized users. Experiments conducted on the FVC2002 DB1, DB2, and DB3 databases indicate that the proposed approach performs better than existing methods, highlighting its effectiveness in providing robust and secure biometric template protection.

title: Evaluating YOLOv8-Pose Model Variants for Accurate Pose Estimation in Oil Palm Ripe Fresh Fruit Bunches (FFB) Detection
authors: Rozilawati Mohd Nor, Wan Zuha Wan Hasan, Hafiz Rashidi Ramli, Muhamad Saufi Mohd Kassim, Nazmi bin Mat Nawi, Nor Mohd Haziq Norsahperi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This study applies YOLOv8-pose variants of nano, small, and medium to detect ripe Fresh Fruit Bunches (FFB) and estimate their poses for orientation analysis in oil palm plantations. A custom dataset of ripe FFB images was annotated with five key point annotations representing anatomical features to support pose estimation. Comparative analysis shows that YOLOv8s achieved the highest mAP 50 of 90.01%, which is 2.3% higher than YOLOv8n and 0.23% higher than YOLOv8m. For pose estimation, YOLOv8s also led with mAP of 89.20% outperforming YOLOv8s and YOLOv8m. Despite this, YOLOv8n offered the best efficiency, with only 3.5 million parameters and a recall of 99.25%. On the other hand, validation loss analysis further confirms the robustness and efficiency of YOLOv8s-pose, which recorded a total loss value that was almost 4.4% lower than YOLOv8n and 6.8% lower than YOLOv8m. These findings indicate that either YOLOv8n or YOLOv8s poses as a suitable base architecture for future improvements, focusing on refining key point definitions, expanding datasets, and optimizing the backbone with lightweight convolutional blocks. It also highlights the model's efficiency in handling the irregular topology of FFBs and its suitability for real-time applications.

title: Feeder Link Constraints-Aware Inter-Satellite Routing for LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Joohan Park, Sungmin Oh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we address the routing problem in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks under stringent feeder link (FL) constraints. LEO networks rely on satellites interconnected via inter-satellite links (ISLs) and connected to the ground through feeder links to a limited number of fixed-position ground gateways (GWs). While the large number of satellites provides spatial diversity for user access, the gateway infrastructure remains sparse due to economic and geographical limitations. As a result, FLs often become a bottleneck in the end-to-end (E2E) routing process, where traffic from user terminals (UEs) must traverse a satellite relay path before reaching a ground gateway. The dynamic nature of satellite positions, limited gateway visibility, and link congestion further complicate routing decisions. To address these challenges, we propose a routing strategy that explicitly accounts for FL availability during path construction. Unlike conventional methods that prioritize access or inter-satellite links first, our approach dynamically adapts routing decisions based on link feasibility, availability, and shared congestion.

title: Democratizing Financial Education: An API-Driven Platform Powered by Retrieval-Augmented Generation
authors: Davi Silva Eleuterio, Pedro Filipe Oliveira, Paulo Matos
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Addressing the critical gap in financial literacy requires scalable educational solutions that resonate with digital-native learners. This paper details an end-to-end system for delivering reliable financial education through an integrable conversational interface. Our architecture first uses a web scraper to automatically build a high-quality knowledge base from a trusted national portal. This curated data then grounds a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) conversational agent, a crucial step to ensure factual accuracy and mitigate Artificial Intelligence (AI) “hallucinations.” The entire service is exposed via a high-performance Application Programming Interface (API), transforming the tool from a standalone application into a versatile service. This API-first design enables seamless integration into diverse educational ecosystems, such as university websites, learning management systems, and mobile apps, creating a trustworthy and scalable AI-powered educational platform.

title: Design & Simulation Stacked Rectangular DRA for Wireless Applications
authors: Simran Taneja, Tarun Gulati
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper presents the design, simulation of a novel Dielectric Resonator Antenna (DRA) optimized for Ultra-Wideband (UWB) applications. The proposed antenna employs a hollow circular configuration derived from a rectangular dielectric resonator to achieve an enhanced impedance bandwidth and improved gain performance. The modified geometry effectively excites multiple resonant modes, contributing to ultra-wideband characteristics with stable radiation properties.Simulation results exhibit strong agreement, confirming the reliability of the design approach. The antenna achieves an impedance bandwidth of $105.05 \% (3.28-10.40 \mathrm{GHz})$ and 105.75% experimentally, with a maximum gain of 7.2 dB. The wide bandwidth and compact structure make the design well-suited for various UWB applications, including military communication, radar detection, satellite links, through-wall imaging, and indoor wireless systems. The proposed DRA thus offers an efficient, high-performance solution for next-generation UWB communication and sensing technologies.

title: A 15-20GHz CMOS Variable-Gain Phase Shifter for UAV Detection Radar Systems
authors: Haram Park, Mingyu Lee, Eunchae Jo, Hyeonwon Song, Seungchan Lee, Jinseok Park
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}-\mathbf{2 0 ~ G H z}$</tex> CMOS variable variable-gain phase shifter (VGPS) that enables simultaneous control of phase and gain. The designed phase shifter employs the I/Q generator that is robust against load impedance variations. Consequently, the proposed design achieves low phase error, even when a matching network is inserted between the I/Q and vector generators. This matching network is composed of inductors and is implemented in a compact form through an efficient layout design. The phase shifter is designed using a 65 nm CMOS process, and the chip area is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.31 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. It achieves a 3-dB bandwidth ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 5}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0. 5 ~ G H z}$</tex>, with an insertion loss of -2.8 dB at the center frequency. The developed VGPS exhibits a 20 dB gain control dynamic range and a 5.625° phase resolution. The rms phase and gain errors are less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 4 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 2 3 ~ d B}$</tex>, respectively.

title: Time Series EV Charging Load Forecasting using Seq2Seq and BiLSTM
authors: Jashanpreet Singh, Yash Satsangi, Veer Rathi, Anuradha Tomar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Forecasting the charging power consumption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) is useful to keep a grid stable and efficient. This study compares the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) with a new method, Residual Sequence to Sequence (Seq2Seq) Model for forecasting. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is applied to decrease the computational demand of models by reducing dimensions.
