The Residual Seq2Seq model enhance the Seq2Seq architecture by integrating residual connections, enabling it to more effectively capture dependencies over time and handle the vanishing gradient issue. Test Results shows that this approach gives accurate prediction of time-series EV charging load data. PCA analysis when performed on the input data shows that it leads to some gain in model accuracy. In the study Residual Seq2Seq model stands out, especially when PCA-transformed data is used compared to LSTM and BiLSTM. In-depth comparative analysis was conducted to specify the importance of advanced neural network architectures, and dimensionality reduction techniques for performing accurate EV charging load forecasting. The Seq2Seq model yields the least predictive errors, with an RMSE of 0.111 and an MAE of 0.073.

title: Enhancing IoT Communication, Cybersecurity, and Data Transmission: Employing Machine Learning Technique for Dynamic Resource Allocation
authors: Manoj Sethi, Vishal Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Over the years, the Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed numerous industries by facilitating interconnectivity and automation at an unprecedented pace. But the increasing number of connected devices poses major challenges for communication efficiency, cybersecurity, and data transfer reliability. Conventional methods of resource allocation are frequently unable to accommodate changing dynamics within a network, resulting in less-than-optimum performance, security issues, and wasteful bandwidth usage. We focused on the utilization of ML approaches for adaptive resources management to improve the communication, security, and data transmission processes in IoT. The use of machine learning encompasses the adoption of these capabilities through adaptive and intelligent decision making, improving network resource management through the analysis of real-time traffic trends, the prediction of congestion and the dynamic allocation of bandwidth. Reinforcement learning (RL) is a well-established method in the domain of artificial intelligence (AI) that can adapt in real-time when combined with deep neural networks (DNN), allowing IoT devices to allocate processing power and communication resources efficiently, minimizing latency and energy consumption with high throughput. Additionally, even more secure ML-based anomaly detection techniques provide a robust cybersecurity approach through the identification of intrusions, the detection of malware, and the prevention of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks in IoT environments. The proposed work combines the supervised & unsupervised machine learning models to use supervised models for enhancing efficiency of transmission of data. Decentralized processing techniques, including federated learning and edge AI, decrease reliance on cloud infrastructure and boost privacy. Further, blockchain integration prevents the impossibility of unauthorized in IoT nodes, which can strengthen trust and data integrity in IoT communication. Experiments show that using the proposed ML-based resource allocation model leads to improved network performance through minimizing packet loss, reducing latency, and enhancing QoS. The results illustrate that ML-based dynamic resource allocation clearly outmaneuvers conventional static allocation methodologies to enhance IoT networks' robustness, adaptability, and fortress.

title: Design of Dual-Frequency Load-Independent Class-E Inverter
authors: Yinchen Xie, Wenqi Zhu, Yutaro Komiyama, Ayano Komanaka, Akihiro Konishi, Kien Nguyen, Hiroo Sekiya
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual-frequency load-independent (LI) class-E inverter. Through analytical expressions of the LI class-E inverter, the conditions for achieving dual-frequency LI operation are derived. By adopting additional shunt capacitance with a switching device and an output filter with a dual-frequency filter, the LI operation can be achieved in the class-E inverter at dual-frequency. A prototype of the proposed inverter, based on the obtained design theory, always achieves zero voltage switching and constant output voltage amplitude without any control against load variations, which demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed inverter.

title: IoT-Based Multi-Parameter Monitoring for Robust Vaccine Storage in Underserved Areas
authors: Surapaneni Ravi Kishan, Mannam Jasmitha, Muthireddy Lakshman Sai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In remote healthcare infrastructures, maintaining vaccine potency under ideal storage conditions continues to be a major challenge. Using DHT22 and HX711 sensors coupled to the ESP32 microcontroller, this paper introduces an affordable, Internet of Things-enabled Smart Vaccine Storage Box that incorporates real-time temperature, humidity, and inventory monitoring. Real-time data visualization and automated alerts via buzzer, SMS, and mobile notifications are made possible by a cloud-based dashboard driven by Google Firebase. The system now has a web-integrated AI chatbot and voice assistant in addition to these essential features, making it easier for healthcare professionals to use. As vaccines are used, the system automatically updates inventory, and users can manually enter new vaccine stock information via the website, such as name, quantity, and expiration dates. In order to ensure prompt decisionmaking for crucial inventory handling, SMS notifications have been improved to include real-time stock updates with related expiration information in addition to temperature and humidity alerts. These enhancements greatly improve decision accuracy, operational transparency, and user engagement. Future developments include blockchain integration for safe and impenetrable data storage and machine learning-based predictive analytics for predicting temperature anomalies and stock depletion. The prototype provides a scalable and intelligent solution for resilient vaccine distribution and storage in underserved areas, having been validated under a variety of conditions.

title: An Analog-Front-End with Ultra Low-Power in Optical Sensor for FMCW LiDAR System
authors: Yehyeon An, Jonghyun Kim, Seungju Lee, Jinwook Burm
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents an analog front-end (AFE) designed for an optical receiver in a frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) light detection and ranging (LiDAR) system. To achieve high linearity and low noise, a shunt feedback transimpedance amplifier (SF-TIA) is proposed with an input DC current cancellation (IDCC) circuit, followed by a postamplifier (PA) and a 50Ω output buffer. The measurement results, implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28-\text{nm}$</tex> CMOS process with a 1 V supply, demonstrate an AFE gain of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$85.5 ~\text{dB} \Omega$</tex>, a bandwidth of 130 MHz, an acceptable input DC current range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0 \mu \mathrm{A}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu \mathrm{A}$</tex>, an input-referred noise of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.04 \text{pA} / \sqrt{H z}$</tex>, a power consumption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$343 \boldsymbol{\mu} ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>, and chip size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.61 \times 0.53 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> with I/O pads. Consequently, the overall operation of the optical sensor combined with the transmitter is evaluated to verify system-level performance with a 0.75% accuracy error.

title: A Novel Machine Learning Based Phishing Link Detection in Social Media
authors: Vivek Tomar, Sangeeta Arora, Kanika Gupta, Sanjay Roka, Swati Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Phishing scams remain a growing threat to online services, especially on social networks where content can be user-generated, constantly changing and spread amongst many users. These campaigns capitalize on user trust, spreading malicious URLs that steal personal credentials like passwords or banking information. The pattern-based systems and rule based systems which depend on blacklists can be weak defences, because they are often rigid in format and may not be effective in detecting new or unknown method advanced Phishing attack including zero -day phishing attacks. To overcome these issues, in this paper we put forward a real-time phishing detection module for a full web stack model tailor made to social media services. The main part of the system is a random forest classifier developed on a labeled dataset containing both benign and phishing URLs. The detection model is implemented with a Python-based Flask API, which receives URL input from a Node.js-powered frontend. The URL-based classifier measures several features, derived by lexical and domain-related factors including presence of IP addresses, HTTPS usage and number of subdomains. The model is proved highly effective on adequacy (97.33% accuracy, 97.39% precision and 97.93% recall) and fluency (ROC-AUC of 99.70%), with predictions returned in less than 250 ms on average. In general, this method provides a fully strong-robustness, scalable and real-time filtering service to detect phishing attack on UGC, making it feasible for being deployed in today’s social media.

title: Towards Low-Latency Object Detection on Board Reactive Search-and-Rescue Drones
authors: Ismail Amessegher, Arthur Gaudard, Kojo Nyamekye Anyinam-Boateng, Hugo Le Blevec, Lionel Génevé, Florian Pouthier, Mathieu Léonardon, Hajer Fradi, Lucia Bergantin, Panagiotis Papadakis, Isabelle Fantoni, Jean-Philippe Diguet, Matthieu Arzel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Drones play a crucial role in search-and-rescue missions by providing real-time information on areas of interest that are difficult to access or endangering to human rescuers. However, analyzing raw video feeds by human operators to detect objects of interest, such as vehicles or victims, becomes increasingly demanding as the mission duration increases. This underscores the need for embedded computer vision to reduce the operator’s cognitive load and enhance mission responsiveness. Towards this goal, we propose a low-latency object detection model based on YOLO, fitted to search-and-rescue missions, and able to process data coming from RGB and event cameras. We also propose a low-latency implementation on FPGA on board drones, achieving accurate detection in less than 20ms. Through a series of tests using a prototype drone, we highlight the features of the model and processing core that favor drone reactivity and operational autonomy.

title: A Continuous-Wave/Frequency-Domain Reconfigurable Light-Sensing Readout Circuit for Functional Biomedical Imaging Application
authors: Wenzhe Qin, Huanyu You, Sibo Peng, Xiafan Gu, Eva Guttmann-Flury, Jiajun Yuan, Jian Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable readout architecture for continuous-wave (CW) and frequency-domain (FD) opto-biological sensing, primarily targeting tissue and brain imaging applications. By reusing hardware resources, the proposed design supports three operating modes: single-channel CW, multi-channel CW, and FD. A duty-cycle-adjustable trans-impedance amplifier (TIA) is introduced to achieve a trade-off between bandwidth and power consumption. Measurement results demonstrate an average power consumption of only 1.99mW, which is significantly lower than that of previously reported FD-only implementations. In CW mode, the correlation coefficient between input and output signals reaches 0.9721, while in FD mode, the measured phase values exhibit a high linearity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r^{2}=0.9882$</tex>) with respect to theoretical predictions.

title: Histopathology Image-Based Breast Cancer Classification Using Transfer Learning Techniques
authors: Priyanka Kaushik, Chilukala Mahender Reddy, Sundaram Arun, Saurabh Pratap Singh Rathore, Nishu Gautam, Aryan Mekde
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Breast cancer stays one of the most common health demanding situations global, and early and correct detection is crucial for improving patient consequences and survival costs. current advancements in deep mastering (DL) have proven substantial capability, especially in the analysis of clinical pix, specifically in histopathological photograph category. This have a look at evaluates the effectiveness of transfer getting to know- primarily based deep learning fashions, consisting of Incep- tionNet, ResNet, and EfficientNet, for classifying breast most cancers from histopathology images. The ICIAR2018-project BACH dataset, which includes publicly to be had breast cancer histology images, is used to educate and examine those models, providing a standardized benchmark for overall performance assessment. The accuracy of each version is analyzed to deter- mine its suitability for scientific decision assist structures. The experimental results imply that EfficientNet plays best some of the 3 architectures, reaching an accuracy of $\mathbf{8 9. 2 \%}$, which surpasses both InceptionNet and ResNet. those findings show the ability of EfficientNet as a dependable model for breast cancer histopathology picture category, contributing to improved diagnostic aid in medical practice.

title: Generative AI for DTN Initialization: High-Fidelity Time-Series Network Data Synthesis via Denoising Diffusion Models
authors: Sangwon Oh, Juhyun Noh, HoYong Ryu, Minsoo Hahn, Jaehyung Park, Jinsul Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: AI-driven Digital Twin Networks (DTNs), essential for autonomous network management, face a critical "cold start" problem: initial data scarcity hinders AI model training, leading to unreliable simulations and suboptimal resource allocation. We propose a generative framework using diffusion models to synthesize high-fidelity network metrics (e.g., latency, jitter), specifically designed to capture their complex, non-stationary time-series characteristics. Our diffusion-based method overcomes the training instability and mode collapse issues of traditional GANs, generating data that more accurately preserves the statistical properties of real network traffic. We validate our framework's superiority over GANs through rigorous statistical analysis and performance on downstream tasks like anomaly detection. This work solves the DTN cold-start problem, enabling reliable AI-driven network management from day one and advancing the adoption of resilient, intelligent network virtualization.

title: Towards Accurate Sentiment Analysis in Customer Reviews: A Sarcasm-Aware Ensemble Framework
authors: Reeta Mishra, Kapil Kumar, Bhavana Shrivastava, Nidhi Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The analysis of user-generated reviews through sentiment methods stands vital for e-commerce businesses and consumer analysis and market tracking purposes. The analysis produces confusing results because linguistic elements like sarcasm can reverse the polarity of statements with sentiment. The research constructs a sentiment classification framework that unites traditional machine learning models with contemporary sarcasm identification algorithms. A balanced portion of Amazon Reviews underwent advanced text normalization with three techniques: lemmatization and negation solution and sarcasm marking via transformer-based detection methods. A combination of text features extraction by TF-IDF vectorization and sarcasm signals conversion to auxiliary binary features completed the processing. The optimized ensemble model comprised SVM with Logistic Regression and Naive Bayes classifiers through execution of Optuna hyperparameter tuning. The experimental findings on a 45,000 -sample balanced dataset show that the system achieves 80.66% accuracy together with stable macro-F1 scores for sentiment identification. The study illustrates that sentiment performance improvements can be achieved through combining an ensemble model with sarcasm-aware feature enhancement.

title: Explainable Deep Feature Learning for Multi-Class Tomato Leaf Disease Classification Using CNN and Ridge Classifier
authors: Budiman, Nur Alamsyah, Muhamad Achya Arifudin, Elia Setiana, Titan Parama Yoga, Dede Irman Pirdaus
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Diseases in tomato plants can lead to a significant reduction in yield, thereby impacting food security in Indonesia. Early disease detection is crucial for rapid and effective disease control. This study aimed to develop a digital image-based classification model that achieves high accuracy and can be easily interpreted for the classification of tomato leaf diseases. The method employed combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for visual feature extraction and Ridge Classification for classification, along with dimension reduction and visualization techniques, including PCA and t-SNE, as well as model interpretation using SHAP. The training test results showed that the model achieved a 0.97 classification accuracy on the Ridge Classifier, with consistent performance across all disease classes. Feature visualization separates classes, whereas SHAP analysis reveals the contribution of each feature to the model's decision, thereby increasing transparency and user confidence. These findings demonstrate that the combination of CNN, Ridge Classifier, and XAI can yield an accurate, efficient, and comprehensible system for detecting plant diseases. This model has the potential to be applied in innovative farming systems to support automatic disease detection and assist decision-making in the field without requiring direct expert intervention

title: Rapid-Response Control Algorithm for Embedded Solar Tracking Systems
authors: Zhiqiang Ding, Yanlin Yao, Shiyan Gao, Yongqiang Ding, Xiaoming Liu, Jifeng Ren, Jing Dong, Jihong Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: To address the limitations of conventional solar tracking systems on embedded platforms-such as slow response, weak anti-interference capability, and hardware constraints-this paper proposes a fast-response control algorithm combining Improved Particle Swarm Optimization (IPSO) with Model Predictive Control (MPC). By integrating real-time data from light sensors and an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU), the algorithm achieves precise solar position prediction and dynamic tracking control, thereby providing effective technical support for enhanced energy utilization efficiency.

title: Opportunities and Challenges of Empowering Programming Courses with Large Language Models
authors: Ke-di Zhang, Ming-fei Wu, Ruo-chun Jin, Jian-jun Xu, Jing Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: This paper presents an empirical study of teaching teams implementing AI-empowered undergraduate programming courses through intelligent teaching assistant platforms. It elaborates on three key aspects of large language models (LLMs) in enhancing teachers' preparation efficiency, assisting students in developing computational thinking skills, and optimizing personalized learning pathways. Furthermore, the study highlights the risks associated with over-reliance on LLMs, the challenges educators encounter when utilizing these models, and the limitations regarding the depth of human-machine interaction. Additionally, it proposes avenues for improvement in AIempowered programming courses across three dimensions: technological application proficiency, effectiveness of teaching practices, and professional development for educators. This provides a theoretical framework for the advanced integration of intelligent technology within foundational computer education.

title: Hybrid LDO Having Small-Output Ripple and Fast-Settling at 0.5V Supply Using Dynamic Gate-Voltage Generation and Fast-PD Decision
authors: Seungwan Kim, Younghyun Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This work presents a digital-analog-hybrid LDO (HLDO) using a multi-level gate-voltage generator (MGG) to achieve a small output ripple (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta V_{R}$</tex>) and a fast-transient response. Using the MGG that can partially turn on transistors in the power MOSFET (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{p}}$</tex>) and thus reduce <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{p}}$</tex>'s LSB current, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta V_{\mathrm{R}}$</tex> was limited to less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$320 \mu \mathrm{V}$</tex>. Also, a fast-decision PD detector having a non-zero decision level expedited the switching of transistors in Mp, thereby reducing the settling time to less than 90 ns.

title: BAI2EPF: Blockchain and AI Bidirectionally Empowered Intelligent Equipment for Pet Feeding
authors: Wenxue Yang, Guofeng Zhang, Yajie Pang, Xuguang Li, Shouzheng Wang, Ying Gao, Shuhan Bie
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Intelligent management of pet feeding is an important research direction in the field of smart home. However, the existing pet feeding equipment is generally affected by the risks of single point failure, data abuse and privacy leakage. To address the aforementioned challenges, we designs and implements a blockchain and AI bidirectionally empowered intelligent equipment for pet feeding. It employs a Raspberry Pi 4 as its edge computing core, integrating a YOLO object detection model to achieve real-time identification of pet positioning, feeding behaviors, and abnormal activities. A multi-node blockchain network is established using HyperLedger Fabric, and a encryption mechanism is adopted to secure data storage. A lightweight interactive interface developed through WeChat Mini Programs enables reliable data traceability and remote control. The experimental results show that by utilizing blockchain and IPFS, the size of pet behavior data stored on the blockchain was reduced by over 99%, while the blockchain itself ensures protection against data tampering and privacy breaches. Moreover, we use pigeon as experimental pet, which can monitor behaviors such as drinking water, eating, stillness, and flight, verifying the effectiveness of this article.

title: Decoupled Design of Periodic Output Feedback Control for Multivariable Systems
authors: Ankita Kumari, Dev Vrat Krishna, Bijnan Bandyopadhyay, Deepak Fulwani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper presents a decoupled design for periodic output feedback (POF) control of multivariable systems with more number of outputs than inputs. Designing conventional periodic output feedback for multivariable systems can be complex due to the increased number of feedback loops. The decoupled design method simplifies the process by allowing each input to receive feedback from fewer outputs, resulting in fewer feedback loops than the direct design for multivariable systems, while ensuring the stability of the closed-loop system.

title: A Hybrid DPSO Approach for Automated Anemia Detection Through Palm Imaging
authors: Gyanender Kumar, Sonia Choudhary, Bhawna Goel, Deepak Kumar, Subhash
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Anemia is a worldwide health issue, and Anyone who cares about their well-being should turn to non-invasive palm image analysis rather than risking harmful methods to its early detection. This study presents a comparative evaluation of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Darwinian Particle Swarm Optimization (DPSO) for feature extraction and classification in anemia diagnosis. While PSO is simple, easy to implement, and capable of fast approach-making it suitable for basic image processing-it often suffers from premature approach and There is a serious susceptibility to local optima in complex medical image analysis, which can compromise the accuracy of results. D overcomes these limitations by borrowing from Darwinian natural selection, significantly boosting exploration and allowing the extraction of far richer textural features from palm images than conventional methods ever achieve. Experimental results supported by statistical analysis show that DPSO consistently achieves higher mean and complex values compared to PSO, indicating its superior ability to capture discriminative features related to hemoglobin levels. For example, patient P1 with a hemoglobin level of 14 shows an complex of 3.8323 using DPSO, compared to 1.8343 with PSO. Although DPSO demands greater computational resources, it delivers more robust diagnostic performance.

title: Applications and Challenges of Blockchain Based Internet of Vehicles
authors: Zhongwei Zhao, Yuwen Chen, Han Yang, Ting Han, Hongdi Zhang, Yue Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The development of the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) has enhanced the level of traffic intelligence. However, it also brings about significant challenges such as data security vulnerabilities, privacy leaks, and the lack of mutual trust among participating entities. The blockchain technology, which is decentralized, immutable, and traceable, provides a solution for building a reliable ecosystem for the IoV. This paper reviews the integration architecture of blockchain and the IoV. It introduces the main application scenarios and key technologies. Moreover, it discusses the related issues of blockchain based IoV and points out the future research directions. The aim of this paper is to provide a reference framework for blockchain research in the IoV, thereby promoting the construction of the next-generation intelligent transportation system.

title: Transformer-Based Bidirectional Attention Network for Segmentation-Free Word-Level Text Recognition with Overlapping Characters
authors: Anand Kumar Pandey, Arun Kumar Shukla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Word-level text recognition continues to present a challenging task in document and scene analysis, particularly in the case of overcrowded characters, where conventional methods based on segmentation fail. This paper proposes a non-segmentation approach for text recognition based on transformer architecture with bidirectional attention. The model exploits an encoding-decoding transformer on top of a convolutional visual feature extraction module that permits a global contextual understanding across character sequences. This method does not rely on temporal convolutional networks or recurrent units but otherwise incorporates the bidirectional attention mechanisms added to improve alignment in sequences, character prediction, and so forth, without clear segmentation. We evaluate our model on benchmark datasets of synthetic and real-world overlapping words, which exhibit dramatic improvements over previous CNN-CTC and TCN methods in terms of accuracy and robustness. The architecture sets the limits of state of the art on end-to-end text recognition through complex visual distortions and brings to light the promise of transformer-based solutions in the area of fine-Grain character interaction.

title: Predictive Modeling of Scalability and Mobility in Cloud Architectures Using Logistic Regression
authors: Ashish Dixit, Rashmi Vaishnav, Surya Saxena, Avadhesh Kumar Gupta, Avanish Srivastava, Gurmeet Kaur
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: - this research paper explores the possibilities of using the Logistic Regression Framework as means of controlling the scalability and mobility of cloud computing servers. The aim of this research paper is to identify the key factors that serve as predictors of good scalability and mobility performance in cloud computing servers. In doing so, the research undertakes a comparative analysis of different cloud computing architectures in order to identify which architectures exhibit better scalability and mobility performance. This comparative evaluation uses a Logical Regression Framework based on two principal record sources: (1) the server performance logs and (2) the server usage charge. Every one of those datasets is explored intensively to locate correlations between certain capabilities and scalability/mobility overall performance. Using this fact, the most appropriate cloud structure is determined to show higher scalability and mobility characteristics. The hope is that these studies can help cloud computing architects and engineers lie out and implement better architecture for their cloud-based applications.

title: Machine Learning Based Spectrum Sensing in Cognitive Radio Networks
authors: Rajesh Reddy Vuyyuru
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Cognitive Radio uses Spectrum Sharing to allow devices to access licensed spectrum bands when not in use by primary users. Spectrum Sensing is crucial for Cognitive Radio to detect available channels. This paper summarizes the effects of parameters like distance between users, number of users, sensing time, fading scenarios, and various spectrum sensing algorithms, including Machine Learning techniques.

title: Axiom Deployment of Open Redirect, Path Traversal, and SSRF Attacks to Accelerate Website Penetration Test Automation
authors: Ryan Muhammad Azizulfiqar Kamajaya, Setiyo Cahyono, Jacob Lumbantoruan, Rheva Anindya Wijayanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: A significant increase in traffic anomalies reported by the National Cyber and Crypto Agency (BSSN) indicates the need for stronger cyber defence techniques. One classification of these anomalies is attacks on web applications. This problem can be addressed with penetration testing. Penetration testing can be conducted through two approaches: manual and automated. Automated penetration testing has the advantage of speed, but it can be further improved by implementing a distributed system. Previous research has proven that the concept of distributed penetration testing automation can speed up the entire process. However, the penetration testing system still uses a Command Line Interface (CLI). For those new to the world of cybersecurity, who may not be very familiar with CLI, a Graphical User Interface (GUI) provides a more user-friendly solution because it is more interactive and easier to use. This research utilised Axiom as the infrastructure to implement a distributed system, employing an experimental approach to compare the speed of non-distributed and distributed penetration testing automation on websites. The ffuf tool was used for open redirect attacks, fdsploit for path traversal attacks, and ssrf-tools for SSRF attacks. Distributed penetration testing automation resulted in a total time savings of 20.17% compared to non-distributed testing. Additionally, this study also yielded a 96% agreement rate on the Likert scale for the ease of implementing distributed penetration testing automation using a GUI on websites, falling into the “strongly agree” category.

title: Alt-FF: A Logic-Level Design of Flip-Flop Control for Side-Channel Protection
authors: Manami Nishimura, Tomoaki Ukezono, Toshinori Sato
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Side-channel attacks on ICs are a significant issue. In particular, it is widely known that when standardized cryptographic processing circuits such as AES or RSA are implemented within an IC, cryptographic keys can be easily leaked through side channels observed from the IC. This poses a serious threat to encrypted communications over the internet, as it means that an attacker with access to the physical information emitted from the IC can easily eavesdrop on or tamper with confidential communications. This paper proposes a novel logic-level countermeasure against side-channel leakage in flip-flops called Alt-FF, which could not be achieved with previously researched transistor-level approaches. While transistor-level countermeasures cannot be implemented on reconfigurable devices such as FPGAs, our logic-level countermeasure can be easily described in RTL and are applicable to existing Furthermore, by incorporating randomness, which could not be utilized in prior transistor-level techniques, the evaluation presented in this paper demonstrates that strong tamper-resistance can be achieved against power analysis attacks on an actual 128-bit AES implementation using a standard FPGA device.

title: Comparison between Gate-Driven CMFBs on Inverter-Based OTAs in Multiple Specifications
authors: Ngo-Doanh Nguyen, Duy-Hieu Bui, Xuan-Tu Tran, Orazio Aiello
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: Resizing an Ultra-Low-Voltage (ULV) operational transconductance amplifier (OTA) topology to target different optimizations can be a significant challenge. This obstacle can be mitigated by using digital standard cells with an automatic place-and-route flow, thereby reducing design effort. Taking advantage of this approach, this paper explores the impact of gate-driven common-mode feedback (CMFB) on ULV inverter-based OTAs using digital NAND and/or NOR in the CMFB, six OTA circuits in total. By varying the drive-strength sets of digital inverters, our OTAs can target multiple specifications at a supply voltage of 0.3 V. For example, with the TSMC 65 nm technology node, one OTA can achieve the smallest area cost, approximately 24.48 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, while another can maximize <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{FoM}_{\mathrm{S}}$</tex>, reaching around 203.14 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kHz} \cdot \text{pF} / \text{nW}$</tex>.

title: Topological and Entropic Analysis of Steganography and Steganalysis via AI-Driven Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Kuldeep Singh Kaswan, Urvashi Sugandh, Jagjit Singh Dhatterwal, Kiran Malik, Anupam Baliyan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: In this paper we introduce a novel combination of TDA and the information-theoretic entropy measures integrated into an AI-based MAS framework to provide an enhanced steganography and steganalysis analysis. As a consequence of advanced hidden means of communication and the increased requirements for smart adaptive destruction methods, the convergence of topology, entropy and AI in security is studied. Leveraging core concepts from steganography, steganalysis, and MAS design, we introduce a model formed by special agents-Embedder, Extractor, Detector, and Coordinator-that circulate in centralized, decentralized, and hybrid communication models. These agents are augmented with deep learning models (CNNs, GANs, Transformers) to extract features, predict payloads, and detect anomalies. We use persistent homology to extract topological features from high dimensional stego-object Feature Spaces, manifesting difference in the underlying manifolds of cover vs. stego data. In addition, we use entropic measures (Shannon, Rényi, KL divergence, predictive entropy) of security, agent uncertainty and information loss/gain in communications. Synergy of topological and entropic views enable us to define joint topological-entropic signatures that enhance readability and the steganalysis agents’ performance. Experimental on image and audio steganography data sets (e.g., BOSSBase, ALASKA) demonstrates the proposed method’s superiority of detection accuracy and robustness over baseline methods. Our findings convey that MAS dynamics particularly in adversarial training, largely decide the topological complexity and entropy landscape of learned feature space. The paper finishes with some discussion on these results when designing adaptive AIbased steganalysis systems.

title: A Ring-Oscillator-Based 2.4 GHz Integer-N PLL Design in SkyWater 130nm Open-Source Technology
authors: Nahwan Faza Assaify, Astria Nur Irfansyah, Totok Mujiono
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: In the open-source chip design environment, phase locked loop (PLL) design is still hampered by the absence of spiral inductor models in the PDK provided by SkyWater. Therefore, a ring oscillator-based voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) is preferred to avoid the use of inductors. Ring oscillator-based lowpower PLLs can be achieved with type-I architecture. However, it has a high power consumption to phase noise compensation. To overcome this problem, a master-slave sampling filter is used. This research focuses on the design of a 2.4 GHz integer-n PLL using the 130 nm SkyWater process. The simulation results show - 167,88 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{dBc}/\text{Hz}$</tex> phase noise at 1 MHz frequency offset and −53,75 dBc reference spur. The complete PLL architecture measures 358,50 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{m} \times 138,0 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> active dimension while consuming 11,63 mW of average power.

title: Implementation of GRU Model for Identifying Hoax News in Indonesia: A Focus on Cyber Security
authors: Christian Ivan Wibowo, SY. Yuliani Yakub
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The spread of hoax news in Indonesia is a serious threat in the context of cybersecurity, especially in the increasingly open digital era. This study proposes the implementation of the Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) model combined with Bahdanau Attention to automatically detect hoax news based on text. The dataset used was obtained from the Mafindo and Kaggle APIs, then processed through text cleaning and augmentation stages to overcome data imbalance. The model architecture is designed with an embedding layer, 32 GRU layers, an attention layer, and a dense layer with sigmoid activation. The model is designed to be trained for a maximum of 50 epochs, but the training process stops automatically at the 10th epoch because there is no further increase in the validation data, according to the early stopping mechanism, and is optimized using the Adam optimizer. The experimental results show that the model achieves a test accuracy of 99.5%, an AUC of 99.8%, and stable performance with a cross-validation accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$99.32 \% \pm 0.08 \%$</tex>. These findings indicate that the combination of GRU and attention is very effective in capturing sequential and contextual patterns in news texts, and has the potential to be applied as a supporting solution in a hoax detection system to strengthen cybersecurity in Indonesia.

title: Exploring Students’ Learning Experiences in Individual, Asynchronous Online Learning
authors: Michelle Celine Jörgens, Tobias Greff
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This exploratory study examined the learning experiences of six students learning in an individual, asynchronous online format. While prior research indicates both benefits and challenges in individual, asynchronous learning, such as flexibility alongside feelings of isolation, there is limited focus on holistic learning experiences in this context. As a representative example of the learning format, a learning unit was designed in Classwork within Microsoft Teams. Based on interpretative phenomenological analysis (IPA), semi-structured interviews were conducted to explore participants’ impressions, feelings, engagement, and interactions. The results indicate mixed experiences. Usability issues, mainly concerned with single-window restriction and navigation, impacted students’ impressions and emotions. The emotions ranged from enjoyment to frustration. Regarding interactions, the students expressed a desire for more interaction with the instructor. It can be concluded that this specific format requires clear and unambiguous instructions, as well as enhanced guidance and feedback. Moreover, the results indicate a preference for a blended learning format, combining asynchronous with synchronous learning.

title: KrikatiApp: A Design Science Research Approach to Indigenous Language Preservation
authors: Gilvânia Elen Costa Frazão, Neliane Raquel Macedo Aquino, Varley Santos de Sá
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a prototype application for the linguistic preservation of the Krikati Indigenous community, using the Design Science Research (DSR) methodology. The project aims to facilitate communication between Krikati speakers and non-Indigenous society by promoting Brazilian Portuguese language learning while supporting the preservation and appreciation of the Krikati language. The research included an assessment of the community’s linguistic needs and the development of a culturally appropriate digital tool. The application was created through a participatory and ethical approach, based on a cooperation agreement between a Federal Institute and the Krikati people. Preliminary results indicate that the prototype represents a meaningful step toward linguistic revitalization, aligned with the cultural rights guaranteed by Article 231 of the Brazilian Constitution. The study also contributes to the broader debate on how educational computing can support minority language communities through inclusive and sustainable technological solutions.

title: A V-Band Noise Canceling LNA for Atmospheric Temperature Profiling Radiometers
authors: Mounika Kare, Anik Batabyal, Rajesh Zele
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This work introduces a novel integration of inductive and transformer feedback techniques for superior noise cancellation. A dual <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$G_{m}$</tex>-boosted common-gate (CG) two-stage low-noise amplifier (LNA) design, utilizing gate-source and drain-source feedback, is presented for atmospheric radiometer applications. Post-layout EM simulation of the two-stage LNA in a 40 nm CMOS process shows a peak gain of 15.1 dB at 55 GHz and a minimum noise figure of 3.8 dB at 55 GHz. With a 3 dB bandwidth of 10 GHz and IIP3 of 8.5 dBm, it consumes 10.28 mW of power from a 1.1 V supply. The two-stage LNA circuit is realized in a size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.42 ~\text{mm} \times 0.42 ~\text{mm}$</tex>. The proposed topology improves the noise figure by at least 1.5 dB across the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{5 0 - 6 0 ~ G H z}$</tex>.

title: Multi-LEO Satellite Cooperative Transmission: A Spatial-Temporal-Frequency Perspective
authors: Yafei Wang, Xiaofan Xu, Yiming Zhu, Wenjin Wang, Rui Ding, Symeon Chatzinotas, Björn Ottersten
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: As satellite communications (SatComs) evolve toward integrated terrestrial and non-terrestrial mobile Internet services for handheld devices, multi-low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite cooperative transmission has emerged as a key technique for breaking single-link capacity limits under current link budget constraints. Focusing on downlink transmission, this paper offers a distinctive and accessible perspective on potential multi-satellite cooperative transmission (MSCT) mechanisms across spatial, temporal, and frequency domains, revealing the unique features they exhibit within the context of mobile SatComs. We begin with an emphasis on spatial-domain cooperation, categorizing it into coherent and non-coherent transmission mechanisms, discussing their gains such as higher channel rank, and comparing their differences and trade-offs, including synchronization requirements. Next, we explore temporal and frequency-domain cooperation via mature schemes such as dual connectivity and carrier aggregation, emphasizing their coordinated resource allocation strategies and unique advantages, including seamless handover. In the hybrid domain, we introduce coordinated multi-point (CoMP) and multi-transmission/reception point (TRP) technologies, outlining their mechanisms and discussing feasibility. We then analyze critical issues such as synchronization, feeder links, exploitation of position-related information, multi-antenna terminal configurations, and satellite swarm architectures that are vital to MSCT. Finally, we provide comparative simulations of multiple MSCT schemes under various key factors with near-practical system configurations, validating the analyses presented in this paper.

title: Drone-Assisted Cyber-Physical Stability-Constrained Resilience Enhancement for Postcontingency Distribution Networks
authors: Pudong Ge, Wangkun Xu, Fei Teng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Extreme events, such as earthquakes and hurricanes, can simultaneously damage power systems and communication networks, making it difficult to restore either system independently due to their increasing cyber-physical interdependence. This article investigates the use of drones to establish an emergency communication network that supports postcontingency distribution network operation. An end-to-end learning-based, cyber-physical stability-constrained framework is proposed for emergency cyber network formation. In this framework, drones are strategically deployed across the distribution network to enable postcontingency communication and coordinate distributed energy resources. The framework incorporates multidrone connected communication optimization, wireless resource allocation, cyber-physical network modeling, and stability criteria extraction. These processes introduce significant computational complexity, including NP-hard challenges and nonlinearities, which are difficult to solve efficiently using traditional optimization methods. To address these limitations, this article develops an end-to-end deep reinforcement learning algorithm that determines optimal multidrone trajectories from the depot, providing a feasible multidrone deployment solution that ensures a stable emergency energy supply.

title: Multi-segment Pulse Charging Strategy for Prolonging the Service Life of Semi-solid-State Batteries
authors: Zixin Guo, Zhichao Ma, Wenyang Zhao, Hongwei Zhao, Luquan Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: As a pivotal transitional technology in battery energy storage systems, semi-solid-state batteries (SSSBs) are currently undergoing an accelerated deployment phase. While pulse charging technology has been extensively investigated to enhance the charging performance of liquid lithium-ion batteries (LLIBs), its impact on SSSBs remains largely unexplored. This work presents the first comprehensive comparative analysis of pulse charging effects on both LLIBs and SSSBs, systematically evaluating critical parameters including maximum temperature rise, discharge capacity, charging speed, and cycle lifetime. Notably, SSSBs with high-impedance characteristics exhibit heightened sensitivity to charging protocols and current parameters. A novel multi-segment pulse charging (M-SPC) strategy is consequently developed. For both battery types, the M-SPC protocol demonstrates remarkable cycle lifetime extension compared to conventional constant current (CC) charging. After 1000 high-current cycles, capacity retention rates reach 84.7% for LLIBs (ten segments and 1 Hz) and 93.7% for SSSBs (ten segments and 0.004 Hz) under M-SPC operation. In contrast, SSSBs subjected to CC charging exhibit swelling-induced rupture and complete failure after merely 800 cycles. Furthermore, nonlinear correlations between pulse segment number/frequency and capacity retention are quantitatively characterized to identify the optimal parameters. These findings provide technical support for the development of electric vehicles and the accelerated application of SSSBs.

title: Sensitivity-Enhanced Refractometer Based on Periodic Chirped Waveguide Broadening
authors: Qianfei Zhu, Xiao Li, Tian Tian, Ze Yu, Dongqing Zhao, Yiwei Ma, Yongtian Zhu, Tao Geng
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: This paper presents a refractive index (RI) fiber sensor based on chirped waveguide broadening by expanding and shrinking the core diameter of multi-mode fibers (MMFs) in the no-core fibers (NCFs). Embedding of MMFs with different core diameter in the NCF enables redistributed optical power from the fundamental core mode to cladding modes, thereby efficiently exciting cladding modes. The experimental results show that in the RI range of 1.33 to 1.42, the sensitivities of Dip A (1450 nm), Dip B (1550 nm), and Dip C (1650 nm) are 568.56 nm/RIU, 851.29 nm/RIU, and 580.91 nm/RIU, respectively. The proposed sensor has the characteristics of high mechanical strength and low temperature crosstalk. It is expected to be used in the fields of environmental monitoring and concentration identification, etc.

title: Coherent Nonlinear Ultrasound Imaging: From Microvasculature to Capillaries_supp4-3665340.mp4
authors: Kailiang Xu
publish: N/A
abstract: It is not straightforward for ultrasound imaging from microvasculature to capillaries. The main challenge stems from the detection of low-velocity or quasi-static signal components in the capillaries. To address this, we propose a coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging method, where a nonlinear coherence operator acted on point spread function is leveraged to improve detection sensitivity of microbubbles. Low-velocity microbubbles can thus be extracted without clutter filtering. Through visualizations of low-velocity microvasculature in rat brain/kidney/testis and early-stage glioma, coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging paves the way towards capillary-level microangiography.

title: Early Detection of Alzheimer’s Disease Using Deep Learning and MRI: A CNN-Based Approach with Enhanced Data Augmentation
authors: Mohammad Ashraf Ottom, Iyad M. Alazzam, Ghadeer N. Alkufahi, Rami Mohawesh, Mohannad Alkhalaileh
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) causes cognitive decline, memory loss, personality changes, and physiological abnormalities. A new case is reported every three seconds, increasing the disease’s global prevalence. Early detection helps manage it and improve patient care. This study uses deep learning, namely Con-volutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and Magnetic Resonance Imaging to diagnose and characterize AD early on. The dataset enlarged to 7,695 images utilizing 1,296 MRI scans and DC-GAN techniques to overcome data constraints. We preprocessed using cropping, CLAHE, and skull stripping. Five CNN models were tested using the Holdout data split (90% training, 10% testing). In the 30-epoch training phase, the VGG-12 model attained 100% AUC, 99.7% accuracy, 99.6% sensitivity, and 99.7% precision. Thus, it was the best model. Testing results: sensitivity 97.4%, accuracy 97.5%, precision 98.3%, and AUC 99.8%. The VGG-12 model beat earlier efforts in some assessment criteria. Deep learning and other advanced data augmentation methods increase Alzheimer’s disease early detection and classification, according to this study.

title: Enhancing New Lightweight Cryptographic Algorithm Using Key-Based Dynamic S-Box
authors: Khairunnisa Novitania Rahardja, Farah Afianti, Favian Dewanta
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The growing proliferation of the Internet of Things (IoT) necessitates lightweight cryptographic algorithms that balance security and efficiency f or r esource-constrained environments. Traditional cryptographic methods are often too resource-intensive for devices with limited processing power, memory, and energy capacity. Lightweight cryptography (LWC) addresses this by providing optimized solutions with minimal hardware over-head. One such candidate, the New Lightweight Cryptographic Algorithm (NLCA), a 128-bit symmetric block cipher. This paper introduces a modified version of NLCA, called ModNLCA, which replaces the original F-function with a dynamic S-Box generated from the secret key and round constants. This modification enhances resistance to linear attacks while potentially reducing computational complexity. The algorithm is implemented on ESP32 microcontrollers to simulate real-world IoT scenarios, where encryption and decryption processes are distributed across nodes via Wi-Fi communication. Experimental results show that while ModNLCA is slightly slower than PRESENT at small data sizes (e.g., 32 bits), it outperforms both NLCA and PRESENT significantly at l arger sizes. At 256 bits, ModNLCA a chieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 3 \%}$</tex> faster encryption and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 8 \%}$</tex> faster decryption compared to PRESENT, while also using memory more efficiently. Moreover, ModNLCA demonstrates a strong diffusion effect, achieving an avalanche effect rate of 25.34 %. These findings s uggest that ModNLCA is a promising candidate for secure and efficient encryption in resource-constrained systems.

title: A NOR8T SRAM Digital Compute-in-Memory Macro for Sparse and Scalable Edge-AI Processing
authors: Pratham Sharma, Mukul Lokhande, Akash Sankhe, Kwok Tai Chui, Brij Bhooshan Gupta, Santosh Kumar Vishvakarma
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: In this work, we propose a 16Kb digital compute-inmemory macro with a novel NOR8T SRAM bitcell for efficient multi-bit MAC operations in edge-AI applications. The proposed NOR8T performs in-memory multiplication without wordline activation, enhancing energy efficiency and robustness to simultaneous row access, with improved transistor density over prior 10T/12T NOR designs. A compact Resource-Efficient Interleaved Adder Tree (REIT) employing IFA-8T and IFA-10T achieves 68% transistor density and 57 % power savings over a conventional CMOS 28T full adder. The macro supports 1-16 bit precision for weights and inputs via bit-serial streaming and allows concurrent MAC and weight updates. Fully digital, it avoids analog-CIM limitations and delivers 1.63 TOPS throughput with 98.5% QoR accuracy on LeNet-5 at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 3} \times$</tex> lower power under 40 % weight sparsity. The proposed design advances a scalable, energy-efficient DCIM architecture tailored for real-time edge intelligence.

title: Time Synchronization for LEO Satellites Positioning in GNSS Resilient Systems
authors: Heonwoo Chu, Jaeyeol Lee, Taehan Moon, Jaeyeong Lee, Jihong Park, Jae-Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites have attracted attention as a new navigation system due to their ability to provide stronger signals compared to medium Earth orbit (MEO) satellites. However, severe clock errors in LEO satellites degrade positioning accuracy, as clock biases distort signal propagation time and cause range estimation errors. Therefore, periodic clock correction using existing Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) is required for positioning with LEO satellites. Reliance on GNSS undermines the resilience of LEO satellite positioning systems, since any disruption or manipulation of GNSS signals directly degrades their performance. Consequently, the absence of a trusted timing reference remains a critical vulnerability for LEO-based positioning. To address this issue, we proposed a method to improve positioning accuracy through clock synchronization of LEO satellites using clock information exchange over inter-satellite link (ISL). The proposed method compensate for clock errors between adjacent satellites through distributed average consensus. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method reduces positioning errors regardless of the satellite clock type.

title: R-CICIDS2017: Making the IDS Benchmark Realistic for Quantized Models in IoT Deployments
authors: Muhamad Rizki Ilahi, Aji Gautama Putrada, Hassan Rizky Putra Sailellah
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: CICIDS2017 is a well-known benchmark dataset for intrusion detection system (IDS) model creation. However, several studies revealed that the CICIDS2017 dataset still has several weaknesses. This research aims to improve R-CICIDS2017 by removing unrealistic features. After removing unrealistic features, we use a deep neural network (DNN) to predict the R-CICIDS-2017 dataset. We focus our predictions on attacks labeled denial of service (DoS) and distributed DoS (DDoS) in the dataset, as these attacks are the most frequent in the Internet of Things (IoT) world. Because implementation in IoT must be lightweight, we only use 0.1 of the entire dataset. We develop quantization for several data types to determine which model is best suited for running on IoT edge devices. The test results show that the Shannon entropy of the sampled and original datasets for each label is identical. This answer indicates that the DNN model for IDS on IoT with R-CICIDS2017 uses a low-complexity algorithm. The DNN test on CICIDS2017 and R-CICIDS2017 reveals that DNNs using unrealistic datasets exhibit better performance; however, this is not feasible for implementation. DNN with R-CICIDS2017 is optimal because its performance surpasses that of GNB and uses features that can be implemented in the IoT environment. Finally, the test shows that dynamic quantization has better accuracy loss than static int 8 quantization, and its model size is better than static float 16 quantization. We obtain a DNN model that achieves optimum efficiency for IDS deployment on edge devices within IoT networks, utilizing R-CICIDS2017.

title: Resilient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Algorithm for Distributed Energy Optimization in Smart Microgrids
authors: Malati Basnet, Ching Joo Jie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The growing complexity of smart microgrids, characterized by distributed renewable energy resources, dynamic load demands, and decentralized control, necessitates intelligent and adaptive energy management solutions. Traditional centralized optimization approaches often suffer from scalability issues, communication overhead, and vulnerability to single-point failures. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Resilient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Algorithm (RMARL) for distributed energy optimization in smart microgrids. The RMARL framework employs autonomous agents representing individual energy units-such as generators, storage systems, and consumers-that collaboratively learn optimal policies through decentralized reinforcement learning. Each agent utilizes local state information and limited peer communication to balance energy generation, consumption, and storage, thereby enhancing overall grid efficiency and resilience. The algorithm integrates a resilience-aware reward function to ensure stability under uncertain conditions such as renewable intermittency, communication loss, and sudden demand surges. Experimental results from simulation studies on IEEE 33-bus and modified microgrid test systems demonstrate that RMARL achieves faster convergence, improved energy efficiency by 12.6%, and enhanced fault tolerance compared to conventional Q-learning and deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG)-based methods. Furthermore, the distributed nature of RMARL ensures reduced communication cost and robust performance under partial observability. In conclusion, the proposed RMARL framework offers a scalable, resilient, and intelligent approach for distributed energy management in future smart microgrids, paving the way for sustainable and autonomous energy ecosystems.

title: AI/ML-Driven Predictive Mobility Management in 3GPP: Technical Insights and Standardization Trends
authors: Wonho Lee, Heeju Chae, Inkyu Bang, Eunkyung Kim, Taehoon Kim, Gosan Noh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper provides an overview of recent standardization efforts in 3GPP to integrate AI/ML-based predictive mobility management into 5G-Advanced networks. It highlights key motivations for transitioning from reactive handover mechanisms to predictive models, summarizes the progression from Release 17 through Release 19, and outlines technical challenges and future directions for intelligent mobility solutions.

title: A New Narrowband Active Noise Control System with Improved Applicability
authors: N. Hara, Y. Xiao, T. Shirakawa, Y. Ma, L. Ma, K. Khorasani
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: In conventional narrowband active noise control (NANC), the discrete Fourier coefficients (DFC) based linear combiner (LC) or the first-order FIR filter with two weights, also called magnitude and phase adjuster (MPA), is used as controller to make the system efficient. Modified NANC systems have been proposed to reduce the computational load of the conventional NANC. In this paper, we propose a NANC system that uses a relatively long FIR filter rather than the two-weight MPAs and only includes a single reference signal filtering (x filtering) block. The reference cosine waves are added up to form a new reference signal that is fed to not only the FIR controller but also the x -filtering block. Comparisons are made in detail between the existing modified MPA-based NANC system and the proposed system in terms of computational cost and noise reduction performance (NRP). Extensive simulations have been conducted to reveal that the proposed NANC system can not only outperform the modified MPA-based NANC system but also requires less computational cost if the number of target frequencies is larger than a specific value.

title: The Development and Validation of a Survey Instrument for Measuring Teachers’ Beliefs and Practices in One-to-One Learning Environments
authors: Lung-Hsiang Wong, Yun Wen, Wenli Chen, Seng Chee Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: In response to the growing emphasis on personalised and collaborative learning, particularly in $1: 1$ (one-device-per-student) settings, we developed and validated TFOLI (Teachers as Facilitators of One-to-One Learning Inventory), a survey instrument to measure school teachers’ beliefs, skills, and practices in facilitating $1: 1$ learning. The survey instrument aims to assess teachers’ beliefs about using Personal Learning Devices (PLDs), their techno-pedagogical practices, and their data literacy. We collected responses from 400 teachers who regularly implement $\mathbf{1: 1}$-mediated lessons. Through Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA), we identified reliable and valid constructs within three domains: beliefs about nurturing participatory, connected, and reflective learning cultures; practices involving creating learning experience of understanding, practice, interaction, and production; and self-evaluated data literacy encompassing “identifying problems”, “interpreting data”, and “making instructional decisions”. This 40-item instrument provides a valuable tool for evaluating teachers’ capabilities to facilitate personalised and collaborative learning in $1: 1$ environments, with potential applicability beyond any specific national context.

title: A Wearable Eye-Tracking Assistive Communication System for Paralyzed Individuals with Speech Impairment
authors: Cynthia Joseph, S.Bala Dhanalakshmi, S. Nithiya Raj, N.S. Priyadarshini, R.M. Gayathri, V.S.Dharani Dharan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The paper outlines the development of a real-time eye-tracking control system meant for assistive communication technology which utilizes the MQTT communication protocol. The system is designed to enable persons with deep-seated motor disabilities to communicate without the need for using any gestures. The system consists of image acquisition, pupil tracking, directional mapping, and the sending of light-weight wireless messages. Using the low overhead MQTT protocol, the system supports real-time communication between the eye movement detection system and the output device or application with minimum latency and bandwidth. This work demonstrates the feasibility and efficiency of removable camera eye movement detection coupled with eye-tracking and MQTT messaging for real-time speech generation and human-computer interaction.

title: Exoskeleton-Based Robotic Gait Training Therapy for Children With Cerebral Palsy
authors: Ekalina Rahayu, Trio Adiono, Muhammad Raihan Fahlevi, Danish Muhammad Hafidz, Infall Syafalni, Erwin Setiawan, Michael Jonathan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Cerebral Palsy (CP) therapy in Indonesia relies on manual physiotherapy, resulting in inconsistent joint angles and varying treatment quality. This research develops an affordable robotic exoskeleton for gait training in children aged 6-12 years with CP to provide consistent angular control during walking exercises. The system features adjustable frame dimensions, integrated safety limits, and precise actuator control using NEMA17 and NEMA23 stepper motors with mobile application integration. Testing results demonstrate successful performance, angular movement precision within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 7.5^{\circ}$</tex> tolerance, translational speed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq 250 ~\text{mm} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, battery life <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>35$</tex> minutes, knee actuator torque of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.905 \mathbf{~ N m}$</tex>, hip actuator torque of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20.601 \mathbf{N m}$</tex>, and compliance with IEC 60664-1 safety standards.

title: Effect of Off-Centre Ball on Lead Frame Plating and Wire Properties
authors: Muhammad Zulfakhri Zulkifli, Haslina Jaafar, Wong Boh Kid
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This study investigates the influence of lead frame plating thickness, wire material, and forming gas (FG) flow rate on Off-Centre Ball (OCB) formation in the semiconductor wire bonding process. A total of over 1,600 free air ball (FAB) samples from 16 runs were fabricated and analyzed using bare copper (Cu) and palladium-coated copper <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{PdCu})$</tex> wires on two types of lead frames: Type A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 140\mu \text{in}\ \text{Ag})$</tex> and type <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{B}(\sim 100\mu \text{in}$</tex> Ag), with FG flow rates ranging from 0.3-0.7 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\ell/\min$</tex>. The results indicate that the optimal condition-PdCu wire on type A lead frame with FG flow of 0.5-0.6 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\ell/\min$</tex> -achieved near-perfect FAB symmetry (0.999622) and a zero off-centre FAB rate, thus minimizing the likelihood of OCB occurrence. Overall, the findings demonstrate that PdCu wire, combined with thicker Ag plating and optimized FG flow, enhances FAB quality, reduces OCB formation, and improves bonding reliability.

title: Machine Learning for DDoS Attack Detection in SDN: a Systematic Literature Review
authors: Tirtadi Muchtar, Kusprasapta Mutijarsa
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The centralized architecture characteristic of Software-Defined Networking (SDN) makes it vulnerable to Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. While Machine learning (ML) offers effective detection solutions, the diversity in algorithms, datasets, and evaluation metrics creates challenges. This systematic literature review (SLR), following the Kitchenham methodology, analyzes ML methodologies for DDoS detection in SDN across more than 30 peer-reviewed articles published between 2021 and 2024, focusing on algorithms, datasets, and performance metrics. Our findings reveal that traditional models like Decision Tree (DT) achieve <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>99 \%$</tex> accuracy on older datasets, while hybrid deep learning (DL) approaches such as LSTM-CNN with autoencoder demonstrate superior performance (up to 99,99%) on Mendeley Data. Key challenges identified include overfitting, dataset imbalance, and limited practical implementation. We recommend exploring hybrid DL architectures for enhanced pattern recognition, adopting dynamic SDN-specific datasets, and conducting real-time evaluations using platforms like Mininet. This SLR provides actionable insights for advancing DDoS detection in SDN environments by highlighting current trends, evaluating model performance, and identifying research gaps.

title: Active Time-Constant Error Compensation in Multi-Bit Continuous-Time Delta-Sigma Modulators
authors: Tobias Wolfer, Eckhard Hennig
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: We present a technique to compensate the effects of process variation induced R-C / <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g}_{\mathrm{m}}-\mathrm{C}$</tex> time-constant (TC) errors in continuous-time (CT) delta-sigma modulators with multibit quantizers. Tunable error compensation factors are shifted around in the modulator loop to positions where they can be implemented efficiently with actively tunable circuit structures, such as the digital-to-analog converters in the feedback paths. This work constitutes a generalization of our previously published TC error compensation technique, which only considered modulators with single-bit quantizers. In the multi-bit case, special attention must be paid to the adjustment of the effective quantizer gain as a function of TC errors on the system and the circuit levels. We derive an active TC tuning scheme for multi-bit CT delta-sigma modulators in cascaded integrator feedback structure. The tuning scheme is applied to a 3-bit modulator circuit implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.35-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> CMOS process. Corner simulations on the transistor level confirm constant nominal performance and stable operation across TC variation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{3 0} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex>.

title: Proposal of Pulse Wave Extraction Method Based on Pulse Wave Selection Method using Adaptively Calculated Kurtosis and Skewness
authors: Yamato Imai, Haruto Sakurai, Minoru Komatsu, Hiroki Matsumoto
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: There is a Pulse Wave (PW) extraction method based on the separation of PW and noise from two observation signals containing both PW and noise. In this method, PW is selected from two series of separation signals. In the conventional PW extraction method, the PW is selected from the separation signals using their kurtosis and skewness. In the conventional method, the procedure for selecting PW from the separation signals is as follows. First, block processing is performed for the separation signals. Next, the kurtosis and skewness are calculated from each block of the separation signals. Finally, PW is selected for each block using these values. By using this method, PW selection is performed with high accuracy for the separation signals reproducing the source signals with high accuracy. In this selection, only information from each block is used. Therefore, the conventional method cannot select with high accuracy for separation signals reproducing the source signals with low accuracy. In this paper, we use information of all previous separation signals for PW selection based on adaptive calculation of kurtosis and skewness. Then, we propose PW extraction method to select the PW with high accuracy, even if separation signals reproducing the source signals are low accuracy.

title: A Hybrid LSTM-Fuzzy Inference Model for Uncertainty-Aware Stock Market Forecasting
authors: V. Suganya, L. Vijayakumar, Elshan Askerov Annur, Rani Venkata Satya Praveen, A Bharathi, M. Amsa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Forecasting the stock market is a challenging Work because to the extreme volatility and unpredictability of financial data. Conventional models frequently fail to effectively account for temporal interdependence and uncertainty, resulting in inferior forecasts. This paper presents a hybrid LSTM-Fuzzy Inference express that systematically blends long short-term memory networks for sequence learning with fuzzy logic to explicitly express uncertainty. The algorithm analyses sequential stock data to produce precise and comprehensible forecasts while evaluating prediction confidence. Experimental findings on benchmark datasets demonstrate enhanced performance, attaining an RMSE of 0.013, MAE of 0.009, and MAPE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex>, outperforming traditional ARIMA and independent LSTM or FIS models. This methodology provides a comprehensive framework for uncertainty-informed financial forecasting, improving decision-making within market fluctuations and outperforming current techniques in precision and clarity.

title: SmartVocab, Combining Logic Reasoning and Large Language Models for Vocabulary Acquisition
authors: Tangrui Li, Xiang Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Vocabulary acquisition is a task that depends on understanding the semantic relationships between words. Given the recent advances in large language models (LLMs) and their strong performance in natural language understanding, this paper explores the challenges of vocabulary acquisition for EAL (English as an Additional Language) learners and the potential role of LLMs in supporting it. We argue that while LLMs effectively capture general linguistic patterns, they lack explicit logical structure when analyzing learners’ cognitive skills, so LLMs can hardly offer personalized learning experiences. To help EAL learners, we propose a novel approach that integrates Non-Axiomatic Logic (NAL) with LLMs to support more personalized and structured vocabulary learning.

title: A Reconfigurable 16KB Cache Architecture for Direct-Mapped and Set-Associative Designs
authors: V Siva Durga Sankar, M Dheeraj Kumar Reddy, Unais I, S Lingeswar, Saisuriyaa G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: A reconfigurable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6 K B}$</tex> cache memory system is designed using Verilog Hardware Description Language to support multiple cache mapping techniques, including direct-mapped and set-associative organizations. The set-associative architecture is configurable as two-way, four-way, or eight-way, offering flexibility in terms of associativity and performance. A mode-selectable control mechanism enables dynamic switching between cache architectures during runtime, based on application-specific requirements or performance trade-offs. The design utilizes Block RAM (BRAM) inference for efficient FPGA implementation, supporting selective activation of cache blocks to optimize access time and minimize power consumption by deactivating unused sets.
