The modular and parameterized structure makes it highly scalable and well-suited for implementation in embedded processors, FPGA-based accelerators with limited resources, and customizable computing platforms. The proposed cache architecture is novel because it allows dynamic runtime reconfiguration between direct-mapped and multiple set-associative cache structures, which is rarely implemented in FPGA-based designs.

title: A Chatbot to Enhance the Portuguese National Tourism Website
authors: Telmo Sampaio, Pedro Filipe Oliveira, Paulo Matos
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The digital transformation of tourism in Portugal has led to the integration of AI-driven solutions to improve visitor engagement. This paper presents the development and implementation of a chatbot for the Portuguese national tourism website, VisitPortugal. The chatbot utilizes natural language processing to provide real-time, personalized assistance across multiple languages, including European languages (Portuguese, English, French, Spanish) and East Asian languages (Traditional Chinese), demonstrating robust cross-linguistic semantic understanding. The architecture incorporates a web crawler to collect and process tourism-related data, a vector database for efficient content retrieval, and GPT-4o Mini for generating contextually relevant responses. By filling gaps in tourism services, the chatbot improves the user experience, increases accessibility, and reinforces Portugal’s position as a technologically advanced tourist destination. The results demonstrate high accuracy in the responses, reinforcing the effectiveness of the chatbot in facilitating seamless travel planning.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Reasoning for Offensive Security: Towards Robust LLM Agents for CTF Automation
authors: Stanislav Elkin, Kirill Anosov, Dmitry Kiselev
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: We present a retrieval-first reasoning-agent architecture for automating offensive cybersecurity tasks in the Capture The Flag (CTF) format. Our core hypothesis is that domain-specific contextual retrieval can stabilize large language model (LLM) reasoning under adversarial, multi-step challenges. To test this, we construct a bespoke retrieval corpus from scratch—excluding benchmark leakage—covering key CTF domains such as binary exploitation, reverse engineering, cryptography, and web vulnerabilities. Using FAISS indexing and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), our agent integrates this corpus with GPT-4o via a lightweight, tool-agnostic pipeline. Evaluated on NYU CTF benchmark [2], the RAG-enhanced agent achieves a 57.1% improvement in task completion over the vanilla GPT-4o baseline. Unlike prior work, which often depends on fragile tool orchestration, we demonstrate that focused retrieval alone significantly improves reasoning stability, reduces hallucinations, and enhances task-solving accuracy. Our threat model also considers prompt injection and contextual ambiguity, underlining the need for interpretable, corpus-grounded architectures in offensive reasoning.

title: Neural Evolutionary Path Planning Algorithm for IoT-Enabled Agricultural Robotics in Smart Farming
authors: Ashish Gautam, Nabin Shrestha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Agriculture can be more sustainable, productive, and efficient using IoT-aware robotics. Autonomous agricultural robots are being used for harvesting, crop monitoring, and watering. One must be quick and smart in a changing agricultural environment to overcome these challenges. Existing path-planning methods (based on evolutionary algorithms or generic neural networks) struggle with convergence time, obstacle navigation, and the optimization of when to deviate from the ideal path, leading to operational inefficiencies. This paper proposes Hybrid Neural-Evolutionary Path Planning (HNEPP) to tackle these challenges. It blends evolutionary algorithm optimization with neural network prediction. The neural network's predictive model provides an effective routing using IoT sensor data, which the evolutionary algorithm refines to reduce energy consumption, journey time, and collision risk. Precision crop monitoring and automated harvesting used the HNEPP agricultural robot architecture. Simulations suggest that the strategy is resilient for smart farming applications, with faster convergence, operational performance, and path efficiency than previous methods. The solution targets agricultural robots.

title: Deep Learning-based ISI and ICI Suppression in OTFS-based ISAC Systems
authors: Soyoon Park, Seongwook Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes a deep learning-based method for suppressing inter-symbol interference (ISI) and inter-carrier interference (ICI) in orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS)-based systems. In conventional OTFS-based systems, the accuracy of channel estimation degrades due to ISI and ICI. To address this problem, we design a neural network that restores the time-domain received signal by removing the effects of ISI and ICI while preserving the channel characteristics. The proposed network adopts the U-Net architecture with attention blocks, and it is trained on simulated datasets that cover diverse numbers of targets and a wide range of signal-to-noise ratio values. We evaluate the training process based on the measure of loss convergence to ensure stable learning. The performance improvement is then quantified by the root mean square error (RMSE), which is reduced from 0.42 to 0.30. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by reconstructing the target profile in the OTFS-based sensing system, showing successful restoration even at 0 dB. These findings demonstrate that the proposed method effectively mitigates ISI and ICI and provides robust performance of target detection in OTFS-based sensing systems.

title: LANTERN: Enabling Seamless Relay-Based Network Expansion in Search and Rescue Environments using an Open Multi-Radio Relay
authors: Tim Gebauer, Steffen Fricke, Manuel Patchou, Stefan Böcker, Christian Wietfeld
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Reliable communication is critical for robotic teleoperation in Search and Rescue missions, particularly in challenging environments such as street canyons, underground garages, and industrial halls. While mesh networks, operating within unlicensed frequencies, extend range through multi-hop connectivity, they face interference, frequency competition, and reduced data rates per hop. Cellular technologies offer a promising alternative by leveraging dedicated frequency bands. However, standard-compliant Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) solutions are limited by hardware compatibility restrictions that result in vendor lock-in. This paper introduces LANTERN, an open multi-radio relay system that builds on the established SEAMLESS Multi-Link protocol, enabling interoperability across diverse communication technologies, including cellular and mesh networks. This architecture ensures reliable operation even in complex environments by combining established systems with modern ones without requiring substantial infrastructure changes. Initial validation experiments using a homogeneous 5G over-the-top relay demonstrate seamless transitions between the umbrella and relay networks, enabling uninterrupted immersive robotic teleoperation during mission-critical operations. In addition, a second case study demonstrates the functionality of heterogeneous relaying between a cellular umbrella and a mesh network, while highlighting potential future improvements to enhance handover and link usage when dealing with heterogeneous technologies.

title: Multi-Index Nonlinear Robust Adaptive Control for Enhanced Performance of Multilevel DC-DC Converters in Thermoelectric Energy Harvesting Systems
authors: C.V. Pavithra, Amalan Joseph J, Enbharajan M, Nantha Kumar S, Savitha S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Thermoelectric energy harvesting (TEH) systems provide a sustainable means of powering emerging applications such as Internet of Things (IoT) devices, wearable electronics, and autonomous sensors. However, the inherently low and variable output voltage of thermoelectric generators (TEGs), compounded by dynamic thermal gradient fluctuations, poses significant challenges for stable and efficient power conditioning. This paper presents a Multi-Index Nonlinear Robust Adaptive Control (MINRAC) scheme for multilevel DC-DC converters in TEH systems. The proposed controller simultaneously addresses multiple performance objectives, including output voltage regulation, conversion efficiency, and component stress minimization. By integrating adaptive parameter estimation, nonlinear compensation, and robust disturbance rejection, MINRAC ensures asymptotic stability and accurate voltage tracking even under severe uncertainties and disturbances. The effectiveness of the approach is validated through MATLAB/Simulink and Python-based simulations, demonstrating superior performance compared to proportional-integral (PI) and sliding mode control (SMC) strategies. Results highlight MINRAC's ability to deliver improved transient response, reduced steady-state error, and enhanced robustness to thermal variations, thereby enabling reliable and high-efficiency energy harvesting for next-generation batteryless electronic systems.

title: Image-based Prompt Injection: Hijacking Multimodal LLMs through Visually Embedded Adversarial Instructions
authors: Neha Nagaraja, Lan Zhang, Zhilong Wang, Bo Zhang, Pawan Patil
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) integrate vision and text to power applications, but this integration introduces new vulnerabilities. We study Image-based Prompt Injection (IPI), a black-box attack in which adversarial instructions are embedded into natural images to override model behavior. Our end-to-end IPI pipeline incorporates segmentation-based region selection, adaptive font scaling, and background-aware rendering to conceal prompts from human perception while preserving model interpretability. Using the COCO dataset and GPT-4-turbo, we evaluate 12 adversarial prompt strategies and multiple embedding configurations. The results show that IPI can reliably manipulate the output of the model, with the most effective configuration achieving up to 64% attack success under stealth constraints. These findings highlight IPI as a practical threat in black-box settings and underscore the need for defenses against multimodal prompt injection.

title: Detection and Ranging of Outdoor Fires for Autonomous Firefighting Drones
authors: Benjamin Ronald Van Manen, Mohamed Khaled Othman, Matko Orsag, Abeje Yenehun Mersha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: This paper presents a fire detection and ranging pipeline for autonomous firefighting drones designed to extinguish fires in areas difficult to reach, such as at elevation or in remote forest areas. Specifically, we propose a real-time pipeline for the detection and ranging of fire, including the detection of people for safety. We compare different object detection models for the localization of fire, smoke and humans and show that fusing the Red, Green of RGB images and the thermal image in a context-aware manner results in a more robust fire detection. Finally, we present a method to localize the source of the fire in RGB images through morphological operations in the HSV color space when thermal radiometric data is not available. Our pipeline is trained, tested and validated on public and custom datasets.

title: All-dielectric broadband interconnects and devices
authors: Guillermo Carpintero, Daniel Headland, Enderson Falcón-Gómez, Daniel Gallego Cabo, Ashish Kumar, Alejandro Rivera
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: Microwave photonic components have amongst its advantages providing a large bandwidth, having recently shown up to 500 GHz. These bandwidths are not usually available due to the high losses in current transmission lines and the limited bandwidth of radiofrequency connectors and interconnects. Recently, dielectric waveguide transmission lines have been shown to enable broadband interconnects as well as functional building block structures for signal processing in the electrical domain. This paper presents the potential of a dielectric slab waveguide platform to integrate Terahertz components, having an operating bandwidth that matches with the highest frequency of photonic components.

title: Real Estate Price Prediction Using Machine Learning: A Comparative Analysis with Stacking Regressor
authors: Richa Sharma, Sarath Chandra K Venkata Nageshwara, Gorintla Srujana, Chinnaiyan Ramasubramanian, Saurabh Kumar, Ravi Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper is dedicated to the real estate price prediction and its importance and the methods used. It provides a systematic framework to the researchers and practitioners and direct them on factors that influence the housing prices and suggest the appropriate machine learning models. The study commences by first importing the necessary Python libraries, loading a real estate data set and conducting intensive data cleaning to accommodate missing values and outliers. Exploratory data analysis exposes important understanding of determinants of housing prices. Following the division of the dataset, the different machine learning models are trained and assessed by using the metrics like Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). The Stacking Regressor becomes the best performing model with the lowest RMSE, and this is selected as the final model, which secures the correct pricing predictions of the property in the dynamic real estate environment. In this study, the dataset of Indian residential property of Kaggle is used, which consists of 14,621 rows and $\mathbf{2 3}$ columns.

title: Rigorous Verification of Implicit Poincaré Map Generated by a Sinusoidally Forced Continuous Piecewise Linear Circuit
authors: Hideaki Okazaki, Naohiko Inaba
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to provide a method for the existence proof of a canard observed in a sinusoidally forced continuous piecewise linear circuit by using an implicit Poincaré map, and interval arithmetic with the use of MATLAB, and INTLAB. The method discussed here are expected to improve analysis and design methods of piecewise linear circuit models.

title: Deep Learning Based Meteorological Radar Data Processing Algorithm and Real-Time Warning Platform Construction
authors: Shuhan Gao, Hailei Meng, Chao Zhou, Ran Jia, Hao Shen, Hui Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In response to the imbalance between accuracy and real-time performance in meteorological radar data processing, as well as the insufficient efficiency of warning platforms, this paper constructs a deep learning based “algorithm platform” collaborative system. At the algorithm level, a spatiotemporal feature learning model that integrates attention mechanism is proposed, combined with model compression and transfer learning strategies, to achieve highprecision processing of multi band radar data. The prediction accuracy reaches 92.3 %, the generalization error is reduced to 4.2 %, and the single frame inference time is controlled within 42 milliseconds, solving the performance bottleneck of traditional algorithms in complex meteorological scenes. At the platform level, a “edge cloud” distributed architecture is designed to compress multi-source data processing latency to within 5 seconds through task splitting and containerized deployment, supporting 100000 level concurrent access and forming a “data model decision” full process closed loop. The multi-source data fusion and dynamic threshold adjustment mechanism further reduce the missed report rate and false alarm rate, verifying the feasibility of the system in business scenarios. Research has shown that this system effectively balances processing accuracy and real-time performance, providing technical support for accurate early warning of severe convective weather.

title: Implementation of an Efficient Skin Disease Classification Framework Using Res-SENet with Hybrid Attention Analyzing Dermatological Images
authors: Priya Jayakanth, G Rosline Nesa Kumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Globally, human skin disease is considered the most contagious dermatological ailment. The dermatological ailments are the only diseases that are analyzed perceptually. Certain skin problems lead to both physiological and psychological stress that affects the patient's health. The application of smart devices in the dermoscopic analysis acquires images of various parts of the skin and face, which facilitates easy diagnosis. In some cases, invasive biopsies are necessary to improve skin disease classification. However, the classification of skin diseases is very challenging as the disease looks different in every case and has many variations in skin tones, and some security issues in maintaining patient information safe are important. Thus, several complications that take place in the classical skin disease classification model are tackled by considering novel deep learning techniques. In the initial phase, required dermatological images are sourced from the benchmark resources. Next, the collected images are provided to the skin disease classification phase. Here, Residual Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks with Hybrid Attention (ResSENet-HA) is employed to execute the skin disease classification. Finally, skin disease classified outcomes are attained from ResSENet-HA, and then different executions are carried out in a developed framework over classical schemes.

title: A Study on Joint Model and Hyperparameter Optimization for Federated Transformer Pre-Training
authors: Claudia Großer, Denis Krompaß, Haokun Chen, Mark Buckley, Thomas A. Runkler
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Foundation Models (FMs) have been a major leap in AI, largely due to their massive scale and pre-training on enormous datasets. Incorporating private data at scale into FM pre-training presents a clear opportunity to capture domainspecific knowledge, improve personalization, and unlock proprietary value. Federated Learning emerges as a promising solution to this challenge, offering a privacy-preserving framework to leverage these private data resources for FM pre-training.Although federated pre-training of FMs from scratch is technically viable, there is currently no strategy for calibrating its training. Given that FM pre-training is already a highly resource-intensive task, executing it in a cross-device federated setting compounds the challenge by introducing limited and heterogeneous compute resources, increased communication overhead, and greater noise and variability in the training signal.We study transformer pre-training including hyperparameter tuning in a heterogeneous, cross-device federated environment with limited communication and small client datasets. Comparing simple and advanced federated optimizers, we find that Fed-Pop — a population-based learning algorithm that employs a tuning-while-training paradigm — performs particularly well for this setting.

title: From Intentions to Actions: Workflow Generation with LLMs for Robots
authors: Justus Flerlage, Alexander Acker, Dominik Scheinert, Soeren Becker, Hamza Yous, Karnakar Reddy, Ibrahim Farhat, Hakim Hacid, Odej Kao
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are reshaping human–machine interaction. Their ability to infer goals, decompose intentions into actions, and generate workflows positions them as a new paradigm for robotics, where adaptability to dynamic and unpredictable environments is crucial. In this work, we formalize the intention-to-workflow transformation for robotics as state-machine–like sequences of actions and propose a modular reference architecture that integrates perception, LLM-based reasoning, and execution. To evaluate this paradigm, we introduce a benchmark of 15 pick-and-place challenges across four categories, performed with a simulated robotic gripper arm and three distinct objects. Experiments with diverse LLM families reveal characteristic error modes, including failures in spatial alignment and object manipulation, while larger models demonstrate greater robustness in complex tasks. These results provide design guidelines for workflow generation in embodied AI and establish a reproducible benchmark. Our work lays the foundation for deploying LLMs as high-level controllers in robotic systems.

title: Evaluating the Energy-Efficiency of the Code Generated by LLMs
authors: Md Arman Islam, Devi Varaprasad Jonnala, Ritika Rekhi, Pratik Pokharel, Siddharth Cilamkoti, Asif Imran, Tevfik Kosar, Bekir Turkkan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: As the quality of code generated by Large Language Models (LLMs) improves, their adoption in the software industry for automated code generation continues to grow. Researchers primarily focus on enhancing the functional correctness of the generated code while commonly overlooking its energy efficiency and environmental impact. This paper investigates the energy efficiency of the code generated by 20 popular LLMs for 878 programming problems of varying difficulty levels and diverse algorithmic categories selected from the LeetCode platform by comparing them against canonical human-written solutions. Although LLMs can produce functionally correct results in most cases, our findings show that the performance and energy efficiency of LLM-produced solutions are often far below those of human-written solutions. Among the studied LLMs, DeepSeek-v3 and GPT-4o generate the most energy-efficient code, whereas Grok-2 and Gemini-1.5-Pro are among the least energy-efficient models. On average, human-generated canonical solutions are approximately 1.17 times more energy efficient than DeepSeek-v3, 1.21 times more energy efficient than GPT-4o, and over 2 times more energy efficient than Grok-2 and Gemini-1.5-Pro. For specific algorithmic groups such as dynamic programming, backtracking, and bit manipulation, LLM-generated code can consume up to 450 times more energy than human-generated canonical solutions.

title: Emissions and Performance Trade-off Between Small and Large Language Models
authors: Anandita Garg, Uma Gaba, Deepan Muthirayan, Anish Roy Chowdhury
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The advent of Large Language Models (LLMs) has raised concerns about their enormous carbon footprint, starting with energy-intensive training and continuing through repeated inference. This study investigates the potential of using fine-tuned Small Language Models (SLMs) as a sustainable alternative for predefined tasks. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the performance-emissions trade-off between LLMs and fine-tuned SLMs across selected tasks under Natural Language Processing, Reasoning and Programming. Our results show that in four out of the six selected tasks, SLMs maintained comparable performances for a significant reduction in carbon emissions during inference. Our findings demonstrate the viability of smaller models in mitigating the environmental impact of resource-heavy LLMs, thus advancing towards sustainable, green AI.

title: An AIGC-Empowered Adaptive Scaffolding Model in Project-Based Learning: A Case Study of OFDM System Design
authors: Ming Cheng, Jian Ouyang, Changfeng Ding, Liping Luo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: This study proposes an AIGC-empowered adaptive scaffolding model to address the pedagogical challenges in complex project-based learning environments. Grounded in constructive alignment, the model operates through interconnected data perception, intelligent decision, and dynamic interaction layers. It facilitates real-time diagnosis of learners' cognitive states and generates personalized supports to form adaptive instructional scaffolding. The model is demonstrated through a case study of an OFDM system design project. A design-based research methodology, which employs triangulated analysis of process, outcome, and perceptual data, is designed to evaluate the model's impact on learning processes and outcomes. This model is promising to operationalize effectively key scaffolding mechanisms. It also shifts the instructor's role from content deliverer to learning architect, and pave the way for a sustainable human-AI collaborative teaching ecosystem that fosters deep learning and expertise development.

title: OTX AlienVault Indicator of Compromise Implementation on MISP Threat Sharing for Network Intrusion Detection System Suricata
authors: Dimas Wahyu Utomo, Nanang Trianto, Ira Rosianal Hikmah, Tiyas Yulita
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: In the ever-evolving cyber era, cyberattack threats are increasingly diverse and elusive. Precise and complete information related to cyber attacks can be utilised to create a reliable network security system that is able to adapt automatically, so that the network is better protected from future threats. Based on the Security Landscape of the National Cyber and Crypto Agency in 2023 there are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$403,990,813$</tex> anomaly traffic which are considered cyber attacks. From the data above, an early detection system is needed using a Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) that always updates its rules to monitor network traffic. Information from Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) results is needed to update NIDS rules. CTI is analysed and relevant information about cyber threats that can be used to understand cyber attacks. The form of CTI results is Indicator of Compromise which contains a list of valid attack attributes. This research implements the AlienVault OTX Indicator of Compromise in MISP Threat Sharing to provide automatic rules updates and improve the performance of Suricata NIDS, Suricata is a NIDS with high detection accuracy because it applies several detection engines or multi-threading. The experimental results show that before the rules update, Suricata was unable to detect the tested attack scenarios, whereas after applying the updated rules from MISP Threat Sharing, Suricata successfully detected 100% of the three attack scenarios. In addition, the average processing time recorded was 347 seconds for fetching IoCs from OTX to MISP and 84 seconds for exporting rules from MISP to Suricata, indicating that the update mechanism can be executed efficiently.

title: Short-Term Electricity Demand Forecasting Using an Integrated CNN-Transformer-LSTM Model
authors: Nico Surantha, Kosei Motokura, Toru Iwao
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Electricity generation, transmission, distribution and retail were separated with the liberalization of the electricity market in Japan. An electricity retailer needs to create a procurement plan in order to purchase electricity from a power generation company and sell the procured electricity to subscribing customers. In order to create a reliable procurement plan, it is essential to forecast the amount of electricity demand. The purpose of this study was to accurately and quickly forecast electricity demand over a short period of time using historical supply and demand data for Japan. In order to achieve accurate forecasts, the CNN-Transformer-LSTM model, which is a combination of a Transformer model, a convolutional neural network (CNN) model, and a long short-term memory (LSTM) model is proposed. In this paper, an original dataset is developed using Shikoku Electric Power Company's electricity demand data and weather-related data from Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) within period 2016-2022. Simulation results shows that the proposed model CNN-Transformer-LSTM achieves the best forecasting performance compared to other methods. It was proven by the achievement of lowest score of root mean squared error (RMSE) and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) in every season data.

title: Low-Voltage-Compatible Low-Frequency Clock Multiplier Circuit Using Monostable Multivibrators
authors: Ryo Akahane, Mizuki Mori, Alvaro Sara, Nobuhiko Nakano
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This paper proposes a low-voltage clock multiplier circuit aimed at realizing on-chip autonomous systems that operate without external power supplies by utilizing indoor light signals. The circuit employs a dual-edge trigger to multiply a 100 Hz clock derived from commercial power-induced light fluctuations and uses a monostable multivibrator to achieve highprecision duty cycle correction. Simulation results demonstrate that the circuit maintains a 50% duty cycle within a ±0.17% margin under variations in supply voltage, temperature, and process conditions. By accurately capturing fluctuations and flickering in light sources, this circuit is expected to be applicable to a wide range of fields, including real-time monitoring of power quality, human flow analysis, and security systems.

title: A Scalable Federated Learning Framework for Efficient Brain Tumor Segmentation With Advanced Data Privacy
authors: Balakesava Reddy Parvathala, Tyj Naga Malleswari, B.V. Seshu Kumari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Timely treatment and diagnosis anticipation are made possible by brain image segmentation, which is a decisive factor of modern healthcare. Shielding private patient information during cross-institutional model training is now probable with Federated-Learning(FL). Advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) for healthcare could be substantial with the combination of these technologies. But data imbalances are common in the medical field; some institutions have small datasets of annotated brain images, while others have bigger datasets with more varied cases. Segmentation accuracy and generalizability are negatively impacted by the non-independent distributed properties of such data. In order to tackle these problems, this paper suggests a model for segmenting brain tumor images on the client cross. The approach would use Virtual-Adversarial-Training(VAT) combined with a 3D U-Net to progress its efficacy on small datasets. This would solve the problems of data scarceness and imbalance in the FLenvironment by making the most of the BT-images that each client has. FedHG presents a powerful method for federated model aggregation that makes use of critical parameters, in this case the ‘weights’ obtained from a publicly available authentication dataset. Experiments on real-world data reveal that the suggested algorithm works better than the baseline FLalgorithm for brain tumor segmentation by 2.2%, and it performs slightly worse than centralized training by 3%, demonstrating its usefulness in the real world.

title: Reputation-Enhanced Leader Election for Blockchain Consensus
authors: Junda Wu, Chengxiang Xia, Qi Chen, Hongyang Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Consensus algorithms are essential for blockchain systems, ensuring consistency and security across distributed nodes. In consortium blockchains, however, existing protocols often fail to quantify node behavior, limiting the ability to reward honest participants or penalize malicious ones, which reduces engagement and increases vulnerability to Byzantine faults. To address this, we propose a reputation-based consensus algorithm that evaluates nodes based on historical and current behavior. By combining behavior-driven reputation scoring with Verifiable Delay Function (VDF)-based leader election, our approach filters out low-reputation nodes while retaining cryptographic fairness, forming a hybrid mechanism atop the Raft protocol. We further enhance Raft’s log replication with reputation-guided strategies, prioritizing efficient replication. Experiments show that our protocol improves throughput by 10% without compromising security, demonstrating both reliability and performance gains.

title: Consortium Blockchain and Its Application of Attribute-based Encryption
authors: Lei Shang, Qingfang Meng, Yuhong Sun, Tao Li, Xu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The traditional online examination systems usually adopt the centralized management, where the information of exam paper, and scores of examinees are stored on a trusted server. Since all the data management depends on the administrator, it is difficult to ensure the integrity and privacy of the data. In response to this problem, this paper designs an examination system based on consortium blockchain, namely Examchain. In this system, legal examinees’ access to the encrypted exam paper is controlled by attribute-based encryption (ABE) before the exam, the examinees’ scores are encrypted and stored in the blockchain after the exam. Through the blockchain, it is guaranteed that examinees’ scores cannot be deleted or tampered with, and the digital signature is used to avoid any dispute on scores. In order to reduce the storage overhead of the exam center, a cloud server is introduced to store the exam paper and examinees’ answers. Analysis and experimental results show that the proposed Examchain meets the design goals of the system.

title: Multi-Agent Foundation Models for Urban Mobility: The Malmö Elderly Case
authors: Alberto Biscalchin, Elnaz Sarkheyli, Arezoo Sarkheyli-Hägele
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Understanding travel behaviour is crucial for developing inclusive, adaptable transportation systems in ageing cities. Yet many public authorities lack the expertise and budget for advanced analytics. We present a modular, multi-agent framework that employs Large Language Models (LLMs) to lower the entry barrier to data-driven mobility analysis. The pipeline extracts interpretable, policy-oriented insights from unstructured survey data and outputs structured reports without manual coding. We demonstrate the approach using Malmö’s 2023 travel survey for residents aged 65+, and benchmark its recommendations against those of (i) a single-agent LLM service (Single Agent), representative of current commercial offerings, and (ii) a human expert baseline (Human), both evaluated in a blinded expert review. The system achieves superior reasoning quality compared to the single-agent baseline, while performing slightly lower on interpretability and focus, and approaches expert-level quality overall—at a fraction of the cost and effort. Key constraints are the current lack of real-time data ingestion and dependence on proprietary commercial APIs. The study provides an open-source proof of concept showing how multi-agent LLMs can make urban mobility analytics more accessible, transparent, and timely. All code and evaluation materials are publicly available.

title: Meta-Heuristic Approches for Optimized Drone Communication Network
authors: Chilakala Sudhamani, S. Varshini, D. Vyshnavi, S. Vikas, K. Esteru
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Nowadays, drone communication networks have become essential technologies due to their flexibility, mobility, and growing applications in various fields such as disaster management, surveillance, and transportation services. However, the drone communication faces many challenges along with the advances. A significant challenge is to optimize the network communication parameters to maintain both reliability and efficiency. In this paper, we considered metaheuristic optimization algorithms such as the Cuckoo Search Algorithm (CSA), Differential Evolution Algorithm (DEA), and Honey Bee Algorithm (HBA) to evaluate the network performance and for the comparative analysis. These algorithms are considered to optimize various parameters such as the Contention Window (CW) and number of UAVs, which is required to enhance the drone network throughput. Simulation results show that the use of these meta-heuristic optimization techniques enhanced the network throughput, and identified the optimized CW size for three algorithms.

title: Design and Implementation of an AI-Enabled Competency-Based Evaluation System for Primary Education Using “DingTalk+"
authors: Shengzhang Zhang, Jun Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of an intelligent, competency-based student evaluation system for primary education, developed using the DingTalk+ platform. Grounded in China’s “Five Domains” framework-moral, intellectual, physical, aesthetic, and labor development-the system was piloted in a district in Fujian Province. It features a layered system architecture and multimodal data collection mechanisms –capturing academic scores, behavioral patterns, and informal learning observations to support holistic, process-oriented assessment. Built on DingTalk’s cloud-based Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) infrastructure, the platform integrates real-time behavioral observations, teacher evaluations, and parent-submitted evidence. Key functionalities include AI-generated formative feedback, gamified point-based incentive mechanisms, and dynamic data dashboards, all designed to enhance the objectivity, student engagement, and instructional utility of assessments. Field data indicate the system’s effectiveness in addressing persistent challenges in traditional evaluation approaches-such as narrow performance indicators, limited reliability, and delayed feedback-while promoting well-rounded student development. The study also identifies persistent challenges: difficulties in integrating with legacy platforms, the complexity of interpreting unstructured behavioral data, uneven engagement among stakeholders, and concerns regarding data privacy and algorithmic transparency. These limitations suggest key areas for further investigation, including the responsible adoption of generative AI, development of lightweight and userfriendly evaluation modules, and studies examining crossregional scalability. Overall, this work contributes both theoretical insight and practical guidance for advancing competency-oriented assessment reform in basic education.

title: Dual-Channel Potentiostat for Electrochemical Measurements with Approximations
authors: Kevin Reagen S., Isa Anshori, Infall Syafalni, Nur Ahmadi, Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani, Tutun Juhana, Trio Adiono
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a compact and dual-channel potentiostat suited for rapid field measurements. Recognizing the limitations of conventional benchtop instruments - their size, cost, and dependence on external power — this proposed design integrates an ESP32-based microcontroller with analog front-end circuitry to achieve nanoampere-level sensitivity. The reading subsystem comprises a control amplifier for potential control, a unity-gain buffer to isolate the reference electrode, and a transimpedance stage that converts cell current to a measurable voltage. A Sallen-Key low-pass filter attenuates high-frequency noise, ensuring stable voltammetric waveforms. Performance was evaluated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) and differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) in potassium ferrocyanide solutions, demonstrating a resolution of up to nanoampere order and stable operation on battery power for over ten consecutive scans. Moreover, we apply some approximations to transform the raw output to the referenced output provided by the commercial potentiostat PalmSens4. Experimental results show that the proposed dual-channel potentiostat achieves up to more than 94% accuracy. The work is potential for practical applications that require parallel and fast measurements using electrochemical method.

title: Integrated Thin-Film Lithium Niobate Receiver for Both Frequency Demultiplexing and Modulation De-chirping Functions in Dual-Band Radar
authors: Yongtao Du, Ningyuan Zhong, Xihua Zou, Fang Zou, Wenlin Bai, Xiaojun Xie, Wei Pan, Lianshan Yan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A dual-band radar system using coherent fusion processing can significantly enhance the ranging resolution by exploiting two or more distinct bands. For instance, conventional dual-band radar receivers typically require two independent channels and frontends to perform frequency demultiplexing and modulation de-chirping functions separately, leading to large size, extra power consumption, and high cost. To overcome these limitations, we have developed a novel dual-band radar receiver chip based on the thin-film lithium niobate platform. Such a single integrated chip is designed to have a complementary periodic electro-optical response, which enables to both demultiplexing the bands and de-chirp the linear frequency-modulated (LFM) signal of the two sub-bands in the dual-band signal simultaneously. In the experiment demonstration, a dual-band LFM signal centered at 9.15 GHz and 16.05 GHz is used, where each sub-band has a 1-GHz bandwidth. Correspondingly, the photonic dual-band radar system using an integrated dual-function receiver has achieved a ranging resolution of 1.93 cm, through the coherent fusion processing of the dual-band signal.

title: Generative AI in Assessment and Feedback Generation in Higher Education: A Systematic Review
authors: Amir Yavariabdi, Bhuwan Paudel, Tamara Carleton, Carlos Diego Andrade De Almeida
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Assessment and feedback activities in higher education are undergoing significant changes. Many universities and institutes still rely on traditional testing and grading methods, which often fall short in supporting meaningful student learning, especially in large classes. Although educational policies, such as those promoted by the Bologna process, encourage more feedback-oriented and student-centered approaches, these practices can be difficult to implement due to time constraints and limited resources. Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI), particularly Large Language Models (LLMs), has shown strong potential in addressing these challenges. This review examines 21 research studies published between 2023 and 2025 that explore the use of GenAI in providing feedback and assessing student work in higher education, with some studies also comparing GenAI’s performance with human instructors. Findings show that LLMs can generate personalized and constructive feedback and/or assist with fair and consistent assessment. However, in most studies, teachers still play a key role, as expert oversight is essential to ensure that grading assessments and assignment feedback are accurate, relevant, and aligned with learning objectives. For GenAI to be used effectively, educators need to understand how to work with these tools, such as learning GenAI prompt design and the basic principles behind LLMs. We recommend that academic institutions provide training for educators in AI literacy, prompt engineering, and the development of teaching strategies that combine the strengths of human judgment with AI support. By effectively integrating LLM tools, major assessment challenges, such as limited time and inconsistent feedback quality, can be addressed while also enhancing student learning and engagement.

title: Autonomous Cyber Resilience via a Co-Evolutionary Arms Race within a Fortified Digital Twin Sandbox
authors: Malikussaid, Sutiyo
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: The convergence of Information Technology and Operational Technology has exposed Industrial Control Systems to adaptive, intelligent adversaries that render static defenses obsolete. This paper introduces the Adversarial Resilience Coevolution (ARC) framework, addressing the “Trinity of Trust” comprising model fidelity, data integrity, and analytical resilience. ARC establishes a co-evolutionary arms race within a Fortified Secure Digital Twin (F-SCDT), where a Deep Reinforcement Learning “Red Agent” autonomously discovers attack paths while an ensemble-based “Blue Agent” is continuously hardened against these threats. Experimental validation on the Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) and Secure Water Treatment (SWaT) testbeds demonstrates superior performance in detecting novel attacks, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}_{1}$</tex>-scores improving from 0.65 to 0.89 and detection latency reduced from over 1200 seconds to 210 seconds. A comprehensive ablation study reveals that the co-evolutionary process itself contributes a 27 % performance improvement. By integrating Explainable AI and proposing a Federated ARC architecture, this work presents a necessary paradigm shift toward dynamic, selfimproving security for critical infrastructure.

title: Severity Assessment of Gas-Insulated Switchgear/Gas-Insulated Transmission Lines Partial Discharge Based on Adaptive Clustering
authors: Shu Niu, Sheng Liu, Zhigang Xue, Zhumao Lu, Na Wu, Hong Liu, Xianhao Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: Partial discharge (PD) induced by insulation defects in gas-insulated switchgear/gas-insulated transmission lines (GIS/GIL) is a primary cause of equipment failure. This study employs phase-resolved photon counting (PRPC) for PD detection due to its exceptional sensitivity and anti-interference capability. Three typical defect models - surface-attached metal, surface scratch, and metallic tip - were prepared. Using a custom-built detection platform, PD tests were conducted under incrementally increased step voltages, with PRPC data acquired based on timephase relationships. To address the challenge of parameter dependency in traditional clustering methods for optical PD pattern recognition, an adaptive K-means clustering algorithm optimized by the second-order difference elbow method was introduced. Experimental results demonstrate that the method automatically and accurately categorizes discharge states. Comparative analysis with conventional clustering methods confirms the superior performance of our approach in processing PRPC data, providing an effective solution for anti-interference intelligent diagnostics of GIS/GIL insulation conditions, and the effectiveness of the algorithm has been verified on field data.

title: On the Effects of Information-Bit Puncturing in Short-Length 5G NR LDPC Codes
authors: Jungim Kim, Yongseouk Choi, Heesang Chung, Youngjo Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In 5G NR systems, the three primary usage scenarios are enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communications (URLLC), and massive Machine Type Communications (mMTC). For data channels, LDPC codes were adopted as the standard channel coding scheme, initially optimized to meet the high-throughput requirements of eMBB services. As part of the LDPC coding process, a fixed puncturing strategy is applied to the information bits, which has been shown to improve system performance in eMBB scenarios. However, in URLLC and mMTC services, where transmissions are typically limited to short block lengths, the effect of information-bit puncturing may differ significantly. This paper investigates the impact of such puncturing on system performance under these short-block conditions.

title: Deepfake Detection: Bi-LSTM Framework with MobileNetV2
authors: Premanand V, Akil S, Aniruth Narayanan S
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: The combination of state-of-the-art deep learning technology which produces deepfakes causes major trust issues that affect people's ability to believe in digital materials. Most established detection methods analyze complete video frames even though they contain considerable useless background information. Such detection techniques perform worse while using more computational resources which makes them unpractical for real-time processing under resource-limited conditions. The proposed framework operates in real-time to detect deepfake changes specifically in facial areas because this is where the most likely fake modifications take place. The first step of the model uses Haar Cascade Classifiers to detect faces and separate them from the video frames. The facial regions undergo processing via MobileNetV2 to accomplish spatial feature extraction. A Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network serves as part of the model to detect temporal inconsistencies found between video sequences because they act as synthetic content indicators. The model uses an attention mechanism to improve understanding and channel its analysis toward essential temporal video segments. The system assessment on Celeb-DF (v2) yielded 95.55 % accuracy along with 89 % F1-score, 82 % precision and 97 % recall. The system demonstrates high efficiency for differentiating between genuine and fake video footage. The model demonstrates optimized performance with minimal processing requirements which enables its real-time use in digital forensic probes as well as media authentication checks and safeguarding applications during security operations. This study suggests an efficient approach to counter the dangeroud deepfake threats through the combination of facial area extraction and deep learning spatial interpretation and sequence-level time research. The proposed system delivers high precision in detection and maintains sufficient lightness to work effectively in mobile and edge computational platforms.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Free Cooling Capacity Optimization for Pharmaceutical Cleanroom HVAC Systems
authors: Joa Hyoung Lee, Hansol Shin, Chang Won Lee, Yoonmee Doh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Industrial cleanroom facilities, particularly in the pharmaceutical sector, consume substantial amounts of energy to meet stringent temperature and humidity control requirements mandated by Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) standards. During winter and transitional seasons, free cooling—utilizing ambient air via cooling towers and heat exchangers—offers a promising approach to reduce chiller operation and associated energy consumption. This study presents a reinforcement learning (RL) framework based on the Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm to determine the optimal capacities of chilled water tanks and heat exchangers for a pharmaceutical cleanroom HVAC system. A gym-based simulation environment was developed to model system dynamics and operational constraints, with multiple observation summarization strategies used to enhance temporal state representation. The reward function was designed to ensure cooling load satisfaction, minimize total energy use, and avoid frequent chiller cycling. Preliminary results demonstrate that the proposed RL framework can adaptively balance cooling load compliance and energy savings, and that transformer-based summarization shows potential for capturing complex temporal patterns in operational data.

title: RF Self-Interference Cancellation Circuits for Advanced Duplex Systems
authors: Gisung Yang, Hwan-Jae Cho, Sangwook Kim, Byung-Wook Min
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Advanced duplex systems promise enhancing of spectral efficiency by enabling simultaneous uplink and downlink transmissions in the same band, but they suffer from severe self-interference (SI) that must be mitigated in the analog domain before digitization. This paper reviews the application of RF self-interference cancellation (SIC) circuits—active cancellation using multi-tap RF cancellers with tunable attenuators, phase shifters, and delay controllers—to realize advanced duplex operation at gNodeBs. From published RF circuit implementations, how to implement three-tap RF cancellation for active cancellation is introduced. Experimental validation confirms that 30-dB active RF cancellation meets the analog SIC requirement for advanced duplex operated in in-band full-duplex mode. These results demonstrate the feasibility of employing proven RF front-end techniques to enable advanced duplex in next-generation communications.

title: AI-Powered Precision Agriculture: Integrating Smart Systems for Sustainable Yield Forecasting and Climate Resilience
authors: Suhail Jaiveer Malik, Kamal Kant Hiran, Tarkeshwar Barua, Ruchi Doshi
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Agricultural productivity faces ongoing challenges from climate variability, soil degradation, and constraints on resources. In this context, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a new disruptive technology in precision agriculture enabling anticipated recommendations using data-based predictions for improved decision-making. This paper presented XTR-Net, a new hybrid agronomic decision-making framework which supports a temporal modeling using Transformer architectures and Reinforcement Learning (RL) for on-the-go agronomic decision-making, and involves SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations) for model interpretation. The hybrid framework architecture is trained on a global, multi-year agricultural dataset made available from Kaggle, and includes key features including crop type, annual rainfall, temperature, pesticide use, and yield, all from multiple countries and climates. XTR-Net's performance was empirically evaluated, achieving a prediction accuracy of 96.3%, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.93, and RMSE of 0.019; XTR-Net outperformed benchmark models, Random Forest, LightGBM, and CNN-LSTM architectures. The Transformer model successfully described the temporal dependencies in year-to-year predictions, and the RL layer made it possible to optimally input data in real-time for the model to simulate the effect of adaptive interventions. The SHAP layer also provided clear, predicted feature explanations at the feature-level, so the model could address whether outcomes were only accurate, or both accurate and interpretable.

title: Privacy-Preserving Credit Scoring Using CKKS-Based Fully Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Arkan Dzaky Raihan Noor, Riska Audina Anindyasari, Muhammad Ogin Hasanuddin
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Credit scoring plays a crucial role in financial decision-making but inherently relies on highly sensitive personal and financial data, raising significant privacy concerns. Conventional credit scoring systems expose raw data to centralized servers, creating vulnerabilities to misuse, unauthorized access, or data breaches. To address this gap, we propose a privacypreserving credit scoring framework based on the CKKS scheme of Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE), which enables arithmetic operations to be performed directly on encrypted data without decryption. Our approach allows clients to encrypt their financial attributes before submission, while the credit scoring model executes inference entirely in the encrypted domain, ensuring that sensitive inputs remain confidential throughout the process. The results demonstrate that encrypted inference achieves accuracy comparable to plaintext computation, with negligible loss due to CKKS approximation, while incurring overhead in terms of latency, ciphertext expansion, and memory usage. We further analyze the trade-offs between performance and security levels to identify practical parameter settings. This work represents a novel demonstration of end-to-end encrypted credit scoring using CKKS-based FHE, highlighting its potential for deployment in privacy-sensitive financial applications.

title: A 56 Gb/s PAM-4 CDR Circuit Using Middle Transition Masking and Integrated Bit Decoding Schemes
authors: Seung-Gyun Kim, Won-Young Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a middle transition masking phase detector (MTM-PD) for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 6 ~ G b} / \mathbf{s}$</tex> pulse amplitude modulation-4 (PAM-4) quarter-rate clock and data recovery (CDR) circuit. The proposed MTM-PD identifies undesirable middle transitions based on Hamming distance and selectively masks phase updates to enhance input slew-rate tolerance. By integrating the data recovery path with the middle-transition masking path, the overall chip area and power consumption are reduced without degrading CDR locking performance. Compared to a conventional PAM-4 bang-bang phase detector (BBPD) with middle transition elimination block, the proposed MTM-PD achieves a power reduction of 7.5 % in the PD block. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed MTM-CDR consumes 38.24 mW and achieves energy efficiency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.68 \text{pJ} / \mathrm{b}$</tex> while recovering PAM-4 data.

title: Hand Gesture Controlled Robot Using STM32 Cortex-M4 and MPU6050
authors: Padala Suraj, G. V. Sai Sisindra Reddy, Jyoti Yadav, Gajanan R. Patil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: With the increasing integration of robotics in various domains, hand gesture-controlled robots have emerged as a promising solution for applications that require intuitive control. These robots are particularly useful in industrial automation, military reconnaissance, and hazardous environments where direct human intervention is not feasible. The paper presents a system that utilizes the MPU6050 sensor, which combines a 3-axis gyroscope and a 3-axis accelerometer to deliver accurate motion sensing. Gesture information is captured wirelessly through a Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) module. An STM32 Nucleo F446RE microcontroller board that contains an STM32 Cortex-M4-based chip is used to process signals in real time and control the robot. The use of this system increases efficiency, accuracy, and responsiveness over traditional control systems.

title: A Real-Time Framework for Prompt Injection Attacks Detection on Cloud-Hosted Large Language Models
authors: Rrezearta Thaqi, Edlira Martiri, Blerim Rexha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: This paper addresses the emerging threat of prompt injection attacks in cloud-hosted large language models (LLMs). These attacks manipulate LLM inputs, causing models to reveal sensitive information, generate harmful outputs, or perform unauthorized actions, significantly undermining data security and user trust. To counteract these threats, we introduce a real-time, modular detection framework that leverages advanced machine learning and natural language processing techniques. Our approach classifies input prompts as benign or malicious using a lightweight DistilBERT-based model, deployed on AWS SageMaker for scalable, low-latency inference. When malicious prompts are identified with high confidence, they are blocked at the gateway layer before reaching the LLM runtime, and structured telemetry events are forwarded to CloudWatch for alerting and auditing. Extensive evaluations in a realistic AWS environment demonstrate that DistilBERT not only exceeds the precision of larger state-of-the-art transformers (such as BERT-base, RoBERTa-large, and DeBERTa-v3) but also provides significantly lower inference latency and reduced deployment costs compared with traditional machine learning algorithms. The system design ensures extensibility, seamless integration with cloud-native services, and supports explainability, as well as potential future enhancements such as reinforcement learning-based adaptive detection. The proposed framework thus offers a practical and reliable defense mechanism against evolving adversarial threats, thereby strengthening the security posture and fostering trust in cloud-based AI technologies across various industries.

title: Predictive Modeling of Indian Startup Performance: A Multivariate Statistical Approach Incorporating Macroeconomic Indicators
authors: Preetnain Kaur Narula, Somesh Sharma, Rajesh Vaidya, Anant Deogaonkar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: An Entrepreneurial ecosystem is essential for effective entrepreneurial development in the economy. Macroenvironmental variable impacts the entrepreneurial ecosystem in the economy. Stability of the economy, political stability, economic stability and stability of financial system are taken as dependent variables while number of businesses registered is taken as dependent variable as a measure of entrepreneurial ecosystem. Regression analysis and correlation studies help to evaluate the connection among the variables that are both dependent and independent. Political stability (Political stability score), economic stability (GDP per capita) and financial stability (Value of NIFTY) are strongly correlated with the entrepreneurial ecosystem. The level of entrepreneurial ecosystem in the country depends on the stability of economy, it’s political system and its economic performance.

title: Dynamic Neuro-Fuzzy Regularization for Fairness-Aware Neural Networks Using Saliency Attribution
authors: Sahar Shah, Davide Ciucci, Sara Manzoni, Italo Zoppis
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Ensuring fairness in machine learning models, particularly neural networks, is critical in sensitive decision-making scenarios. This work introduces a novel bias mitigation strategy that integrates saliency-based attribution with a dynamically learnable neuro-fuzzy logic controller during model training. Unlike traditional fairness-aware models that rely on static constraints or post-hoc corrections, our approach embeds human-interpretable fairness rules directly into the loss function by penalizing models based on their reliance on sensitive features such as race, gender, and disability status. The fuzzy controller learns rule importance and feature saliency thresholds adaptively using differentiable membership functions and rule aggregation. Experimental validation on a synthetic dataset demonstrates that our method significantly reduces the saliency of sensitive features while maintaining classification accuracy. Comparative evaluations with a non-regularized baseline confirm that the proposed technique achieves superior fairness outcomes, validated with statistical significance testing. This approach offers a practical and interpretable pathway for enforcing fairness directly within neural decision-making systems.

title: Machine Learning-Based DDoS Attack Detection in Vehicular Adhoc Networks
authors: Venkateswari R, Venkatalakshmi R, Shankar N, Jaiwanti S, Prithvi S K, Bala Ranjith K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-hoc Networks(VANETs) are an essential component of intelligent transportation systems that enable real-time communication to enhance road safety and efficiently manage traffic. Because wireless communications are open and dynamic, VANETs are vulnerable to security attacks; the most important security need is availability. Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, in which infected systems band together as a botnet to overwhelm the network and deplete its resources, are among the most serious dangers. This research suggests a machine learning-based method to identify and counter DDoS attacks in VANETs, with the goal of maintaining the uninterrupted operation of vital services and protecting motorists. To reduce data dimensionality and improve detection accuracy, a hybrid feature selection technique combining particle swarm optimization (PSO) and the bat algorithm was created. This method helped identify only the most relevant features, thereby reducing the computational overhead and enhancing model performance. The proposed PSO-BAT + XGBoost model significantly surpassed other models in detecting DDoS attacks, achieving 99.98% accuracy and 99% precision, as well as a low packet loss rate of 0.04 %. The results clearly show that the proposed method offers a highly accurate, efficient, and reliable solution for detecting DDoS attacks in VANETs.

title: Adaptive Policy Optimization in Complex Decision-Making via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhiqiang Yu, Yilan Wei, Xiaolan Li, Peipei Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) demonstrates powerful performance in handling complex decision-making tasks, yet the adaptability and convergence efficiency of policies remain critical challenges. This paper proposes an Adaptive Policy Optimization Framework (APOF) that achieves faster convergence and superior performance in complex decision-making environments by dynamically adjusting learning rates and optimization weight parameters. We conduct comprehensive experimental validation across multiple simulated environments, demonstrating that the proposed method achieves a 32.4% improvement in convergence speed compared to baseline algorithms and an 18.7% improvement in final policy performance. Furthermore, the framework exhibits excellent generalization capability and computational efficiency. Specifically, convergence speed is measured by the number of training steps required for the average episodic reward to reach a stable plateau (within 5% variation over 500 consecutive steps), while final performance refers to the steady-state average return after convergence is achieved.

title: Q/V-Band Planar Array Antenna integrated with a Low-cost 3D Printed Dielectric Polarizer and lens
authors: Hakmin Lee, Seong-Mo Moon, Dongpil Chang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel circularly polarized antenna system for Q/V-band LEO satellite communications that integrates a microstrip patch antenna with a dielectric polarizer, cross-slot, and hemispherical lens. The key innovation is the dielectric cross-slot that simultaneously improves impedance matching and stabilizes axial ratio below 3 dB across the operating band. The single-element achieves 18.43 dBic peak gain with over 14.76 dB XPD, while the 1×5 array naturally generates multi-beam patterns with ±22° steering capability due to differential focal lengths. This design eliminates complex feeding networks while providing cost-effective mass production for LEO constellation deployments.

title: Error Correction Scheme Using Single-Parity-Check Codes and Correlation Receiver Output Levels in Optical SIK DS-CDMA Communications
authors: Akio Tsuneda, Takumi Yoshikawa
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: CDMA (code division multiple access) is still an attractive multiple access technique and it has been studied by many researchers, especially most of the recent works are for optical (or visible light) communications. In a correlation receiver of CDMA communication systems based on direct-sequence (DS) spread spectrum techniques, the higher output level is more reliable than the lower one, but the information of the output level is not used in normal decoding and only its sign (+ or −) is utilized for recovering the information bit. In this paper, a simple error-correction method using single-parity-check (SPC) codes and correlation receiver output levels in optical SIK (sequence inversion keyed) DS-CDMA communications is proposed. Though the SPC codes are 1-bit error-detecting codes (i.e., they have no error-correction ability), we show by computer simulations that the proposed error-correction method can correct some error bits and finally reduce the bit error rate. A theoretical analysis of bit error probability after the proposed error correction is also given.

title: Fast and Stable Frequency Tuning of Optoelectronic Terahertz Waves Using Optical Single-Sideband Modulation
authors: Bo Li, Tomohiro Tetsumoto, Ming Che, Masato Kawano, Shenghong Ye, Yuya Mikami, Norihiko Sekine, Kazutoshi Kato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: Rapid and stable terahertz (THz) frequency tuning is crucial for emerging applications like 6G communications and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC). This paper demonstrates a novel optoelectronic scheme, employing fixed-wavelength lasers, tunable optical single-sideband modulation (SSBM), and optoelectronic photomixing in a uni-traveling carrier photodiode (UTC-PD) to achieve such agility. The system leverages the capability of SSBM for precise and rapid sideband control, achieving 6.3 GHz frequency sweeps around 300 GHz within 15 ns and supporting diverse modulation waveforms (step, triangular, sine). This approach offers a concise, efficient, and potentially cost-effective solution for advanced THz systems, significantly contributing to the development of flexible and high-performance THz sources.

title: Design of a Progressive MAC for Drone RC Data Protection
authors: Joungil Yun, Seungyong Yoon, Byoungkoo Kim, Daewon Kim, Yousung Kang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes a progressive message authentication code (MAC) scheme for securing remote control (RC) command data in drone systems. The scheme aims to ensure data integrity under unstable wireless conditions while reducing communication overhead for short-length messages that are frequently transmitted. To improve upon conventional MAC aggregation techniques, we introduce a modified structure that not only incorporates controlled inter-message dependencies but also minimizes inter-bit dependency overlap by employing randomized bit selection. This design is intended to enhance resilience against message loss while progressively strengthening authentication guarantees with ongoing data reception.

title: Data Quality Analysis Framework for Defense Objective Detection Systems
authors: Seungil Noh, Eunjin Choi, Jeongho Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Modern defense systems have increasingly adopted object detection technologies to enhance operational capabilities across surveillance, threat assessment, and tactical intelligence applications. However, existing image quality evaluation methods rely heavily on global metrics, which fail to capture the object-specific quality characteristics that critically influence detection performance in defense scenarios where environmental conditions and operational constraints create unique challenges. To address these fundamental limitations, we present a comprehensive data quality inspection framework that systematically employs 302 quality metrics organized across 14 specialized categories, enabling quantitative assessment of image datasets without requiring expensive computational infrastructure. Throughout extensive evaluation using the PASCAL VOC dataset, our GPGPU-based parallel processing system achieves over 100 images/sec throughput while generating comprehensive quality analysis, demonstrating both technical feasibility and cost-effectiveness for defense organizations with varying computational resources.

title: Broadband linearly frequency-modulated signal generation based on bias switching of MZM
authors: Zheng Wang, Ying Xu, Xukai Ji, Feifei Yin, Yitang Dai, Kun Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A photonic-assisted scheme to generate broadband linearly frequency-modulated signal based on a Mach–Zehnder modulator (MZM) and a dual parallel Mach–Zehnder modulator (DPMZM) is proposed and simulated. The DPMZM is biased to derive carrier suppression even-order dual-sideband modulation and the MZM is biased between the maximum transmission point (MATP) and minimum transmission point (MITP) via a square wave. The switching of the bias states achieves the switching of the 1st order sideband and 2nd order sideband in the spectrum of MZM. In the simulation, the bandwidth of input linearly frequency-modulated (LFM) signal is expanded by 4 times and the time-bandwidth product (TBWP) is enlarged by 8 times. Meanwhile, the generated broadband LFM signal owns positive and negative dual chirp. The proposed scheme not only meets the requirements of the smaller range resolution and further range but also effectively resists range ambiguities in radar systems.

title: Serverless Deployment of an Ensemble Machine Learning Model for Diabetes Prediction: A Practical Study on Challenges and Cost Optimization
authors: Naween Kumar, Dhananjay Kumar, Sharmila, Puru Raj Dhama, Suchita Yadav
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Application of machine learning has demonstrated the potential and good results in diabetes prediction and advancements in early diagnosis and proactive healthcare management. The bigger challenge that should be addressed in this case is the practical implementation of these models because the scalability of these models is a significant issue, especially when it comes to using serverless architecture. We formulate and operationalize an excellent ensemble learning model of diabetes prediction with a tuned neural network, a random forest regressor and a gradient boosting regressor in this research. Hyperparameter tuning was done with Keras Tuner to enhance predictive accuracy. The ensemble is also deployed as a function with Google Cloud Functions. We face and write about practical challenges concerning the inference latency of the TensorFlow inference, cold starting and resource constraints of a serverless architecture. Additional Performance benchmarking is done, and cold start and warm start simulation was performed and captured. The Findings indicate significant trade-offs in the accuracy, deployment efficiency and the operational costs. The paper provides essential knowledge on future large-scale machine learning deployments of cloud platforms.

title: An Analysis of Password Manager Adoption and Trust Among Indonesian Digital Users
authors: Muhammad Malik Pandu Galang, Fadhil Pratama, Yudhistira Nugraha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Password managers are a cornerstone of modern digital security, offering features to generate and store strong, unique passwords. Despite their benefits, adoption remains inconsistent. This study investigates the behaviors and perceptions surrounding password manager usage and the adoption of randomly generated passwords (RGPs) among a cohort of 50 Indonesian users. Through a survey, we analyzed user demographics, their frequency of using password managers, trust in these tools, and password creation habits. Our findings reveal a significant gap between the availability of security features and their adoption. A majority of participants (62 %) have never used an RGP, and a significant 66 % prefer always to create their own passwords. Trust in password managers is varied, with a slight majority expressing trust, and it appears to be a factor in usage patterns. While a large number of users (74 %) recall seeing RGP suggestions, the nudge to use them is largely ineffective for this group. These results highlight a challenge in usable security: the mere presence of a feature does not guarantee its use. User trust and entrenched habits of manually creating passwords are significant barriers that need to be addressed to improve the security posture.

title: An Error-Aware Automatic Grading Framework for Python Programs Based on Structural-Semantic Similarity
authors: Xue Han, Jinwei Wang, Jiayi Che, Jinwei Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Most automatic grading systems for Python rely on the built-in ast module to construct abstract syntax trees (ASTs), but they fail when programs contain syntax errors, limiting their use in real exams. To overcome this, we propose a static grading method based on the Parso library, which is able to construct syntax trees for programs containing syntax errors by explicitly marking error nodes. Building on this, we introduce an erroraware grading framework that simulates human evaluation: student programs are analyzed to identify and classify syntax errors, critical errors are minimally corrected with penalties assigned by error category, and the corrected programs are assessed against reference solutions using structural and semantic similarity metrics. Experiments on exam data show that the method effectively handles erroneous programs and yields grading results closely aligned with human assessments.

title: Inventory Model for a Deteriorating Item with Multivariate Demand under Inflation, Weibull Deterioration, and Learning Effects
authors: Sanjay Singh, Lokesh Sharma, Manoj Mangal, Rajesh Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
