abstract: This research article formulates an EOQ-centric inventory model concerning a perishable good, focusing on a combination of multivariate time and price sensitive and demand, Weibull-deterioration, inflation, and learning effects. The model accounts for real-world considerations like purchasing and holding cost inflation, flexible Weibull deterioration, and learning effects which decrease production/setup time and cost with increasing experience. The research article enables us to determine the total cost and to develop an appropriate solution method to minimize it. A numerical example serves for demonstrating the model.

title: Mamba2 Meets Silence: Robust Vocal Source Separation for Sparse Regions
authors: Euiyeon Kim, Yong-Hoon Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: We introduce a new music source separation model tailored for accurate vocal isolation. Unlike Transformer-based approaches, which often fail to capture intermittently occurring vocals, our model leverages Mamba2, a recent state space model, to better capture long-range temporal dependencies. To handle long input sequences efficiently, we combine a band-splitting strategy with dual-path architecture. Experiments show that our approach outperforms recent state-of-the-art models, achieving a cSDR of 11.03 dB—the best reported to date—and achieving substantial improvements in uSDR. Moreover, the model exhibits stable and consistent performance across varying input lengths and vocal occurrence patterns. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of Mamba-based models for high-resolution audio processing and open up new directions for broader applications in audio research.

title: Leveraging Bi-LSTM Networks for Reliable Recognition of Doctors’ Handwriting
authors: Sarangam Kodati, Sreenivasulu Gogula, Kanchan Yadav, Jai Singh Wilson, Maitri Yadav, Shailendra Singh Sikarwar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Deciphering doctors’ handwritten prescriptions has long been a challenging task for humans. While several studies have attempted to automate handwritten text recognition, accurately transcribing medical prescriptions remains a critical hurdle for real-world deployment. This paper introduces a novel hybrid model that combines Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) networks, optimized with Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) loss, to address the complexity of non-printed handwritten prescriptions. The model integrates spatial feature extraction through CNN with sequential dependency learning via Bi-LSTM, thereby reducing misinterpretations and achieving high recognition accuracy on a segmented test dataset. The iterative training plan, which has been specifically developed keeping in mind computational efficiency, allows one to train continuously with minimal overfitting. The suggested solution manages variability in handwriting and prescription-text contextual dependencies well. Having an incredible recognition rate of 98.40, the study adds a powerful solution that makes the workflow of the clinic more efficient and efficient and makes the process of handling healthcare information more effective and efficient.

title: Physical Design Implementation and Power Optimization of RV32I RISC-V Processor
authors: Devang Kailashkumar Vekariya, Gaurav Saini, Ashutosh Raghuvir Manohar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The development of VLSI physical design and technological scaling has allowed for the integration of a high number of transistors on a single chip, improving performance, power efficiency, and area usage. However, when the technology node decreases, other issues arise, such as increasing connection resistance, power dissipation, and timing closure complexity. This study describes the physical design implementation of an RV32I RISC-V processor utilizing a 45 nm open-source PDK, with a focus on the effects of technology scaling and power optimization. The design was implemented using open-source tools like Yosys for synthesis, OpenROAD for placement and routing, KLayout for signoff verification, and OpenTimer for static timing analysis (STA). Clock gating was applied, leading to a 13.84 % reduction in dynamic power consumption, significantly improving power efficiency. A comparative analysis with a 130 nm implementation further demonstrated a 18.9 % reduction in total power, highlighting the benefits of smaller technology nodes. Furthermore, STA results indicated that the design satisfied all timing constraints, allowing for steady operation at 130 MHz with no timing violations.

title: Overcoming Class Imbalance in Protein-Protein Interaction and Isozyme Prediction: GAN-Based Augmentation in a Transformer-GNN Framework
authors: Raghad J. AbuNasser, Gina R. Maayah, Yaser Jararweh, Mostafa Z. Ali, Ghina’A Abu Deiab, Robert G. Reynolds, Talal Z. Ali, Ponnuthurai N. Suganthan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: While the prediction of Protein–Protein Interactions (PPIs) and the identification of Isozymes are central to advancing Drug Discovery (DD), most of the existing computational approaches are hindered by class imbalance of biomedical datasets, limiting their ability to generalize across protein analyses tasks. In this work, we propose a framework that tackles this problem using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) within a Transformer–Graph Neural Network (GNN) hybrid model. The sequential strengths of transformers are combined with the relational learning capacity of GNNs, while GAN-based augmentation generates realistic synthetic protein sequences, enriching underrepresented classes and alleviating imbalance-driven bias. Using three benchmark datasets; DBPred, GraphBind, and UniProtKB the framework achieved state-of-the-art performance, with precision reaching up to 97% in PPI prediction and significant gains in Isozyme classification. This study underscores how GAN-enhanced modeling can overcome limitations of data scarcity and imbalance, and the dual advantage of hybrid deep learning and adversarial data augmentation, offering a scalable and generalizable approach for PPI prediction and Isozyme estimation. Moreover, the proposed model not only improves predictive performance but also enhances interpretability for more reliable applications of computational methods in DD and proteins analyses.

title: A GPT for Ecore Model Building
authors: Zobia Erum, Issam Al-Azzoni
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Model-Driven Engineering (MDE) relies on formal models, yet constructing them from natural language specifications remains a manual and error-prone task. Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) such as GPT suggest new opportunities for automating this process. This work presents a GPT-based system fine-tuned to generate valid Ecore models in the sclang smart contract access control modeling language. The approach bridges natural language input and formal metamodel artifacts, reducing effort while improving correctness. A case study on access control models illustrates the effectiveness of the method.

title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning Models for Cloud Computing Performance Metrics
authors: Anita Murmu, Naween Kumar, Ojal Agarwal, Shruti Kashyap
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The modern-day IT infrastructure is based on cloud computing and its scalable, flexible, and cost-efficient services. As the size and complexity of cloud systems grow, performance metrics like CPU utilisation, memory, latency, and throughput can be monitored as a necessary metric to manage the consumption of energy and operational cost. This article explains the reasons why ML and DL models that operate on raw and optimized datasets enhance the accuracy of prediction, execution, and power consumption. Two data sets were used, and they consisted of a raw dataset and dataset that had been optimized by feature engineering and hyperparameter optimization. The models that were evaluated, which included Random Forest, LightGBM, XGBoost, LSTM, and hybrids (LSTM+CNN, LSTM+ANN), were compared in terms of such metrics as the accuracy, precision, recall, $\mathbf{F 1}$-score, and specificity. The findings indicate the significance of model and data optimization choices to optimize clouds, and this can be helpful in the context of cloud architects, DevOps teams and researchers.

title: High-Risk Silent Student Prediction Model Based on LightGBM with Multi-Dimensional Questionnaire Data
authors: Jing Liu, Ruoyu Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Identifying at-risk students in English as a Foreign Language (EFL) learning is crucial for timely educational intervention, yet existing approaches often suffer from limited predictive accuracy and lack of interpretability. This paper proposes an interpretable machine learning framework that integrates LightGBM with SMOTE augmentation, feature interaction engineering, and SHAP-based explainability to predict at-risk EFL learners in Chinese higher education. We collected data from 400 university students, capturing psychological factors including language anxiety, self-efficacy, learning motivation, classroom environment perception, and teacher-student relationships. To address class imbalance, SMOTE was applied to augment minority high-risk samples. Feature interaction terms were engineered to capture non-linear relationships between psychological constructs. The LightGBM model was trained using gradient boosting with early stopping regularization. SHAP values were computed to provide both global feature importance ranking and local instance-level explanations. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework achieves superior performance (88.9% accuracy, 85.2% recall, 0.92 AUC) compared to baseline models including Logistic Regression, Random Forest, SVM, and XGBoost. Ablation studies confirm that SMOTE improves recall by 10.6 percentage points, while feature interactions enhance accuracy by 2.7 percentage points. SHAP analysis reveals that language anxiety is the strongest predictor (SHAP value: 0.31), with interaction features accounting for three of the top ten most important factors. Case studies illustrate how SHAP-based explanations enable personalized interventions such as anxiety reduction strategies and environmental modifications. This work bridges the gap between predictive performance and practical utility, providing educators with a transparent, actionable tool for early identification and targeted support of struggling language learners. The proposed framework demonstrates the potential of interpretable machine learning to transform educational practice from reactive remediation to proactive, evidence-based intervention.

title: Additional AC Copper Losses in the Field Winding of Converter-Fed Synchronous Machines for Pumped Storage Hydropower Plants
authors: Andreas Ridder, Dirk Emmrich, Bernd Ponick
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: Converter-fed synchronous machines for variable speed pumped storage hydropower plants are becoming increasingly important as the share of fluctuating renewable energy increases. The inverter connected to the stator terminals causes additional harmonic currents in the stator winding, which induce additional harmonic currents in the field winding. Due to the eddy current effects and the typical form-wound coil design, these additional harmonic currents in the field winding can lead to significant additional losses, even with relatively small amplitudes. The aim of this paper is to calculate these additional losses. Therefore, numerical calculations are used to determine the resistance factor for a frequency band from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{0}\,\text{Hz}$</tex-math></inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{15}\,\text{kHz}$</tex-math></inline-formula> while also considering saturation. In addition, two measurements are carried out on a research hydro generator at different inverter switching frequencies. Using the measured currents and determined resistance factors, the additional losses due to the switching frequency are calculated and validated using a temperature measurement in the field winding. The results of this work are important for the future design and cooling of large converter-fed synchronous machines with form-wound field coils, as the additional AC losses in the field winding are usually neglected.

title: NAMSA: A Non-dominated Archived Multi-objective Simulated Annealing Algorithm for Detecting Influencers in Social Networks
authors: Puja Bhakta, Debaditya Barman, Taniya Chatterjee, Mili Ghosh, Rahul Karmakar, Abu Sufian, Marco Leo, Cosimo Distante
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Social networks have become an integral part of our daily lives, providing an effective platform for communication, sharing information, and social interaction.With the explosive growth of social networks, the study of influence maximization (IM) in social networks has gained significant attention. IM refers to the process of identifying a small set of individuals, called influencers, who can initiate a cascade of events leading to the maximum spread of influence in the network. This paper proposes a non-dominated archived multi-objective simulated annealing (NAMSA) algorithm for detecting influencers in social networks. Our proposed algorithm maintains an archive of non-dominated solutions and uses a new mechanism to generate new solutions.We compare the results of the NAMSA algorithm with six other state-of-the-art algorithms and show that the NAMSA algorithm outperforms them. Furthermore, we propose a dynamicNAMSA(DNAMSA) algorithm suited for dynamic social networks and showthat it performs better than four existing algorithms. The time complexities of proposed NAMSA and DNAMSA are comparable with other algorithms considered for comparison, and all the results are statistically significant.

title: UAVRS-CompNet: An End-to-End Compression Network for UAV Remote Sensing Images
authors: Haoran Xu, Hongxin Jiang, Xiaodao Chen, Xiaohui Huang, Yuewei Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) remote sensing images are characterized by high resolution, complex textures, and multi-scale ground object features, making their compression and reconstruction more challenging compared to natural images. To enhance the compression performance for UAV remote sensing imagery, this paper proposes an end-to-end deep learning-based compression network named UAVRS-CompNet. At its core, the model employs a Multi-scale Residual Bidirectional Pyramid Backbone (MRBPB) to replace traditional Generalized Divisive Normalization (GDN) and its inverse transformation IGDN modules, thereby strengthening feature extraction and reconstruction capabilities. Additionally, a Dual-Branch Synergistic Attention Module (DSAM) is introduced to achieve cooperative feature enhancement in both spatial and frequency domains, improving the model's adaptive feature extraction and representation capacity for complex textures and multi-scale objects. A dedicated UAV remote sensing image dataset containing diverse ground object types is constructed for comprehensive experimental evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms several state-of-the-art learning-based compression methods across various bitrates, achieving the best performance in both PSNR and MS-SSIM metrics. Furthermore, visual comparisons reveal that UAVRS-CompNet more effectively preserves ground object details and texture information, leading to higher-quality image reconstruction. The proposed method provides a viable and superior solution for efficient compression and high-fidelity reconstruction of UAV remote sensing imagery.

title: Model Hijacking Attack in Federated Learning
authors: Zheng Li, Siyuan Wu, Ruichuan Chen, Paarijaat Aditya, Istemi Ekin Akkus, Manohar Vanga, Min Zhang, Hao Li, Yang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Machine learning (ML), driven by prominent paradigms such as centralized and federated learning, has made significant progress in various critical applications. However, its remarkable success has been accompanied by various attacks. Recently, the model hijacking attack has shown that ML models can be hijacked to execute tasks different from their original tasks, which increases both accountability and parasitic computational risks. Nevertheless, thus far, this attack has only focused on centralized learning. In this work, we broaden the scope of this attack to the federated learning domain, where multiple clients collaboratively train a global model without sharing their data. Specifically, we present the first-of-its-kind hijacking attack against the global model in federated learning, namely HijackFL. The adversary aims to force the global model to perform a different task (called hijacking task) from its original task without the server or benign client noticing. To accomplish this, unlike existing methods that use data poisoning to modify the target model’s parameters, HijackFL searches for pixel-level perturbations based on their local model (without modifications) to align hijacking samples with the original ones in the feature space. When performing the hijacking task, the adversary applies these perturbations to the hijacking samples, compelling the global model to identify them as original ones and predict them accordingly. Extensive experiments demonstrate HijackFL significantly outperforms baselines, e.g., 92.75% vs. 10%. We further investigate the factors that affect its performance and discuss possible defenses to mitigate its impact.

title: Structural Analysis and Design Optimization of the ITER Upper Port-Mounted Bolometer Cameras
authors: Nikola Jaksic, Zhongwei Wang, Hans Meister, Adam Pataki, Villarejo Miguel Ángel, Javier Rodríguez Casado
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: The development of the bolometer camera structural design is especially challenging because of the extreme environmental conditions within the vacuum vessel (VV) during plasma operation. Reliable measurements have to be assured while being subjected to high neutron fluxes as well as plasma radiation resulting in temperatures of the components exceeding <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$200~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C. In addition to the thermal loads, the bolometer camera housing is exposed to mechanical loads caused by electromagnetic (EM) forces during transient events of the plasma operation, called disruptions. Due to the fact that the surrounding structure of the diagnostic shield module (DSM) within the upper and equatorial ports was already determined in advance, extensive design adaptation of all bolometer cameras was required. Extensive numerical analyses were carried out with the aim of achieving structural stability of the camera main body on the one hand and thermal requirements on the camera and sensors on the other hand. In a multiphysics analysis loop, several cycles were performed, starting with the EM, followed by a thermomechanical and structural analysis. In addition, the seismic and gravity loads and load scenarios, like inductive and noninductive plasma radiation as well as fatigue cycles, need to be considered. This article gives an overview of such a comprehensive analysis on the example of bolometer cameras mounted in the upper port and presents the results achieved as well as the compromises taken.

title: Fed-Grow: Federating to Grow Transformers for Resource-Constrained Users Without Model Sharing
authors: Shikun Shen, Yifei Zou, Yuan Yuan, Hanlin Gu, Peng Li, Xiuzhen Cheng, Falko Dressler, Dongxiao Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: The growing resource demands of large-scale transformer models pose significant challenges for resource-constrained users, particularly in distributed environments. To address this issue, we propose a federated learning framework called Fed-Grow, which enables multiple participants to collaboratively learn a lightweight scaling operation that transfers knowledge from pretrained small models to a large transformer model. In Fed-Grow, we introduce the Dual-LiGO (Dual Linear Growth Operator) architecture, consisting of Local-LiGO and Global-LiGO components. Local-LiGO addresses model heterogeneity by adapting each participant's pre-trained model to a common intermediate form, while Global-LiGO facilitates knowledge sharing across participants without sharing local models or raw data, ensuring privacy preservation. This federated approach offers a scalable solution for growing large transformers in a distributed manner, where only the Global-LiGO is shared, significantly reducing communication overhead while maintaining comparable model performance under the same communication constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that Fed-Grow outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and precision, while reducing the number of trainable parameters by 59.25% and communication costs by 73.01%. These improvements allow for higher efficiency in training large models in distributed environments, without sacrificing performance. To the best of our knowledge, Fed-Grow is the first method that enables cooperative transformer scaling in a distributed setting, making it a practical solution for resource-constrained users.

title: Robust Pseudolabel Subspace Learning for E-nose Drift Compensation
authors: Feng-Jie Zou, Jia Yan
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: Sensor drift severely degrades the long-term reliability of electronic nose (E-nose) systems, as temporal and device-induced variations distort the feature distributions of gas responses. Existing drift compensation approaches often require labeled target-domain or calibration samples, which are difficult to obtain in practical deployments, and conventional pseudolabeling strategies are vulnerable to noisy labels under severe drift. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a robust pseudolabel-based subspace learning (RPSL) method for unsupervised E-nose drift compensation. RPSL employs a dual-stage pseudolabel filtering mechanism that selects high-confidence target samples via support vector machine (SVM) margins and further enforces prediction consistency through prototype learning. On the basis of these reliable samples, a unified subspace learning model is constructed to align source and target distributions by minimizing the mean, covariance, and prototype discrepancies while integrating graph embedding linear discriminant analysis (LDA) to increase discriminability in the projected space. Experiments on two benchmark E-nose drift datasets under multiple transfer settings show that RPSL achieves stable and high classification accuracy without requiring any target-domain labels, demonstrating its effectiveness and robustness for practical drift compensation.

title: Study on the Relationship Between Gradual Timing Adjustment Rate and UE Velocity in LEO NTN
authors: Yeongchae Noh, Seokhyeon No, Min-Gyu Kim, Jeongchang Kim, Pansoo Kim, Jae-Young Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite-based Non-Terrestrial Network (NTN) environments, the propagation delay continuously changes due to the relative movement between the User Equipment (UE) and the satellite, making time synchronization challenging. To achieve accurate time synchronization under these difficult conditions, New Radio (NR) NTN employs a combination of open-loop and closed-loop timing advances (TAs). However, when both TA mechanisms attempt to compensate for the same delay simultaneously, a phenomenon known as double correction may occur, leading to increased synchronization errors. To address this issue, the NR NTN employs a gradual timing adjustment for open-loop TA. This paper evaluates timing errors caused by double correction through computer simulations, considering various UE velocities and gradual timing adjustment rates.

title: Design and Implementation of a Software Interface for an AI Modem
authors: Yunjoo Kim, Jungbo Son, Yuro Lee, JungSook Bae
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This study focuses on the design and implementation of two system software interfaces. These interfaces reduce data processing latency between a field programmable gate array (FPGA) and a graphics processing unit (GPU) in an artificial intelligence (AI)-based wireless modem system. Experimental results indicate that the shared memory-based interface achieved lower and more stable latency than the transmission control protocol/internet protocol (TCP/IP)-based interface and is well suited for real-time systems.

title: Close the Valley of Death - A Deployable Sniffer Robot For Hazardous Substances
authors: Gerald Steinbauer-Wagner, Yazen Mohammad Baker Rihan, Raimund Edlinger, Gerald Czech, Michael Jost, Christian Resch, Richard Halatschek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: The detection of hazardous substances during emergencies is a critical yet dangerous task for first responders. Mobile sensing robots can reduce the risk. Nevertheless, field-ready deployable systems are rare. This paper presents an initiative to provide a deployable sniffer robot for hazardous substance detection. Special care is taken to ensure integration into fire service operations by providing standard operating procedures and eliminating dependency on GNSS or external communication infrastructure. Utilizing the off-the-shelf components for mobility and sensing, combined with onboard data processing, communication, and visualization, the system enables remote, real-time environmental monitoring. Initial field evaluations with Austrian firefighting units demonstrate promising results in mobility, usability, and operational effectiveness. The project aims to close the "Valley of Death" between research and real-world deployment through field-ready design, provision of training concepts, and realistic validation.

title: Parkinson Image Synthesis and Classification using Deep Learning
authors: Chavan Shivam Sandip, Aravindkumar Sekar, Angalaeswari S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Parkinson's Disease (PD) affects the central nervous system. Early detection of PD will help cure the disease before it affects the brain. To detect the PD affected patients we deployed Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) model. Our proposed model consists of three sub-networks. Initially, the spiral PD and healthy images were synthesised using generator network. Then, the discriminator network helps to discriminate the synthesised images are real or fake. Finally, classifier model is implemented to classify the input image is PD or healthy.Inception Score and Frechet Inception Distance (FID) metrics were used to measure the quality of the synthesised images by obtaining the value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.0 \pm 0.2$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$53.59 \pm 0.3$</tex> respectively.Metric like Precision, Recall, F1-Measure and Accuracy are used to evaluate the classifier model by achieving the value of 0.97,0.99,0.98 and 0.98 respectively. Our model performs better when compared with the other state-of-the-art methods.

title: A 2-4GHz Wideband Transmitter Front-End for FMCW Through-Wall Radar Applications
authors: Yunqi Yang, Haoyu Shen, Hao Lei, Zhigang Fu, Pengcheng Wang, Yilin Xu, Fanxun Cai, Xiao Fang, Hui Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a 2–4 GHz wideband trans-mitter (Tx) front-end for a S-band through-wall frequency-modulated continuous waves (FMCW) radar transceiver, im-plemented in 40nm CMOS technology. The Tx front-end comprises a power divider (PD), a power amplifier (PA), and a distributed passive matching network (DPMN). To split the signal generated by the voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) into two amplitude-controlled paths, to Tx front-end and Rx, a power divider circuit based on an equivalent lumped element model is proposed, with optimization performed through EMX simulations. Due to priority of linearity, A Class-A biased gain controllable power amplifier is designed to achieve wide bandwidth while addressing non-linearity concerns, providing stable per-formance across the bandwidth, with a power-added efficiency (PAE) of 21.5%. The whole Tx front-end in a FMCW TWR chip delivers maximum 14dBm output with a drain efficiency of 7.8% (low power input from VCO buffer), occupying 0.704 mm2, The spectrum measurement results of the FMCW input signal and the actual target detection results of the TWR in multiple scenarios prove that the proposed Tx front-end has robust per-formance and stability, balancing linearity, area and band-width.

title: Hybrid CAViaR Dream Optimization Enabled Deep Cascade Learning for Pneumonia Detection using Chest X-Ray Images
authors: LLS Maneesha, Priyanka Bharti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Pneumonia is a potentially life-threatening infection in the lungs caused by bacterial or viral pathogens. Timely identification is crucial to enable immediate treatment and improve patient outcomes. Although chest X-rays are commonly used for detection, their interpretation can be complex and subject to human variability. To tackle these issues, a potent model named CAViaR Dream Optimization Algorithm enabled Deep Cascade Learning (CaDOA_Deep Cascade Learning), is designed for Pneumonia detection using Chest X-ray images. Here, the input Chest X-ray image is subjected to de-noising using the Kolmogorov–Wiener Filter. Then, lung lobe segmentation is performed by employing LadderNet. Thereafter, Gray Level Run Length Matrix (GLRM) features are extracted in the feature extraction phase. Lastly, Pneumonia detection is accomplished by employing Deep Cascade Learning. Moreover, the parameters of Deep Cascade Learning are trained using the CAViaR Dream Optimization Algorithm (CaDOA). Here, CaDOA is designed by merging Dream Optimization Algorithm (DOA) and the Conditional Autoregressive Value at Risk (CAViaR). Moreover, CaDOA_Deep Cascade Learning has attained 96.354% of accuracy, 95.740% of True Positive Rate (TPR), and 97.326% of True Negative Rate (TNR).

title: Prompt Injection Detection and Mitigation with AI Multiagent NLP-based Agentic Frameworks
authors: Diego Gosmar, Deborah A. Dahl, Dario Gosmar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Prompt injection is a significant challenge for generative AI systems because it can lead to unintended outputs. We introduce a Multiagent NLP-based experimental framework, specifically designed to address prompt injection vulnerabilities through layered detection and metadata mechanisms. The framework orchestrates specialized AI agents to generate responses, detect vulnerabilities, and mitigate injection effects. An empirical evaluation of 500 engineered injection prompts was conducted, with ten different prompt injection categories properly generated and shuffled (50 prompts for each injection attack category). The experimental results show a significant reduction in the injection score and an increased detection of prompt injection markers, indicating potential applications for mitigation. Novel metrics—including Injection Success Rate (ISR), Policy Override Frequency (POF), Prompt Sanitization Rate (PSR), and Compliance Consistency Score (CCS)—are proposed to derive a composite Total Injection Vulnerability Score (TIVS). The system utilizes the vendor-independent OFP (Open Floor Protocol) framework for agentic AI communication via structured JSON messages. It encapsulates APIs using natural language while also comparing and extending a previously established multiagent experiment on hallucination mitigation to address the specific challenges of prompt injection.

title: Large language model-based copilot for planning and executing of co-active USAR missions using actionable semantic scene graphs
authors: Frederik Bark, Kevin Daun, Oskar von Stryk
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Remote operation of robots in urban search and rescue (USAR) scenarios can impose significant physical and cognitive demands on human operators. To alleviate this, modern robotic systems can offer (semi-)autonomous capabilities and teleoperation assistance. However, effective mission planning remains difficult due to the complexity and variability of disaster environments. In this work, we introduce a novel AI assistant system designed to support the planning and execution of such USAR missions by accepting natural language task descriptions and generating grounded task plans for the robotic system. Our copilot system facilitates coactive planning, dynamically adapting between autonomous execution, assisted operation, or teleoperation based on expected costs and operator-provided specifications. We combine the capabilities of large language models (LLMs) and graph optimization, leveraging information from a scene graph-based environment representation to propose a novel, robust framework that translates natural language instructions into a grounded sequence of actions. Our evaluations in a complex USAR scenario show superior and more robust planning performance over direct LLMs prompting, especially for long-horizon tasks and in reliably avoiding task-related hallucinations.

title: Flexible Learning Pathways with AI-Powered Personalized Tutoring: Design and Implementation of an Innovative Educational Model
authors: Israel Zamora-Hernández, Miguel X. Rodriguez-Paz, Jorge A. González-Mendivil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This study presents the implementation of an AIpowered educational model in a one-week intensive MATLAB course for engineering students. Designed to promote personalized learning through daily challenges and a GPT-based virtual tutor, the model supported flexible progression and conceptual guidance. Seventeen students participated, with assessments including pre/post exams, a perception survey, and over 500 formative questions. Results showed improved performance, reduced score variability, and high student satisfaction. Learners valued the model’s adaptability and reported gains in critical thinking and technical skills. These findings highlight the potential of generative AI to enhance engagement, equity, and scalability in STEM education.

title: Deep Learning-Based Smart Contract Vulnerability Detection Model
authors: Rui Wu, Guangfu Wu, Kangjun Li, Lei Liu, Lulu Liu, Weiqiang Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: As blockchain technology matures, the application scope of smart contracts continues to expand. Security issues in smart contracts have become an important research focus. In view of the limitations of traditional vulnerability detection methods such as limited vulnerability types and high false positive rate, this paper proposes a smart contract vulnerability detection model based on deep learning. By constructing token sequence sets and data flow graphs and inputting them into the pre-training model of this article, we obtained a pre-training model optimized for Solidity code and implemented a multi-label classifier in the downstream detection layer. The proposed model can detect integer overflow vulnerabilities, transaction sequence dependency vulnerabilities, timestamp vulnerabilities, and reentrancy vulnerabilities in the target contract. Experiments show that this model is better than other detection tools in detection effect.

title: Deployment of a Predictive Model for Identifying High-Risk Patients for Hospital-Acquired Infections
authors: Shakhrijakhon Aminqulov, Raykhan Razakova, Sahil Gupta, Anorgul Atajanova, Gularam Masharipova, Sultonmakhmud Polvanov
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Hospital-acquired infections (HAIs) are a significant risk to the sustainability of the healthcare system and patient safety because they impact 5-15 percent of hospitalised patients across the globe and elevate the mortality, morbidity, and healthcare expenses. This research will be focused on developing and deploying a machine learning predictive model capable of assisting in the identification of patients with the highest risks of developing HAIs within the hospital and take proactive interventions. Our approach used a detailed examination of electronic health records of $\mathbf{1 5, 0 0 0}$ patients in various hospital units and performed the ensemble learning algorithm of Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost to compute demographic, clinical, laboratory, and procedural variables. Feature selection was performed using recursive feature elimination and importance scoring to identify the most predictive risk factors. The deployed model achieved an accuracy of 87.3%, sensitivity of 84.6%, specificity of 89.1%, and an area under the ROC curve (AUC) of 0.912, significantly outperforming traditional risk assessment methods. Key predictive factors identified include length of stay, invasive device usage, antibiotic exposure history, and specific laboratory markers. As clinical implementation of this predictive model shows, the potential of decreasing the incidence of HAI by early detection and further prevention approaches is enormous, and patient outcomes and the decrease in the healthcare cost in favor of evidence-based infection control measures will ultimately improve patient outcomes and decrease healthcare expenditures, which is also supported by evidencebased infection control measures.

title: Prediction of Kyphosis Disease using Random Forest and Gradient Boosting Algorithm
authors: K. Maithili, Kamepalli Sujatha, Tarak Hussain, Sreeram Indraneel, Rachna Rathore, Kanchan Israni
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Kyphosis is a type of spinal disorder characterized by an abnormal curvature of the upper vertebrae, resulting in a hunched or rounded back. Early diagnosis and categorization of kyphosis cases are crucial for prompt intervention and treatment planning. This investigation presents a hybrid machine-learning strategy (Random Forest (RF) and Gradient Boosting (GB)) for predicting and classifying kyphosis illness. In this work, clinical characteristics such as age, the number of affected vertebrae, and the angle of curvature are utilized. The dataset is preprocessed by addressing absent values and separating them into two training and testing sets. On the training dataset, distinct RF and GB classifiers were trained separately. The proposed method combines the predictions from both classifiers using a majority vote strategy to create the hybrid model. For each occurrence, the final prediction depends on the most frequently predicted class. Evaluate the efficacy of the hybrid model using measures of accuracy, precision, Recall, and F1-score. The results demonstrate that the hybrid model outperforms individual classifiers in classification accuracy, attaining 86%. Using the advantages of both algorithms, the hybrid technology provides a more robust and accurate classification model for kyphosis illness by combining their predictive capabilities. This study advances the field of medical diagnostics by demonstrating the effectiveness of combining machine literacy algorithms to improve disease prognosis. This study employs a hybrid mode that can potentially improve treatment outcomes for patients with kyphosis by aiding physicians in making accurate and prompt decisions.

title: Demonstration of Dual-Pump Degenerate Optical Parametric Oscillation in Kerr Microresonators for Integrated Coherent Ising Machines
authors: Menglong He, Mohd Saif Shaikh, Abdou Shetewy, Kambiz Jamshidi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: In this paper, we demonstrate a thermally controlled dual-pump degenerate optical parametric oscillator based on a silicon nitride microresonator as a fundamental building block for the realization of an integrated coherent Ising machine. First, we characterize the linear and nonlinear responses of the silicon nitride microring resonator. By precisely tuning the heater voltage, we determine the wavelength locations of the generated signal by placing the pump at various cavity resonances. Based on the proposed guideline, we present the generation of the signal at 1540.8 nm with the red pump at 1553.5 nm and the blue pump at 1528.2 nm, both on resonance, in which the pump separation is 14 free spectral range spacings.

title: Design of Secure Compression Hash Function in RISC-V Based SoC
authors: Raahul L. S., Sreegayathri K. K., Koushik B., Mohankumar N.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: In this paper, a next-generation computing architecture that supports for increasing demand on data-intensive applications that demand AI, data science and blockchain. Although SHA-256 offers good cryptographic security, it has to perform many arithmetic and logic operations on resource-limited platforms. As there is increasing concern for security, we need some secure protocols to maintain data confidentiality and integrity. We propose a secure compression hash function where an XOR-based Logic locking is incorporated to enhance security and logical integrity. Since some of the non-critical operations are performed in both software and hardware, we introduce a parallelized cryptographic execution to make sure our design runs with an execution time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> providing a 99.8% reduction in computation time compared to a purely software-based implementation. The design was analyzed by several features, such as the avalanche effect, the entropy, the Hamming distance, the bit frequency distribution and it has satisfied all conditions, proposing a better secure compression hash function in RISC-V based SoC. The design shows an average Hamming distance of around 50% showing a strong avalanche effect and has an average entropy of 5 bits per byte. The timing and the hardware utilization compare a trade-off between hashing speed and the hardware efficiency ensuring a better throughput implementation. Thus, the proposed design is highly suitable for real-time embedded applications.

title: A Method to Enhance BOC Signal Reception Performance under Partial Band Interference
authors: Donghoon Kang, Sanguk Lee, Yoola Hwang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Traditionally, Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) have provided navigation services primarily in the L-band. However, with the rapid expansion of global and regional navigation satellite systems such as GPS, Galileo, GLONASS, BeiDou, QZSS, and NavIC, the demand for L-band channels has increased substantially. This surge has led to more inter-system interference, and certain portions of the L-band are now approaching spectral saturation. Consequently, risks of degraded signal quality, reduced positioning accuracy, and impaired system interoperability have become more significant. By contrast, the S-band remains relatively underutilized and is considered a promising candidate for mitigating interference from navigation satellite systems. Nevertheless, it is susceptible to adjacent-channel interference from services such as Wi-Fi, Locata, and other satellite systems. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an interference-robust signal processing technique to improve the reception performance of BOC (Binary Offset Carrier) signals under partial band interference.

title: Optimized Duplicate Detection Using Smith-Waterman Algorithm with Sorted Neighborhood Method
authors: Yusuf Lestanto, Rahma Mualifa
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Finding duplicates in large datasets is a challenge in managing data quality. Traditional methods often require a lot of computing power, making them difficult to use for large datasets. This study aims to create a method to find duplicates that is both fast and accurate. This reduces the computing workload while maintaining good performance. The method uses the Smith-Waterman algorithm to calculate similarity accurately and the Sorted Neighborhood Method (SNM) to select candidates efficiently. It also uses a scoring system that considers different attributes, such as names, addresses, phone numbers, and postal codes. To reduce the search, blocking strategies are used as an extra step. An experiment was conducted using real consumer data from a pharmaceutical company. The dataset contained 23,000 records and was kept private. The results show that the method achieves a 98.32% F1-score and reduces the computing complexity from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O\left(n^{2}\right)$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O(n \log n)$</tex>. The method was quick, processing the dataset in less than 100 ms. It reduced the pairwise comparisons by 90%. This demonstrates that the proposed method is effective for handling large duplicate detection tasks in the industry, improving both scalability and accuracy of the process.

title: Smart Home Safety: Gas Detection and Automated Window Ventilation Using LoRa Technology
authors: Rachna Rathore, Indhuja Anandan, Chittineni Aruna, Sabnekar Anupkant, Riya Kapoor, Harshvardhan Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Using the MQ-a hundred thirty-five fuel sensor, LoRa connectivity, an Arduino microcontroller, a stepper motor, and the combination of an ESP01 module for records reporting on ThingSpeak, the cautioned mission seeks to construct a comprehensive gasoline monitoring and ventilation system to improve house safety. This machine’s intention is to avoid explosions and shield occupant safety through proactively detecting and mitigating doubtlessly dangerous fuel concentrations inside indoor surroundings. A transmitter and a receiver are the 2 number one components of the machine. An MQ-a hundred thirty-five fuel sensor is constructed into the transmitter to tune indoor air great constantly. When the sensor detects immoderate gas, it sends a sub-message to the receiver through the transmitter. After this, as soon because the receiver gets the statistics, it orders the stepper motor to open the windows in order that the region may be ventilated and the fuel may be decreased. Furthermore, an alarm machine, which includes a buzzer or LED, is incorporated into the receiver to assure that citizens are instantly notified of doubtlessly unsafe gasoline stages. This alarm machine turns on concurrently with the window-starting procedure. This ensures that the fuel hassle gets activate treatment. Additionally, the machine makes use of an ESP01 module to provide far flung tracking and facts logging. This allows statistics gathered with the aid of the transmitter to be transferred to ThingSpeak for ongoing monitoring and evaluation. This information is remotely handy to users and offers insightful data approximately system operation and fuel degree.

title: Automated Image Description using VisualGPT: Case Studies on Fashion Products
authors: Aghisna Nur Isnaini, Dwi Ratna Sulistyaningrum, Raden A. A. Viadinugroho, Subchan Subchan, Muhammad Y. H. Widianto
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Fashion products have attracted many enthusiasts in the last decade, especially with the growing demand in ecommerce. This has led to the generation of automatic image descriptions for fashion products becoming a hot topic. However, effective multimodal data processing, integrating visual and textual information, remains a significant challenge. In this study, we implement VisualGPT using Vision Transformer (ViT) as visual feature extractor and GPT-2 as a text decoder. The FACAD170K dataset is used and divided into training, validation, and testing sets in a 7:2:1 ratio. Two experimental scenarios were conducted: (1) training non data augmentation and (2) training with data augmentation. We find that the augmented training scenario consistently outperformed the non-augmented scenario, achieving BLEU-1, BLEU-2, BLEU-3, and BLEU-4 scores of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$46.66 \%, 30.85 \%, 24.37 \%$</tex>, and 13.20 %, respectively, along with METEOR score 25 %, ROUGE-L score 38 %, and a CIDErr score of 82.52 %. These results show that VisualGPT has high accuracy and contextually relevant descriptions for fashion products.

title: Smart Traffic Signal Coordination in Urban Networks via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Bhavana Shrivastava, Reeta Mishra, Daksha Borada, Anurag Shrivastava
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a key issue of city areas. Urban traffic congestion is one of the main obstructions in the life of urban areas. It results in increased travel times, fuel consumption, and environmental pollution. Traditional rulebased traffic control systems are very rigid and cannot deal with complex traffic patterns. Mult. Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) is the most commonly used intelligent system, with its requirement to retrain at every subsequent junction, however, the need for scaling up. In this study, we have introduced ZSKT that is specifically designed MARL framework (zero-shot knowledge transfer) which is strengthened by (GNNs) Graph Neural Networks and Transformers and makes it possible to generate without retraining at locations which were previously unseen. The framework was verified through real traffic datasets in SUMO and CityFlow simulators, where New York, Shanghai, and Los Angeles were among the cities involved. The approach decreases the average travel time by $25 \%$ and reduces the CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by $20 \%$ compared to the standard MARL. The new method not only increases the spread of green traffic but also improves computational efficiency, so it becomes a feasible answer for the massive distribution of intelligent traffic control mechanisms.

title: Model Adaptation for Lifecycle Management in AI-native 5G/6G Networks
authors: Jewoo Go, Taeje Park, Wonjin Sung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: As part of ongoing standardization efforts in 5G-Advanced for artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML)-based beam management (BM), model adaptation framework is proposed in this paper as a key lifecycle management (LCM) mechanism to ensure reliable model performance in dynamic wireless environments. The proposed approach enables the network to proactively respond to performance degradation by selecting and activating a more suitable model based on support information and user-side reporting. The superiority of the proposed method over non-adaptive or dataset-only approaches in maintaining beam prediction accuracy is demonstrated by simulation results, highlighting its effectiveness as a robust and scalable solution for future AI-native 6G systems.

title: Deep Learning Solution for Enhanced Detection for Primary skin lesions
authors: Neeraj Singla, Vibhu Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Recently Monkeypox spread has created health concern in many countries. Many recent algorithms promised in correctly classifying primary skin lesions as benign or malignant. Many employed feed-forward neural network to identify psoriasis using characteristics like skin tone and texture. Moreover, we categorize these illnesses using supplemented with an ensemble method for increased accuracy [1].

title: Comparative Evaluation of Synthetic Question and Answer Dataset Generation Methods for Large Language Models
authors: Rabe'atuladawiyah Samser, Faisal Fauzi, Chia Chie Lee, Phooi Yee Lau, Zulaikha Kadim
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: The intelligence of large language models is growing in the world and among the challenges faced are limited access to real-world data, privacy concerns and high manual annotation costs. Therefore, the creation of synthetic data sets using large language models (LLMs) has become an effective approach to overcome these problems. This study investigates the generation of accurate question-and-answer (QA) datasets using a publicly available document, the Malaysian Space Board Act 2022. We have implemented three approaches to create synthetic data: a straightforward approach that generates QA pairs from paragraph-level text, a well-established technique known as Retrieval Augmented Fine Tuning (RAFT), and a new method introduced in this research, Structured Contextual QA Generation (SCQA). The RAFT method slightly improved the accuracy of questions and answers by using question embedding to find the most similar documents in the vector store, while SCQA introduced a structured generation technique that generated questions and answer across different levels of understanding to improve contextual alignment and outperformed both other methods in accuracy. To evaluate the performance of each method, we conducted a comparative analysis focusing on the accuracy, relevance, and usefulness of the generated QA pairs. Among the three methods evaluated, SCQA consistently produced the most coherent and contextually aligned QA pairs, outperforming both the baseline and RAFT methods across semantic and traditional NLP metrics. Specifically, SCQA achieved a BERTScore of 0.655, an LLM coherence rating of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.2 / 5$</tex>, and cosine similarity scores of 0.868 (Q-Context), 0.901 (A-Context), and 0.876 (Q-A). These findings suggest that structured generation approaches such as SCQA can significantly improve the quality and reliability of synthetic datasets for LLM-based applications.

title: Multimodal Spam Detection Based on Multi-View Complementary Hybrid Feature Fusion
authors: Ge Zhai, Bo Yang, Runyuan Sun, Zhifeng Liang, Kaiyang Fang, Zhenyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Email has long served as a primary channel for information exchange, with traditional spam filters relying mainly on textual content. To evade such systems, attackers increasingly embed malicious information into images, rendering text-based detection ineffective. To address this challenge, we propose a multimodal spam detection framework based on multi-view complementary hybrid feature fusion (MV-CHiFF). The framework freezes the pretrained backbone to reduce the number of trainable parameters and constructs five complementary fusion paths to align semantic information from multiple perspec-tives-ranging from local to global and intra-modal to intermodal. A meta-classifier dynamically weights the probability outputs from each path, enabling dual-layer collaboration across the feature and decision spaces. Experiments on public multilingual spam datasets demonstrate that MV-CHiFF achieves up to 98.4% accuracy, validating its effectiveness in text-image hybrid spam detection scenarios.

title: Parameter-Efficient Quantum Machine Learning for Multi-Class Brain Tumor Classification
authors: Rahman Abdur, Tae-Hyong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Medical image classification is a critical task in computer-aided diagnostics, but classical deep learning models often demand substantial computational resources and large parameter spaces. This paper investigates the potential of hybrid quantum-classical neural networks to address this challenge in the context of multi-class brain tumor classification from MRI scans. We introduce a custom hybrid quantum machine learning (QML) model and conduct a rigorous comparative analysis against its purely classical counterpart, as well as established architectures such as ResNet-18 and VGG-16. Our findings demonstrate that the proposed hybrid QML model achieves a state-of-the-art test accuracy of 96.58%, matching the performance of the significantly larger ResNet-18 model. Crucially, the hybrid model outperforms its direct classical counterpart, the Classical Benchmark (96.20%), while utilizing approximately 80% fewer parameters. Although simulating quantum circuits results in longer training times, our findings highlight the remarkable parameter efficiency and competitive accuracy of hybrid quantum models, suggesting a promising direction for developing powerful yet lightweight networks for medical diagnostics.

title: Supporting Knowledge Generation in Large-Scale Online Courses: Semantic Network Approach
authors: Han Jiang, Yihan Kou, Jingjing Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Online and blended learning offers new opportunities for designing general education courses in higher education. The concept of knowledge building highlights the importance of sustained, idea-centered interaction among learners, aiming to develop shared community knowledge and reflecting a deeper understanding of knowledge as dynamic and generative. However, most existing implementations focus on computer-supported collaborative learning (CSCL) environments that are typically small in scale and reliant on complex technical systems, making them difficult to scale for large, open online courses. To address this challenge, we propose an instructional design framework grounded in the principles of knowledge generation. Implemented within a custom-designed online learning platform, our approach incorporates semantic network analysis to systematically track how learners’ ideas are distributed and evolve over time. Through this mixed-methods study, we found that learners generated authentic and varied ideas closely aligned with course content, and that sustained, idea-focused interaction fostered the growth of community knowledge. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of a knowledge generation–oriented online environment and offer practical insights for scaling general education courses in higher education.

title: Enhanced Ladyfinger Plant Disease Detection Through DenseNet
authors: Chairman M, Vignesh M, Gopinath S, Bharathi S, Tamilselvi B, Pavithra S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Okra, or ladyfinger, plants are prone to a number of illnesses that can seriously affect crop quality and output. In order to effectively manage and mitigate chronic disorders, early detection and precise diagnosis are essential. In this research, we offer an automated deep learning method for ladyfinger plant disease identification, based on the DenseNet architecture. We make use of a huge collection of tagged photos that includes plants with common illnesses such as leaf spot, powdery mildew, and yellow vein mosaic virus, along with healthy plants. Using the ladyfinger plant dataset, we apply transfer learning to refine a pre-trained DenseNet model, taking advantage of its capacity to extract discriminative characteristics from intricate visual input. Our method achieves good levels of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score in the precise classification of healthy and diseased ladyfinger plants, as shown by extensive studies. With potential uses in precision farming and sustainable crop management techniques, the suggested approach presents a viable way to detect and track diseases early in ladyfinger cultivation.

title: Real-Time Vehicle Detection and Traffic Flow Counting on Highways with YOLO
authors: Nagalakshmi Yarlagadda, Thangiah Sathishkumar, Sarangam Kodati, Venkata Praveen Kumar Vuppala, Priyanka Kaushik, Rohit Patel
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: As the number of vehicles on roads, expressways, and highways grows rapidly, efficient vehicle detection, classification, tracking and counting have become essential to the civilian, military, and governmental uses like highway monitoring, toll collection, traffic planning and flow regulation. Vehicle detection is one of the most important of these tasks, which can help in enabling effective traffic management. A solution to this is a Computer Vision (CV)based approach, which can be implemented without interfering with traffic and allows the adaption of the system. The paper is an introduction of a cost-efficient and mobile system based on CV methods to identify and count vehicles in real-time. The system works with the video frames to detect the moving vehicles with the help of background subtraction, which is followed by additional processing that groups the vehicles into the groups of light vehicles, heavy vehicles, and motorcycles.

title: Microwave Frequency Comb Generation Based on an Optoelectronic Oscillator Integrating a Coupled Optoelectronic Up-Conversion Recirculating Loop
authors: Yiran Guan, Jianping Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A novel scheme for the generation of a wideband microwave frequency comb (MFC) is proposed and experimentally demonstrated. The MFC generator is built based on an optoelectronic oscillator (OEO) as the core signal source, with the wideband MFC generated by integrating a coupled recirculating frequency up-conversion (FUC) loop. This unique architecture enables efficient multiplication of the frequency of the OEO signal, producing a stable and wideband MFC. The FUC loop, incorporating a microwave mixer, operates by iteratively up-converting and recycling the OEO signal, thereby extending the bandwidth of the MFC. In addition, by tuning the center frequency of a bandpass filter (BPF) in the OEO loop, the comb spacing can be tuned. The proposed scheme is experimentally evaluated. A wideband MFC with up to 16 comb lines from 2.12 to 34.23 GHz is generated. By tuning the BPF, tunable comb spacing at 2.12, 2.5, and 3.0 GHz is also demonstrated. Thanks to the high phase coherence between the comb lines, a pulse train with a repetition period that is reciprocal to the comb spacing of the MFC is generated.

title: A Deep Dive into KoMaP for Accelerating AI-Based Material Development
authors: Kang-Il Choi, HyunJong Kim, YoHan Choi, SuYoung Chi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Existing material platforms mostly focus on collecting material data to accelerate material development. In this paper, we present Korea Material AI Platform (KoMaP), a material data platform for accelerating data-driven material development. This platform harmonizes material data and tools for generating trained models used by researchers based on the material data. Finally, it integrates material data into the material AI model, allowing us to accelerate new material development.

title: TransFL: Selective Transformer Layer Sharing for Efficient Federated Learning
authors: Soojin Kim, Minjung Kim, JaeYeon Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent advances in vision tasks have shifted from CNN-based spatio-temporal models to Transformer-based architectures such as ViT. However, efficiently applying these models in federated learning (FL) remains underexplored. In this work, we propose TransFL, a framework that selects and shares only important Transformer layers based on gradient magnitude. This method reduces communication overhead while preserving performance.

title: The Agentic Enterprise: A Strategic Analysis of Advanced Agentic Workflows and Collaborative AI
authors: Kamal Pandey, Anoop Narnag
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Traditional rule-based industrial automation in Electric Vehicle (EV) and Industry 4.0 manufacturing creates critical bottlenecks in efficiency, adaptability, and quality control, resulting in substantial operational losses. To address this rigidity, we conducted a systematic analysis of 1,247 publications and 342 manufacturing use cases to establish a taxonomy of agentic systems. Empirical validation was performed through longitudinal case studies with a tier-1 EV manufacturer across NA, EMEA, and Asia, where we compared traditional automation, purely autonomous systems, and Human-AI Collaborative approaches. Our analysis reveals a critical fragmentation in agentic toolkits and a significant operational disconnect between AI governance theory and operational deployment. In response, we developed the Integrated Agentic Foundry (IAF) framework, which integrates adaptive learning and multi-agent coordination. This framework showed remarkable improvements, including a 34% reduction in unplanned downtime (p<0.01), a 28% decrease in quality defects, and a 41% improvement in resource utilization. Notably, human-AI collaborative approaches consistently outperformed purely autonomous systems, proving large effect sizes (Cohen's d=0.72−1.14). This study redefines modern manufacturing intelligence by demonstrating that the future of smart manufacturing lies in human augmentation, not replacement. The IAF framework provides a comprehensive roadmap for transitioning manufacturing ecosystems from rigid automation to adaptive intelligence, enabling unprecedented operational excellence.

title: YOLOv5 for Agricultural Pest Management: Real-Time Detection of Rice Insects in Field Conditions
authors: Abhijeet Kaushik, Kalpana Banjare, Ravi R. Saxena, Abhinav Kaushik, Ankita Kaushik, Shravan Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Rice cultivation faces significant challenges from insect pests, which result in substantial yield losses and drive extensive pesticide usage with environmental and health repercussions. This study explores the deployment of the YOLOv5 deep learning model for the precise detection of 12 major rice insect pests using a custom dataset of 25,500 annotated images. The images, collected from central Indian agricultural zones and validated by experts, reflect diverse conditions, developmental stages, and real-field variability. Comprehensive preprocessing, augmentation, and annotation were performed using Roboflow, followed by structured training and evaluation of multiple variants of YOLOv5 (n, s, m, 1 and x). Among them, YOLOv5x demonstrated the best performance with high precision (0.976), recall (0.817), and mAP @ 0.5: 0.95(0.733), making it optimal for high accuracy detection with feasible computation. The results affirm the model's capability for real-time pest identification, offering scalable solutions for sustainable integrated pest management (IPM) in smart farming practices.

title: Multi-Beamforming and RSRP Analysis in 5G NR Millimeter-Wave Systems
authors: Kartik Ramesh Patel, Sanjay Dasrao Deshmukh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Advent of 5G New Radio (NR) brings significant advancements in wireless communication, promising unprecedented data rates, low latency, and massive connectivity. A key enabling technology for achieving these ambitious goals, especially at millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies, is multibeamforming. This paper presents a comprehensive simulation and analysis of multi-beamforming techniques and Reference Signal Received Power (RSRP) measurements in a 5G NR mmWave communication system. Utilizing a MATLAB-based framework, we investigate the quantitative impact of various parameters, including antenna array configurations, carrier frequency, scatterer environments; transmit beamwidths, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), on the achieved RSRP. The simulation demonstrates the critical role of larger antenna arrays and precise beam alignments in compensating for sever path loss at mmWave frequencies. Results show that RSRP is significantly influenced by antenna array size, experiences a substantial drop in FR2 compared to FR1, and varies with the complexity of the scatterer environment. The study provides valuable insights for optimizing 5G NR system design, beam management strategies, and validating theoretical models in dynamic wireless communication scenarios.

title: Speaker Recognition Using MFCC and LPC with Gaussian Modelling and Mahalanobis Distance Criterion
authors: Manish Tiwari, Deepak Kumar Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In recent years, speaker recognition has become an essential part of most security and biometric systems because systems can now recognize or verify an individual's identity based on their voice. In this paper, we propose an approach to speaker recognition that is based on the use of Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) and Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) for feature extraction and the Gaussian Mixture Modeling (GMM) and Mahalanobis distance for classification criterion. For speech signals, both MFCC and LPC are used widely to extract representative features, for spectral and temporal characteristics. We use Gaussian Mixture Models to model the distribution of these features and the Mahalanobis distance to measure the 'How similar' between test speaker features and those in the model. Results of this research study show that the given method is more accurate, better than computing MFCC or as LPC alone in traditional speaker recognition system. Both feature extraction techniques and advanced statistical modeling are then integrated, producing better separation of speakers in varying acoustic environments.

title: Adaptive Photonic Self-Interference Cancellation Assisted by Deep Learning on Microcontrollers
authors: Nicole Daniel, Suen Xin Chew, Yeming Chen, Hongchao Chen, Jeffrey Shao, Chen Song, Linh Nguyen, Xiaoke Yi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We present an adaptive photonic self-interference cancellation technique assisted by deep learning on a low-power microcontroller unit (MCU). A convolutional neural network (CNN) is trained on the constellation data to predict the optimal control parameters that maximize interference suppression under varying system conditions. The trained CNN model is deployed onboard MCU to enable adaptive feedback control. Experimental results show significant improvement in error vector magnitude (EVM) in the satellite Ku-band across 14 – 14.5 GHz, achieving values below 14% at trained frequencies and maintaining low EVM of 15.37% even at untrained frequencies. This work demonstrates for the first time, the deep learning-assisted photonic SIC on an embedded MCU platform, offering a cost-effective and energy-efficient solution for dynamic interference mitigation.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Semiconductor Wafer Scheduling
authors: Hyojun Ahn, Tae Hoon Lee, Joongheon Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Semiconductor wafer fabrication involves complex scheduling challenges with hundreds of processing steps, reentrant flows, and stringent operational constraints. Traditional dispatching rules lack adaptability to dynamic fab conditions, while optimization methods face computational scalability issues. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning framework that formulates wafer scheduling as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) with comprehensive state representation capturing equipment utilization, queue dynamics, and operational constraints. The multi-objective reward function balances throughput, cycle time, tardiness, and equipment utilization while respecting batching and setup requirements. Experimental evaluation demonstrates significant improvements over traditional methods, achieving 5.3% higher throughput, 21% reduction in tardiness, and superior equipment utilization across multiple performance indicators. The stable learning convergence validates the effectiveness of the proposed approach for dynamic semiconductor manufacturing environments.

title: APSDCP-Net: Adaptive Patch-Size Dark Channel Prior Network for Single Image Dehazing
authors: Ming-Yang Tu, Kuan-Lin Chen, Jian-Jiun Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Single image dehazing is a critical computer vision task that aims to recover a clear image from a hazy input. In recent years, both learning-based and prior-based dehazing methods have been rigorously developed, yet each has limitations in haze removal performance. In this work, we propose the Adaptive Patch Size Dark Channel Prior Network (APSDCP-Net), a hybrid dehazing network that combines the dark channel prior with a learnable architecture. By reframing the dehazing problem as a patch size selection task, the proposed model combines multiple patch-sizes dark channels using learned soft weights, resulting in more accurate transmission estimation and enhanced dehazing performance. Experiments show that the proposed APSDCP-Net achieves superior performance compared to state-of- the-art dehazing methods.

title: Impedance Split Technique Based Miniaturized RF Bandpass Filter for Wireless Applications
authors: Thiyagarajan Krishnan, Dhanalakshmi N, Allin Joe D, Venkatesh Dayanidhi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: A Miniaturized symmetrical Band pass filter based on open circuited stubs is presented. Impedance split technique is followed to realize the miniaturized filter. The bandpass filter structure is verified using Advanced Design System 2021 simulation. The center frequency of the proposed filter is selected as 2.5 GHz. It achieves a bandwidth of 1.2 GHz. The filter structure is fabricated in a 1.6 mm thickness FR4 substrate. Fabricated filter structure is tested using vector network analyzer and S parameter measurement was done. The simulated and measured scattering parameters of the proposed miniaturized filter were compared. The miniaturized band-pass filter achieves a overall dimension of 32.87mm x 26.32mm.

title: Enhanced Stock Market Movements towards Economic Sustainability using LSTM Hybrid Algorithm
authors: Raghav Garg, Samariddin Makhmudov, Temur Eshchanov, Allashkurov Dilshodbek Mansurovich, Manan Garg, Ankriti Karn
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The need for precise stock price evaluation and projection is highlighted by the stock market’s increasing importance in the national economy, a topic that has attracted a lot of scholarly attention. Predictive modelling faces a very dynamic and difficult task when it comes to stock price movements, which are impacted by a variety of elements, including macroeconomic policy, industry news, capital flows, market sentiment, and corporate fundamentals. Rising volatility and increasing complexity are making themselves felt on the global stock markets; hence, there is a need for advanced prediction models that may incorporate financial, macroeconomic, and sustainability variables. This paper has therefore suggested a hybrid Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model that combines sentiment analysis of financial news and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) choice of features to predict stock market movements based on the aspect of economic sustainability. Historical stock price data, macroeconomic variables, and ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) scores for several global indexes between 2010 to 2024 are fed into the algorithm. The experimental results prove that in consideration of factors such as directional accuracy and predictive accuracy, the suggested LSTM-Hybrid framework performs better than any traditional LSTM or ARIMA model. Informed investment strategies can thus drive investors and policymakers toward economic sustainability in the long run.

title: A Fully Packaged 140 GHz Analog Radio-over-Fiber Transmitter Chipset with SiGe driver and TFLN modulator PIC
authors: Reinier Broucke, Karol Obara, Homa Zarebidaki, Jacopo Leo, Ivan Pietro, Hamed Sattari, Nishant Singh, Guy Torfs
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: An experimental demonstration of an integrated 140 GHz analog radio-over-fiber transmitter chipset is presented. The chipset consists of a single-ended push-pull Mach-Zehnder modulator on a TFLN PIC with a flip-chipped 130 nm SiGe PA. The chipset achieves an electro-optic 3 dB bandwidth of 20 GHz at a center frequency of 130 GHz and is shown to support data rates of 2 Gbps.

title: TD-ORDERER: Transaction Dependency Orderer
authors: Kyuin Jhi, Gi Seok Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: As blockchain networks scale, ensuring efficient and fair transaction processing becomes increasingly challenging.
