Existing systems like Hyperledger Fabric rely on a centralized orderer that lacks full knowledge of transaction intent, leading to failures and unfair execution. We propose a transaction ordering system that replaces or complements the orderer in Hyperledger Fabric. Our system analyzes the internal intent of transactions to minimize conflicts, provides early feedback on likely failures, and considers user fairness during ordering. This approach reduces transaction failure rates and mitigates strategic behaviors, improving both system efficiency and user experience in permissioned blockchain environments.

title: Parameter Design for Channel Knowledge Map Assisted Channel Estimation
authors: Muhammad Awais, Yun Hee Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Efficient channel estimation in massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) with limited pilot resources remains a key challenge. Recently, the concept of a channel knowledge map (CKM) has been proposed to enable location and environment-aware estimation. For a CKM referred to as channel angle-distance map (CADM) proposed for near-field channels, we investigate the sensitivity of the CADM-assisted channel estimation to the number of stored multipath components for a given location. We explore how variations in the number of multipath components in CADM affect the mean squared error (MSE) performance in different signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. Simulation results reveal that a moderate overestimation of multipath components in CADM can improve the MSE performance in high SNR regimes, whereas excessive multipath data degrades the performance in low SNR regimes.

title: Unveiling the sequential pattern of group cognitive engagement in GAI-enhanced learning environment with first-order Markov model
authors: Jirong Tian, Wanqing Hu, Yanyan Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: As we enter the era of “Hybrid Intelligence”, it becomes increasingly important for educators to explore how collaborative learning can become more efficient with the support of Generative AI (GAI). Collaborative learning is a scenario where complex cognitive engagement occurs among group members. Therefore, by analyzing the distribution characteristics and temporal patterns of group cognitive engagement in GAI-enhanced environments, we can gain a deeper understanding of how the intervention of GAI shapes the temporal patterns of cognitive engagement within groups. Furthermore, by comparing high-performing (HP) groups with low-performing (LP) groups, we can gain a clearer understanding of the temporal patterns of cognitive engagement that contribute to better collaboration performances in GAI-enhanced settings. However, current research has yet to address this issue. To bridge this gap, this study primarily employs the process mining method—the first-order Markov model (FOMM)—to examine differences in the distribution characteristics and temporal patterns of cognitive engagement between HP groups and LP groups in a self-designed GAI-enhanced collaborative learning environment. For this purpose, 39 undergraduate students from a key university in China were recruited to participate in an online collaborative writing (OCW) task. The results reveal significant differences between HP and LP groups. Specifically, HP groups engaged in discussions related to specific writing knowledge inspired by the content generated by the GAI. Moreover, HP groups were more actively involved in articulating, elucidating, and analyzing their ideas during collaboration, while LP groups were more inclined to engage in process monitoring intermittently throughout the task. This study not only provides valuable theoretical insights into how GAI’s intervention affects the temporal patterns of group cognitive engagement, but also offers guidance for designing effective scaffolding strategies to promote more efficient collaborative learning outcomes in GAI-enhanced settings.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Edge Intelligence: Bridging Quantum Computing and Distributed AI
authors: Hoa Tran-Dang, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper explores the emerging paradigm of Quantum-Enhanced Edge Intelligence (QEEI), which envisions the integration of quantum computing capabilities with distributed AI at the edge of networks. We review foundational concepts, highlight recent advances in quantum algorithms relevant to edge intelligence, and examine potential applications across domains such as autonomous systems and industrial IoT. The paper outlines a conceptual framework for QEEI, discusses current limitations in hardware and software integration, and offers a forward-looking perspective on research challenges and opportunities at the intersection of quantum computing and edge AI.

title: Sign Language Recognition and Translation to Text and Audio for Divyang Communication as A Microservice
authors: M. A. Potey, Yasmin S. Khan, Prathamesh Nigde, Dipali Shengade, Bhagyashri Jadhav, Yash Dhaytonde
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Communication blocks create major limitations for people who have hearing and speech disabilities when they try to communicate outside their personal circles. Researchers have developed a present-time sign language recognition platform which converts hand movements into written text and spoken words to make hearing-impaired users understand people who do not know sign language. Hand features can be extracted through Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in a system that operates with high accuracy to detect hand gestures. The system uses OpenCV-based skin segmentation and fuzzy c-means clustering methods for improving both gesture tracking and classification functionalities. The research investigates the recognition capabilities of American Sign Language (ASL) and Indian Sign Language (ISL) because they are commonly used by signers globally. The established model operates at an 88% success rate for transforming sign language signals into spoken text. The system benefits people with disabilities yet extends its functionality to human-computer interaction interfaces, gesture-controlled automation systems, and assistive technologies. This research combines deep learning approaches to create a solution connecting the deaf and mute community to standard communication through an accessible solution for sign language interpretation across realworld environments.

title: Enhanced Crop Disease and Pest Detection Using Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Systems with ResNeXt Architecture
authors: Konda Mamatha, Rupesh Kumar Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Crop pests and diseases are responsible for almost 40% of the loss in world agriculture; thus, their early and accurate detection is vital. An Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) with ResNeXt architecture is presented in this paper to improve crop disease and pest detection. ResNeXt explores deep hierarchical features, and ANFIS improves classification by adaptive learning. It has been tested on two benchmark datasets (PlantVillage and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30,000+$</tex>-image realfield dataset) and it achieved 98.5% accuracy, 3-5% better than CNN-based methods. False detection rates were reduced by 12%. Its application to real-time precision agriculture with active disease management is suggested. Real-world deployment and computational speed are the future directions.

title: Unsupervised Learning for Spatial Economic Zoning in North Sumatra
authors: Dian Septiana, Sisti Nadia Amalia, Fanny Ramadhani, Fahmi Ashari S Sihaloho, Prihatin Ningsih Sagala
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: This study proposes a data-driven approach to classify the economic potential of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 3}$</tex> districts and cities in North Sumatra, Indonesia, using unsupervised machine learning. A total of 23 indicators covering economic, demographic, and spatial dimensions were standardized and reduced using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), retaining over 95% of the total variance. Clustering was performed using K-means, DBSCAN, and agglomerative clustering. Internal validation with the Silhouette Score and Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI) showed that agglomerative clustering with three clusters achieved the best performance, with a Silhouette Score of 0.313 and DBI of 0.871. External evaluation using the Adjusted Rand Index (ARI) indicated that KMeans achieved the highest structural alignment. Spatial mapping revealed that the three-cluster agglomerative model outlined macrozones such as urban cores, transitional interiors, and peripheral islands, whereas the five-cluster KMeans model provided finer distinctions by identifying urban-industrial corridors, highland tourism areas, and emerging servicebased municipalities. DBSCAN exposed structural ambiguity, with a four-cluster configuration mirroring KMeans patterns but highlighting uncertain regions through a 36.4 % noise rate, whereas a three-cluster setting captured broader groupings with lower noise. These results demonstrate that unsupervised learning can produce flexible and interpretable regional classifications to support adaptive and evidence-based spatial planning.

title: Bias Detection and Fairness in AI-Based Hiring Systems
authors: Dr. Deepa Rajesh, Devkiran Narayana, Ranbir Sood, Manmohan Sharma, Melanie Lourens, A. Prakash
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The issues of bias detection and fairness assessment in AI-based hiring systems have become the pivotal concerns in the creation of automated recruitment technologies. A dataset of $\mathbf{5, 0 0 0}$ historical hiring decisions provided an understanding of systematic evidence of disparities: men were 6.8 percentage points more likely to be selected than women, whites 18 percentage points more than Blacks, and elite university graduates $\mathbf{2 1. 3}$ percentage points more than those in lower schools. Importantly, such biases were found despite the removal of sensitive attributes in the data, proving the ineffectiveness of present preprocessing techniques. This highlights the importance of advanced fairness evaluation measures and bias reduction policies in order to promote equal opportunity when hiring AI.

title: CNN-Driven Brain Tumour Detection: Enhancing Accuracy and Reliability
authors: Varsha Saxena, Ashutosh Yadav, Disha Srivastava, Meenakshi Negi, Devanshu Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Detecting brain tumours early and accurately using MRI scans is crucial for effective treatment and predicting patient outcomes. We're using a special AI tool called CNN to identify three types of brain tumours(glioma, meningioma & pituitary) in MRI images. Our approach involves cleaning up the images, adjusting their quality and making them consistent. This helps our AI model learn and make accurate predictions. We achieved 93-95% accuracy, which is better than other similar models. We also found that simple techniques like adjusting image quality and flipping images made a big difference. Our model's reliable and explains its decisions, which helps doctors trust it. We're working on making it more robust and inscribe challenges like data quality and privacy concerns.

title: AURA: Air-Mouse for Universal Access
authors: Priya S, Namritha R, Rithveckh D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a low-cost, portable air-mouse system for human-computer interaction using inertial sensing and wireless communication. The system uses an ESP32 microcontroller integrated with an MPU6050 inertial measurement unit (IMU) and tactile push buttons as a handheld transmitter. Motion and click inputs are captured in real time, processed on the ESP32, and transmitted via Bluetooth to a Raspberry Pi 3 Model B+, which emulates a universal Human Interface Device (HID). The Raspberry Pi converts the received data into standard mouse control signals compatible with laptops, smartphones, projectors, and smart TVs. The system supports two operational modes: (i) direct Bluetooth HID mode, where the ESP32 functions as a standalone mouse, and (ii) a hybrid ESP32-Raspberry Pi mode, providing enhanced features such as calibration, filtering, and multi -device pairing. The experimental evaluation demonstrates low latency (40–80 ms), accurate click recognition, and smooth cross-platform performance. The proposed solution is energy efficient, cost effective, and reproducible, making it suitable for applications in smart classrooms, interactive presentations, and IoT-enabled environments.

title: Analysis of Novel Curve Fitting-Based Real Number Modeling Technique for High-Switching Applications in Analog Mixed-Signal Systems
authors: Tamil Surya B, Devadarsan A M, Venkateswaran Padmanabhan, Guha Lakshmanan, Santhanalakshmi Mahalingam, Rajalakshmi Karuppuswamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Increasing demand for complex and high-performance Analog and Mixed-Signal (AMS) designs has created a significant need for efficient verification methodologies. As modern IC designs integrate more functionality, the time and resources required for verification continue to escalate. Ensuring accurate functionality at different abstraction levels is crucial in system design. In addition, simulation tools often involve a trade-off between simulation speed and accuracy. This trade-off is too extreme for analog simulation especially, due to non-linear behaviour and the possibility of wide range of values at each node, making these simulations time-consuming. A black-box model leveraging polynomial regression technique has been proposed to address this issue. Charge Pump and Ring Oscillator circuits are selected for the verification of the proposed technique. Although analog simulator takes significant overhead in simulation time, Spectre has been used for benchmarking the circuits due to its high accuracy. The black-box model proposed is developed using the data collected from Spectre with a focus on output parameters without considering the intermediate nodes. The regression technique relates the input and the output parameters using a multi-degree polynomial to obtain average output values. This is implemented in SystemVerilog using Real Number Modeling (RNM). Then the average output values are assigned to EEnet (U ser Defined N ettype) by behavioral modeling. This novel curve fitting polynomial approach reduces the prolonged simulation time thereby meeting the Time-to-Market requirements.

title: Assessment of Large Models' Problem-Solving Ability in Mathematics
authors: Liheng Zhai, Wenlong Lan, Shenfen Kuang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated strong performance on general tasks, and their potential for solving specialized, challenging problems in fundamental disciplines has become a forefront research focus in artificial intelligence. To systematically evaluate the capabilities of LLMs in specialized subject problem-solving, this study developed a comprehensive evaluation framework based on recent Chinese Gaokao mathematics questions. Eight leading domestic LLMs-DeepSeek-V3, GLM-4.6, Kimi-k2, ERNIE-4.5, DeepSeek-R1, DouBao-Seed-1.6, Qwen3-VL-Plus, and Intern LM2.5-Latest-were selected for systematic testing. The experimental results reveal notable performance variations across different knowledge topics, question types, and difficulty levels. Among the evaluated models, DeepSeek-R1, DeepSeek-V3, Qwen3-VL-Plus, and DouBao-Seed-1.6 exhibited superior performance.

title: Medical Impact of Learning Apps:Fault Tree Analysis
authors: Rijwan Khan, Noor Mohd, Rakesh Moahan Pujahari
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: The process involved in developing Educational Apps and especially those intended for mobile platforms, is markedly dissimilar from that of developing traditional information processing software applications because the former is inherently multidisciplinary in nature. Developing Educational Apps necessitates an integration of media, AI and HumanComputer Interaction techniques. The ever-increasing popularity of learning apps means that increasing students are spending time on these online apps on their mobile devices. As these apps are able to provide a wide variety of material suiting multiple age groups and learning levels, the student age groups that use these apps vary from 02 years to 30 years. These apps provide a multitude of learning modes which suit the needs of the user, be it for getting marks in examinations, improving their knowledge, giving the online test series, preparing for job interviews, etc. In this paper, the authors have analytically analysed the impact of such learning apps medically on the learning of students. Authors have also implemented a system using fault tree analysis for Analytical Analysis of Learning Apps medically.

title: A DL-MRBL Scheme with Variation-Resilient Timing for Wide Voltage STT-MRAM
authors: Ruiqi Zhang, Shuyu Wang, Haoran Du, Hao Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: As an emerging non-volatile memory (NVM), MRAM is promising to replace embedded Flash in advanced process node. However, with decreasing process dimension and supply voltage, the timing standard deviation for sensing increases, posing challenges to sensing reliability and performance. In this paper, we propose a dual-loop MTJ replica bitline (DL-MRBL) scheme, which fully utilizes a single 2T-2MTJ replica bitline column to track the longest precharge latency and generate low standard deviation sensing timing. Our work was implemented with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$</tex> CMOS process and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 0} \mathbf{n m} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{4 0} \mathbf{n m}$</tex> spin-transfer-torque MTJ device, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1 2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{5 1 2}$</tex> MRAM array simulations demonstrate that, compared to logic chain and previous MRAM replica bitline schemes, over a wide voltage range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.6 \mathrm{V}-1.0 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, the SAEN delay was reduced by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2. 6} {\%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 2. 1} {\%}$</tex>, while the timing standard deviation was reduced by 83.8% and 79.6%, respectively. The proposed scheme provides variation-resilient timing and strong process-voltage-temperature (PVT) tracking capability, significantly enhancing performance under low supply voltage.

title: Hybrid CNN-GRU-Attention Network for ECG Signal Classification and Real-Time Diagnosis in Edge Healthcare Systems
authors: Gaurav Kumar, Neeraj Varshney
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) requires specialized expertise along with timely and precise detection, as these diseases lead the global mortality rate. Although electrocardiography (ECG) is one of the most common diagnostics, the manual reading ECG machines require trained personnel, which leads to long waiting periods for patients. In this paper, we focus on developing a real-time automated ECG analysis algorithm using a hybrid deep learning approach, integrating Convolutional Neural Neural Networks with Gated Recurrent Units (CNN-GRU-Attention). Here, the ECG classifier is tailored for real-time processing and edge device deployment. An Attention mechanism improves interpretability and the focus on key parts to raise the model's clinical importance. To enhance model performance, we also propose a custom feature, the Beat-to-Beat Variability Index (BBVI) which is aimed at capturing subtle changes in the patient's heart rate which are linked to arrhythmias. The proposed model was trained and tested on PTB-XL and MIT-BIH Arrhythmia benchmark datasets, obtaining remarkable results with a classification accuracy of 98.8%, an F1-score of 97.9%, and an AUC of 0.992. For evaluating the model's practical applicability, the ECG classification algorithm was integrated into a SimPy-based simulation of a real-time healthcare diagnostics and a semi-automated ECG reading system with model-driven patient flow simulation, edge AI inference delays, and physician feedback loops. An average inference time of 0.49 seconds, a high system throughput of 85 patients per hour, and minimal latency regardless of load conditions. This confirms the model's effectiveness in limited-resource environments such as rural clinics and portable medical devices. This combination model improves accuracy while at the same time providing answers to many important issues of interpretability, efficiency, and deployability, making it a next-generation AI-based diagnostic system for CVD.

title: An Intelligent Framework for Dysarthria Speech Recognition Using Convolutional Recurrent Model with Heuristic Search Algorithm
authors: S. Saranya, Sibi Amaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Speech is a vital medium of communication among people. Once the communication medium is abnormal, it enlarges the complexity of communication. Speech Dysarthria is a disease where speech muscles become weak, and it is challenging to convey or else speech verbally. Patients who suffer from speech dysarthria might not comprehend that this disorder is a sign of manifold other illnesses, and it can predict a condition such as stroke. To help the clinical analysis of dysarthria and to evade the problems related to clinical evaluations, automatic dysarthric speech recognition models can be employed. In recent times, deep learning (DL) has been popular and commonly employed in medical treatment. To accurately and objectively analyze patients with dysarthria, many researchers are utilizing DL to progress automatic recognition of dysarthria. This study presents a Dysarthria Speech Recognition Framework Using Optimized Convolutional Recurrent Model with Optimization Algorithm (DSRF-OCROA) model. The aim is to develop a reliable system that can precisely detect and classify dysarthric speech. In the audio pre-processing stage, the DSRF-OCROA approach applies a non-stationary noise reduction technique to improve the quality of audio signals. For the feature representation process, melspectrogram is used to convert raw speech signals into timefrequency representations for improved analysis. The convolutional long short-term memory (C-LSTM) technique is then employed in the accurate dysarthria speech classification process, and the jellyfish search (JS) approach is used for parameter selection. To comparison study of the DSRF-OCROA model illustrated a superior accuracy value of 92.70% over existing approaches under the Dysarthria detection dataset.

title: Pareto-Optimal Design of OAM Communication Links under Beam Misalignment via a Decomposition-Based CMOEA
authors: Young Jae Moon, Yeon Ho Chung
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Orbital angular momentum multiplexing promises virtually unlimited orthogonal spatial channels for free-space optical links, dramatically increasing system capacity. However, even slight radial, angular, or axial displacements introduce intermodal crosstalk to the system, which degrades throughput and link reliability. In this paper, we present a decomposition-based configurable multi-objective evolutionary algorithm (CMOEA) that jointly optimizes topological charge spacing, multi-input-multi-output equalizer tap count, and tip-tilt control bandwidth in order to minimize misalignment-induced crosstalk while bounding digital signal processing and servo costs. With the simulation environment, we achieved over 99% capacity recovery and effective crosstalk suppression within 16.4 seconds of processing time, outperforming conventional approaches. Our framework supports adaptive reconfiguration with robustness to maintain optimal performance under varying communication conditions.

title: Importance-Aware Subcarrier Mapping for OFDM-Based Digital Semantic Communication
authors: Joohyuk Park, Jiyoon Kim, Yo-Seb Jeon
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes an importance-aware subcarrier mapping scheme for orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-based digital semantic communications. The proposed framework employs a pretrained vision transformer to estimate attention scores for individual image patches and selects the most informative patches for OFDM transmission. By exploiting the frequency-selective nature of OFDM channels, patches with higher attention scores are assigned to subcarriers with superior channel gains, thereby enhancing the reliability of critical semantic information delivery. Simulation results confirm that the proposed scheme consistently achieves higher classification accuracy than conventional mapping strategies, particularly under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions.

title: Hybrid Anomaly-Based Cloud Security with SDP and Machine Learning for Threat Detection
authors: Kalyan Gattupalli, Venkata Surya Bhavana Harish Gollavilli, Poovendran Alagarsundaram, Harikumar Nagarajan, Surendar Rama Sitaraman, Balachander. J
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Dynamic cyber threats are increasingly menacing the agility of cloud computing. Dynamism is required in solutions, given that the conventional methods of security are not dynamically compatible within the changing environment. In order to overcome these limits a hybrid anomaly-based solution is developed which is a kind of enhancement of Software-Defined Perimeter (SDP) with enhanced algorithm in order to make detection more scaled and more accurate. The model proposed will utilise the autoencoders, One-Class SVM, Isolation Forest, and SDP in respect to threats to secure the preprocessing of the data and real-time threat detection. By the combination of these elements, cloud infrastructure efficiency and security are guaranteed along with the detection of anomalies. The objectives of the research are to promote scalability, improve access control, provide more effective anomaly detection and provide efficient data protection in cloud systems. With an accuracy of 96.5, precision of 94.8, recall of 95.2, and a marginally high false positive rate of 2.4 this comparison of the model with the traditional methods shows that better accuracy is achieved by the model. Overall, this composite approach offers scalability, the improved privacy of the data, and the immediate detection of the threat and the improved cloud security.

title: Toward Heterogeneity-Aware Striping in Lustre
authors: Sooyoung Lim, Jaegi Son, Dongmin Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Lustre is a widely adopted parallel file system in high-performance computing (HPC) environments. However, as clusters increasingly incorporate heterogeneous storage devices with varying performance characteristics, Lustre’s default striping mechanism fails to fully leverage the capabilities of faster devices and can even degrade I/O performance. We propose an adaptive, heterogeneity-aware striping mechanism that automatically distributes I/O workload based on the resource capability of each storage device.

title: IEEE Recommended Practice for Data Expression, Exchange, and Processing in Smart Agriculture
authors: N/A

abstract: Recommended practices for data design in smart agriculture are established in this document. It emphasizes standardized methods for data formats, tags, naming conventions, and transfer protocols to enable interoperability, scalability, and efficient data exchange between heterogeneous systems. These practices are pivotal for integrating advanced technologies such as IoT, AI, and robotics into agricultural operations. This recommended practice provides for coexistence and interoperability through common data structures and transfers between heterogeneous systems; various systems from different manufacturers work together to efficiently and effectively meet farmers’ requirements, as in a smart agriculture system.

title: The Coding as Another Language (CAL) Curriculum in Portuguese: Translation, Implementation and Pilot Evaluation
authors: Maribel dos Santos Miranda-Pinto
publish: IEEE Revista Iberoamericana de Tecnologias del Aprendizaje
abstract: This article presents the ScratchJr – Coding as Another Language (CAL) curriculum, translated into Portuguese by researchers from the Arcacomum Association as part of a project funded by the Scratch Education Collaborative (2022–2024), part of the MIT Media Lab. The translation process was supported and validated by the DevTech Research Group (https://sites.bc.edu/codingasanotherlanguage/scratchjrcurricula-portuguese). Between February and May 2025, a pilot study was conducted in a preschool educational setting aimed at exploring the implementation of the curriculum’s lessons. The article describes the main features of the CAL curricula, highlighting their potential for cross-curricular integration across various areas of learning, from Kindergarten to the 2nd Grade of primary education. The results show benefits in terms of creativity, collaboration, communication, responsibility, and sense of community. The study concluded that the CAL curriculum is relevant within the Portuguese educational context, and its expansion and teacher training are recommended to enhance its implementation.

title: Homogenization Optimization of Electric Field in Nonlinear Nonuniform Dielectrics Under Pulsed Excitations
authors: Minyu Mao, Jiawei Wang, Jinghui Shao, Youpeng Huangfu, Shuhong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: Excessive local electric field strength due to pulsed excitations may cause deterioration of electrical insulation in power devices. Although dielectric functionally graded insulations (d-FGIs) can be adopted to relieve this issue, a critical concern arises in the optimal selection of the dielectric parameters (conductivity/permittivity). To solve this problem, this article applies a multiobjective optimization approach based on the nondominated sorting genetic algorithm-II (NSGA-II). Specifically, to self-adapt to the change in the electric field, the dielectric parameters are nonlinearly characterized as exponential functions of the electric field. The nonlinear coefficients of dielectric parameters are essentially determined by a tradeoff among the maximum electric field, the electric field nonuniformity, and the volume/layers of the nonlinear dielectric. A needle–plate and a bushing model are considered as examples, and axisymmetric finite element models are implemented for the evaluation of the distribution of the electric field. For comparison, a double-layer and a multilayer dielectric gradient configuration for the case of the needle-plate are assessed. A multilayer d-FGI bushing model is then investigated for simplicity. The optimization results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for the homogenization of the electric field under pulsed excitations.

title: Sparse-View Dental Panoramic Reconstruction Using Spectrally Tuned Gaussian-Notch Filtering
authors: Hyesun Yang, Jiyong Shim, Duhee Jeon, Sanghyun Cho, Hyosung Cho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: This study presents a method for reconstructing sparse-view panoramic images using a spectrally tuned Gaussian-notch (STGN) filtering framework to support low-dose dental imaging. The approach consists of three steps: 1) acquiring projection data with reduced angular sampling on a clinical panoramic system, 2) reconstructing images using the shift-and-add (SAA) algorithm, and 3) designing an STGN filter in the Fourier domain to selectively suppress periodic stripe artifacts induced by undersampling. The method was validated using numerical simulations and physical phantom experiments under 75% and 50% sampling conditions, corresponding to estimated dose reductions of 25% and 50%, respectively. Monte Carlo simulations were also performed to estimate absorbed doses in radiosensitive organs such as the thyroid, salivary glands, and eye lens. The results show that the proposed method effectively removes periodic stripe artifacts while preserving anatomical structures, yielding image quality comparable to that of full-view reconstructions. The framework is computationally efficient, requires no hardware modification, and can be readily integrated into clinical workflows, enabling substantial dose reduction without compromising diagnostic performance. Beyond dental imaging, the proposed frequency-domain strategy is also applicable to non-medical imaging and inspection systems—such as security screening, cargo inspection, and nondestructive evaluation—where structured detector artifacts similarly degrade image quality.

title: Small-Amplitude Electron Acoustic Solitons in a Magnetized Plasma With Regularized Kappa-Distributed Hot Electrons
authors: Yong Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: The fundamental characteristics of small-amplitude electron acoustic solitons in a magnetized plasma composed of cold electrons and hot electrons with a regularized kappa distribution are investigated by the reductive perturbation method. Korteweg–de Vries–Zakharov–Kuznetsov (KdV–ZK) equation that governs the evolution of these nonlinear structures is derived. A detailed numerical analysis of the KdV–ZK equation is conducted, utilizing plasma parameters representative of Earth’s inner magnetosphere and considering a low spectral index of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\kappa = 0.2$</tex-math> </inline-formula> for the hot electron population. The numerical results reveal that the soliton propagates at a velocity exceeding the effective electron acoustic speed of the medium. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that both the electrostatic potential amplitude and the associated electric field strength exhibit a positive correlation with the soliton speed, whereas the soliton’s spatial width shows an inverse relationship. Additionally, the influence of the propagation angle relative to the background magnetic field indicates that larger angles generally lead to the formation of solitons with greater widths and weaker electric fields. The results obtained can provide insight into explaining the observed electrostatic soliton structures in space plasmas.

title: Adaptive Patch Reshaping for Edge-Based Semantic Segmentation in Remote Sensing
authors: Rostyslav Kosarevych, Oleksiy Lutsyk, Bohdan Rusyn, Natalia Pits, Taras Maksymyuk, Marcel Volosin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Accurate boundary detection between distinct classes is a major challenge in the semantic segmentation of remote sensing images. A widely used strategy involves dividing large images into patches for classification, which requires carefully prepared training, test, and validation datasets. When the resolution of the input image exceeds that of the available labels, upsampling the labels to match the image resolution often leads to suboptimal results. To address this issue, we propose an alternative approach, Adaptive Patch Reshaping (APR), that subdivides both the input image and label patches, then reassigns them to classes according to an information-theoretic criterion. By reshaping patches based on their similarity to representative class characteristics, this method constructs a new training set from the original one. Experimental results using Sentinel-2 imagery demonstrate that the proposed technique, implemented with a lightweight CNN, achieved a classification precision of 89% for the training set, 86% for the test set, and 81% for the validation set. Furthermore, comparative analysis confirms that APR improves the delineation of boundaries between regions, yielding higher F1-scores and Structural Similarity Index values compared to standard patch-based baselines.

title: : Full Reference Video Quality Assessor of Rendered Human Avatars in Virtual Reality_supp1-3663930.pdf
authors: Avinab Saha
publish: N/A
abstract: We present HoloQA, a new state-of-the-art Full Reference Video Quality Assessment (VQA) model that was designed using principles of visual neuroscience, information theory, and self-supervised deep learning to accurately predict the quality of rendered digital human avatars in Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) systems. The growing adoption of VR/AR applications that aim to transmit digital human avatars over bandwidth-limited video networks has driven the need for VQA algorithms that better account for the kinds of distortions that reduce the quality of rendered and viewed avatars. As we will show, standard VQA models often fail to capture distortions unique to the rendering, transmission, and compression of videos containing human avatars. Towards solving this difficult problem, we adopt a multi-level Mixture-of-Experts approach. This involves computing distortion-aware perceptual features and high-level content-aware deep features that capture semantic attributes of human body avatars. The high-level features are computed using a self-supervised, pre-trained deep learning network. We show that HoloQA is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the recently introduced LIVE-Meta Rendered Human Avatar VQA database, demonstrating its efficacy in predicting the quality of rendered human avatars in VR. Furthermore, we demonstrate the competitive performance of HoloQA on other digital human avatar databases and on another synthetically generated video quality use case: cloud gaming. The code associated with this work will be made available on GitHub.

title: A Resonator-Based Active Sensing Tag for Lactate Detection in Saline Solutions
authors: Wendi Zhu, Masoud Baghelani, Peter E. Light, Ashwin K. Iyer
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Lactate is an important biomarker for assessing metabolic function, diagnosing lactic acidosis, and evaluating tissue hypoxia. It is also crucial for monitoring athletic performance in professional and high-level amateur athletes. This paper presents a novel resonator-based wireless active sensing tag for lactate detection in saline solutions. The proposed system integrates a three-port split-ring resonator (SRR) sensor, a wideband amplifier, and an RF switch within a closed-loop oscillator architecture, generating two distinct oscillation frequencies corresponding to the first and second SRR resonance modes. This dual-mode operation allows the active sensing tag to provide sufficient information to determine the concentrations of individual components in a three-component mixture. A wideband antenna is employed for wireless signal transmission, and a microcontroller with a web-based interface enables remote control of the RF switch for frequency selection. Experimental results show that oscillation frequency shifts correlate reliably with the real permittivity of the material under test (MUT), enabling accurate estimation of lactate concentrations across various salt levels. For lactate concentrations ranging from 0 to 2000 mmol/L, polynomial regression yields a mean absolute error (MAE) of 4.567 mmol/L for lactate and 1.050 mmol/L for salt. For lower lactate concentrations ranging from 0 to 100 mmol/L, the model achieves an MAE of 0.752 mmol/L for lactate and 1.320 mmol/L for salt. The proposed sensing system offers non-invasive, wireless, and real-time detection of three-component mixtures, enabling reliable detection of lactate concentrations in complex saline environments.

title: FWM Nonlinearity Reduction Techniques for 2- and 10 km 3.2 Tb/s (16×200 Gb/s) O-Band IM/DD Systems
authors: Silas Oettinghaus, Tom Wettlin, Stefano Calabrò, Nebojša Stojanovic, Stephan Pachnicke
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: In this letter, four-wave mixing (FWM) nonlinearities resulting from wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) propagation near zero dispersion wavelength (ZDW) are studied and mitigation techniques, being polarization interleaving and link segmentation, are systematically analyzed. Link segmentation uses alternating fibers with a slight shift of the ZDW towards shorter and longer wavelengths respectively. 3.2 Tb/s systems, enabled by 16×200 Gb/s 112 GBd PAM-4 signaling with 400 GHz spacing, are simulated for 2 km and 10 km O-band links. The effects of polarization-mode-dispersion on FWM and the tradeoff between nonlinearities and dispersion are studied in detail. Deviations of fiber characteristics and the resulting fluctuations within standard links are taken into consideration. It is shown that link segmentation successfully reduces the FWM penalty to almost zero. The results can be useful for the implementation of next-generation intra data-center networks.

title: A Wide-PDR CMOS Rectifier Employing Dual Mode Technique for Ambient RF Energy Harvesting
authors: Ze Xun Lee, Yan Joe Cheong, Harikrishnan Ramiah, Yi Chen Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper proposes a wide input range crosscoupled differential-drive (CCDD) rectifier for ambient RF energy harvesting, designed in 65 nm CMOS process. A dualmode configuration is introduced, employing adaptive gate biasing to optimize power conversion efficiency (PCE) across varying <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex> input power. In the high-power mode, a feedback circuit suppresses reverse leakage currents, while in the lowpower mode, a gate boosting technique enhances forward current, improving PCE at low RF input power. The post layout simulation results show the rectifier exhibits a wide PCE dynamic range (PDR) of 18.6 dB at 900 MHz with a PCE of 65.7% and a sensitivity of −12 dBm at 1 V output across a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mathrm{k} \Omega$</tex> resistive load. This rectifier demonstrates the widest PDR compared to the recent state-of-the-art design, showing its high adaptability to fluctuating RF input powers, making it wellsuited to power Internet of Things (IoTs) applications.

title: Optimization of Quantum-Assisted Deep Learning Algorithms for High-Performance Cloud Infrastructures
authors: Mohammad Mizanur Rahman, Md. Shamim Reza
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Quantum computing has been combined with deep learning, and this has created new opportunities to accelerate dataintensive applications and add more computational intelligence. Quantum-Assisted Deep Learning (QADL) uses the capability of quantum parallelism to address the limits to training and scaling of conventional neural networks. But applied to the high-performance cloud infrastructures (HPCIs), QADL experiences some challenges, including quantum-classical synchronization delays, inefficient resource usage, and weak scalability to dynamic workloads. In the attempt to overcome these issues, it is proposed in this paper (QADROT), Quantum-Assisted Deep Reinforcement Optimization of Intelligent Training, a new optimization model of effective hybrid computing. The Q-ADROIT uses a quantum-controlled reinforcement learning to allocate computational tasks in both quantum and classical computers dynamically. It combines an adaptive entanglement-based scheduler to reduce the data transfer latency and a hyperparameter tuner that is self-optimizing and uses quantum sampling to enhance convergence and accuracy. Empirical investigations using benchmark data demonstrate that Q-ADROIT outperforms the current models by 41 percent improvement in training speed, a 29 percent decrease in latency and predictive accuracy. In general, Q-ADROIT can greatly enhance the efficiency, scalability and energy optimization of the QADL systems in cloud infrastructures.

title: Multi-Channel Quantum-Effect Thin-Film Transistors for Beyond Cmos Applications
authors: Mohammad Masum Billah, Moath Alathbah, Jung Bae Kim, Jin Jang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: As CMOS scaling approaches its physical limits, conventional single-channel amorphous oxide semiconductor (AOS) thin-film transistors (TFT) face critical challenges related to stability and low carrier mobility, limiting their suitability for ultra-low power, beyond-CMOS applications. This work presents coplanar multi-channel InGaZnO/InZnO quantum-effect transistors and investigates how the quantum effect governs electronic conduction, aiming to overcome key performance and reliability barriers in nanoscale devices. From experiment and simulation, we analyze the formation of quantum confinement between oxide semiconductor layers with two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) and its impact on TFT behavior. Technology computer-aided design (TCAD) results show that the observed threefold enhancement in mobility in multi-channel TFTs arises from quantum confinement effects enabled by a significant conduction band offset (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta \mathbf{E c}$</tex>) at the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{I n Z n O} / \mathbf{I n G a Z n O}$</tex> hetero-interface. Furthermore, tuning the carrier concentration in the oxide semiconductor layers allows precise control over TFT characteristics, revealing that the bottom oxide layer plays a more dominant role than the top in governing 2DEG formation and quantum confinement distribution. This study highlights the potential of heterointerface engineering in multi-channel oxide TFTs with quantum confinement effect as a strategy to enable high-mobility, low-power devices suitable for next-generation beyond-CMOS electronics.

title: A 151.9-165.9 GHz 8.8% FTR Quadrature Voltage Controlled Oscillator in 28-nm FDSOI
authors: Waseem Abbas, Samir Aziri, Christoph Wagner, Golsa Ghiaasi
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a quadrature voltage-controlled oscillator (QVCO) with an 8.8 % frequency tuning range (FTR) implemented in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28-\text{nm}$</tex> FDSOI process. It incorporates a fundamental VCO, a push-push frequency doubler, and an IQ (90 -degree) coupler with a power consumption of 63.8 mW. A novel stacked NMOS-based tuning network is implemented to achieve a wider FTR. The measured output power ranges from -16.7 to -11.9 dBm for frequencies between 151.9 and 165.9 GHz. The measured phase noises are -79.84 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-101.38 \text{dBc} / \text{Hz}$</tex> at 1 and 10 MHz offsets, respectively. The minimum IQ amplitude and phase imbalances are 0.25 dB and 2 degrees, respectively. The chip area, including probing pads, is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 2 8} \times \mathbf{9 4 1} \mu \mathbf{m}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Do LLMs Benefit from Self-Ensembles? A Study of Self-Mixture-of-Agents
authors: Seungho Lee, Donghyun Lee
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have become increasingly prevalent in natural language processing applications due to their strong performance on a wide range of language tasks. However, their outputs are still prone to inconsistency and flaws, limiting their reliability. To address these limitations, we explore Mixture-of-Agents (MoA), an existing ensemble method that aggregates responses from multiple LLMs, which has been proven to enhance performance. Building upon this approach, we attempt to evaluate the effectiveness of Self-Mixture-of-Agents (Self-MoA), an innovative ensemble method that aggregates outputs only from a single top-performing LLM. This raises the central question of whether Self-MoA can yield measurable performance improvements. To evaluate the efficacy of Self-MoA, we evaluated Self-MoA across multiple models and datasets to assess its performance. Additionally, we applied supervised fine-tuning (SFT) to assess its impact on performance. Our results show that Self-MoA improves performance only on certain models. We hypothesize that the size of the model, the consistency of the model, and the purpose of the model all contribute to the effectiveness of Self-MoA. However, applying SFT yielded no improvement.

title: An Automated Outline for Quick Discovery and Classification of Lung Diseases Using Medical Imaging
authors: Inbalatha M, Raghu N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This article targets to identify lung infections by extracting appropriate features from imageries of infected human lungs. A system is designed to classify lung abnormalities using classification techniques for lung disease detection. Performance metrics are enhanced, then the outcomes are validated for improved diagnosis through software tools. The proposed model offers a more effective methodology for detecting lung diseases. The system functions as a ML Classifier, utilizing standard classifiers such as K-Nearest Neighbors (k_NN), Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Naive Bayes (NB). The presentation of diverse classifiers is compared on the basis of recognition accuracy, recognition time, and feature abstraction time along with classification accuracy reaching from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$</tex>. Performance metrics of various PCA levels are estimated including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K=1,3,4,5$</tex>, and so on.

title: A Systematic Framework for Mapping Neural Weights to Conductance for Memristor Based ANN Implementation
authors: Devadarsan A M, Yogeshwaran B S, Tamil Surya B, Krishnaveni Vellingiri, Santhanalakshmi Mahalingam, Rajalakshmi Karuppuswamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Processing-in-memory (PIM) technology is considered as a promising solution to break the Von Neumann bottleneck. The key idea of this technology is to bring memory and computing closer instead of separating them, thus improving the efficiency of data movement. To address these challenges in the implementation of Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), the development of a memristor-based ANN is proposed. Verilog-A models are commonly used to simulate memristor behavior in circuit designs, enabling designers to test and validate memristive dynamics without physical hardware. A novel conductance mapping mechanism has been developed for finding out the conductance value to be programmed into a memristor based on the ANN weights. The framework is verified by implementing equations of ANN using the Verilog-A model of memristor.

title: Deep Learning Model with Multi-Class Labels Improving the Automated Segmentation of Abdominal Organs Using MRI
authors: Ganeshkumar M, Suchir Kohli, Varun Nair, Devasenathipathy Kandasamy, Raju Sharma, Amit Mehndiratta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Automatic and accurate segmentation of abdominal organs using Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is needed to simplify the automate diagnostic process for radiologists and clinicians. However, this is challenging as the size and shape of these organs vary significantly from subject to subject and MRI contrast varies across vendors and acquisition sequences. This research investigates a multi-task pipeline (MTP) for abdominal organ segmentation in MRI. MTP has specialised streams/dedicated Deep Learning (DL) networks for segmenting the organs of interest. Having dedicated DL networks for a single task can improve performance, and this research exploited the idea and investigated a multi-task pipeline with dedicated networks for segmenting multiple organs in the abdomen. However, the results revealed that the MTP could not handle the inter-class similarity in the input MRIs and leading to large number of false-positives.

title: A Silicon Photonic Chip for Simultaneous Microwave and Near-Infrared Dual-Band Beamforming
authors: Ruiqi Zheng, Jingxu Chen, Jinkun Hu, Haikun Huang, Jiejun Zhang, Jianping Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: This study proposes and experimentally demonstrates the world’s first monolithically integrated silicon photonic chip capable of simultaneous microwave and near-infrared dual-band beamforming. The chip integrates a microwave beamforming network and an optical phased array (OPA) system to combine the high connection reliability of microwave band with the large bandwidth advantage of the near-infrared band. The microwave beamforming network employs four 3-bit optical switch delay line (OSDLs) structure with four integrated photodiodes (PDs), while the OPA utilizes sixteen-channel thermo-optic phase shifters coupled with integrated waveguide grating antennas. The experimental results demonstrate that the chip achieves two-dimensional dynamic beam steering, with a microwave beam scanning range of 22.7°×27.4° and an optical beam scanning range of 10°×4.7°.

title: Design and Implementation of Hybrid Approximate Multiplier (HAX8) for Non-Linear RGB Image Brightness Adjustment
authors: Radhakrishnan K.R, Ramesh J, Hariharan M, Vanathi P T
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Multiplication is a critical operation in digital circuit, influencing the performance of arithmetic and signal processing applications. Approximate computing techniques, particularly in compressor-based multipliers, offer a balance struck between computational precision and resource utilization. This work investigates the impact of four different compressor designs (4:2, 5:2, 8:2) on an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8\times 8$</tex> multiplier, evaluating their area, power, and delay characteristics. Error analysis is conducted to assess the trade-offs between computational efficiency and accuracy. The best-performing compressor-based multiplier is then integrated into an image processing application-Non-Linear Brightness Adjustment of an RGB image-where the Red and Green channels undergo transformation while the Blue channel remains unaltered. The proposed design is implemented in Verilog and synthesized using Xilinx Vivado 2018.3. Results demonstrate that the selected multiplier achieves an optimal balance between performance and accuracy, making it suitable for error-resilient applications.

title: A Survey on Deep Learning-Based Anomaly Detection in Photovoltaic Power Generation Systems
authors: Xiaojin Li
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the global energy structure transition towards low-carbon development, the scale of photovoltaic (PV) power generation continues to expand, placing higher demands on the safe and stable operation and system maintenance of PV plants. Traditional detection methods exhibit limitations in efficiency, accuracy, and early fault identification, while deep learning offers novel solutions for PV anomaly detection. This manuscript provides a systematic review of research progress in deep learning-based fault diagnosis methods for PV systems. It begins by analyzing common types of anomalies in PV systems and their characteristics, then elaborates on detection methods based on time-series data and image data: the former utilizes models such as RNN and LSTM to model the relationship between power generation performance and environmental variables for power prediction and early anomaly warning; the latter employs visual models like CNN and YOLO to process infrared and electroluminescence (EL) images for the identification and localization of component defects. The article also summarizes the application of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) in data augmentation. Results indicate that deep learning methods significantly outperform traditional approaches in detection accuracy, automation level, and generalization capability. However, challenges remain, including strong data dependency, insufficient model interpretability, and difficulties in engineering implementation. Future research should focus on fewshot learning, multi-modal fusion, lightweight models, and integration with physical mechanisms to promote the practical application and development of intelligent O&M systems for PV power generation.

title: Improving University Student Outcomes in Substance Abuse Prevention Education: A Strategy for Online Learning Environment
authors: Ze Li, Xianghui Lai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This study examines an online teaching strategy that combines multimedia resources, gamified virtual simulation (GVS), peer collaboration forums, and AI-powered personalized feedback systems to enhance substance abuse prevention education (SAPE) among university students. Conducted as a case study at a Chinese university, the research reveals that this integrated approach significantly improved students' satisfaction and enhanced their knowledge and practical skills in substance abuse prevention. Multimedia and GVS strengthened emotional engagement and knowledge retention, while peer collaboration forums promoted teamwork and problem-solving skills. AI-powered systems offered personalized learning support, further optimizing the learning experience.

title: The Transformer Oil Dissolved Gas Prediction Method Based on Multivariate Variable-Weighting Mechanism
authors: Zhu Ye, Zhou Zhengqin, Yang Yi, Zhan Hao, Li Mengqi, Zhou Wen
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Dissolved gases in transformer oil are important diagnostic indicators of transformer operating conditions. To overcome the limitations of traditional single models in fusion of multi-gas signal information and dynamic response capabilities, this paper proposes an integrated modeling method based on a multivariate variable-weighting mechanism. First, based on the time-series characteristics and nonlinear variation of dissolved gas data, autoregressive moving average (ARMA), gray prediction model (GM), and Transformer-based deep time-series modeling methods are constructed as base prediction models. These models build a multivariate prediction structure from the perspectives of linear trend modeling, gray system approximation, and complex time-series feature extraction. Then, a variable-weighting distribution module based on long short-term memory (LSTM) network is designed, which dynamically outputs the optimal combination weight over time by learning the signal features. Finally, the prediction results of each base model are integrated according to the weights, forming a multivariate variable-weighting combination prediction model. Validation using large-scale real-world data covering multiple substations and operating conditions shows that the proposed multivariate variable-weighting combination prediction model delivers high accuracy and stability.

title: Automatic diagnosis and classification of skin cancer using modified deep learning methods: A Study
authors: Rajendran Sivakumar, K Sathish
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Skin cancer remains one of the most frequent and deadly kinds of cancer in the world, which shows how important it is to find it quickly and accurately. Traditional diagnostic procedures rely heavily on clinical expertise and biopsy techniques, which may be time-consuming, subjective, and hard to get to in remote places. This study looks at how to use improved deep learning (DL) methods to automatically diagnose and classify skin cancer in order to make detection more accurate and reduce the need for human evaluations. The suggested model uses an advanced Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture, together with advanced image preprocessing, data augmentation, and transfer learning, to sort dermoscopic images into two class, such as melanoma and benign lesions. The model is trained and tested using a medical dataset that everyone could access. For measuring performance, accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and the confusion matrix are all important indicators. The new DL technology works better than older CNN models because it can generalise and adapt better to different types of skin lesions. The findings show that DL is a reliable tool for finding skin cancer early.

title: Research On Image Denoising Method Of Transmission Line Insulator
authors: Jian Fan
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Insulator images in transmission lines are captured under unpredictable high-altitude outdoor conditions, inevitably containing noise components during inspection. The inherent noise in these images causes blurriness and edge distortion, severely compromising defect detection accuracy. Traditional wavelet threshold denoising methods suffer from issues like overor under-decorrection, Gibbs effect, and biased noise reduction. This paper proposes an enhanced adaptive wavelet threshold denoising algorithm. Compared with eight existing methods, our improved approach effectively removes noise while preserving critical edge details and visual information, demonstrating superior denoising performance.

title: Beyond Traditional Methods: A NLP and Knowledge Graph Approach to Cyber Threat Detection and Visualization
authors: Muhammad Qaisar, Bilal Ali, Hasan Ali Khattak
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Cyber threat detection, analysis, and mitigation are becoming more and more complex, as traditional signature-based cybersecurity methods tend to be limited in their effectiveness against evolving threats. This work presents a novel framework for real-time threat detection and visualisation leveraging Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Knowledge Graphs (KG). By combining these techniques, this approach connects threat patterns and entities, enabling a more detailed understanding of cyber-attacks. Considering the ever-increasing amount of data and communications, this work demonstrates improvements in detection accuracy as well as the ability to visualise complex attack patterns using the proposed framework, leading to a deeper understanding of cyber-security operations. The proposed framework has been validated using real-world datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in predicting and mitigating threats better than traditional systems. The study provides new insights into the growing role of NLP and KGs in modern cybersecurity environments.

title: RNS Base Conversion Using Optimized Multiword Multipliers for Approximate Modulus Switching
authors: Muhammad Ogin Hasanuddin, Hanho Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Modulus switching is a critical step in approximate homomorphic encryption schemes such as Residue Number System (RNS)-CKKS. At its heart lies RNS base conversion (BConv), which involves repeated large-integer modular multiplications and additions across multiple moduli. This paper proposes a base conversion core for approximate modulus switching using an optimized multiword multiplication strategy mapped to DSP blocks, coupled with Barrett reduction for efficient modular arithmetic. Our architecture includes a memory-buffered datapath coupled with a shift-register-based stream controller that enables efficient partial result reuse and deeply pipelined execution. We compare full-parallel (FP) and datapath-serialized (DS) implementations, leveraging our optimized modular multiplier to achieve 50 % lower latency compared to the baseline. Our proposed DS design, utilizing the Residue Digit Computation Unit (RDCU), provides improved throughput as the polynomial degree increases, making it particularly suitable for low-latency key-switching in RNS-CKKS accelerators.

title: University Students' Acceptance of Emotional Learning Companion Agents: An Empirical Study Based on Social Network Analysis
authors: Shiying Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: With the deep integration of artificial intelligence (AI) in higher education, emotional learning companion agents (ELCAs) that combine multimodal affective computing and educational services are emerging as a promising direction for intelligent learning support and mental health assistance. This study designs and implements an ELCA integrating multimodal affective computing, natural language processing, and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) on the Coze platform, and investigates Chinese university students' acceptance and diffusion patterns. Based on the computational similarity-based Social Network Analysis (SNA), we collected data through an online questionnaire survey (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{N} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex>) complemented by de-identified interaction logs. Results show that students' evaluations of Perceived Usefulness (mean = 4.10), Perceived Ease of Use (mean <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=4.00$</tex>), Behavioral Intention (mean = 4.15), and Social Influence (mean <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=4.05$</tex>) are all above the scale midpoint, indicating generally positive acceptance. Using Pearson correlation coefficients to construct a behavioral-similarity network, combined with the Louvain community detection algorithm and Node2Vec node embeddings, we found a clear “core-periphery” structure, with a dense core cluster and a group of peripheral, behaviorally heterogeneous students. Bootstrap analyses further indicate that key edges and central nodes are robust to sampling variation. The findings suggest that students' acceptance of ELCAs is jointly shaped by cognitive and affective appraisals and by their structural position in the peer network. This study provides technical and empirical evidence for designing, optimizing, and deploying educational agents that integrate multimodal AI and network analysis.

title: Auditing Facial Emotion Recognition Datasets for Posed Expressions and Racial Bias
authors: Rina Khan, Catherine Stinson
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Facial expression recognition (FER) algorithms classify facial expressions into emotions such as happy, sad, or angry. An evaluative challenge facing FER algorithms is the fall in performance when detecting spontaneous expressions compared to posed expressions. An ethical (and evaluative) challenge facing FER algorithms is that they tend to perform poorly for people of some races and skin colors. These challenges are linked to the data collection practices employed in the creation of FER datasets. In this study, we audit two state-of-the-art FER datasets. We take random samples from each dataset and examine whether images are spontaneous or posed. In doing so, we propose a methodology for identifying spontaneous or posed images. We discover a significant number of images that were posed in the datasets purporting to consist of in-the-wild images. Since performance of FER models vary between spontaneous and posed images, the performance of models trained on these datasets will not represent the true performance if such models were to be deployed in in-the-wild applications. We also observe the skin color of individuals in the samples, and test three models trained on each of the datasets to predict facial expressions of people from various races and skin tones. We find that the FER models audited were more likely to predict people labeled as not white or determined to have dark skin as showing a negative emotion such as anger or sadness even when they were smiling. This bias makes such models prone to perpetuate harm in real life applications.

title: Ultra-Low-Power Multi-Level Voltage Reference Circuit in TFTs-Based Flexible Circuit Technology
authors: Noor Ul Amin, Roslina Mohd Sidek, Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: Voltage reference circuits with PVT (Process, Voltage, Temperature) robustness and low power characteristics are key components applied in low power analog and mixed-signal systems. This paper presents a multi-level voltage reference circuit in Flexible Integrated Circuits (FlexICs) utilizing 600 nm single N -type thin-film transistors (TFTs) provided by the Pragmatic PDK. The circuit is simulated with a supply voltage range from 1.3 V to 3 V and validated over a temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-10^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 85 °C. It results in three different voltage references as outputs named VREF3, VREF2, and VREF1, which are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.25 \mathrm{V}, 0.830 \mathrm{V}$</tex>, and 0.42 V, respectively. With a supply voltage of 1.3 V, it has a total power consumption of only 53.8 pW with temperature coefficients (TC) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$491 \text{ppm} /{}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 490 \text{ppm} /{}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$487 \text{ppm} /{}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> for VREF3, VREF2, and VREF1, respectively. The line regulation (LR) for VREF3 is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.68 \% \mathrm{V}$</tex>, VREF2 is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.45 \% \mathrm{V}$</tex>, and VREF1 is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.23 \% \mathrm{V}$</tex>. The area occupied by the design is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$715 \mu^{2}$</tex>. The circuit provides robust performance in the presence of process variations and can be used for ultra-low power, area-constrained, and multilevel voltage reference applications in next-generation flexiblebased integrated systems.

title: The Relationship Between Elderly Speech Features in a Life-Logging Application and the Early Detection of Dementia
authors: Naoka Matsumura, Yuta Izutsu, Nobuyoshi Komuro, Natsuko Arimatsu, Aya Matsumura, Kota Toyama, Norimichi Tsumura, Mizuki Umehara, Ayumi Amemiya
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this study, we aim to extract features from voice data of elderly individuals obtained through a life-logging application and evaluate mild cognitive impairment (MCI). Using the life-logging application, we collected approximately one month of voice data from 24 elderly participants (12 married couples, all aged 65 and over), and extracted features for the classification of MCI. As a result, sparse modeling outperformed other models in classification accuracy, achieving a score of 0.73. Furthermore, silent periods, shimmer, and filler duration were found to be important features for distinguishing MCI.

title: Effective multiple access technique to support minimum data rate
authors: Sucheol Kim, Gyeongrae Im, Hyunwoo Jung, Joon-Gyu Ryu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we find an effective method to maximize the minimum data rate. The non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), especially, is compared with the time division multiple access (TDMA) with user equipment (UE) scheduling. For communication systems with large number of UEs, we assess the minimum data rate of each multiple access techniques and also examine the actual time to support the minimum required data for the entire UEs.

title: DX Platform for Evaluating Radiation and Environment Perturbation: An Application to Fukushima Daiichi Decommissioning
authors: Shinsuke Nakashima, Jiaxu Wu, Toshihide Hanari, Takashi Imabuchi, Nobuto Matsuhira, Kuniaki Kawabata, Qi An, Atsushi Yamashita
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Fuel debris retrieval is the indispensable task for decommissioning Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station (FDNPS). One of the significant barriers is the high radiation which deteriorates the operation efficiency. The radiation makes the robot sensors and the electronics get out of order easily. For the acceleration of decommissioning operation, it is required to develop the DX (Digital Transformation) platform to evaluate the sensor performance in the radiation environment. This research presents the approach exploiting a photorealistic game engine. The developed DX platform contributes to evaluate the sensor degradation and image processing algorithm inside the PCV (Primary Container Vessel) of FDNPS.

title: Towards Safe and Secure LLM Systems: Defense Strategies and Assessment Against Inference-Time Security Risks
authors: Vladyslava Tyshchenko, Nazarii Drushchak
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: LLMs (Large Language Models) power diverse applications from creative content generation to human-like usage of the computer, while still being stochastic and unreliable, which creates potential security loopholes in any system that uses them. In our work, we propose a complete flow of security risk management for LLM systems, including cross-stream mitigation strategies and their incorporation into the development life cycle. Within our case study, we evaluate cloud-based and custom guardrails in the context of RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) based systems, proving the instrumental role of guardrails in achieving lower Attack Success Rates for RAG systems and the need for a holistic risk mitigation framework to cover all security risk categories. Our work aims to showcase best practices for trustworthy inferences contributing to more secure and safer LLM-based applications.

title: Exploring the Impact of Elementary School Students’ Programming on the Relationship between their AI Literacy and Creative Thinking Abilities
authors: Binbin Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy is an indispensable competency for citizens in the AI-driven world. The benefits of applying AI in education, such as making tasks more efficient and helping students generate ideas when writing, are impressive but also bring some serious challenges. One of the primary concerns is that students may rely too heavily on AI for tasks, which could diminish their critical thinking abilities. The purpose of this study is to examine the impact of elementary school students’ AI literacy on their creative thinking abilities and whether programming duration moderates this impact. It is quantitative research. Participants are one hundred forty-nine public elementary school students in Suzhou, Zhejiang Province of China, one of the most developed provinces in the country. The results show that students who learned programming outperformed significantly those who did not learn programming in both AI literacy and creative thinking abilities. Moreover, children’s AI literacy significantly predicts their creative thinking abilities. The analysis showed that the higher AI literacy scores children have, the stronger their creative thinking abilities are. Last but not least, children’s programming duration significantly moderates the relationship between their AI literacy and creative thinking abilities.

title: Augmented-GDA: LLM In-Loop Gradient Descent Algorithm for Smooth Unconstrained Optimization
authors: Belgacem Ben Ziada, Thomas Mongaillard, Hang Zou, Samson Lasaulce, Anthony Girardin, Vineeth S. Varma, Mérouane Debbah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The problem of exploiting large language models (LLMs) for solving optimization problems is new and existing papers rarely address the enhancement of standard solvers through LLM capabilities. We introduce an approach to augment gradient descent algorithms (GDAs) by adopting an agentic perspective.
