Indeed, GDAs remain central to optimization and modern machine learning, yet its efficiency often depends on brittle and time-consuming hyperparameter tuning. We investigate whether an LLM can contribute inside a running gradient method for smooth, unconstrained, single-objective standard-form optimization problems (SFOP) with known or estimable gradients. We present Augmented GDA (AGDA), an LLM in-loop controller that monitors progress and adapts learning-rate schedules in real time while keeping the optimizer family fixed within each run. This places the LLM where feedback is most informative, reducing manual trial-and-error without altering the numerical core. Experiments on benchmark functions and two famous deep learning tasks show that in-loop scheduling is competitive with strong static baselines and can yield faster convergence or lower loss.

title: XGBoost-Based Method for Predicting Distribution Network Line Faults and Its Application
authors: Lu Guo, Hongliang Chang, Yongli Liu, Shenli Lin, Guangrong Dong, Jinpeng Meng, Jinlong Tao
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Extreme weather significantly increases distribution network failures, impacting power supply reliability and economic efficiency, while traditional prediction models often neglect meteorological factors. To quantify the impact of weather on failures, this study utilizes outage records and meteorological data from a specific region between 2022 and 2024 to construct a “weather-failure” coupled dataset. It proposes an XGBoostbased distribution line failure prediction model. The model extracts features including daily precipitation, temperature and humidity, wind speed, and cumulative rainfall. Separate classification models are trained for four equipment types: overhead lines, cable lines, pole-mounted equipment, and transformers. Hyperparameters are optimized through five-fold cross-validation, with the model outputting fault probabilities and calculating line fault indices. On the test set, the model achieved accuracies of $\mathbf{0. 8 6}, \mathbf{0. 9 4}, \mathbf{0. 8 8}$, and $\mathbf{0. 8 9}$ for the four equipment types, with F 1 scores of $0.87,0.96,0.91$, and 0.93, respectively. This demonstrates the model’s ability to effectively capture the nonlinear relationship between meteorological variables and failure probability. The high-risk lines identified based on predicted probabilities align with actual outage occurrences. This method provides quantitative evidence for distribution companies to conduct preventive maintenance and formulate meteorological risk control strategies during extreme weather, thereby enhancing the resilience of distribution networks.

title: Low Noise Amplifier MMIC Design for ISAC Using 0.2 um GaN HEMT Technology
authors: YounSub Noh, HyungSeok Lee, Sung-Bum Bae, ByoungChul Jun, JiHun Kwon
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper describes a 2-stage GaN (Gallium Nitride) LNA (Low Noise Amplifier) MMIC (Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuit) for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) applications. The LNA MMIC is fabricated using WAVICE’s 0.2 μm GaN HEMT (High Electron Mobility Transistor) technology. With a compact size of 1.31 mm × 1.66 mm, the LNA MMIC exhibits a gain of 17.4 dB ~ 19.4 dB and noise figure of 1.15 dB ~ 1.4 dB from 7.125 GHz to 8.4 GHz frequency range.

title: PV-CSP Collaborative Optimization Strategy in Power Market Environment
authors: Fubin Yang, Xiaoyu Pan, Shuqi Cai, Yinuo Du, Yunlin Chen
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: Against the strategic backdrop of China’s “dualcarbon goals”, the installed capacity of new energy has grown rapidly. However, the uncertainty of new energy generation leads to intermittent and fluctuating power output, posing severe challenges to the stability of power systems. Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) is characterized by large capacity, low loss, and fast response and regulation, which is of great significance for accelerating the construction of a new energy system. Based on field investigations of photovoltaic-concentrating solar power (PVCSP) joint projects, this study constructs a mathematical model of the molten salt CSP system. With the goal of maximizing the revenue of the joint system, it establishes a PV-CSP joint optimal operation model that considers medium- and long-term contracts, the day-ahead market, and auxiliary services, and designs a case study to verify its feasibility and economic efficiency. This research provides a reference scheme for the optimal operation of PV-CSP systems.

title: A Process and Temperature Insensitive Two-Step VCO-Based ADC in 90nm CMOS
authors: Sheng-Shiang Lai, Hsin-Laing Chen, Jen-Shiun Chiang
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 ~ M H z}$</tex>-bandwidth 10-bit two-step VCO-based delta-sigma ADC with process and temperature calibration is presented. The proposed ADC achieves robust performance and wide bandwidth by leveraging an open-loop structure and highly digital building blocks. The nonlinearities of the coarse and fine VCO-based quantizers are alleviated by distortion cancellation and voltage swing reduction techniques, respectively. A process and temperature calibration scheme is employed to mitigate the resolution degradation caused by KVCO frequency variation under process and temperature variations, aligning the KVCO closely with the desired gain. Benefiting from the intrinsic dynamic element matching the VCO-based quantizer output, the matching requirement of the DAC cells is greatly relaxed. Simulation results in a 90 nm CMOS process demonstrate that the ADC achieves 53.1 dB SNDR and 57.1 dB SFDR over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 ~ M H z}$</tex> bandwidth at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 ~ G S} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> sampling rate.

title: Comparative Study of Machine Learning in Bone Fracture Classification Based on X-Ray Images
authors: Jimmie Henderson Gunawan, Syahla Aurellia Kanista, Riccosan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This study compares pure deep learning models (CNN and ResNet50) with a hybrid approach for bone fracture detection in X-ray images. The hybrid method utilizes CNN for feature extraction, followed by classification using traditional algorithms such as SVM and k-NN. Image quality is enhanced through preprocessing techniques like normalization and CLAHE. Results indicate that the hybrid approach, particularly CNN-KNN, achieves the highest accuracy of 98.29%, outperforming the standalone deep learning models. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining deep learning with classical classifiers for reliable medical diagnosis support.

title: Secure And Verifiable Credentials of Digital Portfolio Using Blockchain
authors: Preksha Pratap, Khushi, Khushi, Diya Khajuria, Abhishek Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The Personal Portfolio serves as the basis for professional representation, as it holds the most weight. However, these centralized Portfolio solutions can be susceptible to such issues as data tampering, security breaches, system downtime, and non-verifiable validity. This article will introduce Decentralize Portfolio, a blockchain-enabled portfolio management solution that utilizes a decentralized architecture to offer Security, Integrity, and Transparency. This solution provides real ownership and trustless verification through the use of IPFS for the storage of files, Ethereum Smart Contracts to generate immutably stored hash codes, and MetaMask for secure user-controlled access. A discussion on the design, development, and potential impact of the Decentralized Portfolio on web3-based Professional Identities will be provided.

title: Web-Based Application to Predict Plant Disease Using Deep Learning for Precision Agriculture
authors: Sattwic Kapoor, Sarthak Srivastava, Namrata Pradeep Raj, Sasmita Padhy, Naween Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The current reliance on manual examination to detect diseases in plants is not effective, subjective, and too slow to deal with the high menace in the world food supply and the agricultural earnings posed by these diseases. This paper addresses the issue with the help of deep learning and specifically a customized Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) that can recognize plant diseases based on leaf images automatically and accurately. It was trained on large dataset of 87,000 photos in 38 categories with a remarkable validation accuracy of 96.66. The combination of this AI system with webbased technologies to perform real-time inferences proves that the given approach can help to increase the rates of disease detection, streamline the process of pesticide application, and make agricultural practices more sustainable.

title: Agentic and Explainable AI for Pulmonary Disease Detection: A Multimodal Imaging Perspective
authors: Raghi R Menon, M Rajeswari, S Stewart Kirubakaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Pulmonary diseases, such as pulmonary edema, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD),pneumonia, are clinically difficult to diagnose and treat. Recent breakthroughs in artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning (DL) have facilitated automated detection and severity assessment of lung diseases in chest radiographs (CXR), lung ultrasound (LUS) and computed tomography(CT). The literature review reveals a number of methods, such as convolutional neural network (CNN), transfer learningtechniques, contrastive learning, and multimodal data fusion, which have shown high prediction performance. Explainability of AI models has been enhanced viamethods (SHAP, LIME, joint image-text learning) towards better clinical integration and trust. However, as it becomes more and more popular, the real-world use also raises issues such as dataset constraints, computational demands, andgeneralization across various patient demographics. In the future, a number of golden directions can be further explored, including improving the robustness of models, optimizing interpretability, and clinical validation of AI-driven detection frameworks for earlydiagnosis and intervention of pulmonary disease

title: Low-Latency 1.5-Bit Quantizer for a 400 Mbps Continuous- Time Sigma-Delta Modulator in 65 nm CMOS for Biomedical Instrumentation
authors: Wang Shengquan, Jagadheswaran Rajendran, Selvakumar Mariappan, Norhamizah Idros, Asrulnizam Abd Manaf, Narendra Aridas, Arokia Nathan, Binboga S. Yarman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and post-layout simulation of a 1.5 bit flash quantizer operating at 400 Mbps for integration in a continuous-time (CT) sigma-delta modulator targeting biomedical instrumentation applications. The quantizer adopts an over-range tolerant scheme to enhance modulator stability and relax comparator precision requirements, offering improved robustness against device mismatch. A fully differential preamplifier-dynamic latch comparator pair is employed to achieve low decision latency while maintaining high linearity, with careful device sizing and common-centroid layout techniques used to minimize input offset. Post-layout simulation in a 65 nm CMOS process confirm correct operation at 400 Mbps with a decision delay below 400 ps and negligible metastability. The design achieves a peak SNDR of 71 dB over a 6 MHz bandwidth, consuming only 65 uW from a 1.2 V supply, and occupies 0.2025 mm2 active area. These results demonstrate the suitability of the proposed quantizer for compact, energy-efficient CT sigma-delta modulators in medical imaging and bio-signal/cell analysis applications.

title: Compact WDM Terahertz Link With SiC-based UTC-PD and High-Speed Envelope Detection
authors: Shinji Iwamoto, Yoshiki Kamiura, Ryo Doi, Chengyuan Qian, Yuya Mikami, Tadao Ishibashi, Hiroshi Ito, Kazutoshi Kato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We demonstrate a compact WDM-based terahertz (THz) wireless system using a single high-power SiC-based UTC photodiode (UTC-PD) at the transmitter and a high-speed envelope detector at the receiver. Two THz carriers (260 GHz and 280 GHz) are generated via photomixing and transmitted through a shared antenna. Coherent detection with a sub-harmonic mixer downconverts the signals to intermediate frequencies (30 GHz and 50 GHz). A custom envelope detector incorporating a Fermi-level managed barrier diode (FMBD) enables direct baseband extraction at Gbit/s speeds. Using this configuration, we achieved 16 Gbit/s transmission (8 Gbit/s per channel) over a 10 cm free-space link.

title: A Simulation-Based Study on Impact of DVS for Side-Channel Attacks
authors: Ryoma Katsube, Shinichi Nishizawa, Toshinori Sato, Tomoaki Ukezono
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper discuss the impact of supply voltage on the difference in tamper resistance against power analysis attacks in cryptographic circuits. It also investigated whether high tamper resistance against power analysis attacks can be obtained by switching the power supply voltage during cryptographic processing. We target circuits without countermeasures and circuits with countermeasures using wave dynamic differential Logic, collected their traces under different power supply voltages, and compare the success rate of key estimation by Correlation Power Analysis (CPA). We created virtual traces that switched the voltage during cryptographic processing and examined the effect of dynamic voltage scaling on CPA resistance. Result showed that a higher tamper resistance could be obtained at a low voltage of 0.9V, and that high tamper resistance could be obtained by dynamic power scaling.

title: Truncated Adder Integration in a Convolutional Neural Network Approximate Accelerator
authors: Lim Qi Yang, Lim Yang Wei, Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani, Noor Ain Kamsani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: With the increasing demand for energy-efficient hardware to support the growing complexity of deep learning applications, optimizing power and area consumption in neural network accelerators has become a critical challenge. This paper investigates the integration of approximate adders into the Eyeriss architecture to improve its energy efficiency without significantly compromising output accuracy. Our results show that using 6-bit approximation achieves an average mean percentage error of 2.90%, while reducing total cell count by 16.87%, area by 18.90% and power consumption by 23.67%. Extending the approximation to 8 bits increases the error to 6.89% but yields further reductions in cell count (22.12%), area (24.580/0), and power (32.22%). This study highlights the trade-off between computational accuracy and hardware efficiency for resource-constrained CNN accelerators.

title: LNOMS-SS: A Low-Complexity LDPC Decoding Algorithm with Hardware Implementation
authors: KaiShi Wang, Cheng Wang, Songsong Cai, Jiewen Jiang, Xi Gong, Weidong Wang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: With the development of low orbit satellite communication technology, how to improve the communication speed of satellite communication systems and reduce the complexity of system design has become an important research issue. Since the invention of LDPC codes, their excellent decoding performance has been favored by researchers. QC-LDPC codes have become the channel coding scheme for the fifth generation new radio (5G NR) data channel, but at the same time, it has also brought challenges to hardware design. We propose the Layered Normalized Offset Minsum and three layer static scheduling (LNOMS-SS) algorithm. On the basis of the traditional Layered Normalized Minsum algorithm (LNMS) and Layered Offset Minsum algorithm (LOMS), the update order of each layer during hierarchical decoding is determined based on the row weight, column weight, and the number of perforated non-zero elements in the BG matrix. We also implemented the algorithm in hardware and designed an 8-levels LDPC decoder. We proposed innovative designs such as a pre-processing based routing network, a segment approximation based Minsum calculation module, and an improved checksum module. The simulation and implementation results show that our proposed LNOMS-SS algorithm has stronger performance than other algorithms, with lower hardware resource consumption and decoding latency.

title: Attribute-Guided and Hybrid Approaches for Interpretable 3D Object Retrieval
authors: Juwon Lee, Suwoong Lee, Seungjae Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: We propose a 3D content retrieval framework that enables interpretable, efficient, and user-controllable search. Existing methods often rely on latent embeddings, which lack semantic transparency. In contrast, our approach extracts explicit semantic attributes, such as shape, material, and style, from 3D object descriptions. We develop two retrieval prototypes: (1) an attribute-only system using interpretable keywords and (2) a hybrid system combining feature similarity and attribute-based filtering. Using a testbed of 3D objects from Objaverse dataset and ULIP-Objaverse-Triplets resource, we demonstrate improved retrieval control and alignment with user intent.

title: The Integration of AI-Driven Multi-UAV Networks, Edge Computing, and MIMO for IoT Applications
authors: Seema Malik, Shreyash Yadav, Rishabh Jain, Dheeraj Joshi, R. K. Yadav
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Assembling a combination of Artificial Intelligence (AI), teams of drones (UAVs), edge computing, and MIMO technology is practically the state of the art of IoT at the moment. This mixture is transforming the way the various industries operate, more so agriculture. When we marry these technologies, we can obtain data, compute and transmit it in real-time much more easily resulting in smart, automated solutions. As an example, swarms of AI-managed drones can patrol large fields in farming to observe the health of plants, deal with pests, and determine how to optimally water the fields. Simultaneously, the MIMO technology enhances communication and allows it to work more efficiently and even with distant locations. It allows decisions to be made immediately on the spot even with limited resources when you add edge computing resulting in faster speeds and reduced delay. Nevertheless, despite such improvement, we continue to have large blocks in the road such as the repair of network structures, energy savings, and security holes. These are some of the problems we will have to contend with to truly utilize the 6G networks in the future. This paper examines these technologies, their application in agriculture and other fields, and the issues that they cause. It also indicates the direction research should take henceforth in order to render these innovations a success in a 6G IoT world.

title: A Study on the Development of a Radio Interference Analysis System for UAM Services
authors: Cheol-Ho Shin, Ho-kyung Son
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This study proposes a radio interference analysis system to support the initial deployment of Urban Air Mobility (UA M) services by enabling evaluation of interference situations with existing wireless communication systems. A UAM-specific interference model is developed as the system’s foundation, supporting quantitative analysis of mutual interference through various met hodologies. Given UAM’s corridor-based operation, interference scenarios involving base station (BS) and flight corridor locations are emphasized. To address these, a terrain-based radio propagation technique is applied to derive optimal corridor routes, BS placement, and antenna configurations that minimize interference. G IS-based visualization further enhances intuitive understanding of interference impacts, providing insights for effective system planning and deployment.

title: VISTA-SLAM: An Edge-Ready Benchmark Vision for Energy, Bandwidth, and Instance-Persistent Multi-Robot Mapping
authors: Michael Akor, Heoncheol Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Today’s robots need to map and track objects over time, work together as a team, and do all this efficiently on limited energy, especially when connected to edge computing over 5G or Wi-Fi. However, existing SLAM benchmarks do not test whether robots remember the same objects across days, agree on object identities with each other, or measure how much energy their mapping takes. To address these gaps, we introduce VISTA-SLAM, a new benchmark that adds three easy-to-understand metrics: how well robots remember objects (IRR), how well teams agree on object IDs (CAIA), and how efficient mapping is for energy use (SEES). We review 126 recent SLAM papers and find that none cover all these challenges. VISTA-SLAM is designed to set a new standard for testing and comparing robot mapping systems, making it easier to build smarter, more reliable, and energy-aware robot teams for tomorrow’s connected environments.

title: A Development of an Intelligent Learning Based Heterogeneous Clustered Hybrid UAV in Wireless Powered Internet of Things Communication
authors: G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Hybrid Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are becoming important as a method of information sharing. This paper introduces an innovative hybrid UAV network architecture called Intelligent Learning for Heterogeneous Clustered Hybrid UAV (ILHCHU) to improve information sharing and throughput. The suggested system employs UAVs as additional computing resources and communication nodes, offering an aerial perspective of the surroundings and aiding in the identification of potential road hazards. The architecture includes a Clustering Algorithm to enhance resource distribution and a probabilistic model-checking to improve battery efficiency. Utilizing this metric, the ILHCHU model is compared with the earlier baseline methodologies, and achieved the least number of communication steps at 70000, 20 unassigned tasks, a lower total score of 12000, a running time of 80, a time consumed of 185, a greater energy consumption figure of 750, and a coverage rate and repeated coverage rate of 97 and 33, respectively, as well as communication steps of 5000 and a communication composition of 8 all accomplished by our proposed ILHCHU model. The hybrid UAV-assisted communication system displays the potential to improve connectivity, optimize resource usage, and monitor the system environment, positioning it as a key solution for wirelesspowered IoT applications.

title: Enhancing Blockchain Security with Multivariate Post-Quantum Digital Signatures
authors: T.Paul Immanuel, K. Anitha Kumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Blockchain technology, recognized for its decentralized, immutable, and transparent characteristics, traditionally relies on elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) to secure digital signatures and ensure transaction integrity. However, the emergence of quantum computing poses a fundamental threat to ECC, as algorithms such as Shor's can efficiently solve the elliptic curve discrete logarithm problem (ECDLP), rendering ECC-based blockchains insecure. This looming vulnerability necessitates the transition to post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) solutions. Among the various PQC families lattice-based, code-based, hash-based, and isogeny-based multivariate cryptography has emerged as the most suitable for digital signatures in blockchain applications, owing to its strong reliance on the hardness of the Multivariate Quadratic (MQ) problem, which remains intractable for both classical and quantum algorithms. Multivariate schemes provide several advantages, including fast signature generation, efficient verification, and scalability, all of which are essential for high-throughput blockchain networks. Within this family, the Unbalanced Oil and Vinegar (UOV) scheme stands out as the most efficient variant. Efficiency analysis shows that UOV achieves a 99.9% smaller private key than SPHINCS+ and 98.9% smaller than Dilithium 5, a 92.3% reduction in signature size compared to Dilithium 5, and a 99.6% lighter runtime memory requirement than GeMSS, enabling practical deployment even on resource-constrained blockchain nodes. Despite its slightly larger public key than Dilithium, UOV remains significantly more balanced than competing schemes, offering the optimal trade-off between quantum security, storage efficiency, and performance. This research explores the integration of multivariate digital signatures into blockchain, with a focus on UOV, to provide a quantum-resistant framework that ensures long-term transaction security, network scalability, and resilience in the post-quantum era.

title: Open5GLoS: Scalable Cloud-Native Architecture for Open-Source 5G Core Networks
authors: Quang-Huy Tran, Quang Tung Thai, Namseok Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents Open5GLoS, the first proof-of-concept (PoC) framework enabling horizontal scaling and NGAP-aware load balancing of the Access and Mobility Management Function (AMF) in a Kubernetes-based open-source 5G Core. Built on Free5GC, Open5GLoS addresses three limitations in current 3GPP architectures: static AMF ID assignment, gNB–AMF connectivity issues from dynamic IPs, and the absence of standardized SCTP/NGAP load balancing. Our design generates unique AMF IDs, provides gateway-based gNB–AMF discovery, and applies UE-aware load balancing at the NGAP layer. Experiments show an average 15–30% reduction in UE registration time for up to 200 UEs, peaking at 36.9% under higher loads, with 100% registration success even at 250 UEs where single-AMF deployments fail. These results highlight architectural gaps in the 3GPP-defined 5G Core, particularly in identity management, service discovery, and transport protocols at scale. By delivering measurable performance gains, Open5GLoS serves as both a practical reference for cloud-native 5G deployments and a critical input for future standardization.

title: Trade Flow Distortion Analysis Using the MöBius Chain Equilibrium Algorithm (MCEA)
authors: Mohamed Abubaker
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The Disruptions to trade flows create serious problems for global economies because they can result in supply chain interuptions, increased spending, and inefficiencies in the market. This paper attempts to process these complexities by applying two-phase analytical approach which combines conventional trade flow models with the latest developed Mobiuis Chain Equilibrium Algorithm (MCEA), to understand better, manage, and cope with trade flow disruptions. To begin with, the analysis uses enacting the gravity model algorithm - a popular strategy in trade research - to make the baseline trade flows, and look at existing relations between the economies of the countries. This algorithm captures the core dynamics of international trade using several economically important factors like economic size, distance, and existence of trade barriers, which together form the flow of trade. The results of the first phase serve as a much needed empirical basis further analysis aimed at identifying distortions in the global trade network. Building on the outputs from the gravity model, the paper then uses the Möbius Chain Equilibrium Algorithm (MCEA) to examine the intricacies of trade flows on a deeper level. MCEA broadens the initial conclusions by modeling how cascading effects due to tariff alterations, geopolitical friction, or supply chain disruptions disrupt the global network. The detailed study of how partner-specific distortions modify equilibrium conditions over extremely intricate systems governed by trade relations between numerous countries with trade relationships is possible due to the algorithm's sophisticated multidimensional interaction modeling features. Integrating both the predictive capabilities of the gravity model and the dynamic attributes of MCEA creates a strong understanding of distortions in trade flow. The results indicate the combined implementation of both algorithms enhances the understanding of the ramifications of trade interruptions, resulting in more precise predictions and better policy interventions. This research highlights the need to incorporate advanced computational techniques to assess and manage the repercussions of trade flow distortions in the contemporary global economic environment.

title: Rapid DDos Detection and Mitigation Framework in SDN Space
authors: Alfred Antonio, Jonathan Djoko, Rexi Leon Saputra, Ika Dyah Agustia Rachmawati
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Modern-era networks commonly use Software-defined networks (SDN) architecture. Due to its centralized nature, various countermeasures have been taken to defend against Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, such as by integrating machine learning models to the controller. Unfortunately, the additional latency and overhead makes it inefficient against large-scale attacks. This paper migrates the machine learning model directly into the switch, increasing detection and mitigation speed on the controller. The network model consists of two hosts (attacker and victim), one switch, one controller and two machine learning models. The experiment compares two scenarios, Random Forest algorithm placed inside the controller and LUCID inside the switch. The detection and mitigation performance is observed through the network traffic captured by sFlow-RT. The result shows the model inside the switch mitigated the attack in 24 % less time after detection than the model inside the controller. This network model provides faster threat response, better performance and greater stability in SDN.

title: Game-theoretic distributed learning of generative models for heterogeneous data collections
authors: Dmitrij Schlesinger, Boris Flach
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: One of the main challenges in distributed learning arises from the difficulty of handling heterogeneous local models and data. In light of the recent success of generative models, we propose to meet this challenge by building on the idea of exchanging synthetic data instead of sharing model parameters. Local models can then be treated as "black boxes" with the ability to learn their parameters from data and to generate data according to these parameters. Moreover, if the local models admit semi-supervised learning, we can extend the approach by enabling local models on different probability spaces. This allows to handle heterogeneous data with different modalities. We formulate the learning of the local models as a cooperative game starting from the principles of game theory. We prove the existence of a unique Nash equilibrium for exponential family local models and show that the proposed learning approach converges to this equilibrium. We demonstrate the advantages of our approach on standard benchmark vision datasets for image classification and conditional generation.

title: Web-Based Gold Investment Prediction Using K-Nearest Neighbor Classification Method
authors: Irfan Hadi, Dentik Karyaningsih, Sriyadi, Andriansyah, Nining Suryani, Ririn Restu Aria
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Gold remains a popular investment asset worldwide; however, many investors struggle to make decisions because of the complexity of influencing factors and the difficulty in analyzing historical data. This study develops a web-based predictive system designed to support more objective and data-driven gold investment decisions. The system integrates four technical indicators-Moving Average Convergence Divergence, Relative Strength Index, Rate of Change, and Stochastic Oscillator-with the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) classification algorithm to analyze price movement patterns and generate investment signals (buy, hold, sell). The evaluation results show that the KNN model achieves high predictive performance with balanced precision, recall, and F1-score, confirming its reliability for classification tasks. The findings highlight that combining technical indicators with machine learning can effectively transform complex financial data into useful insights. This system has the potential to assist novice investors in minimizing risks and optimizing decisionmaking, while also offering a foundation for future enhancements through the integration of more advanced indicators and adaptive models.

title: Automated Brain Tumor Segmentation and Grade Classification of MRI Using CNN and U-Net
authors: Priya Rana, Avantika Kashyap, Avni Singh, Anchal Patel, Md Aman, Aniya Tyagi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: - detecting brain tumors early is crucial to the success of treatment plans and patient outcomes. In spite of the fact that magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an important tool for detecting brain tumors, they are difficult to detect and classify due to their intricate structures and varying intensities. This paper proposes a deep learning framework that combines U-Net-based tumor segmentation and CNN classification to accurately identify grade of the tumor. Our method was evaluated on well-known benchmark datasets to compare how segmentation impacts classification performance. We evaluated our model using metrics like accuracy, recall, precision, and F1-Score, and it consistently outperformed pre-trained models. Combining these tasks increased classification accuracy to 98.8% when segmentation was included.

title: BC-TMICP: A Blockchain-based Transitional Medical Image Copyright Protection Scheme From Centralization to Decentralization
authors: Xiaohong Cai, Yi Sun, Chao Wang, Tianwei Cai, Yusong Chen, Guangyu Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: With the ongoing progress of information technology, digital medical images play a major role in medical treatment and provide great help for patients’ diagnosis. At the same time, the copyright protection of medical images has also attracted more and more attention from institutions in the medical industry. However, the drawbacks of existing security mechanism for managing and protecting image copyright often lead authors to be embroiled in wars of infringement. Even though legislation has been enacted besides of various technical methods to resist against copyright abuse, it is little profitable. Therefore, we propose a copyright protection method based on blockchain for medical images. By integrating with existing centralized image copyright protection solutions and leveraging their data to build and enhance its knowledge base, the method can smoothly evolve to be a decentralized scheme. Moreover, the tamper-resistant nature of blockchain ensures that once a transaction is committed to the chain, it remains protected from any unauthorized modifications. Experiment shows that the delay fluctuation is small and the system throughput continues to grow when the transaction transmission rate is less than or equals to 200 tps. The result demonstrates the robustness of the proposed transitional blockchain-based copyright protection method for medical images.

title: DAPNN: A Residual-Gated Dual-Attention Neural Network for Multi-Objective Task Scheduling
authors: Chandan Ram, Sumathi R
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Real-time systems require task scheduling with multiple objectives because tasks need immediate processing under conflicting time constraints and delay requirements. The current rule-based and single-objective learning approaches fail to handle dynamic and uncertain environments because they lack sufficient adaptability and expressiveness. The Dual-Attention Priority Neural Network (DAPNN) functions as a deep learning system which performs dual tasks of priority estimation and delay-overhead-deviation tracking. The DAPNN model uses a residual-gated dual-attention mechanism to overcome limitations while ensuring the robustness that handle both temporal dynamics and feature importance. The model generates stable and fine-grained state representations through temporal and feature attention modules which use residual gating for enhancement. The evaluation of DAPNN takes place on public simulation data through comparisons with wellestablished baselines including MLP, NN, CNN, GRU, and LSTM. The experimental result outperforms all tasks including priority classification, expected delay prediction, urgency fairness, and fairness-violation prediction while maintaining efficient convergence and stable state. The residual-gated mechanism in the dual-attention pathway operates independently. The findings demonstrate DAPNN as an ideal framework for multi-objective scheduling in critical real-time applications.

title: Diagnosing Lung Cancer Using Machine Learning Techniques and Genetic Algorithm: A Comparison Study
authors: Abeer Bani Younis, Maryam Nuser, Iyad AlAzzam, Abrar AlAbed-AlHaq, Noor Aldeen Alawad
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Lung cancer is the deadliest kind of cancer, with the greatest death rate. After prostate cancer in males and breast cancer in women, lung cancer is the second most frequent type of cancer. According to forecasts from the International Association of Cancer Society (IACS), About 226,650 new cases of lung cancer (110,680 in men and 115,970 in women) and about 124,730 deaths from lung cancer (64,190 in men and 60,540 in women) in 2025. Early diagnosis of lung cancer and especially determining the stage of the disease (early, intermediate, or advanced) help determining the appropriate treatment plan for each patient.In this research, machine learning methods (Decision Tree (DT), K Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM)), classification methods (K-mean clustering), and Genetic Algorithms (GA)are used to diagnose lung cancer. Data about lung cancer patients were collected. (1000 patients). Data pre-processing was performed, then the feature selection step was started using genetic algorithms. After feature selection, the genetic algorithm and machine learning tools are used to diagnose lung cancer. The dataset was randomly divided into 80% for training and 20% for testing. The genetic algorithm and decision tree achieve the best results, with 100% accuracy, then KNN with 99% accuracy, SVM with 98% accuracy, and the k-mean cluster has less accuracy at 67%.

title: A Practical Demonstration of Mach-Zehnder Modulator Chirp Measurement Using a DC Method
authors: Lam Anh Bui
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A novel DC-based method for characterising the chirp factor of Mach-Zehnder modulators is presented and experimentally validated. The approach is demonstrated by measuring the chirp factor α of a dual-drive modulator with a single arm driven. The results confirm the method's accuracy and its ability to capture the modulator's frequency-dependent chirp behaviour. Using only DC measurements, the method simplifies the setup, reduces cost, and maintains high measurement accuracy.

title: Deep Learning-Based SAR Super-Resolution for Accurate Water Body Mapping
authors: Jung-Hoon Lee, Tae-Yoon Kim, Jongtae Lee, Min-Sik Kim, Yu-Jeong Ahn, Habeen Oh, Jae-Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Fine-resolution Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data is crucial for many geospatial applications but is often limited by high cost and accessibility. This study introduces a novel deep learning framework to generate high-resolution SAR imagery, stylistically equivalent to COSMO-SkyMed, from freely available Sentinel-1 data. To mitigate inherent sensor discrepancies, our comprehensive pipeline performs precise co-registration, radiometric calibration, and domain adaptation to bridge the spectral and structural differences between the C-band and X-band inputs. The core of our framework is a multi-scale conditional GAN, inspired by Pix2pixHD, which uses a coarse-to-fine generator and multi-scale discriminators with a composite loss function to reconstruct detailed SAR textures. Our model not only surpasses existing baselines on key image quality metrics (SSIM, PSNR, DISTS) but also demonstrates tangible practical value. When integrated into a downstream water body detection pipeline, the super-resolved images achieved an Intersection-over-Union (IoU) score exceeding 70%, enabling significantly more precise mapping than possible with original low-resolution data. This work validates deep learning-based super-resolution as a scalable and cost-effective pathway to produce high-fidelity SAR data, effectively democratizing access for critical applications like flood monitoring and disaster assessment.

title: Developing a Dynamic Assessment System to Enhance Medical Students’ Learning Outcomes in Medical Image Interpretation
authors: Tzu-Hua Wang, Shu-Yu Liu, Chien-Hui Kao, Chia-Hung Wu, Ching-Yu Lu, Jiing-Feng Lirng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This study, grounded on the Web-based Adaptive Medical Learning (WAML) digital platform, investigates the effectiveness of implementing graduated prompts in the learning process of medical image interpretation among medical students. The research design integrates principles from dynamic assessment and multimedia learning theory, employing three graduated prompts to guide learners from initial observation to clinical integration. Experimental results demonstrate that learners’ performance significantly improved through graduated prompts. Notably, learners with initially lower achievement levels, after receiving the complete sequence of prompts, exhibited final performance comparable to that of high-achieving peers. This finding reflects the compensation effect of the WAML system, effectively narrowing the performance gap. The results affirm that graduated prompting enhances learning outcomes and facilitates knowledge integration and clinical application skills. These findings offer valuable implications for the future development of adaptive and personalized digital instructional platforms in medical education.

title: Analysis of Healthcare Monitoring System with Federated Learning Model for Multimodal Healthcare Data
authors: Arun Sanjay Dalvi, P. William, Firas Tayseer Ayasrah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and healthcare systems has transformed patient monitoring by enabling real-time analysis of diverse health data. Traditional centralized models, however, raise concerns about data privacy, security, and interoperability, particularly when dealing with multimodal healthcare data such as electronic health records, medical imaging, and wearable sensor outputs. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising solution, allowing collaborative model training across multiple healthcare institutions without transferring sensitive patient data. This study examines the application of federated learning in healthcare monitoring systems, focusing on its ability to handle multimodal datasets while ensuring patient privacy and enhancing predictive accuracy. The analysis highlights the advantages of federated learning, such as decentralized training, data confidentiality, and cross-institutional collaboration, while also addressing challenges including communication overhead, model heterogeneity, and data imbalance. Through a critical review and methodological framework, the paper emphasizes the potential of FL to revolutionize healthcare monitoring systems, making them more secure, scalable, and patient-centric.

title: Implementation of SPI Protocol with Adaptive Baud Rate and Configurable N-Bit Transmission
authors: Singam Aruna, Kethavathu Srinivasa Naik, J Divya Harika, Ponnada Divya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Serial peripheral interface (SPI) protocol is very common in embedded systems based on its simplicity, speediness and capability of being full-duplex in communication. A better SPI design is introduced in this work which accommodates an amenable baud rate producer and adjustable N -bit data transmission. Adaptive baud rate mechanism adjusts clock frequency dynamically and allows reliable communication among devices with varying speed needs as well as enhancing flexibility of the system. The design also has a programmable word length which can be conveniently used to transmit variable sizes of data in the word which is longer than the traditional 8-bit word format. The implementation is provided in the form of Verilog HDL and it is tested by simulation hence ensuring that it operates correctly in various configurations. This design has rendered the SPI controller applicable in a large variety of devices which includes sensor interfacing, multimedia data transfer, and FPGA-based communication systems, where scalability and flexibility is of pivotal concern.

title: A Multichannel Photoplethysmography Pipeline with Signal Quality Assessment for Robust Respiratory Rate Estimation
authors: Jeffrey Chow, Nur Ahmadi, Trio Adiono, Fariska Zakhralativa Ruskanda
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Respiratory rate (RR) is a critical vital sign, but its estimation from wearable photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors is often unreliable due to poor signal quality. Conventional methods rely on a single PPG channel, making them highly susceptible to signal corruption. This paper introduces a novel pipeline that leverages multichannel PPG signals (green, red, and infrared) to improve RR estimation robustness. The proposed pipeline integrates a Signal Quality Assessment (SQA) module to dynamically select the highest-quality channel within a sliding window, followed by RR estimation and an exponential moving average (EMA) smoothing filter. To facilitate this research, a new dataset comprising 36 recordings from 12 healthy subjects was collected, featuring synchronized 3-channel PPG and RR reference data. Experiments show the proposed pipeline significantly outperforms a single-channel baseline, reducing the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) by 39.8% (from 3.62 to 2.18 bpm) and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) by 37.5% (from 4.99 to 3.12 bpm). The framework's modularity was validated using a different core estimation algorithm (AIIRE), which also showed consistent performance gains. These findings demonstrate that a multichannel SQA approach is an effective strategy for developing more accurate and reliable wearable respiratory monitoring systems.

title: Towards Secure and Distributed Chest Disease Diagnosis Using X-Ray Imaging and Federated Learning Models
authors: Shree Smeka J, V Sheeja Kumari, S. P. Santhoshkumar, K. Sivasakthi, S. Hariharasudhan, G. M. Banu Priya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: With the increasing adoption of AI techniques for automated diagnosis, radiographic imaging has become a crucial component in modern healthcare for detecting chest-related diseases. Conventional centralized training approaches raise significant concerns about data privacy, especially in healthcare environments where sensitive patient information is distributed across multiple institutions. In order to solve this, this paper provide a privacy-conscious framework for classifying chest diseases that combines advanced the DenseNet-121 model, built on convolutional neural networks, ResNet-34, and ResNet-50 with federated learning (FL). Patient confidentiality is maintained by this method, which permits cooperative model training across several healthcare facilities without exchanging raw X-ray pictures. Only the model weights are centrally aggregated; every association train a local model using its own data. Tests on benchmark chest X-ray datasets shows the federated system greatly improve data security and scalability while achieving high classification accuracy on par with centralized learning. The combination of FL with cutting-edge CNNs provides a reliable, valuable, and private clarification for the finding and detection of chest diseases in the real world.

title: Image classification with a simple photonic perceptron based on heterodyne detection
authors: Miguel Cuenca Piqueras, Carlos R. Fernandez-Pousa, Hugues Guillet De Chatellus
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: The use of photonic architectures to build neural networks is a fast-growing field, both because these systems offer huge computing potential, and because the power consumption of photonic systems is much lower than that of their electronic equivalents. In this context, we have developed a simple architecture based on a simple heterodyne interferometer, enabling vector multiplication. This architecture enables us to process images in the time domain, and perform image classification tasks. More importantly, the building block we propose can be generalized to multi-heterodyne architectures, enabling ultra-high rate matrix computation for neural network layers, and accelerators for convolutional neural networks.

title: Time Series-Based Zero-Day Vulnerability Prediction
authors: Swapnil Shinde, Amar Buchade, Amol Chincholkar, Sumit Hirve, Deepak Naik, Chandrashekhar Kamargaonkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Zero-day vulnerabilities pose significant threats to digital infrastructure, as they are exploited before developers become aware of and patch them. Proactive risk prediction can enhance cyber security by identifying vulnerabilities that are likely to be critical. This study proposes a time series-based machine learning framework for predicting the risk level of zeroday vulnerabilities using Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures. Data. We leverage natural language processing (TF-IDF) on vulnerability descriptions and train gradient-boosting models to classify vulnerabilities as high-or low-risk based on structured and unstructured features. Our approach includes SMOTE for class imbalance and trend analysis to understand the evolution of high-risk vulnerabilities.

title: Millimeter-Wave Fixed Wireless: Challenges and Insights from Models and Machine Learning
authors: Nutwipa Pinkhumpee, Chumphon Kaewmalee, Ukrit Mankong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We present the results of a Millimeter-Wave Fixed Wireless System field trial in a tropical climate. The experimental results verify the applicability of ITU-R and APT Wireless Group models in estimating the combined effects of rain and wind induced attenuation. In addition, the application of a machine learning technique enables dynamic prediction of the received signal strength, as well as gaining insight into the combined effects on the total attenuation due to several weather parameters.

title: Informatics Education in Spain: A Comparative Analysis within the Framework of the DIGITAL FIRST Project
authors: Raidell Avello-Martínez, Sara Guerreiro-Santalla, Blanca López-Moreno, Valentina Dagienė
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This article analyzes the current state of informatics education in compulsory schooling in Spain, within the framework of the European project DIGITAL FIRST. Based on the analysis of primary data (questionnaires and focus groups with teachers and students) and its contrast with transnational evidence, two key dimensions are addressed: the curricular content and pedagogical methods implemented, and the main barriers perceived by teachers. The results show a broad but uneven thematic coverage, with less systematic inclusion of key technical topics such as programming or algorithms. A coexistence is also observed between traditional teaching approaches and emerging active practices, conditioned by teacher training and the availability of resources. Structural barriers include the lack of curricular institutionalization, limited specific training, and territorial inequities. The study concludes with a call for a national strategy to ensure a structured, inclusive, and high-quality approach to informatics education, aligned with current European frameworks.

title: Memory-Efficient Differential Privacy Accelerator
authors: Muhammad Hamis Haider, Nam-joon Kim, Hao Zhang, Janier Arias-Garcia, Hyuk-Jae Lee, Seok-bum Ko
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper introduces a memory-efficient accelerator for differentially private machine learning that significantly reduces memory overhead through in-line noise generation and approximate gradient computation. The core of the design is a metastability-driven Gaussian noise generator paired with an approximate computation unit, both implemented on FPGA and modeled in Pytorch extension library. We leverage controlled clock phase mismatches to induce entropy in flip-flop arrays. These metastable outputs are processed through a pipelined Box-Muller transform to produce scalable, high-throughput noise samples at configurable privacy levels. By integrating noise addition into the computational pipeline, the system avoids the traditional need for separate noise sampling and post-processing stages, reducing per-epoch memory operations by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 5 \%}$</tex> in simulation and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 6 \%}$</tex> improvement in throughput of the accelerator. The proposed approach offers a scalable and practical solution for hardware-accelerated private learning with strict memory and power constraints.

title: Design of Blockchain-Envisioned Security Mechanism for Anti-Malware as a Service
authors: Rishee Bartwal, Aditya Semwal, Abhay Singh Pal, Akshat Mewar, Mohammad Wazid, Saksham Mittal, Noor Mohd., D. P. Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Anti-Malware as a Service (AMaaS) is a cloud-based security system that offers real-time defense against malware attacks. Blockchain can improve AMaaS by offering a safe, decentralized approach to the exchange and authentication of threat intelligence. It guarantees that malware signatures and changes are transparently documented throughout a distributed network and remain immutable. Through the utilization of blockchain AMaaS becomes more reliable and robust because of the reduced probability of data manipulation or single points of failure. In this paper, we propose, a blockchain-envisioned security mechanism for Anti-malware as a Service (AMaaS). It further, strengths the AMaaS by making the use of the consortium blockchain. The use of a blockchain consortium makes it possible to spot and minimize harmful threats very quickly while at the same time encouraging trust and responsibility in verified participants. Smart contracts automate response actions to threats, making the process faster, more dependable, and easier to audit with minimal dependence on humans. In addition, integrating machine learning algorithms into the blockchain system strengthens the predictive powers of the anti-malware service, most notably in identifying obfuscated, polymorphic, and zero-day threats. Experimental analysis shows that the implementation of the proposed scheme improves organization protection and reduces operational expenses compared to signature-based techniques. We also present the architectural design of the proposed scheme, explore challenges related to its deployment, such as consensus management and scalability, and evaluate its broader implications for future cybersecurity infrastructure development.

title: Comparative Performance Analysis of Clustering Algorithms for Scalable and Reliable Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs)
authors: Anish Shandilya, Varuna Gupta, Bosco Paul Alapatt
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANETs), widely used in intelligent transport systems, require effective clustering techniques to maintain network stability, reduce network latency and enhance communication efficiency. This research presents an in-depth analysis of three widely used clustering algorithms: K-Means, Spectral, and Leiden. Efficacy is assessed across different vehicle densities and speeds. The study focuses on examining four primary factors: the modularity of cluster formation, silhouette score, throughput, packet delay and cluster head change rate. The results obtained from the tests indicate that K-Means always sends more data & has the quickest packet delivery which generates the best-shaped clusters to elect CH. This is the best choice for networks with a varying number of cars that change speeds. Leiden does well when there are a lot of cars on the road. It stays stable but changes for huge graphs. Spectral clustering always does worse, with longer delays, less data getting through, and cluster heads that change too much. These findings show that selecting the right algorithm matters when building VANETs that can grow and stay reliable. The study concludes that K-Means is the best choice for cluster formation & electing $\mathbf{C H}$ where there is a need for quick responses and lots of data flow. Leiden works well in packed networks that need balanced performance. Spectral clustering does not work efficiently when keeping the network running in real-life vehicle situations at higher density & speed.

title: Optimizing Random Forest with Genetic Algorithm for Malware Detection Using PE Header Features
authors: Agung Setiaji, Elisa Bahara Soritua
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The growing prevalence of malware poses a significant threat to cybersecurity, necessitating the development of efficient and accurate detection methods. This study proposes a lightweight classification model that leverages Portable Executable (PE) header data for static malware detection using a Random Forest (RF) classifier optimized by a Genetic Algorithm (GA). The approach aims to enhance detection performance while maintaining computational efficiency suitable for real-world deployment. The baseline Random Forest model demonstrated strong classification capability, which was further improved through GA-based hyperparameter tuning. The optimized model achieved an accuracy of 97.89%, precision of 96.61%, recall of 99.45%, F1 score of 98.01%, and an AUC of 0.9978, while also reducing prediction time to 0.79 seconds. Compared to the baseline model, the GA-tuned RF improved accuracy by 1.06% and F1 score by 0.97%. These results indicate that the GA-tuned model not only improves detection accuracy but also enhances model efficiency. This research highlights the effectiveness of evolutionary optimization in improving machine learning-based malware classification and provides a foundation for future exploration of hybrid static analysis approaches.

title: Study and Performance Analysis of Recent Flip-Flops for Low-Power and High-Speed Applications
authors: Dhandapani Vaithiyanathan, Komal Gupta, Ayush Garg, Manish Verma, Preeti Verma, Baljit Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper presents a detailed study and comparative performance analysis of recently reported flip-flop architectures optimized for low-power and high-speed applications. Key designs, including Conditional-Bridging Flip-Flops (CBFF-S and CBFF-D), Static Contention-Free Differential Flip-Flop (SCDFF), 16-Transistor Static Toggle Flip-Flop (16STFF), Modified C2MOS Toggle Flip-Flop (M-C2MOS TFF), and Redundant-Transition-Free Dual-Edge-Triggered Flip-Flop (STC-DET FF), are evaluated using Cadence simulations in 90-nm CMOS technology. Metrics such as power consumption, clock-to-Q delay, and power-delay product (PDP) are compared under varying switching activities and process corners. The results highlight significant trade-offs in power, delay, and transistor count, providing valuable insights for selecting flip-flops that are suited to energyconstrained, high-performance VLSI systems.

title: Lightweight MLP-Based Operator for Real-Time Voxel-Based 3D Object Detection
authors: George Albert Bitwire, Samuel Kakuba, Dong Seog Han
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Real-time 3D object detection is essential for autonomous driving, enabling rapid understanding of dynamic environments. While voxel-based methods excel due to their structured representation and high accuracy, they face computational bottlenecks stemming from the costliness of 3D convolutions and transformer attention, which hinders real-time deployment. Unlike linear recurrent neural network designs such as Mamba, we propose a lightweight MLP-based operator that replaces these components with parallelizable feed-forward blocks, enabling efficient, geometry-aware feature learning in sparse voxel backbones. On the KITTI benchmark, the proposed operator achieves accuracy within ≈1% of a Mamba-based baseline across AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3D</inf>, AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BEV</inf>, AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">bbox</inf>, and AP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">aos</inf>, while reducing forward latency from 126.58ms to 123.99ms (∼2.0%) and increasing inference throughput from 15.80 to 16.13 samples/s (∼2.1%) under identical settings. These results demonstrate its suitability for scalable, real-time 3D perception in autonomous systems.

title: Design and Implementation of an FPGA-Based Voting System with Biometric Authentication
authors: Pericharla Mohith Manikanta Varma, Rajesh Kannan Megalingam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a secure FPGA-based electronic voting system that integrates biometric authentication and pressure-sensitive validation to enhance voter verification and ensure accurate vote casting. The system employs biometric sensors to verify the identity of each voter before allowing access to the voting interface, thereby preventing unauthorized voting. Additionally, a pressure sensor is used to ensure that enough force is applied during the vote casting process, thus minimizing chances of accidental or invalid votes. The voting system works in two modes: voting mode, which captures and validates votes, and counting mode, where votes are tallied and results are displayed. The FPGA architecture allows for efficient real-time processing of biometric data, pressure input, and vote validation. Ensures a very high reliability and security. Testing of the system reveals its efficiency in ensuring that votes are securely captured and counted; hence it's viable to be used in the real-world electoral environments.

title: A Review of Discussions on Support of Regenerative Payloads in NR NTN
authors: Seungkwon Cho, JunHwan Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Support of regenerative payloads in New radio (NR) non-terrestrial network (NTN) has been mainly discussed in the 3rd generation partnership project (3GPP) radio access network working group 2 (RAN2). In early 2024, the discussion started to develop 3GPP Release 19 NR NTN standards which are scheduled to be published in late 2025. In this paper, we enumerate most of issues identified and discussed in RAN2 for support of regenerative payloads. We present a review of those issues including final discussion results. The review shows that support of regenerative payloads has little impact on the existing specifications from the viewpoint RAN2.

title: Development of Neural Network-Based Personalized Controller for Human Assistive Soft Exosuits
authors: Ayoung Shin, Young-Jun Koo, Jeong-Woo Lee, Seong-Ho Lee, Bumho Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Soft exosuits can provide mobility assistance with lightweight and flexible structures, but conventional controllers often require manual parameter tuning to adapt to different users. This study proposes a neural network–based personalized suit controller trained via deep reinforcement learning with a forward dynamics human–suit simulation. Anthropometric information—height and body weight—was incorporated as inputs, enabling automatic adaptation of assistive forces without post-training adjustments. The controller was trained under randomized anthropometric conditions and evaluated on three representative test cases. Performance was compared with a suit-off condition and a conventional model-based controller without anthropometric adaptation. Results show that the proposed controller consistently reduced hip joint mechanical work across subjects, with decreases of about 7% relative to suit-off and 4% relative to the reference model over the entire gait cycle. The greatest reductions occurred during the swing phase. These findings indicate that the proposed approach generalizes across diverse body types, enhances assistive efficiency, and offers a promising path toward real-world soft exosuit control.

title: A Case Study on the Software-Defined Manufacturing for AI-based Autonomous Manufacturing
authors: YgongGwang Oh, Dongkoo Shon, Tae Hyun Yoon, Hongkyw Choi, Woo-Sung Jung, Dae Seung Yoo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Recent advances are shifting manufacturing from automation toward fully autonomous, AI-driven systems. Achieving AI-based autonomous manufacturing demands seamless, real-virtual integration across all process stages, extending beyond individual machine control. This study introduces a software-defined manufacturing framework that combines integrated process control with virtual commissioning to enable such end-to-end coordination. We apply this methodology to an automotive manufacturing process, demonstrating its effectiveness through a case study. In the last, future Software-Defined Manufacturing research issues for the AI-based autonomous manufacturing are summarized.
