title: Coherent Nonlinear Ultrasound Imaging: From Microvasculature to Capillaries_supp2-3665340.mp4
authors: Kailiang Xu
publish: N/A
abstract: It is not straightforward for ultrasound imaging from microvasculature to capillaries. The main challenge stems from the detection of low-velocity or quasi-static signal components in the capillaries. To address this, we propose a coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging method, where a nonlinear coherence operator acted on point spread function is leveraged to improve detection sensitivity of microbubbles. Low-velocity microbubbles can thus be extracted without clutter filtering. Through visualizations of low-velocity microvasculature in rat brain/kidney/testis and early-stage glioma, coherent nonlinear ultrasound imaging paves the way towards capillary-level microangiography.

title: Benchmarking Subjective Quality Assessment Methodologies for Light Field Compression
authors: Saeed Mahmoudpour, Myllena A. Prado, Shengyang Zhao, Carla L. Pagliari, Joao Prazeres, Mylène C. Q. Farias, Antonio M. G. Pinheiro, Adrian Munteanu, Peter Schelkens
publish: IEEE Transactions on Broadcasting
abstract: This study benchmarks the effectiveness of multiple subjective quality assessment (QA) methods for evaluating the perceptual quality of light field (LF) content in the context of image coding applications. A passive visualization approach is adopted, where LF data are rendered as pseudo-video sequences and assessed on calibrated 4K 2D displays under controlled laboratory conditions. Three subjective test protocols, including two rating-based and a pairwise comparison (ranking-based) method, are evaluated through six experimental configurations, incorporating different viewing trajectories and interaction modes. This setup, together with our proposals for deploying inter-rater consistency criteria (e.g., error consistency), enables a comprehensive evaluation of the reliability and suitability of different subjective experiments for LF QA. The results confirm the superior discriminability of the pairwise comparison tests over the rating-based methods. Among the rating-based approaches, the method employing a comparative scale scoring outperformed the one based on an impairment scale. Moreover, the performance of several objective QA metrics was evaluated by comparing their scores against the subjective scores obtained from the three test protocols. The outcomes of this study provide methodological guidance for designing subjective LF quality experiments, highlighting the trade-offs between reliability, sensitivity, and experimental cost, and offer insights relevant to future standardization efforts in LF coding.

title: TSV-Based Shoelace Inductor: A High-Density Solution for Advanced Packaging Platforms
authors: Yushu Zhao, Yousef Safari, Boris Vaisband
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: High-density and high-quality inductive passives are a key requirement to improve the efficiency of high-speed and high-frequency integrated circuits. With the rise of compute-intensive and high-frequency applications, such as machine learning and 6G communication, significant improvements in terms of inductance density and quality of integrated inductors are still required. Shoelace, a novel integrated solenoid inductor structure, is proposed in this paper. The proposed inductive topology, theoretical models, and simulation of key performance parameters are presented. From the simulation result, the shoelace inductor exhibits 28% improvement in inductance density as compared to conventional integrated solenoid inductors. Furthermore, two variations of the baseline TSV-based shoelace inductor, namely the nested shoelace and the magnetic core shoelace, exhibit inductance density of, respectively, 238.81 nH/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 228.32 nH/mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. In addition, the package-level integration of the proposed inductors is also discussed.

title: Detecting potential subsurface water ice at southern Utopia Planitia of Mars using SHARAD datasets
authors: Yuze Cao, Yongjiu Feng, Jingbo Sun, Rong Wang, Panli Tang, Chao Wang, Rong Huang, Yusheng Xu, Xiong Xu, Sicong Liu, Xiaohua Tong
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The detection of water ice is crucial for the scientific exploration of Mars, as the water ice could provide energy support for future human missions. Orbital radars provide wide coverage and deeper penetration compared to infrared and optical imaging techniques, making them crucial for detecting water ice, particularly in low-latitude regions where water ice lies buried deep beneath the surface. The main advantages of subsurface water ice detection by the Shallow Radar (SHARAD) are its capability to invert dielectric constants and characterize subsurface composition based on dielectric properties. In this study, we inverted the loss tangent and subsurface dielectric constants by building a three-layer reflection model, considering the interference of the mantling layer. We also proposed a new approach to map the potential distribution of water ice by quantifying its dielectric properties. The results indicate that the permittivity of the subsurface material in southern Utopia Planitia (16°-32°N, 105°-135°E) ranges from 3.14 to 7.53, while the loss tangent varies from 0.0013 to 0.0374. The distribution of the water ice indicator, which quantifies the potential presence of subsurface ice, reveals two localized regions with moderate ice potential (indicator values of 0.3–0.7), whereas the other regions show low ice potential. Further analysis reveals two types of deposits, including a low-loss deposit, while the remaining regions are dominated by lava flows from volcanic activity. Although we have not found high-confidence evidence of water ice presence in the research area, our research provides a feasible approach to detecting water ice on Mars, and the findings could offer a reference for future Mars landing missions.

title: A Fingertip-Size Six-Axis Force Sensor via Origami Coil Arrays for Intrinsic Tactile Sensing_supp1-3660186.mp4
authors: Hongbo WANG
publish: N/A
abstract: Force and tactile sensing play increasingly important roles in robotics hands to complete complex tasks safely and effectively, complementing the last piece of the puzzle of human-level dexterity. Despite the advances in flexible sensors and skins, tactile sensing at the fingertip of robotic hands remains an open question. Exploiting embedded six-axis force/torque (F/T) sensors for external stimuli estimation, namely, intrinsic tactile sensing, seems to be an effective solution. Here, we present OriCube, an origami-inspired, fingertip-size (14.5 × 14.5 × 12.5 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>), lightweight (4 g), fully integrated, inductive six-axis F/T sensor. It utilizes an origami coil array to achieve self-decoupled six-axis F/T measurements by detecting the displacements and rotations of a metal shell via eddy–current coupling. A modular silicone spring-based elastomer design allows fine-tuning of the stiffness and performance of each axis independently. The calibrated OriCube exhibits a high resolution of 0.01% F.S. (23 N), low crosstalk (2%), high stability (<0.2% drift in 6 h), and insensitivity to strong magnetic field changes. It is capable of detecting light touch by a feather as well as high impact force when hammered. We demonstrate real-time tactile sensing (contact position and force vector) at the curved surface of a robotic fingertip via one embedded OriCube sensor.

title: How Dare You Refuse Me? How and When AI Negative Hiring Decision Influences Applicants' Reactions_supp1-3665195.docx
authors: Xinyi Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Despite the growing attention given to applicants' reactions to the utilization of artificial intelligence (AI) within organizational recruitment contexts, scholars have paid little attention to the emotional mechanism between AI decision-making (especially negative) and applicants' procedural justice perception, as well as how the perception affects their subsequent behavior. Drawing on the cognitive–functional model of discrete negative emotions, we propose and empirically test the effect of anger triggered by AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' procedural justice perception and complaint behavior. General support for the model testing is obtained from two studies, namely, a laboratory experiment (N = 97) that uses technology for facial expression analysis (i.e., Face Reader 8.0) and an online scenario-based experiment (N = 270). The rigor of our findings is enhanced by collecting data from multiple participant sources, using FaceReader and self-reports in a complementary manner to measure anger, and by introducing control variables for robustness checks. We find that AI-driven negative decisions, rather than human-driven ones, elicit greater anger from applicants. Notably, this effect is weakened for applicants with extensive prior AI experience. Moreover, anger suppresses applicants' perceptions of procedural justice, thus yielding a distinct effect on their complaint behavior. Our study contributes to the understanding of the effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' emotional, cognitive, and behavioral reactions. It also sheds light on the influence of applicants' prior AI experience in reducing the negative effect of AI-driven negative hiring decisions on applicants' subsequent responses.

title: Mitigation of Extreme Events in the Distribution Grid Through Control of Flexible Resources
authors: Xavier Weiss, Arvid Rolander, Hussain Kazmi, Lars Nordström, Patrik Hilber
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Despite ongoing efforts to decarbonize society, climate change continues to result in more extreme events that can reduce the electrical grid’s ability to reliably supply power to end users. At the same time, across the distribution grid, Distributed Energy Resources (DERs), such as renewable generation, energy storage systems, and flexible resources, offer the possibility of operating the grid in novel ways. Distribution System Operator (DSOs) could employ these DERs to improve their ability to mitigate extreme events. This work therefore demonstrates how DERs, in the form of flexible loads, can be controlled by a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) agent to minimize Energy Not Supplied (ENS) in the immediate aftermath of an extreme event. To obtain near-optimal performance on unseen scenarios, an enhanced Implicit Q Network (IQN+) architecture is proposed, trained, and evaluated on a modified CIGRE MV benchmark grid. The resulting IQN+ agent can outperform a passive baseline policy, a trained Rainbow DQN policy, and a single-timestep Optimal Power Flow (OPF) based policy on the test set. Sensitivity analysis reveals that the location and quantity of available DERs also impact the efficacy of the IQN+ agent, with the agent preferentially using actions on loads that result in greater average episode durations. These results highlight the potential for RL to rapidly provide decision support to operators by suggesting potential remedial actions to mitigate the impact of extreme events.

title: Adaptive Runtime Risk Assessment with Aging-Aware Feasibility for Safety-Critical Systems
authors: Yaman Qendah, Jannis Hamborg, Christoph Krauß, Stefan Katzenbeisser
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In safety-critical systems, such as vehicles, continuous and adaptive risk assessment is essential for maintaining security throughout the system lifecycle. Traditional Threat Analysis and Risk Assessments (TARAs), confined to the design phase of a system, fail to address unforeseen vulnerabilities during operation. This paper introduces a framework for continuous runtime risk assessment, aligned with the automotive standard ISO/SAE 21434 as a concrete application scenario, combining classical TARA during initialization and an adapted version during runtime. The runtime phase updates a preweighted Attack Tree (AT) based on emerging vulnerabilities and applies an aging function to adjust risk feasibility using the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS). The novelty of the framework lies in its runtime adaptation capability to new threats. We evaluate our framework using representative automotive architectures and attack scenarios and further conduct an extensive evaluation by applying it to a generic autonomous vehicular architecture. Results demonstrate that the system delivers timely and adaptive risk assessments, effectively manages evolving cybersecurity threats, and offers a resource-efficient solution suitable for real-world deployment.

title: Resolving the Transient Current of SiC MOSFETs: A Sparse Representation Framework for Disentangling Oxide and Bulk Traps
authors: Tao Yu, Xuetong Zhou, Jiayu Zeng, Liujun Long, Boyuan Sun, Xinhong Cheng, Li Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Threshold voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) instability induced by oxide and bulk defects remains a critical reliability concern for SiC MOSFETs in high-power applications. Traditional characterization methods struggle to separate overlapping trap signatures from transient drain current measurements, limiting the ability to predict <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> drift under realistic operating conditions. This paper proposes a physics-informed sparse representation framework that couples multi-temperature transient analysis to discriminate oxide and SiC bulk trap contributions to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> variation. By constructing an overcomplete dictionary from established trap models and enforcing cross-temperature continuity, the method resolves five distinct bulk traps (H1-H5) and extracts time constant spectra (TCS) of oxide traps at various gate biases. Experimental results on commercial 1200 V SiC MOSFETs reveal that trap H2 (activation energy 0.631 eV), associated with p-well implantation, dominates <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> transients under short turn-off durations, while trap H4 (0.834 eV), linked to gate oxidation, critically impacts high temperature operation. Oxide traps exhibit voltage-dependent time constants that extend to near-DC regimes, causing persistent <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> shifts. The proposed method provides quantitative trap parameters essential for reliability qualification and physics-based lifetime modeling, enabling more accurate prediction of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {V\_{TH}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> drift in power converters.

title: FMP3+TECS/Rust: Memory-safe Component Framework for Multi-processor Embedded Systems
authors: Nao Yoshimura, Hiroshi Oyama, Takuya Azumi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: In recent years, embedded systems have become indispensable across a wide range of domains, including automotive and IoT applications. The increasing scale and complexity of these systems have intensified the demand in industrial development environments for platforms that ensure reliability, maintainability, and efficiency simultaneously. Conventional programming languages, such as C and C++, offer high performance but suffer from serious issues related to memory safety, resulting in bugs and security vulnerabilities. In contrast, Rust enables safe development by enforcing memory safety at compile time through its ownership and borrowing mechanisms, contributing to improved code quality and maintainability in industrial settings. Component-based development (CBD) supports modularization by units of functionality, enhancing reusability and structural clarity, which facilitates the handling of large-scale and complex industrial systems. Modern embedded applications, which require high processing performance and energy efficiency, increasingly adopt multi-processor architectures to enable parallel execution. This study proposes a Rust-compatible framework that combines the safety features of Rust with the structural advantages of CBD, based on the TOPPERS Embedded Component Systems (TECS) and the multi-processor real-time operating system TOPPERS FMP3. The proposed framework facilitates safe and reusable CBD in practice by designing and automatically generating Rust code that represents the TECS component structure and through optimization of exclusive control while maintaining safety. Evaluation of execution time demonstrates minimal overhead from integration with the multi-processor RTOS, enabling efficient and reliable application development.

title: A Task-Oriented and Lightweight Semantic Communication System with Secure Federated Aggregation in Distributed Wireless Networks
authors: Jiting Shi, Qianyun Zhang, Yinong Xu, Weihao Zeng, Shufeng Li, Zhenyu Guan, Zhijin Qin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Semantic communication (SemCom) has recently emerged as a promising paradigm for enhancing the efficiency and intelligence of wireless networks. Nevertheless, device het erogeneity, resource constraints, and the vulnerability of deep neural networks in open environments pose significant challenges to its practical deployment. In this paper, we propose a task oriented and lightweight SemCom system with secure aggregation for ensuring efficient and privacy-preserving interactions in distributed networks. First, we design a multi-task SemCom framework that unifies semantic feature extraction from sample based datasets. To accommodate resource-constrained devices, we further introduce a feature distillation mechanism that derives lightweight local models without sacrificing inference accuracy. To preserve the privacy of local datasets while leveraging the generalization capability of distributed devices, we develop a secure model aggregation algorithm based on multiparty homomorphic encryption. Simulation results and comparative experiments validate the effectiveness of our system, which fully utilizes the knowledge embedded in existing high-performance models. Our results demonstrate that the proposed local semantic models outperform the baseline models under limited datasets and reduced parameters. We also analyze the trade-off between computational complexity and security in the proposed aggregation scheme, highlighting its applicability to distributed SemCom scenarios.

title: Dynamical Update Maps for Particle Flow With Differential Algebra
authors: Simone Servadio
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Particle Flow Filters estimate the “a posteriori” probability density function (PDF) by moving an ensemble of particles according to the likelihood. Particles are propagated under the system dynamics until a measurement becomes available, when each particle undergoes an additional stochastic differential equation in a pseudo-time that updates the distribution following a homotopy transformation. This flow of particles can be represented as a recursive update step of the filter. In this work, we leverage the Differential Algebra (DA) representation of the solution flow of dynamics to improve the computational burden of particle flow filters. Thanks to this approximation, both the prediction and the update differential equations are solved in the DA framework, creating two sets of polynomial maps: the first propagates particles forward in time, while the second updates particles, achieving the flow. The final result is a particle flow filter that rapidly propagates and updates PDFs using mathematics based on deviation vectors. Numerical applications show the benefits of the proposed technique, especially in reducing computational time, so that small systems such as CubeSats can run the filter for attitude determination.

title: Integration of Vital Signs Monitoring System Based on Single Antenna Bio-Sensing (SABioS) Method_supp1-3661410.pdf
authors: Amine Miled
publish: N/A
abstract: Accurate respiratory monitoring is essential in critical care settings where abnormal breathing can indicate rapid deterioration and require immediate intervention. Existing non-invasive approaches face trade-offs in comfort, reliability, and portability, limiting their clinical applicability. Single Antenna Bio-Sensing (SABioS) offers an alternative by capturing local dielectric variations with a single wearable antenna, enabling comfortable, non-invasive monitoring of respiratory and cardiac activity. This work presents an implementation of SABioS on a compact custom PCB operating at 915 MHz in combination with a flexible sinusoidal dipole antenna sensor and a dedicated acquisition software, demonstrating the feasibility of portable, low-power, continuous monitoring. The system was evaluated against synchronized medical-grade reference devices, providing the first validation of SABioS for accurate cardiac activity detection in addition to respiration, with respiratory rate agreement of MoD ± LoA = <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.005~\pm ~0.217$</tex-math> </inline-formula> bpm and heart rate agreement of MoD ± LoA = <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.0096~\pm ~0.322$</tex-math> </inline-formula> bpm. Additional experiments confirmed stable operation of the system in long-term monitoring and robust performance across wearing configurations and body positions, including recumbent scenarios for sleep monitoring with up to 13.7 dB SNR improvement. Compared to the earlier proof-of-concept setups of SABioS, the integrated system achieves considerably higher signal-to-noise ratio and measurement accuracy, with up to +24.2 dB SNR improvement, underscoring its potential for continuous vital signs monitoring in practical healthcare applications.

title: Non-Invasive Hemoglobin prediction: A machine learning approach
authors: Karan Kumar, Astha Gupta, Nishant Gupta, Sanjay Srivastava, Mohammad Asim
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The global health crisis, which is characterized by low hemoglobin levels, is known as anemia and affects more than three billion individuals worldwide and is a cause of significant morbidity and mortality. The diagnostic techniques most commonly used in classical diagnosis, which are typically invasive blood tests, are often inconvenient, painful, and resource-intensive, and large-scale screening and continued surveillance is virtually impossible, particularly in low-resource settings. The present review looks at the new direction in noninvasive hemoglobin and anemia forecasting based on the ground-breaking potential of machine learning (ML) algorithms. This paper knowledge regarding a variety of 25 academic researches, the types of non-invasive sensing modalities studied, the scope of the diverse ML algorithms that have been applied, and the performance metrics achieved with them. It highlights how these technologies can transform the face of anemia detection by offering real- time, painless, and low-cost modalities of diagnosing anemia. Moreover, the review identifies such significant issues as diversity of datasets, clinical validation, and algorithmic bias because it identifies potential future research opportunities such as federated learning and smartphone-based screening in order to facilitate the successful implementation and delivery of such innovative approaches.

title: Research on AIGC-Empowered Cultivation of Computational Thinking in High School Students
authors: Jiaxuan Liu, Lan Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Computational Thinking (CT) has been designated as a fundamental 21st-century competency within the OECD Learning Framework 2030. Current teaching practices still face challenges such as insufficient teacher capacity for interdisciplinary transformation, high barriers to entry in traditional programming courses, and the lack of dynamic personalized feedback mechanisms. Artificial Intelligence Generated Content (AIGC), leveraging its capabilities in natural language interaction, dynamic knowledge generation, and multimodal output, overcomes traditional teaching limitations and presents new opportunities for CT cultivation. Therefore, this study constructs an instructional model centered on teacher-student-machine triadic interaction, deeply integrating AIGC. A quasi-experimental method was employed to empirically test the effectiveness of this model in enhancing students’ CT skills. The results indicate that the AIGC-empowered instructional model for CT cultivation significantly enhances students’ CT skills. This study provides theoretical support for instructional model innovation within the context of intelligent education, offers an operational exemplar for reforming senior high school IT curricula, and holds significant reference value for advancing the high-quality development of AI-empowered education.

title: Enhancing E-Learning Effectiveness Based on Student Preferences and Actual Learning Behaviors: a Data-Driven Analysis of LMS Usage
authors: Mira Kartiwi, Teddy Surya Gunawan, Zainatul Shima Abdullah, Lili Marziana Abdullah, Aang Subiyakto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: E-learning has become an integral part of higher education, yet there remains a gap between students’ expectations of e-learning content and their actual engagement with the learning materials provided in Learning Management Systems (LMS). Focusing on courses with varying instructional designs, i.e. guided versus unguided activity sequences, the research investigates discrepancies between anticipated and actual elearning behaviors. The study identifies key engagement trends, revealing that courses with guided sequences achieve nearuniversal access rates and more consistent student interactions compared to unguided courses, which exhibit higher variability and selective engagement. The findings underscore the effectiveness of structured learning pathways in promoting balanced and deeper engagement across all content types. These results highlight the importance of intentional course design in digital learning environments, suggesting that guided sequences mitigate inconsistent participation and enhance overall learning outcomes. The study provides actionable recommendations for optimizing e-learning frameworks through scaffolded instructional strategies.

title: TruckIDMe: Driver Identification from J1939 CAN Bus Signals
authors: Atul Patnala, Felesia Ricanek, Hosam Alamleh, Karl Ricanek
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Driver Behavior Modeling (DBM) has emerged as a critical tool for improving road safety, fleet management, and vehicle security by analyzing driving patterns. This study explores the use of DBM for identity verification in commercial trucking by leveraging Controller Area Network (CAN) bus signals. This work is the first such investigation to explore the J1939 CAN bus data for active identity verification while operating a commercial truck. A novel dataset was collected from 50 drivers operating a commercial truck, capturing 129 vehicle telemetry signals. Various machine learning models, including Decision Tree, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), were trained to distinguish individual drivers based on their driving patterns.

title: HAP-Assisted Disaster Relief Communication with AI-Driven Resource Allocation
authors: Arunima Sharma, Shashikala S, Mallika K S, Prabhavati Angadi, Sowbhagya Krishnamurthy
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In the wake of natural disasters, terrestrial communication infrastructure is often rendered inoperative, severely hampering emergency response efforts. This paper proposes a resilient communication framework leveraging High-Altitude Platforms (HAPs) to provide rapid, wide-area connectivity in disaster-stricken regions. We integrate a reinforcement learning (RL)-based algorithm that dynamically allocates bandwidth and adjusts coverage in real time, enabling efficient and adaptive resource management based on environmental feedback and user demand. The proposed system enhances communication reliability, reduces latency, and optimizes spectral efficiency under uncertain and evolving disaster scenarios. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the RL-driven HAP network in maintaining robust communication links and improving overall disaster response coordination.

title: Improvement of A2C Training Efficiency with FSM-Based Meta-Optimizer on CPU-FPGA Platform
authors: Chavakorn Somjaisuk, Yukio Mitsuyama
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The demand for intelligent edge devices with ondevice learning is increasing, enabling real-time adaptation without reliance on the cloud. However, deploying Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) algorithms like Advantage ActorCritic (A2C) on such platforms remains challenging due to slow convergence and high power consumption. This work presents an A2C system enhanced by a hardware-friendly Finite State Machine (FSM) based meta-optimizer to improve training efficiency. The system's core is a lightweight FSM that adaptively tunes learning rates based on reward trend analysis. Evaluated on the CartPole-v1 benchmark, the integrated A2C and FSM-based meta-optimizer system enables convergence in 513 episodes, compared to 758 episodes required by a baseline A2C, achieving 32.3 % faster convergence. This accelerated training reduces total energy consumption by 58.6 % (from 915.2 kJ to 378.81 kJ). Post-synthesis results on an Ultra96-V2 FPGA show the FSM controller consumes only 7 % of LUTs, 6 % of DSPs, and 5 % of FFs, confirming its hardware efficiency. This combination of accelerated training and minimal overhead demonstrates a compelling approach for developing low-power, self-improving edge systems capable of learning directly in the field.

title: GraphRAG-Based Question Answering for Battlefield Situation Analysis from Simulation Logs
authors: Ji Sung Lee, Sungwoo Jun, Sungwon Do, Changeun Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Battlefield simulation logs contain valuable information for situational understanding, but they are challenging for general users to interpret and analyze effectively. This study proposes a graph-based retrieval-augmented generation approach that structures simulation log data as interconnected entities and relationships, enabling context-aware question answering. By combining explicit relational reasoning with large language model capabilities, the method delivers precise and explainable responses to operational queries. Comparative evaluation against a conventional vector-based RAG approach shows improved accuracy and factual consistency, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed GraphRAG method for battlefield situation analysis.

title: Innovative Ultra-Wideband (UWB) Hands-Free Speaker: Advanced Interaction Driven by Machine Learning via Face and Gesture Recognition
authors: Gayathri S, R. Babitha Lincy, Uma Priyadarsini P S, V. Samuthira Pandi, D Jayalakshmi, Marichamy. D
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The rapid evolution of smart audio technology has necessitated innovative interaction mechanisms that enhance user experience, accessibility, and efficiency. This research presents an Ultra-Wideband (UWB) Hands-Free Speaker integrated with Machine Learning (ML)-driven Face and Gesture Recognition to enable seamless, intuitive control without the need for voice commands or physical contact. Traditional smart speakers primarily rely on voice-based interactions, which may be ineffective in noisy environments or inaccessible to individuals with speech impairments. Our proposed system leverages UWB-based localization, computer vision, and deep learning models to achieve precise face tracking, dynamic gesture control, and adaptive audio spatialization. The system architecture comprises three core components: (1) UWB Localization Module, which detects user presence and spatial positioning in real-time; (2) Computer Vision-Based Face and Gesture Recognition System, utilizing deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformerbased models to recognize user identity and interpret gestures; and (3) AI-Driven Audio Processing, which dynamically adjusts sound directionality and volume based on user location and preferences. The proposed system employs a hybrid learning approach, combining pre-trained models (such as YOLO for gesture detection and FaceNet for identity recognition) with real-time adaptive learning for enhanced accuracy and personalization. Key innovations of this study include (i) precise gesture-driven speaker control using spatial UWB tracking and ML-based recognition, (ii) multi-user interaction with adaptive response, ensuring personalized settings for different individuals, and (iii) robust performance in challenging conditions, including low-light environments and high-noise surroundings. Performance evaluation across multiple test environments demonstrates superior recognition accuracy, low-latency response, and user adaptability compared to traditional voice-controlled and touch-based interfaces. This research contributes to the field of humancomputer interaction (HCI), smart home automation, and accessible technology, offering a more inclusive, efficient, and intelligent user experience. Future work will explore integration with edge computing for real-time inference optimization and expansion into multimodal interaction combining facial expressions, body posture, and contextual AIdriven automation.

title: A Hybrid Recommendation Model for Two-Way Selection by Teachers and Students and Its Application in the Postgraduate Information Platform
authors: Zhong Li, Wanying Zhang, Ning Chen, Yanbing Li, Tong Xiao, Junhao Ye
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: As a core link in the cultivation of innovative talents in the country, the quality of postgraduate education is closely related to the accuracy of the matching between teachers and students. The traditional two-way selection mechanism between postgraduate students and teachers has prominent problems such as information asymmetry, low matching efficiency and insufficient semantic understanding. This paper proposes a hybrid recommendation model for two-way selection between teachers and students in response to these problems and integrates it into the self-developed postgraduate training information platform. This model uses Sentence-BERT to conduct deep semantic encoding on the text of the research direction, effectively overcoming the semantic gap of traditional keyword matching. A three-stage hybrid architecture was designed, including an initial screening layer based on semantics and rules, a core matching layer integrating LightGBM ranking learning and time-aware matrix factorization, and a multi-constraint optimization layer based on the improved Kuhn-Munkres algorithm. In a real-world scenario experiment at a certain university, based on the actual mutual selection data of 327 postgraduate students and 125 supervisors, this model significantly increased the success rate of the first round of two-way matching from 0.56 of the traditional method to 0.88. The satisfaction of teachers and students with the matching results (on a 5-point scale) increased by an average of 0.7 points. Meanwhile, the platform has increased the average management efficiency of the entire process from thesis proposal to defense by 0.67. This study confirmed the advanced nature and effectiveness of the proposed hybrid model integrating deep learning, ranking learning and combinatorial optimization in solving the problem of educational resource allocation.

title: Research on Intelligent Identification and Diagnosis Technology of Mechanical Faults of High-voltage Circuit Breakers
authors: Shuang Li, Haitao Bi, Shuai Wang, Jiaqi Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: The reliability of the mechanical operation of highvoltage circuit breakers is crucial for the safe and stable operation of the power system. According to the delay and amplitude characteristics of the split and closing current waveform and the stability of the control power supply voltage waveform, the working state of the switch and closing coil is judged, some fault trends of the switch operation circuit are predicted, abnormal defects of the switch action characteristics are found in time, and the system failure is prevented from being expanded due to the expansion of equipment defects, and an intelligent detection terminal and background system are developed. It has been applied in many fields, realizing real-time monitoring and early warning of circuit breaker status, improving the level of intelligent operation and inspection, and is of great practical significance for ensuring the reliable operation of the power grid.

title: A 66.7dB-SNDR Pipelined-SAR ADC with On-Chip Bit-Weight Calibration Achieving $\triangle \text{SNDR}<2.4 \text{dB}$ Across PVT Variations
authors: Jinwei Zhang, Haolin Han, Ruili Ren, Shubin Liu, Zhangming Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a two-stage pipelined-SAR ADC with offset cancellation technique, which cancels the equivalent offset induced by the comparator and residue amplifier (RA) by forming a feedback path with a notch filter and level-shift circuits. Moreover, the ADC is calibrated on chip through onetime bit-weight calibration together with an independent path to track the interstage gain. Fabricated in a 40nm CMOS process, the prototype ADC achieves a peak SNDR of 66.7 dB and a SFDR of 87.5 dB at 100 MS/s, while consuming 3.7 mW from a 1.1 V supply. The measured <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle \text{SNDR}$</tex> is less than 2.4 dB under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 5 \%$</tex> supply voltage variation and −20¼C-125¼C temperature variation.

title: A Complex Network Theory-Based Robustness Study of Public Transport Systems in Mountainous Cities
authors: Xiangyue He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: To enhance the resilience of public transit systems in mountainous cities under disruptions, this study takes Liandu District of Lishui City, Zhejiang Province, China, as a case study. A bus stop network is constructed based on complex network theory, where bus stops are modeled as nodes and adjacent stops as edges. Network robustness is evaluated using three indicators: average path length, relative size of the largest connected component, and relative network efficiency. Numerical experiments are conducted to simulate network responses under targeted failures and random failures. The results indicate that the bus stop network in Liandu District exhibits scale-free characteristics and shows pronounced vulnerability under targeted attacks, where the failure of 20 % of key nodes reduces network efficiency to approximately 10 % of its original level. In contrast, the transfer network displays small-world properties and demonstrates relatively stronger robustness. Under random failure scenarios, network stability is higher than that under targeted failures; however, the overall resistance to disruptions remains limited. The findings provide theoretical support for the optimization and emergency management of public transit networks in mountainous cities.

title: A Review on Advancements in Automatic Brain Tumor detection and classification using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Priya, Manik Chandra, Sachi Gupta
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: A brain tumor is an uncontrolled, anomalous growth of brain cells that can be harmful to a person’s health. Because brain tumors can be fatal, early identification is essential to increasing survival rates. Because of its higher resolution, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) is frequently used to detect and locate cancerous brain tumors. For efficient categorization, medical professionals typically need additional information about the size, nature, and alterations of tiny lesions. This study’s objective is to determine best combination of segmentation, brain tumor detection using features extraction including Radiomics extraction method, classification and calculates survival Prediction. This paper represents a comprehensive review and comparative analysis of different ML and DL algorithms that are being used for brain tumor detection and classification. Machine learning model’s performance is measured by compared in terms of Accuracy, Recall, F1-score and Precision. We have been concluded that results are improved with segmentation and feature extraction method merged with classification method.

title: Detection of Infected Areas on Pulai Leaves Through Trainable Weka-Based Image Segmentation
authors: Imam Yuadi, Nisak Ummi Nazikhah, Khoirun Nisa'
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Indonesia's biodiversity is increasingly threatened by human activities and climate change, particularly those impacting endemic plant species such as Alstonia scholaris. This tree, which has ecological and medicinal value, is vulnerable to habitat loss and leaf diseases, reflecting broader patterns of terrestrial ecosystem degradation. This study aims to segment healthy and diseased leaf areas using the fast random forest method. This method is processed through the trainable weka segmentation plugin. Based on testing results, this model achieved an IoU of 0.9674 and an F1-Score of 0.9656. These findings demonstrate the potential of lightweight segmentation tools for ecological monitoring and digital conservation, especially in the context of limited resources. Further analysis using jitter plots of pixel intensity distributions also supports the consistency of segmentation performance across preprocessing variations.

title: A Systematic Literature Review on Machine Learning-Based Information Security Risk Management for Higher Education Institutions
authors: Fathoni Mahardika, Ema Utami, Kusrini, Ferry Wahyu Wibowo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: In this study, we conducted a Systematic Literature Review on the utilization of Machine Learning (ML), clustering techniques, and Big Data Analytics (BDA) in enhancing Information Security Risk Management (ISRM), particularly within higher education institutions. From an initial pool of 316 publications, 38 peer-reviewed studies were synthesized, and 10 were analyzed further based on their performance. The review identifies emerging trends, such as hybrid ML models, Explainable AI (XAI), and semi-supervised approaches. Despite these advancements, research specific to academic settings remains limited. This study proposes a direction for developing a scalable, privacy-aware risk management framework tailored to the unique challenges faced by educational institutions.

title: Learning Engagement in AI-Driven Blended Courses: Survey and Strategies
authors: Weining Zhang, Jing Meng, Na Zhu, Jiayi Luo, Yunqiao Li, Jingwei Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: With the rapid integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into higher education, AI-driven blended English courses have emerged as a prominent instructional model. As a critical factor influencing learning outcomes, student engagement requires systematic investigation in this evolving context. Based on Fredricks’ three-dimensional theory of learning engagement, this study surveyed 587 undergraduates to examine their learning engagement in AI-supported blended English courses. The research used the questionnaire survey method from the perspective of three dimensions: behavior, emotion and cognition. The findings indicate a generally moderate-to-high engagement level of engagement, with emotional engagement being the strongest. Besides, notable group differences were observed. female students and arts majors reported higher emotional engagement, while students with higher English proficiency demonstrated stronger behavioral persistence and focus. Based on these findings, the study proposes targeted instructional strategies to enhance student learning engagement across all dimensions, offering both theoretical guidance and practical implications for the development of effective AI-enhanced blended learning environments.

title: Mitigation method for random subdomain attacks to authoritative DNS servers by traffic control
authors: Hikaru Ichise, Yong Jin, Minoru Ikebe, Katsuyoshi Iida
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: DDoS(Distributed Denial of Services) attack has been one of the most critical cybersecurity threats on the Internet. DDoS attacks send a lot of requests to specific servers, such as DNS (Domain Name System), SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol), Web servers, and so on. Eventually these target servers will be forced to stop their services due to the significant high load caused by the DDoS attacks. Random subdomain attack is one of the DDoS attacks, which aims at the authoritative DNS servers.A huge amount of DNS queries for randomly generated subdomain names will be sent to the target authoritative DNS server via a lot of DNS full-service resolvers in a short time period. Consequently, the process of handling non-existent subdomain names will cause a rapid increase in the resource usage of the authoritative server, such as CPU and memory. Thus, when random subdomain attacks occurred on an authoritative server, the Internet users cannot use the Internet services appropriately.In this paper, we propose a mitigation method for the random subdomain attacks by rate limit and traffic control. The proposed method can mitigate the significant increase in the workload and help the authoritative DNS server keep the name resolution service for the legitimate users. We constructed a local network environment and evaluated the proposed method. The results confirmed that the proposed method could mitigate approximately 3.5 times CPU load under pseudo-random subdomain attacks.

title: Self-Pulsating III-V/Si DFB Laser for Tunable Photonic Microwave Generation
authors: Mourad Azhar, Youcef Driouche, Joan Manel Ramirez, Kamel Merghem
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: This paper presents an investigation on the microwave photonic generation using a self-pulsating heterogeneously integrated III-V-on-SOI distributed feedback quantum well laser. By properly adjusting the bias injection currents, we demonstrate the wideband continuous tuning of photonic microwave signals from 5 to 17 GHz.

title: A High Energy and Area Efficiency DCIM with 2TC Based Dual-Layer Approximate Compressor
authors: Ching-Yu Chen, Wei-Chih Ho, Chia-Wei Su, I-Chyn Wey
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: As process technologies advance, analog CIM experience increasing error rates due to PVT variations. While digital CIM robust to PVT variations, it remains low area and energy efficiencies introduced by adder tree. This paper proposes a digital CIM architecture that employs dynamic logic to perform multiplication. A set of ultra-low-cost compressors composed of only two transistors each (2TC) is designed to form a dual-layer approximate compressor using just 30 transistors in total. This compressor reduces 16 multiplication results to a 3-bit output. Compared to precise compressors, the proposed design reduces transistor count by up to 64.7%, effectively simplifying the downstream adder path. Experimental results show that at an operating frequency of 400 MHz, the architecture achieves an energy efficiency of up to 2492 TOPS/W. Validation using the ResNet-20 model on the CIFAR-10 dataset demonstrates that approximation-aware training can achieve an accuracy of 87.6%, combining accuracy, energy efficiency, and simplified hardware implementation.

title: A Survey on 5G NR Sub-band Full Duplex
authors: Cleland Richmond Odarkwei, Anokye Lois Oforiwaa, Yangho Park, Gosan Noh, Kyoung-Jae Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Sub-band Full Duplex (SBFD) has garnered significant attention in both industry and academia as a promising solution to the pressing challenges of maximizing spectral efficiency and overcoming limitations in dynamic resource operation for next-generation wireless communications. This paper surveys SBFD-related standardization activities in 3GPP Release 18 and Release 19, summarizing key procedures for practical deployment, including enhanced transmission and reception operations, SBFD-aware random access, and cross-link interference (CLI) measurement and reporting mechanisms. This study demonstrates that SBFD has progressed from a conceptual proposal into a practical technology ready for commercial deployment and outlines future directions for its standardization and development.

title: A Fuzzy MCDM Method for Solving Software Requirements Selection Problem
authors: Virat Raj Saxena, Udai Shankar, Mohd. Sadiq, Rajeev Yadav
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Software requirements reflect what stakeholders expect and are critical for the success of software projects. To lower development costs, software companies must choose the most important requirements based on their priority rankings. This paper presents a new process of choosing program specifications in a vague manner. Setting. The proposed approach involves the utilization of a particular. Representation of multiplication mathematically, permitting. Typically, decision-makers to rank the requirements. This will make sure that developers will work based on the. Prioritized needs. The approach is reflected in the form of a. case study concentrated on test system in an institute.

title: Scene Matching-Assisted Adaptive Control of Autonomous Vehicles in CARLA Simulator
authors: Yeonsu Jeong, Jiwon Lee, Minseok Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a practical and lightweight system designed to support robust autonomous driving in adverse weather, especially dense fog. Instead of relying on expensive LiDAR or fragile camera-only setups, our approach combines YOLOv5-based object detection with Vehicle-to-Vehicle (V2V) communication. A key feature of the system is a scene matching method that uses ROI Align to compare feature maps between vehicles and verify visual consistency. This enables a two-stage distance estimation process—starting with an estimate based on V2V velocity and timing data, then refining it using the relative sizes of matched objects. We tested the system in the CARLA simulator under varying fog levels, showing stable performance with over 90% accuracy and real-time processing speeds under 0.3 seconds. The system also includes a fail-safe mechanism that ensures safety in extreme conditions. Our results show that combining camera input with V2V communication can provide reliable cooperative driving even when visibility is severely limited.

title: IoT-Based Elderly Health Management System
authors: Mohd Nazim Mohtar, Siti Anom Ahmad, Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The increasing aging population necessitates innovative solutions for elderly care, leveraging advancements in technology to provide comprehensive health management. This paper explores the development of IoT devices designed to support elderly individuals both at home and in community settings. These systems collect and integrate personal health data from wearable sensors and environmental metrics, providing personalized health insights.

title: Automated Detection of Counterfeit Indian Currency Using Image Processing and Machine Learning
authors: P Saraswathi, V Adeline Joanna, Ar Shanmuga Priya, M Prabha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Counterfeit currency remains a major concern in India, especially with high-value denominations such as 100 and 500 rupees. Most of current methods for detection involve manual checks or physical devices, which can be costly and not accessible to small businesses or rural regions. In this research, we recommend a low-cost software-based method for recognizing false Indian currency that makes use of machine learning and image processing. The approach uses OpenCVbased preprocessing techniques to extract important security features such as color patterns, bleed lines, serial numbers, and watermarks. The Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) is used to measure the similarity between test and actual images, and ORB (Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF) descriptors are applied for feature matching. An experimental analysis of images of Indian currency shows that the suggested method delivers promising outcomes without needing costly hardware. The system can be made available as a mobile or desktop application, making it useful for industries like banking, retail, and others where quick and genuine currency authentication is important.

title: Multiple UEs Initial Access Hardware Experiment
authors: Sucheol Kim, Gyeongrae Im, Hyunwoo Jung, Joon-Gyu Ryu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper organizes hardware experiment of msg3 in initial access. For a case of contention, the adoption of IDMA (interleave division multiple access) can allow more than one UEs (user equipment) to successfully access the BS (base station).

title: A High-Gain MIMO Lens Antenna with Meta-Transmissive Surface for Dual Circular Polarization Conversion in 6G Terrestrial, Airborne, and Non-Terrestrial Communication Networks
authors: Muhammad Hussain, Jaeseong Kim, Hyunjong Choi, Minhyup Song
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The proposed Multi-Input Multi-Output lens antenna (MIMO-LA), integrated with a dual circularly polarized meta-transmissive surface (DCP-MTS), enhances the realized gain and aperture efficiency by effectively addressing key MIMO performance metrics, including diversity gain (DG), envelope correlation coefficient (ECC), mean effective gain (MEG), and multiplexing efficiency (Mx. Eff.). By incorporating an extended transition and reflective wall along with DCP-MTS, the MIMO-LA achieves a realized gain of 13.58 dBi, a DG of 10 dB, an ECC of 0.01, a MEG of −3 dB, Mx. Eff. of −3.02 dB, while maintaining an aperture efficiency of 50.8 % at the operating frequency f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> = 7 GHz. These results validate the effectiveness of the proposed design for 6G industrial applications, particularly in terrestrial, airborne, and non-terrestrial communications networks.

title: Optimized Urban Traffic Simulation Framework Using SUMO with Post-Accident Rerouting and Emergency Alert Mechanisms
authors: Kalpana Devi S, Binay Verma, Chetan Jagannatha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Modern transport systems face major problems such as traffic congestion, accidents, slower emergency response. Currently, accidents or unpredicted traffic jams are handled poorly. This paper presents an intelligent urban traffic simulation framework designed in Python and SUMO (Simulation of Urban Mobility) with the precision combining ultra-fast speed and real-time responsiveness. It integrates vehicle dynamic rerouting, accident detection, sound alert systems, and database-driven logging to solve persistent transport problems. The proposed system imitates a real-world traffic network which can automatically detect violations or accidents when they occur within a defined time and area. The rerouting process consists of three separate steps: Dynamic User Assignment (DUA), followed up with Edge Weight Updates, and then Emergency Rerouting. These systems will ensure the impacted vehicles are effectively re-routed with minimal congestion to those vehicles as well as the global traffic supply. A MySQL database is implemented to record all critical events like timestamp, speed violation, accident alert, and rerouting event. The model is able to produce a variety of performance metrics to examine including the time saved for the re-routed vehicles, congestion level at the time, and success rates of routing. But finding the right balance between modularity and performance optimization is not easy but fundamental in enabling it to be re-programmed for real-time scalability and understanding the behaviors of the driver in disrupted situations. The paper represents an intelligent traffic system that prioritizes meaningful changes to improve the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of traffic systems.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Diabetes Mellitus Prediction Using Hemodynamic and Vascular Stiffness Parameters
authors: Wikan Priambudi, Hasballah Zakaria
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) is a major global health concern associated with severe cardiovascular complications, including increased arterial stiffness. The need for an effective, non-invasive screening method is critical for early risk assessment. This study aims to develop and evaluate the performance of several machine learning models for T2DM prediction using a unique combination of non-invasive vascular parameters. A dataset of 69 subjects from a population in Indonesia, with 21 diagnosed with diabetes, was utilized. Four models Logistic Regression, SVM, Random Forest, and XGBoost were trained and validated using a Leave-One-Out CrossValidation (LOOCV) strategy. The results demonstrate that the Random Forest model achieved the highest performance, yielding an overall accuracy of 85.5 percent, an AUC of 0.921, and an F1-Score of 0.74 for the diabetic class. These findings suggest that a machine learning approach using non-invasive vascular parameters is a viable and effective method for early diabetes screening and has significant potential as a clinical decision support tool.

title: Hybrid Karatsuba Toom-Cook Multiplier with Reduced Computational Complexity for Large Operand Multiplication
authors: Sakthimohan M, Dharaneesh J P, Muralidharan M G, Rohind Raj E, Thennarasu R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: In contexts such as digital signal processing, scientific computing, and cryptography, the need for effective multiplication of large operands is critical. Digital multipliers that use a standard design face rising costs in terms of their computational complexity when operand sizes increase. This paper illustrates a hybrid design of multipliers based on the Karatsuba and Toom-Cook algorithms, which mitigates the complexity of multiplication. The present design takes advantage of Karatsuba's divide-and-conquer principle with the partitioning power of Toom-Cook to decrease the number of partial products and arithmetic operations. The proposed architecture was designed, tested, and implemented in practice on Xilinx Artix-7 FPGA (model xc7al00tcsg324-3) using Verilog HDL design language. Results of synthesis and power analysis show that the proposed implementation is viable: achieve a critical path delay of 10.045 ns and a total of 295 LUTs (0%) and 128 bonded lOBs (60%). Although 5 DSP48El slices (2%) are employed, the proposed implementation consumes 0.082 W of power, largely due to standby power in the quiescent domain. Through hybrid design and minimizing latency while keeping power and area usage to a minimum, proposed implementation has shown substantial resource saving in relation to traditional multipliers. The research demonstrates the Slicing of Power of Hybrid Design.

title: Low-Power Inverter-Based Fully Differential OTA in Flexible Integrated Circuit Technology
authors: Noor Ul Amin, Orazio Aiello, Fakhrul Zaman Rokhani, Roslina Mohd Sidek
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents a fully differential two-stage inverter-based operational transconductance amplifier (OTA). It utilizes inverters based on standard cells featuring 600 nm thin-film transistors (TFTs) in flexible integrated circuits (FlexICs) technology, as provided by the pragmatic PDK. The OTA operates at a power supply of 3 V and achieves a differential gain of 34 dB with a gain bandwidth (GBW) of 111 kHz using a 50-pF capacitive load. Despite maintaining comparable performance to the previous Flexible OTAs, this design exhibits a very low power consumption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.2 \mu \mathrm{W}$</tex>, accompanied by a high slew rate of 535 V/ms. The input-referred integrated noise over the entire GBW is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$178 \mu$</tex> VRMS. The OTA performance is compared to that of state-of-the-art flexible TFT-based amplifiers, with a focus on power consumption, GBW, and drive capability. It achieves remarkable performance with a figure of merit (603 MHz.pF/mW) that ranges from 2X to 826X compared to others.

title: SocialCyber: Developing a Cyber Threat Awareness Simulation Game for Thai Adults
authors: Kanda Lertladaluck, Namon Nugoolsuksiri, Sirawaj Itthipuripat, Kejkaew Thanasuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Online social media platforms play an important role in our daily lives but also introduce significant cyber threats, which can negatively impact Thai adults physically, mentally, and financially. To raise awareness and assess susceptibility to these threats, we developed SocialCyber, a cyber threat awareness simulation game tailored for Thai adults. The game uses interactive gameplay with realistic scenarios to educate users. Our study examined the relationship between deception rates, susceptibility to scams, and financial literacy within this game. Findings revealed a significant correlation between deception rates and susceptibility to scams $(r=0.39, p=0.03)$, a negative relationship between deception rates and financial behavior ($r=-$ 0.37, $p=0.04$), and between susceptibility to scams and financial knowledge ($r=-0.37, p=0.05$). These results demonstrate the effectiveness of SocialCyber simulation game in assessing cyber threat susceptibility and highlight the vital role of financial literacy in mitigating scam victimization among Thai adults.

title:
Survey of π
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    , π
                    <sub>0</sub>
                    -FAST, and π
                    <sub>0.5</sub>
                    : Vision-Language-Action Models in the Physical AI Framework
authors: Seonghyun Kim, Samyeul Noh, Ingook Jang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper provides a survey and comparative analysis of three key VLA-based robot policies from Physical Intelligence: π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>, π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>-FAST, and π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</inf>. π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> introduced a foundation model for robot manipulation that couples a pre-trained visionlanguage backbone with a diffusion-based action policy. Building on π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>, the π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>-FAST model incorporated a novel Frequency-space Action Sequence Tokenization (FAST) scheme, enabling up to five times faster training while matching the performance of diffusion models. The latest model, π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</inf>, extends π<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>’s architecture with co-training on diverse data sources and a hierarchical policy structure to achieve real-world generalization demonstrating, for the first time, successful robotic manipulation in entirely new unseen environments.

title: Stability-Aware UAV Trajectory Planning with Sub-Path Decomposition via Diffusion-Reinforced Decision Making
authors: Minjoo Kim, Soohyun Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Autonomous unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) deployed in mobile access environments encounter challenges arising from dense and irregular obstacles as well as stringent energy constraints. Reliable trajectory planning in such a context is critical, since UAVs must maintain connectivity and coverage while navigating through cluttered spaces. Existing diffusion-based reinforcement learning approaches have been explored, but they are generally trained on entire trajectories, which limits their generalization and leads to high re-planning latency in safety-critical scenarios. To address these limitations, we propose a sub-path decomposition framework that generates candidate segments with a diffusion model and applies reinforcement learning to select among them. This design enables finer-grained decision-making, improved safety, and low-latency trajectory updates. Simulations in procedurally generated mobile access environments demonstrate higher success rates and lower collision risks compared to heuristic baselines, while maintaining comparable energy efficiency. Furthermore, the diffusion model trained with sub-paths exhibits lower collision rates and shorter trajectories than the model trained on full paths. This combination of generative modeling and reinforcement learning provides a scalable approach to safe UAV navigation in mobile access scenarios.

title: AI-Driven Causal Analysis for Business Intelligence: A Scalable Approach from Salesforce Research
authors: Marx Prathap Singh Shanmugam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Causal analysis plays a crucial role in business intelligence, customer analytics, and predictive decision-making. This paper presents the Salesforce CausalAI Library, an opensource framework for causal discovery and inference on timeseries and tabular data. Designed for scalability and efficiency, the library leverages parallel computing and automated causal graph generation to enhance decision-making in AI-driven systems. By integrating causal reasoning with AI analytics, the framework enables businesses to understand the impact of interventions, optimize customer engagement strategies, and improve sales forecasting. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms existing causal inference libraries in speed and accuracy, making it a valuable tool for enterprise AI applications and real-world business insights.

title: Brand Perception Analysis Using Glove Word Embeddings in Digital Marketing Intelligence Tools
authors: Md Shoukot Uzzaman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Brand perception is increasingly pertinent in defining consumer engagement, and subsequent experiential and digital content communications and decisions. Recently, advancements in Natural Language Processing has opened a pathway to study consumer perceptions, brand associations, and sentiment at scale. However, most studies examining brand perception are conducted with simple sentiment classification approaches, and mostly keyword approaches and methods, which limits the ability to uncover complex semantic relationships at the level of consumers' brand attribute perceptions or expressions. This also limits any insights gleaned from these studies to be partial limitations, as well as relying on the reliability and accuracy of the marketing intelligence software to some extent. To address these limitations, we present the Contextualized Brand Sentiment Embedding Framework (CBSEF), and the proposed CBSEF encompasses sentimentweighted semantic analysis via Glove word embeddings for mapping brand perceptions in a refined way. The attributes of the framework allows for the extraction of consumer sentiments relating to deeper associations connected to the mention of brands, while allowing for the classification related to their themes of sentiment, such as quality, trust, and innovation, providing marketers for improved interpretability. The experimental analysis in this paper demonstrates that CBSEF performs better than conventional approaches to sentiment in terms of accuracy as well as relevance thematic clustering, and conforms to context. The discussion highlights how this approach can be leveraged to unveil changing consumer attitudes and support dynamic brand perception monitoring. With this approach, marketers can now draw upon actionable insights to refine their digital campaigns, strengthen brand positioning, and manage consumer perceptions.

title: Development of Adaptive Cuckoo Search Controller for Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cell Systems
authors: Gurijala Sreedhar, CH Hussaian Basha, Arun S Gopinath, Nagaraju Dharavat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Nonrenewable energy capturing is reduced in this world because of the heavy installation price, high natural pollution, unable to deliver electricity for short-distance household applications, and low robustness. In this paper, the fuel module technology is developed for the fast electricity distribution to hydrogen-based electric vehicle systems. This fuel module takes low conduction time and is able to deliver continuous energy to the fuel module-dependent automobile system. Here, the fuel module delivers the highly disturbed nonlinear energy to the load circuit. So, the nature-based Moth Flame Optimization technology is referred to as the fuel supply device for making the proposed system give liner energy to the DC-DC converter circuit. This introduced algorithm has the following features more simplicity, a higher conversion ratio, and less implementation complexity. Finally, the fuel module potential development across the load terminal is very low and it is increased by incorporating the voltage multiplier DC-DC circuit. These introduced DC-DC circuit features are a single switch, heavy voltage gain, better voltage transfer ratio, lower voltage defect on the switches, and easy utility.

title: Comparative Analysis of KNN and SVM Classifiers for Brain Tumor Detection Using GLCM, Shape, and Color Features
authors: Dwi Ratna Sulistyaningrum, Budi Setiyono, Darmaji, Amirul Hakam
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: The number of brain tumor cases worldwide is increasing every year. Therefore, early detection of brain tumors is a crucial step to support successful patient treatment. Medical imaging technologies such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) provide detailed images of brain structures, enabling more comprehensive observation of brain conditions. MRI-based brain tumor detection can be improved by integrating GLCM, shape, and color features, which are then classified using machine learning algorithms. This study compares the performance of KNearest Neighbor (KNN) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) in four feature scenarios. Evaluation was conducted using accuracy, precision, and recall metrics for the Tumor and No Tumor classes. The results show that KNN provides more balanced performance in almost all scenarios, especially the complete combination scenario. SVM shows significant superiority in recall for the Tumor class, but with low precision and recall for the No Tumor class. Overall, the combination of GLCM, shape, and color features yielded the best performance, with KNN being the most consistent and balanced method. At the same time, SVM was superior when sensitivity to tumor detection was the top priority. The results of the classification test using KNN showed the best accuracy of 83.33% with the Euclidean distance and a K value of 17.

title: Prediction of Fertility of a Soil Using ANN: A Computational Intelligence Approach
authors: Rahul Bhandari, Suresh Kaswan, Daulat Sihag, Om Prakash Suthar, Reshma Khan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This research investigation is concerned with the use of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) in forecasting soil fertility, a key parameter in optimizing agricultural productivity. As a result of heterogeneity of soil systems and its inherent complexity, standard prediction techniques tend to be unsatisfactory. ANNs, based on their ability to model non-linear and high-dimensional relationships, are a viable alternative. The suggested method placed greater emphasis on intricate physicochemical soil properties-fertility interactions, achieve high training accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 99 \%$</tex>) and solid validation accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{(} \boldsymbol{\sim} {9 0} \boldsymbol{-} {9 3 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$</tex>. This suggests the model's potential for data-driven soil assessment and knowledge-based farm management decision-making. The study also points to the relevance of sophisticated computational techniques to the revolution in agricultural methods, with ANN-based techniques likely to play an important role in precision farming, land management, and yield optimization.

title: Consumer Decision-Making Model Based on Deep Collaborative Embedding and Temporal Attention
authors: Jinghan Zhu, Wanjing Teng, Hongyan Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the rapid proliferation of digital platforms, accurately predicting the complex and dynamic dimensions of consumer decision-making is the key to improving the efficiency of modern business. However, existing models still have limitations in handling the high dispersion and dynamic preferences in consumer decision data. To address this issue, this paper proposes a dynamic consumer decision modeling framework based on deep collaborative embedding and temporal attention mechanism. The framework aims to decouple and robustly reconstruct consumers' long-term latent trends and short-term dynamic interest termination features through deep learning mechanisms, thereby achieving fine-grained characterization and prediction of dynamic consumer decision-making processes. Experimental results on the real-world datasets MovieLens-1M and Amazon Beauty show that DCE-TAM significantly outperforms mainstream benchmark models such as MF, NeuMF, and SASRec across all evaluation metrics. Ablation experiments further confirm the key contributions of the DCE and TAM core modules in enhancing the model's robustness and dynamic feature-capturing capability. This study provides a solution that combines theoretical innovation and practical applicability for consumer prediction under intelligent marketing scenarios.

title: Understanding the Primary Synchronization Signals in 3GPP Cellular Networks
authors: Byung-Jae Kwak, Jin Kyeong Kim, Chanho Yoon, Jung Ho Myung, Young Jo Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper revisits the design of the LTE and 5G NR Primary Synchronization Signals (PSS) and clarifies several misconceptions and answers key questions not easily addressed elsewhere. We show where their characteristic behavior—sharp autocorrelation peaks and low cross-correlations—actually comes from. We also justify frequency-domain mapping over time-domain mapping in OFDM systems. We show that the current 3GPP PSS choices are effective yet not optimal. We also analyze Zadoff-Chu sequences of composite length and demonstrate how specific root selections can produce undesirable cross-correlation peaks, providing guidance for safe root choices. The results offer a unified, implementation-oriented view of existing PSS designs and practical insights for synchronization sequence design in beyond-5G/6G systems.

title: Multi-Head Attention Based Educational Dialogue System for Context-Aware Problem Solving
authors: Zhan Shu, Li Guan
