publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Educational dialogue systems provide personalized learning through natural language interactions, yet existing approaches often fail to effectively capture contextual dependencies across dialogue turns. This paper proposes a context-aware educational dialogue system integrating multi-head attention mechanisms with bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) networks for problem-solving support. The multi-head attention captures diverse contextual patterns from multiple representation subspaces, while BiLSTM preserves sequential coherence. We evaluate our approach on the MathDial dataset containing 3,000 mathematical tutoring dialogues. Experimental results show our method achieves 84.3% accuracy, significantly outperforming six baselines including SVM (64.2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>), Random Forest (68.5%), LSTM (75.3%), BiLSTM (78.6%), and Transformer (81.2 %). Ablation studies confirm both components contribute substantially, with eight attention heads yielding optimal performance. The proposed hybrid architecture effectively combines global contextual awareness with local sequential modeling, offering a promising approach for developing intelligent tutoring systems that support student learning through context-aware dialogue interactions.

title: Robust Cardiac Arrhythmia Classification Using Hybrid SMOTE and Random Under-Sampling and Machine Learning Models
authors: Shankar Sachin Nimmaganti, Vishnu Vardhana Reddy Karna
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Electrocardiogram (ECG) analysis is crucial for the identification and classification of cardiac arrhythmias; it is a gold standard for cardiovascular mortality. In this work, a well-structured classification process for identifying cardiac arrhythmias using the MIT-BIH dataset. This dataset consists of a raw ECG signal pre-processed with wavelet transform to remove noise without affecting diagnostic features. The PanTompkins algorithm identified $\mathbf{R}$-peaks of the segmented ECG signal. Annotations of heartbeat are divided into five classes: normal, ventricular ectopy, supraventricular ectopy, fusion, and unclassified beats, according to the Association for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation (AAMI EC57) standards. The imbalance in classes is balanced using a hybrid method of Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) and random undersampling. The balanced classes were trained and tested using machine learning models to perform the detection of arrhythmias that enhance the accuracy, precision, and recall. The Random Forest classifier is an ensemble method performs the classification of arrhythmia with an accuracy of $99.56 \%$.

title: The Impact of Near-Surface Meteorological Factors and Underlying Surface Conditions on Icing in Low Mountain and Hilly Areas and Its Application in Newly-Built Transmission Line Projects: A Case Study of a Newly-Built Transmission Line in Wanshan District, Tongren City
authors: Xianfu Zhang, Hao Chen, Shuanghe Cao, Yao He, Jiayi Shen
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: To clarify the impact of near-surface meteorological factors on icing in low mountain and hilly areas and provide a scientific basis for icing design, construction, and operation and maintenance of newly-built transmission line projects, this study takes a newly-built transmission line in Wanshan District, Tongren City as the research object. By collecting historical icing survey data from 1991 to 2024, relevant meteorological data from the China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD) for surface meteorological elements in China from December 2007 to February 2008, and land use type data, methods such as extreme icing event investigation, bivariate correlation analysis, collinearity diagnosis, principal component analysis, and multivariate logistic regression analysis were used to explore the influencing factors of icing, construct an icing prediction model, and verify its effectiveness. The results show that: there is a positive correlation between icing magnitude and altitude; temperature, humidity, and vegetation area have little impact on the change of icing magnitude in the same study area; there is a significant positive correlation between temperature, air pressure, and humidity; altitude has a negative correlation with temperature and humidity; precipitation has a certain correlation with all factors; the multivariate logistic regression model constructed by the variable combination (Combination 4) including all elements (air pressure, altitude, vegetation area, precipitation, humidity, wind speed, temperature) has the best prediction effect, with an overall accuracy rate of $\mathbf{7 0. 4 \%}$; the icing distribution in the study area presents the characteristics of “low in the middle and high at both ends”, with 10 mm icing mainly in the central part, 15 mm icing in the western part, and 20 mm icing in the eastern part, and the prediction results are basically consistent with the actual survey situation. The research results can provide data support and technical reference for icing survey and design of transmission lines.

title: Fusion Attention-Driven Residual Generative Adversarial Networks for Realistic Image Generation
authors: Sonal Fatangare, Premanand Ghadekar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The proficient generating tools GANs have risen and have been in successful use, including applications that may break boundaries over image-to-image interpretation, high-fidelity images, fashion exchanges, and all the applications managing with genuine, high-resolution photos. Issues, in any case, stay, counting mode collapse and preparing flimsiness, but particularly on tending to fine subtle elements as in higherresolution pictures. The methodology to be pursued is to come up with a system that is able to independently produce realistic images from text description by enhancing GANs through the use of a text encoder based on BERT. This paper highlights the advantages of self-attention mechanisms, residual blocks, and gradient penalties in improving image creation, aiming for the ideal Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) score. This approach generates images from the noise and features of text, and it creates an authenticity classifier that measures how authentic the generated images are. More so, the proposed approach demonstrates excellent generalization across various mechanisms and thus is quite practical.

title: Stock Price Prediction Using Time Series Analysis And Sentiment Analysis With Random Forest And LSTM Models
authors: Indu Malik, Babli Kumari, Jasmine, Mirnal Sahai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The growing market is dynamic. Market stock price prediction is a little bit difficult because of it frequent ups and downs. Market stock price can be calculated smoothly and frequently with the help of a hybrid neural network. In this research, the authors used an LSTM with a sentiment analysis algorithm for market prediction timely manner. LSTM stores previous data as well as takes new data, such as news, social media posts, and market hype. Social media is a platform where positive and negative sentiment occur frequently, and its effect on market trends, positive sentiment creates a market up while markets go down with negative sentiment. The model generates deep insight of stock-price behaviour by considering long-term trends/trading as well as short-term. This combination of methods improves the integrity of the model in predicting potential shifts in the price resulting in making well informed choices by the investors, reducing the potential risks, and attaining maximum returns.

title: Multi-Scenario Risk Situation Assessment Method for Distribution Networks With High-Penetration Renewable Resources
authors: Haiquan Huang, Jingjing Bai, Junjie Shao, Min Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: A distribution network with high penetration of distributed generation faces significant risk exposure under uncertainties, concurrent multi-fault conditions, and frequent operational mode switching. However, existing assessment methods are typically limited to static power-flow analysis or a small number of scenarios, making it difficult to simultaneously account for normal operating conditions and N-k contingency scenarios, objective data and subjective preferences, as well as low-probability high-impact tail risks. To address these challenges, this paper develops a risk situational assessment method for distribution networks under complex scenarios. First, multidimensional risk indicators are constructed and uniformly mapped onto a evaluation method. Then, a combined objective-subjective weighting scheme is established to derive a comprehensive risk situational index for the distribution network. Finally, comparative analyses are conducted for representative scenarios under different load levels and DG penetration ratios. The results show that, compared with traditional methods, the proposed combined-weighting model exhibits higher sensitivity in identifying localized high-risk areas under heavy-loading and high-penetration renewable resources conditions. It effectively reveals low-probability high-consequence risks in N-k contingency scenarios and enables a refined characterization of the multi-level risk situation of distribution networks, ranging from “secure” to “warning” to “dangerous”. This provides quantitative support for operational optimization and weak-point mitigation in distribution networks.

title: A Neuro-Symbolic Hybrid Framework with Sentiment Analytics for Cryptocurrency Price Movement Prediction
authors: Dhruv Upmanyu, Deepanshu Rathi, Ranveer Chauhan, Neelu Chaudhary
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The cryptocurrency market is very volatile, non-linear and its behaviour changes frequently, for this very reason it is a challenge for traditional predictive models to perform accurate forecasting. Conventional statistical and machine learning techniques often fail because they are time sensitive and they are not able to capture the sequential dependencies completely. To address these limitations, a framework is proposed which combines the temporal learning capabilities of Spiking Neural Networks (SNN), the sequence modelling strength of Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM) and the interpretability of symbolic reasoning followed by the sentimental analysis. SNNs, which are inspired from biological neurons, model the temporal patterns efficiently through spike-based data encoding and neuron firing dynamics, while LSTMs complement them by capturing long term dependencies and by mitigating the gradient issues in sequential forecasting tasks. Both of them combine together to provide a robust mechanism to learn the complex temporal fluctuations in cryptocurrency price and volume data. Interpretability, which is a major limitation of deep learning models, has been enhanced by integrating a symbolic reasoning engine which applies on the neural outputs. Human readable explanations of model selections are provided by using domain specific logical rules. This dual-layered neuro-symbolic integration ensures not just accuracy, but also transparency and traceability which are the key requirements of financial forecasting applications. And this result is more accurate providing transparent, interpretable explanation for financial decision-making.

title: Detecting AI-Generated Text, Images, and Videos: A Review of Methods and Emerging Frameworks
authors: Gaganjot Kaur, Ayush Deep, Sonu Rauniyar, Amrendra Kumar Singh, Charu Sarswat
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: As technology develops that makes it easy to produce extremely realistic digital information such as text, graphics, and video like ChatGPT and similar tools, learning how to distinguish between what is created by a human and what is generated by a machine, is becoming more and more critical. Furthermore, with generative AI continuing to grow at a breakneck pace and allowing anyone who has access to the Internet to easily and quickly produce high quality, convincing text, images, and video, there is an urgent need to develop appropriate methods for detecting machine generated versus human produced content. Thus, regarding the methods of text detection, It will focus on techniques that aggregate many of the different techniques currently being utilized. This will involve examining the performance of pre trained language models, extracting a variety of statistical features from text files, and incorporating several types of machine learning based classification methods into the overall text detection process, such as Classifiers based on Transformer models, to improve both accuracy and understandability of the results produced by the final classification model. With respect to the detection of whether an image is machine generated, this explanation will provide a brief explanation of the most common available detection tools today, which will include those that examine internal details of images, meta information from an image’s electronic file, such as 2915, and a complete digital history of an image to find out whether it is authentic or not. Similar to determining whether or not an image is machine generated, detecting whether a video is machine generated is also one of the biggest challenges. Realistic fakes will often be comprised of actual faces and voices mixed together. By incorporating these new concepts into existing practice, It is more likely to create stronger, clearer, and more reliable methods of detecting machinegenerated content, methods that can build truth and trust in the technology age.

title: A Two-Stage Deep Learning-based Framework for High-Accuracy Network Intrusion Detection
authors: Myung-Sun Baek, Yong-An Jung, Hyoung-Kyu Song
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Network intrusion detection systems (NIDS) are critical for identifying malicious activities. However, the severe class imbalance in network traffic data and the subtle differences between various attack types pose significant challenges for traditional single-stage classifiers. This paper proposes a novel two-stage deep learning framework that decouples the detection of anomalies from the classification of specific attack types. The first stage employs a binary classifier with focal loss to accurately distinguish anomalous traffic from a large volume of normal traffic. The second stage utilizes a multi-class classifier that focuses exclusively on identifying the specific category of attack from the data flagged as anomalous. Both stages leverage the same CNN 1D-LSTM-based architecture, ensuring feature consistency and simplifying the operational pipeline. We evaluate our model on the CIC-IDS 2017 dataset, demonstrating that our two-stage approach achieves a state-of-the-art accuracy of 99.5%, outperforming several single-stage baseline models.

title: Smart Tourism Planning of Tanjung Aan by Considering the Mandalika Circuit Based on Dynamic Modeling
authors: Husain, Herman Mawengkang, Bambang Krismono Triwijoyo, Elyakim Nova Supriyedi Patty, Heroe Santoso, I Putu Hariyadi, Yudi Sutaryana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: The development of smart Tanjung Aan tourism where the location of Tanjung Aan is located in the Special Economic Zone of Mandalika and is the location for the GP motorbike racing so that in its implementation it has an impact on many factors. The dynamic model approach in this study of tourism becomes clearer in many ways, one of which is the development of smart and sustainable tourism. This approach usually considers a particular problem or the overall picture of tourism. Consequently, tourism management for sustainability becomes difficult. This paper provides an overview of the systems thinking approach for systems analysis using the Causal Loop Diagram (CLD) model for the problem of developing smart and sustainable Tanjung Aan tourism. This study shows that systems thinking is an effective and powerful tool for explaining complexities in tourism management systems. It has helped simplify, clarify, and integrate isolated problems related to the industry and provided a mechanism for group learning and decision-making to achieve desired outcomes. This study proposes systems thinking as an appropriate tool for the development of smart sustainable tourism at Tanjung Aan Beach. The results of this study can describe a dynamic model of development with the CLD approach to identify the influencing factors that show cause and effect.

title: NTN Evolution in 3GPP 5G Advanced
authors: Kunju Kim, Seonghyun Kim, Md Sakil Hasan, Refat Khan, Md Gulam Ishak, Jihwan Moon, Kyoung-Jae Lee, Gosan Noh
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs) have gained increasing attention as a means to overcome the geographical and infrastructural limitations of terrestrial networks. By leveraging satellite and aerial platforms, NTNs offer enhanced connectivity in remote, maritime, and disaster-affected areas where conventional deployment is infeasible. This paper provides a structured overview of the technical background and standardization progress that has shaped NTN development within the 3GPP framework. Beginning with foundational studies in Release 15, and continuing through Releases 16 to 18, this paper outlines key architectural models, protocol enhancements, and deployment challenges. In particular, it highlights the dual track evolution of NR-NTN and IoT-NTN systems tailored for broadband and low-power applications, respectively. The conclusion reflects on current limitations—especially those tied to transparent payload systems—and emphasizes the role of Release 19 in enabling regenerative architectures. Overall, this study underscores the critical importance of NTN as a core enabler of global 5G expansion and a foundational element of the future 6G ecosystem.

title: DMECNet: Dynamic Multi-Expert Convolutional Network for Malware Open-Set Recognition
authors: Xin Li, Jiarui Hu, Shumian Yang, Lei Zhao, Lizhuang Tan, Lijuan Xu, Dawei Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of malware presents challenges for cyber security, especially as traditional models assume all families are known, limiting their effectiveness on novel threats. This paper proposes DMEC Net, a dynamic convolutional network for malware open-set recognition (MOSR). DMECNet converts malware into grayscale images and extracts features via a residual-based shared encoder. A dynamic gating mechanism adaptively fuses feature information based on input character- istics, enhancing recognition of known families while improving detection of unknown samples. To further reduce overconfidence in predictions, a logit-based scoring method replaces standard Softmax confidence. Experiments on BIG2015 and Malimg show that DMECNet improves unknown malware detection by 2.5% and 3.7%, respectively, while maintaining high accuracy on known categories. These results demonstrate DMECNet’s effectiveness and practical potential for robust malware detection in

title: Bridging Security Gaps in Software Requirement Specification through Machine Learning: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Sachin Bhardwaj, Archana Sahai, Pankaj Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This review examines how hybrid learning models can be integrated into the creation of secure Software Requirement Specifications (SRS) to deal with the emerging changes in the field of software engineering. The use of machine learning and deep learning in conjunction with statistical methods through hybrid learning models provides a powerful tool of automating and improving SRS processes. The study highlights how these models help in finding, ranking, and improving requirements while keeping data safe and systems reliable using advanced methods like differential privacy and federated learning. By analyzing existing literature, the review offers conclusions about the transformative impact of hybrid learning models on improving the precision, adaptability, and security of SRS. This work sets the stage for future research aimed at creating more resilient, scalable, and efficient systems for software requirement management.

title: Asynchronous Non-binary SAR ADC Inspired by Hopfield Network
authors: Keita Noda, Keita Sugimoto, Hao San, Xueyan Bai, Shogo Katayama, Dan Yao, Anna Kuwana, Zifei Xu, Haruo Kobayashi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This paper presents a non-binary architecture for a Successive Approximation Register (SAR) Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) based on Hopfield network. The direct implementation of this architecture with a charge-redistribution Capacitive Digital-to-Analog Converter (CDAC) is shown to possess an asymmetric error correction capability stemming from its single-ended circuit topology. To overcome this issue, a configuration incorporating a common-mode voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{c m}$</tex>) is proposed, thereby achieving a pseudo-differential structure. An 8bit, 10-step ADC was designed based on the proposed architecture using a 65 nm SOTB CMOS process. Its viability was confirmed and its performance in terms of AD conversion speed and power consumption was evaluated through SPICE simulations.

title: A Survey of Military Anti-Satellite Weapon Systems and Corresponding Countermeasures
authors: Eunhyuck Kwon, Sungjae Park, Sunghwan Cho
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Real-time satellite communications are increasingly vital for modern military operations, yet Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites face growing threats from anti-satellite (ASAT) weapons. This paper reviews kinetic and non-kinetic ASAT systems—such as direct-ascent missiles and electronic attacks like jamming and spoofing—and assesses their impact on space-based assets. Recent conflicts, notably the Russia- Ukraine war, highlight these vulnerabilities. The study also outlines countermeasures including orbit maneuvers, decoys, beamforming, and anti-jamming techniques. By analyzing current threats and defenses, this work suggests strategies to improve the resilience and survivability of LEO satellite communications.

title: Generative AI for Networking
authors: Faisal Zaman, Ouns Bouachir, Moayad Aloqaily, Ismaeel Al Ridhawi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) and Large Language Models (LLMs) are revolutionizing network management systems, paving the way towards fully autonomous and self-optimizing communication systems. These models enable networks to address complex decision-making tasks across both short-term operational scenarios and long-term strategic planning. Through natural language understanding, LLMs can analyze customer inquiries, predict network congestion patterns, and automate troubleshooting processes, leading to more efficient customer support and network maintenance. GenAI can optimize content delivery by generating personalized recommendations, improving user engagement, and dynamically adjusting network resources based on real-time demands, ultimately enhancing overall performance and user experience in telecommunication services. In this paper, we discuss the pivotal role of GenAI in advancing network performance and achieving the ultimate objective of self-adaptive networks. Moreover, we present a use case that leverages the self-attention mechanism of transformers to perform long-term traffic prediction. Harnessing these cutting-edge technologies demonstrates the transformative power of LLM and GenAI in revolutionizing telecommunication networks, elevating resilience and adaptability to unprecedented levels.

title: A HEVC Steganography Scheme Based on Intra-Frame QDST Coefficient
authors: Si Liu, Yunxia Liu, Hongguo Zhao, Cong Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: As the core encoding standard for $\mathbf{4 K} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{8 K}$ videos, HEVC holds a dominant position in satellite television, streaming media platforms (such as Netflix), and professional film and television storage. Its compression efficiency is $\mathbf{4 0 \% - 5 0 \%}$ higher than that of H.264. Exploring video steganography schemes based on the HEVC standard holds significant application value. This paper presents a highperformance HEVC steganography algorithm based on Intra-frame QDST coefficient. Due to the problem of intraframe distortion drift caused by embedding the intra-frame $4 \times 4$ QDST blocks, this paper first proposes a corresponding solution. Then, in order to reduce the amount of modification to the QDST blocks required by the solution, this paper presents an efficient embedding scheme, further enhancing the imperceptibility of the algorithm. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed steganography scheme exhibits good imperceptibility and embedding capacity.

title: Robust Doppler Compensation for LEO-OFDM Radar Sensing Using Hierarchical 2-D Grid Search
authors: Zahra Zarei, Fitsum Debebe Tilahun, Chung G. Kang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In low Earth orbit (LEO) integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) waveforms encounter severe Doppler shifts and Doppler rate variations arising from the rapid motion of satellites and targets. These time-varying distortions disrupt subcarrier orthogonality and smear the range–Doppler response, causing conventional FFT-based estimation to fail. This work investigates a robust Doppler compensation framework for LEO-OFDM radar sensing. To address this, a hierarchical two-dimensional grid search is introduced to jointly estimate the dominant Doppler frequency and Doppler rate, maximizing a coherence-based metric across OFDM symbols. The results confirm that the proposed 2-D Doppler compensation effectively improves detection reliability.

title: Real-Time ERP-Integrated Adaptive Decision Intelligence Architecture for Enterprise-Scale Supply Chains
authors: Alok Chakraborty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Global supply chains are increasingly complex and vulnerable to cascading disruptions caused by geopolitical events, climate change, transportation delays, and volatile market conditions. Traditional planning and forecasting approaches are often reactive, siloed, and slow to respond, limiting enterprise agility. This research introduces a novel, real-time Decision Intelligence (DI) framework that integrates Transformer-based multi-horizon forecasting with a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) optimization engine, deployed as containerized microservices with seamless ERP/WMS integration and SAP Transportation Management (TM). Unlike prior work, which often combines ML forecasting and optimization in offline or research-only settings, this framework delivers sub-5-second SKU-level decision-making and converts optimization outputs into actionable logistics instructions via SAP TM, enabling real-time adjustments of delivery dates, freight orders, and carrier assignments. Experimental evaluation on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2}$</tex>-month simulated global supply chain dataset demonstrates up to 28% improvement in forecast accuracy, 15-20% cost reduction, and improved service levels, highlighting both the technical novelty and practical enterprise impact of this real-time, adaptive DI architecture.

title: Sim-to-Real Neural Perception for Terrain Classification in Search and Rescue Robotics
authors: Christyan Cruz Ulloa, Naresh Ravichandran, Diego Argüello Ron, Alicia Prieto, Anders Lansner, Pawel Herman, Jaime Del Cerro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Developing robust perception systems for autonomous Search and Rescue (SAR) robots remains a critical challenge due to the scarcity of annotated data from hazardous environments. Real-world datasets are constrained by safety limitations and rarely capture the visual complexity, structural variability, and sensor artifacts characteristic of disaster scenarios. This work introduces a reproducible methodology for generating high-fidelity RGB datasets using NVIDIA IsaacSim, enabling the photorealistic simulation of post-disaster environments with controllable terrain textures, occlusions, and dynamic sensor effects. The pipeline incorporates automatic pixel-wise semantic labeling and is used to train a brain-like neural network model called Bayesian Confidence Propagation Neural Network (BCPNN) that first learns representations in an unsupervised manner and then classifies terrain textures once the labels are made available. The proposed framework is validated through extensive experiments in both simulated environments and physical testbeds that recreate representative SAR conditions under controlled settings. Results show that BCPNN models trained exclusively on synthetic data can generalize effectively to real-world RGB inputs, capturing terrain semantics with sufficient fidelity to support autonomous mobility decisions. This contribution provides a scalable data generation and learning pipeline for perception in extreme environments and establishes a practical foundation for deploying probabilistic terrain understanding in field-ready SAR robotics. The datasets of this development are available in the Zenodo repository. and code in the GitHub repository.

title: Design and Analysis of the Helical Antenna using HFSS
authors: A. Sridivya, Suraya Mubeen, T. Sriram, N. Moham, B. Sunitha, K. Nithil Navtej
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The following research depend on the design and analysis of a helix antenna model using HFSS, a electromagnetic simulation tool. Helical antennas are widely value for their broad bandwidth, gain, and natural circular polarization, making them well suited for advanced applications such space exploration and satellite communications. The project briefs with a deep theoretical principles and governings of helical antenna. The design phase in HFSS involves careful tuning of crucial parameters such as the pitch angle, number of turns, and conductor thickness. The variables are optimized to achieve specific performance, goals like enhanced gain, impedance matching. The outputs like radiation patterns, characteristics like gain, and impedance matching are systematically reviewed to for antenna’s efficiency. The project gives slight modification on aspects like helical radius, turns spacing, and coil counts substantially alter resonance behavior and radiated features. This under scores how geometrical controls are essential in both the digital designs, physical constructions phases. HFSS plays the major role in the studying detail field visualizations, optimization process, leads to a more refineing and effective antenna structure.

title: A Model for Multi-Period Facility-Location and Vehicle Assignment in Post-Disaster Areas Under Uncertainty Using a Deep Learning Approach
authors: Rizki Habibi, Herman Mawengkang, Tulus, Elvina Herawati
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: We propose an integrated multi-period model for facility-location and vehicle assignment in post-disaster areas under demand uncertainty. The pipeline couples a Temp oral Convolutional N etwork forecaster with a capacitated facility-location formulation and multi-depot capacitated vehicle routing, operating online with de layed labels. Using a 20 D emand Nodes, 20 period s synthetic benchmark, we evaluate an operational window (period: 2-20) and a holdout tail (period: 15-20). Operationally, TCN attains the lowest MAPE (7.83%) and RMSE (16.00), improving day-to-day allocation versus baselines. On the stabilized tail, the field-signal baseline slightly outperforms TCN, significant in paired tes ts, consistent with cleaner late-horizon signals. The optimizer sustains near-perfect service (average fill-rate 1.00; minimum 0.97) with a lean plan (1 active D istributi on Center per period), compact routing (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2-4$</tex> vehicles per period; longest tour 146.38 km) and a cumulative cost of IDR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$298,908,410.92$</tex>. Findings show how predictive accuracy, service-level constraints, and cost structure jointly shape robust humanitarian logistics decisions.

title: A 5V-to-1V Hybrid Buck Converter with Asynchronized Switched Inductors and Hybrid Controls for Fast Load Transient
authors: Haoqiang Deng, Ming Yu, Ruidong Li, Chen Hu, Guoqing Li, Xun Liu, Junmin Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid buck converter featuring asynchronized switched inductors that combines voltagemode PWM and adaptive on-time (AOT) control loops. To achieve high efficiency and fast load transient response, a hybrid dual-path structure and a fast-switching buck stage are designed to reduce the voltage stress on power transistors and limit the voltage swing at the switching node. The combined use of voltage-mode PWM and AOT control improves transient performance. Non-uniform inductors are adopted to enhance the slew rate of the overall inductor current and to improve system power density. Implemented in 180 nm BCD technology, the proposed converter achieves a peak efficiency of 96.1% at a voltage conversion ratio (VCR) of 0.267. In addition, the proposed converter demonstrates a fast transient response. For a load step of 10 ns from 0.2 A to 2.2 A, the undershoot and settling time are 49.2 mV and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>, respectively.

title: The Evolution of Provenance-Based Intrusion Detection Systems: A Review of Approaches, Limitations, and Future Directions
authors: Su Wang, Zhiliang Wang, Hongbin Sun, Zheyu Jiang, Xia Yin, Dongqi Han, Han Zhang, Xingang Shi, Jiahai Yang
publish: IEEE Network
abstract: The provenance graph, due to its ability to fully preserve historical information within a host, has been extensively studied and applied in the field of host intrusion detection. Such research is collectively referred to as provenance-based intrusion detection systems (PIDSes). However, recent surveys on PIDSes face limitations such as outdated literature and insufficiently comprehensive classifications. To systematically summarize the evolutionary trajectory and experimental evaluation framework of PIDSes, this paper conducts a literature review from the perspective of PIDSes evolution, proposing a more refined framework for host threat detection. For each fundamental step within the framework, representative PIDSes are reviewed and introduced. Additionally, we qualitatively analyze state-of-the-art (SOTA) PIDSes from the perspective of experimental evaluation, summarize seven key findings derived from experimental evaluations, and provide an analysis of future research directions addressing some existing limitations in the field of PIDSes.

title: Optimized SVM Strategy for Three-Phase Single-Stage Isolated Resonant AC-DC Converter to Enhance Grid Current Quality
authors: Siwei Wu, Haorui Wang, Fengjiang Wu, Yuchen Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article investigates the grid current distortion in the three-phase single-stage isolated resonant ac-dc converters controlled by the standard current space vector modulation (SVM). By deriving the expression of the grid current based on the SVM, it reveals there is the inherent theoretical grid current control error. This error increases with the increase of the modulation index and resonant network impedance angle (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\theta}$</tex-math></inline-formula><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</sub>) and accordingly exacerbating the grid current distortion. To address this issue, an optimized SVM strategy is proposed. The active vectors sequence is redesigned to make the vector dwell times independent of and avoid the effect of the variation of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\theta}$</tex-math></inline-formula><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</sub>. Furthermore, a vector dwell time calculation method based on the resonant current integral model is introduced to eliminate the theoretical grid current error. Detailed experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively suppresses the grid current distortion and verify its accuracy and effectiveness.

title: Evolution of Enhanced Performance of ITO Framework-Based TFTs
authors: Chunlan Wang, Zihan Qin, Xiaohong Liu, Tao Liu, Hao Shi, Dinghao Ma, Jianguo Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: The synergistic enhancement of both the electrical properties and stability of oxide thin-film transistors remains an urgent problem to be solved. Indium tin oxide (ITO) framework (ITO/ITO:indium gallium zinc oxide (IGZO):O) thin-film transistors (TFTs) were fabricated by depositing a Sn-doped IGZO layer on ITO, followed by low-power oxygen treatment. Compared with ITO-based devices, superior performance was shown by the ITO framework TFTs, achieving a high mobility (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\mu }_{\text {FE}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of 52.3cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/Vs, a low threshold voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm{V}_{\text {TH}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of −0.52V, and a steep subthreshold swing (SS) of 0.49V/dec. The devices also exhibited enhanced bias stability, with a threshold voltage shift (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\Delta }$</tex-math> </inline-formula> <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathrm{V}_{\text {TH}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> of +1.89V under positive bias stress (PBS) and −1.32V under negative bias stress (NBS). Notably, this work used the ITO framework structure fabricated by the cosputtering process, which effectively alleviated the interface stress and reduced the interface state density. Combined with the low-power oxygen treatment strategy, defect passivation was achieved, effectively suppressing oxygen vacancies. The synergistic mechanism of the framework structure and oxygen treatment in balancing performance and stability was clarified. These methods provided a simple and effective approach for optimizing oxide thin-film transistors.

title: Scalable Multi-Robot Motion Planning Using Workspace Guidance-Informed Hypergraphs
authors: Courtney McBeth, James D. Motes, Isaac Ngui, Marco Morales, Nancy M. Amato
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: In this work, we propose a method for multiple mobile robot motion planning that efficiently plans for robot teams up to 128 robots (an order of magnitude larger than existing state-of-the-art methods) in congested settings with narrow passages in the environment. We achieve this improvement in scalability by extending the state-of-the-art Decomposable State Space Hypergraph (DaSH)multi-robot planning framework to support mobile robot motion planning in congested environments. This is a problem that DaSH cannot be directly applied to because it lacks a highly structured, easily discretizable task space and features kinodynamic constraints. We accomplish this by exploiting knowledge about the workspace topology to limit exploration of the planning space and through modifying DaSH's conflict resolution scheme. This guidance captures when coordination between robots is necessary, allowing us to decompose the intractably large multi-robot search space while limiting risk of inter-robot conflicts by composing relevant robot groups together while planning.

title: Adaptation and Validation of HAIS-Q for Measuring Information Security Awareness in Indonesian Government Institutions
authors: Muhammad Ihsanul Hakim Mokhsen, Rio Guntur Utomo
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: This study addresses the critical issue of low information security awareness among employees in Indonesian government institutions, a major contributor to data breaches, with 68 % of incidents linked to human error, according to the 2024 Verizon Data Breach Investigations Report. The research adapts the Human Aspects of Information Security Questionnaire (HAIS-Q) to the Indonesian context by incorporating Law No. 27 of 2022 on Personal Data Protection and ISO/IEC 27001:2022 as justifications for the data protection focus area, alongside modern cyber threats such as AI-based attacks and quantum threats, which necessitate employee awareness to recognize and mitigate risks like deepfake-based phishing and potential future data decryption. A mixed-method approach was employed, utilizing quantitative data from a pilot study of 30 government employees to test the instrument, analyzed through Pearson correlation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{r}>0.361,5 \%$</tex> significance) and Cronbach's Alpha (0.920 for knowledge, 0.903 for attitude, 0.853 for behavior), complemented by qualitative insights from expert interviews to validate the inclusion of security culture and data protection focus areas. The adapted HAIS-Q, with 54 items across knowledge, attitude, and behavior dimensions, enhances relevance for Indonesia's public sector. The results provide a reliable, context-specific tool for assessing and improving employee awareness, enabling targeted training and policies to strengthen cybersecurity and safeguard sensitive data.

title: Comparative Study of PRTG and Grafana-Prometheus for Monitoring Information Technology Infrastructure
authors: Dita Nurmadewi, Yusran Rizky Mulyadi, Shidiq Al Hakim
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The effective monitoring of information technology (IT) infrastructure is vital to maintaining the stability and performance of systems in businesses. The speed of notification of incidents in IT infrastructure is critical to minimize downtime and ensure that risk mitigation steps can be taken early. Therefore, this research aims to compare the performance of PRTG Network Monitor and the combination of Prometheus with Grafana regarding alert notification speed, built-in features, and security protocols. The study adopts a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative measurement of alert delivery times with qualitative analysis of system features and security protocols. A simulated environment, using VirtualBox, was set up to evaluate each system's performance under controlled conditions. The results indicate that Prometheus and Grafana excel in alert notification speed and dashboard flexibility, while PRTG offers simpler management but faces scalability and integration challenges. This study provides insights into selecting an optimal monitoring system tailored to IT infrastructure monitoring needs.

title: A Survey of Model Inversion Attacks on Image Domain
authors: Changjin Kim, Chanwoo Hwang, Sunpill Kim, Jae Hong Seo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The widespread deployment of deep learning models in sensitive applications has raised increasing concerns about potential privacy risks. Among them, the Model Inversion Attack (MIA) stands out as a notable threat, aiming to reconstruct data samples representative of the model’s private training data. These risks are particularly concerning in the image domain, where successful attacks may lead to the recovery of recognizable faces or sensitive medical images. In response to the growing research interest in this area, this paper presents a comprehensive survey of MIAs applied to image data. We propose a systematic taxonomy that categorizes attacks by threat models, technical attributes, and core methodologies. Additionally, we discuss widely used evaluation metrics and outline the landscape of existing defenses against MIAs.

title: A Review of the Use of Machine Learning Algorithms in Analyzing Student Performance
authors: Abdullah M. Alfarwan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The use of Machine Learning Algorithm (MLA) tools to analyze student performance has increased rapidly in the last five years. Forty-six empirical studies of MLA used for student performance analyses were systematically reviewed. The results show that most studies employed MLA for prediction of learning performance and were conducted in the classroom or an online learning environment among university students majoring in STEM, with data sources coming from their universities’ system. Students’ behavioral information is most used for measuring students’ outcomes. Deep learning (neural networks) was the most often used MLA technique and possessed the most accurate results. Wrapper technique was the most used feature selection method and cross-validation the most used validation method used with the models.

title: Alma de Tezontle: Artificial intelligence applied to environmental water education
authors: Sergio Palomino-Gámez, José Carlos Vázquez-Parra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Water scarcity is an urgent environmental issue that demands innovative strategies to foster awareness and action within society. In this context, the present study examines the impact of a customized conversational model, Alma de Tezontle, on raising awareness among university students about the water crisis. Using a quasi-experimental design, we compared the waterrelated perceptions of an experimental group, which interacted with the conversational model, and a control group, which received traditional instruction. The results show that the experimental group achieved a higher overall mean score compared to the control group, with a statistically significant difference according to Student’s t-test. Furthermore, the effect size calculation (Cohen’s $d=0.40$) indicated a moderate impact of the AI-based intervention. These findings suggest that interacting with Alma de Tezontle contributed to a greater awareness of the water crisis, highlighting the potential of conversational models in environmental education. In conclusion, integrating artificial intelligence into environmental education represents a promising tool for strengthening ecological awareness and fostering reflection on water sustainability.

title: Efficient MXINT4 Inference via Hardware-Based Dynamic Sparsity Detection and Skip-Activation
authors: Youngchan Kim, Hyun Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Microscaling (MX) quantization has recently garnered significant attention due to its ability to achieve high compression ratios while preserving critical information across various deep learning tasks. It has been officially adopted and deployed across diverse hardware platforms. However, the blockwise processing required during MX quantization introduces considerable overhead, resulting in substantial latency when executed on conventional hardware. Consequently, it becomes challenging to realize actual computational acceleration using standard architectures. This highlights the necessity for a dedicated hardware design tailored to MX quantization, capable of mitigating such overhead and enabling practical speedups. In this paper, we present a hardware quantizer module specifically designed for the MX format and propose the MX quantizer with dynamic sparsity detection (MQDS), which identifies activation sparsity during the quantization process. Furthermore, we introduce a sparse computation flow that leverages the outputs of MQDS to address the area overhead and latency compatibility issues inherent in conventional MX quantization approaches. Experimental results demonstrate that MQDS achieves an average activation skip detection ratio of 66.49 % on vision transformer models while occupying only 12.2 % of the area compared to traditional integer quantization designs.

title: Machine Learning-Based Fault Diagnosis in Electric Motors: A Predictive Maintenance Approach
authors: Ruchi Patel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Industrial bearing faults detection is important in health monitoring of rotating machinery. Electric motors are employed in numerous industries as important equipment. However, electric motors may have a range of problems due to variables including extended use, environmental concerns, and lack of proper maintenance. In order to diagnose and detect electric motor faults using DL and ML approaches, this research study intends to examine the bearing dataset from Case Western Reserve University (CWRU). The experimental outcomes show that the proposed model has an excellent performance with 99.99% accuracy, 99.34% precision, 99% recall and 99.12% F1score, and the loss is remarkably low at 0.001. The comparative testing with this model against existing models like RNN, Xception, Kernel Naive Bayes and SVM shows that the proposed CNN is the most accurate and robust. The manual feature engineering removal ability and the capacity to acquire complex patterns in real time directly out of spectrograms is a major benefit of the model when deployed in real-time. The results show that the suggested approach works well for smart issue detection and has potential for use in large-scale industrial environments. The main objectives of the future endeavors will be improvements in real-time integration and the possibility of generalizing to unfamiliar forms of faults in varying conditions of operation.

title: Sparsity and Autocorrelation Peak Difference Based Joint Noise Level and Blur Extent Estimation
authors: Yu-Chieh Yu, Kuan-Lin Chen, Jian-Jiun Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: The levels of blur and noise play a crucial role in guiding adaptive image restoration and enhancement. This is particularly important due to the inherent trade-off between denoising and deblurring: denoising may oversmooth fine details in sharp regions, while deblurring can introduce artifacts in smooth or noisy areas. To address this challenge, we propose a two-stage method for jointly estimating the noise level and the blur extent of an image. In the first stage, we estimate the noise level and perform denoising to reduce its interference with subsequent processing. In the second stage, we assess the global blur extent from the denoised image. In this work, an efficient and content-invariant noise estimation technique enhanced by sparsity-based compensation and a reliable blur quantification strategy that utilizes difference of peaks (DoP) are proposed. With these techniques, both the noise level and the blur extent can be estimated in an accurate way.

title: Assessment of Crop Yield Forecasting and Evaluation of Climate Change Effects Utilizing ML Methodologies in Agricultural Practices
authors: Vimla Dangi, Chandrashekhar Goswami, Prasun Chakrabarti
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the ever-growing consequences of climate change, granular predictions of agricultural yields are irreplaceable in maintaining the global food security and evidence-based farm planning. However, availability of conventional statistical problems often lacks the nonlinear and time-varying relationships among climatic, soil, and agronomic factors specifically temperature variations, use of pesticides, and rainfall by necessitating misrepresentation and hence destruction of predictive efficacy. The framework uses Gradient Boosting as the meta learner in calibrating final predictions by using Random Forest, Support Vector Regression and the Gradient Boosting Regressor as base learners. To enhance the ability of the model to detect complex interactions as well as linear trends, feature engineering is used in the model using feature scaling and polynomial transformation. Extensive data covering yield history, weather impacts (temperature and rain), and farm inputs (pesticides, fertilizers, and state-to-state data) were utilized both during the training and during the validation of the model. With a weighted F1-score of 0.86, a coefficient determination (R2) of 0.9397, and a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 297, performance evaluation produced exceptional results that outperformed traditional and previously suggested hybrid models. The outcomes show how well such a sophisticated stacking-based ensemble method can generalise across a range of agro-ecological settings and understand complex data distributions.

title: IoT-Enabled Smart Light Management System for Enhancing Layer Quail Farming Efficiency
authors: Norrarat Wattanamongkhol, Nivorn Srikoon, Patcharawadee Poolsamran, Onsulang Sophiphun, Chanakan Laksana, Paitoon Kaewhom
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In Thailand, small-scale farmers are becoming interested in quail farming because it is relatively inexpensive to start, easy to operate, requires minimal space, and produces many eggs quickly. However, if the illumination is not correct, it may significantly reduce egg production. Additionally, controlling temperature and humidity in the area is crucial for maximizing productivity and maintaining the birds' health. This article discusses the development of a smart light management system that integrates with the Internet of Things (IoT) to enhance the efficiency of laying quail farming. A smartphone dashboard lets you monitor and operate the system from anywhere. The experiment utilised LED lights of various colours and photoperiods in different containers. We maintained the temperature at 30°C and the humidity at 65%. When necessary, a sprinkler system was used to lower the temperature. When there was excessive humidity, ventilation fans were used to regulate the level. The results showed that the LED light spectrum had a significant influence on how eggs were made. A 14:2 hour red-to-green light cycle gave the best results. The results indicate that utilizing LED lights with specific spectral qualities is an effective method for enhancing egg production, improving bird health, and increasing egg yield.

title: Fact Checking in Low Resource Languages: Creating Translation-Based Datasets and Benchmarking for Farsi
authors: Alireza Moghaddam, Lwin Moe, Uyen Trang Nguyen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Misinformation poses significant risks to public health, trust, and social cohesion. However, fact-checking datasets and models remain scarce in low-resource languages (LRLs) such as Amharic, Burmese, Chechen, Farsi (Persian), Maguindanao, Pashto, and Uighur. Creating large, manually curated datasets in these languages is often prohibitively expensive. This paper proposes a resource-efficient method for building fact-checking datasets in LRLs using machine translation. Specifically, we introduce FNC-1F, a Farsi dataset created by translating the widely used Fake News Challenge dataset (FNC-1) from English to Farsi with the No Language Left Behind model. Using FNC-1F, we fine-tuned and evaluated three transformer-based models ParsBERT-FA, RoBERTa-fa-ZWNJ, and mDeBERTa-v3. We also validated their performance on real-world, manually curated Farsi test data. Results show that models trained on the translated dataset generalize effectively to native Farsi with only minor performance loss. Beyond presenting a practical approach for building fact-checking datasets in LRLs, this work also establishes the first benchmark for evidence-based fact-checking in Farsi.

title: Performance and Cost Optimization of Federated LLM Agents in Edge Computing Environments
authors: Goutam Tadi, Akshay Mittal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The deployment of Large Language Model (LLM) agents is shifting from centralized cloud infrastructures to decentralized edge computing environments to achieve reduced latency and enhanced data privacy. This transition is driven by the emergence of edge AI applications such as autonomous vehicle command recognition, industrial process monitoring with natural language interfaces, and conversational AI on resource-constrained IoT devices. However, this shift introduces significant challenges due to edge devices’ limited computational resources, storage capacity, and network bandwidth, which severely magnify the performance bottlenecks observed in well-resourced data centers. This paper addresses these challenges by extending cloud-based LLM optimization techniques to the unique constraints of edge computing. We present a comprehensive experimental analysis of federated LLM agent workloads deployed on a Kubernetes (K3s) cluster that simulates a realistic heterogeneous edge environment. Through a systematic ablation study, we evaluate the effectiveness of multiple optimization strategies, including advanced model quantization, distributed caching, and network-aware orchestration, measuring their impact on critical performance metrics such as time-to-first-token (TTFT), model synchronization overhead, and energy consumption. Our results demonstrate that while traditional storage and memory optimizations remain important, network-aware scheduling and adaptive model loading strategies are crucial for achieving practical edge deployment. The proposed optimization framework delivers substantial improvements over naive deployment approaches: a 75% reduction in network bandwidth consumption, a 45% improvement in end-to-end inference latency, and a 61% decrease in energy usage per inference, while maintaining acceptable model quality as measured by perplexity.

title: Multiscale Residual Attention Unet+-based Efficient Change Detection Mechanism in Ecosystem using Satellite Images
authors: S. Suman Das, G. Rosline Nesa Kumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Satellite images provide a precise view of continuous changes, enabling thorough monitoring of ecosystem dynamics over time. This capability is essential for identifying issues such as deforestation, and natural disasters. Additionally, satellite imagery includes vast geographical regions, making it particularly suitable for observing extensive ecosystems. However, a significant challenge in utilizing satellite images is the occurrence of clouds and varying atmospheric conditions that affect the detection accuracy. Furthermore, variations in lighting conditions and sudden changes in seasons also complicate the identification of genuine changes. To address this research gap, an advanced deep learning-based change detection method is implemented for detecting and monitoring changes in ecosystems, including deforestation, desertification, and land degradation. Here, the satellite images are analyzed using deep learning networks for tracking climate-related phenomena such as glacier retreats, rising sea levels, and temperature anomalies. The Multiscale Residual Attention Unet++ (MRA-UNet++) model is developed in this work for the detection of changes that analyze the satellite images very effectively to aid disaster preparedness, early warnings, and recovery planning. The proposed MRA-UNet++-based change detection model is helpful in precision agriculture based on the analysis of crop health, soil quality, and vegetation indices from satellite imagery. The resultant outcomes are validated with the conventional models to show the effectiveness.

title: Smart Surveillance System Using Face Detection for Missing Persons
authors: Kiran More, Saloni Paresh Tiwari, Ishwari Ajay Salunke, Utkarsh Parag Salunkhe, Sara Manish Ansingkar, Vaidik Satish Samarth
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In today's world, facial recognition has become an imperative requirement and can provide numerous useful uses, such as, but not limited to, security systems, user authentication, surveillance, access control, etc. Therefore, the demand for a reliable and accurate facial recognition system has become a necessity for all these possible uses. This study utilizes 3 employed working models to investigate detecting faces in a provided dataset, with further evaluation based on the results of each model. The three models used in this study include Support Vector Machine (SVM), custom-built Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and ResNet50, with transfer learning. All these models are trained and structured to obtain output that is precise and accurate for the preprocessed data for the task of facial recognition. The performance for each model will also be viewed individually to see which model is best adapted to work under and provide an understanding of the strengths and limitations of each model. The result obtained shows that the accuracy of a Convolutional Neural Network model is up to 83% and that of the Support Vector Machine model is up to 79 %, whilst the accuracy of the ResNet50 is up to 88 %. Based on these results, we conclude that the ResNet50 with transfer learning model yields more efficient and scalable results compared to other models, with better effectiveness in its given task.

title: Efficient Architecture for CNN Accelerator using Depthwise Separable Convolution and Operand Isolation Multipliers
authors: Pande Kadek Tresna Juliana, Teuku Muhammad Roffi, Ade Irawan
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: The advancement of technology and interconnectivity has led to an increased adoption of sophisticated applications such as real-time facial recognition and object detection, which heavily rely on digital image processing. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have changed the way images are processed by making it possible to classify, detect, and recognize objects with great accuracy. However, as CNNs increase in layers and parameters to enhance accuracy, they also require the ability to process data efficiently and consume less power. Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) hardware accelerators present a viable solution owing to their adaptability in extensive parallel processing. This study proposed a hardware accelerator for CNNs by integrating the Depthwise Separable Convolution (DSC) technique with Operand Isolation (OI) across multiple multiplier architectures. An 8-bit fixed-point quantization technique was used to optimize data representation, enabling more straightforward computation and reduced memory requirements. The ASIC hardware accelerator was implemented on the Xilinx Kria KV260 Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) platform. The experimental results, implemented with the DSC, reduced model parameters and computational complexity by 23 % as compared to the conventional Digital Signal Processor (DSP)based architecture, while maintaining 90 % accuracy on the MNIST dataset with 8-bit data representation. FPGA synthesis results indicated significant reductions in LUTs, flip-flops, and DSPs, along with LUT RAM, with approximately 2.847 W of power consumption. Further optimization with Operand Isolation and the Dadda Multiplier (DSC-OI+Dadda) removed DSP dependency and achieved comparable efficiency, while the DSC-OI+Shift-and-Add design produced the best resource saving.

title: Detection of Thick Elliptical Structures in Complex Images: A Mixture Model-Based Approach using Ellipse-Anchored Gaussian Distribution
authors: Nafaa Nacereddine, Aicha Baya Goumeidane, Djemel Ziou
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The detection of elliptical shapes in images plays a vital role in numerous computer vision applications, including medical imaging, industrial inspection and remote sensing. While traditional methods primarily focus on thin, well-defined elliptical contours using edge detection or curve fitting, real-world images often present thick, blurred, or partially occluded elliptical structures that challenge these techniques. In this work, we tackle the problem of detecting multiple thick elliptical regions by introducing a novel probabilistic approach based on Finite Mixture Models, where a new distribution, called Ellipse-Anchored Gaussian Distribution (EllAGD) is defined and which models the intensity distribution around elliptical shapes and incorporates a spatial thickness parameter that effectively captures thick contours. An Expectation-Maximization algorithm is used to estimate all the multiple ellipse parameters including spatial occupancy rate, center, axes, orientation angle and thickness. The proposed method is applied on synthetic and real images containing single or multiple thick elliptical structures where, it shows its ability to recover accurately all the structures parameters even with challenging image conditions.

title: Emotion-Aware Prompting for Large Language Models
authors: Belkacem Chikhaoui
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized natural language understanding and generation, yet they often lack the ability to tailor responses according to the emotional context of user input. In this paper, we propose a novel framework for emotion-aware prompting, where user inputs are first analyzed using an emotion detection model, and then used to generate emotionally-aligned prompts for the LLM. We evaluate our approach against standard (emotion-agnostic) prompting using a benchmark emotion-labeled datasets. Our results show that emotion-aware prompting enhances response empathy, alignment, and context sensitivity, making LLMs more suitable for emotionally rich applications such as mental health support, education, and customer service.

title: Precision Agriculture Through Smart Irrigation and Real-Time Nutrient Monitoring Using IoT and AI
authors: Nilakshee Rajule, Prajal Chandane, Sanket Dakare, Omkar Mundhe
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The increasing challenges of resource scarcity, environmental variability, and food security have accelerated the demand for intelligent and sustainable agricultural solutions. This paper presents an enhanced precision agriculture framework that integrates Internet of Things (IoT) sensing technologies with advanced machine learning models to optimize irrigation scheduling and soil nutrient management. Real-time environmental data, including soil moisture, temperature, humidity, and NPK nutrient levels, are collected through a NodeMCU ESP8266-based wireless sensor network. A Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network is employed to forecast future soil moisture trends, enabling proactive irrigation decisions, while an Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) classifier predicts nutrient status categories (Deficient, Optimal, Excess) for nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. By combining sequential pattern learning and highaccuracy classification, the proposed system dynamically controls irrigation and fertilizer application through automated actuators. Experimental validation demonstrates that the hybrid LSTM-XGBoost model achieves significant improvements, attaining 89.5% irrigation prediction accuracy and 88.2 % nutrient classification F1-score, resulting in approximately 47 % water savings and optimized fertilizer utilization. This integrated approach enhances agricultural sustainability by minimizing resource wastage, maintaining soil health, and improving crop productivity. Future work will explore multi-sensor fusion and deep reinforcement learning for further system robustness under diverse agricultural conditions.

title: Enhancing Surveillance Systems Using Video Anomaly Detection
authors: M Niharika, A.P. Siva Kumar, Chidananda K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Video surveillance systems play an essential part in the modern-day security systems. In the technological advancements, CCTV cameras which contains high-resolution that are deployed to for the security purpose of both people and property. However, sometimes it is not possible to monitor all the times manually. Human behavior can't be predictable at any time of action. The research on Convolutional Neural networks classifies the both normal and abnormal activities. On analyzing the normal and abnormal activities, the abnormal activity detects with high efficiency compared to the normal activity. During the scene-specific knowledge, the anomalies may include unusual behavior. Anomaly detection systems can learn how to recognize the patterns and relationships of each scene, leading to more accurate and robust results. The system enables how effectively identifies and flags the unusual events or patterns that requires the action.

title: Ensemble Majority Voting Method to Improve Missing Value Imputation Results in T2DM Prognosis Classifications
authors: Anik Andriani, Anastasia Meyliana, Indriyanti, Lina Ayu Safitri, Paulus Tofan Rapiyanta, Vadlya Maarif
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) is associated with several complications. Previous research has classified the prognosis of T2DM for complications using a patient dataset at Panti Rapih Hospital, Yogyakarta. The dataset was taken from six years of patient medical records. The data set had missing value of 29%. Previous studies compared several imputation methods for missing values. The results demonstrated that the Linear Regression method provided the best imputation performance compared with other imputation methods, including MEAN and KNN. However, the Linear Regression imputation method cannot impute all the missing values in the dataset. The results obtained 598 instances with non-missing values out of the 700 instances in the dataset. Therefore, this study proposes the development of an ensemble method to impute missing values optimally. The proposed Ensemble Majority Voting method uses the imputation results from three base learner methods-MEAN, KNN, and Linear Regression-to vote by calculating the MODE value. The voting results are used as imputation values to build a new imputation dataset. The results show that Ensemble Majority Voting can impute all the missing values. Furthermore, this method improved the performance of the decision tree and Support Vector Machine classification methods when the imputed dataset was applied to classify the prognosis of T2DM patients with their complications. The best accuracy increased by 1.2%.

title: Pungoe Pentest: Orchestration of Web Penetration Testing Tools with Assistance Based on Large Language Model (LLM) Pentest-AI and Retrieval-augmented Generation (RAG)
authors: Syubbanul Siddiq, R Budiarto Hadiprakoso, Prasetyo Adi Wibowo Putro, Girinoto, Deva Finanda Saputra
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Web applications are the most vulnerable applications because they are often targeted for security exploits, so good preventive measures are needed. Penetration testing can be used to identify security vulnerabilities, but testing tools are often standalone and Command Line Interface (CLI)-based, limiting accessibility for ordinary users in the vulnerability identification process. This research designs and implements Pungoe Pentest, a web GUI that orchestrates multiple penetration-testing tools. The system centralizes tool invocation, result management, and LLM-assisted analysis. Additionally, this research implements a Large Language Model (LLM) using the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) method with the Pentest-AI model to assist users in the penetration testing process. With the implementation of RAG, the LLM model is expected to generate context-based recommendations and reduce the risk of hallucinations in model outputs. Evaluation results show that the developed application can detect various vulnerabilities on a web dummy, the implementation of RAG on the Pentest-AI model successfully improves answer accuracy and STS scores compared to before RAG implementation, and SUS testing yields an average SUS score of 83, categorised as Acceptable. The resulting platform, Pungoe Pentest, is expected to serve as an effective tool for both seasoned pentesters and students in the field of web penetration testing.

title: Performance Analysis of M-AODV Routing Protocol for Video Streaming Using Gauss-Markov and Random Waypoint Mobility Models in MANETs
authors: Megha K M, Bhavana M R, Gowthami V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Quality of Service (QoS) factors are directly impacted by mobility models, which have a substantial impact on the efficiency of video streaming on Mobile Ad Hoc Networks (MANETs). In contrast to the commonly used Random Waypoint Model, this work provides a thorough performance evaluation of video transmission over MANETs utilizing the Gauss-Markov mobility model. The NS-3.4.2 network simulator, which incorporates the M-AODV routing protocol, is used to carry out the analysis. The simulation environment is made up of more than fifty mobile nodes that can communicate over a 250-meter range while using a Wi-Fi channel for 100 seconds. Constant Bit Rate (CBR) video traffic is sent at 2.048 Kbps while node mobility is kept at 10 m / s. The goal of the study is to ascertain how mobility patterns affect video streaming performance by examining important QoS parameters such as Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR), end-to-end delay, jitter, and throughput. A comparison of the Random Waypoint and Gauss- Markov mobility models sheds light on how well-suited each is for real-time multimedia applications in dynamic network environments. The results aid in the improvement of adaptive video transmission techniques and mobility-aware protocols in MANET settings.

title: Impact of Number of DMRS Symbols on Self-interference Cancellation in Full-duplex Mobile Communications
authors: Kazuma Matsushima, Takatoshi Sugiyama
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Full-duplex mobile communication, which allows bidirectional transmission and reception over the same frequency band, offers doubled spectral efficiency compared with duplexing methods, such as frequency division duplex (FDD) and time division duplex (TDD). This technique is gaining attention as an access method for mobile communication systems between base station (BS) and user equipment (UE). Self-interference (SI) which occurs between the transmitter (TX) and receiver (RX) of BS must be eliminated to achieve full-duplex mobile communication. We have been investigating a transmission performance of QAM-OFDM signals when applying an adaptive self-interference canceller (SIC) based on channel estimation using demodulation reference signal (DMRS) in full-duplex mobile communication environments. This paper investigates BER performances of QAM-OFDM signals under full-duplex environments where SI channel fluctuates over time. Specifically, the BERs are demonstrated as parameters of number of DMRS symbols per resource block. The simulation results verify that increasing the number of DMRS symbols can achieve the better BER performance under the time-varying self-interference conditions.

title: A 10-Bit 100-kHz Partially Segmented DAC Design for LCD Gamma Correction Using Open-Source EDA Tools
authors: Yohanes Stefanus, Astria N. Irfansyah, Hendra Kusuma
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a partially 10-bit segmented digital-to-analog converter (DAC) operating at 100 kHz, intended to control LCD panels and perform gamma correction for full high definition (FHD) resolution at 60 frames per second (FPS). The DAC architecture combines a 6-bit thermometer-coded R-DAC and a 4-bit binary-weighted DACembedded operational amplifier.
