This architecture was chosen because it offers a significantly smaller chip size than conventional resistor-string DACs (R-DACs) while also providing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$g_{m}$</tex> modulated voltage interpolation along the gamma-voltage transfer curve. The circuit design was carried out using open-source EDA tools and the SkyWater 130 nm PDK. The maximum value of simulated differential non-linearity (DNL) and integral nonlinearity (INL) for temperature variation are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 6 6 1}$</tex> LSB and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2 9 9}$</tex> LSB at 0° C, respectively. This DAC achieves a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 9. 5 4 9 ~ d B}$</tex> and a settling time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 2 5} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{s}$</tex>. The designed DAC occupies an area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13,907.916 \mu ~\mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, which is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 6. 2 6 2 \%}$</tex> smaller than a conventional 10-bit R-DAC.

title: Integrate Cybersecurity in Electric Vehicle Battery Frameworks: Mechanisms for Identifying and Responding to Intrusions on Smart Building Management System Networks
authors: V. S. Prakash, Vennila J, P. Murugesan, N. Karthikeyan, P. Natarajan, G. Prathap
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The development of EVs and their interaction with SBMSs contribute considerably to energy efficiency, grid responsiveness and environmental friendliness. Yet, this unification process raises essential cybersecurity issues related, e.g., to battery management systems (BMS) that, connected to digital infrastructures, are becoming dynamic. However, as EVs grow into key nodes of smart grids and building systems, the battery systems of EVs are confronted with various cyber threats including data intoxication, denial- of-service (DoS) attacks, and intrusion attacking the communication protocols or energy optimization algorithms. This study introduces a secure and adaptive cybersecurity framework for EV battery systems embedded in SBMS systems with an emphasis on realtime intrusion detection and response mechanisms. The proposed approach combines anomaly-based detection and machine learning methods to discover anomaly patterns in vehicular and building energy networks. It taps into distributed sensors, edge intelligence and secure communication technology to track battery state-of-health <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{SoH})$</tex>, energy consumption patterns and control signals. Utilizing blockchain-based logging functionality and federated learning techniques, the system ensures data integrity and privacy whilst it can adapt to new cyber threats. In order to detect and identify the compromised nodes, reconfigure BMS control layers, and keep energy supply to critical building functions running, a hybrid response mechanism is proposed. Performance is evaluated on an SBMS-EV integration testbed and results indicate that the framework has a high accuracy in detecting cyber intrusions, achieves low latency and a low false-alarm rate. The findings confirm notable resistance to APTs, and malicious firmware updates being directed more and more towards IoT-oriented energy devices. This work not only improves the cyber security of EV battery operations in smart buildings, but also has a broader impact in CPS security by providing a scalable, intelligent, and autonomous protection model. The findings signal that it will be possible to safely and securely integrate e-mobility into smart infrastructures of the future in a way that is easy to sustain.

title: Efficient and Secure Multiparty Key Exchange Schemes from Bilinear Maps
authors: Annisa Dini Handayani, Indah Emilia Wijayanti, Uha Isnaini, Prastudy Fauzi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Secure multiparty key exchange (MPKE) protocols are essential for establishing shared secrets among multiple parties over insecure channels. Bilinear maps, leveraging pairing-based cryptography, offer significant advantages in constructing efficient and secure MPKE schemes. This paper proposes two novel multiparty key exchange schemes using a bilinear map that are more efficient and secure than the previous schemes. Our first scheme needs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n-2$</tex> rounds to establish a shared key among <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> even users. Meanwhile, our second scheme requires <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\frac{n-1}{2}$</tex> rounds to establish a shared key between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> odd users. These two schemes are more efficient than the Ingemarsson et al. scheme, which needs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n-1$</tex> rounds for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> users, and the Joux scheme, which only facilitates establishing a shared key among three users. We also demonstrate that our schemes are secure under the computational Diffie-Hellman problem and the computational Bilinear Diffie-Hellman problem. Finally, we present a comprehensive complexity comparison with prior works, showing that our protocols achieve practical efficiency while maintaining robust security guarantees. The results indicate that our constructions are theoretically sound and feasible in practice.

title: High-Precision 4D Parrallel LiDAR Based on Dual Electro-Optic Combs and Injection-Locked OEO
authors: Junze Tian, Jiangyi Tong, Jianhao Duan, Shukang Xu, Bin Wang, Weifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We propose a high-precision 4D parallel light detection and ranging (LiDAR) system by leveraging dual electro-optic combs (DEOCs) and injection-locked optoelectronic oscillator (IL-OEO). In the proposed system, the combined use of DEOCs and a diffraction grating enables parallel detection, minimizing dependence on mechanical beam scanning. The IL-OEO are employed to generate wideband linearly chirped microwave waveform, which are converted into a linearly chirped optical signal via electro-optic modulation, enabling high-precision range detection. 4D imaging of a home-made object is experimentally demonstrated, which achieves a range precision as high as 319.1 µm and a measurement rate as high as 0.19 megapixels per second. This approach provides a practical solution for scalable, high-precision 4D imaging, with potential applications in autonomous vehicles, robotics, industrial automation, and medical imaging.

title: Low-Resource English–Tigrinya MT: Leveraging Multilingual Models, Custom Tokenizers, and Clean Evaluation Benchmarks
authors: Hailay Kidu Teklehaymanot, Gebrearegawi Gebremariam Gidey, Wolfgang Nejdl
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Despite advances in Neural Machine Translation (NMT), low-resource languages like Tigrinya remain underserved due to persistent challenges, including limited corpora, inadequate tokenization strategies, and the lack of standardized evaluation benchmarks. This paper investigates transfer learning techniques using multilingual pretrained models to enhance translation quality for morphologically rich, low-resource languages. We propose a refined approach that integrates language-specific tokenization, informed embedding initialization, and domain-adaptive fine-tuning. To enable rigorous assessment, we construct a high-quality, human-aligned English–Tigrinya evaluation dataset covering diverse domains. Experimental results demonstrate that transfer learning with a custom tokenizer substantially outperforms zero-shot baselines, with gains validated by BLEU, chrF, and qualitative human evaluation. Bonferroni correction is applied to ensure statistical significance across configurations. Error analysis reveals key limitations and informs targeted refinements. This study underscores the importance of linguistically aware modeling and reproducible benchmarks in bridging the performance gap for underrepresented languages. The resources are available https://github.com/hailaykidu/MachineT_TigEng

title: Quantum CNN-GCN-Based Road Hazard Detection with Lyapunov Optimized Control
authors: Juhui Heo, Soohyun Park
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: While Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) enhances traffic efficiency by reducing inter-vehicle distances, shorter headways inevitably make it more challenging to respond promptly and reliably to unexpected road hazards. To address this issue, we assume a system in which Connected Vehicles (CVs) perform real-time hazard detection outside the CACC framework and disseminate the detection results to all vehicles through RSUs. To this end, we propose a lightweight model that integrates Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) and Quantum Convolutional Neural Networks (QCNNs), referred to as Quantum Graph-based Object Detection (QGOD), which exhibits a clear trade-off between detection accuracy and processing latency. Furthermore, the model incorporates a Lyapunov optimization-based control mechanism to dynamically adjust the model architecture according to traffic conditions, thereby maximizing the time-average performance.

title: Using Hybrid Blockchain to Increase Transaction Transparency in Government Bond Investments
authors: Inayatulloh
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Bond investment is the process of purchasing and owning debt securities issued by the government or companies in the hope of obtaining returns in the form of coupons and potential capital gains. The bond investment mechanism involves several stages from issuance to trading in the secondary market. Bond issuance occurs in the primary market, where the issuer (the party issuing the bonds) offers bonds to investors through specific mechanisms. Although bonds are considered a relatively stable investment instrument, several transparency issues can impact investors, such as the risk of financial statement manipulation, which can cause investors to misjudge the credit risk of bonds. Rating agencies sometimes have a conflict of interest because the bond issuer pays them. The ratings given may not fully reflect the actual financial conditions. This research offers a solution to the problem of low transparency in transaction information for bond investments with blockchain technology. By applying blockchain technology to bond investments, each transaction will be validated by all stakeholders, ensuring the information produced is transparent and valid. This research uses a blockchain hybrid model to improve data privacy in government bond investments. The research uses a qualitative approach through literature review and prototype testing. The simulation results with Hyperledger show that blockchain technology can produce transparent and valid information for investors and bond investment stakeholders.

title: Deep Learning Based Sensing Decision for Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Hewon Cho, Jungsook Bae
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a sensing region selection framework for vehicular sensor networks (VSNs) for minimizing age of information (AoI) violations and transmission cost. We formulate the sensing decision problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), where the system state captures vehicle distribution, AoI status, and prior transmission success ratios. A reinforcement learning algorithm, Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), is employed to learn an effective sensing decision policy that balances data freshness and communication efficiency in dynamic environments.

title: Enhancing Video Anomaly Detection Through Optimized Pre-Processing: ROI Cropping and Reconstruction Loss
authors: Dede Firmansyah Saefudin, Jasmir, Zico Pratama Putra
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Anomaly detection in surveillance videos remains challenging because of dynamic backgrounds, dense pedestrian flows, and the instability of conventional reconstruction-based models. This study presents an unsupervised framework that integrates object detection-driven Region of Interest (ROI) cropping, motion enhancement using Background Subtraction MOG2 (BSMOG2), and a lightweight Convolutional Autoencoder (CAE) for frame-level anomaly detection. The pipeline focuses on motion-relevant pedestrian regions through ROI cropping and suppresses background clutter using BSMOG2, while reconstruction is performed on compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times 32$</tex> grayscale patches. An adaptive threshold computed from the mean and standard deviation of the validation reconstruction losses was employed to classify frames as normal or anomalous. Experimental results on three public benchmarks, UCSD Ped1, UCSD Ped2, and CUHK Avenue, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves promising performance, with the highest precision of 0.9305 and F1score of 0.6449 on UCSD Ped2, and competitive AUC-ROC values across datasets (0.5324 on Ped1, 0.5476 on Ped2, and 0.5391 on Avenue). Despite limited recall of complex scenes, the results confirm that ROI-based preprocessing and adaptive thresholding significantly improve anomaly localization and decision stability. This framework offers a lightweight, interpretable, and datasetagnostic solution suitable for real-time video surveillance, paving the way for future extensions using optimization-driven thresholding and attention-based architecture.

title: Precompensation of Nonlinear Phase Shifts for THz Analog Radio-over-Fiber Systems
authors: Ryoji Ito, Takaki Sugiyama, Daisuke Hisano, Akihiro Maruta, Hirofumi Sasaki, Ken Mishina
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: The effect of fiber nonlinearity can be an impairment in terahertz analog radio-over-fiber (A-RoF) systems that require higher optical power and numerous channel multiplexing operations. In this study, we propose a novel precompensation method for nonlinear distortion in A-RoF transmissions and demonstrate the validity of the proposed method through numerical simulations.

title: Budget Allocation in Multi-Task Hyperparameter Optimization
authors: Yeonwoo Cho, Jonghyeon Won, Hyun-Suk Lee, Jang-Won Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In hyperparameter optimization (HPO), efficient use of a limited budget has become crucial as the training cost of machine learning (ML) models continues to increase. Recent applications like open radio access network (O-RAN) and sensor-based platforms run multiple ML models simultaneously, making efficient budget use essential across multiple tasks, not just within a single one. In this paper, we propose Multi-Task Hyperband with Deep Power Laws (MT-HyperDPL), an HPO algorithm augmented with budget allocation across multiple tasks to maximize average performance. Experiments show that the proposed algorithm achieves higher average performance than the baseline algorithm with equal budget allocation.

title: Federated Learning for Privacy-Preserving Diagnosis of Rare Diseases from Distributed Clinical Imaging Data
authors: Rahul Joshi, Suman Kumari, Krishna Pandey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This work introduces a federated learning framework for private diagnosis of rare diseases from distributed clinical images. The task could be performed through a decentralised model training at different hospitals without the exchange of personal patient records, making it compliant with data governance policies and at the same time benefiting from diverse datasets to improve the diagnosis performance. FedAvg with a ResNet-based architecture was employed, which enabled real-time updates and stable generalisation among institutions. The system was tested in various deployment scenarios, including unseen hospital rooms and adversarial conditions. Experiments show that our federated learning training can obtain similar accuracy as centralised training and protect user’ private data so well. This framework shows exciting potential for AI-based secure, scalable and collaborative healthcare diagnostics, especially when targeting low-prevalence conditions.

title: Trajectory Control of a 4WIDS Mining Vehicle
authors: Xigetu He, Junqing Feng, Shudong Liu, Chuang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: Mining sites pose significant challenges due to confined spaces, rugged terrain, and variable slopes, demanding high vehicle maneuverability. Vehicles with four-wheel independent drive and steering (4WIDS) are ideal for such applications owing to their agile mobility. This paper proposes a hierarchical control strategy for trajectory tracking of 4WIDS vehicles in these complex environments. The strategy combines a feedforward controller, which rapidly computes reference wheel angles and driving forces based on kinematics and dynamics, with a feedback model predictive controller. The MPC layer leverages a vehicle dynamics model to optimize control inputs online, minimizing overshoot and steady-state error. Furthermore, an actuator effectiveness matrix is introduced, enabling dynamic control reallocation to maintain performance in the event of actuator failures. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method ensures stable and agile trajectory tracking within a simulated open-pit mine scenario.

title: Trust Without Transparency: An Empirical Analysis of Anonymity and Verifiability in Iron Fish Cryptocurrency
authors: I Putu Bayu Pati, Rinoto A. Prasojo, Yudhistira Nugraha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Cryptocurrencies are designed to provide privacy and decentralization, yet many remain under scrutiny for their technical implementations. Iron Fish is a privacy-oriented cryptocurrency that applies zk-SNARKs to ensure transaction confidentiality. Nonetheless, concerns persist regarding its reliance on a trusted setup, which may undermine user anonymity. This paper offers an empirical evaluation of Iron Fish's privacy guarantees by validating key blockchain components, including hash integrity, cryptographic commitments, and zk-SNARK proofs, using a dataset of 1,521 blocks. The results indicate that hash validation fails due to the proprietary and undisclosed Fish-Hash algorithm. In contrast, other components, such as blockchain structure, Merkle commitments, and zk-SNARKs, successfully pass all tests and operate as intended. These findings demonstrate both the strengths and the limitations of Iron Fish's privacy model, emphasizing the importance of greater transparency in hashing mechanisms. This paper contributes to ongoing discussions on verifiable privacy in blockchain systems and reinforces the role of empirical scrutiny in assessing emerging cryptocurrencies.

title: A Memory-Efficient Framework for Deformable Transformer with Neural Architecture Search
authors: Wendong Mao, Mingfan Zhao, Jianfeng Guan, Qiwei Dong, Zhongfeng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Deformable Attention Transformers (DAT) have shown remarkable performance in computer vision tasks by adaptively focusing on informative image regions. However, their data-dependent sampling mechanism introduces irregular memory access patterns, posing significant challenges for efficient hardware deployment. Existing acceleration methods either incur high hardware overhead or compromise model accuracy. To address these issues, this paper proposes a hardware-friendly optimization framework for DAT. First, a neural architecture search (NAS)-based method with a new slicing strategy is proposed to automatically divide the input feature into uniform patches during the inference process, avoiding memory conflicts without modifying model architecture. The method explores the optimal slice configuration by jointly optimizing hardware cost and inference accuracy. Secondly, an FPGA-based verification system is designed to test the performance of this framework on edge-side hardware. Algorithm experiments on the ImageNet-1K dataset demonstrate that our hardware-friendly framework can maintain have only 0.2% accuracy drop compared to the baseline DAT. Hardware experiments on Xilinx FPGA show the proposed method reduces DRAM access times to 18% compared with existing DAT acceleration methods.

title: Design and Implementation of a MobileNet-Based YOLO Object Detection Model for Resource-Constrained Devices
authors: Seungtae Hong, Gunju Park, Jeong-Si Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a lightweight object detection model optimized for resource-constrained environments by replacing the backbone of YOLO v8 with MobileNet v2. While conventional YOLO models achieve high detection accuracy, they require high-resolution input images and substantial computational resources, making them unsuitable for real-time deployment on embedded or mobile devices. To address this, the proposed model adopts MobileNet v2 as a lightweight backbone and introduces a connector module to integrate it with YOLO v8’s neck and head. We also apply channel-reduction techniques to further minimize the model’s complexity. The model is trained and evaluated using the COCO dataset, with a single-class setup focusing on the person class and an input resolution of 352×352 pixels. Experimental results show that the proposed model reduces the number of parameters by approximately 17% compared to the original YOLO v8, while achieving slightly improved detection accuracy. These results demonstrate that the proposed architecture achieves a favorable trade-off between computational efficiency and detection performance, making it suitable for real-time object detection on devices with limited resources.

title: Analysis of Operational Characteristics of Evaporative Cooling Systems for Offshore Wind
authors: Wenxin Wei
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: The increasing demand for large-capacity wind turbines necessitates greater attention to the motors cooling. Evaporative cooling technology, known for its high cooling efficiency, high reliability and suitability for harsh environments, can be applied to wind turbine cooling. This paper analyzes operational characteristics by establishing platforms for both natural and forced circulation in an evaporative cooling system. First, the variations in system operating parameters such as temperature, pressure, and flow rate are obtained and analyzed, along with their underlying causes, and the bifurcation diagram of the system is plotted. Next, the effects of operational parameters, such as system inclination and pump power, on system performance are examined. Finally, a phase plane diagram of the system is drawn to explore its intrinsic dynamic behavior under specific operating conditions.

title: A Super-Resolution Generative Adversarial Network Approach with Perceptual Loss and Residual Learning
authors: Ketaki S Sawashe, Bageshree V Pathak, Supriya Mangale
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The paper introduces a Super Resolution Generative Adversarial Network (SRGAN)-based technique for improving the image quality. By restoring High Resolution (HR) images while retaining fine texture features from Low Resolution (LR) inputs, the suggested method aims to improve image quality. Unlike traditional SR methods that focus solely on minimizing Mean Squared Error (MSE), our approach incorporates a perceptual loss function combining both content loss and adversarial loss. Deep residual architecture and skip connections are used by the generator. The discriminator distinguishes the real and generated HR images. We employ VGG19 network to capture high-level perceptual features for the content loss calculation. The SRGAN is trained and evaluated using the MIR Flickr dataset, with experiments performed on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times$</tex> downscaled images. The results demonstrate improvements in both statistical measures (PSNR and SSIM) and perceptual quality compared to the LR images. This paper contributes to image enhancement, addressing the limitations of MSE-based optimization and offering a more perceptually accurate SR technique.

title: Asymmetric Password Authentication Transport Layer Security Protocol
authors: Yuhao Han, Libin Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocols are essential for ensuring the confidentiality, integrity, and authentication of data communications. Mutual authentication between client and server is crucial in high-security scenarios such as finance and government. However, existing TLS protocols typically rely on certificate-based public key infrastructures (PKI) for client authentication, which increases deployment complexity and introduces risks associated with third-party trust. In contrast, password-authenticated TLS protocols use memorable passwords for client authentication, offering advantages in simplicity and usability. Nonetheless, such protocols remain vulnerable to server compromise and fail to provide sufficient security against quantum adversaries.To address these challenges, we propose a novel TLS protocol based on asymmetric password-authenticated key exchange (PAKE). The protocol employs an asymmetric PAKE mechanism wherein only password-derived information is stored on the server, while the client derives its private key from the password. This design effectively mitigates the risk of server leakage attacks. The protocol further integrates two types of post-quantum secure key encapsulation mechanisms (KEMs): an OW-ChCCA (One-Way Checkable against Chosen-Ciphertext Attacks) secure KEM for server key exchange and authentication, and an OW-PCA (One-Way Plaintext-Checkable Attacks) secure KEM for binding the client’s password-derived private key to enable client authentication. Both KEMs support multi-user, multi-challenge settings and admit tight, post-quantum secure instantiations.Furthermore, this paper provides a formal security analysis of the proposed protocol within an optimized multi-stage key exchange model. By combining the random oracle and ideal cipher models with a game-based proof methodology, we demonstrate that the protocol achieves mutual authentication and forward secrecy, while also providing tight security bounds and post-quantum resilience. This work thus presents a promising solution for constructing post-quantum password-authenticated TLS protocols.

title: Autonomous Digital Design Implementation on FPGA Using Large Language Models
authors: Moulee Sudharsan R Y, Nithish Kumar K, Visalakshi P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The increasing complexity of digital systems and the need for rapid prototyping have highlighted the demand for automation in hardware design workflows. This proposed work provides a fully autonomous system for implementing digital designs on Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs). The system gets a high-level input describing a digital circuit from the user and makes use of Large Language Model (LLM) to generate the TCL file containing corresponding Verilog HDL code. This TCL file is then passed through a TCL-scripted Vivado workflow, which automates project creation, synthesis, implementation, and bitstream generation without any manual intervention. The proposed method removes the need for users to interact with the Vivado GUI thereby reducing development time and human error. Additionally, the system supports storing the generated files in the GitHub cloud for future references. By bridging AI and EDA toolchains, this research work gives the foundation for a next-generation design-as-code paradigm in hardware development.

title: Enhancing Lightweight IRSR Models via Knowledge Distillation with Structural and Spectral Losses
authors: Seungsoo Han, Dongnyeok Choi, Deukhwa Kim, Jeonghun Kim, Seunghoon Shin
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: For Infrared Image Super-Resolution (IRSR) technology, maintaining performance while reducing model complexity is critical for a wide range of applications. However, existing research on lightweight IRSR has been predominantly limited to modifying model architectures. This study proposes a new methodology that applies Knowledge Distillation, a representative model compression technique from supervised learning, to IRSR models. To this end, we extend the DCKD framework, previously used for RGB image super-resolution, to the IRSR domain and introduce new loss functions designed to maximize the preservation of key structural characteristics in infrared images, namely edge and spectral(Contourlet-domain) information. Through the proposed methodology, a lightweight student model trained with distilled knowledge from a high-performance, complex teacher model consistently achieved superior performance compared to the same architecture trained via standard supervised learning. This study demonstrates that Knowledge Distillation based methodology is effective for developing lightweight IRSR models and is expected to contribute to fields where high-efficiency IRSR is essential, such as real-time military surveillance, disaster response, and nocturnal reconnaissance.

title: Real-Time Surface Defect Detection for Electrical Equipment Based on Lightweight Yolov5
authors: Xueni He, Hao Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: To resolve the conflict between high computational complexity of models and real-time requirements when deploying power equipment defect detection on the edge side, this paper proposes a real-time detection model named MBv3-YOLOv5 based on lightweight YOLOv5. By replacing the backbone network of YOLOv5s with MobileNetV3, the model's parameter count and computational complexity are significantly reduced. Experimental results on a self-built dataset containing 2867 images of electrical equipment defects show that the proposed model maintains high detection accuracy (mAP@0.5 reaches 87.0%) while reducing parameters by 72.3% and computation (FLOPs) by 68.1% compared to the original YOLOv5s, achieving an inference speed of 415 FPS on an RTX 3090 platform. Furthermore, deploying the model on an NVIDIA Jetson Nano edge device and optimizing it with TensorRT enables real-time detection performance of 22 FPS. To comprehensively evaluate edge deployment capability, we tested the model on multiple Jetson series devices (Jetson Nano, TX2, and Xavier NX), with FPS reaching 22,45, and 78 respectively. Additionally, we analyzed the model's detection performance for defects of different sizes, shapes, and locations, finding that the recall rate for small-sized defects (less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times 32$</tex> pixels) needs improvement. Ablation studies and comparisons with various mainstream detection models validate the model's good balance between accuracy and speed, providing a feasible edge-side solution for intelligent inspection of power equipment.

title: Multi-Protocol DAS Using FPGA
authors: Madhavi Repe, Nayan Bhoyar, Vishakha Patil, Siddhi Naikare
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In the changing scenario of embedded systems, the need for high-speed, dependable, and reconfigurable Data Acquisition Systems (DAS) is growing in many fields like industrial automation, health monitoring, and smart infrastructure. This work introduces the implementation of a multiprotocol Data Acquisition System (DAS) on the Cyclone II Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA), intended to effectively harvest and convey sensor readings through Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI), Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C), and Universal Asynchronous Receiver-Transmitter (UART) protocols. In contrast to traditional microcontroller-based approaches, plagued by restricted processing speed and sequential processing, the FPGA-based solution allows genuine parallelism and expeditious data processing. Early indications are that the FPGA system minimizes data acquisition latency by as much as 601 % and maximizes throughput by almost 501 % over microcontroller-based DAS. In addition, the parallel processing ability of the FPGA system enables it to process multiple sensors in parallel without sacrificing performance, with scalability gains of more than 40 %. Information from various sensors is collected and sent to a host PC via FTDI-based UART, where the information is presented on a customized Python Graphic User Interface (GUI). The system provides better speed, efficiency, and scalability, making it a favorable candidate for real-time, multiprotocol data management.

title: ML-Pump: A Machine Learning Based Bidirectional Prediction Framework for Charge Pump Design Optimization
authors: Ashutosh Singh, Anuj Grover, Abhishek Jain
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Charge Pump circuit design presents significant challenges due to interrelated parameters, nonlinear component behavior, and complex performance trade-offs that traditionally require extensive iterations and simulation time. The proposed ML-Pump, a bidirectional predictive model, tackles these challenges by functioning in both forward and reverse directions. It predicts performance metrics (including output voltage, efficiency, and power) from design parameters (including width, length, capacitance, input voltage, load, etc.), and conversely, determines the optimal design parameters needed to achieve the desired performance characteristics. A single-stage cross-coupled charge pump implemented in 90nm CMOS technology was utilized for training and evaluating several machine learning models (Random Forest, Multi-layer Perceptron regressor (MLPRegressor) and Gradient Boosting) on a comprehensive dataset of approximately 65,000 samples generated from Cadence simulations. The MLP Regressor demonstrated superior performance with mean MSE of 2.09e-02 and MAE of 5.00e-02, outperforming Random Forest and Gradient Boosting algorithms. This bidirectional prediction capability enables designers to instantly evaluate performance impacts of parameter changes without time-consuming EDA tool simulations, significantly accelerating the design optimization process. This framework significantly speeds up the design process by enabling early prediction of performance metrics and design parameters, thereby improving efficiency and circuit performance.

title: An Inhomogeneous Plane Wave-based Ray Tracing Algorithm for LEO Atmospheric Propagation Modeling
authors: Bowoo Jang, Jun Heo, Dong-Yeop Na
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this conference paper, we introduce a ray tracing algorithm for low Earth orbit satellite communications where an inhomogeneous plane wave propagates. We analyze our approach in terms of its physical meaning founded on the well-known ray tracing methods in lossy media that is previously proposed. We organize some mathematical formulations using the complex Snell’s law and incorporate the two numerical methods.

title: Cross-Course Prediction of Student Performance: Feature Engineering and Model Evaluation Using LMS and Attendance Data
authors: Matthias Deceuninck, Tom Madou, Sophie De Coppel, Yves R. Sagaert
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The growing use of educational technology and learning management systems in higher education presents opportunities for predicting student performance. This study investigates predictive modeling across diverse academic courses, focusing on data capture, feature engineering, and model evaluation. Data from four undergraduate student groups at a Flemish University of Applied Sciences, including LMS activity and attendance records, were analyzed to assess the generalizability of features. Features were engineered using data available halfway through the semester, enabling timely identification and support of students at risk. The study documents how common data challenges, such as missing values and inflated activity logs were addressed through targeted cleaning and imputation strategies. LASSO regression was employed for feature selection, reducing model complexity while identifying the most informative predictors. Six machine learning models were trained to classify students into low, medium, or high performance levels. Results revealed substantial variation in both feature availability and importance across courses, underscoring the need for tailored models and course-specific analytics to support effective early intervention. While certain categories of features (e.g. performance or engagement) were found to be valuable predictors in specific contexts, yet their broader applicability remains limited.

title: Artificial Intelligence as a tool for developing critical and creative thinking in foreign language teaching, ITALS
authors: Riccardo Giovannimaria Virdis
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This paper summarises the thesis “L’Intelligenza Artificiale come strumento per lo sviluppo del Pensiero Critico e Creativo nell’Insegnamento dell’Italiano come Lingua Straniera. Analisi di un caso nella 3° ESO” [12]. 21st-century education requires tools capable of fostering critical and creative thinking from an early age. This study explores the importance of these competences through an action-research project, combining the pedagogical principles of Sorelle Agazzi with insights from Neuroscience and AI Literacy. It followed a three-phase structure and it highlighted how critical thinking enhances understanding, independent decision-making and social awareness, while creative thinking encourages original problem-solving in authentic and motivating contexts. Neuroscience and AI Literacy paves the way for a new active and inclusive learning, thanks to innovative practices and interactive digital tools. The use of chatbots, such as ChatGPT, has shown significant potential for personalisation, language acquisition and the stimulation of imagination. Results suggest that AI can be an effective educational ally only when guided by a mindful and skilled teacher, capable of promoting reflection, imagination and critical awareness. The thesis aims to propose a pedagogy that bridges tradition and innovation, body and technology, emotion and thought, promoting the development of critical, creative and responsible citizens.

title: DistFedAvg: Distance-Guided Proportional Aggregation for Federated Machine Learning
authors: Atul V Nirpase, Manisha J Nene, Rajendra S Deodhar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Federated Machine Learning enables collaborative training across multiple participating clients without need to share private data. Data heterogeneity among participants poses a significant challenge in federated learning. It can cause divergence in client updates and hinder convergence of the global model. Traditional approaches like FedAvg aggregate updates by equally weighting all clients. This may lead to performance degradation under data heterogeneity. RobFedAvg identifies extreme client updates as outliers and discard node-specific outlier updates prior to aggregation. ResFedAvg considers that extreme client updates may represent significant learning. Therefore, it restricts their contribution rather than discarding them during model averaging. However, ResFedAvg does not consider limiting extreme updates in proportion to their divergence from the mean. All the extreme updates are treated equally for aggregation. This paper proposes Distance-Guided Proportional Aggregation (DistFedAvg), a novel aggregation algorithm that incorporates extreme client updates by weighting them in proportion to their distance from the mean. All other updates are aggregated without modification. Experimental evaluations are carried out on MNIST with IID and non-IID datasets. Distance-Guided Proportional Aggregation performs better compared to RobFedAvg and ResFedAvg in terms of convergence and accuracy on IID and non-IID data.

title: Convolutional Neural Network Approach to Glaucoma Detection through Retinal Fundus Imaging
authors: Sarangam Kodati, Navya Kudinalli Nagappa, Nidhi Sharma, Jai Singh Wilson, Raj Kishor, Madhuri Sharma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper proposes a glaucoma-detecting model, which requires retinal fundus images and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). The suggested method provides a convenient and effective method of detecting the early signs of glaucoma through proper classification of fundus images as healthy or glaucomatous. One of the diseases that can be studied using different deep learning (DL) models in order to accurately localize is glaucoma as an irreversible disease that causes loss of vision. Based on these developments, this study proposes a CNNbased method of dependable glaucoma diagnosis. CNN allows to distinguish between glaucomatous and non-glaucomatous samples well with its layered, differentiable architecture of image segmentation. The framework is tested at six levels, and dropout mechanisms are adopted to improve its performance and to obtain some better representation within glaucomatous areas.

title: Reproducing the Classroom? Spatial Positioning in Frontal Teaching in Social Virtual Reality
authors: Fiona Schmidbauer, Matthias Wölfel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This paper investigates spatial practices in immersive virtual classrooms using the example of a university lecture conducted in social virtual reality (VR). Drawing on spatial sociology, the study examines how students position and reposition themselves after the shift from interactive to frontal teaching units in social VR. Using videography, spatial patterns were recorded, observed, and compared across four semesters. Findings reveal that students consistently enact classroom-like formations such as plenary configurations and spatial distancing from the lecturer even in a gamified, open virtual environment without seating arrangements or explicit instructions. These patterns suggest a transfer of spatial practices from physical to virtual learning contexts. The study highlights how spatial positioning in VR reflects and produces both didactic settings and social dynamics, offering a qualitative perspective on the role of spatiality for learning in social VR.

title: An L-Band Dual-Low-Noise-Amplifier Bank Ic in 65-nm SOI CMOS with <0.8-dB NF and >20-dB Gain for Advanced GNSS Receiver Front Ends
authors: Li Dai, Jin Li, Bo Chen, Linqian Zhao, Tao Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L$</tex>-band dual-low-noise-amplifier (dual-LNA) bank integrated circuit tailored for multi-channel RF front-end architectures in advanced GNSS phased array receivers. Each LNA within the bank adopts a classical cascode topology with inductive source degeneration to achieve high-gain and low-noise performance at the GNSS L1 band (centered at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 7 5. 4 2 ~ M H z). }$</tex> The dualLNA bank is fabricated in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$65-\text{nm}$</tex> SOI CMOS process and it occupies a total silicon area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.666 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. The measured results demonstrate excellent RF-performance consistency between the two LNAs, featuring an in-band noise figure of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.77-0.79 ~\text{dB}$</tex>, an in-band peak gain of 20.1 dB, reverse and output isolations exceeding 17.7 and 29 dB, respectively, and an input-referred thirdorder intercept point of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 2. 4 8 ~ d B m}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 7 3. 4 ~ M H z}$</tex>. Each LNA consumes 14.6 mW from a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.8-\mathrm{V}$</tex> supply.

title: Broadband Photomixing-Based THz Transmitter for Multi-Channel High-Speed Wireless Communication
authors: Yoshiki Kamiura, Shinji Iwamoto, Ryo Doi, Yuya Mikami, Tadao Ishibashi, Kazutoshi Kato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We demonstrate a broadband terahertz (THz) transmitter based on photomixing in a uni-traveling carrier photodiode (UTC-PD) integrated on a silicon carbide (SiC) substrate, enabling multi-channel high-speed wireless communication. The device exhibits a wide 3-dB bandwidth from 244 to 334 GHz and delivers output powers up to 4.07 mW at 278 GHz. Utilizing this capability, we conduct wireless transmission experiments across five carrier frequencies within the operational band, each achieving data rates of 12.5 Gbit/s. All channels achieve bit error rates (BER) below the HD-FEC threshold, validating the system’s scalability and robustness for frequency-division multiplexing.

title: An Overview of Classification Techniques for Epilepsy Symptoms Based on EEG Data
authors: Achmad Noe'man, Yessica Nataliani, Christine Dewi, Evi Maria
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Epilepsy is a prevalent neurological disorder that is typically diagnosed by interpreting electroencephalography (EEG) recordings that reveal patterns of epileptic seizures. However, EEG analysis is complex and requires expertise because of variations in seizures and potential artifacts mimicking epileptiform activity. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) are a prominent approach for addressing these challenges and effectively classifying epilepsy-related EEG signals. This paper provides an overview of classification techniques for detecting epilepsy symptoms using EEG data, focusing on both traditional machine learning and recent advancements in deep learning. An automated method was introduced to detect epilepsy through feature extraction and selection from EEG signals. Key features, such as Approximate Entropy, Fuzzy Entropy, and Standard Deviation, are derived using Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT). A Random Forest algorithm selects relevant features, followed by a CNN for classification. This study also reviews studies comparing machine learning and neural network techniques, showing that CNN-based methods generally outperform traditional approaches, including Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Random Forests, in terms of accuracy. In conclusion, the integration of AI into EEG analysis improves diagnostic accuracy and enables early seizure warnings, offering timely alerts for patients and enhancing their quality of life through more personalized treatment options.

title: Smart Vehicle Accident Detection System Using IOT
authors: Satyam Kumar, Shivam Kumar, R.K. Yadav, Neha Gole, Nidhi Malhotra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: In view of the increasing population and vehicles in India, road accidents have become one of the biggest problems. Road accidents are an unfortunate event that occurs frequently on the roads and these accidents cause property damage, injuries and deaths. Every year about 480000 accidents occur in India in which 188000 people aged 18 to 45 years die, due to which the following are the main causes of accidents, speeding, careless driving, drunk driving, distraction and violation of traffic rules. Apart from this, bad road conditions, increasing population and weather-related problems are also contributing to road accidents. Keeping all these road accidents in mind, IOT based system has been proposed in this paper so that it can effectively help in preventing any kind of accidents and if such a situation arises, how does it detect and inform the concerned authorities and people so that such a situation can be immediately attended to and timely treatment can be done. This system can detect the condition of accidents with the help of gyroscope sensor, IR sensor, alcohol sensor, sleeping sensor. It detects the accident and uses the GPS module to find the location of the accident so that the correct location of the accident can be known and timely arrival can be made. Accordingly, the loved ones of the person and the nearest hospitals are informed through an alert message, using which the problems of road accidents can be reduced, and this system can prove to be helpful in saving the lives of people.

title: Low-Cost Rapid-Development Air-Ground Robotic Solution for Nuclear Power Plant Inspection
authors: Changda Tian, Sasanka Kuruppu Arachchige, Haichuan Li, Juan José García Cárdenas, Hamidreza Raei, Enes Dincer, Alperen Kenan, Paul Bremner, Manuel Giuliani, Gerhard Neumann, Arash Ajoudani, Adriana Tapus, Tomi Westerlund, Joni–Kristian Kämäräinen, Luis Figueredo, Simon Watson, Panos Trahanias
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: This paper presents a practical, low-cost, and swiftly developed heterogeneous robotic system-comprising an aerial drone and a ground vehicle-designed for inspection and situational awareness in nuclear power plant (NPP) environments. Developed during the EnRicH 2025 competition in AKW Zwentendorf, our solution prioritized rapid prototyping using ROS2, off-the-shelf components, and open-source frameworks, achieving deployment within 3 weeks. We detail the design methodology: a 3D-printed airframe for the drone, an Ackermann-steering UGV, and a combined sensor suite composed of LiDAR, IMU, and radiation detection modules. Control and navigation algorithms were implemented using ROS2, leveraging SLAM and a hybrid autonomy paradigm to address GNSS denial inside containment structures. We also tackle communication challenges within shielded environments by integrating a modular mesh network and signal repeaters. Field trials in a real NPP demonstrated robust localization, reliable communication despite severe attenuation, and real-time radiation monitoring. Our contribution is a fully reproducible, low-cost air-ground inspection solution validated in a real NPP, together with a complete open-source release of mechanical designs, BOMs, firmware, and ROS2 software stacks.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: AutoML-Based Hyperparameter Optimization for Machine Learning Models in Software Defect Prediction
authors: Harsih Rianto, Lita Sari Marita, Martua Hami Siregar, Mushliha, Mari Rahmawati, Ahmad Rais Ruli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Software defect prediction (SDP) plays a critical role in improving the quality of software and reducing maintenance costs. However, the performance of predictive models is highly dependent on hyperparameter configuration, which is often tuned manually and may lead to suboptimal results. To address this challenge, this study applies AutoML-based hyperparameter optimization to five widely used classification algorithms: Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GB), and Neural Network (NN). Ten benchmark datasets from the NASA Metrics Data Program (MDP) were employed, and evaluation was conducted using 10-fold cross-validation with comprehensive metrics, including Accuracy, AUC, F1-score, and G-Mean. The experimental results demonstrate that AutoML significantly improves the model performance, particularly for metrics sensitive to class imbalance. The neural Network (NN) achieved the highest F1-score improvement from 0.53 to 0.63 and the highest accuracy of 0.99, while ensemble models (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex> and GB) reached the best AUC values up to 0.98 and G-Mean up to 0.70 on larger datasets such as PC4 and PC5. Conversely, linear models (LR and SVM) showed limited or inconsistent improvements, suggesting that AutoML is more effective for complex algorithm development. Overall, these findings highlight the potential of AutoML to automate hyperparameter optimization and enhance the predictive accuracy of SDP tasks.

title: Agentic Portfolio Construction: A Multi-Agent Architecture for LLM-Driven Financial Asset Allocation
authors: Ahmadreza Hajaghaie, Ruppa K. Thulasiram
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Accurately curating portfolios and managing asset allocation is an essential and complex task in financial risk management. The emergence of large language models (LLMs) has helped resolve this task to a good extent. Recent literature have demonstrated that LLMs alone remain insufficient. We introduce a multi-agent portfolio construction architecture that integrates LLMs with an agentic orchestration architecture to enhance financial asset allocation workflows. With LangGraph, the system orchestrates interactions between LLM-based agents and functional nodes, enabling adaptive decision-making. The pipeline begins with parsing natural language investment objectives, followed by real-time data retrieval, financial metric computation, and portfolio generation tailored to the user’s risk profile and constraints. The results not only addresses risk-aware investing but also that the final output includes validation and a human-readable commentary. This approach addresses key deficiencies in standalone LLMs, such as lack of real-time awareness, by coordinating modular agents that specialize in tasks like data retrieval, analysis, and reporting. The architecture demonstrates how multi-agent LLM systems can perform complex, high-stakes financial tasks with adaptability, transparency, and robustness, marking a promising direction for AI-driven portfolio management.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: Interpretable Deepfake Detection: Enhancing Real vs. Fake Face Classification with Explainable AI and Transfer Learning
authors: Abinash. P, N. Krishnamoorthy, V. Vinothkumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Deepfake detection is a vital challenge in the age of cognitive computing because of its security, misinformation, and identity fraud implications. Article presents an interpretable deepfake detection model built on the DenseNet121 architecture to categorize real and fake faces. The model is trained on a 140,000 images dataset with data augmentation and transfer learning method. Optimized training methods-e.g., early stopping, adaptive learning rate planning, and checkpointing-guarantee effective convergence and overfitting prevention. For added transparency, several Explainable AI (XAI) methods, namely Integrated Gradients, Grad-CAM, Occlusion Sensitivity, Vanilla Gradients, and LIME, are combined to visualize and explain model decisions. These explainability tools demonstrate the network's attention to semantically useful facial areas, building model trustworthiness and diagnostic understanding. Experimental outcomes reveal a 98% classification accuracy, which surpasses baseline models and verifies the reliability of the proposed approach. This article contributes to the development of explainable, high-accuracy AI systems for deepfake detection, which supports the significance of interpretability in security-critical applications

title: BIPSec: An End-to-End Formal Verification Framework for AH/ESP in Industrial-Grade IPSec Protocol Stacks
authors: Chuan Li, Yang Zhang, Rui Yao, Xia Yang, Wensheng Guo, Haiyong Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: IPSec, as a significant network-layer security standard, has been widely deployed. Formal verification methods play a crucial role in the analysis of security protocols. However, existing work still falls short in the end-to-end formal verification of industrial-grade complex protocols. This paper proposes the BIPSec framework, which applies the Behavior-Interaction-Priority (BIP) architecture to collaborative verification of IPSec protocols. The framework employs a three-layer design: 1) Establishing atomic components to model AH/ESP protocol entities, using connectors to constrain transport/tunnel mode data flow paths, and handling resource contention through priority rules; 2) Introducing a bidirectional mapping mechanism between BIP models and strongSwan/XFRM implementations, adopting Netlink message flow control plane verification and Tracepoints data plane evidence collection methods to achieve semantic alignment between formal models and actual code; 3) Employing hierarchical component design and state optimization strategies to effectively manage verification complexity. Experimental results show that BIPSec efficiently verifies the three core properties of AH/ESP, achieving high consistency between protocol layer and implementation layer in test cases, providing an effective verification solution for industrial-grade IPSec protocol stacks.

title: ProvAuditChain: A Gas-Efficient On-Chain Provenance Framework for AI-Driven Smart Contract Audits
authors: George Chidera Akor, Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The increasing use of AI-powered tools for smart contract security audits presents a critical challenge: ensuring the integrity and provenance of audit reports. Traditional methods lack cryptographic guarantees linking audit outputs to specific AI models and source code, creating vulnerabilities to tampering and misattribution. To address this, we propose ProvAuditChain, a gas-efficient, hybrid on-chain/off-chain framework that records immutable provenance of AI-driven audit reports on Layer 2 blockchain networks. ProvAuditChain utilizes lightweight smart contracts to securely anchor cryptographically signed audit report hashes on-chain, while storing the complete reports on decentralized IPFS storage. We deploy the system on the Arbitrum Sepolia testnet and benchmark gas consumption, latency, and throughput across 600 audit cycles. Our results demonstrate a stable average gas cost of approximately 173,000 per audit, equivalent to roughly $0.05 USD, alongside a throughput of nearly six audits per minute. These findings confirm the practical viability of ProvAuditChain for integration into automated CI/CD pipelines, providing a scalable foundation for trustworthy AI accountability in decentralized ecosystems.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Generative Adversarial Network for Patch-Based Image Generation
authors: Jen-Sheng Tsai, Li-Yin Cai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Quantum generative adversarial networks (QGANs) have attracted increasing attention for their potential to surpass classical generative models by leveraging the expressive power of parameterized quantum circuits (PQCs). However, in the current noisy intermediate-scale quantum era, the implementation of fully quantum algorithms is hindered by hardware limitations, restricting most existing approaches to low-resolution generated image. To address this challenge, we propose a hybrid quantum-classical generative adversarial network for patch-based image generation. Our method employs dual PQC-based generators that decompose images into structured patches, while local and global classical discriminators jointly capture local details and preserve global structural coherence. This design addresses scalability limitations of existing QGANs and mitigates patch-boundary artifacts, thereby enabling high-resolution image generation on hardware with restricted qubit counts. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating improvements in image fidelity over existing baselines, and providing insights into the influence of qubit count on generative performance.

title: Attention Mechanism in Neural Flow Models for Imbalanced ECG Beat Classification
authors: Sungpil Woo
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents an empirical study on arrhythmia detection using Neural Flow models enhanced with an attention mechanism. We implement both baseline Neural Flow and its attention-augmented variant to extract target-specific information for ECG beat classification. Following the Association for the Advancement of Medical Instrumentation (AAMI) guidelines for beat labeling, our experimental results demonstrate that incorporating the attention mechanism consistently improves classification performance, particularly under imbalanced data conditions.

title: Policy-based Word Subset Selection for Explaining Black-Box Language Models
authors: Minyoung Hwang, Seokhyun Lee, Changhee Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The development of deep language models (DLMs) has made them more widely used. This has led to a growing need for tools that can help understand how these models work, especially when it comes to understanding the reasoning behind their outputs. This explainability is emerging as a key factor in building trust between users and technologies. Achieving meaningful interpretability remains a significant challenge, especially when DLMs are considered black-box systems, where internal details like parameters and gradients are inaccessible. Although many techniques have been proposed, most struggle to meet two critical goals simultaneously: (i) maintaining efficiency during inference, and (ii) remaining compatible with black-box models without causing out-of-distribution behaviors. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a method that explains model predictions by selecting a concise and informative subset of input words. Our approach involves training a lightweight selection network to identify a minimal yet informative subset of input tokens. Once trained, this network operates with high efficiency, directly identifying a salient subset of words as the explanation for new samples at inference time. For training, we leverage policy gradients for optimization, which critically allows our method to operate without requiring gradient information from the target DLM, thus making it inherently applicable to black-box systems by directly interacting with the target DLM solely through its input-output predictions without requiring any gradient information.

title: A Semi-Supervised Learning Framework for Employee Performance Evaluation using Group-based Features
authors: Seungchan Jeon, Jangkyum Kim, Youngdae Ko
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In the industry, accurate employee performance evaluations are essential for compensation and workforce planning. However, employee performance datasets generally lack reliable labels. Therefore, we present a semi-supervised learning framework that combines a small set of expert-labeled records with a large pool of unlabeled data. In addition, group-based features are incorporated to ensure fair workload allocation among working groups. Also, statistical smoothing is used to stabilize small groups and weights deviations according to task complexity. Lastly, an iterative high-confidence pseudo-labeling procedure is employed to expand the labeled set, while distributional stability is monitored to prevent imbalance. In numerical studies, the framework enlarged the labeled portion from 4% to 92% without destabilizing the core feature distributions. After semi-supervised learning, the main features had stable means and lower standard deviations. This shows that the framework reduces the burden of expert labeling, enables fairer comparisons through group-based features and statistical smoothing, and can be smoothly integrated into employee performance analytics pipelines.

title: A Comparison between Simultaneous and Sequential Multitask Learning for Wireless Signal Classification and Reconstruction
authors: Muhammad Taqiyuddin, Yuhei Nagao, Masayuki Kurosaki, Hiroshi Ochi
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Modern wireless systems, such as UAV-based spectrum monitoring platforms, increasingly require simultaneous signal classification and reconstruction to operate under constrained resources and real-time demands. Multitask learning (MTL) offers a unified model to optimize both tasks jointly, reducing computational cost and deployment complexity; however, the inherent conflict between task objectives-discriminative feature extraction for classification versus signal fidelity preservation for reconstruction-raises concerns about the effectiveness of end-to-end joint optimization. This paper presents a comparative study between two training paradigms: simultaneous multitask learning, where tasks are trained jointly, and sequential multitask learning, where tasks are trained independently before integration. We design a multitask architecture comprising a convolutional encoder, a variational autoencoder (VAE) decoder, and a CNN classifier, employing KL annealing to stabilize the latent space during training. Using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex>-fold cross-validation on wireless IQ signal data, experimental results show that sequential learning achieves orders-of-magnitude better reconstruction quality (MSE < 0.1) while maintaining comparable classification accuracy to simultaneous learning. These findings highlight the limitations of joint training under conflicting objectives and advocate for sequential optimization when high task-specific performance is critical.

title: Enhancing quality content on social media for online education: use of TikTok to learn statistical methods in Market Research
authors: Francisco Paredes-Leon, Marisela Rodriguez-Salvador, Pedro F. Castillo-Valdez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: TikTok, a dynamic social media platform, can effectively serve teaching-learning purposes through versatile and engaging audiovisual content. Despite various discussions on social media’s impact in different contexts, there is a research gap in analyzing its educational value from a student’s perspective, especially in Latin America. This study introduces “Statistical Methods Tokers,” a strategy designed for teaching statistical methods in Market Research II at a private university in Peru. The strategy involved 476 students from August 2020 to December 2024. The results revealed that motivating students to use social media as an educational tool encourages dynamic and creative learning, with students having an active role in their learning.

title: Y-branch Waveguide-type Exclusive OR Logical Gate for THz-band Communication
authors: Koichi Takiguchi, Wataru Ishihara
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We report exclusive OR operation of a Y-branch waveguide for the 300 GHz-band. The exclusive OR operation is carried out through interference between two 20 Gbit/s on-off keying signals at the Y-branch. The results contribute to the development of security enhancement in the terahertz-band signal.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Correction of Indoor Path Loss Models for Wi-SUN Sub-GHz Communications
authors: Hyunho Son, Soyi Jung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Reliable indoor wireless connectivity is essential for building management systems and smart city infrastructure. Wireless smart ubiquitous network, based on the IEEE 802.15.4g standard, provides low-power long-range communication, but performance degrades in corridors due to periodic ripples in the received signal strength indicator (RSSI) caused by multi-path. Existing propagation models often fail to capture these fluctuations, leading to a large prediction error. This paper presents RSSI measurements at 917.1 MHz under frequency-shift keying (FSK) and orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) schemes and proposes reflection-aware path loss models whose coefficients are optimized via the soft actor-critic learning algorithm. The results show a significantly lower error in RSSI predictions, supporting more reliable indoor Internet of Things (IoT) planning.

title: A Sub-100 nW Power-on-Reset Circuit with Integrated Brown-Out Detection and Autonomous Power Gating for Edge Devices
authors: Inseo Son, Yoochang Kim, Young-Ha Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a compact power-on reset (POR) circuit with integrated brown-out reset (BOR) functionality and autonomous power gating. The proposed POR circuit employs a voltage gap generator to provide a reference for the POR threshold, enabling rapid and programmable POR operation over a wide range of supply ramping time <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(t_{\text{ramp }})$</tex>. Additionally, the proposed POR circuit incorporates a power gating controller to reduce quiescent current, which also monitors supply voltage (VDD) droop and automatically reactivates the circuit to generate the BOR signal. Implemented in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$</tex> CMOS process, the prototype POR circuit supports a configurable POR level above 700 mV at a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.8-1.2-\mathrm{V} V_{D D}$</tex> and guarantees a maximum POR delay of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16.4 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> over a broad range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t_{\text{ramp }}$</tex> from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> to 1 s. Owing to the autonomous power gating, the prototype consumes a quiescent current of 95 nA at a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-V V_{D D}$</tex> and occupies an active area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$580 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Study on the Design of a Physical Education Course Analysis and Management System Based on Decision Tree Algorithms
authors: Shihao Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: With the growing level of information technology in college physical education, many people now try to use data-driven methods to improve teaching quality and management. This topic has become very important in education management. Today, physical education courses often face several problems, such as scattered data, a single way of evaluation, and slow teaching feedback. These issues make it hard to support students' personal learning needs and teachers' precise teaching goals. To deal with these challenges, this study builds a physical education course analysis and management system based on a decision tree algorithm. The system uses many types of data, such as students' physical fitness indicators, classroom performance, course participation, and teacher evaluations. After data preprocessing, feature selection, and decision tree modeling, the system can predict student performance, find key factors, and evaluate course quality in a smart way. At the same time, the system shows clear rules through visual tools and provides modular functions. These functions help teachers improve teaching strategies, give students personalized learning feedback, and support managers in making better decisions about course resources. Experimental results show that the decision tree achieves up to 0.87 accuracy and 0.85 F1score, outperforming classical baselines such as logistic regression and SVM, confirming its suitability for physical education course analysis. The system also improves the speed of teaching feedback, the efficiency of course evaluation, and the quality of management decisions. This study offers a useful way to make physical education course management more smart and accurate. It also prepares the ground for future work on multi-model systems, cross-school data sharing, and the use of wearable devices.

title: Smart Blind Stick for Visually Impaired Navigation: Leveraging IoT and Exploring Future Enhancements
authors: Ritesh Kumar Sarkar, Adarsh Kumar, Nishtha Kansal, Seema Malik, Piyush Nautiyal
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: This paper discusses comprehending the obstacles and conditions experienced by the elderly population, such as health and physical ailments, as well as finding a solution for blind and physically challenged people who cannot afford to spend a huge amount of money, or are not technically aware, can use the device without understanding the functions, and caretakers can track the real-time status of the user through a conventional method. The current prototype aims to assist blind and physically disabled individuals by utilising distance measuring sensors (HCSR-04), a feedback system, and communication modules (SIM800L and NEO-6M) with Arduino as a microcontroller. Discussing its future function and various techniques or suggestions for expanding its use cases, as well as the reliability and implementation of various emerging technologies for further development.

title: Enhanced Duplicate Image Detection via Multi-Task Learning and Contrastive Features
authors: Jin-Hyuk Song, Yongseong Cho
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Detecting duplicate images in large-scale databases presents unique challenges compared to video-based detection, primarily due to the limited contextual information within static images. To overcome this, we propose a novel multi-task learning (MTL)-based feature extraction model designed to enhance both the efficiency and accuracy of duplicate image detection. Our model utilizes a MobileNetV2 backbone augmented with two task-specific branches: a low-dimensional embedding branch for efficient similarity retrieval and a classification branch that leverages content-type cues to reduce false positives. Furthermore, we incorporate a contrastive learning strategy with cross-batch negative samples to significantly boost the discriminative power of the learned features. Experimental results confirm that our proposed architecture yields compact and semantically rich representations, evidenced by improved clustering in t-SNE visualizations and stable convergence during training. This approach not only reduces GPU memory requirements but also enhances robustness to various image transformations.

title: Preference Aligned Visuomotor Diffusion Policies for Deformable Object Manipulation_supp1-3665075.mp4
authors: Marco Moletta
publish: N/A
abstract: Humans naturally develop preferences for how manipulation tasks should be performed, which are often subtle, personal, and difficult to articulate. Although it is important for robots to account for these preferences to increase personalization and user satisfaction, they remain largely underexplored in robotic manipulation, particularly in the context of deformable objects like garments and fabrics. In this work, we study how to adapt pretrained visuomotor diffusion policies to reflect preferred behaviors using limited demonstrations. We introduce RKO, a novel preference-alignment method that combines the benefits of two recent frameworks: RPO and KTO. We evaluate RKO against common preference learning frameworks, including these two, as well as a baseline vanilla diffusion policy, on real-world cloth-folding tasks spanning multiple garments and preference settings.
