We show that preference-aligned policies (particularly RKO) achieve superior performance and sample efficiency compared to standard diffusion policy fine-tuning. These results highlight the importance and feasibility of structured preference learning for scaling personalized robot behavior in complex deformable object manipulation tasks.

title: A Highly Sensitive MXene/rGO Piezoresistive Pressure Sensor With Fast Response
authors: Jiekang Xi, Jie Chen, Jingyi Liu, Debo Wang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Flexible pressure sensors as key components in smart wearable devices and electronic skin (e-skin), playing an essential role in signal detection and human-computer interaction. Nevertheless, challenges such as low sensitivity, slow response, and high preparation costs in existing flexible piezoresistive pressure sensors severely constrain their application. In view of these key factors, a novel, highly sensitive, and fast-responsive piezoresistive sensor with a MXene/rGO bilayer configuration is designed. The exceptional sensitivity and fast response characteristics are achieved through the utilization of a unique bilayer design and a synaptic conductive layer with rapid recovery capability. The sensor was fabricated via a cost-effective and facile laser direct writing (LDW) process, with MXene constituting up to 77% of the total mass. Measurement results reveal remarkable performance metrics: a pressure sensitivity of ~15.41 kPa<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup>, a record-breaking response time of 1.97ms, a recovery time of 0.82 ms, hysteresis as low as 5.8%, and a repeatability error below 4.9%. The MXene/rGO sensor exhibits broad application potential in the fields of electronic skin (e-skin), smart wearable devices, and human-computer interaction, especially in scenarios requiring high sensitivity and high-speed sensing capabilities.

title: Temporal Visual Semantics-Induced Human Motion Understanding with Large Language Models
authors: Zheng Xing, Weibing Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Unsupervised human motion segmentation (HMS) can be effectively achieved using subspace clustering techniques. However, traditional methods overlook the role of temporal semantic exploration in HMS. This paper explores the use of temporal vision semantics (TVS) derived from human motion sequences, leveraging the image-to-text capabilities of a large language model (LLM) to enhance subspace clustering performance. The core idea is to extract textual motion information from consecutive frames via LLM and incorporate this learned information into the subspace clustering framework. The primary challenge lies in learning TVS from human motion sequences using LLM and incorporating this information into subspace clustering. To address this, we determine whether consecutive frames depict the same motion by querying the LLM and subsequently learn temporal neighboring information based on its response. We then develop a TVS-integrated subspace clustering approach, incorporating subspace embedding with a temporal regularizer that induces each frame to share similar subspace embeddings with its temporal neighbors. Additionally, segmentation is performed based on subspace embedding with a temporal constraint that induces the grouping of each frame with its temporal neighbors. We also introduce a feedback-enabled framework that continuously optimizes subspace embedding based on the segmentation output. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches on four benchmark human motion datasets.

title: A Fingertip-Size Six-Axis Force Sensor via Origami Coil Arrays for Intrinsic Tactile Sensing_supp3-3660186.mp4
authors: Hongbo WANG
publish: N/A
abstract: Force and tactile sensing play increasingly important roles in robotics hands to complete complex tasks safely and effectively, complementing the last piece of the puzzle of human-level dexterity. Despite the advances in flexible sensors and skins, tactile sensing at the fingertip of robotic hands remains an open question. Exploiting embedded six-axis force/torque (F/T) sensors for external stimuli estimation, namely, intrinsic tactile sensing, seems to be an effective solution. Here, we present OriCube, an origami-inspired, fingertip-size (14.5 × 14.5 × 12.5 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>), lightweight (4 g), fully integrated, inductive six-axis F/T sensor. It utilizes an origami coil array to achieve self-decoupled six-axis F/T measurements by detecting the displacements and rotations of a metal shell via eddy–current coupling. A modular silicone spring-based elastomer design allows fine-tuning of the stiffness and performance of each axis independently. The calibrated OriCube exhibits a high resolution of 0.01% F.S. (23 N), low crosstalk (2%), high stability (<0.2% drift in 6 h), and insensitivity to strong magnetic field changes. It is capable of detecting light touch by a feather as well as high impact force when hammered. We demonstrate real-time tactile sensing (contact position and force vector) at the curved surface of a robotic fingertip via one embedded OriCube sensor.

title: Efficient Point Cloud Processing with High-Dimensional Positional Encoding and Non-Local MLPs_supp1-3665872.pdf
authors: hongshan yu
publish: N/A
abstract: Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) models are the foundation of contemporary point cloud processing. However, their complex network architectures obscure the source of their strength and limit the application of these models. In this article, we develop a two-stage abstraction and refinement (ABS-REF) view for modular feature extraction in point cloud processing. This view elucidates that whereas the early models focused on ABS stages, the more recent techniques devise sophisticated REF stages to attain performance advantages. Then, we propose a High-dimensional Positional Encoding (HPE) module to explicitly utilize intrinsic positional information, extending the “positional encoding” concept from Transformer literature. HPE can be readily deployed in MLP-based architectures and is compatible with transformer-based methods. Within our ABS-REF view, we rethink local aggregation in MLP-based methods and propose replacing time-consuming local MLP operations, which are used to capture local relationships among neighbors. Instead, we use non-local MLPs for efficient non-local information updates, combined with the proposed HPE for effective local information representation. We leverage our modules to develop HPENets, a suite of MLP networks that follow the ABS-REF paradigm, incorporating a scalable HPE-based REF stage. Extensive experiments on seven public datasets across four different tasks show that HPENets deliver a strong balance between efficiency and effectiveness. Notably, HPENet surpasses PointNeXt, a strong MLP-based counterpart, by 1.1% mAcc, 4.0% mIoU, 1.8% mIoU and 0.2% Cls. mIoU, with only 50.0%, 21.5%, 23.1%, 44.4% of FLOPs on ScanObjectNN, S3DIS, ScanNet, and ShapeNetPart, respectively. Source code are available at https://github.com/zouyanmei/HPENet v2.git.

title: Iterative and Real-Time Trajectory Modification Control via Error Decoupling for Wafer Scanner Synchronization
authors: Longbin Jiang, Yunlang Xu, Xiaofeng Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In wafer scanners, synchronization accuracy between the wafer stage and reticle stage (RS) directly determines exposure quality. Existing main–secondary control methods face three challenges. First, the measured synchronization error inherently couples the RS tracking error and main–secondary error, making precise compensation difficult. Second, existing methods based on model inversion or iterative feedforward approaches exhibit limited capability in suppressing inevitable external disturbances. Third, directly modifying existing servo control loops is often impractical due to proprietary control architectures. To address these challenges, this article proposes iterative and real-time synchronization trajectory modification control (IRSTMC), achieving high-precision synchronization tracking and disturbance rejection without altering the original servo control loop. The method features three key innovations. First, a time-frequency analysis-based decoupling technique is developed to predict RS position and extract the dominant main-secondary error, establishing the foundation for precise compensation. Second, a unified dual-module scheme integrating iterative synchronization trajectory modification (ISTM) and real-time synchronization trajectory modification (RSTM) is proposed, where ISTM compensates tracking errors through iterative learning and RSTM suppresses stochastic disturbances through real-time correction via external synchronization feedback. Third, unlike existing trajectory compensation methods requiring predefined references, IRSTMC enables trajectory modification for real-time generated references. Experimental validation demonstrates that IRSTMC achieves 65% improvement over the baseline method and significantly outperforms existing approaches in synchronization accuracy.

title: Ultra-Wideband Reconfigurable Radar Waveform Generation Based on Optical Recirculating Frequency Shifter Loop
authors: Kunlong Li, Bin Wang, Weifeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We propose and experimentally demonstrate an approach for generating ultra-wideband reconfigurable radar waveforms using a recirculating frequency shifter (RFS) loop. In the proposed system, a RFS loop is used to achieve substantial bandwidth extension. Within this architecture, the frequency-modulated optical seed signal undergoes simultaneous temporal and spectral stitching, producing a wideband frequency-modulated optical output signal. By beating the output optical signal of the RFS loop with a continuous-wave optical signal, ultra-wideband reconfigurable radar waveforms can be generated. An experimental demonstration is performed, in which linearly-chirped and frequency-stepped microwave waveforms with a maximum bandwidth of 24 GHz are generated, showcasing the system's capability to produce diverse waveform types with substantial bandwidth. This versatile technique presents new possibilities for adaptive radar systems requiring high-performance waveform agility across multiple operational scenarios.

title: Electro-Optic Doppler Target Simulation for FMCW LiDAR
authors: Johannes Reichstein, Christian Carlowitz, Marius Schmidt
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: With the increasing usage of LiDARs in safety-relevant automotive applications, there is an increasing need for test systems that can verify accurate target detection in production and workshop environments, especially regarding upcoming coherent FMCW approaches. In this paper, we demonstrate for the first time an all-optical, coherent test system concept that can replicate the Doppler effect in a compact setup for FMCW LiDAR systems. It is based on a fiber-optic feedback loop with a Mach-Zehnder modulator for electro-optic Doppler generation. For experimental validation, we use a microwave-photonic FMCW LiDAR at 1 m distance. Moving targets with velocities between 0.3 and 56 km/h have been emulated for the first time in a LiDAR setup over-the-air with more than 25 dB carrier suppression, less than -20 dB I/Q imbalance and modulation harmonics below noise floor.

title: Non-Invasive Blood Glucose Estimation Using Near-Infrared Spectroscopy with an Optical Sensor and MLP-Based Machine Learning
authors: Kazuki Asakura, Saki Takaira, Hiroki Matsumoto
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: In recent years, with the increasing number of individuals suspected of having diabetes, the importance of continuous blood glucose monitoring has grown. However, currently widespread household blood glucose measurement methods are invasive. This not only imposes physical and psychological burdens on users but also poses a risk of infectious diseases. Therefore, there is a strong demand for the development of safe and non-invasive blood glucose measurement devices. A noninvasive and non-destructive method of measuring sugar content of fruits using optical sensors has been established. Focusing on the near-infrared spectroscopy used in this method, the aim is to construct a non-invasive blood glucose measurement method. This paper examines a non-invasive blood glucose estimation method using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy measured by an optical sensor, combined with machine-learning models. First, a glucose concentration prediction model is constructed based on a multilayer perceptron (MLP) trained on absorbance data over the full wavelength range of 680-2500 nm, obtained using near-infrared spectroscopy, which is considered harmless to the human body. Next, considering practical application, Grad-CAM (Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping) is used to identify the wavelengths emphasized by the machine learning model during prediction. Finally, this paper examines a method for estimating glucose concentration using an MLP model trained on absorbance data of the selected wavelengths. The prediction accuracy is evaluated using MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error). The target error is set at 0.1% or less to discriminate between pre- and postprandial glucose variations. As a result, the model using all wavelengths achieves a MAPE of 0.0593%. In the models using eight and seven selected wavelengths, MAPE values of 0.0773% and 0.0658% are confirmed, respectively, both satisfying the target of MAPE below 0.1%. Additionally, it is confirmed that even with 6 to 4 wavelengths, glucose concentration can be estimated with MAPE below 0.2%.

title: A Signed-Transfer SRAM Computing-in-Memory Macro with In-Column Reconfiguration Dac and 2Bit/Cycle Quantization
authors: Ying Pan, Xin Li, Yuanyang Wang, Jiaqi Chen, Yang Lou, Yifan Wu, Jianxing Zhou, Qiushi Feng, Wenqiang Zhang, Baofa Wu, Chenghu Dai, Yu Liu, Xiulong Wu, Zhiting Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper proposes a charge-domain computing-in-memory (CIM) macro in CMOS 28nm technology, which utilizesan in-column reconfiguration scheme to construct CDACs of SAR (Successive Approximation Register) ADC, thereby reducing the capacitors and minimizing the layout area. Additionally, a signed-transfer multiplication unit (STMU) and a 2-bit/cycle quantization technique are employed to enhance computational efficiency. The macro circuit comprises four banks with a total SRAM capacity of 2.88Kb. The post-layout simulation results indicate that, with 3-bit inputs and 5-bit weights (including the sign bit), the proposed macro achieves a peak energy efficiency of 129.2 TOPS/W, while demonstrating inference accuracies of 98.36% and 88.43% on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively.

title: Development of FTM Automatic Measurement System for Indoor Location
authors: Takashi Ookawahara, Yudai Sunagozaka, Rei Hirata, Atushi Koizumi, Hiroshi Oguma, Koki Nakamura, Takenori Sumi, Yukimasa Nagai
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: We conduct measurement experiments using the IEEE802.11-2016 standard with the goal of establishing an indoor location estimation method using Wi-Fi access points (APs) . This standard employs the Fine Time Measurement (FTM) protocol to calculate the distance between an AP and a terminal. To measure indoor ranging accuracy, measurements need to be taken at many points. In this study, we create a measurement robot using line tracing and QR codes, and an Android application that automatically collects FTM data, and built an automatic measurement system. This system enables automatic collection of distance measurement data from many points, shortening the measurement time and reducing human cost and human error. Furthermore, to evaluate the usefulness of the proposed system in comparative experiments, we also investigated the impact of AP height on the positioning accuracy.

title: Mobility-Aware Multi-Agent Learning for Efficient Handover in Multi-Layer Satellite Network
authors: Junyoung Kim, Huiyeon Jang, Soyi Jung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In 6G networks, providing ultra-space, ultra-connectivity, and ultra-precision services is a key objective, driving active research and standardization efforts. Among these, non-terrestrial networks (NTNs), particularly those using low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites, have gained significant attention. However, the high mobility of satellites and the harsh space environment pose challenges to seamless service for terrestrial user equipment (UE), especially mobile UE (MUE). This paper proposes a reinforcement learning-based handover optimization method for multi-layer satellite networks. The scheme utilizes long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to predict the time-series mobility of satellites and MUEs, and applies a multi-agent deep Q-network (MADQN) to optimize handover decisions. Simulation results show that the proposed method improves the quality of service (QoS) for MUEs and enhances overall system throughput.

title: An In-Depth Examination of Occupational Stress among Banking Employees in Uttarakhand
authors: Prakash Garia, Narendra Kumar, Prachi Joshi, Preeti Sharma, Anant Deogaonkar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Workplace stress is a serious issue nowadays. Most managers and entrepreneurs face numerous problems at work and in their personal lives. Stress is ordinary portion of life but extreme stress can influence employee’s capableness, fitness, and sentiments. When an employee is stressed, he loses his confidence, he won’t want to take responsibility, he gets irritated easily, he is not satisfied with his job, and his performance is low which ultimately is a danger to the organization in which he is working. Stress affects organizational welfare as well as the personal behavior of employees. Every employee has different factors of stress. Working in a bank is one of the most stressful jobs due to the consistent pressure of delivering services and the best to their customers. Occupational stress has become a major hazard for many employees due to increasing workload, unrealistic time pressure, inflexible time, less support from colleagues, lesser empowerment, less respect at the workplace, and many more. The study aims to determine the prevalence of employment anxiety in the banking industry and to identify the anxiety factor relationship with the productivity of employees in banks. The study seeks to offer useful insights and suggestions for building a healthier and more effective work environment in the banking industry by identifying stress factors and their impact.

title: CoRN-LN: Compressed Reciprocal Newton Method for Efficient Layer Normalization
authors: Dawon Choi, Hana Kim, Ji-Hoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: In Transformer-based models such as BERT, Layer Normalization (LayerNorm) accounts for a significant portion of total computations, and its efficiency directly impacts model performance. Among LayerNorm components, the reciprocal square root operation is particularly challenging due to its non-linear operations such as division and square root. These operations result in significant accuracy degradation, increased latency and high area overhead. To address these challenges, this paper proposes Compressed Reciprocal Newton's method for efficient Layer Normalization (CoRN-LN) which is a novel approximation architecture that improves accuracy and hardware area. CoRN-LN introduces three key contributions: a 16 bit compression method to reduce computational complexity, the Leading-One-Detector (LOD)-aware initial guess that dynamically adapts to input value to improve accuracy and latency, and the reciprocal-form Newton Approximation to eliminate the divider. The CoRN-LN architecture and the baseline were implemented in Verilog HDL and synthesized using the Samsung 28nm CMOS process for fair comparison. We demonstrate that the CoRN-LN reduces Mean Square Error (MSE) from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.50 \times 10^{-2}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.85 \times 10^{-6}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \times$</tex> area reduction over baseline, using only 2-cycle.

title: PoTS: Proof-of-Training-Steps for Backdoor Detection in Large Language Models
authors: Issam Seddik, Sami Souihi, Mohamed Tamaazousti, Sara Tucci Piergiovanni
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: As Large Language Models (LLMs) gain traction across critical domains, ensuring secure and trustworthy training processes has become a major concern. Backdoor attacks, among various threats—where malicious actors inject hidden triggers into training data—are particularly insidious and difficult to detect. Existing post-training verification solutions like Proof-of-Learning are impractical for LLMs due to their requirement for full retraining, lack robustness against stealthy manipulations, and inability to provide early detection during training—a property that would significantly reduce computational costs. To address these limitations, we introduce Proof-of-Training Steps, a verification protocol that enables an independent auditor (Alice) to confirm that an LLM developer (Bob) has followed the declared training recipe, including data batches, architecture, and hyperparameters. By analyzing the sensitivity of the LLMs’ language modeling head (LM-Head) to input perturbations, our method can expose subtle backdoor injections or deviations in training. Even with backdoor triggers in up to 10% of the training data, our protocol significantly reduces the attacker’s ability to achieve a high attack success rate (ASR). Our method enables early detection of the attack (at the step the attack is injected), with verification step being 3× faster than a training step. Our results highlight the protocol’s potential to enhance the accountability and security of LLM development, especially against insider threats.

title: Advancing Cryptographic Security Through Quantum True Random Number Generation
authors: T.S. Gururaja, Padmapriya Pravinkumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: True randomness is a basic necessity of secure cryptography. This secures the reliability of encryption keys, digital signatures and authentication mechanisms. Classical random number generators based on deterministic algorithms can introduce patterns and decrease reliability. This paper introduces a Quantum True Random Number Generator (QTRNG) takes advantage of the intrinsic unpredictability of quantum mechanics. The proposed quantum circuit uses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R Y(\pi / 2)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R Z(\pi / 2)$</tex> rotations to create superposition states like Hadamard operation. These gates control the phase and orientation of qubits on the Bloch sphere yields measurement outcomes are inherently random. The resulting distributions are unbiased and balanced offers a source of true randomness. The quality of the generated bitstrings is verified using statistical tests such as the NIST SP 800-22, SP 800-90 test suites and autocorrelation tests. The measurements show high entropy, uniform distribution and low bias satisfy the basic requirements for cryptographic security. Phase-based quantum operations provide an efficient for producing high-quality quantum randomness facilitates the construction of effective quantum-secure cryptographic systems.

title: Method for Identifying Abnormal Operating States of Electromechanical Equipment Based on Improved Random Forest Algorithm
authors: Wendong Ji, Bin Liu, Yan Zhao, Yuxiao Li, Lingyu Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In response to the problems of feature redundancy and insufficient dynamic adaptability in the traditional random forest algorithm for identifying the operating status of electromechanical equipment, this study proposes an improved method that integrates feature optimization and dynamic integration strategy. Implementing feature selection through the mutual information ReliefF hybrid algorithm, removing 37% redundant information while retaining key physical features such as vibration peaks and temperature gradients; Introducing a dynamic weight integration mechanism based on classification accuracy and margin, the decision tree weights can be dynamically adjusted by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30 \%-50 \%$</tex> when the sample is at an abnormal boundary; Build a parallel inference architecture for edge cloud collaboration, with a single sample processing delay controlled within 45 ms. Industrial test data shows that this method achieves a recognition accuracy of 96.3% under four types of working conditions, an improvement of 8.2% compared to traditional algorithms. The recall rate for minor abnormalities such as early bearing wear is increased by 12.5%, and the accuracy remains at 90.2% in a 20 dB noise environment. The research results provide a solution for predictive maintenance of electromechanical equipment that combines accuracy and real-time performance. In the future, the application scenarios can be further expanded through model lightweighting and transfer learning.

title: Research on Prediction Model of Lithium Battery Cycle Life
authors: Xiaofang Yu, Shuai Wang
publish: 2025 6th New Power System International Forum - Power System and New Energy Technology Innovation Forum (NPSIF)
abstract: In view of the problems such as low efficiency, complex procedures, high cost and low accuracy in the cycle life detection process of traditional lithium-ion batteries, this paper establishes a research method by integrating traditional detection methods and efficient prediction models. By adopting neural network algorithms represented by extreme learning machines and applying a series of derivative algorithms of extreme learning machines on this basis, including basic extreme learning machines, hierarchical extreme learning machines, weighted extreme learning machines, online sequential extreme learning machines and many other artificial intelligence algorithms based on extreme learning machines as the underlying foundation, an efficient prediction model is built.

title: Federated Matching Learning for Privacy-Preserving and Robust Task Allocation in Industrial Control System Crowdsourced Testing
authors: Xin Liu, Lei Li, Donglan Liu, Rui Wang, Bing Su, Shanjie Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) security is of critical importance to modern infrastructure. Crowdsourced testing has emerged as an effective approach for vulnerability discovery in ICS environments, but faces significant challenges in privacy preservation, multi-objective optimization, and adversarial robustness. This paper proposes a novel Federated Matching Learning (FML) framework for privacy-preserving task allocation in ICS crowdsourced testing. Our method consists of three key components: (1) a FML module that employs knowledge graph-enhanced representations to estimate tasktester affinity without centralizing sensitive data; (2) a hybrid metaheuristic scheduling algorithm that efficiently solves the multi-objective allocation problem on reduced candidate graphs; and (3) a dynamic reputation and adversary detection subsystem that ensures system robustness against malicious participants. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves significant improvements in task completion efficiency while maintaining high vulnerability discovery rates and system robustness, even under high proportions of malicious testers. The proposed framework provides a comprehensive solution for secure, efficient, and reliable crowdsourced testing in ICS.

title: Design Automation for a-IGZO Thin Film Technology Using a Multi-Row Standard Cell Architecture
authors: Yi-Ting Lin, Yalun Tang, Byeonggon Kang, Iris Hui-Ru Jiang, Kenji Nomura, Yuhwa Lo, Lifu Chang, Bill Lin, Chung-Kuan Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Amorphous-IGZO thin-film transistors (a-IGZO TFTs) have attracted increasing attention for emerging applications in wearable devices and IoT technologies, owing to their compatibility with flexible substrates, low processing temperatures, and energy-efficient operation. However, the lack of p-type devices breaks the symmetry of conventional CMOS logic, and the technology requires a double-gate structure with bias voltage to adjust the I-V characteristics. While previous studies have primarily focused on fabrication and application aspects, the electronic design automation (EDA) perspective remains underexplored. In this paper, we propose the first standard cell synthesis framework for a-IGZO TFTs. The framework features a cell layout architecture that integrates bias voltage into power rail planning and adopts multirow transistor placement to address logic asymmetry. Transistor placement is modeled as an exact cover with colors (XCC) problem and solved using the dancing cells algorithm, while intra-cell routing is formulated with satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) to account for double-gate and multi-rail structures. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed architecture and methodologies.

title: Beam Search Method for Active RIS
authors: Manho Park, Heesang Chung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved beam search method for providing indirect access links using active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) technology in wireless communication services. Providing an efficient beam search method in beamforming-based communication services is an important issue related to reducing the overall system load and improving service quality. We propose a beam search scheme that comprehensively utilizes the beam identification information of the base stations and unique gain control information of the active RIS. The proposed method improves the efficiency and speed of beam search process compared to conventional base station-oriented methods. In addition, this method can ensure a high level of service reliability by limiting the search delay to a certain level even in a base station environment utilizing multiple RISs

title: Model to promote STEM careers based on Machine learning for secondary education - Peru
authors: Johana Pamela Campos Davila, Angie Mishelly Gala Salazar, Carlos Alvarado Quintana, Yeny Vargas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Despite growing recognition of the importance of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) careers, female participation in these fields remains significantly lower than that of males. In Peru, social, cultural, educational, and personal factors contribute to this disparity. This study developed a web-based solution to promote STEM career interest among female secondary school students through personalized vocational guidance and inspirational content. A predictive vocational test was implemented within a web application to recommend STEM fields tailored to students’ interests. Following the intervention, changes in students’ perception, interest, and intention toward pursuing STEM careers were assessed using preand post-intervention surveys. Results showed substantial improvements across key indicators: a 38.1% increase in STEM interest (ICI), a 32.0% increase in intention to pursue STEM (ICN), and a $54.9 \%$ enhancement in perception of STEM fields (ICP). Additionally, the machine-learning model integrated into the application achieved a predictive accuracy of $93.3 \%$. This high performance supported the delivery of personalized recommendations and underscores the effectiveness of targeted interventions in fostering STEM awareness and motivation among under-represented populations.

title: Temporal-Spatial EEG Feature Learning for Schizophrenia Classification via Transformers and LSTM Networks
authors: Kunal Gupta, Amandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Schizophrenia is a chronic neuropsychiatric disorder affecting <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\tilde{\mathbf{1}} \%$</tex> of the population, marked by hallucinations, delusions, and cognitive deficits. Its early onset leads to significant disability and suicide risk. Current diagnosis depends on subjective assessments, highlighting the need for objective biomarkers. EEG, a non-invasive tool reflecting neural dysfunction, offers promise in schizophrenia detection. However, its noisy, nonstationary nature limits traditional deep learning models. This work proposes a hybrid Transformer-LSTM architecture to address these challenges. The Transformer extracts temporal features, while the LSTM captures sequential dependencies for improved classification. Tested on a clinical EEG dataset (14 SZ, 14 HC), the model achieves 99.07% accuracy-outperforming CNN, LSTM, and CNN-LSTM baselines. Brain region-wise analysis identifies central and temporal channels as key contributors. The results demonstrate the model's effectiveness and clinical relevance for EEG-based schizophrenia detection.

title: The ISC Creator: Human-Centered Design of Learning Analytics Interactive Indicator Specification Cards
authors: Shoeb Joarder, Mohamed Amine Chatti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Emerging research on human-centered learning analytics (HCLA) has demonstrated the importance of involving diverse stakeholders in co-designing learning analytics (LA) systems. However, there is still a demand for effective and efficient methods to co-design LA dashboards and indicators. Indicator Specification Cards (ISCs) have been introduced recently to facilitate the systematic co-design of indicators by different LA stakeholders. In this paper, we strive to enhance the user experience and usefulness of the ISC-based indicator design process. Towards this end, we present the systematic design, implementation, and evaluation details of the ISC Creator, an interactive LA tool that allows low-cost and flexible design of LA indicators. Our findings demonstrate the importance of carefully considered interactivity and recommendations for orienting and supporting non-expert LA stakeholders to design custom LA indicators.

title: Variable Step-Size Modified One-Tap Affine-Projection Algorithm for Adaptive Null-Forming in Digital Hearing Aids
authors: Yu-Chi Huang, Yu-Hsun Lin, Fu-Jie Tey, Ying-Ren Chien
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This research explores a dual-microphone system that employs a one-tap Affine Projection Algorithm (APA) integrated with a Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR)-adaptive step size parameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex> and an Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) equalizer for adaptive null formation. The primary objective is to attenuate both environmental and impulsive noise components while preserving speech intelligibility. The simulation experiments involved speech signals originating in the frontal direction <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(0^{\circ}\right)$</tex>, with noise sources introduced at varying incident angles. The algorithm adaptively modulated its convergence rate based on real-time SNR estimations, thereby maintaining stability amid rapidly fluctuating acoustic conditions. The findings indicate that the SNRcontrolled step size APA achieves rapid convergence and effectively suppresses noise in dynamic, non-stationary environments. Furthermore, the subsequent IIR filtering stage mitigates spectral distortion and improves speech clarity. The results demonstrate that integrating adaptive projection methods, dynamic stepsize adjustment, and post-filtering substantially enhances realtime speech enhancement performance in challenging acoustic scenarios.

title: Early Student Performance Prediction in Personalized Programming Education
authors: Aymen Omri, Seifeddine Bouallegue, Ayoub Feki, Robert Ford, Bekir Sait Ciftler, Abdullatif Shikfa, Shiban Khan, Salem Al-Naemi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Intelligent recommender systems play a key role in identifying at-risk students and personalizing learning with tailored resources. Accurate prediction of student achievement is crucial for enabling these systems to deliver timely interventions and offer data-driven support. This paper presents the application of machine learning models to predict final exam grades in a university-level programming course. It investigates the use of multi-modal student data to enhance prediction accuracy. In particular, a recent raw dataset of students enrolled in a programming course across ten different class sections, collected one month prior to the final exam, was initially processed. From this data, a comprehensive set of features was engineered, including assessment grades and completion durations, digital learning interactions, and engagement metrics. These features were then used to train and evaluate six machine learning prediction models, where Random Forest has achieved the highest predictive accuracy (above $90 \%$). Feature importance analysis has revealed that the midterm grade and the average completion duration of lab assessments are the most influential predictors. The results highlight the significant potential of early grade prediction as a practical and efficient tool for programming educational recommender systems. This data-driven approach allows instructors to identify and support atrisk students, paving the way for adaptive learning environments that offer personalized feedback, targeted resources, and timely interventions. Ultimately, such systems promote deeper student engagement, enhance academic performance, and improve retention rates within computing disciplines.

title: Hardware-Efficient VLSI Architecture for L-BFGS Detection in MIMO-OFDM Systems
authors: Xuenan Wang, Yijing Yang, Chenggang Yan, Bi Wu, Ke Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Minimum Mean Square Error (MMSE) detection is widely used in Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) systems due to its ability to mitigate noise, reduce interference, and enhance system performance. However, its practical hardware implementation is limited by the high computational cost of matrix inversion. To address this challenge, we propose a hardwareefficient detection framework based on the limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (L-BFGS) algorithm. The framework features a Dual-Phase L-BFGS (DP-LBFGS) structure that enables efficient parallel processing. Additionally, a hybrid optimization strategy combining input bit-width expansion and adaptive iteration termination is introduced to reduce quantization errors and computational overhead. Simulations on an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 16$</tex> Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK) MIMOOFDM system demonstrate that the proposed detector achieves Bit Error Rates (BERs) as low as 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−7</sup>, maintaining over 95% of full-precision performance with significantly reduced complexity. Implementation on a Xilinx Virtex-7 FPGA shows a throughput of 848 Mbps and a hardware efficiency of 4.79 Mbps/K slices, outperforming existing designs by a factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.25 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.04 \times$</tex>.

title: A Hybrid Approach Using Grey Wolf Optimization with Discrete Wavelet Transform and LeNet Features for Tuberculosis Classification in Chest X-Ray
authors: A. Akilandeswari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The aim is to provide a hybrid methodology that fuses Discrete Wavelet Transform with LeNet-based Convolutional Neural Network features for the classification of chest X-ray images. DWT decomposes the images into frequency sub-bands, while feature extraction is covered by LeNet. These combined features are subjected to the evaluation of SVM, Random Forest, and AdaBoost classifiers. The results indicated enhanced classification performance regarding the detection of tuberculosis in chest radiographs. Feature selection can further be optimized by Grey Wolf Optimizer, leading to even better results. The optimized Random Forest classifier yielded an accuracy of 97.1 %.

title: A Hierarchical Learning Approach for Optimal Resource Allocation Strategy for NTN-TN Coexistence Scenarios
authors: Junyoung Kim, Jiseok Jang, Soyi Jung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In sixth-generation (6G) networks, non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) using low Earth orbit (LEO) satellites are expected to be pivotal in extending coverage and service diversity. Most existing studies on LEO-based communications focus on downlink (DL) services within the Long-Term Evolution (LTE) framework. This paper addresses an NTN-terrestrial network (TN) coexistence scenario based on the fifth-generation (5G) orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) architecture and proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning-based resource allocation and scheduling scheme (HRL-RAS). The HRL-RAS optimizes resource distribution to meet heterogeneous user demands and improve key performance indicators (KPIs) such as data rate for future integrated NTN-TN systems.

title: Verti-Arena: A Controllable and Standardized Indoor Testbed for Multi-Terrain Off-Road Autonomy
authors: Haiyue Chen, Aniket Datar, Tong Xu, Francesco Cancelliere, Harsh Rangwala, Madhan Balaji Rao, Daeun Song, David Eichinger, Xuesu Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Off-road navigation is an important capability for mobile robots deployed in environments that are inaccessible or dangerous to humans, such as disaster response or planetary exploration. Progress is limited due to the lack of a controllable and standardized real-world testbed for systematic data collection and validation. To fill this gap, we introduce Verti-Arena, a reconfigurable indoor facility designed specifically for off-road autonomy. By providing a repeatable benchmark environment, Verti-Arena supports reproducible experiments across a variety of vertically challenging terrains and provides precise ground truth measurements through onboard sensors and a motion capture system. Verti-Arena also supports consistent data collection and comparative evaluation of algorithms in off-road autonomy research. We also develop a web-based interface that enables research groups worldwide to remotely conduct standardized off-road autonomy experiments on Verti-Arena.

title: State of Power Estimation of Lithium Ion Battery Using Machine Learning
authors: Saniya Nadaf, Nidhi Agnihotri, Sindhu S Hurakadli, Anoopkumar Patil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel technique for estimating the State of Power (SoP) of Li-ion batteries using machine learning. A hybrid pulse power characterization test is conducted on various Li-ion batteries with different age profiles, adhering to IEC standards, to estimate the internal resistance of the batteries. The estimated resistance is then utilized to develop and train a linear regression model that predicts the SoP of the Li-ion batteries. The model is tested and validated using appropriate statistical parameters to ensure accurate prediction of the SoP.

title: Precise Transmission Delay Measurement in Microwave Photonic Links
authors: Jinping Xiao, Wei Wei, Zhuoran Li, Guoying Zheng, Jinchuan Yao, Weilin Xie, Yi Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: We propose a high-precision and wide-range delay measurement system for microwave photonic transmission links. By modulating a dual-tone signal and employing a double optical mixing architecture, this approach simultaneously achieves wide-range and high-precision delay measurements. Experimental results demonstrate an ultra-high precision of ±12 fs in measuring the motorized optical delay line. Furthermore, we validate the capability of the system for wide-range delay measurement through a 10 km fiber test. The delay measurement accuracy of the system under low signal power conditions is also validated. Therefore, the proposed delay measurement method holds significant potential for distributed systems by enabling precise delay alignment and synchronization among multiple nodes, which is crucial for enhancing overall system coherence.

title: Understanding Human Daily Experience Through Continuous Sensing: ETRI Lifelog Dataset 2024
authors: Se Won Oh, Hyuntae Jeong, Seungeun Chung, Jeong Mook Lim, Kyoung Ju Noh, Sunkyung Lee, Gyuwon Jung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Improving human health and well-being requires an accurate and effective understanding of an individual’s physical and mental state throughout daily life. To support this goal, we utilized smartphones, smartwatches, and sleep sensors to collect data passively and continuously for 24 hours a day, with minimal interference to participants’ usual behavior, enabling us to gather quantitative data on daily behaviors and sleep activities across multiple days. Additionally, we gathered subjective self-reports of participants’ fatigue, stress, and sleep quality through surveys conducted immediately before and after sleep. This comprehensive lifelog dataset is expected to provide a foundational resource for exploring meaningful insights into human daily life and lifestyle patterns, and a portion of the data has been anonymized and made publicly available for further research. In this paper, we introduce the ETRI Lifelog Dataset 2024, detailing its structure and presenting potential applications, such as using machine learning models to predict sleep quality and stress.

title: A Cost-effective Single Element Dielectric Rod Antenna for THz Applications
authors: A. Piroutiniya, M. Ali, A. Kumar, A. Rivera-Lavado, D. De Felipe, L. Liebermeister, P. Winklhofer, G. Carpintero
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: A low-loss silicon rod antenna designed for coupling terahertz (THz) signals from indium phosphide (InP) photoconductive and photodiode devices is presented. Key design considerations addressed in this work include the selection of chip structure, suitable contact pads and appropriate printed circuit board (PCB) material for high-frequency performance.

title: THES-SNN: Thresholded Hybrid Encoding with Single-Spike Neurons for Energy-Efficient Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Jia Yu, Tianyang Yu, Bi Wu, Ke Chen, Chenggang Yan, Weiqiang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) have performance advantages in neuromorphic computing owing to their low power consumption and event-driven characteristics. During SNNs computation, data encoding plays a decisive role. The mainstream encoding methods include direct encoding and time encoding. Direct encoding offers high accuracy but incurs heavy floatingpoint computation, while time encoding reduces computational load through sparsity but suffers from severe information loss and long latency. To address the bottlenecks in single encoding schemes, hybrid encoding is proposed, but it still incurs significant floating-point computation in the input layer. This paper proposes an optimized hybrid sparse encoding strategy that applies threshold-based direct encoding in the first timestep to reduce floating-point computation, followed by time encoding to ensure spike sparsity. A single-spike neuron circuit and a multiplication-free, hardware-friendly encoder are introduced to further reduce power consumption. Experiments show 90.65% and 65.23% accuracy on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, with a 2% drop in input-layer floating-point operations and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5 \%}$</tex> lower spike firing rates. On MNIST, the hardware achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$180 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> inference speed and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.026 \mu \mathrm{J} /$</tex> synapse energy consumption.

title: Approaches to Detect and Mitigate Phishing Threats: a Deep Learning Approach to Prevent Cyber Attacks
authors: Surendra Narang, Venkata Gopi Kolla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Information security in cyberspace suffers greatly from phishing, allowing malicious sites to impersonate real ones and fool users. Phishing scammers use inventive methods and it gets more difficult to watch out for novel phishing sites. This work presents an effective phishing detection framework leveraging both machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques applied to the PhishTank dataset. Data preprocessing covers dealing with missing datapoints, outliers and data imbalance through SMOTE, after which features are extracted, encoded and normalized. Two advanced models-XGBoost and a hybrid CNN-GRU-are implemented to capture complex phishing patterns. The outcomes reveal that XGBoost succeeds with the highest accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(99.68 \%)$</tex>, as well as highest precision, recall and F1score over the other models tested. The CNN-GRU model also does very well, and its high recall suggests it may generalize well to new data. Comparative analysis with traditional ML models like ANN, RF, AdaBoost, and Naïve Bayes highlights the superior detection accuracy of the proposed approaches. The study further evaluates model robustness through loss curves, confusion matrices, and ROC-AUC metrics, confirming their reliability in distinguishing phishing attacks from legitimate instances and providing a promising solution for cybersecurity applications.

title: AutoAlign Tiling Machine for Efficient Floor Setup
authors: Pravin N. Kokitkar, Saurabh Jais, Atish More, Mohan Bijawe, Surbhi Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The paper presents the conceptualization, design, and development of an innovative Automatic Tile Fixing Machine, designed to attain unprecedented precision and uniformity in floor tile applications. The device is integrated with an advanced robotic arm that independently picks tiles from a specified cart and carefully places them onto the flooring surface with high precision. For better operational accuracy, the system features a high-definition vision module and advanced distance-measuring sensors. These are integrated to calculate the number of tiles needed while ensuring flawless alignment to avoid placement inaccuracies. This innovation automates the tiling process, considerably lowering human input, reducing inaccuracies, and maximizing overall efficiency, especially in large-scale development and flooring installations. The system has the potential to revolutionize the flooring industry by enhancing installation rate, precision, and absolute consistency, thus setting a new standard in automated flooring solutions.

title: Explainable Artificial Intelligence Model for Secure Blockchain-Based Cyber-Physical Industrial Systems
authors: Mohammad Idrish Ali, Abdul Momen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The convergence of Cyber-Physical Industrial Systems (CPIS) with intelligent automation has enhanced operational efficiency but simultaneously introduced complex security and interpretability challenges. Conventional Artificial Intelligence (AI) models employed in industrial cybersecurity often lack transparency, making their decisions difficult to justify in critical control environments. Additionally, centralized data management mechanisms remain vulnerable to tampering and single-point failures. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a novel Blockchain-Integrated Explainable Federated Intelligence Framework (B-XFIF) for secure and transparent CPIS operations. The B-XFIF integrates federated learning with blockchain and Explainable AI (XAI) principles to achieve three core objectives: (1) decentralized and privacy-preserving model training across distributed industrial nodes, (2) immutable blockchain-based logging of model updates and security events, and (3) interpretable decision support through explainable reasoning layers. This hybrid approach eliminates the need for centralized data aggregation, ensures data authenticity, and provides human-understandable justifications for AI-driven security decisions. Experimental evaluations on benchmark CPIS datasets demonstrate that B-XFIF enhances detection accuracy by 12%, reduces latency in anomaly response by 18%, and significantly improves operator trust through interpretable insights. The proposed model establishes a foundation for resilient, transparent, and trustworthy industrial ecosystems that align with emerging standards of Industry 5.0. The proposed B-XFIF achieved key parameter values: detection accuracy 94.8%, model update latency 130ms, blockchain throughput 75 TPS, and interpretability score 90%, confirming superior secure and explainable performance.

title: Anomaly Detection for Multi-Region Radio Noise Measurement Data
authors: Youngkeun Yoon, Heonjin Hong, Ho-Kyung Son
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper investigates anomaly detection in multi-region radio noise power measurements through two–dimensional Principal Component Analysis preprocessing, followed by two widely recognized machine learning–based unsupervised outlier detection methods: Density–Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise and Isolation Forest. Measurement data from six regions were synthesized to simulate realistic electromagnetic noise conditions, including sporadic and non-specific anomalous received power events. The preprocessing step reduced the high- dimensional feature space to two principal components while preserving more than 97% of the total variance, thereby enabling efficient visualization and robust feature extraction for subsequent learning algorithms. For radio noise monitoring and interference management across various urban areas in South Korea, this study conducted a comparison and simulation of the performance of well–known unsupervised machine learning algorithms. Although the analysis was limited in terms of the measurement data and the applied unsupervised learning methods, the results indicated that the DBSCAN method was more effective than the Isolation Forest in detecting and capturing anomalies, suggesting its potential applicability in future related research.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Performance Evaluation of Low-Noise Amplers via Generalized Polynomial Chaos Expansion-Based Surrogate Model
authors: Hoyeon Shin, Taeyeong Kim, Jiyong Chung, Moon-Kyu Cho, Songnam Hong, Ickhyun Song
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Statistical performance analysis of low-noise amplifiers (LNA) under process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) variations and device mismatches is crucial for ensuring design robustness. Unfortunately, traditional Monte Carlo (MC) analysis is often computationally prohibitive for complex <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{R F}$</tex> circuits. In this work, a generalized polynomial chaos expansion (gPCE) model is constructed as a surrogate model from a limited set of circuit simulations to approximate a comprehensive figure-of-merit (FoM). The results demonstrate that the third-order gPCE model achieves high predictive accuracy, confirmed by a high coefficient of determination <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}} = \text{0. 9 2 5})$</tex> and a low root mean squared error (RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.007$</tex>). In addition, the proposed model enables the extraction of these statistical moments and tail-risk metrics over 26 times faster than the benchmark MC simulation.

title: Improving the Accuracy of Cognitive Diagnosis with Integration of Online Handwriting Data
authors: Xinqi Yuan, Taiki Furukawa, Kimihiko Miyazaki, Masashi Kudo, Hayato Yamana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The increasing use of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) devices in educational environments has emphasized the value of “tailor-made education,” which provides optimized learning based on each student’s understanding and learning status. Cognitive diagnosis offers a promising approach by estimating students’ knowledge proficiency in specific skills and concepts. However, previous cognitive diagnosis models (CDMs) rely on responses that contain noises, such as careless mistakes and answers by guessing, thereby introducing noise into the model. This paper proposes CWNeuralCDM, a noise-resilient Neural Cognitive Diagnosis Model that incorporates students’ confidence level of each response. We estimate the answer confidence by using students’ online handwriting data, i.e., strokes, integrating response reliability based on the predicted answer confidence into the cognitive diagnosis model. Our experimental evaluation with 67 university student subjects on mathematical skills confirmed that the proposed method reduced RMSE from 0.3167 to 0.3153 and MAE from 0.2163 to 0.2107 with $\mathrm{p}\lt0.05$ when predicting students’ scores compared to without confidence estimation.

title: Real-Time Personalized Feedback Generation System for College English Writing Based on GPT-4 and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Ruoyu Wang, Jing Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Providing effective, personalized feedback on student writing remains a significant challenge in English academic writing instruction, particularly for non-native speakers. Traditional manual feedback is labor-intensive and difficult to scale, while existing automated writing evaluation systems often generate generic suggestions that fail to address individual learners' diverse proficiency levels and error patterns. This paper presents a novel AI-assisted writing feedback system that integrates GPT-4 with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) reinforcement learning to deliver personalized, pedagogically sound guidance. Our system constructs detailed student profiles capturing proficiency levels, error patterns, and learning preferences, which are injected into carefully engineered multidimensional prompts covering content, structure, language, and logic dimensions. The PPO algorithm continuously optimizes feedback quality by learning from human expert evaluations and student revision outcomes through a reward function balancing specificity, constructiveness, and actionability. We conducted a randomized controlled trial with 300 undergraduate students from three universities, comparing our approach against human instructor feedback and vanilla GPT-4 baselines. Experimental results demonstrate that our system achieves 32.5% improvement in essay quality, significantly outperforming human feedback (18.9%) and generic GPT-4 (17.1%), with p<0.001 statistical significance. Student satisfaction ratings reached 4.3/5.0, with particular strengths in feedback specificity (4.5/5.0) and actionability (4.1/5.0). Additionally, the system reduced instructor workload by 65% while maintaining high-quality oversight. Ablation studies confirm that both personalization and reinforcement learning components contribute substantially to overall performance, with their combination yielding synergistic effects. This work establishes a generalizable framework for applying large language models to educational contexts through personalization and continuous learning, offering a scalable solution to individualized writing instruction in resourceconstrained settings.

title: Decentralized Fraud Detection in Telecom Networks via Graph Theory and Blockchain Technology
authors: Bipin B
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Telecom fraud is one of the major challenges facing the industry, which incurs billions of dollars annually and breaks trust between service providers and their customers. Detection systems are typically centralized, opaque, and cannot scale with changing tactics. On the other hand, machine learning-based approaches are powerful but opaque and resource-intensive. This paper presents a novel hybrid framework that applies graph theory and blockchain technology to overcome these challenges. The framework models telecom interactions as a graph and uses deterministic graph-theoretic algorithms to detect fraudulent patterns such as call spamming, fraud rings, and anomalous behaviors. For transparency and tamper-proof accountability, detected frauds are immutably logged onto a Layer 2 blockchain, allowing for scalability and cost-efficiency. A private blockchain layer enables secure data sharing among telecom providers without compromising subscriber privacy. Experiments show how such a framework can effectively detect fraud, maintaining high accuracy while being interpretable and scalable. Such a lightweight, transparent, collaborative alternative can emerge as a solution against the ever-evolving problem of telecom fraud in comparison to other solutions.

title: Generative High-Magnification Image Synthesis for EUV Mask Inspection
authors: Hyejin S. Kim, Seongjin Choi
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes a mask inspection image enhancement method based on the pix2pix architecture to synthesize high-magnification images from low-magnification images of EUV semiconductor pattern masks. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work leveraging generative models to transform low-magnification EUV mask pattern images into their high-magnification equivalents. The proposed method improves defect detection accuracy while reducing the inspection costs associated with high-resolution imaging.

title: Application of Coordinated Optimization Technology for New Energy Station-Level Control Systems Under Power Grid Faults
authors: Jiehong Xu, Xuelei Fang, Chuan Yu, Jie Huang, Ning Zhang, Yue Sun, Heming Zhang, Xiaowan Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: In the context of a high proportion of new energy being connected to the grid, grid faults are prone to cause instability problems in the control systems at the field and station levels of new energy. To address this problem, this paper proposes a coordinated optimization control strategy with multi-strategy collaboration. Firstly, the paper establishes a plant-level control system architecture that captures the dynamic characteristics of new energy units and analyzes the electromagnetic transient characteristics of new energy plants under grid faults. Subsequently, it proposes a voltage/frequency coordinated control strategy based on the Model Predictive Control (MPC) algorithm, along with a power emergency regulation strategy that considers operational constraints. Finally, system simulations demonstrate that the proposed strategy reduces the voltage recovery time during faults to 320 ms and decreases the frequency deviation to 0.45, providing an effective solution for the safe and stable operation of power systems.

title: Federated Anomaly Detection and Mitigation for EV Charging Forecasting Under Cyberattacks
authors: Oluleke Babayomi, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Electric Vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure faces escalating cybersecurity threats that can severely compromise operational efficiency and grid stability. Existing forecasting techniques are limited by the lack of combined robust anomaly mitigation solutions and data privacy preservation. Therefore, this paper addresses these challenges by proposing a novel anomaly-resilient federated learning framework that simultaneously preserves data privacy, detects cyber-attacks, and maintains trustworthy demand prediction accuracy under adversarial conditions. The proposed framework integrates three key innovations: LSTM autoencoder-based distributed anomaly detection deployed at each federated client, interpolation-based anomalous data mitigation to preserve temporal continuity, and federated Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks that enable collaborative learning without centralized data aggregation. The framework is validated on real-world EV charging infrastructure datasets combined with real-world DDoS attack datasets, providing robust validation of the proposed approach under realistic threat scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that the federated approach achieves superior performance compared to centralized models, with 15.2% improvement in R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> accuracy while maintaining data locality. The integrated cyber-attack detection and mitigation system produces trustworthy datasets that enhance prediction reliability, recovering 47.9% of attack-induced performance degradation while maintaining exceptional precision (91.3%) and minimal false positive rates (1.21%). The proposed architecture enables enhanced EV infrastructure planning, privacy-preserving collaborative forecasting, cybersecurity resilience, and rapid recovery from malicious threats across distributed charging networks.

title: Performance Analysis and Selective Retransmission Optimization For Fragmented Post-Quantum IKEv2
authors: Xuejie He, Lei Han, Ziming Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: As quantum computing advances, migrating Internet Key Exchange version 2 (IKEv2) to the scenario of post-quantum cryptography (PQC) is critical for protecting IPsec VPNs. The current solution standardized by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) introduces IKE_INTERMEDIATE exchanges with fragmentation. However, its inherent reliance on a full-message retransmission model causes a severe performance issue in lossy networks. While previous research has quantified this exponential overhead, it has not resolved the underlying conflict between fragmented transmission and full-message retransmission. To address this inefficiency, this paper proposes a lightweight, cache-based selective retransmission mechanism using bitmap acknowledgments. We construct a theoretical model to reveal the root cause of the standard scheme’s overhead and design our backward-compatible solution. A prototype is then implemented and validated on the strongSwan platform. Results demonstrate that our mechanism reduces additional transmission overhead by over 60% under lossy conditions. This work provides a critical optimization for deploying post-quantum protocols in realworld environments, enabling the practical application of large-payload PQC algorithms.

title: Chipkill-Level ECC Using 4-Bit Symbol Reed-Solomon Codes for DDR5 DRAM
authors: Taeuk Ha, Gyuri Kim, Chanki Kim, Sang-Hyo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a DRAM Error Correction Code (ECC) providing chipkill-level protection for x4 DDR5 DIMMs using 4-bit symbol Reed-Solomon (RS) codes. Since ECC was introduced to address increasing DRAM error rates caused by technology scaling, RS codes have been widely employed in various chipkill ECC solutions because of their robust burst error correction capability. Due to the limited codeword length of 4-bit symbol RS codes and mismatches with DDR4 DIMM configurations, 8-bit symbol RS codes have traditionally been preferred. However, the sub-channel configuration of DDR5 DIMMs is well-suited for 4-bit symbol RS codes, offering advantages such as reduced computational complexity and smaller lookup table (LUT) sizes owing to the decreased Galois field size. We propose a DRAM ECC scheme based on (10,8) 4-bit symbol RS codes and present comparative results evaluating its error correction and detection capabilities against existing ECC methods.

title: ‘Self-Supervised Learning for Natural Language Understanding’
authors: Rahul Modak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This research explores the evolution and efficacy of self-supervised learning (SSL) approaches in natural language understanding (NLU) tasks. We investigate how pre-training objectives and architectural considerations influence downstream performance across multiple benchmarks. Our experimental analysis compares contrastive, generative, and hybrid self-supervised paradigms on eight NLU tasks, revealing that multi-task self-supervised strategies outperform single-objective approaches by an average of 4.3%. We introduce a novel adaptive masking strategy that dynamically adjusts masking patterns based on semantic importance, achieving a 2.7% improvement over static masking approaches. Further, we demonstrate that self-supervised pre-training enables models to achieve competitive performance with 60% less labeled data on classification tasks. Our findings suggest that the integration of multiple complementary self-supervision signals and task-specific fine-tuning strategies offers the most promising direction for advancing NLU capabilities while reducing reliance on human annotation.

title: InclusiVRity: Exploring the use and Needs for Virtual Reality in Education for Neurodiversity
authors: Estella Oncins, Aikaterini Tsaousi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Immersive environments have the potential to revolutionize education by enhancing motivation and enriching learning experiences. Recent research suggests that VR-based experiences can be particularly beneficial for neurodiverse students, aiding their social integration and skill-building. Still, the specific applications of VR solutions to address defined educational needs remain unexplored. This paper presents the results of an online survey conducted among 119 teaching professionals and supporters of neurodiverse students to identify the use, needs and interest about the introduction of VR technologies and tools in their teaching and supporting practices in different countries.

title: Development of News Classification Model Using Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (Bert) with Interpretability Analysis Based on Explainable Artificial Intelligence (Xai)
authors: I Gede Maha Putra, Raden Budiarto Hadiprakoso, Stefanus Santori Zen, Rheva Anindya Wijayanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: This study presents the development of an intelligent automated news classification system that uses Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) optimized for Bahasa Indonesia. The research compares three BERT based models, namely IndoBERT, IndoSBERT, and IndoBERTweet, by evaluating their performance through accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score metrics. To improve interpretability and transparency, Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) is applied using the Local Interpretable Model Agnostic Explanations (LIME) method. LIME identifies influential words in text classification and provides insight into the model's decision-making process, which increases user trust. The system is implemented with a Flask based REST API that allows integration into Agency X operational systems for automatic content monitoring and information management. Experimental results show that the IndoBERT model achieves the highest performance with a micro accuracy of 97.04 percent and a micro F1 score of 96.91 percent, surpassing traditional machine learning models and previous BERT studies. LIME also visualizes key features that influence prediction results, making the model more interpretable for end users. The deployed API significantly improves classification efficiency compared to manual labeling. Overall, this research contributes to creating transparent, reliable, and efficient AI based solutions for automated news classification and national information security.

title: Adaptive Decoding of Turbo Product Codes Using Soft Information
authors: Jae-Yong Son
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes two adaptive Chase decoding algorithms for turbo product codes (TPCs) in order to improve the trade-off between error-correcting performance and decoding complexity. The key idea is to reduce the number of test sequences (TSs) in the Chase algorithm by analyzing the soft information for each row or column codeword. The first proposed algorithm utilizes the entropy of the soft decoder input vector: if the entropy of a row or column vector is below a predefined threshold, it is assumed that the decoder input vector is sufficiently reliable, and the number of least reliable bit (LRB) positions used in the Chase algorithm is reduced. The second algorithm uses a confidence-ratio metric, defined as the proportion of decoder input values whose absolute magnitude is below a certain threshold. If the confidence ratio is sufficiently low, the number of LRB positions is similarly reduced. Both algorithms can be combined with the existing syndrome-based decoding algorithm, where error-free hard-decision vectors are detected and excluded from Chase decoding. Simulation results show that the proposed algorithms achieve comparable bit error rate (BER) performance to conventional Chase-based TPCs while fairly reducing decoding complexity. In particular, when combined with the syndrome-based decoding algorithm, the total number of decoding attempts is further reduced by approximately 10% beyond what is achieved by the syndrome-based decoder alone, without any performance degradation.

title: A Three-Level Inverting Buck Converter with 5μs Response Time and 20mV Output Ripple for Micro-Led Displays
authors: Gang Liu, Wuxiao Dong, Ruidong Li, Guoqing Li, Junmin Jiang, Xun Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a three-level inverting buck (3LIB) converter to generate a negative voltage supply for microLED display applications. The proposed architecture integrates a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-1 \times$</tex> switched-capacitor (SC) converter with a three-level buck topology, achieving a voltage conversion ratio (VCR) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-D$</tex> with continuous output current, significantly reduced inductor current ripple, and output voltage ripple. The transfer function of the proposed 3L-IB converter is similar to a buck converter, so simple PWM control and compensation can be adopted to achieve fast transient response. The proposed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{\text{CF}}$</tex> calibration scheme ensures the flying capacitor's voltage stability. Simulated results show that the converter achieves a peak efficiency of 92.24 %, a fast transient response time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>, and an output voltage ripple as low as 20 mV across a wide load range. These characteristics make the proposed 3L-IB suitable for compact, high-performance negative power supply systems in micro-LED displays.

title: WMSM: An Efficient Real-Time Framework for Hebrew Sign Language Recognition and Sentence-Level Translation
authors: Eyal Pasha, Galit Haim
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: This paper introduces WMSM (Word Model, Sentence Mechanism), an innovative deep learning approach for real-time Hebrew Sign Language (HSL) recognition, optimized for mobile devices. WMSM features a novel word-level recognition model combined with a sentence-level prediction mechanism, offering an efficient alternative to traditional sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) frameworks.
