Sign language recognition presents significant challenges, including limited dataset diversity, overfitting, and the difficulty of generalizing across different signers with varying signing styles. These issues are compounded by computational constraints, particularly when deploying models on mobile devices. To address these challenges, the paper details an augmentation pipeline that artificially expands the dataset, enhancing variability and enabling the model to generalize more effectively. Additionally, computational challenges such as packet loss and processing delays were mitigated through optimized model efficiency and the use of CPU-based workflows. The system demonstrates robust translation capabilities, producing coherent sentence-level outputs even under challenging conditions. This approach sets a new benchmark for efficient, high-performance real-time sign language recognition, addressing key challenges in dataset limitations, generalization, and mobile deployment.

title: Pseudo-Random Number Generation Based on Quantum Kicked Rotor Dynamics
authors: Taukhid W. Broto, Supriadi Rustad, Ahmad Zainul Fanani, Sri Winarno, De Rosal Ignatius Moses Setiadi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: Generating high-quality random numbers is essential for cryptography, statistical simulations, and cybersecurity. While pseudo-random number generators (PRNGs) are computationally efficient, their deterministic nature introduces potential security vulnerabilities. Recent research has explored chaotic systems as entropy sources due to their sensitivity to initial conditions-a key property for randomness generation. An emerging direction involves leveraging chaos in quantum systems. This paper proposes a quantum-inspired PRNG based on the Quantum Kicked Rotor (QKR), a well-known model in quantum chaos exhibiting complex dynamics such as dynamical localization. The method simulates the QKR and extracts pseudo-random sequences through momentum basis measurements. The generated sequences are evaluated for statistical quality, including the NIST 800-22 standard, which passed all 15 test. The sequences exhibit strong non-periodicity, a critical property for secure cryptographic applications. The proposed approach combines the unpredictability of quantum chaos with the scalability of classical simulation, offering a practical and efficient alternative for secure random number generation.

title: A Robust Hybrid Image Watermarking Scheme Using DWT, DCT, and QR Decomposition based on Spread Spectrum
authors: Muhammad Farhan Attila, Gelar Budiman, Ledya Novamizanti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: Digital content protection faces the critical challenge of balancing robustness against attacks with imperceptibility. To address this, we propose a novel hybrid watermarking scheme integrating Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) for multi-resolution analysis, Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) for frequency-domain embedding, QR decomposition for numerical stability, and Spread Spectrum (SS) for signal modulation. Our method achieves PSNR more than 30 dB across test images with BER as low as 0.0010 under JPEG compression, outperforming existing techniques in compression resilience. The layered approach maintains content fidelity while resisting common attacks, validated through rigorous testing on standard images. This framework offers significant improvements for applications requiring both security and quality preservation.

title: Improving Waste Classification with Auxiliary Fourier Features and GroupMamba Networks
authors: Yu-Ting Chen, Jocelyn Liao, Liang-Ying Ke, Chih-Hsien Hsia
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: As urbanization intensifies and lifestyles evolve, the volume of municipal solid waste continues to increase annually, placing a heavy burden on the environment. Effective waste classification not only facilitates resource recycling and reduces pressure on landfills but also constitutes a critical element in achieving sustainable development and building smart cities. Traditional automatic waste-sorting methods primarily rely on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image feature extraction; however, CNNs are limited in modeling long-range dependencies (LRD) and are sensitive to data shifts and image degradation, often leading to decreased classification accuracy. To address these issues, this study proposes an automatic waste classification model that integrates the GroupMamba architecture with an auxiliary Fourier augmentation (AFA) technique. Leveraging a state-space model (SSM) and grouped channel attention, the proposed model effectively captures LRD features and cross-channel contextual information, thereby enhancing its representational capacity. In addition, AFA introduces stochastic perturbations in the frequency domain to emulate real-world noise and blur, improving the model's robustness to image variations and unseen samples. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a classification accuracy of 96.88 % on the public TrashNet dataset, outperforming existing approaches and highlighting its potential for applications in smart environments and automated waste-management systems.

title: Generating Question-Answer Pairs for Interviewing Software Engineering using LLMs
authors: Kundjanasith Thonglek, Suphanat Wisitkatanyuchai
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Software engineering interviews require evaluating candidates across a broad range of technical concepts, problem-solving abilities, and coding skills. Traditionally, interviewers manually craft question-answer pairs, a process that is time-consuming, inconsistent, and prone to bias. Recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) offer an opportunity to automate and enhance this process by generating high-quality, structured question-answer pairs. This study presents a systematic approach to generating interview questions using LLMs, ensuring comprehensive coverage of software engineering domains and difficulty levels. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we compare the generated dataset with an existing manually curated dataset using BLEU scores, semantic similarity analysis, and t-SNE visualization. Our results indicate that the proposed dataset maintains domain relevance while significantly improving the semantic coherence and consistency of question-answer pairs across all categories and difficulty levels. We assess the impact of the dataset on classification tasks: training a category classification model on our dataset improves accuracy from 14.95% to 53.21%, while training a difficulty level classifier increases accuracy from 31.02% to 58.64%, demonstrating the enhanced structure and quality of the generated questions. By leveraging AI-driven methodologies, this study contributes to the evolution of structured, scalable, and unbiased software engineering assessments, ultimately enhancing the hiring process for both candidates and organizations.

title: GraphSAGE-Based SDN Anomaly Detection Using GNN
authors: Om Rajendra Bhamre, Anup Ingle, Ketki P. Kshirsagar, Gauri Ghule, Srinivas Chippalkatti, Vijay M. Marathe
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Anomaly detection in Software-Defined Networking (SDN) is critical for ensuring network security and performance, given its centralized control architecture. This paper proposes GraphSAGE-SDN-AD, a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based model leveraging GraphSAGE, to detect anomalies by exploiting SDN's topological structure. Evaluated on the SDN dataset, the model achieves an F1-score of0.92, surpassing baselines such as Graph Attention Networks (GAT), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Deep Neural Networks (DNN). With a training time of approximately 2 hours and an inference time of 10 ms per graph on an NVIDIA RTX 3090, GraphSAGE-SDNAD demonstrates potential for real-time SDN applications. The findings match up with the latest progress in Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), pointing toward future improvements like dynamic GNNs and federated learning to boost scalability and protect privacy better.

title: Spatio-Temporal Disease Forecasting Using SGCN-TGRU with Mobility Integration
authors: Joshika Annie Jose, Kumudha Raimond
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of infectious disease outbreaks is essential for effective public health response but remains difficult due to complex spatial diffusion and temporal dynamics influenced by human mobility. This paper presents a SpatioTemporal Graph Convolutional Network with Gated Recurrent Units (SGCN-TGRU) for outbreak forecasting. The model integrates Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to capture spatial correlations across districts and Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) to model temporal progression. Unlike traditional Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (T-GCN) architectures with static spatial graphs, SGCN-TGRU employs dynamic edge weighting based on mobility patterns and incorporates demographic and density features to enhance spatial sensitivity. Using real-world outbreak data from India (2019-2025) enriched with census and mobility information, the framework outperforms non-spatial baselines. Evaluation using MAE, RMSE, and hotspotdetection metrics shows significant gains in predictive accuracy. The results demonstrate that fusing mobility-driven spatial connectivity with temporal learning improves forecasting reliability and provides actionable insights for proactive epidemic control.

title: Multi Disease Identification in Tomato Plant using CNN and SVM
authors: Shiva Nandan, Shilpa Srivastava, Vandana Mehndiratta, Ritu Agarwal, Meenu Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Tomato is a major trade crop; it is among the most widely consumed crops in daily life. Crop diseases reduce not only the quality of the crops but also their amount of production, thus, detection and identification of the specific diseases is of great importance. Diseases like the Mosaic virus, Bacterial Spot, and Yellow Leaf Curl Virus infect the tomato plant. The advanced detection and classification techniques are mainly employed in the diagnosis of these diseases. This helps in informing the farmers about the types of diseases that attack their crops. In this study, independent CNN and SVM classifiers built to classify the diseases. The CNN model extracts feature such as color and leaf edges from input images- then, it proceeds to classification. For SVM, PCA is applied for feature reduction in order to enhance performance and accuracy before classification. A dataset sourced from plant village has been utilized to train the network CNN and SVM. The proposed neural network model has been applied to categorize 4 types of tomato leaf conditions: one healthy and three diseased types of tomato leaves. The results show that the SVM approach achieves a classification accuracy of 94.33%, whereas the CNN model has slightly higher accuracy of 95.17%.

title: Towards MCQ Generation to Evaluate K-12 Students: Selecting the Effective Modules in Limited Dataset Tuning for LLMs
authors: Viet Anh Nguyen, Tran Minh Duc, Nguyen Viet Trung, Nguyen Thi Anh Tuyet, Pham Minh Duc, Vu Bao Chau
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: The automatic generation of multiple-choice questions (MCQs) from textbook content has become an effective method to meet the requirements of educational curricula, significantly supporting both teachers and learners. In this case study, we focus on utilizing fine-tuned language models to create MCQs tests to assist in the review and assessment of Vietnamese students’ abilities. We have developed a specialized dataset, which includes a large collection of multiple-choice questions and corresponding contexts, based on the new textbooks authorized by the Ministry of Education and Training. Currently, very few models can generate accurate and educationally meaningful questions, especially for Vietnamese-a less commonly used language with a complex structure. To address this challenge, we concentrate on methods tailored to the specific problem: the training dataset is meticulously designed to align with both the thematic scope and the depth of knowledge in the educational curriculum, while training focuses on appropriate layers within the language model. Our results show that the proposed model achieves over 70% performance in generating questions at the comprehension and basic application levels on the test set. This result not only highlights the significant potential of this approach in supporting education but also provides a valuable resource for future research. Moreover, the dataset we introduce will make a substantial contribution to the development of learning and assessment tools, helping both learners and teachers access tests that closely align with textbook content.

title: Improving Threat Intelligence in Healthcare Through a High Interaction DICOM Honeypot
authors: Dendi Risman Saputra, Charles Lim, Kalpin Erlangga Silaen
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The digitalization of healthcare has enhanced operational efficiency while expanding the cyberattack surface, particularly within medical imaging systems that rely on the DICOM protocol. Conventional security mechanisms often struggle to analyze DICOM traffic, while the earlier version of DICOMpot offered only limited interaction and raw logging, which is insufficient for capturing complex attacker behaviors. This research introduces DICOMpot v2.0, a high-interaction honeypot designed for medical imaging networks, advancing both realism and intelligence. The system supports additional core DICOM operations, enriches captured data with external threat intelligence, and integrates a decoy PACS server to emulate production-like environments. Deployed in a controlled virtual environment, the honeypot combined simulated attacks with exposure to real-world traffic. The deployment produced valuable interaction logs that were successfully enriched with threat intelligence. Compared to its predecessor, the updated version captured more detailed activity, improved attacker engagement, and generated structured insights, offering a stronger foundation for securing medical imaging infrastructures.

title: PEAT: A Scalable LLM-Powered Tutoring System with Real-Time Adaptation and Explainable Feedback for Diverse Learners
authors: Suhail T, K. Rajakumari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The Personalized tutoring systems have always tried to closely mimic tutoring by human beings in computerbased environments, but most fall short due to low levels of adaptability, opaque feedback, and difficulty scaling. In response to these issues, PEAT proposes a tutoring system based on LLMs that is scalable, provides real-time adaptive feedback and instruction that is personalized and explainable to various learners. It is a hybrid between large language model generation and reinforcement learning to dynamically adjust the prompts, examine learner profiles, and provide multi-layered feedback. On the large-scale datasets, PEAT scored up to 96.2 % and feedback explainability was higher than 0.95, and increased learner engagement by 61.4 % among different levels of education. It was also shown that the system re-adjusted quickly within less than 130 ms and exhibited great accuracy to reach correction rates of multi-step problems. Development Using EduSim++, PEAT was found to be much more adaptable, transparent, and responsive than the earlier systems. These findings make PEAT a next-generation technology that can democratize intelligent tutoring to become inclusive, real-time time and effective education delivery.

title: Enhancing Recommender Systems with Contextual Awareness Using Hybrid Filtering and Spark-Based Scalability
authors: Md Mahtab Alam, Mumtaz Ahmed
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Recommendation systems have become an integral component of many online services, helping users discover relevant products, media, and content. However, traditional recommendation techniques often overlook the impact of contextual information on user preferences. This research presents a context-aware recommendation framework that incorporates contextual variables using a hybrid approach, blending collaborative filtering and machine learning-based regression methods. Implemented in a scalable Apache Spark environment, our model employs pre-filtering based on contextual data and combines it with user-item interaction modeling through the Surprise library. Evaluation in multiple metrics, including Precision@K, Recall@K, NDCG, and RMSE, demonstrates that incorporating context significantly enhances the quality of recommendations.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization of Explainable AI Models Under Resource Constraints in Embedded Systems
authors: Jagjit Singh Dhatterwal, Dipesh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The use of Explainable AI (XAI) models on resource-limited embedded systems is a serious problem, where understandability, efficiency, and performance have to be selected. In this paper, a multi-objective optimization framework to address XAI model optimization under rigorous memory, computation, and latency constraints is suggested. We investigate what kinds of trade-offs exist between model performance, explainability, and budgetary resource cost, relying on such methods as model pruning, quantization, and Pareto-optimal model selection. Our implementation method can be used to make AI models both interpretable and embedded to satisfy the high requirements of the hardware system (e.g., ARM Cortex, Raspberry Pi). We compare our framework to benchmark datasets via state of art explainable models (e.g., decision trees, rule-based systems and lightweight attention-based neural networks). The experimental evidence shows that optimization strategy can result in up to 30% memory footprint and 40% improved inference times compared to the baseline with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>90 {\%}$</tex> of baseline explainability metrics preserved. The viability of our approach is also confirmed by a case study on real-time embedded deployment. The results emphasize that the training of models based on model compression and explainability-aware optimization can be combined, which allows achieving full transparency and efficiency of AI work in edge processing. The project forms a base on which trustworthy, low-latency XAI models could be used in real-world applications like autonomous systems, medical diagnostics, and Industrial IoT.

title: Bipolar Prediction Multimodal Network: A Machine Learning Model for Euthymic Bipolar Disorder Disease
authors: Santosh Rani, Neeraj Mangla
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The early identification of Euthymic Bipolar Disorder (BD) is extremely important to gain quick intervention and better patient outcomes, but it is still a difficult task because of the very slight symptoms exhibited during the euthymic phase. The paper puts forth the Bipolar Prediction Multimodal Network (BPMNet), which is an efficient Machine Learning (ML) framework that employs clinical, physiological, and behavioral data for the exact BD prediction. BPM-Net merges a Clinical Encoder for structured health records with a Time-Series Encoder for behavioral patterns, along with a Fusion Layer that brings together multimodal features for final classification. BPM-Net, after being trained on a wide-ranging dataset made up of Electronic Health Records (EHRs) and survey responses, attained 98.7% accuracy, and thus surpassed traditional models like Logistic Regression (LR), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Recurrent Neural Network (RNN). The results reveal that BPM-Net can be beneficial in the early BD diagnosis, offer support to personalized treatment, and make continuous monitoring easier. This study highlights the importance of multimodal ML in the psychiatric diagnostics and clinical decision-making area transformation.

title: Harmonic Reduction Using Periodic/Aperiodic Separation Filter for Surface-EMG-Based Force Estimation with Power Line Interference
authors: Daiki Sodenaga, Hisayoshi Muramatsu, Seiichiro Katsura
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Power-line interference can cause electronic devices to malfunction or exhibit degraded performance, particularly in communication and precision measurement systems. In force estimation using surface electromyography (sEMG), such interference should be removed because its 50/60 Hz components and their harmonics overlap with the sEMG spectrum and deteriorate estimation accuracy. Conventional studies have typically employed notch filters or comb filters to eliminate this interference. However, notch filters suppress only the fundamental frequency and its neighboring components, while comb filters can remove harmonic components but provide insufficient harmonic attenuation and require careful adjustment of notch widths due to frequency drift. Moreover, the influence of notch width on force estimation has not been discussed in prior studies. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a force estimation method that removes power line interference with a wide notch width. In particular, a periodic/aperiodic separation filterwas applied to remove a PLI with the wide notch width. It enables flexible notch width adjustment based on the separation of quasi-periodic and quasi-aperiodic components, making it suitable for suppressing power line interference and its harmonics. In this study, thumb-tip force was estimated using interference removal, a preprocessing to an sEMG, and a deep neural network. The preprocessing consisted of band-pass filtering, full-wave rectification, and low-pass filtering. The experimental results demonstrated that the proposed force estimation method suppresses power line interference and improves force estimation accuracy. The suitable notch width was 24.0 Hz in this experiment.

title:
PV-KRRT
                    <sup>*</sup>
                    : Adaptive Classification Sampling and Curvature Constrained Motion Planning for Quadrotor MAVs
authors: Tinghang Ji, Baoquan Li, Hai Zhu, Wuxi Shi, Xuebo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In the article, a position-verified (PV) kinodynamic planning method is proposed based on the extended kinodynamic rapid-exploration random tree (KRRT<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">*</sup>) algorithm. The aim is enabling microaerial vehicles (MAVs) to generate efficient and feasible motion trajectories in unknown complex environments. An initial trajectory is generated first for analyzing obstacles between start and end points. Then, a sampling strategy with adaptive obstacle classification is designed, and is integrated into the KRRT<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">*</sup> method for verifying position of sampling nodes. In collision-prone regions, cylindrical inflated spaces are constructed, so as to improve distribution of the sampling nodes. During the rewiring process, redundant sampling nodes and solving unnecessary boundary value problem (BVP) are eliminated to generate high quality front-end trajectories. Moreover, a trajectory curvature penalty term is designed and combined with penalty terms of trajectory smoothness and path topology deviation, and the quadratic programming (QP) model is constructed. Finally, comparative simulations and experiments are conducted to verify effectiveness and flexibility of the proposed method.

title: FUGC: Benchmarking Semi-Supervised Learning Methods for Cervical Segmentation
authors: Jieyun Bai, Yitong Tang, Zihao Zhou, Mahdi Islam, Musarrat Tabassum, Enrique Almar-Munoz, Hongyu Liu, Hui Meng, Nianjiang Lv, Bo Deng, Yu Chen, Zilun Peng, Yusong Xiao, Li Xiao, Nam-Khanh Tran, Dac-Phu Phan-Le, Hai-Dang Nguyen, Xiao Liu, Jiale Hu, Mingxu Huang, Jitao Liang, Chaolu Feng, Xuezhi Zhang, Lyuyang Tong, Bo Du, Ha-Hieu Pham, Thanh-Huy Nguyen, Min Xu, Juntao Jiang, Jiangning Zhang, Yong Liu, Md. Kamrul Hasan, Jie Gan, Zhuonan Liang, Weidong Cai, Yuxin Huang, Gongning Luo, Mohammad Yaqub, Karim Lekadir
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Accurate segmentation of cervical structures in transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is critical for assessing the risk of spontaneous preterm birth (PTB), yet the scarcity of labeled data limits the performance of supervised learning approaches. This paper introduces the Fetal Ultrasound Grand Challenge (FUGC), the first benchmark for semi-supervised learning in cervical segmentation, hosted at ISBI 2025. FUGC provides a dataset of 890 TVS images, including 500 training images, 90 validation images, and 300 test images. Methods were evaluated using the Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC), Hausdorff Distance (HD), and runtime (RT), with a weighted combination of 0.4/0.4/0.2. The challenge attracted 10 teams with 82 participants submitting innovative solutions. The best-performing methods for each individual metric achieved 90.26% mDSC, 38.88 mHD, and 32.85 ms RT, respectively. FUGC establishes a standardized benchmark for cervical segmentation, demonstrates the efficacy of semi-supervised methods with limited labeled data, and provides a foundation for AI-assisted clinical PTB risk assessment.

title: CaASR: A Causal Lens for Refining Temporal Action Segmentation_supp1-3664960.pdf
authors: Xinyu Yang
publish: N/A
abstract: Temporal Action Segmentation (TAS) is fundamental to video understanding, aiming to recognize and segment actions within untrimmed videos. While over-segmentation errors have received considerable attention, the equally critical issue of out of-context errors stemming from the neglect of implicit causal relationships between actions remains under-explored. However, constraining these unknown causal relationships at the frame level—including identifying causal links and strengths—presents a significant challenge, leading to notable research gaps. To tackle these challenges, we define a Temporal Action Causal Model (TACM) for the TAS task as declarative guidance, which efficiently injects the causal relationship between actions into frame variables in a generated manner. To this end, we propose the Causal Action Segmentation Refiner (CaASR), a refinement framework designed to mitigate out-of-context errors in segmentation results of backbone models. By reconstructing the causal generation process of post-segmentation frame variables, CaASR constrains causal relationships between actions and ensures the reliability of generated causal relationships. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CaASR significantly enhances both segmentation performance and interpretability across various backbone models, including state-of-the-art methods.

title: Accelerating Update Broadcasts Over LoRaWAN Downlink via D2D Cooperation
authors: Anshika Singh, Siddhartha S. Borkotoky
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Broadcast distribution of updates (e.g., security patches, machine learning models) from a server to end devices (EDs) is a critical requirement in the Internet of Things (IoT). In this article, we consider the problem of reliable over-the-air broadcast of updates in Long Range Wide Area Networks (LoRaWANs). Existing broadcast techniques for LoRaWANs suffer from long delivery delays due to low data rates and duty-cycle constraints. We address this problem by proposing a device-level cooperative mechanism, in which updated EDs broadcast a few update fragments to accelerate delivery to their neighbors. We demonstrate large reductions in the delivery time compared with conventional methods. For instance, in a 400-node network spanning 1 km radius and operating at 1% duty-cycle, the proposed scheme reduces the time required to deliver a 10 kB update to an ED at the network’s edge from 42 h to 45 min. The proposed solution thus provides a pathway toward improved security and efficient realization of edge intelligence in LoRaWAN IoT.

title: Hybrid Computing of Decentralized Applications in Edge Web 3.0: A Scheduling Strategy via Decision Transformer
authors: Zhongqi Miao, Xichun Cai, Lixing Chen, Yang Bai, Hongfu Liu, Zhe Qu, Pan Zhou, and Xinping Guan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Web 3.0-enabled edge computing provides a promising foundation for decentralized application (DApp) deployment. However, optimizing execution modes for interdependent task patterns remains challenging due to high computational overhead and blockchain consensus latency. This paper proposes an elastic hybrid architecture for Web 3.0-Enabled Edge Computing Systems (EDGEWEB3.0) that integrates on-chain and off-chain execution. DApp contracts are modeled as Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) and partitioned into dependent task patterns, enabling a structured decomposition of execution. We formulate a DApp task scheduling problem and introduce the Decision Transformer-based Dependent Scheduling (DTDS) algorithm. DTDS employs masked self-attention to capture DAG dependencies and incorporates regularization terms to enforce constraints on service delays, gas costs, and computing capacity. We implement a real-world Web 3.0 testbed based on Ethereum, Goerli, and zkSync. Experimental results demonstrate that DTDS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in gas costs and service delays, providing a scalable solution for DApp execution in environments.

title: Enabling Indoor Autonomous Vehicle Navigation through HCMI Map Construction Using Spatial Data Cubes
authors: Sang-Su Kim, Hee-Tac Jung, Ji-Yeon Kang, Seung-Jae Lee, Jun-Hee Go
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The development and utilization of indoor spatial information in South Korea have emerged as core national policies for implementing digital twins and smart cities. High-definition (HD) indoor maps are essential for safe and reliable autonomous vehicle navigation. Existing mapping methods, such as 2D occupancy grids and SLAM-based techniques, provide basic localization and path planning but do not fully support machine-centric data structures required for real-time autonomous decision-making. This paper proposes a framework for constructing HD indoor maps from a Human-Computer-Machine Interaction (HCMI) perspective, emphasizing machine-centric data integration, real-time processing, and multi-layer spatial representation. By leveraging a spatial data cube, the proposed approach enables sensor fusion and autonomous computation-optimized mapping, improving decision-making efficiency compared to human-centric maps. Reviewing domestic and international HD indoor mapping trends and policies shows that an HCMI-based approach provides scalable and real-time responsive mapping solutions for South Korean indoor autonomous navigation environments.

title: Hand Gesture Controlled Robot with Ultrasonic Object Detection
authors: Natasha Chauhan, Aryan Amrawanshi, Preeti Verma, Dhandapani Vaithiyanathan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: The paper suggests a positive design of a hand gesture control robot. The system bridges the robot and the human by physical change, like hand tilting. Hand motion is detected by an ADXL355 accelerometer, and the system is controlled by an Arduino Lilypad microcontroller. Rather than using a joystick or buttons, the robot is controlled by hand gestures to move. The system employs wireless communication by sending signals from the hand to the robot via radio frequency (RF). The device can be very beneficial for industrial-grade robotic arms, military operations, and surveillance for physical challenges people.

title: Detection of PUCCH Format 0 and Performance Analysis for 5G NR Systems
authors: Seongjin Ahn, Junhwan Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In 5G New Radio, the physical uplink control channel (PUCCH) format 0 is a reference signal-less PUCCH carrying small uplink control information (UCI) payloads based on sequence selection. The PUCCH format 0 detection involves discontinuous transmission detection and UCI decoding, typically requiring a non-coherent sequence detector at the receiver. In this paper, we propose a detection method of PUCCH format 0 based on a new detection parameter. Through computer simulations, we evaluate the detection performance of the proposed method.

title: NWDAF Implementation: Network Function Load Analytics in 5G Core Network
authors: Quang-Vinh Tran, Tuan-Bach Phan, Quang-Diep Pham
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Multivariate data is prevalent in telecom systems and requires efficient processing to extract actionable insights. Leveraging such data, we developed the NWDAF module with a focus on "Network Function (NF) load analytics" to improve Viettel Group’s network performance. Using operational data from Viettel’s 4G Mobility Management Entity (MME) serving as a proxy for 5G behavior our framework supports real-world analysis and optimization of network functions in next-generation deployments.

title: Evaluating the Effect of Search Strategies in a Hierarchically Decentralized Multi-Robot Task Allocation System
authors: Sujeet Kashid, Ashwin Dharmesh Kumat
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: Efficient exploration is a critical component of Multi-Robot Systems (MRS) deployed in safety-critical domains such as disaster response, planetary mining, and infrastructure inspection. In heterogeneous Multi-Robot Task Allocation (MRTA) systems, the search strategy used for the exploration of resources or targets can significantly influence overall mission performance. This paper investigates the impact of three distinct search strategies, random walk, systematic flower pattern search, and spiral outward search, on the effectiveness of a hierarchically decentralized heterogeneous MRTA system developed in our previous works. Using pyrobosim, a 2D simulation environment, modeled after NASA’s Space Robotics Challenge Phase 2, we evaluated how each search strategy affects key performance metrics including time to resource discovery, auction open times, task completion time, and total travel distance. Our findings show that the choice of search strategy substantially influences the coordination dynamics and mission efficiency. The results inform best practices for the deployment of search behaviors in decentralized robotic teams tasked with exploration, rescue, or resource localization.

title: Adaptive Online Learning. Implementing SEL4C-GPT for the Development of Social Entrepreneurship
authors: José Carlos Vázquez-Parra, Sergio Palomino-Gámez
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Adaptive learning has emerged as a key strategy for enhancing education in digital environments, particularly in the development of complex competencies such as social entrepreneurship. This study presents the implementation of SEL4C-GPT, an artificial intelligence-based model designed to personalize the learning experience of university students in online and hybrid courses. Based on an initial assessment, the platform generates individualized learning pathways, optimizing competency acquisition through microlearning, data analytics, and real-time personalization. The research was conducted with 196 students from Mexico, Chile, Colombia, and Bolivia, analyzing the impact of SEL4C-GPT on four key sub-competencies of social entrepreneurship. The findings indicate a significant improvement in social innovation and financial sustainability, along with variations based on gender and educational context. The technology enabled content and activities to be adapted to specific needs, strengthening engagement and interaction in digital learning platforms. The results highlight the potential of adaptive learning in blended and online models, demonstrating how artificial intelligence facilitates the transition from traditional methodologies to more effective digital formats. The study concludes that automated personalization not only enhances the student experience but also drives the scalability of innovative strategies in higher education, fostering more flexible and inclusive learning environments aligned with the demands of digital-age education.

title: Scalable and High-Performance Number-Theoretic Transform Design for Lattice-Based Cryptography
authors: Hien Nguyen, Quang Dang Truong, Hanho Lee, Tuy Tan Nguyen
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Efficient polynomial multiplication is a key operation in post-quantum cryptography (PQC) and homomorphic encryption (HE), particularly in lattice-based schemes where the number-theoretic transform (NTT) is the main contributor to computational cost. To address performance and efficiency challenges in these applications, this paper presents a scalable and high-performance NTT architecture tailored for practical deployments of PQC schemes and HE workloads. The proposed architecture features a mix of radix-2/4 fully pipelined datapath, a stage-aware modular reduction strategy combining K2RED and Montgomery methods, and a compressed twiddle factor storage that leverages symmetry and data access patterns. These innovations collectively enable high-performance NTT computation with minimized hardware costs. Synthesized on Xilinx UltraScale+ FPGA, the design achieves 3.71 KLUTs × ms for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=2^{14}$</tex>, outperforming its predecessors. This architecture presents a compelling solution for FPGA-based cryptographic accelerators, delivering scalable performance across various transform sizes while adhering to practical deployment constraints.

title: Gesture Control and Eye Tracking for Enhanced Human Computer Interaction Using Hidden Markov Kalman Filtering
authors: B Shaivi Reddy, Erumalla Saiteja, M Sai Architha, Alakuntla Sai Madhav Raj, M.A. Jabbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Human-Computer interaction (HCI) focuses mainly on improving user experience, this can be improved in many ways by using eye tracking, hand gestures, voice recognition and touch interfaces. This paper explores the integration of eye tracking and hand gestures to control the device by doing all cursor movements. Hidden Markov Models (HMM) and Kalman Filtering are used in the model to improve accuracy and responsiveness. HMM is used for blink detection and trigger actions like clicks and locks. Kalman Filtering enhances the cursor stability by reducing the noise in the gestures. The model developed contains lock system for locking the movements which was never used for previous models, this ensures there are no unnecessary movements. These results contribute to future technology in assistive, gaming, virtual and disability environment.

title: Optical Handwritten Exam Answer Recognition using Intensely Learned Model
authors: Watcharaphong Yookwan, Jiranun Sangrueng, Athita Onuean, Annupan Rodtook, Krisana Chinnasarn
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a deep learning-based system for automated recognition and scoring of handwritten exam answers from images captured by smartphones. The proposed method comprises multiple stages, including image dewarping, component classification, landmark localization, and character detection using a Traversed-Line YOLOv11-cls model. To enhance recognition accuracy, the character recognizer is trained on a hybrid dataset combining the EMNIST dataset and real handwritten samples from Burapha University students. Experimental evaluations show that the proposed method significantly outperforms traditional OCR systems such as Tesseract and EasyOCR, achieving a character recognition accuracy of 97.8% and word-level accuracy of 91.3%. The system is capable of processing each exam sheet in under 2.2 seconds, making it suitable for large-scale, real-time assessment scenarios. This approach offers a promising solution for automated grading systems, improving both efficiency and accuracy in educational environments.

title: AI-Driven Crop Yield Prediction with State-Level Customization
authors: Atul Srivastava, Ayush Pandey, Divya Agrahari, Vijay Shankar Sharma
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Emerging Technologies in Computer Engineering: Advances in Computing, Healthcare and Smart Systems (ICETCE)
abstract: Accurate crop yield prediction is essential for agricultural planning, enabling farmers and policymakers to optimize resource al location and risk management. This work develops an AI-driven crop yield prediction model incorporating regional parameters such as seasonal rainfall, evapotranspiration, and soil texture. To enhance predictive accuracy, missing values were imputed using the ARIMA model, and categorical features were encoded using Label Encoding. Various machine learning models were tested, including XGBoost, Random Forest, Extra Trees, and a stacked ensemble of XGBoost and Extra Trees. Out of all the models tested, the Extra Trees algorithm came out on top in terms of prediction accuracy. When checking which features mattered most, it be- came clear that Extra Trees leaned heavily towards the crop type, while the stacked model seemed to spread the importance across more variables. This kind of difference suggests that ensemble models might offer a more rounded view of the factors involved, even if sometimes a single model performs better on its own. These findings show how the choice of model and how much weight each feature carries can really affect the prediction results. With better preprocessing and smarter model selection, this work helps improve how we estimate crop yields — a small but meaningful step toward better agricultural planning and food security.

title: Towards Robust SSH Anomaly Detection: A Deep Learning Comparative Analysis
authors: Md Wira Putra Dananjaya, Ni Luh Putu Ika Candrawengi, I Wayan Aditya Suranata, I Gusti Ngurah Darma Paramartha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: In contemporary network infrastructures, the implementation of Secure Shell (SSH) security measures is of paramount importance. However, the system's vulnerability to sophisticated attacks, including brute force attacks and configuration anomalies, is a matter of concern. The timely identification of these sources of danger is hindered by the abundance of log data and existing class imbalances. In this study, the performance of three sequential deep learning models—Long Short-Term Memory, Gated Recurrent Unit, and 1-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network—for detecting anomalies in SSH logs is evaluated and compared. A synthetic log dataset was created to encompass both normal behavior and various types of attacks. This was preprocessed using temporal feature engineering and examined for class imbalances using class weighting. The evaluation process, which utilizes a dedicated test set, has revealed that all models exhibit a high degree of precision in detecting brute force attacks. The GRU model had the highest F1 score and accuracy. The 1D CNN had the best recall rate for regular traffic but the lowest precision. This study thoroughly compared three deep learning models: LSTM, GRU, and 1D CNN. This benchmarking used a new synthetic SSH log dataset to simulate real-world challenges, like extreme class imbalance and rare configuration anomalies. The analysis shows each model's strengths and weaknesses in this context. This study highlights the challenge of detecting brute-force attacks while minimizing false positives. Current anomaly detection methods are limited when it comes to extremely rare patterns.

title: Application of Domestic Operating Systems in the Field of Electric Power Informatization
authors: Jingyu Li, Qiang Li, Chunyuan Miao, Man Guo, Di Cai, Wei Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: With the increasingly urgent demand for independent and controllable power information construction, the application of domestic operating systems in this field has become a key path to break through foreign technological monopolies. This article focuses on the adaptation of domestic operating systems in the context of power informationization. Through architecture design, technical implementation, and experimental verification, a complete application solution has been constructed. The study first analyzed the current application status and existing bottlenecks of domestically produced operating systems in the field of power informationization in China. Based on this, a hierarchical collaborative full stack localization architecture was designed, covering hardware support layer, operating system core layer, data layer, and application layer, achieving seamless collaboration between software and hardware. We have developed cross platform compatibility technology, real-time task scheduling optimization algorithms, and security configuration monitoring mechanisms to meet the real-time and security requirements of power scenarios, and have completed system deployment through standardized implementation processes. The experimental results show that this scheme outperforms traditional foreign systems in response time, security configuration compliance rate, and full lifecycle cost, verifying the applicability of domestic operating systems in core scenarios such as power monitoring and scheduling. The research provides technical support and practical reference for the localization substitution in the field of power informatization, promoting the construction of an independent and controllable system in the energy industry.

title: A Comparative Study of Channel Hardening Between Fixed-Position and Movable Antennas
authors: Suhwan Jang, Chungyong Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Movable antenna (MA) systems represent a novel technology capable of dynamically reconfiguring antenna positions in space. This flexibility introduces capabilities that are inherently unavailable in conventional fixed-position antenna (FPA) systems. In FPA setups, adverse channel conditions such as deep fading are often unavoidable, leading to sporadic performance degradation. Although multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technology alleviates these effects to some extent using multiple antennas distributed over the space, it still falls short of fully exploiting the spatial diversity available in a continuous domain. In contrast, MA systems can actively avoid unfavorable channel conditions by repositioning antennas to locations with improved channel conditions. From a channel estimation standpoint, the ability to observe diverse channels across different positions enhances the reliability of the estimation process. Consequently, MA systems exhibit stronger channel hardening effects compared to their FPA counterparts. Numerical results confirm that MA architectures significantly improve channel hardening performance.

title: Applications of Deep Learning-Based Image Generation and Processing in Visual Communication Design
authors: Siyuan Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: With the continuous advancement of deep learning technology, its application in visual communication design has gradually become a research hotspot. This paper explores the application of deep learning-based image generation and processing in visual communication design, focusing on the specific applications of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in tasks such as image generation, classification, segmentation, denoising, and enhancement. First, Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) generate photorealistic images through adversarial training, driving advancements in style transfer, image synthesis, super-resolution reconstruction, and image restoration/inpainting. This provides designers with more creative and artistic design tools. Second, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) demonstrate formidable capabilities in image classification, segmentation, localization, and denoising/enhancement, enhancing the precision and efficiency of image processing. While deep learning exhibits significant advantages in visual communication design, its limitations–including strong data dependency, high computational resource requirements, and poor model interpretability–restrain its widespread adoption.

title: Integrated Medical Imaging Data and Deep Learning into a Smart Diagnostic Framework: AI-Enabled Biomedical Technology for Early Disease Prediction
authors: Kanimozhi Rajasekaran, Baby Joice. A, Selvaganapathy. M, Mahalakshmi. G, Samadhanapriya. A, Nishavithri. N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Early detection is essential for successful treatment and management of diseases, especially for lifethreatening and chronic diseases like cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and neurodegenerative diseases. Artificial intelligence (AI), and high-resolution medical imaging are changing the way we approach healthcare diagnostics. This study introduces a new intelligent testing framework where multimodal medical imaging data and deep learning algorithms are integrated to support a reliable and early prediction of disease. The proposed framework utilizes CNNs, RNNs and attention mechanisms to learn and analyze multiple medical images including MRI, CT, PET and ultrasound images. In this integrated setting, advanced data pre-processing, segmentation, feature extraction and classification techniques are exploited to (i) identify anomalies, (ii) predict disease progression, and (iii) provide decision support to clinicians. An essential characteristic of the framework is its capability to integrate disparate imaging information and temporal medical records for a more global and individualized diagnosis. The AI models are developed by transfer learning and fine-tuning techniques to increase performance in the prediction accuracy over diverse patients. Furthermore, the system integrates explainable AI (XAI) principles to increase interpretability as well as the trust of clinicians by showing visual and textual explanations corresponding to each diagnosis decision. Intuitive design to visualize the detected biomarkers, anatomical abnormalities and MI conforming AI generated insights in real-time, enhancing the synergism between the reviewers and the machine intelligence. The SDN system also connects with EHRs to learn from past cases and become increasingly more accurate over time. Performance analysis of the framework with benchmark datasets of lung cancer, brain Tumors, and diabetic retinopathy demonstrates the superior performance in terms of sensitivity, specificity and diagnostic speed compared to the traditional diagnostic methods. The method was flexible to new imaging formats, and robust to noise, variations in intensity and artefacts. These findings illustrate the transformative potential of the integration of imaging and clinical data using deep learning for early disease prediction, to help reduce diagnostic latencies, and tailor treatment strategies. In the end, it is a giant step towards AIdriven preventive and precision healthcare systems.

title: UX-Guided Iot-Based Learning Platform for Informal Entrepreneurship Training in Indonesian PKBM: A Human-Technology Symbiosis Approach
authors: Ika Suhartanti Darmo, Andi Wiliam, Viany Utami Tjhin, Apriani Kurnia Suci, Anuar Shah bin Bali Mahomed
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: The urgency of strengthening entrepreneurial capacities in marginalized populations has highlighted the limitations of conventional training mechanisms, especially within the informal education ecosystem in Indonesia, such as Pusat Kegiatan Belajar Masyarakat (PKBM). This study proposes the design and evaluation of a human-centered digital interaction model tailored for informal micro-entrepreneurs in coastal and rural Banten. Leveraging user experience (UX)-driven design, Internet of Things (IoT) architecture, and mobile-based microlearning, the research develops a prototype system that facilitates accessible, adaptive, and culturally contextual entrepreneurship training. We conducted a participatory design process involving 25 PKBM learners and facilitators, resulting in a low-tech mobile platform with voice-guided interactions, offline-first modules, and business simulation gamification. Usability tests using SUS and task-based evaluations revealed an average SUS score of 81.2, with a 96% task completion rate and a significant knowledge gain of +25.6 points (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}<0.001$</tex>). This study contributes a validated, low-literacy-centric HCI model that contrasts with mainstream elearning platforms by prioritizing perceptual interfaces and offlinefirst design, offering a scalable blueprint for informal entrepreneurship education in resource-constrained settings.

title: Improving ASE-based Optoelectronic Oscillator Performance Using a Chirp-like Slicing Approach
authors: Zhuoran Wang, Santiago Bernal, David V. Plant, Lawrence R. Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: The performance of an ASE-based optoelectronic oscillator (OEO) is enhanced through a chirp-like slicing approach. By spectrally slicing the amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) source using a chirp function, the in-band chirp within the pass-band of the microwave photonic (MWP) filter—induced by the fiber’s third-order dispersion (TOD)—is effectively eliminated. When a 25 km fiber is incorporated, this technique achieves a more than 7-fold reduction in filter bandwidth, along with an amplitude enhancement of 9.3 dB. As a result, once the feedback loop is closed, the sidemode suppression ratio (SMSR) improves by 10.7 dB, the phase noise is reduced by 13 dB at a 4 kHz offset at 7.2 GHz, and the output power is increased by 11.7 dB.

title: Integration of Aerial Object Detection System with Flight Controller
authors: Hilam Prasath Swami Vivekananda, Ray Anselm Hai Seng Lim, Ermira Junita Abdullah, Mohd Faisal Abdul Hamid
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an onboard object detection system integrated with a fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) flight controller. The system employs a Raspberry Pi 4 and Pi Camera 3 as a lightweight vision module running a fine-tuned YOLOv8n model for real-time aerial detection. A custom dataset of 83 annotated images was collected and used for transfer learning, achieving a mean Average Precision mAP@50-95=0.871) across four target classes which are buildings, cars, houses and lakes. The optimized YOLOv8n model operates at 2–3 FPS with FP16 precision on the Raspberry Pi 4, maintaining stable inference and acceptable power consumption within an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 11 \mathrm{W}$</tex> system envelope. Field experiments verified onboard detection capability and operational stability under flight conditions. The results demonstrate the feasibility of deploying deep-learning-based vision models on compact, low-cost UAV platforms for aerial monitoring and environmental observation applications.

title: When and How Do Smart Learning Environments Intervene? A Classification Framework for Context-Aware Learning
authors: Yara Youssef, Jan Schneider, Daniel Schiffner
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: Self-directed learning in home environments presents unique challenges, including a lack of real-time guidance and difficulty in maintaining engagement, focus, and well-being. Smart Learning Environments (SLEs) address these challenges by leveraging context-aware technologies that sense and adapt to learners’ needs. While prior frameworks address content adaptation and pedagogical feedback, they often lack a systematic account of how real-time multimodal learner data shape the timing and form of interventions. This paper introduces a conceptual classification framework developed inductively during a systematic literature review of 50 SLE systems. The framework organizes interventions based on the types of data collected—physiological, behavioral, performance-related, and environmental—and characterizes them along five dimensions: modality, intrusiveness, task adaptation, task support, and task regulation. By providing a systematic approach to linking sensed contexts with intervention strategies, the framework enables the analysis, comparison, and design of context-aware interventions in self-directed learning settings.

title: Enhancing the Performance of VLSI Architecture for Arithmetical Application
authors: Sukruth R, Bore Gowda S. B.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: This paper presents an optimized design of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> multiplier using pass transistor logic to address the challenges of power consumption, speed, and circuit complexity in VLSI applications. The architecture suggested has a three-step computation procedure, where-in, 16 partial products are computed using logical AND gates and then tree length is reduced using a series of 3 -input and 2 -input binary adders at strategic points. Buffers are incorporated at major points of the design to guarantee signal integrity and signal voltage. The unique full adder circuit, consisting of Gate Diffusion Input (GDI) XOR gates and Pass Transistor Logic (PTL) XOR and MUX cells has low dynamic and quiescent power consumption and an improved performance. The proposed multiplier compares favorably to current designs with smaller power dissipations, critical path delay and a smaller number of transistors thus it is very efficient in terms of low power and high-speed computer applications. This work establishes a robust framework for designing compact and energy-efficient multipliers, providing valuable insights for advanced digital signal processing and portable device implementations.

title: Blockchain Architecture for Secure Healthcare Data Storage with Privacy, Scalability, Interoperability, and Accessibility Features
authors: M Sowmya, Rajesh Kumar Kaushal, Shanthi Makka
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Data breaches, fragmentation, and patient confinement are ongoing problems for unified healthcare systems. In order to safeguard and manage healthcare data, this write-up proposes a blockchain-based system that consolidate IPFS, Hyperledger Fabric, AES-256 encryption, and smart contracts. Patients obtain control over their records, allowing for managed source sharing while maintaining authorized restrictions and accuracy. Clinical trial data management, pharmaceutical supply chains, and electronic health records are examples of use cases. Reliable throughput, minimal latency, and robust security against unwanted access are demonstrated via performance evaluation. With future prospects in scalability, key management, and regulatory alignment, the strategy improves patient-centric healthcare, interoperability, and compliance.

title: Codebook Design for Wideband FDD Massive MIMO Hybrid Precoding
authors: Muhammad Salman Al Faruq, Danish Mehmood Mughal, Min Young Chung, Sang-Hyo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Obtaining accurate CSI in frequency division duplexing (FDD) systems is a challenging problem due to the extensive feedback overhead. Applying a precoder to the CSI reference signal (CSI-RS) reduces feedback overhead and improves the reception of the CSI-RS. However, fully digital precoding dedicates RF chains for each antenna, which makes massive MIMO with a large antenna array expensive. Hybrid precoding has attracted increasing interest as a practical solution that reduces the number of RF chains. Operating in analog and digital domains introduces additional constraints on the design of the precoder. In this paper, we propose a codebook design for wideband FDD massive MIMO hybrid precoding systems. We formulate the precoding design problem as a sparsity-constrained matrix reconstruction problem. Using orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP), we develop a wideband precoding algorithm that approximates unconstrained partial channel reciprocity precoding using a smaller number of RF chains than the total number of antennas. We present simulation results that exhibit the hybrid precoding shows a slight performance gap compared to unconstrained precoding.

title: Semi-Automated Generation of Object Mask Annotations from Bounding Box Labels Using SAM with Domain-Aware Geometric Constraints
authors: SungWon Moon, Jiwon Lee, Jungsoo Lee, Dowon Nam, Seungjae Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Accurate object segmentation is vital for training and evaluating computer vision models, yet manual mask annotation remains a major bottleneck, especially for domain-specific datasets like traditional paintings. This paper proposes a semi-automated framework that transforms bounding box labels into object masks using MobileSAM, a lightweight prompt-based segmentation model. Full-image candidate masks are generated and refined through geometric constraints, including bounding box containment, relative size thresholds, and spatial alignment. We evaluate candidate masks using Intersection over Union (IoU) metrics and apply domain-aware filtering heuristics to select the most accurate masks. Experiments on traditional painting datasets show that the framework yields high-quality segmentation masks with minimal human intervention, offering a scalable and efficient solution for enhancing annotation pipelines in specialized visual domains.

title: A Visualization-Assisted Insect Classification Human–Machine Interface System Based on Spatial Pyramid Pooling CNN
authors: Song-Min Ke, Chang-Yu Wu, Chang-Yi Chu, Hoh-Siang Liao, Ying-Hsiu Hung, Shin-Chi Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This study proposes an integrated human–machine interface system that combines image acquisition control with classification display. Through a graphical user platform, the system integrates robotic arm–based image capture, automatic coordinate transformation, and real-time classification results, achieving both ease of operation and automation. The front end employs a six-axis robotic arm to perform specified or automatic scanning and image acquisition. On the back end, YOLO-v4 is used to detect insect positions, and the cropped images are fed into a convolutional neural network with a Spatial Pyramid Pooling (SPP) structure (SPP-CNN) for multi-class classification. To address the issue of imbalanced training data, this study adopted multiple data augmentation strategies, increasing the model's classification accuracy to 89.7%, which is a 1.2% improvement over the referenced SPP-CNN architecture. The result demonstrates the effectiveness of data augmentation in enhancing model stability. Users can easily interact with the interface to direct the robotic arm for automated insect image capture and classification, optimizing the monitoring process and substantially reducing manual effort.

title: Evaluation of Bit-Width Effects in Fixed-Point FPGA-Optimized MFCC Computation via Software Simulation for HMM-Based Phrase Speech Recognition
authors: Naoya Yamamura, Chenyu Zhao, Hiroshi Tsutsui, Takeo Ohgane
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: This paper presents an evaluation of bit-width effects in a fixed-point, field-programmable gate array (FPGA)optimized implementation of Mel-frequency cepstral coefficient (MFCC) computation for hidden Markov model (HMM)-based phrase speech recognition, conducted via a software simulation. We developed a software to analyze how the bit widths of fixedpoint operations affect the recognition accuracy of an HMMbased phrase speech recognition system. Experimental results show that recognition accuracy comparable to that of a floatingpoint implementation can be achieved even with significantly reduced bit widths. We determine the minimum required bit widths for key MFCC stages, including the Hanning window and fast Fourier transform (FFT). These findings demonstrate the practicality of the hardware implementation for real-time low-power speech recognition.

title: Design of Electrochemical Biosensor Output Reader Through Modelling the Electrochemical Cell System and Designing a 90nm CMOS Transimpedance Amplifier with Self-Biasing
authors: Suksmandhira Harimurti, M. Rivaldi Ali Septian, Uperianti, Wijdan Insania Kuncoro, Joe Nashtofa Firdaus, M. Saboy Pangindoan S., Khilda Afifah, Isa Anshori, Estananto
publish: 2025 International Symposium on Intelligent Signal Processing and Communication Systems (ISPACS)
abstract: Electrochemical biosensor is a versatile biosensor, which can detect numerous types of biochemical substances quantitatively and with a high specificity. However, the output signal of the biosensor is considerably low and different electrochemical systems can produce different characteristics of the output signals. Hence, in this paper, we reported a model of an ionic-based electrochemical cell system, which could estimate the output signal characteristics of the cell and provided input specification for the reader circuit. A transimpedance amplifier with self-biasing as the reader circuit, designed using a 90nm CMOS technology, was also presented in this paper. The circuit utilized a low power supply voltage of 1.8 V and showcased a high transimpedance gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$79.6 ~\text{dB} \Omega$</tex> with a frequency bandwidth of 199.5 MHz, facilitating a sufficient gain from a low <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{A}$</tex> output current level of the electrochemical biosensor.

title: Study on the Influence of the Energy Recovery Circuit on the Performance of the Reluctance Launcher
authors: Pinghui Li, Wanting Xi, Na Wu, Qihang Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Automation, Electrical Control Systems and Equipment (AECSE)
abstract: To improve the energy utilization efficiency of the reluctance electromagnetic coil launcher, a discharge circuit with the characteristic of balanced energy recovery is proposed, and the discharge characteristics of the circuit at each stage are analyzed. A three-stage simulation model of the reluctance launcher was built, and finite element software was used to conduct simulation calculations. The results show that, compared with the traditional discharge circuit, the energy recovery circuit can match the turn-on timing of the control circuit with the recharging circuit, thus avoiding the projectile being affected by the reverse suction force. The muzzle velocity of the armature is increased from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22.13\ \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$29.2\ \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, and the efficiency is increased from 8% to 13.9%. After the launch process is completed, the circuit can evenly recover the residual energy after the armature acceleration into the capacitors at all levels for the next launch. This design not only improves the energy utilization efficiency but also lays a foundation for realizing rapid and continuous launches.

title: AI-assisted Modem Implementation for Intelligent Wireless Access Systems
authors: Yunjoo Kim, Jungbo Son, Yuro Lee, JungSook Bae
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper proposes a modem architecture that integrates a hardware modem based on a field-programmable gate array (FPGA) and a software modem that uses a graphics processing unit (GPU) to support machine learning (ML)-based channel estimation. In a proof-of-concept (PoC) implementation for an intelligent wireless access system, the proposed modem achieved an improvement of approximately 3.5 dB in signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) under real-time conditions. In addition, parallel processing reduced latency and ensured stable operation.

title: Digital Skill Assessment and Personalized Course Recommendation for Sustainable Workforce Development
authors: Uraiwan Buatoom, Amornrat Makbodee, Dhachayawat Pasomthrap, Wittawas Puntumchinda, Sirima Chinnasarn, Chalitda Madhyamapurush, Thatsanee Charoenporn, Athita Onuean
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents a practical and comprehensive framework for digital skills assessment and persona-based course recommendation designed to support multi-sectoral workforce development. Our approach integrates design thinking, lean startup, and agile principles to build a practical assessment tool covering eight digital skill areas, including data analytics and visualization, digital green sustainability, digital literacy, digital leadership and resilience skills, creative design and digital marketing, government service design skills, cybersecurity, and digital law. The framework was validated with 207 participants from government, education, private companies, and SMEs in Thailand. The assessment uses a three-level proficiency scale and includes timed questions of varying difficulty. We applied k-means clustering to group participants by their skill patterns and used silhouette scores and Davies-Bouldin indices to evaluate the clustering quality. The results show that the framework effectively identifies distinct digital competency profiles and generates personalized learning paths for users. The system can recommend specific courses based on individual skill gaps and job roles. This study offers organizations a practical tool for transforming their workforce digitally, instilling confidence in its real-world applicability.

title: Optimizing Federated Learning in the Era of LLMs: Message Quantization and Streaming
authors: Ziyue Xu, Zhihong Zhang, Holger R. Roth, Chester Chen, Yan Cheng, Andrew Feng
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) offers a promising solution for training machine learning models across distributed data sources while preserving data privacy. However, FL faces critical challenges related to communication overhead and local resource constraints, especially in the era of Large Language Models (LLMs) with billions of parameters. The sheer size of these models exacerbates both memory and communication constraints, making efficient transmission and processing essential for practical deployment. NVIDIA FLARE, an open-source SDK for federated learning, addresses these challenges by introducing advanced communication capabilities. Building upon existing solutions for large object streaming, we enhance FL workflows for LLMs through two key techniques: message quantization and container/file streaming. Quantization reduces message size, while streaming enables efficient memory management, improving scalability and integration with existing workflows. These advancements significantly enhance the robustness and efficiency of FL with LLMs, ensuring better performance in real-world federated learning scenarios.

title: Hierarchical RL-Based Multi-Layer Routing in Integrated TN–NTN Networks
authors: Jiseok Jang, Soyi Jung
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The integration of terrestrial networks and non-terrestrial networks (NTN) is essential for global connectivity but faces routing challenges due to NTN’s high mobility, dynamic topology, and limited link resources. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning-based routing framework in a geostationary Earth orbit – medium Earth orbit – low Earth orbit architecture integrated with terrestrial gateways, separating global hop allocation from regional satellite selection. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher signal-to-noise ratio and lower end-to-end latency compared to conventional distance-based routing.

title: UNet Based Deep Learning for Interferometric SAR Phase Unwrapping
authors: Jeungwoo Ham, Yifang Shi, Haewoon Nam
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Phase Unwrapping (PU) is a fundamental task in Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) processing. conventional model-based approaches often struggle in noisy or complex fringe environments. In this work, we propose a convolution layer-based deep learning model that directly regresses the unwrapped phase from the single-channel-wrapped input. By formulating PU as a supervised regression problem and training with a synthetic interferogram, the proposed method achieves a low root mean square error without relying on explicit residue or branch-cut heuristics. The experimental results demonstrate the robustness and precision of the model, highlighting the potential of learning-based methods in InSAR phase recovery tasks.

title: Federated Agentic Learning with Adaptive Privacy for Cardiovascular Anomaly Detection at the Edge
authors: Josiah Ayoola Isong, Victor Ikenna Kanu, Simeon Okechukwu Ajakwe, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Wearable IoT devices enable continuous cardiovascular monitoring, but privacy risks, communication overhead, and data heterogeneity hinder AI-driven anomaly detection. This paper proposes a Federated Agentic Learning (FAL) framework that embeds autonomous AI agents into edge clients to enable adaptive participation and dynamic Differential Privacy (DP) management. Using the PhysioNet 2017 dataset with a CNN– LSTM model, FAL achieved an F1-score of 92.5%, surpassing standard federated learning (88.1%) and approaching centralized training (95.0%). Communication overhead was reduced by 42%, while fairness improved with 35% lower variance across clients. These results demonstrate that FAL is an efficient, robust, and privacy-preserving foundation for edge-based healthcare AI, paving the way for trustworthy cardiovascular monitoring in real-world deployments.

title: A Ka-band Down Converter IC in 65-nm CMOS for LEO-Satellite Payloads
authors: Hongkie Lim, Seong-Mo Moon, Dong-Pil Chang
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: A Ka-band down-converter integrated circuit (IC), implemented in a 65-nm CMOS process, is presented for Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite communication payloads. The proposed single-chip solution integrates the complete RF, IF, and LO stages and employs an in-phase/quadrature (I/Q) architecture for image rejection. In the LO path, a transformer-based quadrature coupler is compactly implemented, offering low insertion loss. A passive fourth-order low-pass filter (LPF) is employed for channel selection and spur rejection, and its gain-peaking feature is exploited to enhance wideband IF performance. Simulation results show that the chip operates over the 27.5-30.5 GHz RF band, achieving a peak conversion gain of 14.5 dB and a minimum noise figure (NF) of 8.4 dB. The total chip area, including pads, is 890 μm by 880 μm with a total power consumption of 46.6 mW.

title: Experimental Results for Indoor Positioning Based on Wi-Fi FTM and RSSI
authors: Koki Nakamura, Takashi Ookawara, Yudai Sunagozaka, Rei Hirata, Atsushi Koizumi, Takenori Sumi, Jianlin Guo, Yukimasa Nagai, Hiroshi Oguma
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Indoor positioning methods using wireless signal propagation data have attracted significant interest for applications such as monitoring IoT devices and tracking human behavior. The IEEE 802.11 FTM (Fine Timing Measurement) protocol, used for Wi-Fi location, was introduced to the market in 2016. The FTM protocol can measure the distance between Wi-Fi access point (AP) and station (STA). By measuring the distances between multiple Wi-Fi APs and STAs, the indoor position of the STA can be estimated. In this paper, we collected FTM and RSSI measurements in an indoor environment using FTM-enabled Wi-Fi APs and STAs, and evaluated indoor positioning accuracy through geometric calculations based on FTM data as well as a machine learning approach using both FTM and RSSI data as inputs. Furthermore, for the machine learning approach, we also assessed the impact of varying the number of Wi-Fi AP data elements supplied to the model in increments of AP count. The results demonstrated that positioning accuracy achieved by the machine learning approach surpassed that of geometric calculations.
