Moreover, even when the number of input data elements to the machine learning model was limited, utilizing FTM data obtained from at least one AP mitigated the degradation in positioning accuracy within the machine learning framework.

title: Fair and Scalable Resume Screening Using Generative AI
authors: Shuzhou Liu, Himajit Aithal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The increasing volume of applications per job posting has made manual resume screening inefficient, error-prone, and susceptible to unconscious bias. This paper presents a scalable, bias-aware resume screening framework powered by the ChatGPT-4o Large Language Model. The proposed system automatically extracts and weights key skills and qualifications from job descriptions, analyzes candidate resumes in conjunction with publicly available online profiles (e.g., GitHub, LinkedIn), and ranks applicants based on semantic alignment with job requirements. To ensure fairness, the system anonymizes bias-sensitive attributes such as gender, age, race, and disability prior to analysis. A prompt-engineered pipeline guides the model through structured evaluation steps, providing interpretable ranking rationales. The approach improves the consistency, transparency, and equity of candidate selection, while reducing the overall time to screen resumes and offering a practical solution for modern recruitment challenges.

title: Performance Analysis of Optimizer Variations in CNN Algorithms for Flower Classification with Digital Images
authors: Wani Syafitri, Siti Masripah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advanced Information Scientific Development (ICAISD)
abstract: Plant species classification is essential for implementing smart agriculture. Manual classification methods have several limitations, particularly in terms of consistency and accuracy when applied over extended periods. Therefore, deep learning-based approaches provide a more suitable alternative for addressing this task. One of the most widely used algorithms for image classification is the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), which can extract various visual features from images, including patterns, colors, and object structures. In this study, two CNN architectures, VGG16 and InceptionV3, were employed to classify flower species. Furthermore, a performance comparison was conducted using several popular optimization methods: Adam, AdamW, NAdam, RMSProp, and SGD. The experimental results demonstrate that the highest accuracy was achieved by the VGG16 model with the AdamW optimizer, reaching an accuracy of 94.29 % and F 1 -Score of 92.53 %. For the InceptionV3 model, the best performance was obtained with the SGD optimizer, achieving an accuracy of 95.24 % and an F1-Score of 93.50 %. These findings indicate that the models, combined with the applied optimization approaches, can effectively capture the distinctive visual characteristics of each flower species, making them highly effective for image-based classification systems in the botanical domain.

title: Tackling Traveling Salesman Problems with a Cluster-Based Quantum-Classical Optimization
authors: Saweed Hussain, Lutfiana Sausan, Abdur Rahman, Chimeremma Sandra Amadi, Hoon Ryu
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: A hybrid quantum-classical framework is exploited to solve the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) based on a Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). To overcome the computational limitation of the Grover’s Search Algorithm (GSA) stemming from path encoding and arithmetic subroutines, a clustering-based strategy is employed to decompose a 16-city TSP into four 4-city subproblems, each of which can be solved with a 16-qubit budget. Intra-cluster solutions are optimized with QAOA, and are classically stitched to construct the global tour. Our results clearly validate the effectiveness of the hierarchical design of the algorithm, highlighting its feasibility for mid-scale quantum optimizations.

title: Explainable Deep Learning Framework for Multisource Data Fusion in University Mental Health Analysis
authors: Qiqin Yu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Mental health issues among university students have become a growing concern in higher education. Conventional psychological assessment methods based on single-source data often exhibit limited accuracy and weak interpretability. This paper proposes an explainable deep learning framework for multisource data fusion that integrates behavioral, academic, psychological, and social media information. The framework employs a multi-head attention mechanism to adaptively learn the contribution of each data source and incorporates LIME and Grad-CAM techniques to enhance interpretability. Experiments on a real-world dataset of 4,287 students demonstrate that the proposed method achieves 92.35% accuracy, 89.16% recall, and 90.62% F1-score in psychological risk detection, outperforming existing multimodal fusion models by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 9 - 5. 0 \%}$</tex>. These results highlight the framework's potential to support early mental health warning systems in universities.

title: A Gesture-Based Mobile Interface for Enhanced Image Accessibility for Visually Impaired
authors: Raju Shrestha, Nikhil Amatya
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel Android application that enhances image accessibility for visually impaired users through a gesture-based interface supporting touch, slide, and swipe interactions. Addressing the limitations of existing mobile accessibility tools, the prototype combines gesture-based interaction with synchronized audio and haptic feedback to convey information about detected objects using an on-device object detection model. A user study with 24 participants of varying visual abilities evaluated its usability and effectiveness through structured questionnaires and statistical analysis. Results show that the multimodal feedback significantly improved users’ ability to interpret image content and navigate visual information non-visually. While promising, limitations such as reliance on the native gallery suggest the need for an integrated accessible gallery, real-time scene understanding, and richer image descriptions in future work. Overall, the study demonstrates a user-centric, real-time, and multimodal approach to improving image accessibility on mobile devices for visually impaired individuals.

title: Fine-Grained Diffractive Slab for Accurate and Low-Complexity On-Chip Photonic Convolution
authors: Zichao Shen, Weichao Ma, Ruixuan Wang, Wangzhe Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: An integrated photonic circuit is designed and implemented on a silicon nitride photonic platform, based on high-precision, fine-grained diffractive structures. It is capable to conduct Fourier transform and convolution operations and refresh convolution kernels real-time, taking 24 × 24 diffraction slabs as computing core. Numerical analysis indicates that the S-parameter of diffractive slab closely match the theoretical values. The capability of the chip to perform Fourier transform and convolution is demonstrated by validating frequency shifting property and differential convolution calculations, with root mean square error of 0.045, 0.0281 and 0.1185 respectively. Notably, the system achieves high-precision computation using only half the number of modulators and drivers, demonstrating significant potential for accelerating complex processing tasks.

title: Automatic Document Classification and Intelligent Archiving System for Academic Administration Based on BERT-TextCNN Fusion Model
authors: Yu Li, Zhenxi Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: Efficient management and classification of educational administrative documents is crucial for modern higher education institutions, yet manual archiving remains time-consuming and error-prone. This paper proposes a novel BERT-TextCNN fusion model that integrates global semantic understanding with local n-gram feature extraction for intelligent document classification. The model employs a dual-branch architecture where the BERT branch captures contextual semantics through pre-trained transformers, while the TextCNN branch extracts discriminative local patterns through multi-scale convolutional networks. Two key innovations are introduced: (1) a multi-granularity semantic fusion layer utilizing attention mechanisms to adaptively combine features from both branches, and (2) a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism that automatically balances branch contributions based on document characteristics. Extensive experiments on a real-world dataset of 80,000 Chinese educational documents across 12 categories demonstrate that our model achieves 94.7% classification accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines including BERT-base (88.5%) and BERT + BiLSTM (90.1%) by 6.2% and 4.6% respectively, while maintaining 26% faster inference speed (38.6 ms/doc). Ablation studies validate the effectiveness of each component, with the attention-based fusion contributing 3.4% and dynamic weighting contributing 1.9% performance gain. The model exhibits exceptional robustness across varying document lengths (93.8%-95.1% accuracy) through adaptive weight adjustment. A 3-month pilot deployment at a major Chinese university processed 12,547 documents with 94.2% accuracy, reducing manual archiving time by 86-89% and achieving 92% user satisfaction. These results demonstrate the practical value of our approach for intelligent educational document management systems.

title: Effect of Mesa-Diameter on the 3-dB Bandwidth Enhancement of an InGaAs Photodiode with Inductive Signal Electrode
authors: Duk-Jun Kim, Seok-Jun Yun, Shinmo An, Dong-Hun Lee, Young-Tak Han
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Backside-illuminated InGaAs photodiodes were fabricated using two types of high-impedance coplanar waveguide (CPW) transmission line with different signal electrode designs. The effect of mesa diameter on the enhancement of the 3-dB bandwidth of the fabricated photodiodes was then analyzed based on optical/electrical (O/E) frequency response measurements.

title: Hybrid LLM and Sentence Transformer Evaluation for ITS Programming Exercises
authors: Javier Ortega-Morla, Daniel Ferreiro, Alejandro Paz-Lopez, Beatriz Péerez-Sáanchez, Sara Guerreiro-Santalla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Education Technology and Computers (ICETC)
abstract: This paper explores automatic evaluation and feedback generation for varied student output in programming exercises. To this end, a hybrid approach was implemented, combining Sentence Transformer Models for output classification with General Purpose Large Language Models for generating brief, informative feedback. The solution was tested on a dataset of 1,300 manually labeled student outputs from programming exams at the University of A Coruña. Finally, this system will be integrated into ProgTutor, an Intelligent Tutoring System, to replace the current evaluation method and enable its assessment in large-scale, real-world conditions.

title: Implementation of Wi-Fi NSTR MLO Coexisting with LTE-LAA via ns-3
authors: Suhwan Jung, Seokwoo Choi, Youngkeun Yoon, Ho-Kyung Son, Hyoil Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: The coexistence between Wi-Fi and the cellular technology in the unlicensed spectrum has been a significant research topic for several years. To investigate their coexistence performance, ns-3, one of the most popular network simulators, introduced the LTE-LAA project in 2016 [1], but its modules have not been updated in later versions of ns-3. Moreover, ns-3 does not yet support Wi-Fi 7’s NSTR(Non-Simultaneous Transmit and Receive) MLO(Multi-Link Operation) features. Therefore, there is an urgent need to update both LTE-LAA and Wi-Fi modules of ns-3 accordingly. This paper presents a methodology to modify ns-3 to address the aforementioned need, so as to enable the ns-3 simulator to accurately evaluate coexistence scenarios between Wi-Fi MLO and LTE-LAA.

title: An Enhanced ASAP7 PDK with Power Via Technology for IR Drop and PPA Evaluation
authors: Mingjie Yu, Jiaqi Dou, Bingyi Ye, Yang Shen, Xiaojin Li, Yanling Shi, Yuhang Zhang, Yabin Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This paper presents a redesign of the open-source 7 nm FinFET ASAP7 PDK to integrate PowerVia and backside metal technologies. We designed the backside metal stack and updated the technology files to include specifications for backside metal layers and vias. We developed comprehensive 6-track and 5-track standard cell libraries, each comprising 241 cells and incorporating PowerVia technology. Furthermore, we established a place-and-route flow that supports backside metals for largescale circuit-level evaluation. Experimental results show that the PV-6T library reduces chip-level area by 15%-18% and mitigates maximum static IR drop by 64%-79%, while the PV-5T library delivers 20% cell-level area scaling, 28%-32% chip-level area reduction and reduces maximum static IR drop by 71% 82%. Routing congestion is mitigated, enabling up to 94% core utilization, and the frequency is increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.39 \times$</tex> in average.

title: AI-Driven Misinformation Mitigation: Implementation of RAG System for Hoax Detection and Cybersecurity in Indonesia
authors: Rivo Juicer Wowor, SY Yuliani Yakub, Santi Indarjani
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Cryptography, Informatics, and Cybersecurity (ICoCICs)
abstract: The proliferation of hoax news and disinformation campaigns in Indonesia presents significant cybersecurity challenges, with coordinated attacks leveraging sophisticated botnets and automated content generation systems to manipulate public perception. This study addresses the critical need for automated hoax detection systems by developing and evaluating Large Language Models (LLM) with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system specifically d esigned f or Indonesian hoax news identification. Our system integrates Google Gemma3 4b for query optimization, with Google Gemini 2.5 Flash Preview serving as the primary judgment model. The retrieval mechanism combines two complementary knowledge sources: embeddings from the comprehensive Mafindo h oax <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> ews d ataset processed through IndoBERT and stored in a Milvus vector database, and real-time web content retrieved via the Tavily Web API from verified Dewan Pers Indonesia member websites. The system was rigorously evaluated against standalone large language models using a test dataset of 500 LLM-augmented news queries, demon-strating substantial improvements in hoax detection accuracy. Our RAG implementation achieved 79.5% accuracy, 84.9% precision, 72.8% recall, and an F1-score of 78.4%, significantly outperforming comparable plain LLM baselines. This finding proves that RAG systems and LLMs are capable of effective hoax detection, especially in low-resource languages like Indonesian, by determining the truthfulness of a text based on factual evidence and linguistic aspects. This finding also suggests the potential for more advanced RAG systems to further enhance hoax detection in the Indonesian language.

title: Upgrading a Multi-Level Coding Method and Constructing Circular Matrices for Evidence-Based Strategies: A Case of Policy-Oriented Educational Research
authors: Wanying Liang, Jia Tian, Yuqing Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: A method of circular matrix construction based on upgrading a multi-level coding method was introduced and discussed with a case of policy-oriented educational research aiming at exploring evidence-based strategies. After theoretical basis selection, data collection, and mixed analysis, a multi-level coding method was expanded, and a need matrix and a response matrix were constructed within a socio-ecosystem framework. Each matrix contains rows and columns of numbers for needs or responses at epicentre-, micro-, meso-, exo-, and macro-levels, representing the typicalness of the needs and significance of responses. This method is expected to be used to further analyze relationships among content in a matrix, with the expanded multilevel coding method potentially informing smart algorithm development for unstructured qualitative data mining and processing, while its shortcoming is that the method's validity highly depends on researchers' capacity for data collection and inference from the numbers in one matrix to those in another. Readers are encouraged to test and/or criticize the method.

title: Prompt to Path: LLM-Guided Multi-Objective Eco-Routing via Geohash-Compressed Urban Graphs
authors: Madyan Bagosher, Isam Mashhour Al Jawarneh, Luca Foschini, Paolo Bellavista
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Cycling is a widely-practiced, eco-friendly mode of transportation essential for sustainable urban mobility. Determining routes that optimize for environmental factors, such as better air quality (AQ) and high vegetation (NDVI) as opposed to just faster routes is an important first step in incentivizing bike riding as a form of transportation. However, existing navigation systems often fall short and fail to facilitate this multi-objective, environment aware routing. To address this, we introduce a scalable eco-routing framework Geohash-Based Multi-Objective Bike Routing (GB-MOBR), that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to interpret natural language prompts for route preferences. The challenge lies in the prohibitive computational cost of multi-objective algorithms with large scale graph-based networks. Therefore, we first construct a fine-grained, multi-criteria graph by associating environmental data (AQ, NDVI, Congestion, Green Roofs, Meteorological) with a street network using KD-Trees for efficient spatial matching. Then, to enable scalable optimization, we apply a Geohash-based graph aggregation technique to create a smaller, topologically equivalent graph. We compare the performance and solution quality of these algorithms: Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Dijkstra and Yen's K-Shortest Paths on both graphs and examine their performance. Results demonstrate that our aggregation method reduces computation time by up to 90% and therefore making the algorithms more viable for real-time use.

title: Quantum-Dot Mobility Prediction Algorithm for Flexible Nanoelectronic Fabrication in Wearable Electronics
authors: Shailendra Shah, Mohammad Idrish Ali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The possibilities of flexible nanoelectronics in lightweight, elastic, and high-performance electronics have made interest in the manufacturing of elastic wearable gadgets of next-generation technologies. Nevertheless, quantum dot (QD) films on flexible substrates have not been studied in detail regarding the charge transport. Interdot disorder variability, energy-strain loss, and dissimilar morphology of substrates are variabilities that lead to poor charge transport and are unsightly bottlenecks to the possible betterment of devices and to the quantum dots and films device manufacture. To overcome the abovementioned metrology and fabrication issues, our proposal of a new Quantum-Dot Mobility Estimation through Topological Adaptive Network (QD-METAN) is provided. Using adaptive physics-informed mobility rules in the graph modeling of QD networks offers a new viewpoint. QD-METAN, unlike the other topological-network-driven noisy QD mobility estimates, is a dynamic topological network, binds up single QD energy states, and the edges are threads of strain and charge propagation. QD-METAN gets around the constraints of passive models of network constriction and rigidity by modulating frictional limits via mechanosynthesis. The comparison with experimental data demonstrates that QDMETAN is capable of predicting electron and hole mobilities with over 94 percent accuracy and outperforms not only the conventional machine-learning but also the continuum simulation methods. Besides this, the technique also provides information on the optimal patterns of deposition of QD masses, substrate selection, as well as processing conditions to eliminate trial and error in experiments. Experimental data collected on flexible QD thin-film transistors confirm that the trends in mobility of the device on bending and stretching are identical to those of QD-METAN, which proves the practical usefulness of the model. This establishes new paths in predictive design in flexible nanoelectronics since it incorporates topological network analysis and adaptive physics and gives more credibility, scale, or capability to the wearables.

title: Rice Crop Disease Detection Using a Hybrid CNN-ViT Model Enhanced with Explainable AI and Attention-Based Interpretability
authors: Nimisha Manna James, Naitri Panchal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: Given the increasing threats to the yield of rice crop, early identification of diseases has become important for prompt intervention and sustainable agriculture, preserving the economic growth. This paper compares four deep learning architectures-Resnet50, MobileNetV2, DeiT-Tiny and MobileViT with a custom-designed hybrid CNN-ViT model on the Paddy Doctor dataset across eight disease classes and one healthy class. The proposed methodology of hybrid CNN-ViT model uses CNN for feature extraction of spatial patterns and a transformer-based encoder for analyzing global patterns in the image. All models were evaluated based on the accuracy and efficiency achieved. The hybrid model achieved maximum accuracy of 96.54 % proving its supreme efficiency in crop disease monitoring. Furthermore, Grad-CAM++ and Attention Heatmaps were used for explainability to provide better interpretability. The integrated framework showed reliable performance in rice crop disease detection making it suitable for agricultural monitoring.

title: How Well Does ChatGPT Understand Drug Mechanisms? A Knowledge + Reasoning Evaluation Dataset
authors: Sunil Mohan, Theofanis Karaletsos
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Two scientific fields showing increasing interest in pre-trained large language models (LLMs) are drug development / repurposing, and personalized medicine. For both, LLMs have to demonstrate factual knowledge as well as a deep understanding of drug mechanisms, so they can recall and reason about relevant knowledge in novel situations. Drug mechanisms of action are described as a series of interactions between biomedical entities, which interlink into one or more chains directed from the drug to the targeted disease. Composing the effects of the interactions in a candidate chain leads to an inference about whether the drug might be useful or not for that disease. We introduce a dataset that evaluates LLMs on both factual knowledge of known mechanisms, and their ability to reason about them under novel situations, presented as counterfactuals that the models are unlikely to have seen during training. Using this dataset, we show that o4-mini outperforms the 4o, o3, and o3-mini models from OpenAI. We demonstrate that the open world setting for reasoning tasks, which requires the model to recall relevant knowledge, is more challenging than the closed world setting where the needed factual knowledge is provided. We also show that counterfactuals affecting internal links in the reasoning chain present a much harder task than those affecting a link from the drug mentioned in the prompt.

title: A Digital Twin Simulator for Physics-Inspired AI in 6G Wireless Networks
authors: Seung Hyun Oh, Wookjin Lee, Youngjin Song, Jung Bum Lee, Gun Kim, Sang Hyun Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Future 6G networks will operate in dense urban environments where accurate modeling of wireless propagation is essential. We construct a digital twin of the Seoul metropolitan area, with buildings and streets represented in full 3D. Radio propagation is simulated using the NVIDIA Sionna channel model, providing a realistic representation of the urban wireless channel. Within this environment, communication scenarios are represented as interacting entities whose dynamics are approximated by a neural solver trained to emulate the underlying physical processes. The proposed simulator offers a practical platform for evaluating and optimizing association strategies in future networks.

title: I Understand Understand You: A Reliable Multi-Agent Facilitator for Reducing Communication Breakdowns
authors: Onyedikachukwu Tochukwu Mba, Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: Imagine a mediator who fosters active listening and effective communication between English speakers, without judgment, but by encouraging each party involved to be themselves. Imagine that this speaker not only hears you, but "understands understands" you! Picture that conversations between English-speaking professionals from across the globe can be possible and seamless, and all the while, without any form of prejudice! Think about it, for a moment, that there would no longer be any need for code-switching! This is why I Understand Understand You (IUUY), an active-listening facilitator and a coach that helps promote multi-culturally competent conversations, might just be the answer you have been waiting for. IUUY, though still in its early research and development stages, is a multi-agent AI system (MAS) augmented by blockchain technology to facilitate great conversations and reduce communication breakdowns, both ethically and securely. Currently a 4-agent entity, it aims to foster fair, inclusive, and trustworthy conversations in culturally diverse professional and personal spaces. An Agile methodology, particularly the Scrum framework, will guide its continuous iterative development, user-centric prototyping, and responsive learning cycles.

title: Ensemble Deep Learning Model for Performance Analysis of It Professionals in Adaptive E-Learning Environments
authors: Yuvapriya P, Subramanian P, Surendran R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Electronics and Computing, Communication Networking Automation Technologies (ICEC2NT)
abstract: In the today's digitally transforming scenario, the performance analysis of IT professionals within adaptive elearning platforms has become a critical component for personalized training and career development. Still, the variability in learning behaviors and data inconsistency makes the major challenges to accurate classification and performance profiling. To address the issue, the proposed model based on ensemble framework is designed for performance analysis of IT professionals into three categories like High, Medium, and Low by considering the interaction data within e-learning systems. The proposed model comprises four integral stages like data gathering from user activity logs, pre-processing to remove duplicates, feature selection using Information Gain to retain the most significant attributes and the proposed ensemble classifier. The ensemble integrates Xception, ShuffleNet, SRU, and Hybrid ShuffleSRU for spatiotemporal learning. Majority voting is used to take the decision making on the outputs that ensures the reliable classification. The proposed approach demonstrates enhanced classification performance across multiple evaluation metrics such as accuracy, F1-score, Cohen's Kappa, and MCC.

title: Towards Speed-Agnostic Time-Series Forecasting for Proactive Handover
authors: Junseo Lee, Suwan Yoon, Changhee Lee
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: In modern cellular networks, the handover (HO) of selecting the optimal base station according to the user equipment (UE) mobility is indispensable. However, conventional HO mechanisms primarily rely on reactive methods, which face inherent limitations in dealing with network uncertainties and real-time adaptability. To overcome these challenges, recent studies have introduced proactive HO schemes that leverage deep learning-based time-series forecasting models. Nevertheless, these approaches still suffer from degraded prediction performance under diverse UE speed environments due to global distribution shift, and naively constructing separate models for each mobility speed is highly inefficient. In this study, we address this inefficiency by proposing a speed-agnostic unified model. Specifically, we incorporate the existing Reversible Instance Normalization (RevIN) technique and introduce our newly proposed method, Residual Normalization (RN). We apply these normalization schemes to deep learning-based time-series forecasting models (DLinear, NLinear, and TCN), and through training and evaluation on datasets collected at varying mobility speeds, we demonstrate improved generalization capability of the forecasting models.

title: A 12-μV Offset Low-Input-Bias-Current High-Precision CMOS Operational Amplifier with Automatic Offset Calibration
authors: Kunxun Luo, Jingquan Liu, Mingyi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: This brief presents a low-input-bias-current (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{B}$</tex>), high-precision CMOS operational amplifier utilizing an automatic offset calibration (AOC) technique. The proposed AOC incorporates a BOXCAR switched-capacitor (SC) integrator to improve calibration accuracy without degrading <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{B}$</tex> and input impedance. The prototype has been implemented in a standard <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) process. Simulation results show that an intrinsic input offset voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{O S}$</tex>) ranging up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{2. 6 ~ m V}$</tex> can be calibrated within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$500 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>, achieving a residual <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{o s}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \mu ~\mathrm{V}$</tex>. Benefiting from the reduced <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V_{o s}$</tex>, the common-mode rejection ratio (CMRR) is improved to 108.7 dB. An extremely low typical <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{B}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18 f ~\mathrm{A}$</tex> makes the prototype well suited for high-precision and highimpedance interfaces that require wide bandwidth.

title: SMILE: Sensor Data-driven Detection and Counterfactual Pattern Analysis for Loneliness in Older Adults
authors: Xiayan Ji, Ahhyun Yuh, Viktor Erdélyi, Teruhiro Mizumoto, Hyonyoung Choi, Sean Harrison, Emma Cho, Takashi Suehiro, Takeshi Nakagawa, Yutian Cheng, Gondo Yasuyuki, Hajime Nagahara, Teruo Higashino, George Demiris, Oleg Sokolsky, Insup Lee
publish: ACM Transactions on Computing for Healthcare
abstract: None

title: Hybrid Multilingual Sentiment Analysis and Emotional Support System for Arabic and English Texts
authors: Mohammad Kharabsheh, Ala Mughaid, Dalal Idreis, Sewar ALdassouqi, Mahmoud Aljamal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Multilingual sentiment analysis and emotional support systems have become crucial in addressing the growing need for real-time, personalized emotional assistance across diverse linguistic and cultural contexts. Arabic and English texts, in particular, present unique challenges due to linguistic complexity, cultural nuances, and limited scalability in existing models. Existing systems often struggle with real-time application, personalization, and handling complex emotional expressions, such as sarcasm and mixed sentiments. To overcome these limitations, we propose a hybrid approach combining BERT and keyword-based methods to enhance sentiment analysis and provide tailored emotional support. Our system achieves a high classification accuracy of 99%, reduced response times of 2.5 seconds, and a user satisfaction rating of 4.3/5, demonstrating significant improvements in adaptability and user engagement. These results establish our system as a robust tool for applications in mental health, customer service, and social media analysis, while paving the way for future advancements in multilingual emotional intelligence technologies.

title: QCA Realization of Lightweight ASCON S-Box for Security Critical Applications
authors: Saravanan P, Parthasarathy R, Mohan Kumar S, Niveditha AR, Kavin M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The growing need for ultra-low-power and high-density nanoelectronic circuits in IoT and embedded systems has led to the investigation of Quantum-dot Cellular Automata (QCA) as an alternative to traditional CMOS technology. This research introduces a QCA-based implementation of the core permutation logic S-Box of ASCON–a lightweight cryptographic algorithm that includes authenticated encryption with associated data (AEAD) and hashing functions. ASCON was chosen as one of the winners of the CAESAR competition due to its high security, compact hardware design, and reliability in resource-limited environments such as IoT applications. In the proposed design, Bit-sliced implementation is used to generate the output. This work establishes the basis for a complete 320-bit QCA version of ASCON and offers insights into the challenges involved in implementing cryptographic functions within the QCA logic framework

title: Course-Aware Gated Representation and Multi-Task Learning for Urgent Post Identification in MOOC Discussion Forums
authors: Jianlin Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: The Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) provide large-scale discussion forums where students express opinions and seek support. However, the rapidly increasing volume of forum posts imposes severe information overload on instructors, making it difficult to promptly identify truly urgent posts that require immediate intervention. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Course-Aware Gated Representation and Multi-Task Learning framework for distinguishing urgent posts in MOOC forums. The proposed model integrates a course-aware gating mechanism that adaptively modulates BERT-based text representations using course embeddings, enabling course-conditioned feature modulation. In addition, a multi-task learning framework jointly optimizes urgency classification with sentiment polarity classification and question detection, providing complementary semantic supervision. Experimental results on the Stanford MOOC forum dataset show that the proposed model achieves a weighted F1score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$93.4\%$</tex> on Group A and urgent-posts precision of 81.5% and 83.2% on Groups B and C, respectively, outperforming state-of-the-art methods (AT-CX-LGF in Group A, BERT-CNN in Group B, and CWHNN in Group C) by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2 \%, 0.5 \%$</tex>, and 2.5%. Further analysis on concept drift demonstrates that the model can rapidly adapt when limited data from emerging courses or domains become available, highlighting its practical applicability in dynamic MOOC environments.

title: Person Re-Identification Across Multi-Camera Systems Using Vision Language Models
authors: Beibut Amirgaliyev, Miras Mussabek, Aliya Bekmukhanbet
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Intelligent solutions that improve public safety while handling enormous data streams are desperately needed, as evidenced by the explosive growth of surveillance systems. Large-scale deployment issues, appearance variations, and occlusion can all lead to errors in traditional camera tracking by saved recordings. In order to overcome these drawbacks, we suggest a deep learning-based framework that combines person description module and re-identification(Re-ID), which allows for strong identity association across several cameras. Our system uses detection, tracking modules to locate a person in the video and Re-ID to identify people in a variety of scenarios. Person description module utilizes vision language model(VLM) to describe target person. After testing this system with different VLMs the most suitable was Gemma3:4B, which achieves higher lexical overlap with the reference captions, reflected in its BLEU score of 0.0768 and ROUGE-L of 0.3283 and semantic similarity of 0.5887. These elements work together to improve reliability in crowd monitoring, anomaly detection, and multi-camera tracking.

title: Integrated multibeam beamformers at microwave and millimeter wave frequencies
authors: Luca Rinaldi, Valentina Gemmato, Federico Camponeschi, Filippo Scotti, Paolo Ghelfi, Mirco Scaffardi, Antonella Bogoni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: Phased array antennas are crucial for next-generation wireless, radar, and satellite systems. Optical beamforming networks (OBFNs) overcome these challenges by enabling wideband, reconfigurable, and multibeam operation with reduced size, weight, and power. Recent advances in integrated microwave photonics have enabled chip-scale OBFNs, combining compactness with scalability. This paper reviews integrated OBFN architectures and reports experimental demonstrations of single-and multibeam reception using a Blass-matrix-based receiver within the SPACEBEAM project, confirming their potential for future communication and sensing applications.

title: Dynamic Channel Decoupling and Cross-Modal Contrastive Learning for Change Captioning
authors: Weicheng Zhao, Gen Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: The task of change captioning aims to accurately identify differences between a pair of similar images and express them precisely in natural language. A key challenge is ensuring that the identified difference features are not affected by distractors (illumination and viewpoint changes). To address this, this paper proposes a Dynamic Channel Decoupling Module, which first decouples channels and then calculates the difference sensitivity scores for corresponding channels, thereby capturing key channels closely associated with image differences. Furthermore, to generate feature representations from the most relevant differential features, we design a Cross-modal Contrastive Module for the explicit establishment of channel-level semantic associations. This module enhances caption quality by maximizing the similarity between each channel and its corresponding linguistic tokens. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method achieves performance comparable to state-of-the-art approaches on two public datasets.

title: Trustworthy AI for Resource-Constrained Edge: A Trust Degradation Mode Effect Analysis (TDMEA) Framework
authors: Deeder Aurongzeb
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The increasing deployment of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in resource-constrained edge environments necessitates a robust framework for ensuring trustworthiness. This paper introduces the Trust Degradation Mode Effect Analysis (TDMEA), a novel methodology adapted from Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA), designed to proactively identify, analyze, and prioritize potential trust failures in edge AI. We highlight that inherent edge limitations (e.g., computational power, memory, energy) exacerbate complex trade-offs among critical trust dimensions such as accuracy, privacy, and explainability. TDMEA provides a structured approach to dissecting these challenges, emphasizing the critical role of detectability in prioritizing risks given edge monitoring limitations. The framework underscores that trust degradation is an evolving problem, driven by dynamic environments and necessary edge optimizations. TDMEA time dependency can provide real time index which can be explored further as an AI measure index. We conclude that building resilient trust in edge AI requires a holistic design philosophy, integrating resource-efficient robustness, lightweight adaptive learning, privacy-preserving solutions, and on-device self-healing, all guided by continuous governance and monitoring.

title: A CMOS Rectifier with 0.9V/1.8V Selectable Bounded Output Voltage for IoT Sensors
authors: Yan Joe Cheong, Harikrishnan Ramiah, Yi Chen Lee, Wen Xun Lian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Circuit and System Symposium (ICSyS)
abstract: This paper presents a 900 MHz CMOS rectifier with selectable bounded output voltage at 0.9 V or 1.8 V, targeting for low power Internet of Thing (IoT) applications. The proposed rectifier is integrated with an auxiliary rectifier, a voltage sensor and a voltage limiter. The auxiliary rectifier provides a reference voltage to the voltage sensor, which generates control signals based on the sensed voltage. These control signals control the voltage limiter to bound the main rectifier output voltage. The voltage limiter utilizes a voltage divider topology to branch out two different nodes, 0.9 V and 1.8 V. The proposed rectifier is simulated in Cadence Virtuoso using TSMC 65 nm technology. The post-layout simulations show the rectifier achieves an operating range of 6 dB and 3 dB for 0.9 V mode operation and 1.8 V mode operation respectively.

title: Real-Time Intrusion Detection and Tracking for Effective Livestock Virtual Fencing in Agriculture Using YOLOv8 and AI-Controlled Laser Actuation
authors: Krishnaprakash A., Mydhili S. K., Aakash M, Ramprasaath R. S., Pradeep P.
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: The effective protection of livestock and wildlife from threats is a critical aspect of animal welfare and conservation efforts. Traditional methods often rely on constant human vigilance, which is resource-intensive and prone to error. With advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT), virtual monitoring offers a robust solution for real-time threat detection and proactive intervention. This project proposes the development of an integrated AI/IoT-powered system designed for the autonomous detection of specific animal threats or intruders within designated areas, coupled with an automated warning or elimination mechanism. The system will employ an array of interconnected sensors, including advanced computer vision (e.g., YOLOv8-based object detection) and potentially radar, to continuously monitor the environment for unauthorized animal presence or predatory threats. Upon detection and identification of a designated threat, the system's core processing unit, like a Raspberry Pi, will precisely calculate the target's coordinates. This data will be transmitted to an Arduino-controlled, multi-axis turret system. This turret, equipped with a calibrated laser or other specified non-lethal deterrent/elimination mechanism, will then accurately track and engage the identified threat, providing an immediate and localized response. Furthermore, anomaly detection algorithms will enhance reliability by cross-referencing sensor inputs, while a GSM module will provide real-time alerts to stakeholders upon engagement or significant events. The integration of YOLOv8 with sensor fusion has achieved high detection F1-score of over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex>. This ensures reliable real-time identification of specific animal threats. It also has a quick response time of about 2.1 seconds from detection to activation of the deterrent ensuring no attack and no loss on both sides.

title: Legal Assistance in Low-Resource Languages: Evaluating RAG and Fine-Tuned LLMs for Greek e-Governance
authors: Maria Tsourma, Dimitrios Michail, Iraklis Varlamis, Anastasios Drosou, Dimitrios Tzovaras
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) has paved the way for more efficient and accessible e-government services. Conversational agents (aka chatbots), powered by large language models (LLMs), offer a promising solution for enhancing citizen engagement, streamlining bureaucratic processes, and providing instant access to governmental information. This paper presents a knowledge management system of curated Greek governmental data, accessible via a conversational agent, designed to assist internal civil servants in navigating public services, legal frameworks, and administrative procedures. The conversational agent is implemented using a hybrid approach combining a Retrieval-And-augmented-generation (RAG) approach and a fine-tuned LLM, which combines an external document retrieval system, enabling real-time access to up-to-date governmental sources while mitigating the risks of outdated or hallucinated responses. This knowledge management system captures Greek governmental processes from two sources: (a) data available in the Greek MITOS central database, and (b) the Government Gazette, which is the official publication of the Hellenic Republic. The documents from the second source are used on the RAG approach to enhance its knowledge and reliability, while the data from the first source were used for the preparation of a synthetic dataset for the answer generation part of the agent to fine-tune a pre-trained language model, ensuring a deep understanding of policy documents, official guidelines, and public administration protocols. This paper explores both implementations’ architectural differences, performance benchmarks, and practical implications. We analyze their strengths and limitations regarding accuracy, scalability, and adaptability to evolving governmental policies. Our findings contribute to the ongoing discourse on AI-driven public service automation and offer insights for future deployments of AI in e-government ecosystems.

title: RecFlash: Fast Recommendation Inference on NAND Flash-Based In-Storage Computing with Embedding-Optimized Data Mapping
authors: Jangho Baik, Gisan Ji, Wonbo Shim, Sungju Ryu
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Recommendation systems are widely used for personalized suggestions, but the growing amount of user data makes real-time processing difficult. NAND flash-based in-storage computing (ISC) is a favorable solution due to its large capacity, but random memory access patterns in recommendation systems cause underutilized internal bandwidth and degraded performance. This paper proposes RecFlash, a fast recommendation inference accelerator using a data remapping algorithm with NAND flash-based ISC. Experimental results show that it improves latency by up to 81 % over the existing ISC architectures.

title: Sparsity-Gated Fp16 Mac Pipeline for Energyefficient Edram-Based Neural Inference
authors: Akshay Kumar Sharma, Kyung Ki Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Neural network inference accelerators routinely execute vast numbers of multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations, many of which are redundant due to the inherent sparsity in input activations and model weights. Conventional MAC units fail to exploit this sparsity, resulting in unnecessary switching activity, increased dynamic power consumption, and area inefficiency. This paper introduces a Sparsity-Gated MAC (SG-MAC) pipeline optimized for low-power eDRAM-based inference systems. The proposed architecture supports multiple operations-including dot product, MAC, and fused activation functions, while integrating lightweight SKIP logic at three pipeline stages: multiplier gating, register write gating, and accumulation bypass. This multi-level gating dynamically eliminates redundant floating-point computations, significantly reducing logic utilization (up to 61% reduction LUTs) and power consumption compared to standard FP16 MAC designs. Experimental results on FPGA demonstrate that SG-MAC achieves substantial hardware efficiency and energy savings, all while providing extended functionality for modern neural workloads. The design offers a scalable and hardware-friendly solution for energy-constrained AI inference platforms, maintaining compatibility with diverse neural network operations.

title: Exploring RAGs Applications in Healthcare
authors: Khadija Almohsen, Nabil Hewahi
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Foundation and Large Language Models (FLLM)
abstract: Retrieval Augmented Generations (RAGs) is an emerging field of computing that has exceptional capabilities inherited from the strengths of both Large Language Models (LLMs) and Information Retrieval (IR) models. By integrating external, domain-specific knowledge into the response-generation process, RAG models overcome critical limitations of standalone LLMs, such as hallucinations, outdated knowledge, and limited domain specificity. RAGs bring novelty to its applications to wide range of domains, including healthcare where the need for accurate, transparent, and up-to-date information is critical. This paper presents a scholarly review of this cutting-edge field, with a focus on its adoption in healthcare. It synthesizes recent literature across various use cases, provides a comparative analysis of existing studies, identifies critical gaps in the current research, outlines the limitations in them, and suggests potential directions for future work. Unlike prior reviews, this work provides a structured comparative framework categorizing RAG healthcare applications by task, data source, model type, and evaluation strategy, thereby offering a roadmap for both researchers and practitioners.

title: Optimization Strategies and Performance Analysis Using Mobile Applications: Modern Approaches for Enhance User Experience
authors: Shweta Goyal, Venkata Suresh Babu Chilluri, Birendra Kumar Saraswat, B.P. Joshi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: Mobile applications are getting more advanced and as the sophistication increases, there goes a corresponding requirement to have optimization strategies to enhance user experience. The paper provides empirical research on the M-machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models as performance optimization methods of mobile applications with respect to crash prediction, energy management, and real time responsiveness. Some classic ML algorithms, such as the Random Forest and Support Vector Machine, obtained the moderate level of accuracy yet failed to work well with sequential use data. Convolutional Neural Networks and Long Short-Term Memory enhanced more accuracy, but both did not work well when utilized independently. Therefore, a hybrid CNN-LSTM model was designed, a model that used spatial features extraction by the CNN and temporal sequence learning by the LSTM. It was shown through experimental results the framework outperformed all baselines having attained the highest accuracy (94.8%), the lowest RMSE (0.11) and the lowest execution latency, hence offering a more reliable and responsive user experience. The conclusions indicate the possibility of hybrid DL models as modern optimization techniques of mobile applications. Future research to be conducted is massive validation, real-time implementation, integration with edge computing, and user-centred personalization without compromising data privacy.

title: NGS-based threshold homomorphic encryption scheme without CRS
authors: Xu Zhao, Zheng Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Blockchain Technology and Information Security (ICBCTIS)
abstract: Homomorphic encryption (HE) has become a core technology in privacy-preserving computation due to its support for performing computations directly on ciphertext. However, the common random string (CRS) model introduced in existing schemes to optimize efficiency poses significant security risks, constituting a potential threat in open networks. To address this, a NGS-based HE without CRS is innovatively proposed in this paper. By constructing a three-layer security conversion mechanism for ciphertexts and relying on the reduction of underlying lattice hard problems, the scheme eliminates CRS dependency while ensuring security. Analysis indicates that this scheme significantly reduces the size of ciphertexts and evaluation keys. The expanded ciphertext generation requires no additional auxiliary information as well as avoids introducing new noise, thereby avoiding cumulative noise effects. Moreover, the extended ciphertext generation only requires processing an $n(n \times 1)$-dimensional vector, substantially reducing the system’s memory overhead.

title: Nanomechanical Self-Timed Power Management Circuit for Low-Power IoT Devices
authors: Guangwei Liao, Roshan Weerasekera, Dinesh Pamunuwa
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems (APCCAS)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IoT) applications often see harsh environmental conditions such as high temperatures and radiation levels, which reduce the efficiency of CMOS power converters. This paper presents a nanoelectromechanical (NEM) relay-based power management unit that can operate in such conditions with zero standby power. The proposed circuit is selftimed and does not need a clock or an external synchronization signal, and minimises switching activity to mitigate against the limited lifetime of NEM relays. Simulation results show that the proposed circuit can maintain a stable voltage of 5.7 V DC when supplying a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \mu \mathrm{A}$</tex> load, with 33% power conversion efficiency. This proof of concept demonstrates the potential of nanomechanical circuits for power management in low-power harsh environment IoT applications where Si transistors struggle to operate.

title: Automated Intrusion Type Identification in Networks Using Machine Learning
authors: Vinod Sharma, Kailash Aseri, Sankati Ramakrishna, Anandakumar Haldorai, Kotte Kavita, Rajesh Kumar Upadhyay
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Advancement in Electronics &amp; Communication Engineering (AECE)
abstract: The increased complexity and frequency of network breaches gift tremendous obstacles in community gadget security protection. on the way to address this problem, a proposed solution is the implementation of an Intrusion kind Classifier (ITC), which makes use of a machine learning technique to perceive and categorize network intrusions autonomously. The system employs a huge range of variables derived from community site visitors’ facts and employs more than one device learning techniques to efficaciously discover and classify numerous kinds of intrusions. The number one objective of the ITC is to improve the effectiveness and precision of intrusion detection thru the usage of a multi-magnificence category framework. This framework is designed to distinguish among distinctive styles of intrusions, inclusive of Denial of service (DoS), disbursed Denial of provider (DDoS), intrusions caused by malware, and other styles of network assaults. through the usage of sizeable datasets, the ITC famous encouraging results inside the identification and category of those intrusions, attaining notable ranges of precision and recollect costs. The presented method demonstrates a realistic and efficient strategy for boosting the security of computer networks, facilitating set off reactions to possible dangers and weaknesses in tricky network settings. The assist vector gadget set of rules is extensively recognized as one of the topperforming algorithms in diverse community infrastructure domains.

title: HCGBot: Hierarchical Semantic Consistency Modeling with Graph Learning for Twitter Bot Detection
authors: Yiling Zhang, Chunling Wu, Yu Hui, Peng Xiong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Information Science and Education (ICISE-IE)
abstract: The detection of Twitter bots has become increasingly important and challenging for safeguarding the authenticity of online interactions and preventing the manipulation of public opinion. Although existing detection methods have achieved certain progress in textual semantics and social network structure, they generally suffer from coarse-grained user semantic representations, insufficient capability in discerning semantic consistency, and inadequate integration of content and structural information. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multimodal detection framework, HCGBot, which performs hierarchical semantic consistency modeling in conjunction with social network structure for Twitter bot detection. We evaluate HCGBot on two widely used benchmark datasets for Twitter bot detection, and the experimental results demonstrate that HCGBot outperforms existing methods across multiple metrics, validating the effectiveness of hierarchical semantic consistency modeling combined with graph-based detection.

title: A Multi-Wavelength Microwave Photonic Transponder for Future Synthetic Aperture Radar Satellite Formations
authors: Josef Ydreborg, Sigurd Huber, Gerhard Krieger
publish: 2025 IEEE International Topical Meeting on Microwave Photonics (MWP)
abstract: In this paper a new microwave photonic concept for enabling bi- or multi-static spaceborne synthetic aperture radar (SAR) systems is presented. In the concept, there is one master satellite and one or more transponder satellites. The master transmits a radar signal and the function of the multi-wavelength microwave photonic transponder is to relay multiple antenna array channels, which are fed by the radar echos, back to the master. This is achieved leveraging a phase-preserving modulation, wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) and freespace optics (FSO). The modulation format used allows the system to avoid synchronizing the clocks of the platforms with each other. Preliminary results for gain, noise performance, and dynamic range are calculated and the delay knowledge achievable for the system is discussed. Finally, there is a discussion on future research and some concluding remarks.

title: Implementation of a Fallen Person Detector
authors: Junghak Kim, Geon-Woo Kim
publish: 2025 16th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology Convergence (ICTC)
abstract: This paper presents an implementation example of a detector that identifies fallen individuals as detection objects. The authors of this paper have been continually building datasets necessary for training and evaluating neural network models to be used as such detectors. This paper briefly explains the reasons why such datasets need to be constructed, and shows that, by utilizing theses datasets, it is possible to implement a detector capable of detecting human objects that represent the meaning of "fallen."

title: First Responders’ Perceptions of Semantic Information for Situational Awareness in Robot-Assisted Emergency Response
authors: Tianshu Ruan, Zoe Betta, Georgios Tzoumas, Rustam Stolkin, Manolis Chiou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Safety Security Rescue Robotics (SSRR)
abstract: This study investigates First Responders’ (FRs) attitudes toward the use of semantic information and Situational Awareness (SA) in robotic systems during emergency operations. A structured questionnaire was administered to 22 FRs across eight countries, capturing their demographic profiles, general attitudes toward robots, and experiences with semantics-enhanced SA. Results show that most FRs expressed positive attitudes toward robots, and rated the usefulness of semantic information for building SA at an average of 3.6 out of 5. Semantic information was also valued for its role in predicting unforeseen emergencies (mean 3.9). Participants reported requiring an average of 74.6% accuracy to trust semantic outputs and 67.8% for them to be considered useful, revealing a willingness to use imperfect but informative AI support tools.To the best of our knowledge, this study offers novel insights by being one of the first to directly survey FRs on semantic-based SA in a cross-national context. It reveals the types of semantic information most valued in the field—such as object identity, spatial relationships, and risk context—and connects these preferences to the respondents’ roles, experience, and education levels. The findings also expose a critical gap between lab-based robotics capabilities and the realities of field deployment, highlighting the need for more meaningful collaboration between FRs and robotics researchers. These insights contribute to the development of more user-aligned and situationally aware robotic systems for emergency response.

title: Modeling and Cloud-Based Control of a DSTATCOM-Integrated Micro Grid System
authors: Kavitha. C, Sivakumar. P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: This paper presents a unique micro grid setup that uses a Distribution Static Compensator (DSTATCOM) to interact with the national grid. Separate power electronic converters for solar PV sources, a bank of batteries, a super capacitor, a controllable R load, and a single phase inverter with a controllable AC load are all part of the suggested micro grid structure. The entire crucial data is logged into a shared computer via a serial data communication port found in a shared digital signal controller, even if all of the power converters can be controlled by local micro controllers. The entire system can be managed locally, and if needed, the cloud can be used to monitor vital information and send override commands to the relevant system from the cloud control dashboard. The creation of innovative control schemes for the individual power electronic converters is another area of research attention. The suggested power electronic converter system's dynamic models have been implemented using MATLAB SIMULINK. The trial prototype could potentially be created to confirm the suggested concept.

title: Eco-Adaptive RF Harvesting Algorithm for Energy-Efficient Cognitive Wireless Body Sensor Platforms
authors: Anju Thapa, Divya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Innovations in Engineering and Technology (ICIIET)
abstract: Wireless Body Sensor Networks (WBSNs) are integral to modern healthcare applications, enabling continuous health monitoring and personalized care. However, these systems face critical challenges due to limited battery life, unpredictable energy availability, and dynamic body-centric communication environments. Energy inefficiency can lead to frequent maintenance, reduced reliability, and compromised patient monitoring. To address these challenges, this study proposes an Eco-Adaptive RF Harvesting Algorithm (EARHA) designed for energy-efficient cognitive WBSN platforms. EARHA intelligently integrates ambient radio frequency (RF) energy harvesting with adaptive power management, dynamically adjusting sensor transmission power and duty cycles based on energy availability and network conditions. The algorithm employs cognitive sensing to detect optimal RF sources while minimizing interference and ensuring reliable data transmission. Simulation results demonstrate that EARHA improves energy harvesting efficiency by up to 35% compared to conventional WBSN approaches, reduces energy consumption per transmission by 28%, and prolongs network lifetime by approximately 40%. Furthermore, the algorithm maintains a packet delivery ratio above 95% under varying RF environments, highlighting its robustness and adaptability. The findings indicate that integrating eco-adaptive RF harvesting with cognitive power management can significantly enhance the sustainability and operational efficiency of WBSNs, offering a practical solution for continuous health monitoring without frequent battery replacement. This study lays the foundation for future research on self-sustainable body sensor networks and provides a roadmap for designing energy-aware protocols for wearable healthcare devices.

title: DUET-Net: A Physics-Aware Deep Learning Framework for Joint Sensing and Communication Channel Estimation in ISAC Systems
authors: Jiexin Zhang, Shu Xu, Chunguo Li, Yongming Huang, Luxi Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Joint sensing and communication channel estimation (JSCCE) is a critical problem in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems, where two types of channels inherently share similar physical propagation mechanisms while exhibit distinct task-specific characteristics. Leveraging this property, this work proposes a multi-objective unified framework that combines the feature extraction capacity of deep learning with the principled exploitation of ISAC channel commonalities and differences. Specifically, we design a novel dual-task unified estimation Transformer network (DUET-Net) comprising a shared encoder backbone for capturing correlated sparse channel features, alongside dual-head decoders with task-specific branches for accommodating the individual statistical characteristics and structural properties of the two channels. To further address the limited angular resolution in communication channels, we incorporate an angle-aware attention (AAA) module that selectively emphasizes informative angular components. Moreover, an uncertainty-weighted multi-task loss is introduced to adaptively balance the training process of both tasks in accordance to their different learning dynamics, thereby improving convergence stability. Extensive numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed DUET-Net consistently outperforms existing methods over a wide range of transmit power levels and across various scenarios, with an efficient performance-complexity trade-off. The effectiveness of the designed modules is further confirmed by ablation studies.

title: Ωkypous: Harnessing Timing Slacks and Coordinated DVFS for Power-Efficient Serverless Workflows
authors: Achilleas Tzenetopoulos, Dimosthenis Masouros, Sotirios Xydis, Dimitrios Soudris
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: Serverless workflows have emerged in Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) platforms to represent the operational structure of traditional applications. With latency propagation effects becoming increasingly prominent, step-wise resource tuning is required to address Service-Level-Objectives (SLOs). Modern processors’ allowance for fine-grained Dynamic Voltage and Frequency Scaling (DVFS), coupled with serverless workflows’ intermittent nature, presents a unique opportunity to reduce power while meeting SLOs. We introduce Ωkypous, an SLOdriven DVFS framework for serverless workflows. Ωkypous employs a grey-box model that predicts functions’ execution latency and power under different Core and Uncore frequency combinations. Based on these predictions and the timing slacks between workflow functions, Ωkypous uses a closed-loop control mechanism to dynamically adjust Core and Uncore frequencies, reducing power consumption without compromising predefined end-to-end latency constraints. Our evaluation on real-world traces from Azure demonstrates an average power consumption reduction of 16% compared to state-of-the-art power management frameworks, while consistently maintaining low SLO violation rates (1.8%), even when operating under power caps.
